description:
I came here for a coffee with a business partner. It was his idea. I loved the place. I had a tea and he had a latte. The atmosphere was really trendy; the crowd is cool and the whole experience was fantastic. 

BUT WHAT WILL STAND OUT IN MY MIND the most is the experience that I had when I was there. There was a 24-26 yr old red hot Asian chic standing in front of me in line. She was wearing a very short skirt, high heels and a trench coat - not an uncommon look for San Francisco. When she got done paying for her coffee she dropped a 2-1/2" roll of $100's on the floor in front of me. There must have been at least $5000 in that roll. I picked it up and walked over to her at the coffee station and said, "Excuse me, Miss, you dropped this..." She reached out and wrenched those bills out of my hand, stuffed them into her raincoat pocket and bolted out the door!

We were howling! Not even a "thank you". My partner suggested, "Maybe she's prejudice?" Who knows? It certainly was something that I won't forget. 

I really enjoy this neighborhood (SoMa) and I liked this coffee shop. Trust me, try it - you'll like it.
author: J K.

description:
The coffee is definitely still hands down the best - BUT and there is a BIG BUT, if only they were consistent! 

The music is always something weird, jarring and loud. Why make a place unpleasant to pass off as a quirky hipster hangout?

Also baristas seem moody and in desperate need of some caffeine to perk up their moods. 

This place could easily become a coffee hub however overall customer experience is not great anymore. So sad to see my favorite coffee shop struggling to achieve what used to be a first-right-time coffee, all the time, everytime. Now the coffee is always a hit or a miss. Either the temperature is not right, or the espresso is pulled too long, or it tastes burnt, or it is way too strong. I don't know - super disappointing to give this place several chances to improve itself. however, there seems to be no light at the end of the tunnel.

Oh and what's up with the cookies and pastries - I can almost always spot flies in the food display (note health hazard!). and they cannot even warm up a cookie - which is overtly sweet and all the food seems like it was picked up from the day-old section of a next door bakery. 

Don't care about standards anymore four barrel?
author: Raj R.

description:
On a Saturday afternoon around 2pm, Four Barrel was busy but not overly crowded. There was a short line to order, and our espresso drinks seemed to take a good 5-10 minutes. There wasn't room for 3 to sit inside, but we sat outside on the parklet and could people watch (it was a bit chilly though - probably why it was easier to find seats out there). I also finally got to try a pastry here! 

* Buckwheat Peach Corn donut - 3.5 stars
Surprisingly good blend of flavors, but I prefer a little more moistness in my donuts (I'm always a yeasty-donut kind of gal, vs. cake-y donut).

Paired this with an iced coffee - good stuff.
author: Ziyan C.

description: Another great coffee shop in SF. Stopped by on a Sunday morning around 9AM and the shop was pretty busy. Seems a bit busy/loud to get work done but its a great place to grab coffee and go or sit down and chat with friends. Seating it a bit limited inside but theres also a few spots outside too.
author: Tiffany K.

description:
Oh man San Francisco has a fierce coffee competition. Trendy coffee shops like Four Barrel Coffee, Blue Bottle, Philz Coffee, Sightglass Coffee, Ritual Coffee Roasters, etc. are all considered a part of the "Third Wave" coffee shops (canned coffee like Folgers = first wave & Peet's / Starbucks = second wave). Currently there are two Four Barrel locations in SF and Four Barrel is also in partnership with The Mill (a bakery shop in SF). They offer cupping classes (free - every Saturday & Sunday from 12:30 PM to 1:30 PM), 3-hour espresso + milk preparation classes ($200 per person), and 90-minute better brewing at home classes ($35 per person). I didn't get to try specialty coffees at the "slow bar" (pour over style) and I just ordered at the front counter.

***

Pecan Muffin ($4.50): Cold muffin, but still tasted pretty good (not overly sweet).

Latte ($5): It had a pretty balanced steamed milk & espresso ratio. The drink didn't taste too diluted and latte art was nice.

***

I personally still prefer Philz Coffee because Four Barrel is missing the "it" factor, but Four Barrel serves a good cup of coffee.
author: Luke L.

description:
LOVE the coffee here! They also make a mean affogato! 

It's really fun to watch them actually roast their coffee in the back! 

I can't wait to come back for one of their cupping classes!
author: Hanna S.

description: Started day with Four Barrel coffee. It was my first time going to the cafe. Took a friend who got the hot chocolate and didn't like it because it was too bitter. I got an almond milk latte which was what it was suppose to be. I really liked the inside decorum.
author: Stacie J.

description: So glad we needed some coffee (like is there ever really a time you don't) & had time to kill. Alex was simply the best (sorry Tina, I just had to). Terrific history of the place & 2 wonderful cups of pour over. Hopefully Four Barrel will be a stop every time we're in town.
author: Bill L.

description:
A very artsy eclectic & rustic coffeehouse in the Mission district. This unassuming hipster coffeehouse had no signs up top but Siri guided us here! I noticed their cool unorthodox bar seating outside. Gosh the Yelper in me was slipping bc I forgot a pic.

They had a full window of baked goods. Croissants & donuts looked yummy but we passed this time. You also have the option to purchase their coffee beans by the pound. Their source? From Latin America, East Africa & Indonesia.  Four Barrel included quite a large bar with open bar seating in the back area. 

When you first enter on your left you can see a separate area of pour over coffee like another trendsetter coffeehouse. There was a line there but somehow we figured out to stand at the longer line down the center.

Luckily someone was leaving so I grabbed their table inside to enjoy our coffee drinks. We were very lucky as it wasn't too packed inside for a weekend Saturday morning. Our barista was quick to making my great tasting plain latte. Their latte art was cute though I've had better back home in Sacramento. 

However I did appreciate the pretty intricate artwork inside Four Barrel coffee cafe. I thought it was quite beautiful and dressed the walls gorgeously. Just wished no one was in there bc I would have taken way more pictures but I didn't want to be obtrusive or annoying as some photographers can be. It's too bad bc it appears they change their artwork every so often.

Would we come back? Maybe. We did walk over a mile to get here & a mile back to a confirmed appointment. We  know those San Francisco hills were great for exercising! Thanks JC for the artisan coffee recommendation! Maybe next time I will have to try their affogato where they add two scoops of delicious Frozen Kuhsterd ice cream to their delicious coffee. 

Now that would be: absolutely. divine. dessert. coffee. heaven. enjoy.
author: Karen K.

description:
I support anywhere there serves Song Tea, so Four Barrel has my vote.

Great space to work in or hang out at if you can find a table. San Francisco priced and straight forward selection. 

They sell coffee accessories and do cupping classes there as well.
author: Patty B.

description: Good coffee, slow service. They don't take names while ordering, so a good chance your drink might go to somebody else first if that person ordered the same drink after you. Happened to me twice and had to wait for around 20-30 mins to get it.
author: Rishabh G.

description:
It has all the right things, except the coffee.

The space is on point, with all the hipster talismans in place: exposed wood, bikes on hooks, a roaster in the back, gallery art adoring the walls. Service was friendly and it is clear that this is a valued space for the laptop-wielding set. The man-bunned, necktie-wearing specialist at the pourover bar appeared deep in conversation with a fellow coffee snob.

But the coffee itself was blargh. I had a cappuccino and the wife had decaf iced latter. Both seemed subpar. The espresso tasted burnt, the steamed milk (in my cap) less than hot. We expected so much more!

Perhaps we'll swing by again, but with so many excellent cafes and roasters in the area, it'll be hard to do so.
author: Jon W.

description:
After a morning of exploring the Mission District, we needed to grab some coffee and charge our phones. I searched Yelp and a couple of short blocks later we were in attendance. The coffee shop is a neighborhood favorite it seems because it was busy and full. Luckily, we were able to grab 2 chairs at the back table near the bathroom. Outside of the crowd of people inside, the second thing I noticed upon entrance was the rustic decor. All of the tables and chairs are made of wood. The vibe is calm. Definitely a chill place to relax, study, and meet deadlines. 

The coffee shop is a short walk from the Clarion Murals. 
The negative is there are no outlets for charging. The main reason for stopping through was to grab a charge for my phone and I was left unable to utilize modern day technology. 

While people watching, I decided to grab a coffee. I went up to the counter and noticed cookies and instantly changed my plans. I ordered 2 walnut chocolate chip cookies and a hot chocolate (the wind has been blowing). I watched the barista make the hot chocolate and I thought it was pretty interesting. However, my tastebuds thought otherwise. That was the most non chocolate tasting and disgusting hot chocolate. It was pretty in appearance but offensive to my mouth. The hot chocolate costed $4 and the cookies were $1.39 each. 

Free water is provided and can be found on the counter inside a metal pitcher. The coffee prices are quite affordable. The space is quiet and has lovely black, abstract art filled walls. There is only one bathroom but it is gender neutral. The back half of the coffee shop has an industrial feel  with a workshop and I am assuming is where they produce and package the items sold in the shop. 

The coffee shop in itself deserves 5 stars. The staff is friendly. The 3 stars is because of the horrible hot chocolate and the fact that I can still remember the taste.
author: Latrunda S.

description:
Pretty large coffee spot with plenty of seating to hang out with friends or get some reading or work done. There's even an outdoor seating area to catch some sun on those nice days. 

The cold coffee was light and had very little acidity.
author: James B.

description:
Loved the place and the ambiance, very relaxing and chill, great for people watching and just take some time to enjoy life. The people who work here are definitely the best! 

We had a catch up moment with our friend from out of the country here and we treasured every moment that we had at this coffee shop. The pour over coffee was also really good (according to my fiance, I don't drink coffee in the morning due to stomach problem). I got the raspberry croissant and it brightened up my day and my tummy really well.
author: Nathania Y.

description:
The more I write these reviews the more apparent it is that I have certain addictions from movies to treats and museums to concerts. And one of these addictions is terribly obvious and it's coffee. I told myself that to have less clutter in my life I would make my souvenirs from San Francisco caffeine. I am allowed two bags of coffee. 

And one of the best coffee spots is Four Barrel. I heard there was some recent events that were negative but now it's back on track with female heads. This makes me very happy. 

I jumped around a lot while I was in San Francisco/Oakland. On this day I had to drag a suitcase with me. This made it difficult to read all the descriptions of the bagged coffee. I lean on the nutty and sweet flavor palette. My bag did serve as a placeholder on the long line but I constantly had to run back and move it. After I finally made my selection I got back in line. The treats looked amazing but on this visit I was focusing on coffee. 

I asked the lady working where the best place to plug in my phone in was. According to the clerk there are no places to plug in. Ouch! Double ouch when you're traveling. I had no intention in making this place my home office but a little juice goes a long way when you have to walk and need directions.

I ordered my latte anyway. $5 for the latte and an additional $1 for oat milk. I will say that this was more than NY in midtown. When I'm on vacation I have addictions and would pay top dollar for these activities. They did serve my latte in a stunning mug that looked super handmade pottery style. I also enjoyed the fresh flower arrangement while ordering. And in the corner of my eye I noticed the coffee shop's record collection. 

I enjoyed the large art pieces against the walls. It is always a treat for me to sit and sip a perfectly made caffeine drink from an actual cup. Vacation life, I could get used to this! 

I will add that they have a bathroom. And I appreciate a place that serves coffee and knows that a bathroom is essential. 

I love seeing the back area with the giant coffee roaster machines. I'm weird. Something about that machinery creating something I love so much brings me joy. 

The name of my coffee purchase is "Nicaragua - El Diablo". Something wicked this way comes! Beware coffee pot! NY is going to get wild with some San Francisco coffee.
author: Carolina S.

description: Great coffee, great ambience! Mission doesn't seem to have too many coffee spots to come in and do work but this is one of them. I wish they offered non fat milk but the almond cappuccinos are great. They brew the beans right in the back .. can't beat that
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
Visited this coffee shop on a small trip. 

It's so amazing how much different the Bay Area is from SoCal when it's literally the same state. Everything is so different and I just love SF's culture and style. And especially the coffee shops. It's unlike SoCal with our minimal and aesthetic shops, here is really home feel and hip, which pulls me in more.

Coffee is undoubtedly better than SoCal. I love the fact that four barrel has a station dedicated for pour over, which is my favorite type! The barista is awesome and engaging. Tried a Peru single origin, love the flavor profile. 

Definitely one for the book!
author: Allen W.

description:
What's up with these overpriced coffee shops with no wifi???

If I'm going to be paying a premium for my tiny cup of coffee, I expect there to be wifi available. How does my hair salon and gym offer wifi but Four Barrel doesn't???

I visited Four Barrel because it was on my check list of hipster coffee shops to visit in SF. While I'm not a fan of paying for overpriced coffee, I am a fan of people watching because it's my favorite spectator sport, but while I'm at it I usually like to crank out some work. Came with my laptop in tow only to find that there's no wifi. So I sat there with my tiny cappuccino to soak in the ambiance. 

Four Barrel is located on Valencia and occupies a huge piece of real estate. The place is large and like any SF coffee shop, there's plenty of wooden paneling throughout, hipster plants here and there, and plenty of patrons conversing while sipping on caffeine.

I should have just ordered a regular coffee because my cappuccino was lackluster. It lacked depth and body. It was flat in my book and not only that, it took 5ever just to make. They had about 4-5 staff members manning the counter but none of them seemed to be making any drinks. 

The music here is super loud, making holding conversations very difficult. If I wanted to scream to get my point across I would have gone bar hopping to Zeitgeist nearby. 

I'll be harping on the fact that I still firmly believe coffee shops should provide wifi access. Maybe they wanted to encourage more of a social aspect of coffee with the loud music, the large display of vinyl records, and the longer community tables.
author: Connie M.

description:
Years of living in the Bay Area definitely upped my coffee game. Before I moved to San Francisco, coffee was the drink I rarely turned to when I told myself I needed a boost of energy. I didn't think it particularly tastes good, but it seemed like it was the name of the game in this thing called adulthood. 

Finding Four Barrel was one of the places that probably turned me into a legitimate coffee connoisseur. Maybe it was the rustic setting that housed a very sophisticated coffee operation. Most likely, it was the well-made espresso drinks that showed me how great coffee could be. Nowadays, I often walk into Four Barrel and have to brave a long line (though it usually moves quickly) and seats can be hard to find. Yet, I always leave this place enjoying my coffee!
author: Keith H.

description:
This is my neighborhood coffee shop and although I make a great effort to always support small business, I don't think I am coming back again. 
From the overpriced coffee and pastries to the slow service and front of the house employee's bad attitude. 
One barista serving such a big place seems like a bad business move. When I asked the cashier if they only had one barista she responded with sarcasm, "the other person is at lunch. Lunch is also important you know". No need for sarcasm or attitude. We are the customers and also important.
author: Moy V.

description:
Found this place about a year ago and forgot to leave a review.

Was just in a few days ago. My drink is their macchiato which is a nice and quaint drink in their clay cups. They always give me latte art on it which is fabulous.

Their signature espresso bean is very tart, it is an extremely unique flavor and very different from other coffee shops. It's almost as if you can still taste the berry that the bean originated from.

Some may think it's an acquired taste, but I still love it all together.

Here's the constructive feedback:

No wifi. I get it. Be social, talk to the person across from you. Be gone, hipsters. All the coffee squatters can go squat at the Starbucks.

However, as iconoclastic as this coffee shop may be, they simply do not have enough seating for people to enjoy their wonderful coffee and a nice conversation. Also, their tables are barely bigger than 2x2 planks on two plank legs. There is nothing humble about this place, this place is popular and their coffee tastes great. There's some seating outside, not sitting outside though (not when it's a lot warmer and nicer in doors).

So no wifi, and also not enough seating (the times I've been, at least).

Otherwise, I really like the place and the coffee is great.
author: Tom S.

description:
The ambiance is undeniably beautiful wall to wall with stimulating decor. In the back the industrial set up sets a good tone. With the door open the flies circle as you enter inside, maybe investing in a stylish fan to go along with everything else they have going on. 
They have a variation of drink options which are different and trendy. The products that they carry are intriguing and good gifts for those coffee lovers in your circle. Absolutely loved the ambiance aside from the flies and pungent restroom but it is a restroom so benefit of the doubt. It could use some well needed attention that's all. It has a funky smell to it making it unappetizing to enjoy anything after being inside but overall a decent visit.
author: Sabrina V.

description:
I have been meaning to check out four barrel for a while, and finally got to when a friend and I met up for coffee. The interior of this location is very cute. They have a slow bar off to the side, where I imagine they take their sweet old time in hand brewing coffee for you for those that have the time. There is minimal seating, so I would suggest going off hours if you want to find a spot quickly. 

Then they have their main coffee bar, which is the usual order and go if need be. Their pastries looked delicious. The barista said they were from Neighbor Bakehouse, which is a lovely bakery in Potrero Hill. I just wanted some coffee, and ordered a cortado. I didn't see a cortado on the menu, but the barista said she would make it, which was very kind of her. Initially the cortado was good, but as I continued to drink it, the espresso tasted more and more bitter. I think Four Barrel has a bit of a stronger and bitter espresso taste than what I prefer. I have had Four Barrel coffee at other locations that served it and had a similar thought in the past, so don't think it's a one time happening. 

I know Four Barrel has a great following and is super popular in the Bay, but it's not my cup of tea and would choose to get my coffee elsewhere like Verve or Andytown :P
author: Jackie C.

description: Drip coffee was nice and crisp, although lukewarm. I recommend trying a pastry, especially the blueberry/lemon muffin--it was moist and very delicious! I wouldn't recommend this place to study, as it's packed and no WiFi. Although, it is a nice spot for a quick break.
author: Jeanette Jane G.

description: A damn good cortado (not on the menu and $4.25), but it's not a place to read or study. They play loud music, and you can't really have a good chat w/ a friend either. Just take it to go I guess, but definite not good for a relaxing sit down.
author: Thomas L.

description:
Four Barrel is one of my favorite mission coffee shops. Anytime I need to show someone a great
coffee spot, I take them here. 

Four Barrel offers two bars. A "slow bar" for you pour over fans and a normal bar for lattes, nitro coffee, etc. 

I Opted for a Nitro coffee this time around. I love how it comes "chIlled" and not over ice. Finally I'm not forced to drink my coffee so fast to prevent it from watering down. 

There's tons of seating both indoor and outside! I also really enjoy the ever changing art that lines the walls inside four Barrel. 

In the back of four Barrel, if you're lucky you can watch them roast the beans in person. Grab a seat at the bar and enjoy! 

Perfect place to grab a coffee, hangout, or get a drink to go and make your way to Dolores Park.
author: Nick F.

description: Wow! This coffee will wake you up! I got an iced coffee and loved it. Nice space as well for work or meeting a friend.
author: Stephanie K.

description: Originally I was pissed after paying $4 to the parking meter with the intention of coming to this coffee shop to do some computer based training and finding out they don't have WiFi. I was kinda surprised a cafe would not have WiFi but this place is kinda hipster so I wasn't completely shocked. Anyway, out $9 after parking and buying a $5 drink and didn't get anything done, BUT my almond milk latte was delicious, they have a really good vibe and play great records, and roast the beans in house. So I don't recommend this place if you need to work or study online but for a good cup of coffee, sure!
author: Margaret D.

description:
Coffee was a bit too acidic for my taste but not bad. We ordered a mocha, a nitro coffee, and their rosella mint iced tea.  

My favorite of the three was the nitro coffee once I added a bit of almond milk to balance the acidity (normally I drink my coffee black). 

Wouldn't go out of my way to come back on my own but I wouldn't complain if others wanted to check it out. 

Anything is better than Starbucks.
author: Dani K.

description:
The Valencia branch of Four Barrel is my all time favorite café in San Francisco. I like the vibe in this place. Not all people come here to work on their laptops like other coffee chains. Maybe it is due to the absence of wifi that significant number of patrons frequenting this place come to meet friends and chat. I prefer cafes that don't feel like libraries. 

I am a big fan of their latte. Although their espresso is almost bitter for my taste, it works perfectly in their lattes and cappuccinos. The presentation of their drinks is perfect with their coffee cups and saucers (terracotta?). 

Their selection of baked goods are delicious. I have had some fancy donut variations here before. 

The decor is very modern and hipster. I like that their record player is hooked up to a legit amplifier. They always showcase the sleeve of the vinyl they are currently playing. They also decorate the walls with cool artwork. 

Great coffee, cool decor, good music, nice people. Get it? That is what a great cafe is.
author: Doruk B.

description: We went to little star pizza and after that great meal we stopped in here to get a coffee. I tried the affogatto (not sure if I spelled that right), it's basically ice cream with a coffee pour over, it tasted amazing! my wife got the caramel latte and she also loved it. there is a cool alley right next this place that has some cool murals so we took some pics there afterwards.  I can't wait to come back here and get something else, I also really liked the inside of the coffee shop.
author: Maninderpal M.

description: I think this is so far my favorite coffee in San Francisco. I've been here years ago and I remembered I liked their coffee but now I know why. And I drink a lot of coffee so that's saying a lot. They got their latte down to perfect milk coffee ratio. My complaint with lattes is that there's too much milk and not enough coffee. It's nice and smooth but the milk doesn't mask the flavor of coffee and it's nice and foamy on top juuust the way I love it. Not just that inside is super cute. Wooden furniture, pretty cool paintings up on the walls that I can't afford to buy, and they roast their own beans right inside.
author: Jane K.

description:
So first the good. Coffee is incredible and both well roasted as brewed. Had a few items and all were great! The thing I loved best were the classes held on prem. They partner with other local businesses to do pairings and educational classes. They also have a Sat/Sun free cupping, which is led by one of the best roasters in the country. The spot is vibey and love the way they built out the space. 

The downside would be no outlets and no wifi. I get the reason, and totally respect that they encourage disconnecting. For me it's not convenient, but not a deal breaker. The coffee is a tad pricey, but the dollars stay local, and to me that's worth the cost.
author: Jenny D.

description: got an iced almond milk latte. music was on point - my favorite album ever, Channel Orange - and coffee was good. came to de-plug and draw, and the ambience made the two hours worth.
author: Swan K.

description: Another amazing coffee shop in SF. This one is another one of my absolute favorites. The coffee is always strong and delicious, they have a beautiful space in a great location, and friendly / fast service. My only qualm is they do not have enough seating, like most coffee shops in the city.
author: Michelle B.

description:
Cool spot with a nice atmosphere, but the entire experience was just ok.

One of my biggest pet peeves is when other customers hover around the drink area and think that every drink is theirs (even if they ordered something completely different). Someone else grabbed my drink before I did, and being the germaphobe that I am, did not appreciate this. They should go by a name system, or at least call out the drinks when they're ready instead of just leaving them at the bar.

I ordered an iced latte, which for starters, was way tinier than any iced latte I've ever received. Taste-wise, the espresso was strong and pungent, which I liked. 

Bathrooms here were disgusting and smelly, hence the low stars.
author: Shirley H.

description:
I dream of Four Barrel. It's like a biohacker's paradise to have coffee beans that are wet process, single origin, cage free, grass fed, pasture raised, etc. Ha. Well the first two is true. 

Enjoy and ask questions because they are experts!
author: Amy W.

description: Coffee is acidic and meh in my opinion, super trendy place but meh coffee. My girlfriends espresso was admittedly very good. And there's also no heavy whipping cream so.. no keto.
author: John S.

description:
I thought this place would be overwhelmingly crowded at 5 pm, but I was pleasantly surprised. I grabbed a window seat to catch up with a friend, but there were also tables available.

I grabbed a Kenyan iced coffee, which came in a pretty generic glass (my photo fell victim to camera shake), but the uniqueness of this spot lies on the walls. I enjoyed browsing the art and taking in the decor.

There's space to sit outside, and if you have a bike, there are also racks. Looking forward to grabbing my laptop and sitting out sometime.
author: Nicholas G.

description:
Tasty coffee, but nothing spectacular compared to other locations in the area. I was really looking forward to trying four barrel out, but unfortunately, my experience was slightly underwhelming. Also, it's price skyrockets out of the warehouse and seating is rather limited. 

Environment:
The lighting is dim and the seating is limited. There are only a few tables on the right side of the place. There is a large roaster in the back and a taller table with stool for more seating. The ambiance I felt was more of a cold one. People that came here to order coffee seemed like they were grumpy and in a rush to get somewhere. The place is a mix between a museum and a warehouse. 

Latte (4/5): 
The latte ($5) was pretty tasty, but just ok. The milk was very fresh but heavier on the milk. I did like the frothiness, aromatic, and tangy taste of the coffee though.

Service: 
Again, I feel the baristas were very unwelcoming. When I arrived, the cashier looked unmotivated and tired. I initially first ordered a vanilla latte, but they had run out of vanilla already. I ended up opting for a regular latte, which I didn't mind. The latte was made pretty slowly and people waiting seemed very impatient as well.

Last Thoughts:
The latte wasn't bad, just nothing special. Not a fan of the interior or the people working here. Also, the prices are higher here...The utopia in this reputable coffee shop will shatter once you see the prices. The cups aren't that big at all and the wait is quite slow as I only observed one barista making drinks. The verdict? This location is too overpretentious and overpriced for me. There are a lot of places around the SF Bay Area that serve Four Barrel coffee, at much more reasonable prices, so I would suggest hitting up those spots instead.
author: Rebecca C.

description:
I'm sorry. There are many nice worker at Four Barrel, the space is gorgeous, the music often surprising, and the espresso is nearly always on point, but I must publicly complain that the iced coffee is awful, it has always been awful, and it will continue to be awful until people start letting you know how awful it is. And yes, I know I deserve to be punished for icing coffee given that we have maybe four days a year when it's warm enough to enjoy iced coffee.

Please send someone up to on a pilgrimage to Noble Coffee in Ashland to know what iced coffee can be. This "nitro" stuff is all hype.
author: Seth G.

description:
I love this spot!! It's so cute and spacious. They have a great bike rack area outside and some public seating out there, and they have a decent amount of tables inside! Honestly they could put in a bunch more tables if they didn't just have a ton of empty space in the middle, but it does make the entire place seem more spacious. 

They only have one type of tea, so this probably isn't the place for those who don't enjoy coffee or just want tea if it's later in the day. The coffee I've had here is great! I love the lattes and the drip coffee. Definitely a nice spot to meet up with some friends and catch up, especially since they don't have WiFi.
author: Frannie Y.

description: We still rave about the coffee here. Their space is also a plus. We loved the modern industrial vibe and seeing the coffee roasting process located in the back of the store. Money and time well spent!
author: Elly K.

description: On a recent trip to San Francisco, this coffee shop was in my top 5 must-try places for a self-guided coffee tour.  This was the first stop on our third day there, and it did not disappoint.  First of all, the building is HUGE and there are more than enough tables to sit at (if that's what to you want to do while enjoying a good cup of coffee). Second of all, the minimalist coffee menu and hipster decor in the place told me this was gonna be ALL about the coffee beans. I love this trend of third-wave coffee that's been happening for the last five years or so, and I will try as many as I can while it lasts.  This place also gets bonus points for having a separate bar just for pour overs. Nice!
author: Ashley L.

description: We dodged in here for a few minutes to order a coffee and show the scene to my teen step-kids who live out of town. They were impressed. Coffee is strong, bitter and pretty much as good as it gets, in my book.
author: Camille L.

description:
Everything in SF is pretty pricey, and this is no exception; however, you are definitely paying for what you get. This is a no-nonsense coffee and bakery that serves the basics like lattes, capuccinos, etc. without flavored syrups (unless it's a special). The focus is on their coffees and the wonderful quality of their pastries. We got:

Latte (with alternative milk): Smooth, mellow, and inviting. It was a nice and slow pick-me-up that gave me a lazy smile and gave me enough energy to waddle my way to brunch. You can tell that they make their espressos exactly as it should.

Espresso: As I said, you know it's done right. It comes with that almost milky appearance and goes down nice and smooth. Hits your gut and BOOM! I'm awake! They gave us a cup of water, but it's really not needed if you love your coffee.

Almond cake (GF): A tiny bit on the sweet side, but that's what coffee is for! There's also a very rich, almond flavor that most pastries tend to lack, but this is definitely an almond party in your mouth! The cake was perfectly moist and had just the right texture without being too crumbly or too sticky. Amazing.

Breakfast muffin (GF): Honestly I forgot what this muffin was called, but it was gluten free and had some dried cranberries in it. This was actually my favorite of the two pastries, as it was just the right amount of sweetness (the dried berries give it that extra zing!) Once again, baked to perfection. 

As I said, this is a wonderful place with crazy amazing quality foods. The latte and 2 pastries alone almost came out to $15, so expect to empty the wallet for this one--or is this normal in SF? Either way, I recommend you try it at least once before you run away from the prices.
author: Monica L.

description:
A bit disappointed on the fact that they do not carry non-fat milk, yet the macadamia milk certainly made it up! It was a bit thicker and more nutty than the regular almond milk that I have tried elsewhere, very unique texture!

Cute cup made of ceramics, and lovely latte art, the best way to kick off Friday (and the long weekend)!
author: Elaine H.

description: Great coffee in an open, airy space. Came during June and happily saw a pride flag hung near the coffee roasting area in the back! Cute seats, quick service, nice baristas. There's a bike rack out front for customer use!
author: Alex R.

description:
My brother suggested Four Barrel Coffee if I'm in the Mission District. Did not disappoint! I went with a friend at 11AM on a Tuesday. Parking was a bit hard to find (usual for the most parts in the city) but it wasn't impossible; only took 5 minutes to drive around.  

HUGE HUGE HUGE beautiful space with a backside where they roast and coffee taste the beans. Super interesting and cool.  

Cleanliness (5/5): Everything was stocked and clean. I didn't see any dirty cups or plates left on tables so in addition to customers returning the cups, the staff must be on top of cleaning tables. The organization of the space helped to give that really clean feel. The retail walls (every bag of coffee was in perfect line and stocked), the pour over station, the pastry case, the roastery area, and the espresso bar areas were all organized. 

Customer Connection (5/5): cashier/barista greeted us right away. Even though we were still undecided on what to try, he was really welcoming! I walked away after I ordered by my friend and he talked for 1 minute or so, and she said it was a good conversation. We mustve interacted with at least 3 team members and they all were nice, friendly, and thanked us. I felt appreciated! 

Service/Product Quality (5/5): My friend ordered a macchiato (and the speck and manchego croissant) and I ordered a latte. I like the fact the barista asked if we wanted it for here or togo. Sometimes I want a drink for here but forget to ask - I think that shows great engagement on their end. My friend said she liked her drink and croissant. My latte was good - I could taste the sweet caramelly and smooth notes of the espresso. The for here cups are in ceremic mugs. Very cool.
author: Martin N.

description:
These two stars are for the friendly cat and the physical ambience (cool space inside and parquet outside).  The service gets negative stars.  I live in the neighborhood and walk by frequently, but rarely go to (Four) Barrel because I don't drink coffee.  I do eat croissants and end up at (Four) Barrel when my usual neighborhood spot is out of them.  

The last time I went, I asked what kind of croissants they had and chose the one they said was filled with cheese.  What they didn't tell me is that it was also filled with meat.  Not just meat, but prosciutto - ham - pig meat.  You'd think they would mention this given that many people have a "no pig eating" policy.  Once I picked out the prosciutto and the prosciutto-tainted cheese, the remainder of the $4.00 croissant (pretty much just crust) was ok.  

This morning, when my usual spot and my back-up spot were both out of croissants, I ended up at (Four) Barrel.  I went up to the register and the barista (medium blond, septum piercing) was painstaking making some sort of toast. It looked like maybe nut butter and jam and boy was she being though. Spreading the ingredients just so, making sure to get them allllll the way to the crust and evenly across the toast.  Topping it with just a smidge of ground salt.  Carefully placing it on a plate.  Putting the plate on a back counter.  

The whole endeavor took several minutes and at no time did she even acknowledge my presence.  I made eye contact with the other barista (very short brown/black hair also pierced) who was busy making coffee and she offered nothing.  No "Good morning," no "We'll be right with you," not one word.  As I'm standing there, ready to pay a ridiculous $4.00 for a roll, I start to wonder . . . who is that toast for?  It was for her!  After I got the croissant, I hung out and, sure enough, she started eating it.

And my croissant was stale.  Maybe it went stale during the toast making marathon.  Sigh.
author: J W.

description:
Yay...it seems that calmer minds have prevailed.  Although a name change is in progress the hostile environment has taken a step back and the operation of business seems to have returned to it previous pleasantness.
.
For now local artists works are still on display. At $5.00 I do love the rich/not burned flavor of their Latte. And, there is a separate pour-over station if that is more your speed. They carry a diverse assortment of pastries yet have no Wi-Fi, thank you. A park let with built-in bike parking at the front door still expands their sitting space a bit yet only the thinnest of bike wheels can fit into this custom stand. For the discriminating pallet a dozen or so whole bean roasts from Rwanda to Ethiopia and Guatemala are available for sale.

Enjoy...
author: Caesar A.

description:
I was looking forward to loving this place as it was highly recommended by couple friends who go there regularly every Saturday morning.

We visited July 23rd in the pm hours after a long stroll in the city.

The place was really nice with the wooden feel and so airy. You could see the coffee roasters in the back. 

Self service at the counter.

What I didn't like is how cold the coffee/hot cocoa was. None of the four of us enjoyed that and the taste wasn't that good either. Can't say I will be back.
author: Heliana M.

description:
This place is absolutely adorable! You can smell the delicious coffee from down the block practically! 

I needed a cup of coffee before my big project day in the City. This place popped up and so I walked a few blocks there. The aroma as soon as you walk in made me want to wait in the long line for a cup of joe. Their coffee is definitely sourced well and their staff seem to really know what they are doing.

My cup of coffee was delicious. The aroma didn't lie to me at all. It was a rich and complex blend, so much flavor in one sip. I didn't grab a pastry but those looked fresh as well.

This spot seems to be pretty busy so be prepared to wait a little while. Coffee is the fastest thing to get as they give it to you right as you pay. Check this cute spot out!
author: Bri D.

description:
The kouign Amann here is amazing!!! I ended up buying another togo since we devoured that first one right away. Came by on the way out of town for a quick breakfast. The interior was just beautiful! I loved the set up, decor, the little details of this place. The staff was friendly. I ordered a mocha and 2 chocolate milk. The cup the mocha came in was just so beautiful as well. It seemed to be made of clay and had no handle which was really neat. 

Their attempt at chocolate milk was drinkable but you can tell it's not what kids would consider "chocolate milk". Only because it seemed they used high quality chocolate meant for hot drinks into cold milk. Kids were still able to drink it. 

I would recommend people come by for their coffee but definitely grab a kouign amann as well. It was just so delicious!!!!
author: Jenny K.

description:
Ok coffee, only non dairy option is almond (which is fine but for a hipster haven like this place, I'd expect more). They don't have WiFi which I suppose is to help ensure people don't camp out indefinitely. Service is fine, a little slow. 

One thing I did notice - I went to use the rest room and the toilet seat had completely come loose and was hanging off the side of the toilet. When I went to mention it to one of the Baristas they seemed pretty indifferent and just shrugged it off.

Not the worst, not the best, it's there if you're in the area and in need of a caffeine fix.
author: Rebecca M.

description:
Love this coffee shop. The vibe and interior is very hipster. The cafe had a good amount of seating inside allows you come hang out and work or chill. 

Cool place enjoy the Coffeee!!
author: Lin L.

description:
I'm only visiting SF for a couple days and decided to try this place as it was close to where I am staying. It's great! 

Cool, open, community hip vibe with nice decor and decent music. 

I had the cappuccino and it was delicious. Also random but the cup and saucer it was served on was very unique - it looks like it was hand sculpted from clay, like yesterday. Idk. Also had the German coffee cake - was very good, super moist and flavorful. Service was fast and friendly. 

The Mission neighborhood is very cool. It has a strong community feel, but definitely seems sketch in many areas. This place seems to be a sign of the gentrification in the area. I like it.
author: Alex S.

description: Fancy coffee bar - but okay, I must admit, I like it!! And the coffee is great!! The environment and people there Are nice - and the staff is friendly.. So although a little hipster, which probably for some people is a plus, it's a great place and I like it a lot!!
author: Nadia S.

description: Awesome espresso drinks made with love and artistic designs. This place had a fun, hip atmosphere and wasn't too crowded. It had a steady flow of customers but room to sit. Friendly staff and good selection of bakery items (gluten free options too).
author: Lindsey J.

description: I was in the Mission on a Saturday afternoon and decided to come here for its high ratings. I got an iced americano and didn't stay long but would come back another time to work as there's ample space and I like the hipster interior with its greenery and natural lighting!
author: Regina X.

description: I love coffee and this is one of my favorite places! Ordered a latte, came in a nice ceramic cup, and a pistachio blackberry croissant to dine in  Wish they were closer to me!
author: Angelica G.

description: This coffee house is hip and serves delicious coffee.  There's ample room inside to sit and chill or work.  Their coffee beans are roasted on the premises, so it's got to be fresh.  This place sells their beans to other houses, so they have a following.  It's nice that there is free almond milk in their jug if you're lactose intolerant or sensitive., (in addition to regular milk)
author: Mabe S.

description:
4/19/2017:

This coffee shop is the best. Four Barrel Coffee is the coffee shops with quality coffee, latte art, consistent friendly service, baristas are always prompt and friendly, most importantly bonus points for clean facility. I decided to come in for a latte and without a doubt, Four Barrel is my first stop.

Wait time from putting in my order to retrieving it took less than 10 minutes. I admire the seating they have inside and outside. I love the parklets right in front. It is a great way to enjoy a cup of coffee with that pastry on cool and dry or warm and sunny days.

FYI:
16th St / Mission Bart Station is actually within a walking distance from here. If you are in need of a morning coffee, come on on and count on Four Barrel Coffee.

One of the nearby bus routes serving the area include:
- 14 Mission
- 14R Mission Rapid
- 22 Fillmore
- 33 Ashbury / 18th St
- 49 Van Ness / Mission
- 55 16th St

Reasons for the rating:
- clean facility
- prompt service
- friendly baristas
- quality coffee
- latte art

Overall, positive first time experience here and I enjoyed the coffee.
author: Bennett W.

description:
As my friend babbled on and on about how much he loves the macchiato here, I had one question to ask him, "how big is it?"  Size isn't really an issue for me just as long as I get that quick satisfaction ;P but since I started the day pretty early, in my mind, bigger meant stronger.  I kept going back and forth between the Latte and Cappuccino but ended up getting what else, the macchiato.  

This is probably the only coffee shop I"ve ever visited where the line went out the door.  Hype?  Good coffee?  All of the above?  And if you're wondering, the small cup of macchiato hit the spot.
author: Linda N.

description:
Located in the Mission District. They have a few locations in CA. Very spacious and trendy spot for the coffee fanatic. There is a space where they have different kinds of beans they will make for you on the spot, beans to purchase, chairs along the wall and an area in the back where you can see them roast the beans and such. 

Menu is small but they're good at what they make. Ordered a latte, came in this very cute cup with beautiful latte art. One of the best lattes I've had! The espresso was rich and strong and the bitterness was just slightly balanced out with the milk. I drank it so quickly! Service and atmosphere was super friendly and would definitely come back to stay or grab something on the go.
author: Alyson Y.

description:
I don't really consider myself great at distinguishing coffees (for me coffee is on more of a pass fail scale than 1-10), but enjoy trying different artisan coffees anyways. Unfortunately I still don't have that distinguishing skill, but I can say Four Barrel is definitely well over the pass threshold. 

I came here around noon on a Sunday and it looked like there were two solid lines, but they both moved quickly and I got my cappuccino within five minutes of ordering. Extra points for carrying Dyanmo Donuts, which are soft and brioche-y and perfect for pairing with coffee! Seating was pretty sparse, not too bad if you're by yourself but could be a struggle to find a place to sit with more than two people. On that same note, the noise level was at a medium chatter so it might not be conducive for doing work (unless that's the kind of white noise you prefer, which may very well be the case because there were people there studying). But if all you're looking for is a solid cup of coffee to start your day, Four Barrel is a real good option.
author: Amy J.

description:
I cannot explain how perfect Four Barrel is. After accidentally stumbling into its Valencia location, I fell in love. Their cappuccinos are unbelievably good and their everything croissant is nothing short of addictive. Great staff, lots of space, and a beautifully decorated atmosphere. Highly recommended dining in. Their coffee cups and long wooden tables are perfect for meeting up with a few people or working offline for a few hours.

Great place, wish there was one back home in Canada.
author: Emily L.

description:
Four Barrel is a really nice artisinal coffeeshop. The space is pretty dark, huge, open, and very well designed but it seems to be always busy so finding a space to work might be hard. The front left side has a tea bar. 

I just shared an Americano with Angie but what the fuck one sip of the coffee made me SO caffeinated I could have sworn it was spiked with something. I couldn't focus on anything and was really paranoid for like 2 hours. Still, I'd go again for the atmosphere and ambiance. :)
author: Yenny Z.

description:
I got an Americano here and it was very... Watery. I know an Americano is a diluted espresso but still. I also think that their beans have a hint of earthy and woodsy (almost musky) note at the end that I'm not a big fan of. But hey, I'm not a coffee connoisseur, so maybe this is what quality coffee should taste like. I'm just saying that this is what I tasted and I'm not a huge fan. 

Just FYI, the line on the left is for pour over or drip coffee for different beans. The line straight ahead is for lattes, cappuccino, etc.
author: Susanna C.

description: For a coffee shop to only have almond milk is pretty sad. Took one sip and threw it away
author: Milena D.

description:
Four barrel is probably my favorite coffee place in the city. I love their coffee from the single origin pour over to the  affogato. I also enjoy the cappuccino and the mocha. The mocha is made with dandelion chocolate. 

I love the space as well; it's spacious and yet very cozy. They also display pretty cool arts that they change from time to time, and they play pretty awesome music too. 

Pastries are pretty decent here too. They serve dynamo donuts, which is pretty awesome!
author: Sam M.

description: Yep fast, friendly enough, and great espresso shots! Kind of a coffee lounge but they know what they're doing for sure!
author: Nick N Parker S.

description: What more can I say about this place besides it lives up to its hype. Ya, I mean it busy and what not, and ya I'm sure everything says that hipsters come here etc...but come on, the coffee and the service and coffee isssss amazing. Anyone that complains about this place can walk thier asses back to suburbia to dunkn donuts.
author: Jaycob D.

description:
Latte : the coffee bean was well-roasted not too heavy, so coffee and milk are balanced. 
Nitro coffee : very trendy to have the nitro coffee, very fresh, like beer. 
Environment : deco is very cute and artistic with many creative paintings on the wall. Good place to chat with friends or for a date.
author: Lily C.

description: I am a coffee snob and I can tell you the coffee here is worth the hype. It's not the same when you have four barrel coffee at the ferry terminal. This is the real deal. The interior is cute although hard to grab a table but the coffee beans are so smooth that the small inconveniences hardly matter! Check out this place if you like a good cuppa!
author: Ruchi M.

description:
One of those local coffee companies defines the stereotype of San Francisco. On a regular afternoon finishing up the day from a long day of work. I never thought I would think to say that working in a coffee shop was more productive than my apartment, but with my significant other with our MacBooks is an excellent place to get some work done while always enjoying each others company.

I will have to admit coffee shops on Valencia tend to blend in with the vibe, but this one had a bit of personality that makes it a little different. Walked into to the coffee shop was a location that provided ample seating with two public parklets outside the shop. Greeted inside was some more room and the open space that brings the place to life. In the shop, there was a lot of character that the place provided. There is a nice whiff of coffee. From the coffee bags and coffee apparatus sold. The animal heads on the wall, the vinyl records that were put up are and played through the duration.  Presented is the counter with an open view of the coffee making. Around the place you see was there is some pretty spectacular lighting which makes the place kind of feel like a cabin in the evening. From the local art on the wall to the coffee bean making it is a pretty spectacular place.

Going up to the counter service is quite good. The menu is straightforward and concise, and the staff is pretty friendly. From ordering the coffee was made on the side while prices seemed to be pretty typical and in-line with expected. 

From the place, we ended up ordering the Affogato. Mixing espresso and a scoop of vanilla ice cream it reminded me of my visit to Fob Kitchen I wanted to re-visit and try it again. Upon receiving the drink, there was a beautiful aroma from the freshly brewed coffee. It is welcoming and just something that reeled you in. After taking a spoonful of both, it was a kick in the face of flavors in your mouth. The coffee just feels empowering. The presentation is great with softened vanilla sticking out of the cup and coffee drizzling down from the pour from the brew. The cup and the saucer is a fine clay like material which is felt different and quite nice.

The one caveat I would say here is the lack of Wifi. Understandable for the costs it makes it a little hard to work having to rely upon other services such as a personal hotspot or somebody else's wifi connection. Not a deal breaker but something to consider.

Overall I would say this place is a good place to grab a coffee and do some work. The atmosphere feels great, and the coffee is also good and will give you a jolt. Also, a nice place to just sit down and chat as it is not too loud either. I would rate this place a good 5/5 for what it does best. Coffee.

Tips:
1. Get the Affogato or even any of their coffees it smells fresh and is great
2. Come here on Saturdays where you can to see get some fresh grinding of coffee
3. Not a bad place to bring a date
4. Bring your own Wireless Hotspot of some sort.
author: Frank O.

description: Fun and coffee for me can't get much better.  Four Barrel Coffee has great vibe, hipster decor with upscale mission denizens hanging out.  Some people like Blue Bottle, I like the coffee here better.  We bought some beans to take home and sadly just ran out yesterday.  I have been a Peets fan, but most of their blends are too week. If I lived in the Mission, i would be here often.
author: Diane V.

description: Four Barrel is definitely one of the best coffee shops in the Bay Area. They definitely know their stuff and they make delicious coffee. The staff is all very nice and welcoming and the atmosphere is so open and friendly. One of my favorite parts is that they offer classes as well! I can't wait to take the Espresso and Milk Preparation Class in November!
author: Daniel C.

description: No Wifi.  Coffee is pretty good.  Vibe is great.  A good place to meet.  Bohemian, Portland/old Berkeley kind of place
author: J I.

description:
I work about 2-3 minutes away from this place so it's pretty often that I find myself here in the morning or for a afternoon rally latte.... They do it just right here! Lattes are amazing... my favorite's their Mocha Latte! And the ambiance inside is incredible. 

My favorite part about this place is the always changing art that they display on their walls! Definitely check it out if you're in the mission.
author: Carrie L.

description: A wonderfully quaint spot to grab a cup of coffee in the morning. I had a cup of the Ruirui beans from Kenya. My cup came out in 3 minutes and it was warm and flavorful! Best cup of coffee I have had in San Francisco!
author: Stephen D.

description:
Serious, coffee. Came here just to get the vibe, and got swept up in the culture. Wonderful staff, nice customers, and a chill time.
Enjoy!
author: William M.

description:
I'm only giving Four Barrel Coffee 4 stars (but really I'd pick 3.5 if I could) because their coffee is delicious, the inside is trendy, and the aesthetics are on point; besides that, however, their tables are pretty small (makes it hard to study if you're there to get work done on a laptop), the inside is pretty spread out yet with limited tables and chairs so there isn't actually much seating available despite all that space, and, best of all, there is no wifi. 

Four Barrel Coffee is great for folks who want to pop in for a coffee and maybe sit and hangout, but if you're looking to study (aka need wifi), this is not your study cafe. I repeat, abort, abort!
author: Joy K.

description:
I really enjoyed their cappuccino with the homemade almond macadamia milk. The expresso was nutty and smooth. 
The quiche they had was amazing! Seriously wow 
I just really wished they had a toaster.
author: Nancy A.

description:
Lack luster. Could care less for the "Dickson's Cider" on the secret menu. F*#k it and Suck it mugs?  What could that be referencing? How do they get away with this?

There are many other women friendly coffee shops you can spend your money at that are just as good.
author: Chris L.

description: One of the few places in the Mission where you can have a coffee, pastry, and be able to read or work at a table. It can get packed and busy quickly during the weekends and morning rush. Heads up: they keep it SIMPLE and don't have flavors to add to your drinks (for example, no vanilla lattes). They have gluten-free pastry items for GF customers.
author: Sarah N.

description:
https://www.sfchronicle.com/food/article/Four-Barrel-is-back-Its-name-change-lasted-11-12519382.php

Need I say more folks? 

"It's not about what they're going to do. This whole thing is about what they didn't do. How they failed the employees. I mean, time's up... The name change and everything -- that's not what their focus should be on right now. Their focus should be on making sure employees feel safe to come forward."

No second chance for a serial rapist, who threatened and silenced eight women using his position. While he may have left the company, the new owners revoked their actions that had been intended for accountability, showing once again that they care more for profits than people.

Take a stand and abandon this place folks; there are many other local coffeeshops to visit in this city.
author: A G.

description: Came in here to work a little today. The aroma of their coffee bean is amazing. As I waited in line deciding whether to get their latte or hot chocolate, I came to a quick conclusion "Why not a mocha?!" Well that's what I ordered and loved! Perfectly sweetened and creamy mocha.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
I love the ambiance and atmosphere here, because they have many sitting tables and area for you to hang out. Nice interior design and open space, the menu is straightforward the service is good. it only takes 5mins from line up to order to get coffee. 
they also offer coffee class in the back for you to attend, quite interesting.
Not a big fun of their latte, but overall, it was an lovely experience.
author: Ao L.

description: Delicious coffee. This is my favorite coffee in the entire Bay Area! I prefer this over any other coffee place. Love the mocha and macchiato. I don't usually take macchiato, as I can't take a high caffeine concentrated coffee. This is truly one exception and I'm totally prepared to take all the caffeine consequences to my body by drinking lots of water. Yes I have the tendency of having shortness of breath if the caffeine level is too high. I guess I can call myself a caffeine detector. :) Nice environment with insufficient seats though. More seating area would be great. Please open a chain in South Bay soon and have four barrel coffee ice cream please...
author: Cheryl E.

description: Today's experience (years later) was good - friendly person taking order, friendly barista, quick service...but also an easy order: one decaf Americano.
author: Kenneth B.

description: Fabulous coffee and cute, cozy vibes. I got a regular hot coffee with their house made almond, macadamia milk. So delish, fresh and energizing! There are seats for folks to enjoy and you can even see them roasting the beans in the back!
author: Alyssa W.

description: I love the atmosphere, the open concept and of course the coffee. I had the cappachino, it was good and strong. My wife had the latte, which she loved
author: Khaled A.

description:
Great atmosphere + coffee with plenty of space and seating made this the perfect place for a weekday morning coffee break, albeit a bit chilly inside in winter. 

When a friend joined me, the ambient noise was at a perfect level - but if you are often bothered by noise, you might finder the grinder in the back + conversations around you + music a bit loud.
author: Jennifer W.

description: Beautiful interior with high ceilings and excellent music. Was there fairly early around 9am and they had some metal music blasting which I loved. My latte though wasn't that great since it was served too hot but would go back again.
author: Mark M.

description: Hanging a LGBT flag with an unfriendly passive aggressive staff towards a LGBT person is kinda of ironic. Your coffee is great but so does other local coffee joint nearby.
author: Henry W.

description:
If left to own star-scale I woulda gone with 3 stars, but 'meh. I've experienced better" is literally what I think every time I'm in here.

I actually really like the space - huge! (if not a bit underutilized).  Bright and open, a fair amount of shared table seating in the front half, with sun from the front and the back.   Woody natural vibe, some boar heads on the wall, peppered with cool art, and some thin but muscley tatted hipsters that are nice on the eyes - totally into the vibe. 

The biggest meh.... the coffee is HORRIBLE.  Of the four times I've been here, each latte has been curdled, burnt, bitter, and/or unpalatable.  I don't know if it's the almond or soy milk I pair it with, or if all four visits have been unlucky batches, but I seriously can't get it down. 

There is no wifi here - I know, I know, poor on-the-cusp-millenial me.  But seriously, if I'm going to spend $10-12 bucks on a coffee and a pastry a bit of wifi to work on some emails while relaxing w said cringe-worthy coffee makes the whole thing more enjoyable.  Find a way to limit the time if you don't want people loitering.  

Will I go back? Probably.  With an eye roll at some visiting friend's suggestion.  Will it be for the coffee? No way
author: Jenna S.

description:
This place GETS coffee; wow, just wow! I was on vacation and wanted a good cup of coffee. Turns out this place has a GREAT cup of coffee. I ordered an Americano which was brewed to perfection. This place is big, bustling and bold. Love it! 

Staff was knowledgeable, helpful and downright amazing. Would I come back here? You're asking? Kudos to you, Four Barrels; well done!
author: Kyle K.

description:
No WIFI here. Probably to deter people from overstaying their welcome with studying, netflixing. 
That said, the coffee menu is simple and minimal. Think I'm N Out of the coffee world. You can get coffee or a cap or a latte. It's quite refreshing to have such a simple menu without so many flavors and shots etc. 

Pastries we're really good. We had the banana chocolate scone as well as the almond cake. Really good. Had a latte and a specialty seasonal pumpkin drink. Both great. 

The interior is super cute and inviting. Cute tables with a street view or inside to watch the baristas work.  There's also a separate tea section. 

Note: if you take the Bart there and take the 16th/mission exit, prepare yourself. There will some people talking to themselves. There will be urine. However the walk is short and should be safe. I wouldn't walk there in the dark tho. However once you're closer to The Cafe, it's like an entirely new part of town. What a diff a couple of blocks make.
author: Dan P.

description: I came here on Saturday with a friend for a quick pick-me-up. I love the decor & vibes here. It's a cute, unique coffee shop, which I personally think is better than Blue Bottle. I'm from the east coast and never tried nitro coffee before, so this was my first time trying it. The cold brew nitro coffee here is strong, flavorful, and has great texture. The people here are really nice, too, which I think is most important anyway. I highly recommend this place if you're sick of Starbucks & Philz and want to try something new!
author: Jenny M.

description:
Yummy, great atmosphere and clean staff! I love the fresh smell of coffee from half a mile away.

Similar to blue bottle, but unique in their own way. The inside decor is lovely!
author: Sarah C.

description:
Great coffee.

Especially the lattes.

Maybe one of the best there is out there in the Bay area. Wish they had one in Orange County. A hipster place. Looks packed all the time. At least on Friday morning when we came in. The cost is $5 for a latte. The other options are considerable good. They have a separate pour over station which is genius! The barista (not sure his title) has a number or coffee machines on display behind him. On the counter, they have a sample platte or their delicious chocolate cookie. I would definitely recommend this place not just for their coffee, but also for their pastries as well.
author: Lila L.

description: Drank this whole hot chocolate and found a bug at the end. Had to pull it up to a photo. Thanks for serving me a bug with some not so good hot chocolate. I have been visiting Four Barrel whenever I'm in town from New York City but I won't be doing that anymore.
author: Ahmed F.

description:
I was excited to try one of SF's most reputable coffee shops, but unfortunately my visit was very underwhelming... And this is coming from a craft-coffee-loving, cool-space-hunting, hipster-wannabe, Instagramming millennial -_-;;

Yes the coffee is good, but not mind-blowingly better than all the many choices for artisan coffee around SF. The menu is simple, with coffee and espresso essentials. 

But the utopia in this picture-perfect coffee shop shatters once you see the prices, which skyrocket out the (warehouse) roof. I got a mocha, which was a whopping $5.75, AND tax was not included (it was $6.22 total), AND it was served in a tiny cup that looked like a sad 8oz., AND they pretentiously only offer whole milk or housemade almond/macadamia nut milk (extra $1). So if I had been lactose intolerant, I would have to pay over $7 for a small mocha! 

The mocha itself was quite good, blended with quality Dandelion chocolate for deliciously bitter, dark chocolately notes layered over freshly roasted espresso. It was complex and delectable and all, but overpriced at the end of the day. (Would rather grab some tacos or a bowl of noodles at Yamo in the neighborhood for about the same price)

Other observations:
- The wait is also quite slow; for all the profit that they make, I only observed one barista making drinks. 
- Note that there is no wifi, so it's not meant for getting work done. (I dislike how customers' coffee shop uses are sacrificed for better turnover and more profit.)
- The ambiance reminds me a lot of coffee shops in Portland, with a roasting section in the back, wooden stools and tables, and exposed beams. The industrial vibe is photogenic, but not really unique in its own right as it looks imported from Portland.
- Parking is actually not impossible, at least in the mornings. There are plenty of metered spots, with free parking a short walk away.
- If you are going to splurge here, be sure to get your camera phones ready. The latte art is noteworthy and they serve drinks in beautiful stoneware, which I believe they rotate (though when I went, the fancy saucer was a hue of beige that ended up looking like a compostable paper plate in pictures).

***Pro tip: There are a lot of places around the SF Bay Area that serve Four Barrel coffee, at much more reasonable prices (e.g. B. patisserie's Four Barrel mocha is only $4.75, 12oz., tax included!)

The verdict? The original Four Barrel location is a neat spot, but too pretentious and overpriced for my tastes.... it costs 2 arms and 2 legs, as if you've been shot by a 4-barrel pistol. Sorry, bad pun xD
author: Edna C.

description: Very high prices, but fantastic quality coffee and the shop has lots of character.
author: Joseph B.

description: Happy to choose this place over the others. I really enjoyed the almond cashew cappuccino perfectly served in beautiful mugs which makes it more wonderful and delicious. Quality was great. Surely recommend to everyone who loves coffee and looking for a good place and amazing service. Thanks
author: Ellie S.

description: What happened? This was my go-to place for years and now it seems to be a ghost of what it once was. The staff is horrible, especially the older lady, the coffee has been sub-par the last few times I went. Sad really. Luckily SF has many other great coffee shops. Its strange the mill, which serves 4 barrel does a better job then 4 barrel itself.
author: SImon C.

description: Coffee the way it should be. Great location and the interior is very cool. Bathroom is very clean and plenty of seating.  Quality does come at a price so if you want cheap find a drive through. If you want something delicious crafted perfectly then you found the right spot.
author: Manny G.

description:
Four barrel is one of the better coffee places in San Francisco that lives up to the hype. Fair prices and good coffee. Pretty standard choices of menu. I advise to either go early or to wait out rush hour times since the line and wait can get long. Definitely
My favorite coffee place! 

The ambience of the place is like any other coffee place but it does offer an outdoor seating area that is nice to be at during sunny days!
author: Katty X.

description: Mmmm coffee and Hot Chocolate!  What a great space to enjoy coffee from the street to the standing bar facing the roasting machines in the back.  The drip coffee bar was a nice to have option when ordering your daily dose of caffeine, if you're willing to wait some time.  The kids loved the Hot Cocoa on a chilly SF day.
author: Anthony E.

description: I love the rustic interior design of this place! There was 2 places to order, there was bar on the left that had 4 different types of cold drip/filtered/V60 (looked like a science experiment which was cool) and the front bar where you ordered more common coffees like lattes, they also had a pastries which were nice to snack on. The coffee was really smooth to drink, didn't need a lot of sugar or extra condiments!
author: Shan N.

description:
Great cappuccino! I love the atmosphere here. 
If you're big on coffee, you'll wanna try it here. I personally prefer coffee places where there's a space to mingle and chat. Good to find a place where majority of the people are engaging with others rather than buried under a laptop and typing away. Great location to catch up with friends!
author: Kelly L.

description: Nice vibe, good coffee, elegant tables, i wish i hadnt drank coffee from certain other vision-clear container shop..this place serves solid coffee
author: Ji T.

description:
Arguably, the best coffee in san francisco. If a coffee shop done everything right and making sure the cheapest coffee picked correctly, roast correctly, brewed correctly and served correctly. You know they are in serious business. House Coffee are not bitter, has right consistency, has a good aroma.  Tried multiple espresso type drink and always impressed. 
They also have good selection of pastry and snacks
author: Dan A.

description:
I don't know THAT much about coffee but the mocha that I got here was phenomenal. A lot of times, mocha is too chocolate-y and too sweet but this was the perfect amount of sweetness without being too bitter. It came in a really cute wooden cup too! My friend got the latte and he really enjoyed it as well. 
They have really unique baked goods from local San Francisco shops too. 
The whole place smelled wonderful and there was adequate seating.
author: Vi-Van N.

description:
Okay the decor is nice SUPER hipster. But overpriced and no WiFi?!?!? What place doesn't have WiFi that sells 5 dollar coffee and all these desks and no ability to work.
Super lame
I would definitely not come back here
And the desks are super impractical they are barely big enough to fit a laptop
author: Ryan C.

description: Mediocre. Drip coffee is a bit thin. No WiFi. No place to recharge your phone. Tables/chairs look cool, but really not comfortable. I think their goal is to have you stay as little time as possible. Achieved.
author: Peter K.

description: Little hard to find, there was no sign from the way we were approaching the shop. But were able to confirm quickly that it was the place we wanted. Coffee was fabulous and it was nice to be able to sit outside and enjoy it.
author: Amanda L.

description: Great coffee and friendly staff, nice atmosphere, but no wi fi (is listed as having wi fi on Yelp). If you want an ok place to work and do not need wi fi, it's volume isn't bad with earbuds and space is open and easy.
author: Kristin S.

description: Friendly staff, beautiful space, and excellent coffee and pastries. I recently enjoyed a pistachio pastry (highly recommend) and a superb latte out of a handcrafted ceramic mug. Space is decently sized and featured lovely exposed wooden beams and more industrial aesthetic details.
author: Ailien V.

description:
I was really surprised with our experience this morning, especially based on previous (mostly positive) reviews. I've been visiting cafes in the city as my new Monday morning routine. This has to be the worst Monday yet. First, the cashier who rang us up was super unfriendly -- she  seemed annoyed that I had questions about the pastries/coffee. We chose a veggie and a meat quiche, a latte, and a mocha. I asked if they had flavored lattes and was told no (but a previous reviewer said they have Vanilla Lattes?). Anyway, the quiches were cold -- coagulated, chunky bits of cheese cold. We asked if our quiches could be warmed up and were told "they've already been warmed up." We had to take our cold quiches to work to actually eat them :/

I thought my mocha was good, but for whatever reason, there was no hint of mocha/chocolate in the drink. The latte wasn't that impressive either, but the latte art was exquisite. This could have been a mediocre 3 star review (meaning I wouldn't have left a review, period), but the service/cold pastry knocked them down to a solid 2. There's definitely room for growth here.
author: Jane L.

description:
Four Barrel is a hip and fun coffehouse. They offer high end coffee, serving its community and visitors. Their outdoor seating allows one to enjoy the urban jungle, while sipping their favorite beverage. They use an old German coffee roaster that holds heat and let enough amount of air flow that produces their fantastic coffee, one drip at a time.  Founded under the principle of helping local coffee growers, sourcing form Latin America, East Africa and Indonesia,  Four Barrel's hopes to achieve to provide local farmers a better life by partnering with them. If you find yourself in the neighborhood of Valencia and 15th, do pay them a visit, and enjoy their expansive selection of coffee and more!

Until then, be kind to one another and Cheers! ~ :p
author: Edwin R.

description: I love the coffee selections! It has way better taste than Starbucks. 12 oz coffee beans for $20. Am I disappointed? Not at all. It gives you that different flavor profile that you never knew that it exists in different coffee beans. Not all coffee beans are created equal!
author: Jeff l.

description:
Hadn't been here before but kept hearings great things about it. I honestly kept confusing this place with Sightglass (not a huge fan of that place) but I'm so glad I finally came here yesterday! 

It's...awesome! I had already had enough caffeine and was still full from a late lunch but got an almond macadamia latte just cuz I had to try it.  Wow! So creamy and delicious! No sugar or sweetener needed.  Couldn't finish it cuz I was too full but will be back here soon!  This is now one of my favorite Bay Area coffee shops :)
author: Monica J.

description: eh, just over-priced coffee in a crowded cafe.  nothing special at all
author: Jackie A.

description: Come here all the time because it's my favorite coffee in the city.  Love the coffee bar. Service is usually always on point.  Really been fading fast though the last few times.  Need to bring back Brad, think that's his name.  Chick working today was very rude.  Had to wait 23 minutes for my coffee with attitude.  Hopefully the service picks back up because it's the best coffee in the city.
author: Mj D.

description:
I know the review I'm about to write is a bit controversial, but it is just my opinion! Four Barrel is the best place in SF, and maybe in the bay area, to get a latte for me. Blue Bottle and Ritual are all fine and good at what they do, but I slightly prefer the taste of Four Barrel.

Let's start with the price. I pay $6 for a latte here. It's normally $5, but it's an extra $1 for almond milk (which they make in-house). I normally don't spend this much on coffee, but will make the exception if I am in the area and feeling especially tired. From what I can tell from the menu, there are no bigger sizes available, which is fine with me. I don't understand getting a large latte, because it will eventually get cold before I can finish it. 

Service here is a fast and efficient. The baristas are not perky and outgoing like the ones at Philz, but they are nice and mellow. Depending on the time you go, it can get pretty crowded. I personally like sitting in the back and watching the roasting process in action, but it's also not a bad place to people-watch. It seems like all kinds of people come in here! The decor of this place is pleasing to the eyes too. I dig the rustic feel they have going on with the taxidermy.

Basically, this third wave coffee movement is the best thing to happen to my sleep-deprived self.
author: Karen R.

description: First time coming here after looking for a coffee shop while I was in the city. The cappuccino was rich in flavor and delicious! Great ambiance and the staff are very nice. Definitely will come come again.
author: Sandra R.

description:
