I am a legitimate coffee snob, especially coming from Australia and getting to go to Melbourne a lot. I usually find myself disappointed with most of the coffee served to me in the USA so was somewhat apprehensive when I crossed the threshold of Four Barrel Coffee.
It seems my fears were legitimately unfounded, this is honestly some of the best coffee I have ever sampled and one of the most delicious Almond Milk Iced Lattes I've ever consumed!
I really liked the separate coffee bar where they have a fresh run of beans every week ordered in from all parts of the globe!
If you can get over the hipster vibe and deal with coffee snobs like myself you will fall totally in love with this amazing place!
author: Leah M.

description:
An Ok taste of coffee. 
Personally I am a little bit picky in choosing the right coffee and sometimes I ask questions. This time the barista didn't know anything about the coffee he was making. Which shouldn't be a problem for most of the customers.
author: Endri M.

description: Took the Espresso & Milk course taught by Brett a few weeks ago. Learned a lot and now am excited to be setting up my own in home Espresso Bar. Brett has been beyond helpful, knowledgeable and enthusiastic in helping me select the right equipment (which they don't sell!) looking forward to the Coffee class in a few weeks!
author: Selin K.

description:
What a funky little place, in a good way. Tucked away off a busy street and next to a tiny hillside park, this Four Barrel has a great little (hipster) hole in the wall vibe.

If you've visited any Four Barrel before then you already know the coffee is legit but you come to this one for the amazing wood paneling ceiling, the two large garage doors that are rolled up on a nice day, the freshly cut spring flowers on the large wooden tables. 

You don't come here, however, for the pour over coffee (they don't do pour over) or for the restrooms (nope, no restrooms either). Lack of made-for-you-right-then coffee and potty area aside, the espresso drinks are still incredible and the almond butter toasts are to die for. 

If you're a Four Barrel fan, I would recommend stopping by this location for a new experience and setting.
author: Lori T.

description:
The first time I came in here, I felt conspicuous.  The mission vibe is pretty fierce here, & I've never been accused of looking very "mission."  

Probably because I don't.  

Because I was on my way to work, I was wearing a dress w heels.  I don't have any tattoos.  And I don't have anything pierced except for my earlobes.  So, I really didn't fit in, & consequently I didn't feel like I fit in.  

But I didn't let that bother me.  And the next couple of times I came in I forgot all about it.  I'm here for only one thing, & one thing only.

Good coffee.

I love that there's both soy & almond milk in the house.  I love the record player in the corner.  I love all the wood.

But, in addition to the line to order, there's always a big wait for your beverage.  The line can go quick, but there's still a long wait for your drink.  

Sigh.

This city is full of fantastic, artisan coffee.  So understandably it's a combination of other contributing factors that will dictate which venue you choose.

If I'm on this side of Valencia, it's fine.  But I'd rather hit Ritual several blocks further down.  

3 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description:
A pretty hipster, modern spacious place to do some work (but it does get packed). The staff is very friendly and there's metered parking nearby that's convenient, if you want to pay.

Coffee wise, I ordered the classic iced coffee, which was bold and refreshing - however, the prices here are a bit up there, but then again, you're paying for the quality, just like Philz. There is free wifi and a decent number of tables to catch up with a friend or to do some work.

Perhaps next time I should try a hot coffee, to see if it tastes as bold as the iced coffee.
author: Cheri C.

description: Good coffee. The Nitro Coffee is quite interesting, if too sour for my tastes. It's a nice, quiet spot to sit down, though it's very large & blessed with a great deal of natural light. Regrettably, there are no electrical outlets, so you can't charge your laptop.
author: John L.

description: Bradley at the pour over barista counter was awesome! His passion for Four Barrel Coffee was something I was thankful to experience. His descriptions of each distinct roast was incredible and detailed. The vibe in this place is amazing. Warm feel when you walk in, people are hanging out, on laptops working, enjoying coffee over conversations. They take their coffee game very seriously. Took home a 12oz whole bean pack of their Ethiopia Qorema--a wonderful everyday, anytime coffee that was roasted in house 2 days before my purchase. Enjoy!
author: Dimitri R.

description: Four Barrel coffee is the definition of a hipster (or bougie?) coffee shop in the mission - and I'm not gonna lie, I love it. I went at 1 pm on a weekday so it was almost empty - service was super quick and the baristas were really nice. The place itself is spectacular - complete with a roastery inside the shop (yes, they roast their own beans). I had an iced mocha which was delicious - not too sweet and you could definitely taste the coffee. It was a little bit pricey but that is to be expected from this kind of place in the mission. I also loved that they don't have a modern sound system but place actual records on a record player!
author: Sam M.

description: A casual get together cafe with easy access bike racks, indoor and outdoor seating. Tasty coffee, definitely going to try the slow bar next time!
author: Victor C.

description:
Still, the most solid cappuccino by far. With almond milk! Tasted absolutely delicious.

Also got the Everything Croissant ($4) today, which changed everything about croissants. The amount of fluff and air in there, so light, so delicious, yet none of that buttery finger grease afterwards. Totally overpriced as always, but worth saving a couple of dollars for :)

Still no wifi and bad reception in the cafe though :( but I'm guessing it's purposeful.
author: Maggie G.

description:
Everything i had envisaged when it comes to SF coffee places. Laid back, grungey, kinda hipster (without being nauseatingly so), rock music, large open space plastered in wood. Coffee was good, not amazing but certainly nothing to complain about. 

Nothing much of value to add to the other reviews. All in all just a great place to whittle away a few hours working/people watching/reading the paper.
author: Tommaso S.

description:
I love Four Barrel! I wish I lived locally, because I would come here all the time. 

Loved the space and the people were super friendly, but the most important thing: The coffee was EXCELLENT. 

My guy and I both ordered the latte with almond milk (which is made in house!) and they were perfection. The milk was steamed perfectly and the flavor was on point!
We also ordered a chocolate rose doughnut and a chocolate croissant and they too were amazing. 

I could do without the animal heads on the wall (I will never understand why people like this look), but I go for the coffee and not the decor, after all. 

You should go!
author: Paige H.

description:
What a gem this place is! Located in the Mission District close to Castro/Lower Haight, Four Barrel is one of the best coffee shops you'll find in San Francisco!

I highly recommend their affogato, scoops of vanilla ice cream topped with espresso. Very delicious treat!
author: Brandon B.

description: Tastefully decorated, clean, and spacious coffee shop! Unfortunately they don't offer free wifi but if you're looking for a place to chat or perhaps work on some offline work, this is the perfect place! Opens relatively late for a coffee shop as well which is a plus :)
author: Mandy H.

description: Let your neurons form this image:  an image that is more similar to a sensation.  You might be  intringued  now  by the ancestors of tall forests as they invite you in.  So you recline on one.  You breathe in the rythmic aroma.  And you think to yourself , "I don't want to  Feel  So  Happy"  , but a waterfall pulls you in and starts to make your soul  tingle  intensely  into the fertile ground.
author: Godric G.

description: Recommended by my frnd ,a day i want there withmy bf to grab a cup of coffee.we ordered hot coffee for both of us. the sitting space was airy and with wooden interior.it was a calm and quite place to have a converaation over a coffe with someone.jst the thing which was missing was table service..
author: Eva G.

description:
I've been a little disappointed with their coffee here more than once now. Most recently I got an almond milk latte -- the taste was off; harsh and bitter in an unusual way, it was grainy, and... I can't believe how petty I sound. Thing is, each coffee costs like a lesser meal, so I don't think it's unreasonable to expect objectively great coffee.

Yes, it's a nice place to be; looks amazingly hipstery and whatnot, I just think it's a little overrated. I like the coffee two blocks away at Noman better.
author: Mattis E.

description: Nice open industrial vibe place with great coffee and pastries.  Good peripheral seating and outside parklet. Music playing inside.
author: John L.

description:
Atmosphere 5 out of 5
Service 5 out of 5
Coffee 5 out of 5
Presentation 4 out of 5

I had an early happy hour/dinner nearby and decided to stop by this coffee shop based on ratings and pictures on Yelp. I am a big coffee drinker so I am always out looking for the best coffee in the city. Walking into the coffee shop, I was shocked by the nicely decorated coffee shop. I enjoyed the big window panels by the door with tables for people to work on. On top of the tables are creative lighting that are made out of very thick ropes. Behind register/coffee area, there is a big machine and very open area. The place have plenty of seating, which is great for groups of people as well as individual that wants to come here and work. If there are no seatings inside, there are plenty of public parklets outside with tables and chairs that you can sit at within the block. The noise level isn't too loud but it isn't silent either. You can here little conversations here and there. The noise level is low enough for you to clearly hear the music playing in the coffee shop. The music is the best part. As vinyl makes a comeback, this is one of the few coffee shop that I have seen so far that uses vinyl, which gives off a nicer sound and helps people like me focus on my work while enjoying the music.

As I was waiting for my coffee, I asked the barista what kind of machine is behind the register/coffee area. The barista was very nice and told me that the machine was actually how they used to roast their coffee before opening a bigger facility in Oakland, and inform me about events that take place on the weekends at this location. On Saturdays and Sundays of every week, there are coffee roasting events where guest can go to the back and get a viewing. The event is from 12 PM to 1:30 PM. I will be sure to check it out as I really enjoy coffee and learning how good coffee comes about.

Coming here, I got the Affogato as I was in the mood for both ice cream and coffee. My first bite into the affogato was amazing. The texture from the ice cream mixed with mini coffee beans gives it a sweet and bitter taste, finished off with the coffee as the sauce. I enjoy my coffee very strong and bitter and the affogato definitely nailed it for me. 

As far as the presentation goes, it would have given a 3 out of 5 since it is similar to all of the other coffee shops in town. However, I gave it a 4 out of 5 because if you drink your coffee there, your coffee comes in ceramic cup and saucer, which makes it very interesting and unique. The cup is round but it is not perfectly round as it have edges that doesn't give it the true round feel.

Overall, I would rate this place a 5 out of 5 for the great atmosphere, good service, amazing coffee and presentation.
author: Chenny O.

description:
I should have known it wasn't a place to study with the loud music when I walked in. I don't understand how a coffee shop doesn't have WiFi. Major bummer. 
The regular black coffee is overpriced, but the muffin was great!
author: Brent J.

description:
Love 3rd wave. 
Walking by here, i couldn't miss this great smell. I like the taste and the place here. It's mix of a museum and warehouse. So many arts on the wall and pretty interior. Also there is huge factory machines on the back. You can definitely enjoy both here.
author: Nazuki Y.

description:
I love Four Barrel and this store. Coming to Valencia st, this is the best coffee shop in the area. Four Barrel's coffee suits everyones palate. It's not too acidic and brings a nice earthy and light smoke to the tongue. 

I love the decor here. The hogs on the walls, the cabin-like feel, and the small wooden seating for customers. The outside seating is amazing too with it's lounge stool seating over seeing the streets. 

The baristas here are no joke. They are friendly but most importantly they are on point. They are focused and have an amazing work ethic. I didn't see anyone slacking off or having "off-time" which is great. The coffee is also roasted in-house for customers to witness. 

I ordered a macchiato which was held by their dark grey clay espresso cups. I love their dish set here as well! The clay cups and saucers compliment the atmosphere. 

It felt like a nice cold winter evening with lots of people standing around having the perfect time with their coffees. One of the best coffee sessions I've had in a long time. I loved every bit of it.
author: Allister D.

description: No surprise everyone is obsessed with this hipster af coffee shop along Valencia. Clearly they have design down, reigning in their big game meets authentic roaster vibe. Tables and chairs line the walls with viewing access to both the sexy barista men and roasting process in the back. Staff is extremely nice and well versed on cafe knowledge as we all have come to expect. Music is cool but too loud for a coffee house. Also no wifi....booo. Coffee is bold and strong and fabulous.
author: Alanna A.

description: One of my fav Bay Area roasters... with a great location, wide open polished concrete floors with views of the roasters... the coffee is excellent as well which is why we are all here... so come enjoy the space and the coffee... maybe take an outdoor seat in the parklet... it's a worthy coffee stop...
author: Reg B.

description: The coffee is great! They roast and brew on site. BUT I was terribly offended by the decorations. They have four boar heads on the wall together with a Buddha representation. I think this is very inappropriate.
author: Simon B.

description:
Coffee - great. I ordered an Americano with almond milk. A slight touch of bitterness, some acidity, and some nutty sweetness to top it all off. 

Interior - bad. Terrible, limited communal seating. If you tilted your laptop screen back, you'd be invading someone's personal space. Would it really kill your aesthetic to put in some more seats?? No wifi, either.
author: Patricia Z.

description:
Great coffee but it's pretty pricey. The place is large with beautiful decorations and a nice atmosphere. There's a huge roaster in the back too. They get really crowded on weekends so you might need to take your cup to go.

The latte ($5) was good but nothing special compared to other coffee shops in the area in my opinion.
author: Linda X.

description: Great coffee and even better service. Try the affogato (espresso + vanilla ice cream) Thanks Titan and Vincent. Ask Vincent for a cappuccino, his art is impeccable.
author: TravelingHungry ..

description: This is my favorite coffee shop in the Mission. Bright, lively atmosphere. Nice staff. Plus they have the prettiest bathroom floor I've ever seen. Go see for yo'self.
author: Tracy R.

description: This place is like always busy... I stopped by with some of my college roommates to catch up over coffee, we had a hard time finding a table inside so we opted for the parklet that's right outside. This place is super hip... as per usual for the SF scene these days. There are two counters - the pour over bar and the regular register with a simple coffee menu. I got an affogato and a toffee chip cookie... sugary overload, just the way I like it. I'm usually pretty sensitive to caffeine so this affogato hit me pretty hard, the cookie was also very delicious. They don't have wifi, so don't count on getting much work done here unless you can work offline.
author: Elaine N.

description:
We toured our foreign friends around the area and stumbled upon this place.  For a suburban  guy, this place is expensive!  $6 I think for a soy milk latte.  It was good but I'd maybe pay $3 for it, not $6.  This place is definitely for people that work in the area or live nearby that can afford coming here.

Regardless of price, the quality of the latte I tried was great.   I saw this machine/coffee mixing thing in the back, so I guess they freshly grind coffee and do coffee stuff from scratch?  That's cool.  As you can see I'm not really a coffee person and don't have much knowledge about it.  But this place is worth checking out if you got the monies.
author: Gabriel D.

description:
To update my review, I've given up on Four Barrel. It's a great atmosphere, cool everything, but- the coffee went from hit or miss to mostly miss. I even did the slow bar. The taste of coffee is really important to me.

What is ironic is the bathroom. They say the bathroom is for everyone, meaning any gender, including transgender. But then they say it's only for customers! Which means they are customerists!  JK, but hey, the irony.

I wish they had better tasting coffee.
author: Jane S.

description: The quintessential hipster mission coffee stop. Come for the coffee stay for the taxidermy! Not a great place to set up with a laptop "though I've seen it done" their standouts are their espresso - their pastries from B Patisserie and the overall vibe. You might feel less hip when walking in but you'll feel more hip as you leave!
author: Justin S.

description: Awesome coffee and a nice variety of pastries! Ambience is very hip.  The milk they used in the latte  was super creamy.  I never tasted milk like that.  I deducted one star because The only downside is that there is a different line (separated section) exclusively and only for slow drIp coffee; so if you are getting your drip coffee and another  different item (I got a latte, donut and drip coffee) you have to do two lines and thats to waiting times.  Not good if you are in a hurry and the place is packed.   The employees are very nice and knowledgeable.  I would recommend this place.
author: Y C.

description: Let me start by saying the coffee is delicious and great selection too. This might sound weird but I think they have the most cool bathroom I've seen at a coffee store. Fast staff!
author: Marc P.

description: Great place, looks amazing, always clean. Simple and affective menu with a great atmosphere. My only complaint is how long it takes to get your actual order SOMETIMES, usually because the person making it, is too busy chit chatting. That aside, I love the coffee and their baked goods.
author: Erikk G.

description: Had a cappuccino. Tasted light and a little fuller than other ones I've had. Pastries are good. The place is beautiful but I didn't enjoy the vibe. It's hard to find a seat and felt really pretentious.
author: Elaine C.

description: Not all espressos are perfectly poured so you don't always get the same quality. It was quite good but not my favorite. They also have a tasting bar for different beans.
author: Connor D.

description: Being Australian, I have high expectations on what a good espresso should taste like. Four Barrel definitely delivers and reminds me of an espresso I would get back home. Anyone who is a coffee snob like me, you should check this place out, you won't be disappointed!
author: Charlotte H.

description: Always fab place to have coffee in sf .. there ambiance and staff both were awesome nice neighborhood.. love to dwell have sip of nice cappuccino they had good selection of pastries!!
author: raja g.

description: Fave coffee spot in SF.  Good service, nice environment, great coffee most of all.
author: Rodney P.

description: My latte was extremely satisfying. The taste and presentation go hand in hand, I felt like i was in heaven drinking my latte. Im giving 3 stars because they don't offer wifi and their seating configuration needs work. A lot of space is wasted and it feels socially odd, like a cafeteria or something. At least offer paid wifi.
author: Matt T.

description:
I honestly love this place.
I wish I had the time to actually sit down and enjoy the atmosphere here, but every time I've come here for coffee, it's been in a rush.

I always order their almond milk cappuccino and it is good. I'm definitely someone who prefers my coffee on the bitter side, however, and I wish that was the case, as mine are always a bit sweet for my preference.
But then again, I really need to spend some quality time here so I can make all these extra requests and just enjoy my coffee!
author: Chelsey C.

description: Great coffee, excellent and informative service combined in a great space with good tunes. I was impressed by the turntable that attached to a tube type McIntosh amplifier. Neat touch!
author: Rick L.

description:
In all fairness, I'm not anywhere near hipster enough for a place like this. I'm a simple girl who likes her coffee hot and full of flavor. I don't need art. I don't need to be told why I'm ordering coffee wrong and not getting 'the best experience'. It's coffee folks. It's not going to change your life.

Anyway, I ordered whatever it was that the person told me I should get (Because when in Rome...do what they tell you or you will be judged severely), and it tasted good. But it was warm. Not hot. Maybe that's the ultimate temperature to experience all the flavors. But I wasn't a fan. I may not know a lot about the recently emerged intricacies of coffee, but I know I like it hot. Also..the art...I'm not quite sure what it was supposed to be, but it looked a little on the phallic side. Am I wrong? I mean, if that's what it was supposed to be that's fine, but if not I'm a little confused...
author: Kari E.

description:
Yes I'm a Coffee Addict with a capital "A" and I've run across yet another cool hipster coffee shop in SF. This one serves rock solid espresso delights and has a very unique barista area complete with a record player. Some of you young'uns might have to google what that is.

The space although somewhat dimly lit is airy and spacious. Seating is somewhat respectable and service comes with a caffeinated smile.

 If you love coffee anywhere remotely as much as I do, you will do yourself a favor and check them out.
author: Dennis W.

description: Searched up the #1 coffee spot in SF for a spur of the moment trip and saw their amazing reviews! I ordered their latte with in house almond macadamia milk and boy did I taste it! Cute heart created on top of my drink to add the love. The service was speedy even with the amount of people there on a Saturday 3pm and great City weather!
author: May A.

description: I went on a Sunday and ordered iced latte with almond milk. The milk was homemade with almonds and cashews and you can even see them in the bottom. There was a line of approx 10 people but it moved on very quickly. It was kind overpriced for me. The cup was like 12oz and costs me$5 with an extra $1 for almond milk.
author: Ziyi W.

description: I love going to coffee shops. I've tried Four Barrel coffee ice cream from Tin Pot Creamery in Palo Alto so wanted to give this place a try since we were in the city. I always get lattes. The lattes here are very good. Rich, dark, and almost caramel-y. They have a separate bar area for pour overs. The space is huge. Rustic and hipster-y? Service was okay, not overtly friendly, but it was
author: Susan K.

description: I've been coming here on and off for a few years now, mostly because it's pretty close to where i work. The place has a great design and love the fact that they usually feature some kind of art from time to time. Do they have the best coffee? No. Do the make the best pastries or desserts? Not really, but if you are not fussy and don't mind the occasional attitude served as a side with your order then all should be well. They make good tea though, fair is fair so yeah there's that!
author: Sophia V.

description:
I love Four Barrel SO MUCH and would be lost without it.  I literally have nothing negative to say, so here's all the positive:

(1) Almond Macadamia Milk - they house-make this, and it is ah-mazing.  A lot of almond milks and almond milk "products" (I'm lookling at you, Starbucks) are kind of watery and burnt.  This has so much depth and natural sweetness.  It makes the absolute best almond latte that I've ever had.

(2) Local Art - I love their constantly rotating local art collection!  Great to support the community :)

(3) Pastries - I don't know who supplies their pastries, but they're SO GOOD.  The everything croissant is ridiculous, and the vegan chocolate donut is one of the best donuts I've had anywhere.

(4) Prices - More than Starbucks, but not by much.  Definitely in the ballpark by San Francisco standards.

(5) Seating - Love the outdoor seating area.  Not sure if that was a City or Four Barrel initiative, but it's fantastic.

Weekends that I can't make it here make me sad :(  It's the best!
author: Tay H.

description: GET THE AFFOGATO IT IS AMAZING. Being Italian an working at an Italian restaurant this is by far the best affogato iv ever had. Mugs are rad and creative. Coffee changes every monthish but the bean are nothing but fresh and have great taste. You will not be disappointed coming here. Baristas are the best and give sooo much information about coffee in you are addicts like we are.
author: Angel M.

description:
Ridiculous to charge an extra $1 for the ONLY milk alternative option. 
And why is it taking a year to make an iced almond mac latte?! There's nobody here!
Also, the veggie quiche is super gross.
What a waste of $12 for this terrible four barrel trip.
author: Brooke F.

description: Very cute and cool coffee shop! You can smell the coffee being roasted as you walk up to the store. The macchiato was delicious and combined well with the croissant.
author: Hector S.

description: Camille at the pour over bar is arrogant, righteous, and a big a-hole. This time it was her but there have been others in the past. Camille gave me a sample and I asked her if there was a less bitter coffee for purchase. She just replied, "it's not bitter". Ok?"
author: Zorayr K.

description:
The most amazing single pour coffee I've had in a long long time. When you enter, go hard left to get the single pour fresh brew method. 

The brew lady was very polite, very beautiful in all respects. She made great recommendations and carefully poured while measuring temps and water volumes. Like chemistry procedure.

Result was a super tasty tasty non acidic cup of smoothness. This is coffee!

Must visit here again. Must. Yes, it is terribly hipster but also fun and positive and dedicated to the art of coffee. Methinks it beats Philz and even blue bottle.
author: tony z.

description:
Nice hip decor. Pretty large place. Good amount of seating. 

Service was good. Dog friendly.

Almond Latte - $4.50 + $.50 - Nutty and creamy latte. Comes with some milk art.

Coffee - $3 - Fresh and smooth black coffee. 

Prices are pretty steep but very good.
author: Kevin W.

description:
Big time coffee lover. First time customer and it won't be my last. I love the shop. Everything about this place is a coffee lover/Hipster dream. 

It gets crowed (I went on a Sunday afternoon) and street parking is tough to find. If you're looking for wifi, Good luck, you find it here. This place is strictly for good conversation and good coffee. 

Inside they have a huge coffee bar and bar specifically pour overs. (I told you it's a coffee lovers dream). We got the mocha Lattes with the house made macadamia almost milk. Gosh, I can still taste it, it tastes like "MORE"! I also recommend getting the maple bacon donut.

Their cups and dishes are completely unique, made with ceramic clay. Next time I'm going to try one of their pour overs.
author: Anthony R.

description:
Four Barrel is a fantastic coffeeshop to start your day in the Mission. They have a slow coffee bar with pourover options as well as quick cups of coffee, espressos...you name it!

My wife is obsessed with Four Barrel coffee ever since bringing some beans back to the east coast. I've since tried to replicate the roast she had with limited success. It just hasn't been as smooth as the first time she's got it. Nevertheless, this is a great coffee shop and I make it a point to stop in here for a cup of joe whenever I'm in the Mission in SF.
author: Alex L.

description: Came here for some Affogato. Nothing like icecream in espresso on an unusually hot day in SFO. And nothing like four pigs mounted on the wall of a coffeehouse! I think just knowing that its also a brewery makes the affogato taste even better!
author: Dhiraj P.

description:
Cool hipster stop. 

Had an americano. It was strong, but they had no artificial sweeteners. 4 stars. Would try something else next time
author: Jenny V.

description:
I happened to drop by on Four Barrel Coffee's 9th anniversary, so the place was swirling with preparations--e.g., for decor, a free photo booth, and even a farm animal petting zoo.  What's more, all coffee that was only $1, including coffee from their slow bar!

The slow bar's baristas were very knowledgeable and gregarious.  They were happy to answer our questions, no matter how basic.  Most importantly, the slow bar's coffee was very good.
author: Bobby Z.

description: Their coffee is very good but their bathroom is absolutely disgusting. Urine all over the seat and floor, No toiletpapers, smells awful. In Japan, there is a saying, if you want to see the true value of the business, look at their bathroom.
author: Miho B.

description: Cool vibes abound in this warehouse-style open space that links the sitting area with coffee-prep station and big coffee grinder in the back. The art on the walls is unique and dare I say bizarre. I would even call the metal bike storage lining the front sidewalk, art. This place is totally hip, with a laid back vibe. And yes their coffee is superior as well.
author: Zena B.

description: Okay fine!  I listened to the in crowd and gave this place a whirl. The iced coffee here is pretty dang decent. The staff is hella nice and educated about coffee. And the espresso is so good I just wanted 5 shots to myself - but I didn't because then I'd be super crazy all day!  The surrounding neighborhood is a little sketchy for those of you unfamiliar with SF.
author: Kristin H.

description: So I'm reviewing this as if I actually drank the coffee/tea here but my friend did so I'm going off his review which was pretty good. The reason I didn't actually drink my tea here is probably going to make my top 5 list of embarrassing moments list. So, I ordered my tea and then proceeded to go add sugar and there I was, in front of this unlabeled jar with an amber-tinted fluid and some spoons inside. I figure, "oh, this must be simple syrup...so hipster of them!" I then took a few spoonfuls of this fluid and put it in my tea and walked back to my table. As I was sitting down about to take a sip, I noticed similar jars on this side of the cafe and to my horror, I noticed that people would use a spoon in the empty jar, mix their coffee/cream/sugar, and then discard the spoon in the amber-tinted jar of water. I immediately looked around and realized that I did NOT put simple syrup into my tea, I just put a watered down mixture of probably hundreds of people's coffee into my herbal tea. I awkwardly sat there with my friend who was enjoying his untainted coffee while I caressed my teacup harboring hundreds of licked spoon germs. I'm going to blame my starbucks-limited coffeshop etiquette on this mistake and not the actual cafe (who maybe should label the dirty jar with something, but...I'm probably the only one this happened to [knowingly at least]).
author: Wade C.

description:
Stopped in over here after getting off the 16th St Mission BART station on a random hunt for Moon Cake in the Mission. Don't ask. 

The coffee here is legit and at $5 for a latte, it launches the prices right on par with all the other cool, hipster coffee spots around SF. It comes with some pretty latte art and is a darn good brew. For the coffee alone, it'd be 5-stars.

Minus 1 star = Service was a little slow considering I was the only one in line .and still managed to catch four pokemon, traipsed by three pokestops, and came back to find that my latte still wasn't ready.

Minus 1 more star = ..I was not a fan of the maple bacon donut. There was a bit of a sour after-taste from the dough. Not sure if maybe the donut had just been sitting around too long, or if its supposed to taste like that.

Definitely come for the coffee if you have some time, or if you're looking for a good place to bunker down and study/work. Plenty of seating and tables!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
This place slays lattes to perfection effortlessly. It is good to see that one shop is still flying the consistency of perfection flag high since my last visit about 4 years ago. Had an almond milk latte w their house made almond milk, 4.5/5. This place might join my US top 3 establishments for lattes - Joe out of NY, La Colombe out of Philly and now representing SF.

The staff is super friendly, they walk around with an ease almost contradictory to the stone faced lab rat baristas in most other highbrow establishments. Yet their execution is flawless - the steaming of milk, the right ratio of it to espresso and a not too shabby latte art. 

The space feels like a barn that a lot of coffee shops would covet but not emulate without looking like they tried too hard. 

But ultimately it's about that silky, light as a cup of cotton of latte which upon touching the lips convinces you that in your palm lies an ephemeral libation of sensual pleasure beaming with taste and aroma to take your mind to a place far away from your mundane routines. 

Keep it up guys!! Rootin for your long lasting success.
author: Bharat W.

description: This is one of the most famous places for coffee. There are always a lot of people here, but the line moves fast. There is also a place for outdoor recreation. A great place for an accidental collision of neighbors. Coffee is delicious and strong. A great place, I love it.
author: Sarah W.

description: Great coffee, nice  people, good  music in the background.  Best place of coffee and chill.
author: Jose Luis U.

description: This might be my favorite coffee shop I've ever been to, to date-and I've been to shops all over the world. From their big open layout, their decor, the various brew methods, the product packaging, barista knowledge....everything about this place screams elegance and excellence. I ordered an iced coffee black, as I usually do-along with the baristas choice on a bag of beans to use with my Aeropress. He suggested a Colombian bag of the Lucas Melo-which is currently fueling this wordy review. I can't wait until the next time I have a few hours to kill in San Francisco, because I will definitely be returning to spend time in this coffee lovers paradise. Good job-keep up the good work. This place is what true coffee lovers dream of.
author: Steve S.

description: In spite of the decades I have spent drinking coffee, this place reminds me how little I know. Thankfully the baristas are nice enough to provide some education while making your coffee, even when it is busy, which is always. The cafe is always bustling (think the sounds from the Noisli/Coffitivity apps) and has a nice ambiance. This is a great place to meet friends, but places to sit might be hard to come by.
author: Benita P.

description: Really enjoyed the coffee and atmosphere. At first it seemed like a long line but it moved quickly. We got the cappuccino which was a perfect blend and a sweet pastry that really complimented the coffee. Would come back again!
author: Adrienne C.

description: The coffee was okay but so overpriced. And it wasn't even hot! On the bright side they had free cookies to sample! And the inside is very cozy, warm, and inviting!
author: Samantha C.

description: Four Barrel's coffee speaks for itself. If you're looking for delicious, high caffeine coffee - this is the spot! That said, it's probably not the best place to come if you're trying to get work done as it is loud, crowded and there's no Wifi. I made this mistake once and that was all I needed to learn it is not a place to post up and do work. But if you're looking to get lit off of caffeine and catch up with friends, go go go!
author: Natasha B.

description:
This is my favorite spot in San Francisco. Fuckin great coffee, dank pastries, friendly staff. Great place to vibe out and catch up with friends on the weekend.
4 blocks from my house makes this place my daily addiction!
author: Sam L.

description: Four Barrel apparently competes with Blue Bottle and Philz for best coffee in San Francisco (the world?). It's telling that "hipster" is one of the three most mentioned descriptors of this place. It indeed feels like the epicenter of that aesthetic. Although probably hundreds of miles from the nearest hunter or taxidermist, trophy heads are mounted here alongside local art. And while the activity here is decidedly post-industrial, the rough, dark woods, exposed rafters, and stained concrete flooring evoke a 19th century workshop, and not of the coffee-roastery sort. Another nod to the 19th century is their lack of WiFi and power outlets, which encourages older, more communal modes of coffee drinking. Come here if you're serious about coffee and vinyl records, not your telecommute. The drip house-roasted coffee was good, as were the baked goods.
author: David L.

description: Over priced coffee for a place without WiFi access, it's 2017, my grandmother has wifi. The roast is ok, but  nothing special. Your paying for the pretentiousness of it all. The staff is friendly.
author: Juan C.

description: Great place to grab a coffee and you can get the fancy stuff or a regular old coffee.  I went for a cold brew and was not disappointed!  The decor in this place is spot-on as well.
author: Sara M.

description:
A good spot to stop for a consistently good cup of espresso or coffee. 
The prices are fair and Usually the customer service is good, Though you'll find the random apathetic tattooed people who couldn't bear to say Hi or Thanks or even look at you with less than a grimace.
author: Carl O.

description:
Attempted to grab an iced coffee on a Saturday evening . . . Which, to be fair, is not prime coffee time. Unfortunately, the barista told me that the "iced coffee machine" was being repaired. She offered an iced americano instead. I can't stand americanos, iced or otherwise, so ummmmmmed for a few seconds and then asked for an iced latte.

No production issues on the latte, which was excellent. The best bit is that the barista gave me the iced latte on the house, which was so sweet of her!

Had the service not been so stellar and the coffee not so great, I would probably not return. The music was bizarrely loud, so this really isn't a place to study or work. Plus, the drinks are pretty pricy. BUT return I will, because that iced coffee really was great.
author: Kat C.

description:
Cool spot... But did I really just pay like $7 ($6 and change + $1 tip) for a latte?! And then wait like 10 minutes to receive it... It was pretty yummy, but not $7 and change yummy. 

I requested nonfat milk, but was told they only have whole milk and almond milk (which is an additional $1). He mentioned they make the almond milk in house, so if you like that I recommend trying it. I'm not the biggest fan, so I went with whole (and saved myself from an $8 and change latte). 

Both the guy taking my order and the one making my drink were really friendly. They both asked about my day, and the one making the drink apologized it was taking so long, in addition to making it really pretty. 

There's a few tables and a couple bar areas inside, and a gorgeous outdoor bar area (+ lots of bike parking). Great high ceilings and industrial feel. The ambiance (even though it's hard to find seats) is pretty lovely if you've got good company or an interesting book. No wifi, of course. 

I've had their drip coffee and really enjoyed it.  Overall though, it's a cool spot with over priced (but quality) coffee. Definitely wouldn't make this my regular spot, but recommend giving it a go, or especially buying their beans and brewing it yourself.
author: Angela F.

description:
Four Barrel is definitely a stop for me if I'm in the area.  Really dig the espresso here and I'm a fan of the iced lattes.  

Yes it's super hipster, but the crowd is pretty mixed.  Usually people are just hanging around and chatting.  Baristas are a bit arrogant especially if you do not know how to order your coffee.  Saw the guy taking the order did a small eye roll to the couple in front of me.  Eh.

I've tried a few pastries here.  Pretty sure the donuts are from Dynamo?  

The roasting area is right in the back and it is open so it's fun to just check it out also.
author: Duke C.

description: Absolutely love the coffee here.  Their lattes are amazing but also have a variety of drip coffee. The last time I ordered it did take about 15 minutes.
author: Emily K.

description:
This is probably one of the best (and definitely on the expensive side) of coffee shops I ever been to in SF in terms of the quality of third wave coffee. Fourbarrel makes their drinks REALLY good, where it makes you appreciate the roasting process and overall flavor of the coffee with no additives needed. If you aren't used to drinking this kind of stuff, it may be a little too bitter and strong for some. You can watch them behind the counter making the drinks and creating latte art perfect for the instagram-esque pictures.

I came here recently this past weekend and noticed they upped the prices of their drinks. A latte is now $5 when it used to be $4-4.50 and a mocha is $5.75. Looks like the cost of good coffee is going up as well as the cost of living in the city! Also almond milk is an additional $1 if you're going the non-dairy route.

I feel each time I came here, it's always been busy in the mornings to early-mid afternoons. Usually there's a line and all the seats are taken; tables and the counter in the very back which happens to be in front of the big coffee roasting area. The service here is very fast, efficient and friendly which I like, and they have two baristas behind the counter making drinks. I never tried any of their pastries, but from the looks of other pictures, they look pretty good! I usually come here on occasion if I'm in the area or when a friend is in town/hasn't been here before since it's pricey, but no regrets ever!
author: Kathleen S.

description: Good coffee still, but went to get a pastry and aborted as there were literally 20 tiny flys all over it. Guy didn't care, left it in there. Gross. I wouldn't eat here.
author: Russell S.

description:
Congratulations, Four Barrel. You've successfully pissed me off enough times that I will never be coming back even though I live down the street.

I used to be a barista and I know how much tips matter, so I used to always tip generously here, until I noticed that the baristas have never once thanked me, smiled at me, or even given me a proper reply when I'd confirm that a drink was mine to pick up.

Today was the last straw. I placed my order, carefully specifying TWICE that I needed room for almond milk. When the barista (curly haired young woman with glasses) put a drink on the counter that looked like my iced americano (as usual, I had to guess because I'm not worthy of a reply), there was no room for milk.

I asked her, "Could you please scoop out the ice to make some room?" She gave me the dirtiest look and dramatically scooped the cubes out one by one while shaking her head in disdain.

I said, "Thanks, can I have the almond milk?" She gave me even more attitude as she heavily placed the jug on the counter, as if to say, "HERE."

Guess what? I'm not an animal. I'm a human. Above that, I'm a customer and not even an unreasonable one. So start paying respect where respect is due. Or you're going to piss the hell out of all your customers. You've certainly do so with me.
author: Grace Y.

description:
I love Four Barrel Coffee. They have some interesting drinks on their menu for everyone to try. I ordered the goat's milk affogato and it was absolutely delicious. I was expecting the goat's milk ice cream to have a tart taste but it was surprisingly creamy and it complimented the coffee. My friend ordered an ice black coffee and it tasted great as well. Not too bitter but just right.

The interior of the space was nice and airy. I also loved their animal head fixtures on the wall, it added character to the place. The staff was friendly and helpful, service was fast as well. I loved the outdoor seating in their cute little wooden fixtures. You get a good view of Valencia Street while you're sipping your coffee.

I will definitely come back to Four Barrel Coffee every time I'm in The Bay.
author: Andrea S.

description: Mollie, Bobby, and the crew do a kick ass job of being the bad asses of coffee! Warm, friendly, helpful, and good at giving suggestions if needed. I went with the suggestion of a macchiato with a coffee chaser paired with the cheese and sauerkraut croissant. Best suggestion ever. Thanks guys.
author: Brian J.

description:
This is the most hipster place on planet earth.  So hipster, I felt like we were on a TV show of some sort because it was so unreal.  I'll admit though, the coffee was good.  

I spent $$$ for a latte made with almond macadamia nut milk from a lady who took my order with a meh attitude.  We sat in the parklette outside and people watched.  

I would have given it 3 stars but I bump it to 4 because actually, I do recommend coming here to visit- just to get the true hipster experience.
author: Lyn C.

description: Hipster coffee galore! What happened to just a good ol cup of joe? Why does it need to be so expensive? The lines were long, and I figured the coffee would be mind blowing. Not impressed. ENJOY!
author: Darlene Y.

description:
Non-coffee drinkers: They have tea here! YES! Can I get'a AMMMMEN! When I came here 3 years ago they didn't, so I'm glad they upgraded. It's not listed on their menu, but the side bar offers an oolong and herbal tea. I got the herbal tea for $3.81. It was a unique combination of lemongrass, rose, and ginger. Very soothing.

And I finally tried these kouign amann's pastries I keep seeing photos of. Sure is some buttery goodness for you. 

I like this place. It has indoor and outdoor seating; there's an open layout; you can do work or meet up with people, and there's an overall good vibe. Very hipster. Very Mission.
author: Joanna L.

description:
So I was visiting San Francisco for about a week and was in search of an amazing Coffee Shop.. I had been a bit disappointed to be honest until I finally made it to one I had bookmarked on Yelp, but didn't get to until my second to last day. Four Barrel Coffee was it. It was the coffee shop I was looking for.

The atmostphere here was amazing. The service was so great and the coffee?! The best I had during my whole trip. Smooth and delicious.

Another huge surprise was there banana chocolate scone. I'm not really a scone person - I honestly can't say if I've actually ever had on before this. But this scone was incredible! The perfect thing for breakfast to dip into your coffee, especially when it's delicious Four Barrel Coffee!

Seriously go here for their coffee and for that banana chocolate scone. You will not be disappointed!
author: Kerry H.

description: I definitely rate this cafe and that's coming from someone who lives in Melbourne (well known for it's amazing coffee). The fit out is huge and really cool, the roaster at the back is awesome and there are plenty of places to sit and just chill. Definitely would recommend to fellow Melbournians.
author: Weilynn T.

description:
The place I used to deem hipster coffee without the attitude, has seem to succomb to being like the rest.

I used to come in, and have lovely conversations with the baristas at the "slow bar" to discover what beans I should take home next. I enjoyed their passion, and the care they would take to guide me and share their opinions to discover something I would really enjoy.

I no longer work or live nearby, but I happened to be in the neighborhood and sought said experience that I remembered so dearly.

Unfortunately, My visit today wasn't so pleasant. It was a long line in the regular line, but only one other customer ahead of me in the "slow" bar to the left. When I get the attention of the barista, he tells me to let him know when I've decided, to which I told him I wanted to talk about the difference between two Kenya beans. He seemed hesitant to want to give me his time. I tell him I want something bold and he just says, "get this one" and goes about his business. This is a far departure from my previous experiences where nuances and details would be shared. He makes my coffee, and it's a good quality cup. But wasn't enough of a proper experience for me to purchase beans, which was my original intent. 

Maybe things have changed since my last visit over a year ago. My past experience with the slow bar was that it was a placed to slow down and truly take the time to discover the coffee, and not be treated like a grab and go customer.

Sorry, Four Barrel. It seems like Jeremy's original intent of providing great service along with their fantastic product is now lost. I will no longer be going out of my way to visit this location.
author: Ellis A.

description:
Another overrated "meh" establishment (like much of San Francisco to be honest).

The ambience is good and the pastries and coffee are delicious, but the prices are eye-popping. I admit that SF rents are probably the main reason for the inflated prices, but it still stings, especially when you tack on the cost of getting to downtown (Bay Bridge toll+parking or BART).
author: Thomas Y.

description: A great place to chill, and relax. Great coffee and hot cocoa. And if you are alone, I have a great suggestion for you to do and not feel alone: you can just watch that pig heads on the wall and enjoy the music maybe with a hot cocoa in your hand.
author: Paul Y.

description:
This is one of my favorite places for coffee in the city. It's hyped up for a reason because it will not disappoint. It can get super crowded since it is well-known, but trust me, it is worth it. It's kind of hard to find a seat, so I usually get my coffee and baked good and then peace out. It's got a cool vibe - kind of industrial, kind of minimal.

As for coffee, you can't go wrong with an almond milk latte here. It's a good blend of nutty and rich from the almond milk and the espresso. As for drip coffee, I really enjoy the Colombia Andino - I like the butterscotch.

Let me start a separate paragraph for the pastries. I discovered the best toffee chip cookies here and there was no turning back. They are from Anthony's Cookies down the street also on Valencia. I always get at least two or three when I come to Four Barrel because yes, they are that good. It's buttery and sweet and delicious. I have no shame and will finish all of them with my cup of coffee. The other pastries are also great - I have tried the kouign amann and the croissants, which also do not disappoint.

This is a long overdue review. As hyped up and crowded as Four Barrel can get every time you go there, it does not disappoint. Ever.
author: Steph V.

description:
I only give this place a star for the decor. $5 for a latte and I'm not joking when I say I've had better at Peets.
Overpriced and I was very surprised at how busy this place was for how terrible the drinks taste.
author: Cynthia G.

description:
I am coming to seriously dislike the parking situation in San Francisco. Really need to figure out an alternative. The parking spots on the street had been converted to a green space a portion of which is a seating area for this establishment.

Ordered the cafe mocha and it was very good. Coffee is not too strong for me.

Their hot chocolate is also very good.

If you are entertaining the idea of parking your laptop here and setting up your mobile office here for the day, make sure you are fully charged with portable external batteries because I could find NO power outlets on site.

The bathroom is large and nicely, eccentrically, decorated.

This cafe roast their coffee beans on site. And it is in full view of the customers. Very very cool and very very interesting.
author: Kislev A.

description: Sublime coffee. Beans this tasty don't need any sugar added! Efficient service. Great outdoor seating options in parklet on lively Valencia St. Delicious pastries, cookies, and doughnuts. Interesting art exhibits.
author: Sarah S.

description: Wow, this is expensive coffee!  People seem to love it, and I thought it was fine, but not as good as Starbucks.  Hardly any food choices.
author: Rob G.

description: This place simply has an amazing culture and vibe feel to it. Great place to sit down and work. Pour overs are the best
author: Chris M.

description:
I was going to a training around the area and I needed coffee to keep me up. I was happy to check this out since I've been never been. 
Great service, guy was engaging. 
Iced coffee... like I would expect, nice and strong! Definitely kept me up. 
banana chocolate scone was delish, not too sweet, good quality!
author: Claire J.

description: My favorite next to Dandelion, Craftman and Wolves, and Philz. Try their lattes and mocha
author: Fredo L.

description:
This place seems to be the spot or something
Very packed but there are seatings
Parking is a little difficult to find around here

Quick service. Chill and well lit place. Iced coffee is $4.00
author: Amy V.

description:
What is there not to love about this roaster house? From the decor, to the barista, and amazing coffee. My cappuccino is always....ALWAYS made to perfection! That's why its my favorite in the city for years. 

Expect a line at any given time. Fresh pastries and sweet outdoors seating.
author: Hanah P.

description: The atmosphere and pastries are great. Customer service was top notch. The coffee... terrible! I've been here 3 times (typically at the request of a friend) and each time the coffee tastes burned, super "earthy", and/or watered down. I've ended up throwing the cup out each time. Save your money.
author: Angela R.

description:
Looking for the nearest popular coffee shop, my friend and I stumbled upon Four Barrel Coffee. The ambiance and positive vibes were quite nice in this spacious coffee shop, as you can see people either working on their laptops peacefully or catching up with a friend, even as late as 7:00PM. However, like many other reviewers have stated, this place is definitely packed despite the large amount of space it offers - almost every table and stool was occupied and we kind of had to  stand around until a spot opened up.

For a nice coffee fix, my friend and I ordered two lattes together. She ordered a regular latte while I got a Mocha Latte. The latte art was definitely on point at Four Barrel Coffee and we received similar designs with some minor differences. As for the quality of the drinks, they were delicious as well. However, being the sweettooth that I am, I definitely had to add more creamer and sugar in my coffee, hah. Overall, I would definitely recommend Four Barrel Coffee as one of the nicest coffee shops to visit if you're ever visiting San Francisco.
author: Michelle S.

description:
Incredibly hipster coffee shop on Valencia. Four Barrel is an airy space with a modern industrial vibe, complete with bike decor on the street side seating (or maybe that was actually a customers vintage bike) and plenty of indoor seating to sip your beverage. They roast their own coffee in the back of the shop and have a separate coffee bar for pour overs if you're into that.   

I got my americano (delicious) and an artisan coconut donut (they're pastry selection looks amazing and included gluten free almond cake and strawberry Earl grey and maple bacon donuts). Great neighborhood coffee shop and I respect their respect for coffee.
author: Ruth M.

description: I am in love with their ceramic cups and of course their coffee. The only downside is that they don't have wifi. Their outdoor area is also cool to hang out!
author: Birce G.

description: Every single time I end up here, I curse myself for it: any corner store would be better-equipped than these guys: no pastry, no 0%, no 2%, no coconut milk- only almond milk for an extra buck! This is one of the worst, most overrated coffee places in San Francisco. Having said this all, there's one thing they'll give you plenty of: their attitude that only matches their notorious lack of options!!!
author: Alek K.

description: The decor is hipster industrial, so a cool place to hang out and work. Great parklet out front. But my cappucino was watery, I was underwhelmed.
author: Kate A.

description: Terrible treatment of female employees really leaves a bad taste in your mouth. Won't be going here again until the ownership restructures.
author: Mike G.

description:
First off, this place screams urban SF hipster. From the cool outdoor bike racks and outdoor patio to the interior light set up, this place is heaven for someone who has an eye for aesthetically appealing spaces.

I ordered from the pour over bar. Barista knew what he was doing when asked about brewing process and techniques, which made for an interesting conversation. 

Price was on par with other coffee roasters in the city, but what made this place so interesting was their roaster set up in the back. 

definitely take the time to witness how they roast their coffee. Very cool to see such processes inside their store.
Often pretty crowded so finding seats maybe a struggle.

The Rwanda Kanya had great body and balance. would come back for coffee and creative space!
author: Brian L.

description: Strong coffee.  More of the sour, harsh, bold taste.  If you need the caffeine, recommended. I personably prefer more of the smooth taste, and less acidic.
author: Gloria T.

description: Good place to visit by coffee lovers. Not crowed, spacious coffee shop. Need better bakery with coffee...
author: Sung H.

description:
Really hip space/vibes/coffee. They roast their own beans! They bag and sell their beans! AND there's a public restroooooom! Win's all around!

When I entered Four Barrel last Friday afternoon, I was quite hazy due to a severe case of food comatose. Despite my post-brunch lull, I was feeling QUITE spontaneous and asked my barista for a recommendation. He suggested that I try a "short Americano," which he explained was just an Americano with a little less water. I believe the cup that I got my beverage in was 8 oz! It was $3.25. The Americano was actually not the craziest thing that my barista-man could have suggested...in fact, it was not crazy at all...but he said that it was his favorite! 

AND FOR GOOD REASON!!! Thank you, BARISTA-MAN. 
I could really taste the cocoa notes in their roast! How awesome. I rarely take coffee black, unless it's iced-- and if I get it hot, I like a little bit of honey. BUT! This hot Americano did not require me to add anything extra. It hit the spot. 

P.S.- Clarion Alley is very close to Four Barrel! My friends and I accidentally stumbled upon it on our way to the car. I loved how there were so many new murals painted since I visited last August!
author: Juliana P.

description:
Great coffee!  The best pick-me-up latte in SF.

I also like the choice of beans to take home.
author: Gary G.

description:
After all these years, I got to try a pour-over coffee at Four Barrel. I'm usually too late and only get their batch brew. It was a Rwanda coffee brewed with care using a Beehouse ceramic cone dripper. It was very good. This kind of light roast single origin coffee is best experienced without adding any cream or sugar to get the full unique flavor. 

I'm glad Four Barrel is still around. It appeared that the roaster in the back wasn't in full operation though. I read somewhere they're roasting in Oakland now.
author: RK W.

description: Delicious coffee and beautiful space. I tried this and Blue Bottle while in SF and much preferred the coffee here. Only downside is the price.
author: Elizabeth T.

description: I was attracted by the significant smell of coffee that covered the whole street... The Four Barrel Coffee looks like a perfect place for modern coffee lovers. The interior of this place is just amazing, especially accompanied with the beautiful wooden dishes. If you want to have a meeting with your friends, it is one of the best places to do it!
author: Mariya O.

description: Great service, awesome coffee, relaxed atmosphere. A place I would go again. I love the sitting area outside, it's a breath of fresh air
author: Myra Z.

description: Best latte I've ever had my life!!!! Highly recommend and the wooden cups were pretty dope
author: Nathan D.

description:
I enjoy the taste of coffee but am sensitive to caffeine. I ordered a decaf. Confirmed when I was handed my drink it was decaf. However, it definitely was not. I had heart palpitations for hours. 
When a customer asks for decaf there is a reason. This request should not be taken lightly. I will not return.
author: H A.

description: Pastries are delicious and pair well with their excellent light to medium roast coffee. The decor takes you outside the norm of SF. Staff is very personable, friendly and knowledgable. If it's a nice day, enjoy the parklet.
author: Laurisha C.

description: good coffee and an aesthetically pleasing space. would recommend! the restroom was also clean so it was a plus. seems like a great spot to work and spend a few hours during the week if it is not super crowded.
author: Meghan M.

description: The coffee at four barrel is killer! My only issue is there is no wifi and it's almost impossible to find a seat. The overcrowding isn't there fault, just an issue with the city itself though. Definitely worth stopping by, their separate coffee only bar is especially fun!
author: Krista H.

description: This is definitely one of the coolest cafes I've been to. The baristas are very friendly. I got a mocha and it was really good but not very sweet. It was amazing after I added sugar.
author: Alyssa S.

description: Not much variety, but we got the affogato's those were really good!!!!!! Parking is a pain though!!!
author: Elena B.

description:
Drinks - 9/10
Service - 9/10
Atmosphere - 8/10
Instaworthy - 10/10

I tried the Mocha latte and a Cappuccino, the coffee comes in really cute brown ceramic cups and plates that fits perfectly with the aesthetics of this cafe. The coffee was also delicious!!!! I wanted another cup for sure. 

However, they do not have soy milk, only regular/skim and almond.
author: Meher G.

description:
Four barrel is one heck of a coffee place! It's a very spacious place with outdoor and indoor seating. The environment is pretty nice and seems like a great place to chat it up with friends or family. Not great if you're trying to do any cyber work as they do not offer wifi! They also don't offer sandwiches. Only coffee and pastries! Their coffees are more expensive than the usual coffee as they consider themselves high end! I mean I agree, it's very very good coffee but still eh, I feel it's slightly more expensive than the rest when it should be equal. Regardless, it was a great experience and their pastries are excellent! 

I will be back four barrel
author: Revan N.

description:
The coffee beans here are great, high quality you can taste for sure. Tons of seating available and you can watch them roast and grind their coffee in the back. 

I was disappointed with the almond latte, some folks mentioned it was good, but I thought the almond taste was much too overpowering. It was the strangest thing, it tasted just like a mouthful of dry almonds...but in liquid form. And once I got to the bottom, there was just too many sediments to enjoy.

Aside from that, there's a lot to enjoy from this cafe!
author: Emily T.

description:
Four Barrel is hipster AF and their coffee is amazeballs. Also sitting inside was nice because toward the back of the room is where they do all the coffee assortment.

They have a pour-over bar and an espresso bar, so get in the right line. I opted for the mocha latte and a toffee cookie. The cookie was a little on the hard side but it was chewier in the middle. The mocha itself was so velvety, not too sweet, and made me so happy (:

They also have super cute merchandise.
author: Christine K.

description: I loved their almond milk latte with homemade almond-macadamia nut milk. Now they stopped making their own nut milk and they use some watery flavorless bottled almond cashew milk that makes the latte just taste bitter. Same price for the latte though. I would have paid a couple bucks more for the homemade nut milk. Now I won't be coming in for coffee at all.
author: Sarita O.

description:
I wish I could say that this place was a barrel of fun.

But being here is like being with a barrel of monkeys.

The lines are long, and people are cutting in and out, and the Batista's don't stop it.

All the tables are full, and dirty with old cups and napkins.

Got my drink to go.

The Retena Guatemala coffee blend was made fresh, and didn't taste like the cherry and cream notes listed.

It was strong, and Batista took forever to remake my drink since he gave my drink to another guy also waiting for the same blend.

It would be nice if they could remember who ordered what and in what order.

This was one crazy madhouse.

Like four barrels of monkeys....
author: Jack R.

description:
After a great brunch at Mission Beach Cafe, we walked over to Four Barrel Coffee for some more coffee.  The inside is hipster nation with even the bathroom having a deer in forest design on the floor lol.  Lots of wood, industrial metal, nautical rope designs.

I liked how they have a slow pour section, and they also have the regular espresso pull drinks.  I opted for an almond latte.  It was strong and tasted good, but I have to say I've had better.  I think the atmosphere makes up for the coffee, especially since you can see the actual coffee roasting in the back of the place.  We sat in the back bar area where you face the people working on roasting the beans.  They also sell cool coffee bitters along with the coffee beans, which I thought was nice for anyone who is interested in buying bitters.  Overall, I liked trying this place especially because I always end up getting Blue Bottle or Philz in SF, but they have both of those places in LA now.
author: Catherine K.

description:
This is one of my favorite coffee places in SF. The mocha was without a doubt the smoothest one I've ever had, and the chocolate was rich but not too sweet. I don't usually like chocolate in my coffee, but four barrel does it right. We also ordered a macchiato, which was amazing, and an amann pastry which was pretty good. 

The interior is also beautiful. If it weren't so out of the way from where I usually am, I would love to study here for hours on end. Will definitely be back!
author: Rachel W.

description:
Love this place... This is my all time fav for coffee...
They have a pretty cool ambiance... you should totally hang out with your friends here..

My favs here are their affogato, mocha & cappacino...
author: Deebs M.

description:
Cool vibes / Hipster

Amazing coffee

Ample seating 

No WiFi - purely for reading, catching up with people, etc.

Minimal menu - simplicity is the ultimate sophistication
author: Roopa S.

description:
Delicious coffee, my fav spot in San Francisco.

Their Mato pourover is insanely good.  It's the most "floral" thing I've ever tasted.  Espressos are delicious as well, and the decor is beautiful.
author: Brian S.

description: Cute coffee shop with great ambiance. The coffee is great and the pastries are wonderful. I had the maple bacon donut which had a great density and wasn't overly sweet. Be aware that if you order anything but a coffee (which you'd get immediately), it may be a 10-15 minute wait as there is only one person making lattes, mochas, etc.
author: Trudy L.

description: If you are paying $12 for coffee and a pastry, they should have the courtesy to offer free Wi-Fi. Over priced. Over hyped. Above average coffee.
author: Sue N.

description:
I get it, it could be a little too hipster, a little too pretentious. But maybe I'm just a typical girl that's won over by this kinda cute hip ambience and stuff. YES I ADMIT I LOVE THIS PLACE!

Their coffee is legit plus they provide cream (not just half and half) which makes it even more delicious. I also got the maple bacon donut and yum--I finished that stuff too fast I don't even remember eating it.  

Lots of seats available even outdoor! Whenever I'm nearby I can see myself coming here often.
author: Becky M.

description:
Today I came by after brunch around 11am with my friends. I seems like every time I come, all the seats are occupied... Anyways, I order an iced coffee. Ive had Four Barrel before and I like it very much, but there are people who feel that their coffee is a little more acidic, so this is probably not the place for you if you don't want like acidic coffee. The coffee was good, but I feel like the prices were raised from the last time I came a few months ago. Almost $5 for a latte and a cappuccino is a little much. 

At the back of the store, you can see them roast the beans and it's pretty cool. I've had the affogato before and I love it!
author: Lydia H.

description:
Had to try this place ... I heard it is one of the top four places in SF for a Capp. 

Meh. I enjoy coffee but much like craft beer many seem to be trying to get a bit too over the top with their flavor profiles and one up the competition. It is an overwhelming attack on the taste buds ... fruit, chocolate, nuts, acidity ... that is what I feel happened here. 

Ritual and blue bottle both top four barrels in the fight for the top spot for delicious coffee in the city.
author: Dennis B.

description:
TOP notch coffee and the most AMAZING fresh pastries (I need to remember to ask them where they get the pastries because some of them are even better than the coffee).

Side note: For my fellow lactose-intolerant, coffee lover friends, they have the option of almond milk, but no soy.

The only thing I don't like about Four Barrel is the fact that they don't have Wi-Fi, which I think should be pretty standard for any cafe. But honestly...the service, the atmosphere/decor, the coffee, and the pastries still make it 100% deserving of 4 stars.
author: Sara L.

description:
This review is for their coffee and their classes. The coffee is good, albeit a bit pricey, but you're mostly paying for the space, which offers a lot of seating and some strange art, so that's okay.

The classes, on the other hand, are held at night in their back room on a regular basis. They are super informative and include samples of many roasts and, most importantly, the class is 100% free. If you have any interest in the coffee process (from sourcing to roasting to brewing), then you should check it out.
author: Nick K.

description:
I liked this place! The almond milk latte totally hit the spot. The service was fast and friendly. Decor was awesome. Big spacious area. The only thing was that it's popular so it can be hard to get a table.

Would definitely recommend
author: Angela T.

description:
This was the only place I went to for coffee during my one day visit in SF! I wanted to try the best coffee in the city and decided to give this cafe a shot since I have already tried other highly rated coffee shops like Philz and Blue Bottle in LA.

The almond milk latte was just a-okay for me, like I wasn't wow'd or tasted anything spectacular or different relative to other lattes that I have tried, but the ambiance and rustic decor and hip vibe definitely screams SF. 

If I lived here, I would definitely come here to get some work done because of the warm atmosphere and maybe consider giving their coffee another shot for that "wow" factor.
author: Linda N.

description:
The coffee isn't bad, the atmosphere is usually pleasant--the choice of wall-art and music is fine--the staff are courteous, the seating is great, their location and beans are superb but my primary gripe is that Four Barrel only offers almond milk as their single plant based alternative. Which, to be fair, isn't all that big a deal--especially because they make their own in-house almond milk and I think that's pretty kick-ass. The problem is in the longevity. 

Basically, I woke up this morning expecting to finish off most of my almond-milk latte that I bought last night and it was a congealed gelatinous sludge of undrinkable caffeine. I'm not a fan of throwing down $7 for 12oz of drink only to find most of it ruined by an overnight stay in my fridge. For now, I'll stick with Ritual or Blue Bottle until they either modify their almond milk or provide additional plant-based milks--coconut, oat, hemp, couscous, pea, soy, rice, anything really that isn't mucus-inducing rapid bovine growth fluid.
author: Derek M.

description: This is my favorite coffee house in the city. The people are pleasant. The atmosphere is light and airy with the scent of coffee. The blackberry croissant is my favorite. The coffee is great. You can get coffee beans for home too. It's always a great Christmas present for the coffee lover.
author: Shawna F.

description:
This was one of the best coffee shops I visited in San Francisco...by the time I got to this coffee shop I had already visited Sight Glass  and Blue Bottle  so I was already really caffeinated 
I ordered a single origin espresso which was extremely good. I also took home a bag of coffee that was really good brewed at home 
They roast their own coffee so that's a plus and honestly I do not understand people complaining about "hipsters" ...just drink your damn coffee or go somewhere else, no one looks down at you and everyone minds their own business..baristas are really friendly, some even too friendly that they talk with people for a while ..but at the end you get your good cup of Joe
author: Luis E M.

description: I loved the ambience and also the fact that they have a huge machinery to brew their own company. 4star was because of expensive and quantity
author: Mahek C.

description: Hipster is the word that comes to mind, which might make me -1 star because I feel old and square when I come in here. The coffee itself more than makes up for it. Best cup in SF at the moment IMHO.
author: Stephen A.

description: The hippest of the hip, the trendiest of the trendy. Parklet with a bike rack, dead animals on the wall and all. OK, they make good coffee if you like third wave coffee, which I don't, because it's too light and acidic for my tastes. BUT! If you want a SERIOUS coffee education, attend their classes. They have a classroom. Really. These people mean it. How can you not love them for it? Coffee and Conflict? THAT is an interesting class. They do cuppings if you want to try all their coffees and understand more about coffee regions and terroir. And if you're a barista, see if your employer will splurge for the pricey one-on-one classes where you'll learn how to froth with the pros and make a proper cortado for when some pretentious *** orders one. And what kind of self respecting 21st century barista doesn't put hearts on top of their cappuccinos? Also: espresso is science! There's a reason these machines cost so much. Learn the nitty-gritty of how to calibrate your grinder and pull the perfect shot. You might even learn to love third wave coffee.
author: L. M.

description:
Great coffee.. love the environment.

Affagato and Almond Milk Late is my fav.
I love outside seating. Will be back!!
author: Tammy B.

description: The Coffee is excellent and the croissants are so good especially with butter added inside! The music is loud and usually old hits I've never heard before so I occasionally Shazam songs that I like. There's no public WiFi networks so usually seats are available to hang out and use your phone which of course is more secure. I've read peeps saying it's "hipster" but I just think it's the locals just being themselves. Of course I don't see many blue hairs living in the mission these days.
author: John N.

description:
The Location:

Four Barrel Coffee is kind of the coolest place ever. It's right on Valencia street in SF's Mission District- home to many hip shops and restaurants. Customers appear to feel very 'at home' here, noted when I saw tons of people posting up to "work on their laptop" and read stuff. 

The Product:

Four Barrel keeps their menu minimal (in tune with other hip coffee shops) but offer up a brew that is distinct and delicious! The mocha I ordered was the perfect temperature, full bodied, and had just the right amount of sweetness. I also liked the little Four Barrel "jacket." 

The 'Wow' Factor:

I adore their Four Barrel Coffee mugs (i.e. angry Santa). Also, their Instagram account is totally hilarious (@fourbarrelcoffee) featuring amazing haiku poems!
author: Nicole W.

description: Had the Mocha at the stall near Ferry Building on Thursday.  It's pricy but the quality of the beans and the subtle taste justify the price.  Great stuff, I am gonna try the rest of the menu soon.
author: Ani R.

description:
Stop hating on the 'stachio. Those little green croissants are super addictive - probably a gateway to harder sweets. Who cares if they're the most un-French pastries to ever come in to the category? Because America. 

The atmosphere is comfortable, a nice respite from the streets of the mission. 

But most importantly, the coffee is bangin, and if you sweet talk the coffee gremlins at less busy times you can pick their brains for coffee tips. Mmmm
author: Andrea F.

description: Amazing place! The best coffee i have ever tasted! Great interior and friendly staff, fast service. Highly recommended!
author: Alina E.

description:
Me speaking to my sister: "This place is hipster as fxck" 

Random stranger not pleased at me stating the obvious: "you're in San Francisco. It's not hipster, it's character"

Okay bro, whatever. I'm from So Cal. Go get a tan and leave me alone, I wasn't talking to you, my voice is naturally loud. 

ANYWAY. 

OH MY GAWWWWDDD. Hipster hangout heaven meets coffee of the gods. No but really, the coffee was excellent and the entire place had the greatest aroma due to the fact the roast their own beans. Awesome! 

Pros: excellent coffee, DUH. I ordered an iced Breve Latte which was delicious. Yes, I was a Nike wearing, powerlifting, so cal iced coffee drinker. Ok sorry whatever. I'm a coffee addict, I still know what's good.
