Cons: the people working there act like they've been hand chosen to serve you the coffee gods elixir. Seriously, don't ask their advice unless you don't mind a dirty look accompanied by a snotty answer. 

All in all, I'm still a coffee addict and I would return.
author: Marissa B.

description: Absolutely love the coffee here! I visit on Saturdays and it gets crowded fast. Their lattes are amazing but also have a variety of drip coffee. The last time I ordered it did take about twenty minutes.
author: Kimberly G.

description:
Great place to grab coffee and catch up with a friend.

If you're coming here hoping for a smoothie or lattes with syrup, you're in the wrong place!

Very friendly staff and plenty of seats. 

I had a latte with almond milk and it was great! I added some brown sugar afterwards to make it a little bit sweeter. 

One restroom towards the back. Street parking everywhere.
author: Danae L.

description:
What a really neat experience. The outside seating made me give this place four stars. What better place for a visitor to chill and take up the San Francisco vibe. I really enjoyed the coffee too. The donut ...mehhh. But hey what was I doing eating it that in the first place? 

The atmosphere here is inspiring and if your into good coffee and people watching this is your place. Bring a note book.
author: Christopher B.

description: This is the absolute best coffee place ever. Screw wifi and the other crap . The people here are actually quite unique and that's very cool. Thank you for being you
author: Julane S.

description: Coffee has a bit of a sour taste to it. It's definitely different but good once you've had a few sips. I would have rated this place higher if they had more of a variety of milk. Whole milk and their almond milk just didn't cut it for me. I usually can do any milk ranging from nonfat to 2% but whole just changes the way a latte tastes. Nice vibe and baristas are sweet too. If your into the whole hipster vibe this is the place to be. Cute shop as well.
author: Marilyn M.

description: Ambience was great! This place was packed on a Sunday morning. I don't usually like coffee, but this was definitely one of the best mochas I've ever had. Would definitely come here again.
author: Catherine S.

description:
Get over yourself, this place. I appreciate that there is a fine art to a good cup of coffee, but I just didn't have the best experience here. 

Slow service for two lattes. No wifi. Super loud. Tiny tables. Seems like they discourage people from coming here to work. Almond cake wasn't bad though...

I don't know guys, just not my bag I guess.
author: Carol M.

description:
Hip coffee joint with a large spacious atmosphere. Came here for an espresso and was not disappointed. 

You can sit upstairs and look down at the coffee roasting and long lines. If you're in the area, be sure to stop by for a good pick-me-up.
author: Reid Y.

description:
Four Barrel is my favorite coffee spot in San Francisco. The mocha at Sight Glass is comparable but the mocha at Four Barrel is slightly better. There is also outside seating at the entrance that gives you a charming feel of trellises at a vineyard. It looks great at night. If you get there at the wrong time when everyone else is trying to get their coffee to start their morning, there is a long line out the door. The line is a testament to the quality of the coffee.

If you are visiting San Francisco and looking for recommendations, feel free to message me through Yelp and I can share my itinerary, which includes my Yelp reviews. The information for an electronic copy can also be found via my Yelp profile.
author: Patrick W.

description:
Got beans? 

Four Barrel has got you covered. 

Admittedly, I'm not a coffee connoisseur. I'm not even a caffeine addict. But my little heart skips a beat whenever I see Four Barrel at a restaurant or a cafe. I've subconsciously pledged loyalty to this brand without realizing it until now. 

My cousin, who's moved halfway across the world, is the type of person who can appreciate fine beans such as Four Barrel. Naturally, I had to get her a bag. Whole beans range from $16 - $20 per lb. 

The cool, hipster baristas are approachable and knowledgeable. Ask if you have a preference between bold/mild/caramel/spicy flavors. They can definitely point you in the right direction.

On your way out, grab an iced drink while you stroll along the Mission. It's always sunny in this part of town and I can't imagine a more perfect way to spend a lazy Sunday enjoying it like a local would. 

With an iced Americano in hand, of course  ;)
author: Janice C.

description: No secret that this place is the one to go to for all the classic coffee/latte drinks. Good quality, but nothing too original or surprising. I couldn't find anything that makes this place stand out from other good coffee places either in SF or in Europe. I would recommend ordering at the side bar, not the main bar; their selection of slow drips are amazing, and the barista can really help you find your perfect flavor. (And the line is much shorter, too!)
author: Tim B.

description:
I was looking for a coffee shop to work out of and found this place on yelp. I'm really not a coffee snob, so I'm rating this on the atmosphere.

The place is spacious and has really cute decor. I honestly just wanted coffee so i could take a cute instagram pic..and i was able to do that here :)

my only complaint that there are no outlets anywhere!! My laptop died and the only thing I had left to keep me company was the picture I took moments before.
author: Andy H.

description:
Update as of 8th Oct 2016 -
Four barrel, I am so disappointed with you guys.  I have been coming here almost every weekend for the past 8 months and I'm disappointed how you guys price gouge.  

First you mark up the lattes from 4.50 to 5 (with tax it's 5.44) while competitors like ritual offer at 4.50 (incl tax).  I asked why and you said it's because of upgraded milk.  I sucked it up.

Then two weeks ago, you guys changed the for-here cups.  They used to be bigger and nicer.  They are smaller now and I just feel so cheated with these tricks you guys are playing.  You want loyalty but you do these tricks it leaves a terrible taste and makes me not want to come here again.  I expected better from you guys.  


--old review--

Great coffee, ambience, ceramic cups, service and vibe.  

But $5 is on the higher side price wise for a latte so knocked off one star for it.
author: V V.

description: Both yesterday, February 13th, and today, I had occasion to interact with the staff members who were operating the back counter. They couldn't have been more gracious, helpful, and welcoming. Oh and the coffee is terrific which is why I buy it by the bag to savor at home. I hope this treasure of a place continues to thrive.
author: Florence C.

description:
My experience with Four Barrel has been a true "Pride and Prejudice" love story.

-I visited the first time.

-The Four Barrel staff proudly served me great coffee but perhaps misread my request for drink customization and/or wifi.

-I misjudged this motivation and became quite prejudiced. I could admit they were good but always somewhat begrudgingly. 

-I visited other coffee shops, I read the reviews, I talked with friends about how exceptional the quality is here. I saw how friendly they are to all of their regular clientele!

-I realized Four Barrel might be the coffee shop love of my life and their mocha is pretty much unbeatable in the city of San Francisco and maybe worldwide.

-I go there almost every day and couldn't be gladder.

Yes, the price is a little higher than your average Joe. But it's also a lot better! 

Also their pastries are extremely delectable.
author: Stephanie T.

description: This place is great: high quality coffee, friendly service, and tasteful wooden seating. Their cups and plates are cute as well. I work just down the street and this is the go to for all of my coworkers. Just keep in mind you pay for the quality, but if you understand the experience and quality, you definitely won't regret coming here.
author: Art S.

description:
5 stars because in spite of the price, the coffee really is that good. 

Four Barrel turned me on to espresso drinks after a lifetime of regular coffee. $4.50 for a cappuccino, but you get what you pay for. Espresso drinks are "just right": not too bitter and not too creamy. Only coffee shop I know that uses pasture-raised milk, roast their own beans, and they have this coffee thing down to a science. They also have a "slow bar" with a variety of varietals, pour over style. These are also quite good, the only coffee I can drink black. 

Beautiful space - airy and craftsman-y - and they have a cool old-timey roaster in the back where they roast their own coffee. Staff are always friendly, latte art game is strong. If you come at a peak time, which means weekends morning to midday, it will be extremely crowded. 15 min+ wait and standing room only. Plenty of seating other times. In competition with Ritual for best coffee in the San Francisco, it's a virtual tie in my mind.
author: Bud P.

description: I want to love this place. I really do. The interior is beautifully decorated and the line always moves quickly. It's always packed so clearly people like it, but I feel like it's overhyped by hipsters in the Mission. Every time I've been here I've gotten mediocre service. Some of the baristas are quite moody and the last time I was here will be the last time I go here. $5 for a small, average tasting latte? No thanks. If I'm going to pay that much for coffee, I shouldn't be receiving attitude for no reason.
author: Jenny L.

description:
Four Barrel is one of those places that coffee elites, renowned baristas, and aspiring connoisseurs speak of as THE place to get coffee in San Francisco.  After several visits over the course of a week, plus many visits to other SF shops, I can whole-heartedly agree with the accolades.

Great coffee is the result of doing three incredibly difficult and skilled trades very well: farming, roasting, and brewing. The staff at Four Barrel leaves nothing to chance: they direct trade with farms around the world to find the best lots, the in-house roasters labor over the coffee with complete quality-control over the product, and the resulting beans are freshly brewed just a few meters away by qualified baristas that actually respect the coffee.

The result is an exceptional experience: whether an espresso, macchiato, or cortado, every drink is consistently created by the team of baristas.  For a more one-on-one approach, try out the Slow Bar near the entrance to have a conversation about their work and sample some other brew methods.

Overall, put all the silly stereotypes aside and come in with an open mind quenching for great coffee.
author: Rob W.

description: Good coffee. Friendly staff (usually). Fun hipster SF vibe. Not as good as SightGlass or Blue Bottle, but still decent coffee.
author: JonJon W.

description:
My goal every time I visit SF is their coffee shops. My boyfriend recommended me this coffee shop, and I gave it a try.

Ambience - A very CUTE setting for a cup of coffee with friends, coworkers or even if you just want me time. The place is quite big, with a good amount of seating, mostly for 2 with several long tables for groups more than 4. I loved how simple the place is decorated as well as the calm and relaxing vibes it gives when you walk in. We sat outside, and the weather was perfect paired up with the cappuccino that I ordered.

coffee - I ordered the cappuccino and it was one of the best ones I've tried thus far. As always, I'm a sucker for designs, so the design was cute. 

Parking - you wouldn't be SF if you didn't have to park in the street right? Depending on the time you go will depict the parking, but just be ready to walk and explore while walking to the place, nothing wrong with that.  

My overall experience was GREAT, which is why I am rating them a 5. I am definitely coming back to try the other coffees that they have to offer. If you are in the area, and are looking for a coffee shop, I recommend giving this place a try, because I don't think you will be disappointed!
author: Chazmine D.

description: Nice spot to have coffee.  Breakfast sandwiches are pretty good.  Great location but always busy.  A little difficult to find parking but worth the effort.  Recommend.
author: Scott B.

description: This cafe is a great place to meet with a friend but a bad place to go if you are tying to get work done. Personally, it was not my cup of coffee because there was no internet, no outlets, it was a little loud, and I paid like 8 dollars for a 12 oz mocha and the coffee was a bit too acidic for my taste. That being said the decor and staff were great. It is just one of those coffee bars that is designed to talk at. So as long as you know what your getting into it is great:)
author: Annelise M.

description: The brewed coffee is too fruity and acidic for my taste. Love the place and the decoration, but the coffee used to be in pr with Peet's coffee.
author: Mehran A.

description:
Four Barrel Coffee. I have mixed feelings about you. 
If you like waiting in lines and spending at least $3.75 for drip coffee and $4.25 for a pistachio croissant, then this place is for you. If you also like to pay an extra $0.50 for almond milk, not because you like it so much but because their only other option is whole milk, then this is the perfect place to be. Don't get me wrong, their $5.25 almond mocha was good, but did I think it was overpriced? Yes.
I also received the worst customer service at a coffee place at this exact location. Asking the cashier for suggestions on anything in here was like pulling teeth- no opinions about anything. The yuppie coffee experience just isn't worth it. But 3 stars instead of 2 because the roast is pretty tasty.
author: Grace L.

description:
The definition of a hipster coffee joint. I feel like four barrel is THE go to place for many people in the mission and the city for that matter. You can tell by how reviewed this place is. 

I've had the coffee, cappuccino and latte. The coffee is meh and too bitter for my liking but the latte and cappuccino make it up with their excellence. They're both of the right strength and texture so definitely check them out. A downside is the price and the serving size but that's what you get for being such a popular destination for coffee lovers.
author: Ray H.

description:
Not a place that you can do most week--

I popped in here during my commute from FiDi to my house to grab a coffee and join a webcast with my team. Waited in line for a long while only to chat with a barista who clearly did not want to be there. Once my order was placed (and I tipped) I sat down at an open spot and got my computer out. I didn't see a wifi spot pop up so I went and asked another barista what their wifi info was. He just kinda shrugged and said they are a disconnected coffee shop so people can talk without distractions or something. 

I just scooped up my stuff and walked out before my $6 latte was ready so that I could go somewhere else and be productive. 

Not my scene at all.
author: Casey S.

description:
Coffee on point. Amazing Pour over bar and timely service. Even in the midst of a long line, cashier was still happy to answer questions and describe different drink options.
Very hipster environment but friendly instead of snooty.
author: Emily C.

description:
The coffee and latte are alright. To me it felt like it was more hype. The coffee is well overpriced. 
Be warned there's no internet or charge stations. So come fully charged.
author: Shahid Z.

description:
+ pretty coffee latte art 
+ hipster ambiance
+ great service.
The guy at the counter allowed me to ponder for my choices for coffee since it was first time & gave me recommendations. 

- the cappuccino is a bit too strong & too bitter for my taste 
- a tad bit expensive for a macchiato 

I'll probably stop by just because of the latte art if I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Kathleen U.

description:
Okay, here I am about 18 months after my visit posting a review. I just logged into Yelp for a different reason, was reminded of a place down the street from here called Cream (good, check it out), and then remembered that there was a coffee shop I loved and I needed to write about it, which brings me here. 

I came here twice around 7/4/15 with my friend. Both times, we were greeted with friendly smiles and received our order promptly. Now I'm from the Seattle area, so I like to think I know good coffee. This place was great. I remember tagging myself here on Facebook and raving about the smooth espresso. 

If you're in the area, check it out. They have funny mugs for purchase, a bit spendy (I think I paid $19 or $20 for a regular coffee mug), but it's still one of my favorite mugs. It may or may not have a cuss word on it, so it doesn't always come out of the cupboard.
author: Dusty M.

description: No wifi. Too cavernous and noisy. Good coffee but I wont be back. A coffee place without wifi is worse than useless.
author: Keith R.

description: This was a very nice coffee house, but it is on the pricier side. I really liked the decor and atmosphere here. We got iced mochas and those were good - tasted better than the average mocha! It wasn't too sweet. Overall a good experience and I would come back.
author: Wendy W.

description: The coffee is good, the place & ambiance are great. Very cool vibe with a record player and friendly staff. Such a cool place to meet friends or to work on your laptop.
author: N G.

description:
Saturday, 1:00 PM.
Note: no wi-fi.

Quickie:
+ Drink quality
+ Service
- Hygiene
- Turnaround
* Menu variety

And then...?
Their website references to some of its growers. I like the social undertone that powers this company.

**********
Stuffed my face in:
1. Iced latte
    + Refreshing roast

Constructive comments:
*Expand food menu beyond pastries
author: Chuck N.

description: I love you coffeee!!  What an amazing spot.. super good coffee and the atmosphere is amazing... their baked good are to die for
author: Marina G.

description: Super cute place, but the coffee was very bitter and sour. I ordered a latte with almond-cashew milk and it was very sour tasting.
author: Isabella M.

description:
I'm a big fan of their lattes. However, don't don't DON'T get their hot chocolate. Maybe they just made it bad that one time. But it literally tasted like a liquid chocolate bread. It sure looked pretty though!

The interior is really hipster and there's a lot of seating! There's water cups on the side with the animal heads. It's really close to Mission Beach Cafe and if you go there for lunch, I'd recommend coming here for coffee because you're going to wait 40mins+ for MBC.
author: Kristine K.

description:
I am a coffee drinker that is willing to go on missions or simply to the Mission District for my drug of choice. I'm in San Francisco regularly, so I've naturally already gone to two of the holy coffee trilogy (Blue Bottle and Sightglass) in San Francisco during other trips. During this last trip, it was time to take on Four Barrel.

With their wood panels, long benches, and gorgeous chairs, this is a beautiful and surprisingly large coffee shop for San Francisco. When I am in California and going for a bite to eat or grabbing a drink, I often prepare myself to walk into a room the size of a closet; Four Barrel is the opposite of that presumption. It is an expansive caffeinated space. As the coffee did its magic during the time I was there, I saw many things I missed during my first pass. Subtle things like six-foot long black rope chandeliers, giant shelves, and tall stools. Your eyes can play tricks on you here.

One of the things I didn't miss during the first walk-through was a tasting counter to the right of the door when you first walk in. This counter was run by an animated and focused barista explaining the coffee flavors in elaborate detail, like a sommelier describes wine flavors- of which, I am a giant fan.

Past the expressive barista are rows of expensive little 12 oz. packets of prepared coffee goodness on the wall. For a few Hamiltons, you can leave with a couple of uniform bricks to take to your kitchen in San Francisco or to stuff in your luggage, so your t-shirts can smell like honeycomb and orange liqueur coffee.

Prompted by the friendly service, I found myself ordering quickly and not being intimidated by the wonderful options. Going back a minute, the service was really great. I mean, why wouldn't I get great service? You can just tell I am an awesome person by my order: a coconut donut and a latte. To their credit, they gave me more deserved props for my mid-day donut order than most baristas would. The coconut donut I chose was light and fluffy even with its huge shavings on top and tons of sugar-loaded, decision-making validation.

From the front door, you almost have complete line-of-sight to the back. The front area is quite open (I'm sure to help with line management when they get busy) with the back containing more sitting nooks. There is also vinyl on the wall, making the entire vibe more soulful-intelligent-artisan than dirty-snotty-hipster.

One note about coffee's ultimate counterpart: milk. Here, they only serve almond milk. Not even soy. For me, this is the perfect latte. It is how I have it at home, so I am not biased at all when I praise this decision, but (as milk-in-coffee is a polarizing topic amongst any two people) it is good to know before going to Four Barrel.

So, you have your detailed donut and your perfect latte, you find a seat and then the entertainment starts. The vintage Probat machine in the back churning coffee beans around is manned by a few lightly adorned, but serious looking guys in the back. One guy is smelling the beans from a siphon in the center of the machine that could be pulled out to test (what I imagine is) the done-ness of the beans. Another guy moves the very expensive coffee around in large Rubbermaid bins. These active coffeeologists are making decisions on a stage more public than I have seen in most coffee shops. They are concentrating celebrities with an audience literally taking notes and photographing their movements.

After the show and before I walked out, I caught sight of the "suck it" mugs, which both confirmed my love of this place and were exactly what I needed to see after the day I had had.

Is Four Barrel worth the stop? Absolutely. Even if you are not punching holes in the imaginary punch card of the San Francisco Holy Trilogy of Coffee, I hope you have a little time for yourself here at some point.
author: Erica G.

description:
Entering Four Barrel, I already knew that I would be loving this spot.

The smell of freshly grounded coffee beans, the looks of that drip coffee, the welcoming of bike parking in the front and the vibe that this place exudes, makes Four Barrel happening!

With the visual effects of the slow dripping of black coffee, you become enticed and await the tasting of it.  I must say, that the black coffee was naturally at its best all by itself and the taste was simply clean!  You don't need to ruin it by adding sugar, milk or cream to it.  The best black coffee I have ever had.

Enjoy the blend of black coffee with their signature B. Patisserie, Kouign Amann pastry and it will be a splendid combo.

There is dining and if you go further in, you get to see the making of grounded coffee with the machine!  Once completed, they do put the grounded coffee in barrels!  The place suits its name.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Awesome café in Mission. Making coffee is an art for the staff at Four Barrel, although they lose a star for not being very friendly and giving a bit of attitude to customers.

Other than that, the place is beautiful and has a great vibe.
author: Alex N.

description: Came by with the mister for a quick Saturday coffee before we continue to explore SF for the weekend. Pretty easy to find the location driving by, since they have a little unique seating area on the sidewalk. Walked in and was happily greeted by the cashier who took our order. She passed the order onto a barista to her left, but he rejected our order and told her to give it to someone else. Umm that's not weird at all, but okay. So she gave it to the barista to her right. We paid and moved over to the right to pick up our drinks. I asked for my drink with extra ice and the barista did not seem to like the idea that I wanted a few more ice cubes. Again, not weird at all... I guess. Got our drinks and went on our ways. Not going to complain too much about the barista's customer service since the coffee itself was good and we'll probably not be back a second time in future SF visits. Onto the next!
author: Nancy B.

description: Terrific atmosphere, awesome service, yummy meals. If you're visiting, I would suggest their pumpkin spice latte along with banana chocolate scone. I seriously liked my time here. I will return here.
author: Patricia B.

description:
The coffee itself gets five stars as well as the look of the place but what it lacks is wifi and speed of service.

Second visit here as the coffee is amazing however expect to wait at least ten min for coffee if not more

Value 3.5/5
Atmosphere 4/5 no wifi
Service 2/5
Quality 4.5/5

14/20
author: Nina S.

description:
Not a huge coffee person, but this is just the perfect Coffee shop! Right when you walk in, YA KNOW THIS PLACE WILL BE AMAZING, with the cute bike parking patio and outdoor seating. Topping that with clean and contemporary decor, this place stole my heart. With seating all around, I would definitely come back here just to relax, read a book, study. This place just screams good vibes. 

HUGE HIGHLIGHTS 
-I love their almond milk so so so so much - add it to anything or just even pour it in a cup - it is perfffffecccttt. 
-The baristas are so cool and chique and always make fun conversation and just seem to love their job.  
- Biker's paradise. Loads of bike parking and it is so great to meet fellow bikers in the area! 
-Assortment of baked goods and coffee/teas. They had me at the almond milk, but there are just so many great choices. Smooth. Delicious. and GAHDAHM AMAZING.
author: Eric Joseph D.

description:
Just like the outdated carburetor from which Four Barrel evokes its name, the place itself is old 'n busted. While Ritual Coffee down the street is running on Direct Injection, Four Barrel gets left in the dust.

Recently after a great night spent in the city, we wanted a coffee pick-me-up the next morning. Since Four Barrel has been a longtime bookmark of mine, we decided to go outta our way to check it out. Despite the usual Mission parking situation, we managed to find an open metered space. It wasn't even worth the $1 or so I dropped in the meter.

I attempted to order two soy lattes. Since they don't do soymilk here, we ended up with almond milk instead. While I appreciate the inclusion of almond milk as a dairy alternative, I do not appreciate the exclusion of soymilk. Almond milk just doesn't do it for me in a latte. It overpowers the espresso. The only place that does a decent job of frothing almond milk is Timeless Coffee in Oakland. Even still, I prefer soymilk or even coconut milk.

The real reason for the lowly star rating? This two shots of espresso with a layer of frothed almond milk just wasn't very good. http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/four-barrel-coffee-san-francisco?select=CJ-uIyDc_j2QoL6j15MQZg#YH_OiPFy2wYswt857CHDyA I could have easily downed this drink in one gulp, pinky up 'n everythang. Also for the price, you best not upcharge me on the almond milk. It's an extra fiddy cents to add a dollop of foam to my espresso?

Perhaps they got my order wrong and gave us something else since I don't see how this size latte would put a dent in volume of their to go cups. However the guy working the machine said "your other almond milk latte will be right up" as I walked over to grab the first.

Their only redeeming quality? They have a pretty cool name and an awesome looking, quite large storefront. Although with the spaciousness, they could stand to add a few seats given the amount of hipsters standing in line. The parklet outside is a nice touch as well. That's about it.

With no Vegan pastries in sight, there's very little that would encourage a repeat visit except for their pour over coffee. Since I can get much better at Ritual or Philz, Four Barrel is relegated to the junkyard, the same way most of the vehicles that were outfitted with carburetors are now today.

My babygirl had pretty much the same impression as myself. I *think* she hated it even more than I did... http://www.yelp.com/biz/four-barrel-coffee-san-francisco#hrid:jF-C0h8cRleQLsY15f6CFA
author: John B.

description: Their almond milk latte is the best I've ever had, hands down. I asked where they got their almond milk (so that I could go buy it), but was informed that they 'make it themselves,' which explains why it tastes so good.
author: Rebecca O.

description:
I'm visiting from LA and Four Barrel coffee beans have been popping up in many local coffee shops in my area so I decided to bookmark Four Barrel so when I go to SF, I can visit because all the baristas I've spoken to in LA really enjoy their beans. 

The price of Four Barrel is approximately the same as coffee in LA so I didn't think the price of the coffee was too expensive but rather average and appropriately priced. I picked up the espresso, affogato, and a slow pour over. I also picked up a couple of those wrapped chocolate taffy things which were excellent and went really well with my espresso.
 
The affogato is made with buffalo milk (wtf??? crazy) which is why I wanted to try it. The ice cream of the affogato felt creamier than any affogato ice cream I've had which was a plus. The espresso tasted like a couple of other espressos I've had before, but it's not bad. The slow pour over was good. 

Service was fast, the baristas do not smile nor talk as much as the baristas i've come across in LA lol but service was good.
author: Jasmine L.

description:
Today, Tues, Aug 20, 2013 they celebrated their 5th yr Anniversary!  I had to take the day off to go!  Took Bart to 16th St Bart & walked up 16th to Valencia.

Line was long, but it moved pretty fast.

Got a mocha reg. $4.75! for FREE w/ latte art.  All their drinks were free from 7am-4pm!  Awesome.

Cake was from Tartine & it was almost 1pm before they brought 2 huge sheet cakes.  I got a slice of the coconut passionfruit cake.  It was tasty.

Skee Ball they had 2 to play for free, that was fun.  My high score was 230, need more practice.

FREE Photo Booth - go inside & do 4 poses - get pictures soon afterwards.  Yippee!

Petting Zoo on the sidewalk outside.  I took some pics, didn't pet any animals.  Rabbit, duck, alpaca, goat is what I saw.

One taco truck was nearby to buy some lunch - I only took a few pics, didn't buy.

One unisex bathroom in the back.

Can't wait for next yr!  Thank you Four Barrel Coffee!  I'll be back soon to buy more coffee & kouign amanns from B Patisserie.

Note to self: should have gotten affogato, normally $5.5 someone else got!  Didn't see on their menu, next yr.
author: Ann L.

description:
Four barrels may be my number 1 for coffee in San Fran. The space is huge & they have two machines running & a really efficient line system which means that even when they're packed, you never wait too long to order or get your coffee.

There's some seating off to one side and a little cabinet of pastries and treats, but really the coffee is the star of the show.

They do excellent espresso - I've never tried other varieties!
author: Victoria C.

description: Great coffee and atmosphere but ridiculously overpriced. Even compared to other SF coffee prices.
author: Sarah R.

description:
Wow this place gets PACKED. But still, service is amazing and the quality of the coffee is perfection. Not to mention the decor and ambience; the walls are decorated with unique pieces of artwork and coffee/merch for sale, and there's even a bike parking structure and outdoor bar seating to complete the experience. 

I didn't see a sign on the outside of the store, so if you don't know what it looks like, it might be a little tricky to find. But just look for the wood, and you've found yourself a beautiful cup of joe.
author: Sabrina C.

description:
The best espresso in the United States of America. Not italian style. This is a 440 V8 engine. This is extravagance. This is top down open highways pedal to the metal. This is vinyl records turned up way too load. This is opulence in brown. This is three times too much, but you can't stop. 
This is coffee that is obsessed over and carefully crafted. Complex beautiful sophisticated warm balanced with interesting notes that hit one at a time in rapid joy, top to finish. This is the beginning of craftsmanship coming back to what Americans do.  So proud of these guys. 
$1.50 AN OUNCE! OMFG SF prices.
author: Eric H.

description:
The coffee here is great. Probably one of my favourite places to go for coffee and meeting up with people. However, I'm leaving this place three stars because of the TERRIBLE utilisation of space in this store. 

Upon entering, you approach a large, empty space that services two coffee brewing methods -- a slower brew off to the left, and your typical ready-to-go coffee in front. Squeezed on the right side are some pitiful seating options, along with bar-type seating in the back. But why the hell is there so much open space? You can see the back of the store, which is the same size as the occupied storefront, and it looks empty. Not a lot of items are even stored there, and a lot of space could be reclaimed for extra seating. The front area could also service more customer seating. The outdoor area is nice, but I am just astonished at how wasteful and thoughtless a space could be, especially in crowded, expensive, and environmentally-minded practicality of San Francisco.
author: Jenny N.

description:
Yes five stars. I love going to Four Barrel Coffee. The Ambiance is wonderful, comfortable and warm.  The space just feels good to be in.  I really like the modern look and the wood tables and dark wood colors and open space.

The coffee is so good.  There is always a line so we get to wait and savor the experience.  I just get the coffee and sip slowly.  The drip coffee is $3.00 which is fine.  The service is wonderful.  It is always great to drop in over the weekend while we are in SF and needing our morning coffee magic! Four Barrel Coffee does the job every time.
author: Michael S.

description:
Great pour over and good espresso. I always come here for coffee when I visit SF. It's a good reason to visit! But you have to make it before 5 pm if you're a pour-over fan like myself. And they have a a variety of exquisite beans. The pour over bar is separate from the espresso bar, which is a feature I smile to myself about every time I visit. The espresso line is always about 5 to 10 people deep; going out the door at times. The pour over Barista is "usually" friendly and a pour over lover. I always enjoy having a Barista to talk shop with. Unfortunately this wasn't the case in my last visit; can't win them all. 

I digress, I enjoy the outside patio facing the street and the bar in rear that gives you a view of how they roast the beans and then bag them. It's a fun time! Lots of wood is used inside, giving warmth to the shop. Only downside is that some of their merchandise is rather vulgar for my taste and coffee is definitely are the on the pricey side! But worth it every time. 

Bottom line: Their coffee is the stuff of Legends.
author: Raul M.

description: The only thing weaker than their cold brew is their no-wifi policy, which they are strangely proud of.
author: Michael B.

description:
I had an Affogato and it was delicious. I loved the contradictory taste of very bitter coffee and very sweet ice-cream.

Very cool enviroment but it might be too crowded for working
author: Salim M.

description:
I dropped in for an iced coffee and was instantly overwhelmed with Hipsterism. Hipster describes the decor and the people.

I'm not sure how people can work or study here because it can get very loud. There's almost always a crowd too.

This is a great place to bring friends from out of town or with other Hipster locals to socialize about Hipster things. 

The coffee was strong and flavorful. I'm looking forward to come back to try their lattes.
author: Chris W.

description:
This place is upscale trendy -it has a very cool interior design; they roast their own coffee in the back; and they take their coffee seriously (the guy who took my order was friendly, but otherwise, some very serious looking baristas; a separate coffee coffee bar for cold brews; etc). 

This place is very popular: the indoor and out door seating area were packed;  there was a long line to order, and a also a long line to use the restroom. 

The mocha I bought did not taste good, and had clumps of undisolved chocolate powder at the bottom.

In the end, this place seemed more about presentation than good tasting coffee (they had the fancy latte art, but the drink itself wasn't good). The highlight of my visit was the strawberry pastry. 

It we neat to see that coffee roaster in action, but I didn't know what I was observing -it would be cool to have a a display of photographs explaining how the roasting process works -along these lines, the art they have on the wall was if poor quality, and out of place in an otherwise tasteful interior. Also noteworthy is that the girl who made the drink was hawt, and looked like the coffee shop version of Coyote Ugly. And kudos to the young lady with the laptop who made room for me on the bar counter -she was very friendly, and that was much appreciated.

Overall: neat to visit as a tourist, but just not my scene.
author: Man From Atlantis ..

description:
Really fun spot--it's great to see the roasting process while you enjoy your coffee. And it's such a nice big interior. 

The coffee is of course excellent. 

Also note that there is a cool outdoor space worth trying out.
author: JM H.

description:
Great ambiance and decoration - average coffee

Tried this place out - ordered an earl grey strawberry donut pastry, a hot coffee, and a cold brew to go. And the pastry was the best part of my order (something that probably doesn't bode well for a coffee shop).

The cold brew was extremely watered down - I was basically drinking water. They combine a small, small cup with way too much ice, so I was basically drinking 10% coffee, 60% ice and 30% water.  When you combine that with the fact that the place doesn't have WiFi, this place is a solid three-stars. I haven't tried their slow-brew coffee (at this small station on the left after you walk in), so I'll probably return some time for that. Other than that, I wouldn't really recommend this place.
author: Matthew L.

description: The coffee is awesome but too expensive. Truly a hipster place and the epitome of coffee snobbery. I bought some Rwanda Tumba which was truly the best coffee I have ever had!  I will definitely go back and buy beans to make it at home. Mmmmmmm!!!
author: Joan M.

description:
If there was a definition of hipster in the dictionary - it would show a picture of everything thats going on inside this place. 

Beards? check.
Suspenders? check.
Signs made out of foraged vintage toolshed parts? check
Baristas with an attitude? super-check

But even with all the pretentious that is going on here - I have to admit Four Barrel makes some of the best coffee beans in town. Its my go-to spot to buy freshly roasted beans to make my morning espresso at home. My latest craze is their Ethiopia Bulga beans. They have a lovely fruit, sweet overtone and silky smooth finish. Its no wonder they won a Good Food award for it! Just kinda wish they were less snobby.. but hey - as long as they keep making good coffee beans, I'll be ok with a few beards here and there.
author: Henry W.

description: Met a friend for coffee here. Not being a huge coffee drinker, I went for the mocha, which IMO one of the least coffee, coffee drinks. Haha, if you know what I mean. Also picked up the kougin amann  pastry to nibble on. It's pretty messy to eat. But I did my best. Pretty good. But not as good as the my favorite NY bakery. Mocha was good - strong coffee flavor, if that's what you like. Haha. Pretty design. The whole  trip cost me about $10. The place is pretty hipster-ish. Décor is all wooden and brown. Filled with lots of people just hanging out or studying. Seems like a chill place to be on an afternoon.
author: Alison W.

description:
As Bug Bunny would say, "Ehhhh, What's all the hubbub, bub?"

My wife found out about Four Barrel from a coffee loving friend and we have stopped by a few times for coffee but I am not sure why - the coffee is good but not great, there is street parking only (i.e. NO parking), and prices are higher than Peet's or Starbucks.  If you are a people watcher there is ample seating and the crowd is eclectic, to say the least, so you will be sufficiently bemused.  But serious coffee lovers will find that the product falls short of all the hype.

To be blunt, I have had better coffee elsewhere, including many Peet's, so Four Barrel is really not worth the effort to me!
author: Ethan Z.

description: On my first visit to SF, I visited this place very early in the morning. I had a chance to have their vegan lemon poppyseed donut and I loved it. I went the next day again for coffee and I was very impressed by another donut--- orange ginger... i think if I visit SF again this place is definitely going to be on my list
author: Simi P.

description:
I think very few people would not like the interior design at Four Barrel. I personally can't resist those rustic wooden tables and beautifully crafted decor.  It's intimate (small tables) yet spacious, which accommodates the sometimes long lines.

My personal favorite part of Four Barrels is their "slow bar". It gave me an opportunity to understand more about the ratio between coffee beans and water content to create the perfect cup of pour over. Extremely friendly and knowledgeable staff who is willing to educate you if you are interested.
author: Crystal W.

description:
I really like the ambiance here. They roast beans in the back of the shop....mmm...the smell. So. Artisanal.

As for the espresso drinks, could have been fuller-bodied. I ordered a latte, date ordered an almond latte, and sister got a mocha. I tried all three and none were spectacular...just eh. I actually like getting their beans and making drip coffee at home better.

I'll prob give this place another try if I'm within a few blocks, but there are so many other great coffee shops in the neighborhood.
author: Bonnie L.

description: Good coffee! Had a mocha and it was done well. Cool art work and quick service. Plenty of space. Limited ingredients so expect a straightforward, simple menu.
author: Madisyn B.

description: Bitter coffee and service...Don't waste your time here. There are much better places in the area.
author: Karina V.

description: Great location in the mission. They have outdoor public seating space (bar-like) that faces the street and gets sun! It's lovely to grab a seat here on one of the high chairs, drink coffee and watch the world go by. Interior space is also beautiful - open with high ceilings and thoughtfully decorated. There always seems to be a line but service is a bit slow. No longer shocked by the $4 ice coffee price in this area but still high especially for an iced coffee with lots of ice cubes. The coffee was delicious - very smooth and no bitterness.
author: Yin H.

description:
Great coffee in a great neighborhood. Beautiful decoration and environment. 

Loved coming here early morning before work or on the weekends and getting some reading or work done. Really pleasant for working and having quiet coffee chats.

Their pastries aren't my favorite but definitely not a deterrent to coming here.
author: Dana N.

description:
I've always liked this coffee shop and the coffee is good but not enough to rave about it. It's personally a place that I've frequented in the past because of its location.

I brought a friend here and she complained about the misuse of space here. It bothers some people more than others I guess.
author: Katherine D.

description:
This review is for their pour over coffees. This morning was our first time to Four Barrel, and we ordered the Lucas Melo and Rwanda. We are pour over regulars at Philz, and had high hopes for the pour overs here. 

Like other reviewers noted, the pour overs were both way under-extracted and super sour. They also took about 15 or 20 minutes to get from the time we ordered, leaving us extra bummed when we finally got them. They were so sour and undrinkable that we tossed them in the trash and headed out.
author: Ashlee C.

description: The decor may be nice and the space incredibly open and good for working or meeting someone for a chat but this is one of the most unhygienic coffee shops I've been to in any state that I've visited. The place seemed grungy and gross and I had to swat past an army of gnats while walking through the front door. The only thing that had real allure was the cup and saucer that they served my drink in. And don't even get me started on the bathrooms..ick!! The cappuccino was good but not THAT good. I liked that it was slightly less acidic than other ones I've had and smooth going down, but nothing can make up for the sheer lack of concern of the sanitation in this place!
author: Ann K.

description:
(Rating: +++ is perfect)
Atmosphere+++:
Inside of the shop was so stylish like sightglass coffee shop in Soma, which has also a working roasting machine.

Service+++:
Workers are professional about coffee.

Value++:
Average

Latte +++:
It was a good balance between bitter and creamy.
author: Hiromi S.

description: Good looking place, clean and comfortable. However I felt very rushed picking a pastry, as they're only right by the cash register and the barista was waiting on me, and felt ultra rushed again when I was putting away my wallet after ordering. She was piercing into me, waiting and it was awkward! Strong coffee if you like that. Not a whole lot of options but that's the appeal I believe. Got mine with almond milk though for all you vegan/lactose-free people out there. Super clean all gender bathroom, and the seating facing Valencia street is cute! Rustic and charming. However to me, it doesn't feel very warm and "homey" but more trendy and hipster. Not gunna be a regular but i'll pop in a couple times here and there.
author: Erica L.

description: Very good coffee, if you are latte lover this is the place, The only thing that didn`t help to much is that it looked pack inside. Service ok.
author: Lorraine M.

description: Fantastic coffee, great space, and the nicest baristas. They have 9-10 coffees freshly roasted at all times and a full pour over bar with 3-4 options. You can watch them roast all their coffee in the back too which is cool. There is plenty of seating and The baristas are so friendly and really want you to learn and appreciate the coffee- the barista even gave me his personal coffee sample to take home since I could not buy a full bag. A MUST for anyone visiting SF who lives coffee.
author: Farrell M.

description:
Well that sucked.

Popped in to grab an almond milk mocha and a slice of almond cake. I love their lattes, and was in the mood to try their mocha so i did.

Service was friendly as usual.

I noticed the barista seemed to be having some trouble mixing the chocolate with the espresso as I saw him attempting to stir it in my cup. He added a splash of the steamed almond milk to help the chocolate dissolve, and gave it another stir. Seeming satisfied, he topped off my drink and gave it to me. 

It was not very hot, which I don't mind because I can drink it without waiting for it too cool. I quickly noticed the drink seemed gritty and "pulpy" I got home a couple of minutes later and opened the cup to investigate, and found it swirling with a ton of undissolved chocolate, i gave it a ferocious stirring trying to settle the mess. I sipped it a bit longer, then set it aside since it wasn't very enjoyable. After a while i reheated it and gave it some more ferocious stirring in hopes of getting it mixed properly, but to no avail. Sat around for a few minutes, wringing my hands and debating whether or not I would be playing the role of That Asshole Who Came To Complain About Her Drink. After wringing my hands about it, and anticipating the Difficult Customer treatment I decided $5.50 was too much of my poor person money to spend on something that was bound to go down the sink drain.

So I went back to Four Barrel.

I went back to Four Barrel and never in my life have I been spoken to so condescendingly as I was just now. This guy talked to me like I was the dumbest kid in class who just got caught eating paste and had the gall to ask why it didn't taste good. I approached the counter, popped the lid off of my mocha slurry and asked if they're supposed to be like this. The guy behind the counter cuts me off, 

"Wellll, what kind of miillllllk is iiiiit?"

"It's almon-"

"Is it allllmond miiiilk?"

"Yes, it's almond milk."

he leans across the counter for added school marm effect.

"That's just what almond milk dooooes. It's just like that."

"Really? Because I've had a lot of almond milk before and-"

"We use this brand almond milk called Cah-Lee-Fah (yes, he enunciated the shit out of 'Califa') and the batches are just different alllll the tiiiime."

"You're telling me the chucks floating in my cup are-"

"Almond milk. How long ago did you order this?"

"About 40 minutes ago, but it was like that as soon as I got it."

"Uh-huh. All i can dooo for you is make you another one. Is that what you want?"

"Uh... Sure."

He whips around, tells the barista my order in the most clipped, "Can you make this bitch what she wants?" tone imaginable, and I step back feeling like fresh ca-ca scraped off a shoe onto a curb.

Guess what? The allllmonnnnd milllk from Cah-Lee-Fah mocha I have now isn't a chocolate and almonnnd miiilllk slurry, but a nice, not too sweet mocha, so guess it wasn't just what alllmonnnd miiiilk just doeeees after all. 

The barista behind the counter obviously knew what he was doing as I watched him make my drink, thoroughly stir the chocolate with a whisk, then pour my milk into the cup.

Happy with the driiiink, not happy with the Serviiiiice. By the by, I've worked in cafes as a barista for 10 years, don't bullshit a bullshitter.
author: meeks b.

description:
I momentarily lost recollection of where I was upon coming here this morning for the first time. Industrial-looking interior + flannel + bicycles + black rimmed glasses + MacBook Pros... were we in San Francisco or Portland? 

The fact that today I was wearing a leather jacket and red flannel over jeans and combat boots was not lost on me. I realized, with a shrug of resignation, I should just stop cracking old ass jokes about hipsters and embrace who I've become in my old age. I mean, if you can't beat 'em, join 'em right?

Anyway, great coffee.
author: Aivy C.

description: Some of the nicest coffee I have ever had. This place is really charming. I had a cappuccino and some toast with cashew butter and jam. Delicious!
author: Carol D.

description:
Some of of the best-prepared coffee in San Francisco. That's saying something. The roasted beans are top-notch and the barista make pour-overs and espresso-based drinks perfectly. They can be accompanied by odd yet delicious local baked goods as well. The interior of the shop is quite interesting (as most roasteries are nowadays) and out front they have a cool seating area with stools and high bars right next to the street. Not only that but it's right down the street from Munroe Motors, a sweet motorcycle shop that's fun to drink a coffee while walking around.

My only gripes are the layout. There isn't much seating and the really annoying thing is the separation of the pour-over bar and customer line from the "everything else" counter and customer line. It creates for crowding and confusion by the entrance. The pour-over bar also has different hours than the regular counter. Why, Four Barrel, why?
author: Patrick S.

description:
Here are my reasons for the 3 stars:
Pros:
The flavor of the coffee is very good .  it is strong but not acidity.
The baristas are super nice and cool they always smile!!!
The pastries are good not a lot of them but always good and fresh.
Cons:
I like my americano coffee hot !!!! but they always give me my coffee warm eventhough I specifically ask them to please give me my coffee hot  I go to a lot of coffee shops (LIKE LITERALLY LOTS OF COFFEE SHOPS) and i always get my americano hot. And it is not cheap coffee so i think i deserve my coffee the way a like it.
The bathroom  is always  beyond dirty!!! I do not get it.
But i am going to give it another try .
See u later Four Barrel   !!!!!!!
author: Cecilia C.

description:
The quintessential SF coffee shop. 

When you have visitors in town, bring 'em here. The neo-rustic decor, hipster-ed out baristas and quality coffee will satisfy all their expectations about our city and more.

And who am I kidding -- as a local, I freaking love this place too. I'm especially fond of their cappuccinos with almond milk which come adorned with flowers or hearts. (Did I mention the coffee art is on point here? Makes for pretty Instagram photos. Just sayin'.)
author: Tiffany W.

description: One of the best almond milk lattes Ive ever had. The place is cute to boot. Plenty of space to hang out or work. Seatings outside as well.,
author: Karena H.

description:
My girlfriend and I went here two days in a row for the pour over bar. The baristas were friendly both times and the coffee was excellent. Four over roasts their own
Beans and they're known all over california for their coffee. They also have a great selection of brewing equipment if you're looking to make a better cup at home.
author: Hank C.

description: Coffee was great but the pastry, like croissant and muffin, were not impressive. Inside seating area is always so packed but I don't recommend sitting outside! Very dusty.
author: Kenny K.

description: The setting is top notch. And the coffee is even better. Walking up to the slow bar you are handed your beans to smell before your coffee is made. The gentlemen behind the bar did not just know coffee but lived it but there wasn't an entitled arrogant bone in him. He was friendly and more than willing to share any information he could with me and my friend. He was engaging and we learned lots while we watched him make our coffee. And then the coffee itself. Whoa! This was some of the freshest most flavorful coffee I've ever had. It was one of those cups that the flavors ebb and flow as the coffee cools down and it revealed a whole new aspect of the coffee. That's when you know they've done a good job. If I could give more than five stars I would. I love this place.
author: Logan T.

description:
Delicious coffee - nutty, smooth, rich, buttery goodness. Minus one star for the price "/ Small almond milk latte $5. 

Hipster. Lines are usually long. No dogs allowed inside but there's a cute outdoor seating area!
author: Alyssaaa S.

description: Hipstery, spacious, nice decor, and as pricey as you'd come to expect a place like this in SF to be. The menu is just the basics. If you want a nice photo for the experience, ice coffee isn't quite as satisfying as the lattes.
author: Joy Y.

description: Four barrel is by far the best quality of coffee in SF.i talked with John, one of the managers typical coffee chat and he was the most non pretentious coffee guru I met in all of SF. Thank you so much for the killer cortado and awesome bag of beans
author: Kimberly K.

description: Well, I've always liked their beans and consider paying $5 for an iced latte a treat instead of an assault on my wallet. Except for today, I got a nasty surprise at the bottom of my drink in the form of a dead fly. Nice.
author: Sally T.

description:
In stark contrast to Janice C's review below, I am a coffee connoisseur (wait, what does that even mean?). And I am a caffeine addict. Convicted. My skin peels and my hair starts falling out if I don't get my fix every AM.

South American Beans. Own roastery. Industrial interior.

Pour overs, lattes, espressos, cappuchinos. Made with the best beans in the city. No kidding. I sent my friend Phil home early to get here, stepped on a star buck on the way, and waived Peet goodbye.

Four Barrel becomes my new Ritual.
author: Sebastian F.

description:
Everyone has a different personal taste for coffee.  

My personal taste is that I don't really care for Four Barrel, mainly because in my opinion, it has a very tar-like flavor.

The shop itself is cute, but there are hardly any outlets, which is a little odd.  There is also NO wi-fi.  I'm guessing they don't want the "come and stay all day" crowd, but either way, it's a coffee shop...there should be outlets and wi-fi.

I would probably consider giving this place 3 stars if it wasn't for the pretentious barista behind the counter.  She was definitely giving me the "I work at Four Barrel on Valencia so I'm the shit" vibe, which I found quite uninviting.
author: Juliana K.

description:
The coffee is pretty good here, the space is 100% WHEELCHAIR-ACCESSIBLE, and there's ample seating...but I still can't give Four Barrel their 5th star.  Here's why:

1.  They don't have artificial sweeteners for my coffee.  Sure, I know what you're thinking:  Sugar is cool again, because, like, you know, it's totally naaaatural and stuff.  Plus, those artificial sweeteners will give you brain lesions, m'kay?  Nope, sorry.  Sugar gives me migraines and the artificial sweetener I use, Splenda causes neither brain bleeds nor headaches por moi...so, seriously, Four Barrel?  Cut the snob routine and just put out a few packets of the yellow stuff for those of us who want it, m'kay?

2.  There is a SERIOUS hipster vibe here.  This is firmly established by the disaffected baristas who work here, and who will be just barely polite, but never friendly, and certainly never offer anything resembling a look of approval.

3.  This coffee shop does not have Wi-Fi.  Yup, I know what you're thinking:  But, Amy, how can a super-cool coffee shop not offer such a fundamental item as complimentary Wi-Fi to their guests??  After all, even Starbucks, Peets, and even McDonalds give that to their patrons!  Nope, sorry, this place is a hipster up-scale coffee shop.  They're too good for people sitting there on their laptops.  

In fact, they really don't want you to stick around in general.  Nothing about the place feels warm or inviting, from those cold cement floors to the vacuous 1/2 mile trek from the front door to the register...you could even host an ironic square dancing party with this much space!  But it most certainly doesn't feel like a place you'd want to hunker down with a cup of joe, relax, and hang out for a while.

So, for now, 4-stars for the delicious Iced Lattes I get here.  That 5th star will remain my hostage until Four Barrel's Hipster Overlords hear my plea and put out a few lousy packets of Splenda for the rest of us plebes.  I have no hope that they will actually institute free Wi-Fi...after all, isn't that what the kids are using their cell phones for these days?!
author: Amy L.

description:
I am no coffee connoisseur, but I do know the difference between good and bad coffee. The coffee at Four Barrel is good; no, it's very good. I usually get their espresso, but if you're in the mood for tea, their Old Tree Yunnan Red is an excellent option. All the baristas there are cool and hipster, and are willing to help you try out their different coffees. The earthen cups in which they serve the tea and coffee, and also the fancy German machinery at the rear, adds to the vibe and feel of the place.

The space is quite large, but finding a spot during peak times can get difficult. They also have an outside seating space if you're in the mood to enjoy the San Francisco wind.

They don't have WiFi, so you might end up burning up some data tethering from your phone. Alternatively, you could take this as an opportunity to get away from tech (don't we all need that), and read a book, write in your journal, or just make a new friend.
author: Pradyumn S.

description: They are the best-served coffee in town. They currently the only one using Jersey Milk.
author: Justin L.

description: Cool concept but the music was too loud for a place with high ceilings -- had to go outside just to have a conversation. The five dollar "ginger pull apart" pastry was dry and tasteless. Cashier didn't offer to warm it up so I'm guessing they don't warm up pastries. Waiting in line will come with your fair share of swatting at flies/gnats. Coffee prices seemed a little outrageous, but maybe I haven't been to enough SF coffee shops to make a fair comparison.
author: Tony B.

description:
Had the opportunity to try Four Barrel Coffee for free and for the first time, thanks to Zagat's #SF30under30. This place has a nice setup from the outdoor street side patio all the way to the inside spacious seating area. I was really surprised at how big this place is, given that this is San Francisco after all and other coffee shops would not be half this size. Hard to imagine this place would ever be short on seats, so good for groups and hanging out, yes. Unfortunately, if you plan on being productive on the computer, this place does not offer any wifi. 

The entrance is a bit confusing initially when you walk in, first you see the pour over station to your left and then a register in the front serving the usual coffee's, latte's and cappuccino's etc. Since the coffee was free, I decided to try a few things from both sides. I tried an ice coffee black that was a bit weak in flavor, so I tried to save it by adding some sugar and throwing in almond milk that was readily available at the counter. Unfortunately, not much I could do to save it since I didn't want a heavy dose of sugar in my cup. I then tried a cup of cappuccino which I thoroughly enjoyed and if I do another visit, might be something I'd order again.

At the pour over station, I asked for a roast that was a bit earthy and nutty, the barista was really friendly and helpful and suggested a particular roast that was specific to my request. The coffee itself was also weak in flavor, can't help but say I was disappointed that a carefully crafted pour over didn't meet my expectation. The thing I noticed from all three drinks was their coffee was not bitter and low on acidity, which was a good thing, but as far as flavor goes it didn't really make me crave more at the end of my visit. As far as strength goes, you would think after having 3 different tastings I would be jacked up on caffeine the rest of the day, but not an ounce of jitter hit me at all. I was glad I got the opportunity to try a new coffee spot and to consider something other than my usual cup of Philz, but I won't be switching blends anytime soon.
author: Limuel G.

description: Amazing place, you'll only get coffee there, no pastries (you can do like me and then go to Tartine 2 blocks away). The place is epic, has some sort of bean factory where they make there own coffee. They have several types of coffee - Kenyan, Colombian... Had a latte, it was great! They don't have any pastries though :/
author: Rachida I.

description: Good coffee, and for those lactose intolerant people, free almond milk!! Although there are plenty of seats, this place gets pretty packed. Learn to make new friends and join a table with random coffee drinkers!
author: Janet H.

description:
Decided to try something new.... I arrived and asked for something Bold (Dark) but with some extra caffine. The guy with the nose piercing said we do one cup at a time of the Salvadorian. I asked if it was Bold and I just realized he evaded the question and said it was chocolaty .... well it was not a one cup at a time, which normally tells me that it's not made thru the machine like at Philz, and really did not meet my expectations. 

The real concern was before he filled my Contigo I asked him to please fill all the way to the fill line and he said sure. We'll he didn't. Most of all he did fill it after I asked again only to walk away and hear him commenting to the next customer "it was not that much to fill, he was just very picky"

1.the coffee was not at all what I wanted
2. I asked to fill to fill line but he didn't
3. He made me a joke to his next customer
4. I paid for the coffee not him

Happy Sunday
author: A D.

description:
For the amount of space at Four Barrel Coffee, there is not all that much seating inside, especially during busy times. It's cool that they have outdoor patio seating with convenient bike rakes. They play their music loud and don't have any WiFi or outlets, so it's definitely more of a place to grab a coffee and pastries with friends instead of doing work. I haven't had the pastries yet so maybe that in itself would add an extra star to my review.

I just had an iced coffee which was okay. The service was okay as well. I'm not a fan of the animal heads on the walls, but I guess they're cool. It's like staying at a cabin in the mountains or woods. I'm not sure what people are fascinated by. Just seems like a regular 'ol coffee shop to me!
author: Stefanie C.

description:
Have a real coffee grinder at the shop so it was pretty cool. Apparently the coffee here is better than Philz. You can really customise your coffee if you know coffee really well.

Tried the mocha and loved it as it wasn't really chocolately but just the right mix of coffee and chocolate.
author: Yilin T.

description:
Oooooh, such a hard decision to make. I went to Four Barrel this past December and ever since I've been torn apart whether or not I want to write a review for this place. The reason for this is because coffee is such a subjective topic to be giving opinions on, so many people love coffee and there are so many varieties of coffee. Me personally, I'm more of a sweet-tooth coffee person. I also enjoy French-press Vietnamese style iced coffees. If you're like me, please do not waste your money here, because you will not enjoy it. Four Barrel is more for the refined coffee taster, the person who loves strong bitter coffee that's going to kick you in the face really hard. But hey, everyone is allowed to love whatever coffee they want, and this place just doesn't have the coffee for me. WITH THAT SAID, I am not basing my 3 stars on their coffee, because that would be completely unfair for their company. 

Rather, I am basing my 3 stars off of the entire experience I received at Four Barrel, I'm talking service now. Let's be honest, the service really wasn't that great. And for a highly reviewed place like this I kind of expected a lot better. The vibe that you get from the workers here would be pretentious, you kind of get that vibe from the customers as well but the ones I talked to were all very nice. I wish I could say the same for the workers. I wanted to buy a package of coffee for my mom, and since I'm not some type of coffee wizard I felt the need to ask someone who worked there. The person I asked wasn't very nice about it and got up in my face, started asking me questions about coffee that I had no idea how to answer. When I was curious and asked more questions, it only seemed to upset the young man, it almost looked like he was in pain because I didn't look like I trusted his judgement. 

I also ordered a "chocolate-claw" pastry and they didn't even offer to heat it up for me. I would've asked, but wow, didn't really feel welcome to ask any more questions. Overall it was an okay experience, kind of seems like a place the college-version of Ted Mosby would love hanging out in. Super hipster if you're into that type of stuff.
author: Kyle L.

description:
I was stoked on trying Four Barrel directly from the source. Well, I'm happy to report its every bit of a coffee Mecca as I could ever have imagined. It's like stepping into someone's awesomely gnarly loft apartment which happens to hold a coffee roaster, a pour over bar, incredibly beautiful espresso machines, dudes with the most righteous beards I've ever seen, hip kids and their cool backpacks, and air that is only truly breathed by the avant garde. 

It was badass. The place is just awesome. 

The pour over bar is a really nice touch, too. For practicality's sake, it does make more sense to separate this time-consuming process from other beverage options. They had several varieties to choose from, too. 

Due to our hoofing it up and down the Mission hills, I went with an iced coffee. It was splendid. 

I would come back here in a heartbeat. I'd love to grab a pour over next time and also grab something out of their small bakery case. 

Long live Four Barrel.
author: Benjamin G.

description: Great coffee. Really delicious. Really nice space, too.
author: Jen G.

description:
In my humble opinion, Four Barrel is more about seeing and being seen in a hipster hangout than it is about the coffee. Your best bet is trying out the more unique brews from the drip coffee station. The main barista station serves up OK coffee that's more smooth than bold. That having been said, service is always cheerful, engaging, and helpful. 

The hipster atmosphere is certainly the big draw to this place, and the vibe is loud and social. The lack of power outlets and wi-fi (hint: you can try stealing free, unsecure wi-fi from the nearby public housing project) underscores the fact that this isn't a place to sit by yourself staring at a laptop screen. Sounds from the roasters churning in the background only enhance the lively ambience. The action has spilled outside, with their beautiful parklet out front (complete with bike racks), and even to the alleyway out back, if their infamous "mucho smoocho" sign on the back door is any indication.

While I prefer the coffee at Ritual and Blue Bottle, I'm all for more lively, social coffeehouses, and the West Bay is blessed to have so many of these places - especially on the same street.
author: Vincent L.

description: Maybe it's just me (judging by the reviews...), but I wasn't thrilled with the coffee here. I am a cappuccino fiend and would ballpark my consumption at around 5,000+ over the course of my life (not kidding). The coffee here just tasted bizarre. I was trying to get into it and couldn't. The ambiance inside is really cute, but it was tough to find a place to sit. There is some outdoor seating, so try to catch Four Barrel on a nice day -- if you enjoy their coffee.
author: Nic Z.

description:
Good coffee/good latte art, alright service, no wifi.

Came here on a Thursday afternoon and ordered a mocha. They have a simple menu with your coffee basics. My mocha had beautiful latte art (with hearts!!), which I loved. And it tasted pretty good too! Not the best mocha, but considering all the amazing mochas I've had around SF/the bay, it was in the same league. Not as sweet and chocolatey as I would've liked. Especially since I ordered a mocha over a reg coffee to satisfy my sweet tooth that day. And it was a little too foamy. 

The decor inside is definitely hip/hipstery. The place definitely attracts an interesting blend of people (which makes for great people watching!). There is a good blend of people coming in to read, catch up with friends, and coming in an out on a coffee run. Regardless, there's a good influx of people and the place is constantly pretty busy. They roast their own coffee beans inside, if you're interested in watching. And they have bar seating next to it, if you really do want to watch haha. The rest of the seating is somewhat limited. The tables are pretty small, so it's not great to actually do work on. But it's suitable for reading or just sitting and talking.

ALSO, THERE IS NO WIFI. Which means, it's hard to get any actual work done. Plus, I ended up mostly just people watching anyways. 

And bathroom is nice, but there's only one. 

I'll probably be in the neighborhood again and try their coffee next time. But really, I'm not in too much of a rush...
author: Julie L.

description:
Come to Four Barrel for the ambiance.  Don't get me wrong - the espresso is great, but the feel of the place is the epitome of bougie hipster cafe, complete with the roastery in the back and welded metal street seating.

My favorite combo at Four Barrel is a cappuccino and one of their scones.

Careful coming on the weekends and planning to camp out to do work - it gets pretty busy.
author: Jacqueline R.

description:
Located in the heart of the ever bustling Mission district, Four Barrel is probably one of the pioneers of craft/ hipster/ yuppie/ gourmet/ specialty coffee houses in San Francisco. I love the rustic interior decor, the high ceilings, and the ample amount of tables, counter space, and seating available. This place is HUGE! There is also outdoor seating on the sidewalk space in front. 

It's a perfect place for a coffee pit stop or coffee date, and it's even a good place to get some studying and work done. 

They roast their own blends on location and have fresh grounds ready for purchase. Their coffee roast is similar to that of Front Cafe -- medium roast. I tend to like my coffee espresso a bit darker and bolder. 

I always opt for the almond latte and aww over the latte art each time. I love the brown mugs they serve their drinks in. Service was friendly and quick. Prices are decent for craft coffee. My almond latte was about $4.

Definitely worth a try if you're looking to get that quality craft coffee experience in San Francisco!
author: Ellen W.

description:
Excellent raspberry chocolate scone. I got the house drip coffee and I was less than impressed. Weak, flavorless, nothing I'd return for. Also I think their containers labeled "dairy" are just milk,  was disappointed because I assumed it would be cream. Cool ambiance tho.

*update: I heard from someone at the business, they've gone back to putting out half & half instead of whole milk and the dispensers are labeled
author: Vanessa M.

description:
I came here upon a Saturday evening and this place was more or less packed. 
Here are the pros and cons of this place:
Pros: Pretty shop!! Gorgeous pictures on walls, nice interior, open bar, record corner, even the condiment bar was beautiful. The outside seating areas are so aesthetic and there are even bike racks! 
Another pro was fast service. Though there was a line, our coffee came out very very quickly.
Cons: The price. Okay honestly how is iced coffee 6 dollars. It was one cup, about a medium size, also they fill it up half way with ice so it's basically done after 3 sips. 6 freaking bucks. Never drinking coffee here again lol.
Overall, would come for the shop but coffee is super super super expensive... You could buy about 2 cups of coffee elsewhere. But again, very pretty shop!!
author: Diana O.

description: Maybe best coffee in town. Very hipster but liked the architecture and how they set up the place. Also good to meet random people.
author: Wolfgang G.

description:
I love the atmosphere here, and a simple
Iced latte really delivers a unique flavor that I haven't tasted before. Love the vibe here. It's very Valencia Street, which I suppose may be a bit polarizing to some. Personally, I dig it.
author: Patrick F.

description: The quest for coffee continues, and we (finally!) made it to Four Barrel this past weekend.  First of all, Four Barrel probably wins in the category of best looking establishment.  Sightglass might have two stories,but Four Barrel's seating area makes everything feel so cozy!  I also deeply appreciate that their pour over area is separate and you even get an opportunity to have a one-on-one with your barista and talk about what's being served.  The barista who made our drinks was probably one of the nicest people we've come across at coffee place like this, and it was so pleasant to have a casual conversation while enjoying your coffee.  Parking is a little tricky around here, but otherwise, I absolutely love Four Barrel, their coffee, their shop, and their people.  We'll definitely be back soon!
author: Lisa I.

description: This is about as trendy as the coffee joints get but still stays true to the bean. Very artsy bike rack out front and they are always spinning great vinyl over the speakers inside. Nice outdoor seating if you just want to people watch or go inside to see their pour over and espresso process. Super friendly staff that are very approachable and not at all pretentious. You will pay a premium for their Whole beans or coffee drinks, but they're well worth it. There are also small snacks from local bakers and typically have some sort of sweets if you want to take something to go.  Also got a small retail section where you can get your coffee fix on invite all of the tools needed to homebrew perfection. Lines some time can be an issue, depending on what time of day you come, but where are they not in this neighborhood?
author: David M.

description:
As in all things food and drink, I only want the best in my coffee. I used to drink Starbucks, but ever since I've discovered "third wave coffee" (Blue Bottle, Four  Barrel, Intelligentsia, etc), I can no longer bring myself to drink Starbucks' bitter and horrible tasting coffee. You see I like to drink my coffee black and Four Barrel's coffee, drip or espresso, can be enjoyed in its unadulterated state.  Four Barrel indeed is one of the best coffee roasters in San Francisco. 

I've only been to their cafe on Valencia. Have you been there? The little parklet in front of their cafe is so cool--a great place to soak in the sun while you're enjoying your coffee. Inside, it is a little dark with all that wood, but there is a lot of space for sitting and milling around, and the high ceiling helps. 

I've taken a "Better Brewing at Home Class" at their Valencia cafe. If you're serious about your coffee and want to learn how to brew it and learn about the differences in taste for each brewing method, take this class. It's an hour and a half class and their trainer will demonstrate each brewing process that you can do at home. There must have been at least 8 types that he showed us. He showed us what the grind size looks like for each brewing method because that matters and let us taste the coffee from each brewing method. Mind you this was at 5 pm, so you will come out of that class all buzzed with caffeine. Don't think I slept early that night, but it was all worth it! Out of all the brewing methods, my favorites ended up being the Chemex, V60 and the Aeropress.   The V60 produced the best cup but it is also the trickiest one.  The Chemex method is what I ended up adopting for its ease and great results.

I follow Four Barrel on IG and I swear they post the coolest events there.  We went to their Cocktail + Coffee party at Trou Normand.  That was a blast! For $30, we had a number of regular cocktails and cocktails with cold and hot brew coffee. Just recently, I went to their Cowgirl Creamery cheese talk at their training lab.
