Cheesemongers talked about all things related to cheese and we tasted six different kinds of cheeses. We also paired the cheeses with Four Barrel's cold brew and a couple of their hot brew coffees. I thought the cold brew went well the cheeses. Oh, and did I mention this cheese event was free? Amazing. 

People who are passionate about what they do create great products and Four Barrel is passionate about coffee.  If you want to make better coffee at home, sign up for their class.  If you want a latte or an espresso made for you, visit them at their Valencia and Portola cafes!
author: Hazel C.

description:
My favorite coffee place in the Mission. Good music, good vibes, good coffee. I always just get a normal house coffee but everything is really good! Super close to 16th/Mission BART so it's super convenient if you're outside of SF. 
Definitely one of my favorite coffee places EVER.
author: Kyle D.

description:
I mean, yeah. It's pretentious as f. But there are boat heads on the wall. That's cool, right?!

Jokes aside the people here are kind, the service is quick and the coffee is great.

Just don't ask for anything that's craved at Starbucks.
author: Elle B.

description:
Service is just fine. Decor is gorgeous. Why oh why do you refuse to use soy? Sure, soy in excess is unhealthy but anything in excess can be harmful. Are you using almonds to support a California crop? I doubt it, but please let me know! AND! almonds are water guzzling jerks, totally unsustainable for Cali! 

Almond milk heated or cold is just yukk!! How many people that work there have tried all of the coffee + espresso beverages w/ almond milk and think it tastes great? If it doesn't taste great don't serve it. It doesn't taste great, so I will no longer and you don't have an alternative for me. :/ So I must say goodbye.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
The coffee here is definitely good and worth trying, although the whole experience of visiting the shop isn't ideal.

I've visited Four Barrel Coffee only on weekends, so I have no idea how is it on weekdays, Every weekend this place is packed! The logic outcomes are long lines, lack of places to sit, and smelly wash room. 
I know that Four Barrel tries to fight the computer sitters by eliminating the electricity outlets. Meaning, computer sitters occupy the place as long as their battery lasts, but as a battery life grows longer, and they stay there longer too. 
Lines to get a cup of coffee are long and boring. First you wait for the register, then you wait to get the coffee.
The line to One And Only washroom is long too. Although it decorated beautifully, it is absolutely disgusting by the middle of the day. No clean up schedule is visible around facilities. Although, they are showcasing interesting products like powder hand soap and hand drying fan to bring fresh air in the smelly hell of public WC. 

Hopefully, this will give the management idea how to improve customers' experience.
author: Julia G.

description: Lately I've been coming here every Saturday morning and I initially really liked the cappuccino, interior and the fact there is no wireless. After the first few weeks of this routine, it's become tiresome to wait on the disinterested baristas to complete making the drink at their glacial pace and then set it out seemingly without a word so that I can keep getting up and checking to see if the liquid gold  has been delivered.  Or maybe I'm just cranky until I've had my coffee.
author: Tom B.

description:
One of the best lattes I've ever tried! I love the milk that they use. It finally tastes like coffee you would get in Europe. I did notice that some baristas are being a little sarcastic towards customer which made me feel uncomfortable. I'm leaving you tips guys so don't roll your eyes on me. 
But coffee was excellent!
author: John A.

description:
Four Barrel Coffee has an atmosphere that's unmatched, but a product that is at many other locations exceeded.

Star 1: How was the service and atmosphere?

As per my header, the atmosphere at Four Barrel is exceptional, and is without a doubt one of the best I've seen at any coffee shop from New York through LA. The dual bar and table seating on each side of the counter is unique, and the abundant outdoor seating is an added bonus when the weather is nice. Service is fast and friendly. Star Granted.

Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost?

In the neo-Starbucks age of $5-$10 mochas and specialty drinks, I'm down for anything under $5. FBC's $4.25 mocha falls on the tail end of my sweet spot, and the presentation matches the fair price:

http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=bSoqRNFjMFkxmhJcR4QjXg&userid=OKX-V5j_qfuOebeHeWGrHg

Star Granted.

Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?

Just okay. I'm a mocha fan, but my chocolately treat was a bit too heavy on the 'treat'. It was a bit weak, sugary to a fault even though I didn't add any, and the real downside was a massive clump of chocolate in the bottom even after stirred as a result of the mocha simply not being hot enough. Plain and simple, the product didn't blow me away. No Stars Granted.

Star 5: Would you eat here every day if you could?

The atmosphere draws in all of the stars here, and it's the reason I could come here every single day. Boost the product a bit and this becomes a favorite. Star Granted.
author: Paul V.

description: This coffee shop is quite noisy with the loud music and conversations. they have quite the selection of coffee but it doesn't make up for the lackluster ambience. coffee shops should be quiet places for folks to carry on light conversation, read or work on their laptops. the latte itself was fine although they only offered almond milk as an alternative to dairy. their dairy is supposed to be from a farm that produced milk for lactose intolerant patrons. be mindful of the noise, if that doesn't bother you then you'll probably enjoy their beans.
author: Mario C.

description:
When you can spend half an hour chatting with a hawt viking, what do you have to lose?

Very tasty, yet heady and strong -- coffee, people. I'm talking about the coffee. 

I opted for the individual drip, while the line of about 15 people for regular brew stretched the length of the place. Hey, I was on vacation. 

I went for the Colombian, but had to shamefully add milk because it was too strong for my palate. Let's just chalk that up to me being distracted by the barista's silky,  blond locks and not reading the adorable tiny chalkboards next to each glass canister of beans on the individual drip counter. They're described like wine on a wine list, and it's pretty spot on. But obviously not for amateurs.

Some tables along the edge of the warehousey space and a counter along the back where you can watch them get to working with their beans.

The viking also fed me some tasty treats made by a local artisan baker. I mean, of course they're made locally and are awesome. Of course. I love you, SF.
author: Claire F.

description: It's a fantastic place to drink some locally-roasted coffee.  We recently café crawled our way around San Francisco and were pleased with the quality and diversity of the local coffee roasting scene. So if you find yourself in San Francisco, don't hesitate on trying Four barrel coffee shop.
author: Air C.

description:
Trendy alert!

A beautiful interior space to marvel at. Loved the outdoor parklet, as well!

Strong coffee. Made for true connoisseurs. Can you handle it?
author: Mansi A.

description: Absolutely as delicious as I remembered it. My only crime was waiting so long to get back. Incredible coffee, super cool space, very friendly staff, and good tunes playing. Highly recommend
author: Matt V.

description: Iced coffee on a warm Winter day in SF. Perfect. Cant go wrong with an iced coffee. Bf got the Kenya pour over and it's delicious! Ambience is chill. Kind of busy for a Sunday early afternoon but not unbearable. Found seats easily. I'd come back if I were in the neighborhood, again.
author: Roxane P.

description:
My review comes a little late as I have been there so many times and after debating with myself about the place, I gave it a four star. Well, don't expect a lot by looking at so many cool reviews is what I would say. I definitely love this place, the rock music in the background, cool interior, make your own coffee beans and plenty of space to sit and do your work. But I was still debating as they don't usually have much to eat. I have been there working or chatting with my friends long hours and I wished they had something more in the food menu. Day before yesterday I ordered a Vegetarian Tart and I thought it wasn't fresh enough that I couldn't finish it. 

Coming to their drinks menu, I love their coffee cups and that would be my best latte so far. I am a Vanilla Latte fan but they don't have it in their menu :(

Overall, I would say my ratings are specially for the place than drinks/food and you will definitely end up going to this place again and again!
author: Pratibha S.

description:
There's nothing like a Sunday in San Francisco - except maybe a Sunday in Los Angeles. (I want to see how many San Franciscans that upsets). 

ANYWAYS - 
After making friends with a woman who owns a summer home in Connecticut on the BART we took a quick walk from the 16th and Mission Bart station to this cool little spot. Though, it's pretty large for urban standards. Immediately you're hit with the coffee trend that has been sweeping the nation as of late. And don't worry, I'm not judging - I love the coffee trend. Oh and I love coffee too. 

Coffee is solid. Mocha was a dark mocha too which is grand. 

The workers are pretty chill as well. I know a lot of people expect a certain level of judge from the coffee crowd but that was definitely not the case today. Though there was a brief discussion about why I wanted my espresso over ice hahahaha. I like iced drinks, okay!!

The price is pretty average for the product as well. $3 Americano and $5 Mocha. 

Overall - good job today, SF. Good job.
author: Paul Z.

description:
This love this place, there are a number of different seats enjoy an eye opening brew.  Good music for working too :)

It's usually crowded by the afternoon though so get there early or you might have to take the coffee to go.
author: Erik V.

description: Not only do these guys make a great cup of coffee but, they have to be the nicest people working in the city. Seriously. One of the gals that works the counter is so genuine and kind I would come back even if the coffee weren't so good. love it.
author: JP A.

description: Valencia wouldn't be the same without this place. No shame in admitting house made almond milk and in house roasting takes coffee to another level. Thank you.
author: Original G.

description:
These guys take their coffee very seriously. Get in, order your coffee and sit down thank you very much.

The coffee is delicious and full bodied in flavour. It is super cool to be able to watch the coffee beans being fire roasted from a bench up the back of the warehouse and they have these things called tortels* that made me look at coffee in a whole new light. I now blame this place for making me crave dark chocolate and caramel chews every time I order a coffee.

That said, if you're looking for pleasantries more than a smashing coffee, then you might try another spot in town.

*A tortel: A gooey, chewy, caramel like square full of almonds and a dark chocolate base.
author: Chloe R.

description: Probably my favorite coffee house in SF and a great place to hang when craving outstanding coffee and a cool hipster atmosphere.  Parking is rather tough where you might need to circle around the block a few times, but stopping into Four Barrel is so worth the effort.  Pour overs are made perfectly, so are cappuccinos or really ... any coffee ordered.  We stop in during every SF visit to thoroughly enjoy the coffee and to take advantage of taking home some of our favorites.  Since I'm a decaf drinker, the decaf expresso blend is a regular choice that has elements of rhubarb and red plum.  Another new favorite is the decaf los chelazos that reflects milk chocolate dipped almonds and apricot marmalade.  Both selections go through a proprietary reverse osmosis decaffeination Swiss Water Process in British Columbia.  Whole bean coffee runs a little high ($20+/12oz bag) but perfection doesn't come cheap :-).
author: Kelly P.

description: My mom and I stopped by to grab some coffee on our way to Knead Patissiere (I think it was about 6-min away?). We to-go order a latte and cappuccino, which were decorated with some lovely floral and heart foam art, respectively. Taste-quality wise, my mom said she really enjoyed her latte, and I loved my cappuccino with the addition of almond milk in accompaniment to my pomme d'amour from Knead. The slight bitterness of the cappuccino really complimented the sweetness of the pastry well. I wasn't aware that Four Barrel had pastries of their own until I got there, so I will have to try that on my next visit!
author: AJ S.

description:
I was lucky enough to enjoy a leisurely Wednesday morning with the bf, so we decided to grab some coffee before heading to brunch at Mama's (caffeine was definitely needed to tide us over while waiting in that line). Here's the rundown:

Service: It's a small coffee shop feel in a big space. The employees know their stuff, are friendly, and are efficient. 

Ambiance: It has a fresh feeling inside. A clean, open space (the shop spans the entire building so you can see out to the back doors past all their coffee grinding contraptions). There's a fair amount of tables and chairs if you want to sit and enjoy your coffee there. There's also a nice set up outside where you can park your bikes on the bike rack (let's face it, it's the Mission), and look out onto the street while you sip your beverage.

Coffee: You can get everything from their amazing drip coffee to a nice latte (whole milk or almond milk only). I'm not a huge coffee connoisseur, but I think they have Blue Bottle beat! I ordered a latte with almond milk and it was so good -- hit the spot perfectly! My bf ordered a regular coffee and you cannot go wrong with that either. 

Location: Lucky for me, they're a short walk from my bf's apartment. Even for those who find their way by car just to get a sip of this good stuff, apparently it's perfectly acceptable to park your car in the middle turn lane with your emergency blinkers on so you can run in and grab your cup of joe.

Four Barrel Coffee, you have a new fan.
author: Leana L.

description: Decent coffee, but their listing falsely advertises that they have WiFi, when in fact they don't. Don't try to come here if you're looking to get work done.
author: Sean T.

description: This must be the most hipster coffee place I've ever been in, lol. That being said, it was absolutely fab. I walk by here all the time and it's almost always busy. I loved the environment - busy, but not overwhelming when I went with my friend over the weekend. The staff was friendly and the order came out quickly. The cappuccino I had was good, especially when paired with the coconut donut  ;) It wasn't too difficult to find seats (there's indoor and some outdoor seating available), but it does all seem to be about the timing. There's bike parking out front, or it's also easy to get to by car (street parking) or transit.
author: Bianca C.

description:
The barista at the slow bar making the coffee with a beeline (I'm a Hario V60 fan) made an amazing cup of coffee for me. 

If you can make me a good cup of coffee using a beeline, well, I'll be coming back. If it was a v60, that would've made is a 5 star as that's harder but the flavors will be like a party in your mouth, if done right.
author: Kate P.

description:
Love the coffee, especially the cold-brew iced coffee.  

I recommend asking for the iced coffee with "no room" to get extra coffee.

However, minus one star for:
1. Limited seating
2. Only one bathroom, which always seems to have a line, despite #1.
3. Lack of Wi-Fi, likely to deter long stays to solve for #1.
author: Greg B.

description:
Great coffee,  great atmosphere... Friendly baristas who are very knowledgeable about the coffee..  
I would recommend this place go anyone seeking a great cup of coffee..
author: John T.

description: Not the absolute best coffee I have ever had but very good. The staff was helpful and friendly--no real "frills" to their coffee other than the decoration. However, coffee enthusiasts would argue that shouldn't need any frills :)
author: Brittany L.

description:
The bitter rivalry between San Francisco's coffeeshops is just as heated as their brews, one where beans are spilled and Dunkin' Donuts is bush league.

Four Barrel Coffee is right up there with Blue Bottle and Ritual for best cuppa joe. It's a bit more down to earth than the other two, going for a more rustic look and feel (the boar heads on the wall kind of solidify it). Coffee is smooth with a bit of body to it, and it comes out ever so slightly cheaper than its rivals ($2.50).

I'm the type of guy who likes to take their cup black though, so the robust nature of Blue Bottle (and their Giant Steps blend) reigns supreme.  Still, Four Barrel is pure quality.
author: Casey S.

description:
Second visit. Beautiful decor. Clean cafe. Ginormous for what is served. Problem started with my order. Simple nonfat wet cappuccino. Well, that's when I was "educated" that they only have whole milk or almond milk. In fact, I was advised "we only carry milk from a cow or almonds." Bwahahaha (internal laugh). Let me see your almond milk (wondering the carb content and brand). Califia-  don't they carry this at Safeway? 

To avoid stomach issue I use nonfat milk. American whole milk agitates my stomach due to processing. Interestingly, since Whole milk in Europe isn't a problem. 

Next, the cashier confused my order with my friends. Fine, but again I was "corrected" with a "so you don't want this you want that" uh, no you can't keep track of who ordered what since you refused to wait my label inspection of your Almond milk. 

So, the cappuccino review: 
Obligatory Floral milk design expected- most places do this. 
Special roasted flavor? Not really.
Rich creamy froth? Nope.
Ergonomic cups? Nope- they are ceramic mini soup cups. Not easy if hot. Unless it's snowing outside- 
The ambiance- super! But that's just people vibe.

Coffee experience: three cups per day minimum. french press at home- Italian percolator at home, frother at home. Peets, Muddy waters, Philz, blue bottle, Paris Baguette, Mexico,  El Salvador, Italy, France, Guatemala. Yes I drink coffee at night. Yes I sniff my roast. Yes it's my special addiction. 

Overall impression: Spacey, nice pit stop for coffee with friends - This place is clean. Staff clear tables fast! I appreciate that! Sadly, this place takes itself too seriously - the cashiers facial expression when I asked for nonfat milk was classic new SF- you'd think I was ordering sulfuric acid! Dare NOT ask for Splenda!!! Faux pas!! I'm so over that third eye, hemp shirt, namaste hoopla- look peeps I like clean living but last I checked nonfat milk is also Cow Milk! 

And listen, I'm born and raised San Franciscan I remember when that area was nothing but the hood. And yes it's nicer- yes the mission is now trendy - but the whole almond milk and whole milk stand on Califa grocery store milk is Rediculous and a reflection of what's wrong with these spots in the mission! Get over it! Carry some nonfat- low fat it's not sulfuric acid nor radioactive! Going to abuelita's for stovetop percolator coffee next time- oh with a side pupusa!! Now that's earthy!!!
author: Nancy N.

description:
I love coffee, and four barrel is one of my favorite coffee. 

SF has the most expensive coffee, but hey, they're good. Four barrel is definitely one of my favorite coffee. Their lattes and cappuccinos are great as well. There's nothing much to say about this place, 3 words to describe this place: Good Coffee Beans. I go here so often I don't know what else to say.

They have great selection for the pastries as well to compliment your coffee.
author: Toni Rose M.

description:
Private Investigations
Case 2014-01_4bc

End transcript  7:33:12 am_01_19_14

7:32 am
Subjects are seen leaving the building. The coffee beans - 12 oz., Guatemalan - are visible in male's right hand. They seem content. "On to Muir Woods!" was picked up on the microphone. Their visit at 4B has no doubt been an effective way to start a day trip of adventure. 

And, yes, it would appear to have been worth the wait.

7:20 am
Subject #2 has finished her cappuccino. She is heard quite clearly to have "liked it." Subject #1 looks at his empty mug (French Press, Kenyan single origin). He is scanning the room, his eyes drawn to the vintage Probat roaster in the rear of the building like a moth to a flame. Crowds arrive, order coffee drinks, and leave. Some remain, lingering over coffee, croissants, and the like. Typical morning at 4B, based on past surveillance.

7:10 am
Subjects receive their coffee drinks - a cup of black coffee and a cappuccino. The bag of beans Subject #1 places on the table, watching over it attentively like a mother osprey doting of her young. (Aside: determine size and place of origin later). The foot traffic is discernibly picking up, the music is louder. Western Country. Kitty Wells, Heartbreak USA (1961), in the original vinyl. Most appropriate. There is much love in evidence, judging by the gathering crowds. At 7:10 on a Sunday morning.

7:05 am 
Subjects enter the building. They are confused about ordering, trying to get a pour over. Staff explain that the pour over bar opens at 9 am. After some give-and-take, both subjects agree on their orders. There also are beans in a brown bag, presumably single origin, possibly Central American. Bears further investigation.

6:48 am
Subjects arrive by car, park on the opposite side of the street. They are here BEFORE 4B opens. Surveillance will continue. One can only assume that there is, indeed, something valuable inside. Coffee, it would seem. 

But will it be worth the wait?
author: Bradley N.

description:
7x7 100 Best Things to Eat Before You Die 2012

#54 Kouign Amann at Four Barrel 

(the pastry chef sells her goods through Four Barrel)*

O M G.....Crispy, Flaky Golden Sugary Heaven =)

I think that about sums it up.....

Oh and the coffee is pretty damn good too! No need for cream and sugar! It just gets in the way of the pure coffee goodness

Overall Thoughts

There pastry chef is one talented lady, only makes sense she will be opening her own shop soon...Tartine...you better watch out
author: Eddie W.

description:
Has
Coffee
And desserts
For morning chats
But no wifi love for the laptopping.
author: Justin L.

description:
Americano was strong and delicious. I was wrunk (wired + drunk) after 2 sips.

We sat at the bar in the back of the shop and watched the master roasters at work. 

Lighting and decor was simple but unique. Would come back for sure.
author: Jennifer C.

description: Great coffee. Wish they had a better choice of snacks though since the current selection is limited and pricey.
author: Owen C.

description: Super friendly barista, good selections, and drinks that deliver.  Great vibe, adequate power sources and wifi.  Great hole in the wall!
author: Julie L.

description:
Am I missing something here? Everyone raves about this place like it's the elixir of the gods or something. Is this like when people (mostly pretentious, mostly hipster) swear that whiskey tastes "good" when in fact it's awful and they feign being refined by drinking something that tastes like gasoline?

Don't get me wrong, I love love love coffee! I like Philz, Blue Bottle, Contraband, Community, the coffee w/ condensed milk at Lee's Sandwiches, etc. HOWEVER, the Macchiato I had today at Four Barrel was acidic, tangy, sour, and just plain awful!  I did not finish it which is saying a lot because it's pretty pricey and they use tiny cups. 

I just do not get the hype. What I drank today was the opposite of smooth and tasty. Not a fan. Not impressed :/
author: Semuteh F.

description:
Nothing Special

The coffee was lukewarm, and the service was even colder than that.
There is no wi-fi.

If the goal is to make sure customers don't make a second visit, then...  Mission Accomplished!

There are much better options available.
author: Ted Q.

description:
Lovely interior, my kinda coffeeshop. Almost looks like a tiny coffee factory inside. They grind the beans on the spot so you can experience it while sipping on your cappy. Good coffee too! Though I do wish there would be more variety for those of us who take our coffee with a little sweetness.
*everything here is sold as double-shot*
author: T L.

description:
ordered a rose donut with my two coffees and pretzel. 

Which she forgot to ring up. 

Minus all of the stars.


Went up to see if my drinks were ready and turns out they never even started making it. So I had to wait even longer. 


I am calling the police.
author: Michael V.

description:
Im not a coffee connoisseur, but I have to say that this place isn't bad. There is a slight hype because of the coffee trend in San Francisco. But this place has such a great vibe. 

First off, I have to say the cups are the cutest things ever, I wanted to take it home with me so bad. The vibe is pretty nice and has coffee roasting in the back, people working. But I have to say its the best just to sit outside on their parklet and just chat and people watch.

Coffe, I have to say is pretty good. Its has a strong roasted flavor if you're into that. The Latte was really good, but I personally love the affogato! Location is great too! This place is at the very beginning of all the restaurants on Valencia so there isn't too much parking competition or crowd. 

Overall, great vibe and place to get coffee and just chat. I have to say, I do like the chill vibe compared to Ritual Coffee.
author: Mark L.

description:
3.5 stars for Four Barrel Coffee. Come for the ambiance, stay to people watch. As for the coffee itself, I have had better in the Bay Area (Of the coffee shops in the Bay Area that I've been to, I prefer Philz. But, my friend was the opposite; she much preferred Four Barrel over Philz). Disclaimer: I am not a hipster, nor am I much of a coffee drinker. 

Coffee: I liked the iced mocha ($5), particularly the coffee bits at the bottom of the cup. The coffee did seem a bit more acidic and sour than I am used to; it's a much more brass taste. 

Ambiance: Hipster with a pinch of normcore. Very industrial interiors with concrete flooring and exposed ceilings. My favorite part was the unique array of taxidermy along the wall. Outside has cool, urban seating as well as space-saving bicycle parking.
author: Phoebe C.

description: Ordered a cappuccino and was given a latte. I informed the barista of the error and she again made another latte. The place was loud and uncomfortable, I will not be returning.
author: Rudy S.

description:
This is the ultimate hipster spot... wild bike rack/seating area outside on the street... 4 pig heads on the wall and celebrity baristas.. no really like DJs, but baristas spinning vinyl (yes actual records) 

Tattoo You was playing when I left today
author: Alan R.

description:
I love the location and design of this place. They truly turned an insignificant hole in the wall into something beautiful to come to. Their space and park let are amazing.

Their coffee and pastries are great quality as well.
author: Joshua C.

description: ehh, the coffee is ok but unless you want to fund two white collar owners (who also let a toxic work environment carry on for who knows how long, search Jeremy Tooker if you don't already know) of a supposedly punk coffee shop, you should venture elsewhere.
author: Ventura G.

description:
Possibly the best latte I've had in my life. The seating is rather limited, but definitely a good space to either have a coffee with a friend or sit along the bar and work. 

The baristas were very nice and helpful. I will just wear my black rimmed glasses next time I go so I can fit in.
author: Steph D.

description:
I didn't want to like this place.  

I generally avoid the spendy-trendy coffee joints, generally opting for home brewed coffee, 7-11, Dunkin, and the occasional Starbucks.   This was simply the closest place to my work that was open after 5pm, so, grudgingly I went for an end-of-day pick-me-up. 

Most of the time, I find hipster coffee houses to be pretentious, overpriced, and lacking in substance. 

Not so here.  The mocha was excellent.  You could see the care the barista put into the drink, and the you can taste the superior quality.  Despite the hipster vibe, the atmosphere and employees were very welcoming. The $5 mocha, while too pricey to justify making this a regular stop for me, was well worth the price.  I'll be back (albeit occasionally).

This would be a great place to meet friends for a cup of coffee.  Not exactly a place to grab a cheap cup on your way to work, though.
author: Ron C.

description:
FourBarrel Coffee is now one of my favorites, especially for a good latte!

There was a steady flow of people on Saturday and most of the seats inside were taken. My girlfriend and I ended up sitting on the back bar near the roaster which was cool. I noticed the employee who was roasting was dedicated to what he was doing - smelling the roast every so often and even putting his ear up to the roaster to listen. It was nice knowing they pay attention to quality! Most of the patrons seemed to be studying or on their computers. Staff was pleasant.
author: Josh L.

description:
I must say that Grant and Alex are the most helpful people ever! Ive been coming in the last 2 weekends from over 1 hour away for their coffee. I bought a bag of coffee last weekend and it wasnt.exactly the cup i was looking for. Came back to talk to these gentlemen and both Grant and Alex were extremely understanding and accomodating. Grant poured me 2 different coffees and sat and talked me through the roasting process and how each batch can be slightly different. They never made me feel bad for my distate in the first bag I bought and even gave me a free bag of a new coffee that was more towards my desired tasting tones! They had their roaster bag one up for me right there since the shelf bags were all out. 

 Grant is more than friendly and knowledgeable. With so much great coffee in the city, service really puts you over the top! I will gladly drive over an hour for this kind of service and amazing coffee... thanks guys!!
author: Demsina B.

description:
To be completely honest, I don't like coffee. Never touch the stuff. So while my friends seemed quite happy with their iced coffees, I have nothing to say on what the premise of this establishment is about (coffee).

I will, however, sing words of praise for their baked goods. Good God, it makes any chain coffee shop you know look like sloppy seconds compared to this wondrous land of flaky morning treats. 

It's very difficult to choose just one thing ot get, so if you're lucky, you'll come in a hungry group, or if you aren't lucky, you'll just get a few "for later". What I did get to try were the:

BLACKBERRY PISTACHIO CROISSANT. Umm...wow. I've never had that combination of flavors in a croissant before, and it completely blew me away. The pistachio wasn't too heavy or thick, and the blackberry was a nice sweet swirl in the perfectly flaky breakfast that I had. It did get a little sweet as I continued eating it, so milk (or I guess coffee) would be a welcome companion to this.

ORANGE-CHOCOLATE KOUGIN-AMANN. I've never tried one until yesterday, and I clearly see what I have been missing out on. It's a complete dessert pastry, in my opinion, very sweet and buttery, but outstanding. The giant dollop of melted chocolatey ganache in the middle was incredible, and the whole thing was just a pleasure to have even a few bites of.

CHOCOLATE SPICE DONUT. My friend, who raves about their donuts, walked away with this bad boy, and while I didn't try much, it's delicious - thick, not overly sweet, and with a nice bite to it.

I could care less about their drinks, but be sure to try out their pastries, lovingly nestled together in their display case at the main counter!
author: Claire S.

description:
4 reasons why I can't stand Four Barrel Coffee:

1. It takes me 9+ hours to get from home to here door to door. 
2. Alex the barista gave my 2nd grade best friend a cookie for her birthday. As best bud, it is my duty to give her a birthday cookie first and he beat me. He's also way cuter than me (dammit!)
3. Bradley the barista amused us with his witty informative banter while plying us with a wonderful Chemex pour over of the Andino Columbia he recommended. It was the 3rd coffee drink I had in the space of an hour and I was too way too buzzed and spazzed out on great coffee to compete on any kind of intellectual level. sigh.
4. When I asked both Alex and Bradley where I should go for lunch, they both looked at each other and said the exact same thing at the exact same time (Bar Tartine. Smoked potatoes. Best ever). What is this synchronicity... are they the Food Illuminati or something? What gives? And what other sweet intel are they holding out on?!

That's it, I'm pissed. Completely unacceptable.
author: Alma C.

description:
I'm gonna be straight up with you.... their almond milk latte is really sexy. I stopped by this evening for a quick caffeine fix after dinner. 

Wait just one hot minute... a latte at 8pm? Madness! Well, that's just how I roll, folks. I am an odd duck, and I drink java all day, every day, baby. 

I walked in and the place was surprisingly packed. There was a buzz of excitement in the air. Not a single table was unoccupied, so I made a quick decision to have my beverage to-go. I scoped out their menu, which is very straightforward. It features the usual suspects: coffee, Americano, macchiato, cappuccino, latte, mocha, hot chocolate, iced coffee... that's about it. All drinks come in one size, so no need to specify how big you want it. 

They have a record player hooked up to speakers, filling the patron's ears with blissful sounds. They have an impressive record collection directly above. I resisted the urge to hop the counter and shuffle through their LPs, even though the idea was mighty tempting. The barista danced around as he pulled what appeared to be a perfect espresso shot. 

After a few minutes, the cup was placed in front of me. Be still, my heart! 

I eagerly took a sip of my drink, and I was transported to a land of beauty. Imagine Willy Wonka's chocolate factory. However, instead of a chocolate river, there would be a river of fragrant, perfectly brewed coffee. I mentally frolicked through imaginary green fields as Gene Wilder serenaded me. Yes, Four Barrel espresso is delicious enough to make one hallucinate about "a world of pure imagination". Make sure you are in a controlled environment so you can fully enjoy your own personal utopia. 

Note to self: must buy a reusable coffee mug at my earliest convenience. I feel as though I waste a lot of those sad little paper cups and sleeves. Save the planet! Buy a thermos.
author: Brandi W.

description:
Found this place when searching for "best place to study free wifi". There's no free wifi here. 

The hot chocolate was ok. Nothing special.
author: Irene L.

description:
While I wouldn't come at peak times as the lines become overwhelming, I recommend stopping in for an iced coffee + kouign-amman. I'm not a coffee person at all, but I relished every drop of this iced coffee. The pastry was similarly amazing...never tried anything quite like it before! This place is relatively pricey, but worth it in my opinion. The inside has this trendy warehouse thing going for it and feels refreshingly roomy for a coffee shop...not a bad place to try to read or write, especially at non-peak times.

Tip: They have simple syrup behind the counter, so remember to ask for it! They keep it out of sight so customers don't make a mess.
author: Neha S.

description:
Industrial rustic decor, people with thick-rimmed fake glasses, and taxidermy hog heads? Just another day at UrbanOutfitters, if UrbanOutfitters sold coffee. 

Yes, it is a hipster-chic coffee shop. Very open, modern, and spacious. Ironically the seating seemed a bit limited and tables were small. Great for catching up with a friend or... just yourself. 

The service was also very fast and the baristas here are nice. I came in the late afternoon for a little pick-me-up and I didn't experience a long line of groggy hipsters. Just groggy me. 

I'm not a coffee snob by any means but I personally found the espresso here 'okay'. I wasn't too thrilled about it but also not disgusted by it. I love my Americanos and theirs wasn't super bitter but ... I guess I wasn't a fan of the taste. To each their own! 

I could see myself coming back here for a quick caffeine fix if I'm in the area during nap time.
author: Krissy L.

description:
After returning a few times... I've decided Four Barrel just isn't for me. Their roasts are too acidic. First few sips are good, but as I continue to drink it, I just don't thoroughly enjoy it. Still great coffee, just not my cup of it.

What truly irks me is the lack of dairy options. Four Barrel only offers whole or almond milk.  Yes, REALLY. 
I thought a hipster ass joint would at least have soy but ok.. 

And I realize how fcking stereotypical San Franciscan of me that sounds but I would think the standard is at least 2%!

And why the eff does the weekday staff crew always give me these judgmental looks and snippety attitude at 7am like I'm one of the techies ruining SF?! SORRY I HAVE A BITCHY RESTING FACE. And also sorry not sorry I'm usually the only one up in this joint dressed in business attire while the rest of y'all are in jeans and hoodies. Fun fact: I'm not a fcking techie

My search for the best coffee in the Mission before I have to jet off to work continues..
author: Susy C.

description: If you want good coffee with baristas who know their coffee, come here! I love coming here and seeing them roast their own coffee beans. They have a variety of drip coffee to choose from to please any type of palette.
author: Chris K.

description:
Saw this place on thrillest's online article "21 best coffee shops in America" and hypebeast eats did a video bit on it.  So I immediately bookmarked it on yelp and decided to see what all the hype was about. I have to say I was very pleased with the atmosphere and the friend friendliness of the employee upon walking in. I was also very pleased with the fact that this coffee shop had affogatos, as some good coffee places don't.  
The quality and taste of the cappuccino was awesome!  If you're in the city, I would definitely say this is one of the "must-visit" places.
author: Vishaal P.

description:
Solid coffee. Good people. Cool atmosphere. No wifi, but plenty of seating, make 4B a great place for morning coffee and meetings. I usually park my bike outside and stay for about an hour. 

The drip coffee is better than the espresso drinks here, but all in all a great place.
author: Brian H.

description: I want to start with saying I like the place, the baristas were friendly and helpful. The vibe was relaxed and welcoming. These are important things to me because I was really just stopping in to rest after walking all over mission district. I'm from out of state and the hospitality was comforting. I'm a tea person. So I can't attest to the coffee quality but their herbal tea could stand to be steeped just a couple more minutes. Don't get me wrong it was a good blend, but I like strong tea. Would recommend if you're looking for a cool place to people watch.
author: Hillary S.

description: Dropped in for a quick double espresso (they don't do singles). The vibe is like something out of Portlandia. Pasty-skinned hipsters. 70s vintage punk music playing from an LP with a tube amplifier. It's cool but a little affected. The espresso had this odd salty flavor. Is it supposed to be that way?
author: Scott S.

description:
It's so hipster that it's a little disconcerting. Regardless, I still sat inside for about two hours with my morning coffee, enthralled by the open room where everything happens together: the sorting, the roasting, the pressing, the steaming, the ordering, and the whittling away of time. The French pressed coffee is perfect start to the day, but I have to say that the blueberry cake wasn't very sweet or, well, blueberry. 

The lack of electric outlets is extremely frustrating. As you get absorbed into the environment and the richness of the coffee, however, your other extraneous needs ALMOST disappear altogether. And you just feel content.
author: Jack C.

description: Lucky me, the first time I stopped by this place, it was their 10 year anniversary or something so I got their iced latte for only $1 which on any regular day would be $5...I'd call that a steal! Anyways I really enjoyed their ice latte and came back again two days ago while I was in the area for their hot latte. Two times within a short time period when I don't even live in SF? Must mean it's pretty darn good eh? Would come back almost everyday if I didn't have a small coffee budget.
author: Vicki L.

description:
IMPORTANT: All drinks are DOUBLE shots. 

Meaning, there's twice the amount of caffeine in a drink compared to other coffee shops, so a latte here is twice as strong compared to a latte from Starbucks/Peets/Philz.

Iced mocha (Four Barrel) + several cups of barley tea at Sushi Zen + honey tea from Purple Kow = COULD NOT SLEEP THE WHOLE NIGHT. Guys, please be aware that if you are in any way sensitive to caffeine to be wary when getting coffee here! It's pretty strong.

Iced latte= Too strong.
Iced mocha= This is my favorite. They have ACTUAL chocolate shavings!
author: Vicki L.

description:
By far the best coffee I ever had in California. My favorite is the Late and it taste better when u drink it in a to go cup. Also I love the Pistachio Croissant very much, but it's hardly available. I think you have to be there early in the morning to be lucky enough to get one of these. 

Will be there every time I'm in the city :)
author: Tareq M.

description:
Environment is superb...coffee is awesome and love the slow bar that provide drip coffee. Only problem is no WiFi and got to pay for parking....

Well..that's the trade off if you want to go to mission district
author: Chin Man L.

description: Ever since moving to Sf and becoming a bit of a coffee enthusiast, I've been to so many coffee shops in the city and I've got to say this place is one of my favorites. The baristas were friendly, the atmosphere was awesome, my coffee was delicious, and my latte art was beautiful.
author: Kathlena H.

description: The coffee at Four Barrels is artisan and uniquely crafted! Their customer service is excellent and their baristas were very responsive and friendly.
author: Yonathan C.

description:
Ever since I had my very first Kouign Amann from B Patisserie, I have been in love with them. When I found out that Four Barrel Coffee also serves them, I knew I had to make a trip! We got super lucky and found a parking spot few steps away from the place. I must've also been super lucky because I was able to score the last Kouign Amann! :)

Latte - Very smooth and delicious. It was not too sweet nor too bitter. In my opinion, it's comparable to Sightglass Coffee. I actually think the prices at Four Barrel are more worth it. Plus, they also have latte art. :)

Orange Currant Kouign Amann - These Kouign Amanns are baked by B Patisserie. It was just the way I imagined it to be. Very flaky and buttery. Even though I had purchased it at the end of the day, the Kouign Amann still had that crisp to it. Even though it was coated with sugar, it was not too overly sweet. There was a very good amount of currant in it with a hint of orange taste. 

I'm definitely going to be back to try some other flavors of the Kouign Amann including the different types of donuts they serve. I just need to make sure I come in the morning before they sell out! :)
author: Philana C.

description:
Terrific coffee for an affordable price!

For all you students, terrible place to study. No wifi, no outlets. Also, not quite ideal for catchup conversations since they are constantly roasting coffee and the place is constantly packed on weekends. Bathroom is also beyond disgusting.
author: Suji C.

description:
Spacious & easy to get a seat. Tried a pour over coffee and pistachio/blackberry croissant.  Both were great.  Worth the $9 for both :)

Staff is v friendly, genuinely happy to be working here, and knowledgeable about what they serve. 

My only knock is that they do not offer wifi.
author: craig l.

description:
Maybe the greatest cafe in the city. I love this place. 

always brews a strong cup.
author: Mark J.

description:
It's pretty awesome watching the whole coffee production in the back. Their coffee is a bit more expensive than at some of the other local places, but for beans they have more variety. However, some of the beans were roasted a week prior, so you need to check the dates. I did manage to get a bag roasted from the day prior, so it was super fresh.

They have b patisserie kouign amanns here, so if you don't want to go all the way up to pac heights, it's convenient for that.  Their chocolate banana scone is not bad - not too sweet, and I like interesting scone flavors.

The park let and bike racks out front are a nice touch. No wifi.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
Pretentious, Slightly Over Priced, and Long Lines... 

That being said, get your ASS TO FOUR BARREL COFFEE. 
This place rocks when you're looking for a cool place to sit. It rocks when you have a friend visiting from out of town and want them to be jealous you live in SF. And it rocks when you want the hands down best espresso drinks in the city. 

Like I said earlier, there are long lines, drinks are slightly over priced.. and sometimes I get annoyed with the people who work there for being just a little too "hipster cool" rather than getting my drink out faster. 

But to be honest I easily forget all of these things when I pick up my beautifully designed hand crafted latte and take a bite of my Flourless Almond Cake. 

Not to mention, I've probably gained 20 instagram followers JUST from my looks-out-of-a-magazine pics from this place. 

I love you Four Barrel, keep doin' whatcha do.
author: Paisley P.

description: Pretty good. I got a cappuccino and a chocolate claw to go. I don't usually like hot coffee but I did enjoy this one. You can really taste the coffee and it's absolutely delicious. The atmosphere of the place is amazing too and filled with people. One day I really do want to sit there take it all in.
author: Julie L.

description: Beautiful decoration and ambiance. I liked the bean oven in the back. The staff seems to be truly involved in the coffee roasting and preparation business.
author: Johanna S.

description:
This place has awesome coffee. I'd have to say they're my tied for 2nd (Coffee Bar SF, being the other) on my list of coffee brewers in SF. 

The ambiance is super cool going in. They do sell Dynamo Donuts, which are always delicious. The only con about this place is that the only cream alternative is almond milk. I personally prefer soy with espresso drinks, but that's just me. All in all, the people working there are super nice and not douchey like Blue Bottle snobs.
author: Aaron C.

description:
Items selected:

b.patisserie chocolate sable
Colombia Andino
Ethiopia Aricha
Ethiopia Wote
Colombia Las Cauchos

Two visits over the course of three days and four single origin samples from the pourover counter plus a couple complimentary chocolate sables from b.patisserie - along with Heart in Portland Four Barrel remains perhaps my favorite roaster in the United States.  From the smooth caramel and stonefruit notes of the Andino to the thick mouthfeel and melon tones of the Yirgacheffe Wote it remains impressive to me how much flavor the team at Four Barrel can coax from the beans using such a light roasting process but having purchased 60oz of coffee since returning to Phoenix I'm glad to continue exploring their technique as new seasons and new beans arrive.
author: Michael U.

description:
I am no coffee n00b...I'm a coffee sn0b!! When life deals you a bad hand and you're allergic to alcohol, sometimes the comforting or enjoyable drink is coffee.  In search of the BEST coffee and latte became our mission.  Who would have guessed there are so many out there?  The usual coffee chain stores (Starbucks and Peets) have been out shined.

As any great financial advisor would tell you.  The best way to save money is to cut out buying coffee and start making it at home.  Ya ya ya...we've all heard it, but we don't listen.  Our minds still tells us we need to go to a café, better yet I think our lazy A$$ is the one that speaks for us.

When Mr. BYS said there is a coffee shop he wanted to try out, I was excited.  Driving out of our way to get to this café was a waste of time and gas.  We were lucky enough to get a parking two doors down from the café.  As we entered it was packed the line was almost out the door.  There were plenty of seats inside but was taken by hoarders laying out their newspapers and although they had no Wi-Fi connection here.  It didn't stop the ones who pulled out their laptops.  411 peeps, if it's communal seating, don't be an A$$ and take up the entire table.  

Once I found us a seat and Mr. BYS brought our lattes.  I looked at it and said..."this is a latte"? He even questioned it too.  Why were we puzzled...because the size of the cup was like a tea cup but smaller.  

http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/four-barrel-coffee-san-francisco?select=GctXrJbV0geOK-ebfUxwxQ#GctXrJbV0geOK-ebfUxwxQ

So, a café latte is 60ml Espresso, 175-300 ml Steamed Milk & 2ml of Milk Foam that is why it's called a Latte "MILK COFFEE"....what I got was similar to a Cappuccino which is 60ml Espresso, 60ml steamed milk & 60ml Foamed Milk.  If we have to pay an extra 50cents for Almond milk (since they don't carry soy) than give me the amount I paid for.  Don't short change me and give it to me in a "foam version".  Yes, I commend you for the pretty artwork of a heart on my latte.  At same time, it's creepy drinking my coffee as I stare at the numerous dead animal heads plastered against the walls.

IS THIS LOCATION GOOD FOR "MEET UP DATE PLACE"?
I would say NO!! There is more communal seating here.  The atmosphere is very loud.  

Mr. BYS review of this place and what he thought about it...
http://www.yelp.com/biz/four-barrel-coffee-san-francisco#hrid:RfDgueR9X41efeOzkPiGaw
author: Rachel B.

description:
I think can understand the hype now. I went in Sunday morning with my man, line was long, but it was a beautiful day and I had never been there, so I was okay with the wait. The decor is really cool: huge warehouse but decorated with simple pieces, modern, with wood tables, drip bar, cool dark metal bike racks out front. 

They roast their own beans which is pretty cool, and they really seem to care about how the beans taste (I saw one barista sipping a shot of espresso and commenting to the cashier about the flavor, which he reported back to the customer). I got cappucino, everything is a double shot. It came in a cute dark blue ceramic tumbler cup, which was cute, the flavor was rich and earthy, not burned. Boyfriend got an iced Americano, he didn't like it and thought it tasted like Equator (which he doesn't like). I wanted a pastry but sadly they were out of banana chocolate scones. 

It's a hipster place, worth the wait, and the walk.
author: Crystal C.

description: Love the pour over bar.  Super friendly, helpful and passionate barista.  You have a choice to personalize at one section or go to main counter for all drinks and snacks.  I prefer
author: Devin B.

description:
Great ambiance.. Check
Great quality Coffee.. Check
Knowledgable staff.. Check

Did I miss any requirement for a good coffee place? I've grown to appreciate a slow brewed drip black coffee. The process it takes to make, the knowledge behind setting up a good pour, all worthwhile for me to venture outside of making a cup at home. My only beef was I didn't get outside because it was packed.. But no fault in the management team.
author: Samuel C.

description:
Really great coffee and cool ambiance but no wifi :-(

Staff is super friendly and helpful.
author: Andrew S.

description: I stopped in on a recent trip to San Francisco and was very pleasantly surprised. The pink flamingo was delicious and I often wish I could grab one. I knocked off one star because of the exorbitant price.
author: Amanda S.

description: Love walking into a coffee shop and being welcomed by the smell of coffee! This place is quite impressive - not only from a ambiance, smell and coffee selection perspective, but the staff is knowledgable and hospitable! This, to me, is a coffee shop and sets the bar really high for the rest of them. I had a Ethiopian bean, through a chemex pour over, just phenomenal - smooth and full of flavour. Happy to have discovered this place during my visit to SF.
author: Jenna M.

description:
Came here based on the yelp reviews but the coffee was bitter and nothing special. Giving it a three based on the coffee, since SF has a good coffee scene, I was disappointed. 

Had some animal heads on the walls, which was an interesting vibe. I did think that it was nice and big, and it was pretty easy to find a seat. It also has an area where you can stand. They also have seats outside, which is nice during the day.
author: Yun K.

description: First time here and this place is so good, tried the Affogato and it's a must try item. Will definitely be coming back to this spot. No wifi so don't expect to get work done on the laptop. Good environment to chat.
author: Derick N.

description:
Battle of the Best Coffee on Valencia Street.
Four Barrel vs. Ritual.
They are set apart by 6 blocks, but only one can be Valencia's best. Based on coffee, service, and decor.
Coffee- This one is tough. Ritual serves more of a medium roast but packs a lot aromas. Four Barrel serves a bolder coffee that fits me more but only serves drinks using whole milk or soy. Ritual has the edge just because I am use to 2% or fat free lattes but that doesn't mean I won't go in. It just means I got to break the rules.
Service- Four Barrel has a more friendly service and the staff seems more happier. Two baristas showcasing their talents. I love how they call your name then pour the milk into the espresso. 5 seconds later, edible artwork.
Decor- Both places have an open space but Four Barrel has the edge because their roaster is on display and does both tables and coffee bar.

Four Barrel is Valencia Street BEST!
author: Kien M.

description:
Fixies hung outside. Wooden furniture. Latte art. A guy smokin' out of an apple pipe outside.

This place is the epitome of hipster. 

The coffee is solid and even though the baristas aren't the jolliest, you can tell they know what they're doing. Heck, they probably do pour overs in their sleep. The latte is served with just the right amount of foam and temperature. I don't have to customize it at all. Not even a cup sleeve.

The downside is that the drinks are a bit pricier but at least you're getting what you pay for. Not a place to study since there's no wifi and it's pretty loud. There are a lot of people standing around and socializing so it's great for a casual meet up. And the smell of coffee inside.. Oh my god, I wish they made a room freshener out of it.
author: Ashley L.

description: This place is to cool! They roast right on site, it's a dreamy coffee shop! Very stylish, I only got a drip coffee and it was amazing, it had a sweet taste (no i didn't sweetened it)
author: Kimberly Anne I.

description: Absolutely love this coffee! It's hard to explain how delicious it is. I highly recommend you stop by and see for yourself. ASAP
author: Ceecee M.

description:
The main roast results in sour-ish taste that I don't care for, but those that like light roast may enjoy. I go to a different smaller location so other locations may have more roasts available. 

The environment is cool.

The food looks good.
author: Chris G.

description: Good coffee great ambience. Would be nice to have wifi and outlets. But I'll definitely go back for the coffee
author: Zeel S.

description: This place is definitely a scene but the space is really nice - open and airy and I like that they rotate the art. Coffee is good but a bit overpriced, mostly the iced. Pro tip: their chocolate chip cookies erase any and all memory of (over)payment.
author: DeAnna C.

description:
Very arty, latte-arty, cool coffee art
Sad, bad, bland hot chocolate
Coffee art cool but that's about it!
author: Me Iz S.

description:
Love the communal style seating inside and the outdoor street seating. They also have bike racks! Very hipster spot with an artistic industrial feel on the inside. Great people watching and generally a very young crowd. Line moves quickly.

Coffee - a little too acidic for my taste. I usually don't add sugar to really good coffee but all the coffee I've had from here has needed a bit of sugar. I'm going to buy a pound anyway and give Four Barrel a fourth chance.
author: Jennifer A.

description: Yes, yes, yes, the coffee here really is that good. A really beautiful minimal space to look around while you wait in line and you will be waiting in line. Stow all the hate for everything hipster, it's not their fault that this coffee is that great. The roasted aroma alone is a great appetizer to a truly exceptionally crafted latte. I got mine with soy milk and it still came out frothy with some art on top. Sidewalk bar seating with a hot cup of coffee. Tops for sure.
author: William R.

description: It is a cool place to get some really good coffee.  While that is a good thing, there is a long line and no seating.  After walking around up and down Valencia, I was looking forward to a nice cup and taking a breather but there was not an empty chair anywhere.
author: Mark D.

description:
They have rules here:

1. On a scale of 1 to hipster deluxe, you have to be in the 8+ range
2. Must bike to location
3. Must have a solid level of knowledge about coffee's indigenous roots and roasting process

I don't live in SF...so maybe this is the standard. All things aside, the coffee was pretty good and I enjoyed the vibe. A little European and great people watching. Outdoor seating was perfect to enjoy sunshine and lots of people had their pups. 

The baked goods looked amazing...next time!
author: Sierra G.

description:
I came here on a trip to San Fran excited for some really great coffee.

I lived in Portland and was extremely spoiled with java.

I ordered a soy latte but they only have almond milk.  I am not a huge fan of almond milk in lattes.  It creates a weird burnt flavor (according to my palate).

After I ordered I was told my drink would be ready on the right side of the bar.  I stood and waited about 10 minutes when I finally asked the barista about my order.  She rolled her eyes when I said I had a latte to go.  

"The to go orders are all on the right side of the bar."

"Um....this is the right side"

"No it's not it's the left side"

So what they meant when they said "the right side" was THEIR right side.  If you face the bar I was on the correct side of the bar but since they are standing opposite of me the left was THEIR right. 

Anyways, it was annoying how rude they were and I was less than impressed with the coffee.
author: Nicole B.

description:
Is it douchey of me to write my review on Four Barrel based on my mocha experience? Is that not serious-coffee-nerd enough? I pondered this, and then thought, hey, if Four Barrel has it on the menu, it can't be THAT douchey. So anyways- I had been brunching it up in the Mission, which means imbibing on mimosas, and needed a little pick me up. I walked in Four Barrel and uncharacteristically ordered an iced mocha. I usually avoid mochas because the chain establishments that I frequent make them SO sweet it grosses me out. So why did I order one? I dunno. I wasn't in my normal frame of mind (thanks a lot Dr. Teeth!). So I got an iced mocha and a chocolate chip cookie, because obviously, I'm on a diet, and headed outside to stare at stuff. 

I took a sip of that iced mocha and wanted to ask the stranger next to me if he wanted a sip, because it was so f***ing good! Perfection. I have only had one mocha in my life that I ever liked, and it was in London. Four Barrel, you make snobby old London a distant memory for me. I used to tell people that the best part of my London trip were the mochas I knocked back everyday. Now I don't need to go back to London, because 4B made the most delicious mocha in the universe. It wasn't sweet. It tasted of chocolate but wasn't syrupy and cavity inducing. It was just perfect. The great taste of their coffee wasn't hidden, you could taste it dancing side my side with the delicious chocolate flavor. 

Readers, if  you have decided you hate mochas because they are overly sweet, but you like chocolate, go to Four Barrel and try theirs. It's a completely different experience.
author: Liz M.

description: Whenever, I get back to SF, I have to make a least one trip to Four Barrel. Once you get by the ubiquitous fixies parked out front, you walk into the domain of big city coffee lovers. They roast some great beans there, and create excellent cappuccinos and espresso drinks. Beside the main counter where you can order coffee and baked goodies, there's a pour-over bar in front of the place. They offer several daily choices, and are always happy to educate you as to what you're drinking. Can get a bit busy, but stay for the long haul. Definitely an excellent locals scene.
author: Tom M.

description:
Who the in the world is Rossi?  :) This guy Rossi, after I checked in here told me that this was good coffee, I still don't know who he is. (I am teasing Rossi)  My buddy Marci and her friend Lola, who I have been friends with on Yelp for years and who now decided to start her own business in San Francisco and is fabulous, ahem....sorry if I sound like an old Aunt talking about my niece... told me about this place. Thank you Rossi and Marci. 

This place did not disappoint, the pour over coffee was mild, closed out on the finish (I have no idea what the fuk that means) but it was good. I know this sounds schmoozerish and I apologize if it does but I liked the employees here. They were sans attitude and fart whiffing, smiled (which is important to we SoCali'ers) and were very patient with my dumb hungover ass.  I loved the suggestions and your savory/sweet pasteries went really, really well with my cold chilled glass of water.

Minus one star for only having one toilet, really?  Especially when that dude with a kid who looked like she was about 10 wearing a diaper needed a change which made all of us wait for 20+ minsj, I almost lost full bowel control waiting for so long, if I move to San Francisco, I am so totally buying Depends. Most of these fancy coffee places are lacking in the restroom area.
author: Patricia Patti P W.

description: Probably the best latte I've had. Perfect temperature and brew when they served it. I really like the open floor space and you can see them making the coffee cause it's on the middle of the store. They have a good amount of seats for people to bring their laptops and stuff.
author: Erville V.

description:
Coffee is an experience, and they always provide a great one. The baristas are well-trained and passionate about their craft. They have a front bar that specializes in single origin espresso and pour over coffee, while the main bar is offers their espresso blend and pressed coffee.

This is one of my favorite spots in San Francisco that I always try to stop by. Their espresso is delicious with very little, almost nonexistent, bitter finish. Their roaster is located in the back where guests can sit at the back bar and watch them work. It adds a complete experience by displaying the process of it's beginning stages and how it ends in the cup in your hands.

Overall, it's a great and pleasant experience. I recommend their espresso, press coffee, and their cappuccino. If you have a passion for coffee, then come to this place. You will not be disappointed.
author: Mark R.

description: Kind of too cool for me (I don't have any tattoos and my hair is its natural color) but a nice place to grab a cup of coffee. Lots of western-themed art/decor, which is fun. Surprisingly uncrowded, but then again I was there in the evening.
author: Amy P.

description:
Anecdote: Tried to order a banana cheddar scone but was thwarted by the four barrel employee who was much more awake than I was.  Banana cheddar sounds like an awful scone.  Their scones, however, are very good.

The espresso is delicious, the pastries are what make it worth coming back, and the music is what gives you that tap in your feet while you drink your spresso.

I really do love their pastries, which are not sweet, but lightly filling and very well made. The carrot bran muffin is easily the best carrot bran muffin I have ever had!
author: Alex H.

description: I stopped here a few months back...the staff was friendly, the drinks were smoking hot, and the crowd wasn't that bad. They were a little too hipster for my taste, but I managed. The wall art is really decorative. I really wish they had better options as it pertains to milk, I am not a big almond milk fan personally.
author: Jeff M.

description:
This place is sooo.. hipster.

Which is fine. I'm not a hater. But I feel like this place is overrated. I ordered an iced latte with almond milk and it was good, but it didn't taste amazing or anything. The taste is comparable to Blue Bottle, which I'm not a huge fan of either. I'd rather have Philz. Their Koign Amann (round sweet, flaky pastry) was pretty amazing though. 

The interior is pretty cool though, with wooden tables lining the walls and a huge roaster (like an actual guy roasting the coffee beans AND the huge machine) in the back. There's also hipster outdoor seating.
author: Stephanie G.

description: The customer service is phenomenal. I ordered a pour over at the bar and  the barista explained to me what he was doing. I'm a coffee enthusiast. I learned a lot on the art of making pour over. The place has a chill vibe and good ambience. It has a business feel to it. A good amount are talking about their business or startups. I just love it and I will keep coming back. They also have a coffee roaster and you can get fresh roasted coffee. After watching a TED talk on coffee, apparently freshly roasted coffee makes a huge difference on your cup. They sell 12 oz bags for $18, a bit pricy but well worth the investment.
author: Brian C.

description: Cool place! Great coffee! Indoor & outdoor seating! Music I haven't heard before...but COOL!  I'd come back when we're in town..
author: Adam H.

description:
No Wi-Fi and no power source? Seriously?!
Personally I was completely unimpressed with my overall experience. I'd heard some "good" things about this pace before hand, but sadly it was a big MEH for me. From service to ambiance to coffee, pretty average in my book. I shan't be wasting any more of my time in any more line ups at this place!
author: Denyse L.

description:
This is why the Mission is my choice in neighborhood for a fun meet-up with girlfriends (or guy friends, I don't discriminate if coffee is involved). My friend suggested we meet here as she raved about their almond milk latte. Though I was quite a few blocks away from here, I decided to make the mini trek to Four Barrel. Figured I could use the walk after taking on the deliciousness of the Mission (I visit SF just to eat, and think that's absolutely normal). Four Barrel - you did not disappoint!

I was immediately excited as I walked in to find a warm, cabin-like atmosphere with wooden tables. The coffee shop was big, and completely packed! I liked their long communal tables, perfect for a large group or for sharing with friendly strangers. 

The coffee! I love love love roasted/non-acidic coffee and that's exactly what I got! Of course, I had to get the almond milk latte as per my friend's (persistent) urging, and the almond milk added a synergistic nutty flavor that I loved! To my dismay, there was no way I could take on a pastry post-lunch so I didn't get the Kouign Amann - but I've had it before from B Patisserie - and it makes for a perfect complement to a good cup of coffee! One note: they don't have stevia here! :( Ready to get weird stares from my friend, I popped one out from my emergency spot but it would've been great if they had some.

*This place is not for studying! No wifi, super loud, and I doubt they have outlets. Come here to enjoy happy weather, great coffee, and an energized crowd - the perfect representation of Mission district.
author: Aradhana V.

description:
Great little place for a nice fresh cup of coffee. Cute little location with nice seating inside and infront of the store. Only thing is it is a pretty popular spot so there is a bit of a wait and sonetimes they forget or mess up on an order. Other than that if you have time in the area...this is a great stop. 

And grab the pistachio croissant if they have them! They are killer!.
author: Gabriela R.

description:
Why is Four Barrel Coffee amazing? Because they care about their community! I used to work for a non-profit organization in SF, and we asked big chain coffee places like Starbucks and Peet's Coffee to donate to our programs and events, and literally none of them did. However when I asked Four Barrel, they were gladly willing to donate fresh grounds of coffee, and not just 1 or 2 bags but pounds of coffee for our needs. 

On to the coffee, it's legit. Try if for yourself and you won't regret it. 

Very spacious interior, and yes it has the whole hipster industrial chic look, but you can't deny it looks nice.
author: Steve C.

description:
So good.period. get the pour over-its like honey in your mouth. 

Only Boo factor-no wifi.
author: Priscilla N.

description: Here's the thing, they make their own almond milk at this location ONLY! The difference is worth going way out of my way to get here! I'm biased. I like Four Barrel coffee better than all the others. Worth the wait if there is a line. Worth a stay if there is seating!
author: Sergio M.

description: I liked the coffee here better than blue bottle. A bit more of a refined edge, not as bitter/acidic. Had a cappucino and there was a faint hint of sea salt. Pretty darn good and a quintessential sf/mission atmosphere
author: Philip L.

description:
In all fairness, I'm not a coffee expert.  As long as it tastes good, I'm content.  Four Barrel has great coffee beans, and the coffee is exactly what I want in the morning.  This coffee doesn't need a ton of sugar or cream to make it delicious.  I will actually drink it black.  The price is fair, and the baristas are chill.

The only downside is a long line, but as long as one isn't rushing, the line isn't too bad.
author: Amanda J.

description: The best coffee in SF. The best coffee I ever had, ever ever ever. I'm here every day, 5 years and counting. I probably leave half of my paycheck here. Did I say it's the best? Super nice staff too. Coffee!!! Wheee. (Ok maybe I just had a tad too much caffeine).
author: Dejana B.

description: Staff attitude is bad. Place is crowded and coffee is good. So if you can stand the long lines, the poor attitude, the fact you have no place to sit and the high prices then go for it.
author: Balon N.

description: Awesome deco & great coffee! Will visit again soon.
author: Sujin K.

description:
Shaky towns' coffee culture is an interesting topic. It's flavorful aroma is pungent and familiar enough that it has become its own fog, and it has managed to engulf a small(ish) city we call San Francisco. 

With the promise of an immediate energy boost, we've collectively become so reliant on this brown bitter liquid that the thought of how ridiculously expensive it is has faded away with karl the fog. So hunting down the best cup of coffee is a game every San Franciscan plays, and for a brief moment I think I've won this game.

Upon entry, the spacious caffeine laboratory emits a high-end essence, and it's ambience is significantly amplified with romantic songs about heartbreak that will fill every 90's indie / emo kid with nostalgia. You feel like a bitch'n prom queen/king.

Greeted by four boars, I follow their eyes to the wooden menu. Yup, as expected $4 for a small cup of Cappuccino. Maybe that's why they're all silently squealing.

A hairy man steps forward to the counter.

"Hey brah." A recycled fake smile. "What would you like?" While mindlessly staring at his tattoos like a 5-year-old boy locked onto a pair of breasts, I went with what the poor Boars neglected: A $4 Cappuccino. As feelings of guilt rushed through my fingers, I tapped on "15% tip." Why did I do that?

"CAAAAAPPUCCINUUU!"

The hairy lumber jack "brah" covered in tattoos stylishly handed me the clay half-assed mug with a genuine smile. He must have known I tipped him. Son of a boar.

After scanning the room several times, I parked my submarine (heavy ass bag) on a chair across from a not-so-hairy man sliding away on Tinder. As I cupped my palms around the mug, he was surprised by my presence, quickly hid his phone in embarrassment, gulped his coffee, and power walked out of the front door to continue his search for a Tinderella. 

Slightly better and smoother than the rest, I sipped on my overpriced bitter-sweet coffee, and pulled out my vibrating phone out of my butt-pocket. 

"Jenna sent you a message!"
author: Ken W.

description:
Cutest cafe I've ever visited. 

I ordered the latte with almond milk ($4.75). Espresso was strong and flavorful. Perfect morning/afternoon/evening cup. Whether you're here to read on your own or catch up with an old friend, this place has lots of tables available for you to enjoy your caffeine fix in the perfect setting. 

They also have this nice little deck on the sidewalk with "bar-like" seating for you to enjoy the sun or relax outdoors. Although I hate having to pay for sunday meter, parking has definitely been less of an issue on the weekends with that implemented. Otherwise, walk/muni here so you can avoid the hassle of looking for a parking spot. 

I just wish they had a closer location so I could visit this place more often!
author: Patricia K.

description: Legit. Great space and staff. Awesome vibes. Hot chocolate game...weak sauce...coffee and pastries..amazing! #westcoasttrotting
author: Raysa L.

description: Coffee was not good at all, though the barista was good at drawing on my capuccino. Also, staff seemed not to be interested in their guests at all. A bit disappointing
author: Aistė R.

description: Great decor, great atmosphere, great music, and most importantly, great coffee and friendly baristas. Glad I stopped in. It's close to some other cool and quirky shops too. Definitely worth the trip.
author: Michael C.

description:
5.0 kouign amman
3.0 coffee

We dropped in with the intent of having the kouign amann pastry.  This is my favorite French pastry now.  Half croissant and half palmier.  So buttery and flaky. I got the chocolate one.  The kouign here made 7x7 Magazine's 100 things to eat before you die list.

I enjoyed it, but  my all time favorite is the kouign amann made by the Starter Bakery in the east bay.

As for the coffee, I'm puzzled.  I had the drip coffee, Guatemala ?? Something.  It looked like a strong cup of coffee but it lacked robust flavor.  I'll need to try a French press cup of coffee next time.
author: Shirley N.

description:
Four Barrel Staff do not know how to roast their own beans.

Sorry, it's a tough thing to say aloud, but it's also true.

The atmosphere is cool looking, but inside it's not that comfortable with stiff chairs, and zombie staff members, who give you extremely (even with milk), bitter cofffee, and its not the beans - its the way they make it!

Maybe that's how their regular customer wants it, but I consider myself a coffee lover, and I've had Four Barrel beans at OTHER establishments who have made the latte's I've ordered SING.

In estimation - here's a recommendation - Go to OTIS CAFE on Maiden Lane downtown between Grant and Post.

They roast Four Barrel beans to perfection, great fast service by two sweet girls who obviously know their stuff.

OTIS CAFE - trust me. They know Four Barrel better than anyone.

As for FB - they, much like the other FB, lost my support.
author: Kristina B.

description:
Yes!! This!! Ambience, service, size, location.... All 5 stars. Most critically for this coffee snob, their bean is par excellence. It pairs nicely with the pastry (I opted for the bacon and cheddar scone - - yeah I did! Mmmm..... no regrets).
After finding the *worst* coffee on the west coast only 24 hours ago, I'm thrilled to have found a delicious cup in a great spot. The buzz about this place doesn't begin to describe its greatness. Wonderful place, wonderful people, beautiful coffee and pastries. Hooray for this cafe!!
author: Elizabeth D.

description:
NO WIFI - wtf this is freaking SF. 

I came to get some work done and have a cup of coffee or two. Coffee is great but the service is shitty. One of the chicks came to remove my coffee when I still wasn't done? Are you kidding me? #Rude 

Good place to come and chat but not the place for you to come and do work.
author: Ron C.

description:
First 'real coffee' encounter!

I'm not a huge coffee person. In fact, I'm definitely more of a tea person. That said, I do enjoy the taste of coffee every now and then. 

I ordered the latte. Added in several teaspoons of raw sugar (I have a tremendous sweet tooth!) It was a pretty great cup of coffee...especially on a cool morning in SF. I was pleased to see that they offered almond milk as a non-dairy alternative. Maybe next time I'll try that with my coffee. 

Four Barrel is actually pretty spacious. Their coffee bar is in the middle of the store, and there's a slow drip coffee station to the left. There's seating all around, mostly communal though. 

Pretty great coffee shop. Perfect for talking/chatting with a friend. Can't wait for my friend to introduce me to more great coffee spots around the city!
author: Carole Y.

description:
For the mocha, the hot chocolate, and the slow drips. For the ability to get yummy pastries and bags of coffee to take home.  And for the ok-dog-rule (you can bring your well-behaved pet inside with you).  YAY. :D

ILY Four Barrel~
author: Jennifer Y.

description: Yummmmmmmm the coffee is sew gouda gouda. I have like 84 check ins here they must be doing something right
author: Alex S.

description: Welcoming, homey, large coffee shop on Valencia St. Unique bike parking and charming space. Staff are accommodating and friendly, and my favorite part is the pour over bar on the side. Note that there is no wifi, so its a place for reading, chatting, or offline work.
author: Sebastian L.

description:
Like Philz? Like Blue Bottle? In WHAT WAY?  I see that it's a prime spot for hipsters and it smells freaking good when you walk into here.
