I understand that places can make Caffe Lattes a little differently but generally it's a shot of espresso with some steamed milk and foam.  Unfortunately, the espresso wasn't strong enough in flavor to break out of the milk.  All I could taste was light, coffee-flavored milk... I could've made that at home and saved $3.75.

Next time I'll just get a regular cup of coffee.
author: Shannon L.

description: The Four Barrel is so far the best coffee place I have tried in San Fran. I had some experience with high quality coffee at the Embarcadero and the Octavia place (Blue) but this place in unsurpassed so far. The prices are high.
author: Jeffery K.

description:
On the plus side: Gold-standard coffee; expertly prepped.
On the minus: UNHAPPY ABOUT THE ALMOND MILK.  :(

Four Barrel recently switched from soy milk to almond, jumping on some bandwagon to make all the vegans stop drinking coffee, as far as I can tell.  (I'm not even vegan anymore, but I still don't like all that lactose in my coffee.)  It tastes chalky, like a bad soy milk; and it just doesn't foam the same way, _at all_.  Pretty unhappy about this.  Bring back the soy, Four Barrel!
author: Nori H.

description: Very hip and up beat ambience.  I had their latte and it was creamy perfect.  They played California Beach Boy music...super fun.  The place is open and airy with a welcoming feel.  The guy at the counter was helpful too when I wasn't sure what to bring back as a gift.  5 stars!!!
author: Bibi L.

description:
What else can I say about Four Barrel that hasn't been sad in 1400+ reviews?

The Americano that I ordered was on point--the perfect temperature, extraction, and beautiful taste. All of their drinks are double shot, btw. Americanos, coffee, and espressos are $3+tax here. Everything else, like cappuccinos, is somewhere above $3.50+tax.

The setup inside was beautiful (you can actually see the roasting equipment in the back). There's seating outside if you want some fresh air, or seating in the back if you want to see all the action.

The staff was friendly (that's a big deal at some of these SF shops). Don't expect a conversation, but I at least saw them say hello and smile to many people. That's a lot to ask from some of these well-known SF coffee joints.

Sorry, if you're looking for free WiFi, Four Barrel doesn't have it. You're still free to bring your laptop and do non-internet kinda things, though. 

One last thing: if you're in hurry and want a quick drink, this may not be the place for you. It's one of the pretty popular roasters / coffee shops in the area, so you can always expect a line. But waiting in line is well worth it.
author: Tik P.

description:
Decided to pull in here on a 1-hr stopover in San Francisco, and it's such a pleasant aromatic surprise! The shop is retro and low profile, but bustling with one amazing drink after another from the hands of the super-cool tatooed baristas, and the big cranking roaster in the back. 
They have a dedicated bar for single origins, with a great variety of African and South American estate beans to choose from. The baristas amazed me by tossing the first two espresso shots he's not totally satisfied with, and by explaining about each bean with passion, smile and knowledge while deftly crafting my espresso and drip. The Kenya Gachatha drip that I tried was very refreshing with orange blossom notes and a lovely hint of butter in the finish.
This is not a quick coffee fix, but rather an art experience, hearty on a cold rainy day.
Definitely hanging out here again when in San Francisco next.
author: Jimmy C.

description: Probably one of my favorite coffee shops in the city. Simple, delicious coffee. You can add a little bit of milk and sugar if that's your thing, but I think it's one of the few places you can just enjoy the taste of the coffee.
author: Aaron C.

description:
Love, love, love. My latte was great.

This place seems a little douchy and pretentious, but honestly who gives a flying fooey when the coffee is good.
author: Adrian K.

description:
I like to consider myself a coffee connoisseur. Every time I'm in a new city, I like to go on these "coffee quests" and make it an appoint to find myself the best cup of Joe in town and Four Barrel comes pretty darn close. :)

I ordered the cappuccino and it was excellent. Let me just say...my taste buds were quite satisfied and wanted more by the end of the cup. I also liked the concept of an "open space" layout (very different from your typical coffee shop). It created a light and fun environment...and hell, it was poppin'. I just recently moved to the city, definitely coming back for more! Yummy!
author: Kelsey S.

description: This is by far my favorite coffee spot in SF. Consistently great espresso drinks, friendly baristas and a beautiful patio.
author: Rachel L.

description:
I was meeting up with my pal in the Mission to catch up and arrived in the area a bit early.  In need of somewhere to camp till lunch, I navigated over to Four Barrel Coffee.  They're known for their delicious and, as it turns out, pretty strong coffee.  Another thing that I wish I had know earlier however is that they don't have WiFi.

I ordered a simple latte and it doesn't appear that they offer any syrups for flavor.  However, it's really unneeded because the coffee itself has so much flavor.  I'm not a connoisseur, but even I could drink this stuff unsweetened.

There is a public parklet that is open to anybody so you can enjoy your Four Barrel Coffee outside with your dog.  It was a fairly wet day in the city so the seats were empty this time but I can imagine them being quite busy on most days.  Prices are pretty much on par with coffee in the area and my latte was $3.75.  The shop is abuzz all-day, everyday and so it can get pretty loud normally.  If you want a quiet place to read, this probably isn't for you.  But if you just want to grab and go, you've come to the right place.

Food: 8/10

Service: 8/10

Price: $

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description: Beautiful interior and delicious coffee. I got the affogato with buffalo milk gelato -- creamy, not too sweet, and a perfect complement to their smooth espresso. Highly recommended.
author: Jen T.

description:
I ordered an iced mocha and it tasted good...and then I found a long hair in it.  And another long hair. :(

I'm scared to go back.
author: David A.

description: We visited on a recent vacation to SF. A friend had recommended it. I'm so glad. It was artistically decorated and had amazing coffee/pastries. And we're picky when it comes to coffee & pastries. If you love savory delights, their "everything croissant" will blow your mind. Not a lot of seating, but I expect that with coffee shops. The seat we were at was an uncomfortable high bar, but we were on vacation and having fun. This place is a place we'll remember from our trip. If you're going to work or read a book, maybe not the best place.
author: Jennifer A.

description:
Very, very good coffee. I got a Chemex Guatemalan roast, which turned out having great strong flavor (unfortunately I can't go into deep description into the coffee notes because a very long wine tasting session and more coffees came shortly afterward, blocking out my memory of the taste...will update next time! I just remembered that I LOVED it). This stuff is not the typical diluted hand-poured coffee water you get at most places in South Bay or Blue Bottle.

Service was excellent. This is definitely one of my top spots for coffee in Norcal.
author: Dianna D.

description:
Most roasts here are single origin with the exception of one espresso blend and one decaf blend. I think the roasts here are more suitable for the french press or espressos. I haven't really found out which ones are better for pour over. Probably all of them. I'll have to pick up a bag to make at home. Pour over is only available earlier in the day, before 3PM.

Service is great. You will go unnoticed here. One can even pay up after walking away with one cup of coffee and while thinking about a second.

The tables here are tiny, but just enough for one or two people. They are definitely not comfortable, but at least you'll get some work done. There is also bar or counter space in the back. It's space efficient and I like the large empty floorspace in the center so that it's apparent where the line forms or the baristas can immediately greet you from behind the counter. I also like that all the coffee-making action is right behind the low counter right in the center of the room. The low counters make me feel like I can walk right over and make myself a cup of coffee or wash my own mug after using.

Another cool thing about this place is that all their music is played on vinyls. The single restroom looks nice with fresh flowers, pretty wallpaper, and chandelier, even the floor has a neat graphic, but it could do with some air freshener.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
I have conflicting emotions when it comes to Four Barrel Coffee.

I love the space. There are lots of lumberjack looking, bearded guys standing around drinking coffee, looking hot. (Hey, straight bears are my target demographic.) I love that they roast on site. I love that they sell Dandelion Chocolate at the counter. Beautifully simple and rustic decor.

It's so full of it's own pretension that I gagged on it - oh, wait, that was just the overly roasted (see all burnt) coffee beans.  All of the seating is meant for looks and not comfort so I ended up with my left butt cheek asleep after 25 minutes.

So, yeah, I don't know where I stand on Four Barrel. I will visit again and report back, okay?
author: Tara H.

description:
This is my #2 go to coffee. #1 is Stumptown coffee, also known as the best damn coffee I've ever enjoyed. Four Barrell is just about the only place I will purchase whole beans b/c I know they roast em in house, often and refuse to provide the customer with stale beans. Other places, even my beloved Philz, have been known to dish out stale beans and that's not exactly good for the customer. 

I'd like to thank everyone at Four Barrel for their dedication and excellent customer service.
author: Hector G.

description: The espresso guy was very knowledgable and it was delicous! Pour over was good too.
author: E T.

description: Sure, this place is super cute but the prices and wait for the bathroom make me feel like a chump.  The almond macadamia milk is perfectly putrid.
author: Tina H.

description: It's really awesome that this place has such an awesome vibe. I adore that this place is very hip and modern. Love the little details that this place had put the effort in to like the wood tables, Chemex bottles, coffee bean mason jars and much more!
author: Michelle M.

description:
Ordered a cafe latte with almond milk here and it was surprisingly good! Never tried it with almond milk before so I was surprised that it tasted so light, just the way I liked it! The place itself is nice but one disappointing thing is that there is no outlet to plug your laptop! There were many tables to sit, but no outlet? C'mon! I was desperate for one to charge my phone! Also, the restroom was dirty and stinky! They need to clean it daily!!!!

For these two reasons, I am giving it 3 stars.  Otherwise, I do like the drinks here.
author: Nhi R.

description: Cool, clean spot.  You can see the workspace, which has this neat (dare I say steampunk?) looking roaster.  Cheaper than I was expecting.
author: Zachary S.

description:
I am moving this to 3 stars because I was grumpy when I wrote the review. Review stands, although I am wholly aware both are wildly insignificant. 

Their ability to make a cold pressed iced coffee well... decent. However, They *THINK* they have turned water into wine.  It's surreal. You made cold pressed coffee. Get over yourselves.  This coffee is fine if you accidentally happen upon it.  But going here?  If you are into architecture and design, which I am.... the beautiful space will immediately be destroyed by EVERYBODY.

It's absurd, it's objectionable, and it's just stupid. The smarmy smug and disinterested "I bet you are ordering wrong" vibe from the cashier, the "we're saving the world but we're just making a stupid drink" culture, the hipster pastries that are just dry and flavorless....

And this: 

"Oh you want a certain type of drink?  That's wrong, you don't know what you want"....

That is my favorite thing about SF, it's hipster culture of stupid BS, and how no one understands business vs branding themselves as a fad "flash in the pan trend" vs someone with long term sense.  They have firmly anchored themselves with being a  gimmick.  It's why Apple won't be on top forever.... you get about 5 years of telling the consumer what it wants before they figure out they've been tricked.

Here's the hallmark of why this place sucks:

We're talking 10,000 sq feet of space and they don't have one available trash can inside or out for the guests?

This is the type of place that makes me so happy to have moved from the cultural void that is SF.  The lack of self awareness is absolutely shameful.
author: Uncle Fishbits Aeneas X.

description: You know what you're getting with 4 barrel. the coffee is good, I'm glad they're open early. Some coffee places in that neighborhood aren't open early which is crazy. I like that they have a pour over bar to ease the line situation. Not my favorite coffee but it's pretty good and very consistent.
author: Geoff G.

description: Great coffee place in the Mission. Very spacious interior with sidewalk seats outside. I'm not the best judge of coffee, but I thought it was pretty good :) Dog friendly too!
author: Sherry L.

description: I never thought I'd really be able to tell the difference between good coffee and bad coffee.  In college I just drank the frap-type cofees from the chain coffee places for the caffeine kick to get me through classes and hated anything close to black coffee.  I realized I was drinking coffee all wrong and it was only because I had never been introduced to GREAT coffee until I went to Rome and had an espresso that knocked my socks off.  When I came home I was sad that no one had coffee like them until I discovered Four Barrel.  Four Barrel helped me see that I had been doing coffee all wrong here.  I love their mochas.  They aren't super sweet like the chain coffee places and the chocolate they use isn't just the cheap stuff.  Four Barrel coffee has changed my view on drinking coffee; I no longer drink it for the caffeine fix.  I drink it because it's good stuff.
author: L C.

description: Great coffee.  Just that - pure and simple.  Only have tried the slow drip varieties; it's been so good, I haven't had the heart to try anything else.  Great coffee spot.
author: Rachael S.

description:
***The coffee at Four Barrel looks like serious business and their kouign amann from B. Patisserie is crispy, crunchy, flaky, light, sticky, moist, and sweet***

I am not a coffee drinker, but I think Four Barrel is probably a great spot for coffee lovers.  Four Barrel is a fairly big place, but it was still quite packed with coffee drinkers on a late weekday afternoon.

The servers seem to be hipster types and the same goes for the atmosphere.  The space is big, open and industrial.  It is also rustic with a few subtle throwback decorations here and there.

While some restaurants have open kitchens, Four Barrel has an open roasting room (that is enclosed in glass).  There are huge machines where the casually dressed staff roast the coffee beans.  The room is a little bit art studio and a little bit high school shop.

They had a few nice looking pastries, but I was there to try the kouign amann from B. Patisserie, which will be opening up its own brick and mortar location soon.  I've never had this pastry before so I don't know how it rates against other places, but I liked this one a lot.

It was a mix of crispy, crunchy and flaky pastry.  It was also nicely sweet without being too sugary.  It had a great and moist honey center.

Service was quick and fine.

The price of the pastry was high, but that is to be expected given that they are bringing in a fresh pastry from an outside gourmet shop.

If you've never had this pastry before, I think Four Barrel is worth a try.  And if you are a coffee fan, you might find some good stuff here.

Street parking in Mission is hard to find so you might be in for a walk.
author: Anthony N.

description: It's different than your average drink place. You'll be thinking you're lost because of its location. It's in an ally filled with graffiti. Some may not like it but the ally and the graffiti and the crate seats kinda made it what it is. Soon this place will find its niche and grow to become a pretty good looking place. Not yet but looking forward to changing this 3 to a 5 star.
author: Gemini M.

description: Espresso was good, had a unique taste to it, but definitely not burnt like Starbucks coffee is. Price was reasonable- $3.26 including tax for a shot of espresso. Not horrendous. Loved the decor, especially the pig heads hanging on the wall, and the fact that they had almond, soy, and regular creamer, as well as different types of chunky granulated sugars to add into your coffee.
author: Matt D.

description:
I had been driving by Four Barrel for some time. With the aesthetics of outdoor seating and a spacious interior, I was excited to try this spot and paid for the parking thinking I would be spending time there. 

What I found was $3 brewed coffee (they graciously charge 50 cents extra for the luxury of frozen water in it) that luckily I sampled before purchasing because it truly was awful, weak and acidic. There was no tea selection to refer to in absence of good coffee and they offered unappealing, expensive pastries that looked like small children baked them. Not to mention no wifi, which for $3 a pop I would think the owners would afford their customers. 

Because of all of the above, I walked out without buying anything or staying, and with no plans return. To me, this is just a trendy, crappy coffeehouse capitalizing on people's poor sense of coffee.
author: Shannon V.

description:
Smooth coffee. Knowledgeable staff. Lots of seating room -though not enough for their huge following, for sure. I like the rustic yet sophisticated feel and the buzz -- of the people and the coffee!

Definitely worth the stop for coffee enthusiasts!
author: Jess L.

description: One star for the pretentious Batista making snide remarks. I was asking my friend what type of machine they were using and the smart-mouthed barista looked at us stone cold and said, "It's called an espresso machine." I said, "I know but what kind?" He replied that he didn't know. Two seconds later he told us what kind and said it was custom. We all left before even trying the coffee because we were so put off by the barista.
author: LoveFood W.

description: Amazing coffee, large space that can accommodate the almost 100 people we saw in there. You can watch them roasting and bagging their own coffee in the back. They have a satellite pour-over coffee bar, and extra seating in the parkette out front on the street.
author: Stephen Y.

description: I hate to admit I have turned into such a coffee snob, and I think I have Four Barrel to blame. It is crazy hipster, a super fun interior with the coffee roasting machine in the back, and lots of wood and cool wall decor. I could hang out for hours in this place just looking around. The coffee is so smooth and flavorful, and the espresso drinks are creamy and delicious. I also love the bike parking! I would honestly come here every day if my employer allowed me to work in coffee shops.
author: Liza F.

description:
The coffee is stupid good and ordering from their Slow Bar provides for an even tastier cup, as well as a conversation with one of their knowledgable baristas. At times, the line at the register may seem long, but I usually have coffee in my hand in a matter of minutes.

Their pastries are great, but I rarely get them because I'm so intent on having my tastebuds enjoy every last drop of coffee that escapes my mug.

The atmosphere is great as well. They have a wall dedicated to the display of the works of  one local artist at a time. You can watch employees roast coffee in the back. There's a bike rack outside next to a spacious parklet with bar seating.They almost always have vinyl spinning, including Sabbath, Beatles and Tame Impala. From the chandelier in the bathroom to the hog trophies towering above the clientele near the register, it's obvious that a lot of thought went into creating the resulting ambience.
author: Walter R.

description: Coffee here is amazing and the crossiants are equally good.  The decor is beautiful and the line moves fast.
author: Sudoni M.

description:
Didn't enjoy the service from the man who took my order. He didn't seem very friendly but more than likely because of how busy it was. 

I ordered a dark chocolate mocha and it was amazing! Not too hot to where I couldn't drink it but warm enough where it didn't get cold in five seconds. I also ordered a banana chocolate croissant. Loved it! 

A major plus is this place has wi fi! 

I would probably go again if it was a little less packed. A friend and I tried this place out together but couldn't get a seat for a few minutes.
author: Erica L.

description:
Space is beautiful and it's a full house at any given time.  

Pet peeve: people who are quick to label everything and everyone in the Mission as "hipster" or people who say the Mission has started to gentrify. Ask the Mission natives. They'll tell you gentrification has started in the neighborhood YEARS before the tech busses started wheeling in the South Bay folks. And if anything, Four Barrel feels somewhat trendy as far as SF goes since it appears there are probably more people coming here to "check out the scene" and see what the fuss is all about than those who are actual coffee afficionados. 

Now to the coffee. Coffee itself is wonderful. There is a certain balance of acidity that I seek in a good cup and they have it. Flavor is definitely there and some people appreciate a good cup when they see it, others don't and pretend they do. I've seen this pretentiousness first hand. 

Staff is friendly enough (there is nothing worse than a crabby or a despondant looking staff serving you coffee) and my cup arrives within decent time despite the lengthy lines.
author: Esther A.

description: For really fun coffee entertainment, you can't beat this place. Bring a friend and a few bucks and enjoy yourself. The structure is awesome, the staff is working hard, and the coffee is really very good. If you want to sip alone snuggled up with your iPad in a quiet corner, maybe this is not the place...
author: laurence c.

description: AMAZING coffee selection - the pour over selection cycles and they have some of the best coffee selection in town. It's such a treat to watch the roasting process in the back and if you're interested enough they will talk you through the process and give you information if you want to know more. I use take my coffee with cream but their coffees are so exceptional and flavorful and has so much depth of flavor that I drink it black.
author: Zarlakhta W.

description: Great coffee - esp. love the iced latte. Friendly staff, cool space - just what you would expect for a cafe on Valencia Street/the Mission/SF.
author: Sarah T.

description: Perfect way to spend a rainy Sunday. It's a coffee house, but I think they should rename themselves Bacon Cheddar Scone and Four Barrel Coffee. I'm definitely too old to blend in with this hipster crowd, but it was a great vibe and great cup of Joe.
author: Richard W.

description:
You know how they have the "vegetarians go crazy for this place" option on yelp? They should have one for "hipsters go crazy for this place" so you know when to avoid a place full of snobs. The decor of it was cool, but overall it was a really meh place. If you're going to act too cool to serve certain people then maybe you should require a secret code before walking in and blatantly state your craft is just way too precious for public consumption. Anyways had an iced almond milk latte because although I love whole milk my stomach likes to disagree and almond milk was my only other option. I took a sip and was instantly reminded why I don't do almond milk. The coffee itself wasn't anything to rave about either. I ended up giving it away. Maybe I'm biased because I worked for Philz, but no one will ever top an iced Philtered Soul for me.

PS with the length of hair that the guys who work here have... how are you getting away with not having hair fall in people's drinks... I don't know whether to be impressed or creeped that you guys do better hair flips than I do....
author: Puka N.

description: Such delicious coffee. Took me from near dead hungover to having a reason to live again. And the chocolate hazelnut donut. Holy fuck.
author: Regina L.

description:
One of my favourite coffee shops in the city. The staff are simply astonishing at what they do, and the coffee is crazy good. It's no wonder there are queues all the way to the outside.

I also love that they all share the load and do everything from making amazing coffee to the dishes.
author: Sam H.

description: I had such high expectations for a place so highly recommending by a friend. Firstly, I bought an almond milk mocha for over $7 that tasted awful. I know that this is probably due to the low fat in the almond milk, but they should really improve their recipe by either providing coconut milk or adding more sugar and chocolate. Secondly, I came here to study, and there's no wifi and no plugs! This is really such a bummer, since this place does have great seating. Lastly, there are four mounted pig heads near the counter which are really quite disturbing. I won't return.
author: Bonnie C.

description: If I lived within a one block radius, I'd be here every day. Excellent coffee and pastries. I have a mouth crush on the juicy pieces of fruit inside the scones. Unlike other coffee shops, the people who work here seem like they have had their morning cup. Very fun, cool and hip vibe all around. It's worth the trip.
author: Anna L.

description:
Prime. Came here with a friend who was quite the coffee aficionado. I'm a total noob with coffee and normally drink caramel lattes from Starbucks... but Four Barrel was such an excellent introduction to coffee. Mmm. 

First thing I noticed when coming into the place was how spacious it is. Holy crap. There are very few places I see in SF with that much empty space--which was much needed given how quickly the line reformed every minute! The decor was very hipster as everything in SF tends to be. They had some lovely hipster bike stands outside and outdoor seating.

I ordered a latte and my friend ordered an espresso. As someone who has only had caramel lattes and a plain latte, the Four Barrel latte was such a pleasant surprise. I tend to lean toward sweeter flavored drinks, but the ratio of Coffee to milk in the latte was just perfect. Too perfect. The coffee flavor was plenty prevalent but the normal bitterness was balanced out with the milk. Perfection. Mr. Coffee Aficionado also raved about the smoothness of his espresso.

Can we also please talk about the price here? They charge prices that are pretty much the same (if not cheaper) than places like Starbucks but clearly offer supreme quality drinks. What isn't great about this place?

tldr; best coffee I've ever had
author: Jasmine X.

description: Very disappointing experience here. After having read about the incredible slow pour bar I made a special trip across the city while on vacation to this location to experience the awesomeness. Unfortunately for me, I learned that on Sunday mornings the coffee shop operates like a Starbucks until 8am when the slow pour bar opens. They offer one coffee that comes from a pot (even fewer than Starbucks), and "other coffee drinks". I would understand if they listed the hours for their slow pour bar online, but they don't, so there was no way to know unless I called in advance to make sure a craft coffee shop can do a pour over. This review is a warning to make sure you call in advance to make sure the slow pour bar is open if you would like to choose your coffee from a selection, and get the craft coffee this place is renowned for, and not get one coffee from a pot.
author: Brett B.

description: NO WIFI. I repeat: NO WIFI. Listen, the coffee is pretty delicious and they offer a public parklet outside rather than being butt heads with "for customer only" seating. But everything else about this place reminds me why I left Portland. Including the "post-wifi" silliness.
author: Peter S.

description: You can't deny the taste of Four Barrel's wonderfully selected and prepared coffee. I wish it were a little less precious, but I wish a lot of things in San Francisco were a little less precious.
author: John M.

description: Spend less time talking and more time running your business. Really? Talking instead of helping customers?
author: Diana L.

description:
I didn't know what to expect when I came in for the first time yesterday. The ambiance was pleasant. It wasn't offensively packed like Ritual usually is. There was a comfy elegance saying: this is a hipster spot but it doesn't have to be a douche spot. I ordered the cafe latte with soy-they don't serve soy but they had almond milk. I watched the barrista take his time making my drink. The coffee was so smooth so delicious. I'm guilty over sweetening my coffee but this latte didn't need anything. I ordered the sugar brioche which was moist and perfect. You can watch the fellow coffee workers work with the coffee beans and everything in the back. 

Great coffee. Great atmosphere. Highly recommended.
author: Caroline N.

description:
14.07.11.         1st visit

Coffee ---------- pretty good
Inside ----------- not design for comfort and not people friendly
Service --------- they need to improve it badly ... in efficient

Note:
      Saw then dump the freshly hot processed bean into rubber containers
            Think of the heat making the rubber releasing the toxic fume into the beans
            Other places were using metal containers.
            Sorry ... after seeing that ... no more
            Think ... BPA, heat something plastic and/or rubber and sniff it
                    ... now picture that in contact with the processed beans !!!
author: S.K. Y.

description:
THE BEST $2 coffee you will ever have! nothing but hot and delicious coffee here.

on another note you can also sit and enjoy a day of "hipster watching" because they are all swarming here, its all good tho.
author: Jaime D.

description:
Four Barrel is a name that gets thrown around often in The City, often in the same sentence as Blue Bottle and Sightglass, so it's been hyped up for me for a long time. I don't know why it took me three years of living in SF (and the seemingly infinite number of cups of coffee imbibed during law school) to finally try Four Barrel.  The interior is decorated with lots of wood accents and cool lighting, there is ample seating, and lots of bike parking out front (I LOL'd at it, to be honest. Sup, Hipsterville.) The older gentleman who took my order was very courteous and the barista was quick and polite. 

But when it comes down to it, the coffee is inferior to those aforementioned coffee roasters. I ordered a cappuccino and an iced coffee.  The iced coffee was bitter, almost as bad as Starbucks. The cappuccino was also a tad on the bitter side, not nearly as bad as the iced coffee, and not nearly as good as Blue Bottle and Sightglass.

I was also appalled at the price of the baked goods. The cookies are tiny, like chips ahoy size, and retail for $1.50. I almost bought a pistachio donut, until I saw a fly land on it, inside the covered display case! I considered all other pastries tainted after that.

I don't like Four Barrel coffee. Sorry I'm not sorry.
author: Jenn C.

description: But really goddamn expensive! Great atmosphere for students by the prices will limit the poorer from even attempting.
author: Annie B.

description: Great coffee and treats, mediocre staff at best (got a hard "fine" when asking how's it going at the register) and no wifi... Now that's a joke. Would say 3.5
author: Kyle M.

description: And the first sip was taken.....OUTSTANDING!!  To get the whole experience I wish I could have sat outside and people watch while drinking this coffee but either way I am enjoying my Saturday. The place is definitely hipster and I like the 2 coffee bar idea. One for pour-overs and one for everything else. The staff was super friendly and there was plenty of different types of coffee beans to choose from.  This is a place I will definitely be again and will be passing the word along. I was also stoked to find that there were 2 other places to get Four Barrels coffee from.
author: Sean B.

description:
Wow.  Another one of those places I swore I had already written a review for!

For years, my go to coffee shop was Ritual down the street.  It still is.  When I bring guests from out of town I take them to two places: Ritual and 4Barrel.

Here's why:
Ritual has a extremely clean taste on their espressos.  Even the blends that are bright and complex, still come out clean.  Clean is good!  It's the mark of a barista that knows what they are doing.  though I must admit I'm not a fan of the Sweet-tooth sometimes.  That's more on the beans than the actual barista though.
then there's 4Barrel.  I'd say just as clean on the after taste as Ritual but I generally love all their Friendos.

4Barrel drinks across the board are tart when infused with fruits but never sour.  The aroma is always heavenly.  The Initial taste is bold, bright and the right amount of bitter.  The after-taste varies but is consistently pleasant. 

the baristas are super awesome.  just good, intelligent people who know their roasting-trade.

I know taste is subjective, but 100% of the people I've brought here agree that this is a top notch roaster in the City.  A must go for all coffee lovers!
author: Anthony L.

description:
Try the lemon thyme donut and thank me later. Wait. That's not all - I can with all honesty recommend just about everything on the menu because I had the great pleasure of staying at my friend's house who lives across the street from this place. The atmosphere is very cool: warehouse style, walls draped with artistic local photos, and bike friendly as witness to the gang of fixed gears outside the front door. 

Now to the coffee. The coffee is divine. Rich. Bold. Smooth. It reminds me of when I went to a coffee plantation in Costa Rica. I don't think I ever had as good of coffee until I went to Four Barrel. My favorite is the latte with almond milk, which is a healthier alternative to soy or skim, but hey you won't be able to tell. 

Truth be told if you are a fan of good coffee this is the best in the city. This place rocks.
author: Melissa P.

description:
A SF native brought us here and summarized- SF takes itself wayyy too seriously. Don't get me wrong, it was so good we came here twice in one day, once for single drip espresso and once for coffee. It was the best espresso and coffee I've ever had. 

However the one shot of espresso took about 20 minutes to make. After selecting beans with the most appropriate "notes," and grinding said beans, they actually made and discarded several shots before arriving at the conclusion the one I was about to consume was acceptable. I have no idea how, apparently I am an espresso philistine. 

After all this waiting, I finally had my first sip.  I think the clouds parted and Jesus rays came streaming down from the heavens. Angels were strumming harps and birds were chirping. Four Barrel you have henceforth ruined all others for me!!

With time to kill in the same area later that day we returned for coffee. Of course it was wonderful.
author: Tara W.

description:
I am impressed with you, Four Barrel.

Service - very friendly

Bacon Cheddar scone and Dynamo Coconut Donut - very yummy

Decaf Americano - very strong

But the biggest reason for the 5 solid stars:

The barista handed my drink to me, then called me back a few minutes later because he realized someone else accidentally made me a regular.   

I was this close to being overcaffeine-ated, but the barista saved me.

Thanks barista dude, I appreciate you!
author: Lucy Y.

description:
I'm not a coffee pro, but if you live in San Francisco you at the very least make half-hearted attempts to keep up with the caffeine consumption rates in this town. 

I have to say this because I know I'm not the only one thinking it. This place is Hipsterville. My hippie (not to be confused with hipster) friend, long-time resident of the Mission, whispered to me, "No matter how long I've been here, I'll never get used to hipsters."

She didn't mean it in a bad way. Just in a way where, if there's a room full of hipsters, or goths, or jocks, or, hell, PUPPIES, you're going to notice the abundance. 

But this is about coffee. 

It wasn't very good here. I've had Four Barrel coffee (French press, no milk no sugar) twice in a restaurant and it was on the acidic side. It also lacked a nice aroma. Since I was straight at the source I decided to try a mocha. The espresso in it was as acidic as my previous samples and it did not mesh well with milk as chocolate. It was unpleasant. 

I wish I had Philz instead. Or Blue Bottle. Maybe even Ritual. Nonetheless, Four Barrel is worth a visit just to survey their space. 

So... Come on down to Hipsterville!
author: Erika C.

description: Love the coffee here. I'm from Seattle and always find the coffee in SF just a little too bold and not quite as smooth as the stuff I'm used to, but Four Barrel was absolutely delicious. So good, so so good.
author: Diana H.

description:
Great tasting coffee, in a very cool venue. 

Latte is very creamy, without being too foamy. 

The wait for your drink is entirely too long, but the cool decor in the space keeps your mind occupied so it is not unbearable. 

Will go here many times again in the future, but will attempt to do so during less peak hours.
author: Chris S.

description:
Probably the best cup of coffe i've ever had! I decided to try their "pour over" coffee which is basically a slower way of brewing and you literally pour the water over the coffee beans thru a filter and it slowly drips into your cup! I had an ethiopian coffee bean and it tasted like vanilla and cranberry. 

Everything was moderately priced $2-4 for most items including pastries and espresso.

Only bad thing is there is no wifi and very limited seating. Not a good place to sit down and read or do some work.

This place is very "hipster" so prepare to see some interesting characters!

located in the Mission. plenty of street parking during the day

can get very busy at times especially at the pour over line since the barista explains to you how the machine works and the different types of flavors
author: Obed C.

description:
Alright, I know this Third Wave coffee business can seem like a bit of hipster nonsense, but I'm pretty much in love with Four Barrel-- so long as I'm there during non-peak hours. If I'm lucky enough to be awake at 8am on the weekend, I'm happy to roll out of bed and stroll over for a fastidiously poured cup of coffee and a carefully selected pastry from one of our local bakeries. Sitting at the window and watching the hipster nonsense walk by as I enjoy my own hipster nonsense is perfectly agreeable and I shan't scoff at it any longer. 

I took one of their secret late-night coffee education classes with their resident coffee nerd Alex, and it was both informative and fascinating. If you don't appreciate coffee, Alex will enlighten you in the most genuine way imaginable. I now understand the magic behind the coffee that less-informed people might judge as over-hyped or pretentious. It was well worth my time to learn about not only the science of coffee, but moreover, the ethical goodness included inside your cup of Four Barrel. 

Quite simply, I appreciate the integrity of their business. And it happens to pair nicely with the taste of an expertly crafted cup of pour-over.
author: Meredith C.

description: I dig the design of this place. I like the island type counter which you can order at, sit alongside or go behind and see the roaster. Ordering process was a bit strange, I was told mine would be the second cappuccino made in the next batch. It works though, but so does taking names. I do like the point of difference though. Coffee was nice though, strong and bold, although milk was over aerated.
author: Chris K.

description: Friendly service, pretty good coffee, great ambiance. Definitely worth a visit - I'll bring my hubs next time.
author: Autumn Y.

description: Drinks are delicious! The seating is a little awkward and the coffee is very expensive, but the location is perfect and the drinks are worth it. Great vibes.
author: Stephanie S.

description: If you like sweet drinks this is not the coffee shop for you. Ordered a mocha and it was not sweet at all. It was more of a very dark bitter chocolate taste and very intense. If you're not used to alot of caffeine I would recommend sharing a drink with someone as the coffee here is super strong. It's a cool coffee shop to look around in though.
author: Cheyne T.

description: Fun coffee joint with yummy pastries and all the fancy espresso you could ever want. Great atmosphere to meet a couple of friends and a cute outdoor area to sit if it's nice outside. Although the line is usually pretty long, if you are a coffee fanatic its definitely worth it.
author: Amanda C.

description:
The first time I came here, I felt really out of place. There were so many hipsters dressed with their big sweaters, chunky scarves, and giant glasses and I walked in here with my workout clothes. BUT, that did not matter to me after I got my coffee because it was fantastic. The coffee is strong and tasty. I really like it and always make a stop when I am in the area. It is also a nice place to hang out with friends or get some work done. Just FYI, there is no wifi, but I still like coming here to get some writing done. 

Funny thing, their bathroom has artwork on the floor. That totally freaked me out, but it was a cool painting.
author: Breniel L.

description:
Great experience, good people, great coffee.  

The place is super cute, they have a record playing that's pumping out jams, boar heads on the walls and adorable staff walking around in best aprons I've ever seen (old school, canvas olive colored fabric w/ rose gold grommets and stripped fabric belt ropes). My attention to detail is intense, I know - but these things were sweet.

The barista was super friendly, asking how my day was and what I was up to - he was just adorable and put a smile on my face. I ordered an espresso shot straight up and waited for my drink.

Considering how busy it was in there, they cranked it out and I soon had my adorable little espresso cup in hand.

The espresso was strong, bold and flavorful.  It packed a great toasty punch with some nice warm smoke flavor and a hint of fruity dry sweetness.  I took my cup outside on the outdoor patio and sat in the sun with my people. It made for a lovely experience and a great overall atmosphere.

You should definitely stop by, you won't regret it.
author: Lauren B.

description: Amazing place, you'll only get coffee there, no pastries The place is epic, has some sort of bean factory where they make there own coffee. They have several types of coffee - Kenyan, Colombian... Had a latte, it was great! They don't have any pastries though. What gives? Tartine is just 2 blocks away though.
author: Amy L.

description: The staff are pretencious and dismissive, but the coffee is fantastic.  My mocha had a heart design on it.  Pretty cool.  The place is backed and super clean.  The prices are steep but worth it as it a nice spacious place to hang on a Saturday morning...
author: Marvelous Margaret M.

description:
One of my favorite coffee spots! I love their lattes. They seem to be the perfect blend. Not too much caffeine (for me, Blue Bottle has waaaay too much). 

The baristas here are always SUPER nice! Definitely worth the wait.

Only thing I hate about this place is when I try to come here to be all hipster with my raybans, macbook, and TOMS I can't use the internet! There's no wifi!!!.. OR OUTLETS!! Occasionally you can steal some neighboring wifi.. but you're better off bringing *GASP*PRINTED BOOKS!
author: Angela L.

description: Four Barrel Coffee smells amazing! The inside of the coffee shop is large and half the shop is devoted to their roasting and grinding of their beans. Pretty crowded and you'd probably not find a place to sit as there aren't too many tables. The line was long, but it moved quickly. I got a latte and thought that it was good. Definitely smelled better than it tastes because I didn't think their milk to coffee ratio was to my preference, but nonetheless, it's amazing coffee. I suggest you come over here and try their coffee and check out the back of the shop too!
author: Carmen C.

description: Love that Four Barrel is super close to my work! Coffee, latte, mochas are all wonderful! Almond milk for the win!! The only downfall is their cups are too small for the amount of coffee I consume lol.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I had a really nice experience here. It was my first time in, so I stopped by the slow bar area near the front for a pourover experience. The guy there was helpful and explained the whole experience here, and then helped me select a blend. The coffee was delicious, even without my typical half and half, which I can appreciate.

It's also a really pleasant environment. There are a bunch of long tables that you can sit at to enjoy your drink and some excellent people watching, or sit down to read or use a tablet/computer if that's your thing. There is also some nice seating at a little bar on the sidewalk outside which is pretty cool.
author: Brent W.

description:
I finally had the opportunity to visit Four Barrel Coffee place last night on my break. 

Even at 7pm, the energetic crowd were socializing and planning for the evening. Others are studying and doing researchs on the free Wi-fi. While I was working and still on-duty with my uniform. 

When I walk in, the center is the square where they do all their kitchen duties and make the crafty beverages and food preparation. I took a $3.00 cup of latte. All coffee and espresso beverages are made from their own line of beans. And with an empty stomach and being Saturday in the evening, I was so shock to see some pastries left. And without any hesitation,  I also took a Balsamic Caramel Glazed doughnut for $3.50. 

When I finally got my drink, my beverage had the foam of the leaf made by the artistic barista. One sip of the beverage, I was like, "Damn, good latte!"

My latte was a nice compliment with my gourmet glazed doughnut. The doughnut was tasty and the unique mixture of both sweet and savory on the glazed topping is something you don't see at any doughnut shop. 

Without a doubt, I'll be back and try the drip coffee made with their own line of specialty beans. 

If you ask me where does Four Barrel rank as best coffee in San Francisco, I couldn't answer that. But it is ranked high up there though as a good coffee place.
author: Matt G.

description:
For my money this is the best coffee in the Bay area. 

Yes there are many other fine spots. But they do a great job of being both cutting edge and approachable at the same time.

Keep up the good work, I'll be in the corner sipping.
author: Jeremy M.

description: Toffee chip cookie is amazing! The coffee is fresh, great consistency and flavor. Will run you about $4 a cup and the cookie around $1.50. Stop by for a cookie at least if you can, just be prepared to dodge the hipsters as they scrounge for outlets for their Mac book airs.
author: Hungry H.

description:
Best espresso in SF.  

Great space, great machines, love that bearded barista guy.  Whats his name?  Thor?  Something like that.  Almost bought his tshirt/mug.  I heard the ginger bearded Thor insulted some guy and made him cry for ordering a soy cappucino.  Hmm.  You crazy west coasters!

Blue Bottle has indeed invaded NYC, but not these guys.  Luckily got pointers from a friend so checked this place out in the Mission.
author: Anita S.

description:
This was _really_ good! There was a bogus line flopping out the doors which I found a little revolting since I'm from Seattle and typically don't have to deal with that. However, I noticed a stand inside that was doing pour overs without a line so I hopped into that. They had a selection of four different beans on display that was really nice -- I wish more places did that. I had Kenya Karatina and ended up buying an 8oz bag of beans as well. It was really delicious and had an amazing fruity aftertaste that I've never experienced before. 

The building is really quite spacious, but it was a beautiful day and I opted to sit outside. Got to chat about coffee with the baristas a little bit too. Highly recommended.
author: Stanlo S.

description:
Hipster heavy environment. Women Barista was on one during our visit.

She served up coffee to patrons that ordered after us. Maybe on purpose, maybe not. When we inquired about our order she didn't look too pleased.  The steam power of the barista machine must have gotten to her head. With great power, comes great bitchiness.

Little flies were trapped in their baked goods case.

Great coffee though.
author: Robin K.

description:
Wowza. This place was busy but run like a machine. I was totally impressed by the number of people that move through this place. 

There is a counter for espresso drinks such as americano, latte and the like. All of this is with Four Barrel coffee that I believe is roasted in the back. I thought the coffee was excellent. The service was fast and friendly.

There is also another counter that handles only hand poured coffee.  

The seating is not abundant for such a large place but there are a number of seats. All of them were full when I was there.

This place also has a unique bathroom. Go see it. Trust me.
author: Ryan L.

description: I landed in SF, with 2 bags of luggage and began wandering around the city, to stop and read at a coffee place. Four Barrel Cafe was on my walk, and I dropped in for a quick but delicious cup of iced latte. This turned into a four-hour people watching episode: colleagues chatting, French people debating, and a couple chasing each other, in a passionate argument. Outside, there's a seating awning where I enjoyed myself until it began drizzling. With my hands numb, I went inside and drank a hot latte with a donut. That was probably the most amazing cup of coffee I've had in my life. The donut was a creative spin on passion fruit and caramel, so it was pretty good...but not my favorite. I am going back to the cafe right now to get some coffee beans, so I can enjoy the goodness back in San Diego.
author: Marina P.

description:
Not a huge fan of the coffee but it is good. Most of all, though, I'm not a fan of the rude, self-important, snobbish folks who tend to inhabit the place; not, all mind you, but enough it often makes for an unpleasant experience.

I was standing in line recently and a young man ran into me while walking and texting. He looked at me with a scowl and told me to watch where I was going. No, I didn't hit him and I didn't yell at him. I just laughed at him. The young lady behind me looked him in the eye and asked, "Are you serious??? You ran into him!" He stormed off. I bought her coffee.

Oh, and Four Barrel folks, I know you don't have any control over those kind of rude folks. I just wish you did.
author: John A.

description: Yes. Stopped in because of the cool name and cool decor but man the coffee too we discovered is obviously what this place is known for
author: Lisa K.

description:
Unfortunately I'm dropping my favorite shop in SF down to a 4 star because, like almost every other great coffee shop in SF, I think their roast is a bit too light. I'm wondering if this trend is because (possibly) SF coffee fans tend to prefer extremely light roast (possibly because it's the opposite end of the spectrum from chain coffee like Starbucks).

I still love Four Barrel, but I gotta be honest.
author: Bernard F.

description:
Frankly, it's 3.5 stars but I'll round up because the average cup of coffee is quite good. Great ambience, good feel, and packed with people from all the popularity. 

You can't really come in to enjoy and sit because it's a little on the louder side for noise level. You have to get in, grab your coffee, then get out.
author: Ernest L.

description:
Step into Four Barrel Coffee is like stepping into a like an Abercrombie store. Good looking staff, customers you want associate with, music pumping from many speakers hung around the store. Bruce Springsteen's classic album Born to Run was the music when I went.

As for the coffee, they use chocolate pieces instead of syrup in the mocha. Now you know.
author: Lams L.

description:
What gets this LA girl walking half an hour from the Mission to SOMA every day when I'm in town for work, even if I'm lugging a 100 pound laptop? Only Four Barrel, baby. From the moment I wake up I look forward to my trips to Four Barrel, where the smiling hipsters behind the counter fill my cup with their rich, strongly caffeinated delicousness and fuel my power walk through the ghetto and to my office. Sometimes when I'm feeling really decadent I'll indulge in one of their banana chocolate chip scones, and figure I'll just pump my legs that much harder to burn the calories off. 

The coffee's pretty reasonably priced, though the beans and the pastries are pretty pricey. It's still a great gift idea though for the coffee lovers in your life - I picked up a few bags for Christmas and they were (for the most part) a hit. Beware - the beans range from $16-20... quite a pretty penny!

One day I'll stop by when I'm not in a rush to get to work and enjoy their nice outdoor or indoor seating. I always envy those who can kick back in the mornings with their newspapers and cups o' joe while I'm hurrying on my way! 

Cheers to one of my favorite local coffee spots - thanks for keeping me moving!
author: Christina P.

description:
Brass Tacks

nothing but

aaaand I rest my case.
(light roast, smooth, wonderful flavor, perfect with the donut I just had)
author: Jana C.

description: 5 stars for the option if having almond milk... Which made my almond milk cappuccino both healthy and delicious!  Prices are steep...$4.50 for one drink, but the quality is good and service is friendly and fast. If I was in the area I would definitely stop in.
author: Hayley H.

description: Short and simple DON'T get the mocha the nastiest thing ever! It literally taste like chalk. No flavor what so ever! The place is cute and all but it would be better if they had more coffee choices. The menu is basic not much to offer and the coffee is pretty pricey. I have been to better coffee shops.
author: Mayra G.

description:
This cool hipster looking coffee shop has a cool vibe to it.  After walking in I saw 3 different lines and just decided to line up in the main line.  The one to left is for made to order coffees which cost more and the long line in the back is the bathroom.

I had gotten coffee with 3 other people and we unanimously thought that the coffee was too sour.  Adding cream helps but it is still noticeable.  I also prefer my coffee to have a darker roast than what was served but I wouldn't count that against them.
author: Kenneth H.

description: I love Four Barrel. The coffee is delicious, the pastries as well ( a bit expensive but that's pretty much most of SF) and the people roasting the coffee are so so nice. I love that it is so close to my office and that it is open early. Yay Four Barrel.
author: Dounia L.

description:
This place deserves every ounce of it's accolades!

I'm a huge coffee snob and a service industry veteran and I can tell you the employees here excel in every category, not the least of which is PASSION. They love what they are doing and it's apparent. 

While you are becoming intoxicated by the incredible aromas generated by they're amazing coffee, you are being told a story about the man who grew the beans! 

Now, I can't  recommend that you go during crazy busy times but, just know, there is a very good reason they are busy.

GO. Enjoy the coffee, the pastries and the service. You'll be back.
author: Robert M.

description: My fiance and I came here in the late afternoon and ordered the Affogato and Iced Coffee. The Affogato was absolutely delicious! The ice cream was so good and I think they hand make it on site. The espresso was strong and bitter, but it went really well with the sweetness of the ice cream. The Affogato was the most expensive drink on the menu to my knowledge, but it is worth it! The Iced Coffee was good too, but the Affogato is the best in my opinion. The atmosphere of Four Barrel is peaceful too. Lots of people were sitting down studying and talking. We will definitely come again! ;)
author: David B.

description:
This is my favorite coffee shop in San Francisco. By far. 

Allow me to offer a few dos and don'ts for those who haven't visited yet:

1) Don't Instagram your coffee. The world doesn't need more of those. Just stop it.
2) Do check out the pour overs. Good way to skip the main line when they're busy
3) Don't ask for a punch card. It's not that kind of place.
4) Do visit when it's nice out. There's outdoor seating and parking for your bike.
5) Don't ask for a Venti. No one has ever enjoyed a Big Gulp sized coffee.
author: David P.

description:
If you like drip coffee, go to Philz or Blue Bottle. If you love espresso, this is a true espresso bar!

The barista knew what she was doing.  My latte came out perfectly.  The foam was stiff enough to hold a design, and even better it could hold the raw sugar I usually add to my coffee.  That's good foam!

I was so impressed by the espresso machine that I inquired about it.  Apparently, the espresso machine was custom-built for Four Barrel.  So, there's nothing like it!

My only qualm was that the coffee could have been hotter.  It was warm, but I wanted it hot.  I like to sit and read with a coffee.  By the time I was done reading, the coffee was colder than I prefer.  The upside: no coffee granules/sediment on the bottom, so it's good to the last drop.

There are plenty of seats, for 2 people or 4 people.  But, the place seems to fill up quickly.  The set-up is good for a short stay, but I don't think it would be comfortable to study in for a prolonged period.
author: Sue N.

description:
It cannot be anymore hipster than Four Barrel. Having walked by here a few times when visiting my sister, I have always been tempted to stop by for a drink. After hearing my sister rave for weeks about her favorite drink from here, the almond milk latte, I decided I just had to try it this past week. 

The almond milk latte was everything she said it would be and more. Typically almond lattes I've had, like at Peet's, always leave a sort of odd taste in my mouth. I was worried that the almond milk would overpower this drink but I was wrong. The drink was perfect. It was smooth, creamy and perfectly made! I would have drank two if there was an option to get a bigger size mmm. I can't wait to go back and try other drinks! 

The ambiance is also really nice! Sort of dim lighting, lots of open space and some small/big tables for seating. Interesting crowds and cool baristas! 

Other things:
+Be prepared to spend more than your usual Starbucks/Peets bill here (almond milk latte was $4.50....$4 for the latte, 50 cents for the almond milk) 
+No tea options on the menu, only coffee/espresso based drinks
+They have a few snacks they offer but they were wiped out when I came around 5:30 on a Thursday evening
+No wifi
+If you get plain coffee, you get the option of adding soy milk, almond milk, regular milk or creamer to your cup for no extra charge! Might be a better option than getting an almond based espresso drink if you're watching your wallet. 
+This is not a grab n go kind of coffee stop--when I went I think it took about 7-8 minutes before my drink was ready which is drastically more than typical coffee shops--so don't stop here if you're in a rush! Enjoy the ambiance, the interesting artwork, the different types of people you will see, and wait patiently for your coffee! It's worth the wait :)
author: Anu P.

description:
I died and went to coffee heaven....

San Francisco has a lot of places that offer amazing coffee.  But they got nothing on Four Barrel! I had the most delicious latte of my entire life!
author: Dasha B.

description:
Nice staff every time!

Great coffee...

love the space..

Almond milk latte YUM!
author: T. C.

description: I'm going to be honest - I did not actually have any of their coffee.  I recently worked an event that was thrown here.  The staff, and especially management, was excellent to work with an so accommodating.  Wish I lived closer, I could definitely see myself stopping by once in a while
author: Jessica G.

description:
Cool spot. The espresso is not to my taste (too strong/acrid.) The iced coffee is above average. The line over the weekend isn't worth the wait, but definitely worth a stop if you are in town or in the neighborhood. Service is cool and prompt. 

They only have almond milk & regular, which is annoying. SF coffee shops need to have something other than milk and almond milk (minus one star.)
author: Sneha P.

description:
This is one of the coffee shops in San Francisco that Takes Coffee Very Seriously. I'm not always in the mood for that attitude and I actually think it's pretty silly. Despite that, the coffee here is actually pretty great. Both the regular cap and almond cappuccino were delicious and foamy (it's harder to make foam with almond milk so this is impressive). Their ice coffee is a tad too bitter so you might want to add ice or milk.

The physical atmosphere of the shop is awesome. It's enormous. There are little wood picnic tables. Cute and minimal--and masculine--at the same time.

They have no wifi so don't ask. Sometimes the other patrons are really annoying.
author: Jake S.

description:
Parklet 5
Coffee drink... 3.5....eh (was just Luke warm)
Ambiance 4
Attitude 2

I didn't appreciate the attitude that I got when I asked for nonfat milk. I was quickly informed that they have soy or whole milk. There are a lot of special diets out there...please recognize this...or at least tell me in a more pleasant way.
author: Amy O.

description:
Wow!  This place has a few magical ingredients.  Great coffee is the start of course, with really approachable friendly welcoming staff working there.  There was a clear aim to engage from the employees, who all seemed interested in their jobs.  Little freebies of cookies and chocolate came my way a couple of times, and the beans I took home from here have turned out to be very well roasted.

I like that there are fewer large work spaces here, which means fewer laptops and silently studying and working types and more conversation and coffee drinking!  Yay for this place, it's really alive and kicking!

Will definitely be visiting again.
author: Michael B.

description: The smooth creamy bold flavors of the morning roast coffee was phenomenal. The double Choctaw donut was mouth watering good. The interior decor was rustic with a touch of modern. I could work here all day long continually staying focused and inspired.
author: James C.

description: Super cool/skilled baristas make the best cappuccino outside Italy, hands down. All with real vinyl playing in the background!
author: Tim K.

description:
Alright, so. Don't be turned off by my rating for this place! Let me explain.

I had been walking around, exploring The Mission District for maybe 2 hours and I had no bottle of water with me (I know, what was I thinking?! With all the SF hills that randomly assault your legs out of nowhere -__-.), and so when I came across Four Barrel, I thought "HALLELUJAH!" 

Four Barrel is definitely really...hipster, haha. I don't know how else to describe it! The layout of the shop is really cool - lots of wooden tables and stools... The baristas are enclosed within this glass/wood box where you can walk around it and watch them do their thing. Since I hadn't read anything about Four Barrel before, I wasn't quite sure what to order. So when I got up to the register, I just got an iced coffee and an apple coffee cake. I feel like I should also note that the cashier was also just casually sipping on a latte, hahaa. 

Anyways, the iced coffee - bleh :| I personally did not like it at all. To the point where I was almost about to throw it away because that's how much I did not like it! It was just really bitter and left a really bitter aftertaste. But I didn't throw it away, simply because I was just sooo thirsty from walking around all day. However, the apple coffee cake was really yummy! There were bits of apple in it and I could taste cinnamon in there. mmm. The apple coffee cake made my Four Barrel experience just a little bit better. 

After coming home and reading all these Yelp reviews, I feel like I should give this place another chance! If I'm ever in the area, I will definitely stop by again.
author: Polly H.

description: Want a moderately flirtatious banter with your barista as they pour your brew? Keep walking. This is a coffee roaster of serious business where the conversation is kept to a minimum and a well-oiled ordering system is kept to a tight schedule. I ordered a cappuccino and while the coffee tasted quite decent there was something strange about the texture of the milk. For me, I sense the best way to experience Four Barrel Coffee, as I will next time I visit, is to order from their pour over counter and drink it black.
author: Lani P.

description:
I still can't figure out why Four Barrel has a turntable with records and a fantastic amplifier in what is essentially a room specially designed to have the worst acoustics in San Francisco--besides maybe the middle of the BART tunnel.

For some reason it doesn't bother me conceptually that this place doesn't have wifi.

These baristas are super nice and friendly. You can ask them questions and they won't bite you!
author: Klevin D.

description:
This artistic gem features the best coffee in SF. Beautiful latte art, friendly staff, and often has roasting happening on site--so live entertainment if you, like me, are obsessed with coffee in all of it's stages of life. 

For roast quality and drink preparation I rate them relative to some other greats as:
1. Four Barrel and Stumptown (Portland) -- tie for perfection
2. Ritual Coffee Roasters
3. Blue Bottle. (This would be the top of my gourmet list for the adventurous, for their care, variety, and novelty. But BB roasts are slightly less accessible IMHO.)
4. Philz

If you like coffee, take the time to get a pour over. The friendly staff will brew you a cup of perfection. 

Can't miss with the cappuccino (perfect foam texture), latte, mocha, or other espresso drinks.
author: Josh J.

description:
I ordered regular drip coffee. It was weak, plasticky, and acidic- bad and undrinkable in ways I still can't quite articulate. 

Also they don't have wifi.
author: Rajiv A.

description:
I was pretty shocked that I never visited this place considering I am frequently on Valencia street these days and always find myself at Ritual Coffee Roasters one way or another. A friend suggested this place and I knew I had to try it when we passed by looking for parking and there was basically a swarm outside the door.

This place is chaotic. Make no mistake, this is not your average, come hang out, chat, study, listen to music coffee house. You come here for the people watching or chaos, or both, or you come here to get it to go and bounce. There's very little room to do much else and especially if you're plotting to use their restroom, be prepared for a hefty wait.

The coffee, however, was surprisingly good. They do hand pours as well and make some killer french press all. the. time. The place reminds me of Sight Glass Coffee for sure, but with just a crazy amount of people.
author: Lorrie M.

description: I never feel cool enough to be spend much time here but their coffee is good and hits the spot. The interior design is unique and interesting. The coffee is a bit pricey but not unexpected. The first time I came a couple years ago I felt like everyone was judging me- I was just not hipster enough I guess. Today, the cashier was sweet and the overall vibe was more relaxed and welcoming, which was refreshing. Hopefully it stays that way!
author: Misty M.

description:
This has the most amazing reviews, so I was obviously incredibly interested. The ambiance is prime, the music is choice, and half the male clientele looks like Moby (which makes for the best of people watching.)
However they have no tea, no outlets, and no wifi. Don't come if you plan on getting work done. 
Maybe I'll come back if I'm ever taking a tired hipster out for a pick me up. I'm pretty bummed about the happenings here.  
The guy just did do some latte art on my hot chocolate. It would almost sound condescending, but you could totally tell his heart behind it was sweet.
author: Rebecca A.

description:
Amazing coffee. Patries look good too.  No wifi - so chat to your OH or friend.  

Great seeing all the roasting, packing and tasting in house.  cool industrial feel.

Could definatley tell quality was in every cup.  another coffee to dream about!
author: Emma W.

description:
I stopped in here for the first time a few months back after just moving into the neighborhood. I love the decor and the space - especially the public seating outdoors, very clever. However, that's where most of the stars come from.

I ordered an iced coffee with skim milk. BIG MISTAKE. The barista snarked at me - 'oh, we don't serve that kind of thing here...' Pardon? Non-fat milk? I was then educated for 5 minutes on how they only serve almond milk and whole milk, and if I were looking for a low-fat option, I should clearly have almond milk. It was the weirdest interaction I've had as a consumer in a long time. 

Coffee was ok, nothing to write home about and sort of sour. I definitely prefer Blue Bottle and Philz. I didn't think limiting the options (almond/whole milk, granulated sugar) was exactly novel as much as hipster douchedom, but whatever.

It's the closest coffee shop to my house, and I'll drop in from time to time. But I just don't see what the fuss was all about.
author: Alexandra K.

description:
Whoa, when did a latte and a chocolate croissant start costing $11?!

Maybe it's just me, but that's a little bit much. Loved this place but I'd rather pay $11 somewhere else and get an actual meal.
author: Vicente G.

description:
Four Barrel has created something extremely rare: a culture. The community that has surrounded their business is one of a kind and it is thriving! I've gone to a few of their art shows and other events and I've always had a great time talking to their team about their beans and other adventures. 

Two great secrets about 4B: 
Since they roast their own beans in the roastery that is in the back of the house, they are always putting out burlap coffee sacks on the street which can be beautiful wall decorations, or they can be used for gardening & compost. 

Also, it can get extremely busy on the weekends. But just walk around the corner of the block to Caledonia alley, for some Caledonia coffee, you won't be disappointed!

LASTLY - buy one of their F*CK IT cups to take home. They are a cheeky way to drink your morning brew and they make for some great photo props.
author: Chelsea C.

description:
Cappuccino heaven! 

Love places that don't over milk the drink and let you taste the coffee. Definitely the case here. 

Great pour in a great atmosphere makes it all come together. Well done!
author: Scott S.

description: This is a gorgeous space with stellar coffee. Everything is solid. The baristas seem to be a bit harried.... like... I wish I could engage them a bit about the coffee but they are too busy. The coffee sizes could be larger.  Anyway, great, great place.
author: Ari R.

description: Good coffee with no wifi or a single electric plug to charge a device. They clearly dont want you staying here too long. Why the 1 star review?  Blatant rudeness by a barista!   Unacceptable.  I will not be back.
author: tatiana k.

description:
Worst iced mocha ever! I'm super thrilled that I spent close to $5 on this disaster. The mocha powder didn't melt into the milk and espresso, and thus, with every sip I was swallowing bits of powdered mocha. It was pretty gross! To anyone in charge- please try your iced mocha so that you can fix it...

I'm guessing their strength lies in plain old coffee and espresso.  I bought a pound of beans which I'm pretty excited to try at home. Hopefully I'll have a glowing review after I make myself a cup at home.. Oh as an added bonus they only have whole milk and soy- really?? Anyone else find that kind of weird??
author: Ritu K.

description: If Andy Warhol had a coffee shop in the 60's, this indeed would be it(minus the drugs). The large lofty industrial vibe, records, loud music, colorful vibrant art, and tasty, smooth coffee. Being here made me relax. It was very crowded inside, but thanks to my fav parklet outside I still felt a part of the in crowd.
author: Court S.

description:
Drink:
Coffee - more acidic side. 

SERVICE
Good.

ATMOSPHERE:
Love their atmosphere. Industrial, urban, open, minimalistic. They have outdoor seating now along the sidewalk which is kinda nice high bar stool seating

12.19.13
author: Angela L.

description: This is the best coffee and cafe I have been thus far! Love the hogs and the products.
author: Andrew L.

description: Four Barrel is a solid coffee spot. I've only gotten their beehouse pourovers, the barista's know what they're doing. Sometimes I get an underextracted cup, but they're consistent regardless. The decor is top notch and I like how everyone just sits together. No wifi or outlets, though so if you need a place to plug in your laptop, you should go somewhere else.
author: Nick F.

description:
5 stars for Lauren - one of the managers - who reached to to me with a nice message!  Thank you.

I really, REALLY appreciate great customer service - mostly because I have been lucky in my lifetime to have experienced some really amazing customer service (strangely enough, some of those experiences were at some hawker stalls in Malaysia!).  Well, I really care, because I've always strived to give the best customer service where ever I work...
author: Barb L.

description: Great coffee, but their latest change to their almond milk has really deterred me from going there daily as I used to. It tastes like sour cashews and does not resemble almond milk in the slightest anymore. Hope that they switch back to almond milk or at least provide multiple non-dairy alternatives for the lactose intolerant.
author: Sarah Z.

description:
Vibe: Super chill, great conversation and calming noise to the place. Perfect for catching up with friends or reading a book if you're okay with a consistent, but uniquely soothing background noise. The seating at the parklet is also awesome.

Coffee: The best in SF! The lattes are outstanding and the drip coffee is supposedly top-notch. Pro tip: For non-coffee drinkers, the hot (and cold) chocolate is amazing, though you won't find it on the menu.

Service: Super friendly and hip. They keep the line moving pretty quickly and are happy to answer questions or chat, if you have questions or want to shoot the breeze. Super chill and awesome people, all around.

Value: It's pretty fairly-priced when compared to Ritual and Blue Bottle, and the atmosphere is really unique and unlike any other coffee shop in SF.
author: Luke B.

description:
A pretty serious coffee shop for aficionados. Sure the ultra-hardcore are religiously dedicated to Ritual in these parts, but Four Barrel does stand it's ground. 

I've been twice and both times had a cappuccino. The first one was flawlessly prepared and great tasting, the second one was less perfect but still good. Their baked goods are decent too, I'm a sucker for their gourmet donuts (who isn't a sucker for donuts?). 

The space is chic, but seating isn't super comfy or copious at peak times (they have a sweet roasting machine which takes up about half the building). 

I do have one gripe, the second time I was in here the window washing guy told a bunch of us to get out of our seats so he could clean. Given it was the middle of the day and coffee shop was pretty busy I found that pretty annoying.
author: Jeremy S.

description: Too hip for my san diegan soul. Loved the latte. Loved the banana chocolate chip scone. Loved the interior decor of the place. A little too long of a wait to get your coffee after you order.
author: Tina B.

description:
5-stars for the store concept. 
1-star for the people who think this is a place to study or work. 

You'll see a lot of ass cracks from over-weight hipsters. Coffee suddenly doesn't taste so good.
author: Harry V.

description: Great coffee, not too pretentious, lots of room to study or relax, and they run the roaster in the back occasionally, which is fun. The line can be a buzzkill, but I mean, coffee is goooood.
author: Kimberly K.

description: Best latte in the city, and the secret back alley entrance on Caledonia Street (that's open only on the weekends) almost never has a line. Hipster coffee at its finest.
author: Keith M.

description: This is a really cool space, probably one of the coolest coffeeshops I have ever seen in many ways. I even took pictures of it, it was so cool. The machines were also pretty cool, unfortunately the cappuchino was pretty meh in general. The coffee seemed overroasted, but lacked the punch of an italian espresso. I'd stick to some of the better spots for good coffee, but if you want to hang out this is the place.
author: Jonah K.

description:
I'm a Scrooge during the holidays.  Anyone who knows me and my relationship with my family can understand why.  So when I was looking to escape for a little bit and hunker down at a cafe to do some work, I was looking forward to Four Barrel.  I happened to come at a good time, as today is the day after Xmas, and everyone is in the Powell/SF Shopping Centre area returning gifts they didn't really want/need. 

The line moved very quickly and I ordered a latte.  I asked the cashier if there was a password for wifi, and she informed me that they didn't have it.  DOH!  It seems they don't really want anyone camping, as there aren't any electrical outlets available to patrons, as well.  I get it, but I still needed a little escape, and was a bit bummed that Four Barrel couldn't provide that to me.

I sat at a little table started to people watch and was content with this for awhile.  My latte was delicious.  Smooth and not bitter.  I enjoyed every sip.  Next time, I'll get my coffee to go, or bring a book.
author: mariel v.
