description: Coffee hit the spot!! It's our second time here. The taste of the coffee brought us back! Too bad they don't have good pastries though. Plus the line to the only restroom is looonnngg. Took15 mins wait!! There is usually a line to buy the coffee too. Which I attribute to the laid back arty hippie culture of the whole place including the baristas!:p. no harm done with though. So will definitely comeback when I miss the coffee taste again!
author: Chow C.

description:
How awesome is it that you get to watch the coffee beans turn from green to brown while sipping on a hot cup of heaven?

AND, you can hang outside where the cool breeze reminds you how awesome SF is ... all year around. :)
author: Jister Y.

description:
Of all of the Third Wave coffee companies in The City, I think that Fourbarrel is probably my favorite. Despite their annoying granola hipster vibe, the coffee is seriously good and the baristas are approachable and respectful.

Blue Bottle, Ritual, Sightglass, Philz (arguably), and Fourbarrel are the pioneers of Third Wave coffee and they make Starbucks/Peets look like your grandma's Folgers. Their coffee is high quality, less burnt-to-a-crisp, and generally sits well with me. The only downside attributable to these places is that the baristas treat their customers with contempt and disrespect.

Luckily, I've found that Fourbarrel's staff is fairly down-to-earth and friendlier than the others. Amazingly, they're still able to make a great espresso; proving that rudeness isn't necessarily the secret ingredient of good espresso.

Perhaps the biggest downside here is that their coffee is $5 a cup--which seems ludicrously over-priced. But given the average price of Third Wave coffee, that *is* the going rate so you can't fault them for it. Overall, the service great, the coffee is great, but the prices are high.
author: M T.

description:
"Baby, baby, baby 
What's it gonna be? 
Oh baby, baby, baby 
Is it him or is it me?"

Some people walk in here and immediately notice the scent of coffee beans.  Others notice the scent of hipster.  Whichever you fancy, Four Barrel will satisfy.

"Don't make me waste my time 
Don't make me lose my mind, baby" 

You can smell the hipsters, see the hipsters, and of course hear the hipsters.

"Baby, baby, baby 
Can't U stay with me 2night? 
Oh Baby, baby, baby 
Don't my kisses please U right?"

What is that behind the counter.  Could it actually be...?

"U were so hard 2 find 
The beautiful ones, they hurt U every time"

Oh hells yes it's a RECORD PLAYER.  Major hipster points, especially since they're using it to play records and not scratch, which was like soooo 90's, and I mean that in an outdated 90's kind-of-way, not a retro-cool hipster 90's kind-of-way.

"Paint a perfect picture 
Bring to life 
The vision in ones mind 
The Beautiful ones 
Always smash the picture 
Always everytime"

Holy shit - are you playing PRINCE on this record player of yours?

"If I told you baby 
That I was in love with you 
Oh Baby baby baby 
If we got married 
Would that be cool?"

Yes you are playing Prince.  DOUBLE HIPSTER POINTS.

"You make me so confused 
The beautiful ones 
You seem always to lose"

Wait a minute...is this The Beautiful Ones from Purple Rain? 

"Baby, baby, baby 

What's it gonna be baby? 
Do you want him? or 
Do you do want me? 
Cuz I want YOU. 
Say I want YOU 
Tell me baby 
Do you want me 
I gotta KNOW 
I gotta KNOW 
Do you want me?"

Oh. My. Fuck. It IS The Beautiful Ones. You were't just satisfied playing some Top 40 Prince song like Raspberry Beret, were you Four Barrel baristas? Oh no, you had to pull out the big guns with some random Prince shit.  BRAVO.  I award you TRIPLE hipster points for that.

"Can I tell you a story?? 
Sometimes you lose 
Let me tell you 
Sometimes 
Sometimes 
Sometimes you win 
Yes you do 
I say sometimes 
Sometimes 
I get so confused 
Yes I do 
But I say right now 
Right now 
I know what I want 
I want you 

Baby, baby, baby 
Listen 

I may not know where I'm going baby 
Look here 
I may not knkow what I need 
But one thing 
One thing for certain baby 

I know what I want 
And it's to please you baby 
Please you baby 
I'm begging down on my knees 
I want you 
Yea 
I want you 
Baby baby baby baby 
I want you 
Yes I do"

And oh yeah - good coffee.
author: Doctor L.

description:
Wow, this here San Francisco sure doesn't have a shortage of amazing, hand crafted coffee roasters, huh? Between Ritual, Blue Bottle, Philz, De la Paz, Sightglass, Thanksgiving, etc... there's really no good excuse to ever get caught sipping on bland Aramark office swill ever again. While it comes as no surprise whatsoever, you can throw Four Barrel right in the mix of some of the best beans in the city, and possibly even the entire West Coast as well. Simply put, this stuff is heavenly.

Aside from the piquant roasts and spot on espresso drinks, you're not likely to find a cooler looking space for caffeine intake anywhere else in town. I'm usually not the type to lounge in a coffee shop for any longer than it takes for me to order and await my drip, but the minimalist, hip decor calls to me like the Sirens of Homer's Odyssey, begging for an extended romp in their massive warehouse along Valencia. Very open and airy, polished concrete flooring, enough seating to accommodate a hefty handful of the Mission's finest, an appreciation for analog with an old school turntable and stacks of records behind the coffee bar, and those contemporary rope lights that make me want to run to the nearest Home Depot to try and recreate the entwined burlap look myself. If the Ace Hotel were a coffee bar, it'd look just like Four Barrel.

The lines can be out the door at times, which is usually a turn off for most... but if you can exercise just a small bit of patience, you'll be rewarded handsomely.
author: Ruggy J.

description:
So I read some reviews and was afraid I was going to be treated like a leper here. Nevertheless, wearing obvious Gap clothes and asics shoes I brave it with my little family from san diego. We looked a little sun drenched too! We were not looking very urban as the scene was.
Anyways, the coffee was fliippin amazing. Had a latte and cant wait to visit again some day! Even if you park illegally, take the chance...yes, its that GOOD! 
Employees were VERY nice, no snobbery could be seen. Girl at counter, was from Carlsbad here in san diego and she was amazingly helpful and extra nice to us. We chateed about SD a bit and that made me feel welcome and at home even more so. She even poured milk in cups for kids at no charge! Hope she doesn't get into trouble for that! ;o)  We both got round 2 to go with four more to go pastries so I hope that made up for the small cups of milk she gave my kids!
As you can tell, I fell in love! Go there, even of youre square...you'll LOVE it!
author: P I.

description: I enjoy getting a coffee and bellying up the bar-like seating area out front of the shop and watch the cars zoom by.  I've met my buddy here several times and there is always a line and busy.  And the coffee is great too!  I
author: Brent T.

description: Espresso is one of the worse I had. Good scones. Nice hipster atmosphere. I don't believe this is the best coffee shop in the area, but love the look and feel.
author: Bre V.

description: Flourless gluten free almond cake.Really moist and flavorful.Cant believe it is flourless.
author: Priyanka L.

description:
This is an open coffee house exactly like you want it to be. Nothing small and cramped and cozy about this place. It's open, airy, full of reclaimed wood and serious coffee drinkers. I'm not knocking it for lack of coziness. It's just not cozy.

I consider myself, full-on coffee person at this point. If you have a mass drip machine in your shop, I'm questioning your ability to make good coffee.

Four Barrel is great. You walk up to the guy* and he will choose a coffee for you like most sommeliers will choose you a great wine for your day. It's pretty spectacular. 

It's the kind of coffee shop that if you're lucky to have near your house, you appreciate the hell out of it, and a destination location if you have to travel. Either way, I can't see this being my only visit to Four Barrel Coffee.

*Review is for drip/pour over service only.
author: Mari H.

description:
The coffee was excellent. I have, however, never been in a more pretentious coffee house in my life, and that's saying a lot. The staff spend an extra long time to notice you, and even longer to get around to making your coffee. While you wait, you can look at the walls, which are covered with photos of the staff in pretentious poses. No coffee
Is worth this much self-celebration and disdain for the customer. Sorry.
author: Jake B.

description: The best coffee ever,  my husband took me there he promised to be the best latte and it was,  their pistachio  croissant is phenomenal we were lucky to find some, we sat outside every thing was perfect,  i will definitely be back again
author: Ghenwa S.

description:
This is one of my favorite spots for coffee on Sunday's! It is kid friendly and I love how you can sit in the back and watch them roast the coffee beans. The smell is heavenly. 

They have great coffee and friendly staff! My 4 year old loves their pastries. That is a big deal as he is a picky eater. I also love the eclectic group of people that come through for their coffee fix too.

Note parking is hard to come by but what else is new in the city especially on Sunday's when parking is free.

Enjoy!
author: Carmelina A.

description:
This was an awesome coffee joint, and honestly my first true San Francisco individual coffee drip experience so it holds a special place in my heart.  

Bradley, the barista who helped me and my friend choose our perfect blends, had a depth of coffee knowledge that was beyond impressive without being arrogant or condescending.  I adore learning about all the various nuances in coffee, food, wine, etc., and this was just the place to get not only an unique blend of coffee but also a tutorial on the process of making said cup.  

I also really enjoyed the airy, open feel of the shop, though it seems there are never enough seats to go around.
author: Hannah A.

description: There is a coffee war brewing up (get it?) in San Francisco and Four Barrel can definitely hold its own. The coffee is good and strong, but my heart still belongs to Blue Bottle. Everything is pretty similar right down to the latte art. The mocha here is slightly more sweet. I like the spacious location and the giant machinery in the back, but seating is pretty limited. Overall, Four Barrel is a solid coffee stop.
author: Bailey Z.

description:
This location is a lot like The Mill on divisadero near Alamo Square except instead of fresh bread popping out, there's fresh coffee bean roasting on site.

Four Barrel coffee is...how do I say, just plain good.  I love blue bottle because I think it helped kick off the local and independent coffee scene in the bay area, but the coffee at four barrel is in my opinion, better.  And I'm talking black coffee...most lattes or cappuccinos can taste great with whole milk but if you take your coffee black, it's all about four barrel.

Big space, great light, no wi-fi (encourage community and conversation they say).   Large communal tables, single bar seats, a few tables and some outdoor seating--seems like the perfect combo of space.  It's a great location to meet up with a friend or to ponder about life if you get a window bar seat looking out in the city. 

They have a decent looking selection of pastries (which the cashier said came from different bakeries, one of which included B patisserie--pretty awesome).

Got some coffee beans which cost $17.50 for a small little bag.  Talk about expensive.  But if you are high-end about your coffee, can differentiate good from bad, and you like to spoil yourself every so often like a good glass of wine, go high-end and go for four barrel.
author: Tammie C.

description:
Exactly what I wanted for lunch. 

A cheap and balanced meal that doesn't disappoint in quantity. 

I ate the medium size pho soap (it's actually very big and filling)
Spicy and delicious !

Food arrived quickly.
author: Yaniv C.

description:
This place is a lovely alternative to high street coffee chains. It has great character and the buzz is intense here. Imagine Apple Store but for coffee lovers. Four barrel offers endless coffee options with nice little pastries to go with. This is a very quirky joint which will provide anyone with a warm and home-like feel. 
We had a latte, cappuccino and an iced-mocha which were all beyond expectation. Definitely above average and not too shabby for me. 
Young people, students and casual coffee goers will enjoy coming here. Not designed for a quiet date or a pram.
As far as the pastries are concerned they are perhaps smaller than the average size but are packed with flavour, intuitive in design and baked to a high standard.
The almond & Apple brioche proved a credible purchase justified by its soft and chewy texture partnered with just enough fruit on top. Second up was the bacon and cheese scone (biscuit). I'll be frank: not admired by my taste palette. Was dry and bland and didn't really shout out at me l, contrary to everything else in the store (including the four dead animal wall heads with roses stuck in their snouts). 
Overall, Sunday afternoon coffee catch up? This is the place to be. Warm and bubbly staff add a bonus to your experience. 
Don't hesitate!
author: C G S.

description: My husband returned with Four Barrel after a coffee expedition while we were waiting in line for brunch. It was amazing. Super strong, smooth, and intense without being bitter. I flipped. They've officially surpassed Blue Bottle as my favorite drip coffee in SF.
author: Meg K.

description:
I love the setting of this place and the decorations. The people are always friendly and I like chatting with the people who makes my cafe latte . 

Coffee is always good and consistent unlike certain places I know. 

This place is always packed so I always take my coffee to go .
author: Amber H.

description: I really loved this place when I lived in SF. Killer coffee and all that. Just came in for the first time after moving away and the attitude of the staff sucked. I mean, we're all a bunch of coffee snob hipsters but I don't need a scoff and a chuckle when I just wanted some black tea. I didn't buy anything here this time but I whizzed all over their bathroom, so the one star is for that.
author: Brandon W.

description: Love this place. Three buildings down from my work and I pass on my way from bart every morning and have learned this is the go to coffee place. The selection is great and the vibe is indescribable. Staff is always so happy to help you with your drink order and although the line is always long, you are in and out within three minutes. A+ on price and flavor. Should out for two different coffee stations too!
author: Jess C.

description:
"Oh, how fine are the Emperor's new clothes! Don't they fit him to perfection?" 
Nobody would confess that they couldn't see anything, for that would prove them either unfit for their position, or a fool.

And so the success of the acid-water sold as espresso served at McHipster's Four Barrel is explained.

"Under-roasting coffee makes sour flavors dominate. 
Starbucks and your local third wave coffee shops are overshooting in opposite directions...both over-roasting and under-roasting must be avoided"~the truth
author: Lame Lake Meese Z.

description:
Amazing coffee, quick service.  Pastries were great.  Staff was fun and helped us with directions.  They don't have wifi and are proud of it (advising us to disconnect)

Happy I found this gem
author: Jason C.

description:
I dont understand why I had to wait half hr for a cup of Americano coffee when I could have gotten the same quality or even better one in Starbucks. Maybe people are not coffee junkies in Bay areas. 

I certainly would not recommend it unless you are going on a date. (it certainly helps you prolong your conversation time)
author: Meizi H.

description:
I was excited to come here because I'd had Four Barrel at Otis Café on Maiden Lane and LOVED IT, so I was eager to come to the original. Mayhaps my expectations were just too high. The cappuccino I had was good, but the one tried at Otis was better. 

Also, in terms of the space: yes, I think it's SUPER pretentious and strange in terms of the sparse, eccentric, industrial decorations, plus this place is LOUD and was way too crowded for me to sit anywhere. I do, however, like being able to see the "behind the scenes" roasting and drink preparation. Staff was friendly, prices are relatively high, and the wait on a busy, sunny Sunday afternoon was surprisingly short.

Fine overall, but I wasn't super-wowed by the coffee and didn't like the vibe of the place. Even though it's large and has seating, it's definitely not a place I'd feel comfortable sitting down to enjoy my coffee. Still, the drink was more than decent, and for my personal preference ranking, I'd definitely choose it over any Blue Bottle or Philz offering.
author: Marie L.

description: Best coffee ever.  I'd give it 5 stars if it weren't for that "F..ck It" coffee mug they sell.  Sell some PG mugs; for the kids sake.
author: Edward V.

description: Best coffee in SF!! Everything about it is so tasty and wonderful. My favorite is an iced almond milk latte!
author: Alex P.

description: Not just a normal place for coffee that you can have like anywhere else but this is the place to experienced coffee truly, in the back side of the café they have their own roaster filled the whole café with freshness and very fragrant of coffee aromatic.
author: Naene T.

description:
Delicious iced latte 
On a warm summers day 
Makes all your grumpiness go away


Me likes this place a lot. But please don't come because the lines are long enough as it is :P
author: Christina H.

description: as a non-coffee drinker - this coffee is damn good.  get the drip, drink it black, and enjoy.  staff was super friendly and helpful.  place was PACKED on sunday, so if you're trying to chill and work, this isn't the place.
author: Jenna C.

description: There's plenty of seating, the doors are opened so you get that fresh breeze while enjoying your coffee. It's a nice place to come and relax. The coffee is delicious as expected. I got an espresso and the taste notes I got were blue berry, dark chocolate mandarin...it was the best espresso I had.
author: Jane H.

description: Best coffee. Turned me into a coffee drinker. I like it even better than blue bottle or sight glass.
author: Kylie C.

description: BEST coffee I've had in the city. Perfect foam and perfect balance of espresso to milk in their lattes. You dont need anything else-- their aromatic espresso and smooth steamy milk is the most satisfying wake up call you can ask for.
author: Judy L.

description:
Good coffee, fun atmosphere. Good spot in the mission, love the parklet outside.

Staff is super hipster + super helpful when picking out beans.  You can tell how passionate they are about their coffee, pretty cute!

Their coffee beans come in 12oz - 2 bags will run you about $32. Heads up.
author: Melody T.

description: They deserve the gold star star of third wave coffee if there ever was one. The lines on the weekends are always long but the latte's are just so perfectly made. And the parklet outside is a good place to people watch from.
author: Rahul H.

description: Now favorite coffee shop in Northern California/SF. AND for us mocha lovers - you can get your mocha with the local dandelion chocolate. Amazing! Also, gorgeous interior design, a little bit of everything. Will have to check out Dandelion Chocolate now as well!
author: Nazee M.

description: For me, nothing extraordinary or out of this world.  They were really nice, so I gave them three stars:) But their coffee is pretty good. The ambiance is ok. But what really made me want to give them two stars is their selection of baked goods to go along with the good coffee.  If there was a good selection plus the good coffee, then 4 stars!!
author: Angel M.

description: Such a cute coffee shop!! I just got a decaf americano, but it was delicious! The guys at the register and espresso machines were super nice and didn't mind talking to me while I waited for my beverage, which is awesome. I love being able to watch the coffee roasters do their thing in the back of the shop too!
author: Brittany R.

description:
First of all, their coffee lingers forever through your palate, even during its worst malady.  You get to witness the whole coffee process (with the exception of careful coffee bean harvesting) which physically involves a  "coffee mill" in the open. 

Secondly, I totally dig their Bike Parklet. What a masterpiece.  I know I've seen several conventional bike corrals popping up all over the city.... Please do take this smashing Bike Parklet as an attractive epitome of uber-trendy-and-all-that-artwork that could function as practical landmarks where patrons would also be able to use effectively. Sustainable, baby :)

Good job, parklet planners!

Their cappuccino with a few bites of Dynamo Donuts (which are also sold here....simple yummification) 

And guys, if you complain about how overly yuppie/hipster this place claims to be. Hush, hush.. take a few sips and enjoy this well-earned "cool" while it lasts.
author: Jesada P.

description:
This is a review of their product since they serve it at my workplace, not the retail location.

By far the worst coffee I have ever had, regardless of whether the barista or machine is preparing it. Brown water, too acidic, and not much else to it.
author: Anthony C.

description:
Four Barrel was one of the two coffee shops that my husband and I wanted (and had) to visit while in San Francisco. When we finally got there (bus + walk) I was so happy. The shop was HUGE! It was spacious and beautiful, and the coffees were lovely. The barista who made our drinks was cool, friendly, and very skilled.

 It was a perfect day for coffee!

We got an espresso, a macchiato, and a cappuccino. They were all delicious. We also checked out their roasting area (at the back of the shop) and it was a great setup and layout. It was a very pleasant visit.
author: Yiching P.

description:
First word that comes to mind.... TRENDY.  There is no such thing as single file here.  Most customers tend to stand right in fron of the cashier while they wait for their drinks because they have no where else to go and are clueless as to what's exactly happening inside Four Barrel.

The space is beautiful and the fact that they have a barista posing as a deejay and spinning fat coffee shop beats on vinyl is pretty unique and unequivocally Mission. There is even an espresso tasting counter to the left upon entrance.  Four Barrel is a sight to see for sure.  Just be forewarned about the line... or lack there of.  Don't spend all of your precious time waiting for a drink that will never come if you have yet to order.  Ask questions - "Are you in line?" "no" and move on to the front.

The staff, although well trained seem to be as clueless as the customer base with a lackadaisical approach to serving your coffee or taking your order.  I give it FOUR stars for it's hipster approach to keeping with the current city trend in beans.

One word... Trendy.
author: Kevin J.

description:
First place I stopped in for my first visit to San Fran and I am so glad I did! I guess a place with a 1000+ reviews hardly needs my accolades so I will make it short and sweet. 

My latte was perfect. They serve their own coffee and looks like they roast it on the spot in small batches. Wonderfully rich and sweet notes, and a dark red crema with a beautiful rosetta latte art.

The service was prompt and adequately friendly.
 
The cafe itself has a cool setup with the roaster in the middle of the store and small chairs set up around the perimeter. Someone even started playing some vinyl. 

Warning: If you have low tolerance for hipsters or you cannot survive without wifi, this might not be your spot.
author: Teddy M.

description:
AMAZING ESPRESSO! The Americano is perfect, and I usually HATE Americanos. Bonus points because they offer self-serve almond milk!

Other reasons why 4B ranks up there with Philz as my favorite SF coffeehouse: FANTASTIC customer service and friendly baristas! Such a rarity/unexpected surprise since this is not something hipster cafes are usually known for. Prices are awesome too: espresso, americanos, and coffee start at a relatively paltry $2.50. This ain't no $4 cup o joe (I'm looking -- or rather, glaring -- at you, Ritual....), and yet it's definitely among SF's best.

Gorgeous space, amazing decor. Truly an SF gem!!
author: Cam Y.

description: Great coffee, great people. We stopped in for a quick lunch date and we had a great time. I ordered the cappuccino and Kouign Amann. The perfect combonation. I am usually a starbucks girl but the baristas were kind and took the time to help me out. I will say, if you dont enjoy the delicious flavor of coffee and are looking for sweet flavored coffee drinks, this might not be for you. I enjoyed myself.
author: Christina R.

description:
I'm from the east coast where Wawa coffee is A-OK and Dunkin Donuts coffee is downright exciting. Four Barrel is delish and it's beautiful inside but the general coffee snobbery is just a bit too much for me. 

But maybe you shouldn't trust someone who thinks 7-11's Columbian roast is just fine, so fine.
author: Natalie S.

description:
Love the staff. Love the coffee. Love the atmosphere. Love the price.

I enjoy sitting at the back bar-style seating to watch the bean process. The staff is super open to questions and love talking coffee, or really anything. 

Great music playing constantly. Only downside is no wi-fi, otherwise I'd probably be here all the time. 

When my coffee subscriptions from other places is running low, this is where I buy my beans. They're fresh and flavorful, with many options!
author: Lauren A.

description:
Amazing coffee and even though it was full, it didn't take too long to get served.

Space is a little light on seating, but the atmosphere is good and the staff is very friendly.
author: Kyle K.

description:
Super hipster coffee shop on the now increasingly gentrified Valencia St (but Four Barrel was at the conception of that). Some will argue that they hate Four Barrel and those who follow know nothing about coffee. To that I say, to each their own. I used to be one of the naysayers who has since turned a new leaf and I now crave that sour aftertaste when I drink non FBC.

Cruising around the Mission on the weekend and don't want to wait in line? Head to the alley around back on Caledonia and pick something up, watch the bike messengers meet up over a cup, and laugh at those still in line when you're all done.
author: Johanna L.

description:
Great coffee shop!  The coffee is amazing and they have a couple secret avenues for beating the inevitably long queues:

1) The Slow Bar - Have you coffee brewed within one picolitre and microgram of precision while the barista explains to you what donkey to ride to get to the farm your coffee was grown on in rural Ethiopia.  Double the price of a normal cup but god damn is it good.  Pretentiousness 11/10

2) The back alley - Step over still steaming piles of hobo faeces to go "backdoor" on this coffee shop and have a line that is 1/4 the normal length and with a clientele significantly less douchey.

Great pastries too.

4.5/5 but missing the extra half point due to the long queues of hipsters and expensive prices on the roasted coffee.
author: Meow S.

description:
I stopped by Four Barrel for my coffee fix and so I could get some work done.

The place itself is pretty neat. Relaxed yet quirky atmosphere. The coffee is definitely wonderful quality.

I ordered a standard iced coffee (added soy milk myself) and an anise donut. The coffee was notably awesome, but the donut was just okay to me. They have a small selection of pastries so get one while you can if you're craving it.

It's not too hard to find a seat. They have seating outside and inside. The unfortunate thing is that they don't have public wifi so I couldn't do research online for my papers. The bright side to this is you won't be quite as distracted by other aspects of the internet.

Anyway, great place. Not my favorite cafe, but I do like the coffee a lot.
author: Sofia R.

description: I enjoyed my latte, but they didn't have soy milk, but it was still good.  This place gets super packed and it's hard to find a seat!
author: Misty P.

description: I love their beans! Their pour over coffee is expensive and I personally would rather just buy their beans and make the pour over coffee myself. It's a pain to find parking and the line can get painfully long during weekends. It is worth a try for people who like to drink their coffee plain because you can really taste the difference between the different types of beans and brews.  They sell freshly brewed beans!
author: Pam Y.

description:
I am addicted to coffee.
It has come to the point where I can drink a cup a day and still sleep early. 
So having stated that, this coffee is good.  Not amazing, but definitely a solid cup of coffee.  I got an americano, and the beans are really good.  It's clean and not muddled.

When my friends and I came in to sit down and just relax for a bit, the front literally screamed at us.  You can't miss this place, it is packed day in and day out, with these crazy, rusted, geometric bars hanging over their outdoor seating.  The inside is huge, but half of the store, the half in the back, is purely for roasting and packaging the coffee on site.  

We took seats in the back which faced all their coffee beans and roasting machinery.  It was really cool to see it happen right in front of me, but because of the machinery, it it extremely loud.  This isn't really a place to get work done, or talk for that fact.  

Good coffee, but a little overwhelming.  I had never seen so much plaid and handle bar mustaches condensed in one spot as much as I had the hour I spent here.
author: Sinan W.

description: The epic-center of all that is hipster.  But really awesome coffee/espressos, and I also had a great cookie.  Hipsters know their coffee.  I'll be back when in the area...
author: Andy S.

description: this coffee shop has THE BEST emphasis on BEST hot chocolate I've ever had in my life. I'm always on the search for the best coffee and Four Barrel by far has the best coffee and drinks
author: Terri P.

description: No WiFi, which makes sense as they extract maximum profits only if they can get you to leave as soon as you've forked over your money. Coffee was good, but I'm not really a connoisseur, unlike you.
author: Robert K.

description:
Four Barrel is amazing. I've only been there once but as far as first impressions go, they hit it out of the park. I went to their 5th birthday party celebration where they had a petting zoo, skee ball, cake and FREE coffee (and not just coffee - anything on the menu!) 

I got the affogato, normally $5.50 - worth every penny! The affogato is two shots of espresso poured over caramel ice cream. The espresso looked perfect (like seriously, perfect - the right color, texture, everything) and the natural bitterness of espresso was cut by the creamy delicious ice cream. 

The employees were all super nice, friendly and smiley, which is saying something given how busy they were. Even though there was a large crowd there for free coffee, no drink was rushed. Each one was served with dedication and a smile. 

The atmosphere is cool - some stuffed animal heads on the wall and lots of wood. Plenty of places to sit, including a little outdoor area on Valencia. The aroma is the store is intoxicating - they roast all their coffee on site. 

A perfect coffee shop.
author: Dena E.

description: As a barista I know a good shop when I enter one. If you only have time for one cup of coffee in SF and you want to either be educated in coffee or just experience the best, go here. It's not elitist but they are the best.
author: Patrick F.

description:
What a better way to wrap up my friend's visit to San Francisco than a trip to Four Barrel. Imagine 4 good college friends who were separated by immigration, get together over a cup of coffee for a LOT of catching up to do. 

The ambiance was very rustic, sophisticated and personal. 

The coffee beans scent was awakening. I got the regular latte; and it didn't even need any sugar added on to it...nor cream, nor milk. Or maybe coz I don't like my coffee too sweet.

This is actually a good photoshoot place. I loved the bricks.

*pretty bathroom too!
author: Monica H.

description:
I'm not a coffee drinker.  But this is some damn good coffee.  Enjoyed an iced latte with almond milk and simple syrup and found myself a new life.  

Minus a half star for the location of the tiny prep station, which functionally makes sense next to the pickup area, but not so great when it's uber crowded and you feel like you're in the way.  The other minus half goes to the spoon setup - a simple "used spoons here" and "clean spoons" would suffice.  There were two spoon canisters and then an old Half & Half container with spoons in it.  

I mean, I GUESS I can figure it out...but what if I'm wrong and use some hipster"s spoon after they've licked it?  I don't know where that tongue's been.
author: Tamar D.

description:
Took my father from out of city here for morning cup of joe (72yrs old) and he was all "what's up with all the 'where's Waldo's?!!' This is one of those hipster places, huh?' LoL ... Great stuff, typically lighter and fruitier tasting then I prefer tho, I like their bourbon beans, expensive for what it is per pound -- I feel like it's overall pricing is geared towards the deep pocket hipster
Crowd, u know the ones with the 1k plus fixed gears lined up out front. Good pastries.
author: John O.

description:
Nearly perfect cappuccino.  Everything is a double shot, no sizes, scaled down selections that make a purist paradise.

Orders may not come out quickly, the drinks are craft made.  The music comes from records and expect retro tunes.  It is loud and not a place to try to do work, but it's a great place to meet friends.
author: Mike M.

description:
Yes the coffee is good, yes the service is great, yes they have boar heads on the wall. I'd say five stars all around except for one thing: the reclaimed wood. Goodness they really jumped on the reclaimed wood bandwagon. Now I like reclaimed wood as much as the next person; We've gotta think sustainably and that wood's not gonna reclaim itself. But there's just gotta be other reclaimed materials you can use aside from just wood. I mean, they use A LOT of reclaimed wood; Portlandia-esque levels of it. And, I want to emphasize, I'm a huge fan of being eco-friendly. It just seems like we're taking this reclaimed wood trend a bit too far. Vary it up a little, y'know?

Anyhoo, I love getting my cup a joe here from one of their "service with a smile" baristas. It's just... well, the reclaimed wood. It's a bit much.
author: Fakename D.

description:
Four Barrel Coffee is the definition of hipster.

Yes, I do claim to be a coffee connoisseur and the measure of any coffee shop is their REGULAR drip coffee. I ordered a cup for $2 and it kind of fell flat. It tasted like a Colombian (Latin America) coffee but without any soul at all.

It was so mediocre I do what I never do unless I'm drinking Starbucks drip swill - add milk and sugar.

Maybe the hand pulled drip coffee they had on the side of the main counter is better.... maybe the espresso is better.... but that's all kind of a moot point for a coffee shop if your regular drip is that uninspiring.

I wanted to really like this place (especially the Urkel Jerks painting, hilarious) but heck Peet's, Philz, Blue Bottle.... half a dozen places make a better drip cup. Their drip coffee is swill, like Miller High Life is to beer.
author: Doug R.

description:
Came here to try the kouign amman which made the 7x7 list this year.  YES! That should be on the list.  Actually, all the pastries here should be on the list.  My BF and I biked to the mission and decided to stop here for coffee and the kouign amman.

The kouign amman is like a mix between croissant and apple pie.  Delicious!! Nice, flaky and crunchy outside. Soft and buttery on the inside.  I wish this thing was bigger.  

The soy latte are amazing too.  Huge dinning space and a really edgy outdoor seating section.  Lots of cool hipsters and super friendly staff.

Plenty of spaces to park your bike.
author: Ying F.

description:
Love this place. This is the establishment that helped me to fall in love with the accents, intricacies, and deliciousness of single-origin, third wave, light roast goodness.

While I haven't done much work here, it has definitely been a great place for conversations and people watching. My favorite thing to do is to sit close to the coffee roaster, watching the back-of-house people in action.

The baristas here are friendly and knowledgeable.

This is always a must, to stop by, whenever I'm in the Mission.
author: David D.

description: Just came into San Francisco for the day, looking for a usual cafe to go to in the morning. I got a recommendation by multiple people to go to Four Barrel Coffee. I'm so glad I came here!! The coffee here is literary the best coffee I have ever had in the Bay Area. I am a barista an am a pretty big coffee expert. I liked the espresso and coffee here more than Blue Bottle, Philz, Peets, and of course Starbucks. This place is amazing! If you ever get a chance to come to SF, don't forget to stop for coffee here. You will not regret it...
author: Mocha L.

description:
Only 4/5 because the pastries are $4-$5 and I kinda think I deserve a sandwich or something for that much. 

Otherwise I love the skinny wooden table-desks, the great tasting cup o Joe, the records on the walls, and especially the parklet outside to enjoy the weather.
author: Kate S.

description: Excellent coffee of course.  Great staff, friendly.  Ordered the special Gigone, super good.  The only minus is the seating which isn't very comfortable and no wifi, and can get a bit noisy :(  But come for coffee anyway.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Their coffee is really good. Really good for making french press at home. One of top local coffee companies. I live the ambiance of the coffee shop too. 
But today I used the restroom for the first time. It smelled like those public restrooms on market street that you don't want to walk by them. Now i wonder if their coffee is sanitized. :(
author: Aram S.

description:
As good as coffee gets. If you are visiting San Francisco this is the place you want to go for the best coffee. Other good choices are Blue Bottle and Sightglass.


The Place:
There are no huge signs outside of Four Barrel, but there are usually people outside on their street seating. Depending on that time you come, it is pretty busy. Espresso based drinks are typically faster than the pour-over bar. Lots of seating inside and outside. 

The People: 
I have met people from all walks of life here. I spoke Arabic with a businessman from Egypt, talked politics with a young man from Maine, and talked to myself (of course no one cares in San Francisco). Men and women of all ages attend this place comfortably. 

The Atmosphere:
Friendly.Not a hipster only coffee house.  Take a friend to chat, or come alone and enjoy people-watching. There is always a wide-variety of people from all types of backgrounds (even religious!) who are probably willing to talk. Not the best place to study (who would want to with such good coffee!), but some people do read and study here. 

The Experience:
There is no better place in the Bay area. If you have time, try the pour over station and order some great coffee. Once you order, the barista will let you smell the freshly ground beans. They have pour-over coffee down to a science. The brew always fills the cup up to the top, and always has extraordinary flavor. Typically there are 5 or 6 fresh roasts you can order, or you can get into the espresso line and try a latte or cappuccino, though macchiato is my favorite!

My advice: Make this your first coffee stop if you are new to the Bay area, or if you are visiting. Then check out the Castro district for other fun stuff!
author: Chris P.

description:
Let me start by saying the decor is AMAZING! the restroom is awesome lol very hipster employees who aren't very friendly AT ALL! 

I ordered a mocha  with an oatmeal and cranberry cookie. The mocha was alright, nothing special. The cookie was delicious though! 

coming from LA I can't really be too harsh on judging the location, however, my boyfriend was wearing a LA hat (bad idea) and got harassed on the way out. We just laughed. 

All in all if I knew that a mocha would have cost me $5- plus 
the cookie $1.50 x 2 (for my boyfriend too) I would have 
probably went to a coffee shop closer to the hotel I'm staying 
at.
author: Yessenia O.

description:
I thought this place was going to blow but it was actually a place I'd come back to for the coffee. I'm not down with long lines for a cafe but that's what happened here. It kind of seemed more like a place people had to be rather than a coffee shop where you can just enjoy yourself and whatever it is you do there. I was there to have a latte and catch up with a friend, the drink was great, the service was genuine.
This is apparently the place you bring your Mac power book to as well, I counted no less than five while I was there, kinda' funny.
author: Lizzy M.

description:
Arrogant staff. A hot beverage should be Hot NOT Luke warm. No matter what you tell them they always make the way they want to. When asked ( v nicely) to make me extra hot coffee, it's disregarded. When Requested again, they roll eyes. Surely the customer should leave happy, after all they are paying for the coffee. 

They are always in a hurry. It's good to be efficient but not at the cost of selling sub-standard products. 

Coffee is good but not worth my time and money and definitely not the attitude.
author: George S.

description:
Definitely my favorite coffee spot- it may be the awesome vinyls constantly spinning and crooning tunes from different decades, it could be the absolutely intoxicating scent of freshly brewed coffee, or it may be the fact that they do not have Wi-fi, so people are forced to hang out and converse with one another - any which way you look at it, 

Four Barrel Coffee is delicious, well-priced, and has just the right vibe I need when I drink my coffee. The coffee itself is consistent and tasty. Paying a bit more for a personal brew can be a fun, delicious experience. The staff is knowledgable about the coffee they serve and, in general, are usually friendly. The lines can pose as a bit of a problem if you are in a hurry, but it is worth the wait.
author: Calvin J.

description:
Great coffee, nice ambiance and location. A perfect stop in a lazy Saturday in the city. Hipsters, tourists and curious minds (like me!).

A more rustic and unpretentious space design, a creative atmosphere compared to other fancy coffee shops in the city. 

My latte macchiato was perfectly creamy, hot and well prepared, with a strong taste and smell, kudos to the barista. Young people everywhere.
author: Rodny L.

description: Four Barrel has an excellent selection and some of the strongest coffee around.  The scene is hipster, so be reading to have good conversation with the friendly patrons.  Its a spacious spot, and we had no trouble finding a seat.  The latte's come with a creative artistic toothpicking on the top.  I'm planning on going here anytime I'm down on Valencia.
author: Sudarat P.

description:
I tried coming here once to study with a friend but it was too crowded and there aren't many spots to sit. With that said, this is not an ideal place to study so I would go elsewhere on Valencia like The Summit. The Summit has long tables and free wifi.

Anyway, you should come here for a legit cup of coffee. I like watching the big machines in the back process the coffee beans.

I didn't get a chance to try out the pour-over bar area since it was closed.
I would recommend getting coffee where they double the strength and then add ice to attenuate it to the strength of one cup and now you have iced coffee but with their original blend (instead of getting an iced coffee blend). I never liked iced coffee blend.

It would be cool to bike here someday and park my bike on the racks outside.

This is an SF gem.
author: Marlon T.

description:
It's good, but for me not "the coolaide" it is for some people.
Staff was very nice and the service is very good.
author: Katie F.

description:
I'm not a coffee snob. Truth be told, if you made me do the Pepsi Challenge with one type of coffee and another, I'd be hard pressed to identify Peet's v. Starbucks v. Coffee Bean. Heresy, I know, but somehow I just never developed a discriminating palate. I'm like Honey Badger. I don't care.

So when my friends become insistent upon finding "great" coffee, my little internal voice says "Excellent, drive around an extra fifteen minutes, fight for parking, pay way too much... ugh..." And unfortunately I was built without good filters so I then realize I said it out loud and my friend is giving me the stinkeye. Whoops.

But Four Barrel was a pleasant surprise. Okay, fine, part of it was that I found parking straight away, which improved my disposition tenfold. But the vibe of the place was super-cool, the coffee wasn't overpriced, it was very flavorful and enjoyable, and the aesthetic of the place was really hip, modern, industrial, groovy.
author: Sean B.

description: I'm giving 4stars bcz I'm not much on coffe but love espresso. Usually have some sugar with it to cut the bitterness but it was still super bitter. I'm sure it's a good coffee shop as my friends rave about it, just not for me. Cool atmosphere and all tho
author: Austin C.

description:
I ordered the caffe latte at this place and I was very impressed by it. The coffee tasted nice and smooth and not overpowering. Like many people have said, I would rank it up there with blue bottle coffee. The prices are very similar but I do prefer this place over blue bottle.

i like how they give you metal spoons to mix the coffee and opposed to wooden sticks at many places since you are able to fully incorporate the sugar into the coffee easier, as well as being more environmentally friendly.

I am a fan of this place and whenever i'm in the area i will make a trip back to this place.
author: Spencer E.

description:
Hands down one of the best shots of espresso I've had - this perfectly balanced espresso had a syrupy mouth feel starting with light citrus notes giving way to a caramel-chocolately finish. 5/5 
Equipment: La Marzocco Mistral; Mazzer Robur grinder. 

I'm reluctant to give Four Barrel a perfect 5 on account of the pretentious barista who served me. 

Honourable mentions: 
- no plugs or wifi: just a great space to have a coffee, chat, and/or listen to one of the many records being played 
- some pretty sweet boar heads mounted above the retail area
author: Tonja B.

description:
Great coffee and so..much...space. I can't believe how big it is, especially for the Mission. AND they don't try to pack in as many tables as physically possible.

I dig the tables--remind me of old-school school desks (yeah, just go with it). Wooden and not very deep. Super cool. I really like the space.

Can't speak to their baked goods, but I have it on good authority that they're great.

The good: damn, that's a hot cappuccino (take note, Blue Bottle, with your lukewarm beverages). 
The bad: there is the quite the ebb and flow of the line, so it's a crapshoot of how quickly you'll get your caffeine.
author: Amanda B.

description: To be honest, their espresso is not my favorite (I find it a tad too bitter), but I liked the atmosphere of the space, which was pleasantly non-confrontational. I like the plates and cups they use, as well as the baked goods they offer.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Coffee: 4.5/5
I had a really delicious, strong latte. Well-made, perfect without any acidity or burnt taste.

Ambiance: 3/5
It's cool that you can see the coffee being made, but it made the whole place really chaotic and loud. Not a good place to do an work (which I think is the point...they don;t cater to the laptop work crowd here)

The entire line is just a bunch of people who look the same, all typing furiously on their phones as they wait to order coffee.

Also...why no breakfast sandwiches or bagels?
author: Vicki G.

description:
If you want your order taken by The Viking, go to Four Barrel. I think he's badass.

If you want your coffee made by an androgynous looking hipster, go to Four Barrel.  I guess that's the style of the Mission.

If you like cream designs, go to Four Barrel. They're artsy.

If you like your drink real strong, go to Four Barrel. Every shot is a double shot.

If you prefer records over mp3's, radio and playlists, go to Four Barrel. They're what they spin.

If you like cool bathrooms, go to Four Barrel. Check out their photo wall. Are you on it?

If you ever wondered how things work, go to Four Barrel. Walk to the back and watch them roast the beans.

If you're looking for a place to chill and a cup of joe, go to Four Barrel. Just get there before 8. They close early. We shouldn't be drinking caffeine after 2 anyway, right?

Go to Four Barrel. They are going to get big before you even know it.
author: Rachel A.

description: Why go to Starbucks when you have places like Blue Bottle, Philz and Four Barrel?  Good coffee.  Great service.  Delicious treats.  But get there early or your favorite goodie might be gone - they sell out fast.
author: Rose A.

description: Fourbarrel coffee tastes nasty, it's not strong and cost more than the average. Three bucks!!
author: Roger H.

description:
Probably one of my all-time favorite shops. Just a wonderful place to have coffee.

Very spacious interior. Lots of seating, and lots of standing room (there's a bunch of outdoor seating on the curb as well). Records play from an old turntable all day long.

Coffee is top notch. House espresso is full-bodied and a bit smoky. Also has a fruity tinge at the end of a sip. If a shot isn't extracted properly, they'll pull it again. Very consistent espresso quality here.

Tons of bike parking out front.

All in all, a class establishment. They stick to the basics... high quality coffee and a great place to sit.
author: Nick D.

description: Chill vibe, great people, hip decor, and delicious top notch coffee. Four Barrel is one of the best coffee shops and coffee roasters in California, and the shop does not disappoint. Outdoor seats and tables are placed on the sidewalk for those sunny SF summer afternoons, and the inside of the shop exudes a hipster vibe with its simple wood themed tables, chairs, and ceiling. The decor is simple with some drawings along the wall and a couple animal heads along the other. Besides the typical latte, coffee, etc., Four Barrel also offers a slow roast bar, where a barista makes pourovers with different coffee beans from around the world. Sipping on my Ethiopian pourover, I was able to see the bean roasting equipment in the back, which is rare for a coffee shop. After seeing that, I knew Four Barrel is serious about its coffee. All caffeine addicts need to come here!
author: Annie C.

description:
According to Yelp, 5,950 people could read this review.

I'll be more satisfied if a only a dozen of you spent a fracture of time reading my reviews within a Yelp year.

Anyway, this is the Mission's Hub for Coffee and Confectionary excellence. The main purpose of my excursion to try these three items:

Caffe Latte (to compare to Farley's East, Oakland, North Oakland): (http://instagram.com/p/kNlajcnh91/)

and of course...

Bacon Cheddar Scone and Frozen Kuhsterd x Four Barrel (or Izakaya Sozai)'s limited edition White Chocolate Saikyo Miso Kuhsterd

(http://instagram.com/p/kNk79-nh86/)

The latte is excellent, I've had a few that ranked up there (La Columbe, NYC and Portola, Costa Mesa), now you can join them.

The scone was a bit dry for me and although I got the hints of bacon it sort of fell apart with the cheddar being lost in the taste. FK asked me personally to compare their 'kuhsterd' to something I've before and not to boast their egos but it's one of a kind. The custard remains in the cup the moment you flip it over (product quality and integrity), the white chocolate is bold and mellows out with the saikyo miso as a finish. The closest thing I can do a compere and contrast would be Yogurtland's White Chocolate flavor but texturally and flavor balance it was a bit too sweet for me.

Despite the long lines, the customer service was excellent seeing as one of the workers followed up with me the day before when I inquired about said highlighted flavor.

If you can overlook the long line (rainy Friday late morning-afternoon), the benefits outweigh the cons seeing you can try confectionaries from: b patisserie and dynamo donuts, this is a must stop for any coffee (or food lover). 3.5 but rounded up to 4 for quality in products and customer service. Cheers.
author: Ryan M.

description:
Nothing that haven't been said already. 

1) The coffee is okay. 

2) However the second you ask for the internet wifi password, the attitude/sarcasm from the  minimum waged baristas come out.  The bad customer service is unnecessary, I think most customers will understand that you are trying to create a  relaxing atmosphere without laptops once they realize there's no wifi available. A simple, "No we do not have internet here" will suffice. (Unfortunately, I tipped first before I received their sarcasm)

Also on another note-  I can't help but over hear the greasy haired girl hipster glasses barista talking to her colleague about her new love who works at a farm and also farmers market on the weekends. It's like watching Portlandia live.
author: Jessica T.

description:
I've been hearing about Four Barrel Coffee for a couple years now. So, I decided to check'em out. I ordered the drip coffee. It was kinda on the sour side but it had a nice caramelized finish. It reminded me of Sight Glass coffee. So, you know, it's ok. Not entirely sure what the craze was all about. I still think Philz Coffee is the City's best.

Ambiance-wise, this place is pretty nice. Ultra hipster central. Staff was super friendly. A nice stop if you're in the Mission area.
author: Garland W.

description: Came in and got a cappuccino. Service was really fast. The crowd here is artsy/hipster. There is no internet, so don't expect to come in a get work that requires an internet connection. Great place to come in with a friend to talk. Also make sure to visit the restroom and admire the decor there. Both the wall and the floor are beautiful.
author: Vassiliki K.

description: One of my favorite places for coffee over the years.  There are two lines, one for espresso bases drinks and drip coffee, and one to the left with hand poured coffees. Pretty busy on the weekends, but the barista behind the single cup counter still took the time to talk about how they brew coffee and the different varieties.  I'm always surprised by people complaining about the attitude here, I've only found the staff to be really warm and friendly.  Prices aren't terrible either (by California standards) - most hand poured coffees are around $4-4.50.  The coffee quality is awesome as well, a good variety brewed on a beehive brewer.  You can even sit in the back and watch them roast beans.
author: Eric N.

description:
We went at about 2 PM Sunday. 

It was difficult for even 2 people to get seats together, never mind the 4 people we had. The line was long when we came in and it seemed to take quite a while to get through each person, though that fluctuated shorter to longer as we sat there so maybe it's just a question of luck.

My $3 coffee was not that good, kind of unpleasantly acid and watery. Husband's $3.50 iced coffee was apparently OK, but they didn't have any simple syrup out to sweeten, only granulated sugar. Our friends seemed to enjoy their mocha and espresso + a touch of milk drinks, though. We didn't try pour-over coffees or any pastries.

No wi-fi is a big minus.
author: Lisa H.

description:
As good coffeeshops go, Four Barrel is pretty average. You've got your shiny, microfoamey espresso drinks, and you've got your made-to-order pour-overs, and your Zooey Deschanellish baristas. All pretty standard stuff.

This isn't a sit-down-and-read sort of place. When I stopped by, it was noisy, crowded and chaotic. There were a bunch of people milling about in front of the counter -- some ordering, some waiting for drinks, and some just practicing their milling. I ordered a double espresso and joined them. There seemed to be some folks milling on the far side of the counter, but I couldn't tell if they were employees or customers.

The espresso was nice enough, though quite acidic, like a shot of caffeinated lemonade concentrate. On subsequent trips, I tried the ready-brewed French press, and a pour-over from the slow bar; I liked both more than the espresso. Worth stopping by if you're in the neighborhood.
author: Nath A.

description:
Four barrel coffee is one of those name coffees i was hoping to run into.
unfortunately for them, i found them during an unopportune lapse.

locale: general pop-up (3/)

coffee drips: $3cup
-coffee drip brewed.
-coffee smooth, not so bold, not much definition. guess i like it more robust. not impressed.
-check this up to a bad bean, will retry at another location.
author: Victor G.

description:
This is where it's at.

Some of the best coffee in SF.  Tremendous baristas, whipping out awesome espresso.  Busy, but not slow.  Great looking place.

Come here to enjoy some coffee, not to work.
author: Rob W.

description: Very trendy cafe. The coffee is tasteful but the latte got too much milk. I think it's too creamy for me. The table and decoration are very special. It's def a great place for young folks.
author: Ashley C.

description:
I have always loved this place.  I don't live in San Francisco anymore but frequently visit my friends and family (as I live an hour away now) and often suggest we meet at Four Barrel.  Yesterday was one of those days.  Met my aunt at Four Barrel.  Was not having a great day.  Was very excited to drink a cup of their delicious coffee and feel better...
Then I saw the sign on the counter. "SOY IT AIN'T SO".  I've been vegan for six years.  This sign stated (I took a picture so I could directly quote it): "After 4+ years of offering "soy drink" as a dairy alternative for all you...cow-hating hippies, we here at Four Barrel have recently decided that life is just too short to drink soymilk."
...wow.  The sign goes on to say that they are now offering almond milk in an effort to make our coffee "less...legumey".  
I don't eat much soy, but I do love soy lattés.  The problem with almond milk is that it often tastes like water.  I tried not to think too much about how incredibly offensive this sign was (I'm sure they're trying to be funny, but calling me a cow-hating hippie is not a great way to win me over to your new non-dairy offering) and went ahead and ordered an almond milk latté.  
It was awful.  It tasted like black coffee with foamy water.  I would have much rather just had black coffee.  Why have the almond milk if it is tasteless?  I'm sure, on its own, this almond milk might taste great, but paired with the delicious coffee, any taste it had is lost.  So now, not only had their offensive sign given me a stomach ache, but I was stuck drinking this truly awful beverage.
Now, if they had approached it differently -- put a sign up saying "In an effort to support small farms and avoid supporting monoculture, we now offer almond milk instead of soy" or something...this whole experience would probably have gone differently.  I would still have thought my latté was awful, but at least I wouldn't have had the figurative bad taste in my mouth.  Four Barrel made it clear that they would rather not have vegan customers, and I'm ready to take the hint and never come back.  It does make me sad, though, because like I said before, I've loved this place for years.  
Life is too short to drink soymilk?
No.  Life is too short to put up with condescending, snobby hipsters when all you want is a delicious cup of coffee.  Luckily, we still have Ritual & Blue Bottle.
author: Leila-Anne C.

description:
Chemicals in my Coffee!

I was late on a Saturday night and I was beginning to crave something sweet and delicious to keep me up for hours on end. In my world that typically means something with chocolate. I really wanted a doughnut but with all the doughnut shops closed for the night, I decided to settle for a mocha. Prior to my visit, I had never heard of Four Barrel, but I trusted the other reviews on Yelp and made my way inside. It was cold, barren, and the seating uncomfortable, not like your typical cozy cafe.

While I was waiting for the barista to return to the counter, I noticed something off about Four Barrel, something you really wouldn't expect to see in a coffee shop. Much to my surprise and utter disgust, they had decorated one of their walls with real taxidermy hog heads mounted on plaques like a safari hunter's trophy-room, for  what reason I don't know. Regardless, already having walked several blocks to get the coffee, I decided to order anyway. I ordered my small mocha, which is very common and easy to make, and waited with my friends. After an unreasonably long wait, my drink was finally announced. It was very hot, much hotter than any other coffee I've ever ordered. When it finally cooled down, I was already heading for the BART.

I took a sip and instantly noticed that something was off. It tasted like chemicals and was very waxy. Taking a few more sips, I now noticed just how horrible it was. I thought for a second, maybe this is some special type of coffee that tastes bitter. Nope, when I opened up the lid I saw little floating pieces of melted wax and just to make sure I pulled some out with my finger. Wow. The coffee tasted horrible and I was drinking melted wax from the lining of the togo coffee cup. $4.25 down the drain... literally. How displeasing... I will never return to Four Barrel Coffee and I hope you don't have the same experience that I did.
author: Kyle B.

description:
Love this place for its chill and open atmosphere.  Great place to sit and read (and by "read", I mean pretend to read while you people-watch).

It's super hipster, but I appreciate that the baristas are never pretentious and are willing to give good recommendations to coffee n00bs like me.  

I know this may sound preposterous, but I wasn't a fan of the drip coffee.   However, you should know that I enjoy drip coffee from 7-11s and gas stations, so perhaps I'm not the best judge of what good coffee is.  Their lattes and espressos are seriously delicious though. 

No wifi, no outlets, but plenty of great seating.  It gets busy, and the line can be long sometimes, but it moves fairly quickly for how diligently they make each cup of coffee. I'll definitely be back - my goal is to come back enough times to learn how to talk like a coffee connoisseur.  Last time I was there, I learned what "pour-over" means, so...baby steps.
author: Rohini R.

description:
You know how you clear the line at Four Barrel? Show up with a chatty 2 year old in a stroller and watch the hipsters part like the Red Sea for Moses!  They'll also make your order much faster than normal for the same reasons. 
It's a great cup of coffee for a smaller price than you would pay at just about any major chain. I love watching the coffee geeks trying out all the slow drip varieties in their special doohickey thingamajigs. 
If for no other reason, the hipster watching is particularly good and the fixie bike parking is plentiful.
author: Jill D.

description: Who says that U.S. can't make great coffee?! One of the best shots of espresso I ever had. I got the affogato with a creamy perfect scoop of vanilla ice cream dipped in the coffee and it was the perfect blend of flavors. If you order 'for here' they serve you in these beautiful ceramic mugs and plates. The ambiance of the coffee shop is really beautiful with beautiful people (yes, I don't have any problems with hipsters). The line was long but worth the wait and service was very good.
author: Natalie S.

description:
(See pics)

Have to write an update :)

Realized that they have a much bigger selection of pastries if you go in the morning. After seeing pictures of goodies like Asiago & black pepper gougère and kumquat cocoa nib scone, some Yelpers pondered if they are from Tartine. I don't know but will make a note to ask because the pastries were absolutely amazing!

This was also one of the places that the coffee is on the mellow side. It gives you the gentle kick instead of the hard punch, perfect on a yielding weekend.
author: T L.

description:
Okay so I get that soy isn't great for you or good for the planet, but come on Four Barrel, almond milk sounds like a good idea, but it tastes like nasty beans in a latte! 

Tastes like barftastic barf. I can no longer come here because your almond milk drinks taste like crap. At least give people the option of soy. I'd even take lactose free milk if you had that. Sigh. At least I have Sightglass.
author: Skye W.

description: Their lattes and mochas are extremely good. Very foamy and rich. I don't like that they only offer one size and that their prices are on the higher end. However, they do have a great vibe and their barristas are friendly so cool looking. So I guess I forgive them! I definitely keep coming back. They are so cool I bought my friend a mug of theirs that says "Fuck It" and is surrounded by beautiful flowers. Only Four Barrel would get me to buy something so obscene that somehow looks so tasteful on a mug!
author: Judith G.

description:
One word: pretension

"Excuse me, do you have wifi?"

"No, we're like TOTALLY analog here!"

If you were totally analog shouldn't you be using an abacus to ring me up rather than your fancy-smancy cash register that takes credit cards?

That little exchange should tell you enough about this hipster hive.  A bunch of young twerps using words which they have no idea what they mean trying to condescend a customer paying way too much for crappy coffee.

Yes, they roast their own beans; that doesn't mean they are doing it well, in fact I'm convinced they have no clue as to what they are doing.  The soap in the bathroom is DISGUSTING, it's the powdery kinda stuff you'd expect to find in a prison in the deep south circa the 1940's.  Yeah, they play records here too but crappy music played on vinyl is still crappy music.

Why come here if the coffee's shit and the people have bad attitudes?  To look cool (or "dek" as the hipsters say) in front of the other trust fund idiots.  I don't have a fancy mostache, rich parents, tattoos, piercings, or any literature by Kafka so I'll spend my money elsewhere; perhaps somewhere where they actually know how to brew a cup of coffee.
author: D D.

description:
Continuing with my epic coffee adventures, I stopped by Four Barrel Coffee to try some good coffee! The place is pretty big, with two counters to order from - one with the more intense drip coffee and one with more classic orders, such as espressos, lattes, etc.

Studying the short list of drip coffee, I decided to try the Guatemala San Augustine Bourbon. A really solid cup of coffee - dark, not too heavy, and not so bitter. There's a bunch of seats with very narrow tables, with a large open space for the loads of customers ordering coffee.

A good coffee shop to visit in the Mission district. Definitely worth a try if you find yourself tired walking around SF.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Love the coffee (Guatemalan all the way!), the chocolate cookies, the ambience, and the baristas are always nice :)

I enjoy reading a good book and watching them roast...smells so good in there!
author: Esther C.

description: Nice space with plenty of seats. Creative desserts. Strong coffee. Hipster spot for sure because of the area. Creepy animal heads on the wall. Not sure how that fits in but um yeah.
author: E. Y. G.

description:
Y U M. The people working here definitely know their coffee and espresso.

I love the sky roofs cause they bring in a LOT of natural light. It's quite wonderful. Also the place is a LOT bigger than expected. They have a HUGE coffee roaster in the back. Also, on the side, they have a separate area just for pour-over. So hipster. But they definitely know their coffee, foreals.
author: Amy S.

description: Pretentious and expensive, but still some of the best espresso drinks around! $5 for a latte - ridiculous but so good.
author: Kckc C.

description:
Such a lovely space - the coffee is great, the service is (mostly) friendly, and we'll-behaved dogs are welcomed with a blind eye.

They recently raised their prices, which puts them a bit higher than I'm comfortable with, but they're a small local place, so I'm happy to support that.

I wish the pastries weren't quite so expensive.

And they play vinyl all day, which is fun.
author: judah m.

description:
Blue Bottle, Philz, Ritual, and now Four Barrel!?!

San Francisco has to have the most discriminating, sleep deprived population in the nation. How else can you explain the number of RIDICULOUSLY good coffee roasters in the city? 

As if their crack juice wasn't enough, somehow Four Barrel has managed to convert their warehouse into a brightly lit, welcoming space that you can't help but linger in after you've finished  your Cappucino or Latte.

Great Coffee on the cheap counts as a gem in my book.
author: Kevin T.

description: Was visiting from out of town and was happy to find this location, and smell the fresh coffee the moment you walk into this location. Great cup of joe, and staff were very friendly. Only downside is that it tends to be on the busier side.
author: Grant M.

description:
The coffee and pastries are ridiculously good.  Five stars.

The service can be shoddy.  They're nice but incredibly inefficient.  The pour-over line had about ten people waiting while the barista choose explain the tools used in pour-over process.  Eventually, another barista came over and instead of getting four coffee's going -- got one and waved a friend over to talk with.     

Also, no power and no wifi.
author: Corey H.

description: I love Four Barrel's slow bar.  Particularly the detailed and friendly attention I get from Bradley and the other staff members that staff this bar.  They are always helpful, sunny and knowledgeable about the coffee selections, which change weekly.
author: Ambere S.

description: I enjoy the Four Barrel Coffee shop as often as I  am near it. The coffee is bold and tastes great. Its not over priced, and has a nice atmosphere for me to do the crossword.
author: Jeffery H.

description: Fantastic coffee, cool vibe and amazing ceramics. Beautiful interior. I also had a carrot bran muffin which was delicious. I definitely recommend getting an early cup of coffee here.
author: Audrey W.

description:
This place is so pretty!! I would totally study here if I lived I'm the area.

I was very entertained by the wide variety of cup sizes that they have here for each kind of drink. Their drink list, on the other hand, is nice and simple - definitely not the long list you get at Starbucks (not to mention all their secret drinks). 

I enjoyed my cup of iced coffee. But I'm no coffee connoisseur so that's really all I can say, haha. 

 And my favorite thing about hipster coffee shops? Almond milk!!!! 

Will definitely be back if I'm in the area!
author: Ashley N.

description:
1. Love the coffee - strong with a little acidity
2. Interiors are cool - the quirky taxidermy 
3. Ingenious outside seating with bike racks
author: Camille A.

description:
Well we didn't know that this was the hipster Four Barrel Coffee which explains the long line. 

Now that I know it's a snob coffee shop that serves overpriced coffee, I won't probably go back.
author: Pooky C.

description: This was one of our favorite places during our most recent visit to SF. The staff was really friendly and helped us charge our phones (too bad there aren't more public outlets). The coffee is top notch and made with love. The donuts are crazy delicious and all sorts of different flavors (passionfruit - omg!). The polished wood and warthog decor really set the mood for drinking a great cup of coffee. The atmosphere of hardworking hipsters roasting coffee in the back is pretty cool to watch when you're a party of one. The bathroom is A. clean B. stocked with Swedish soap crystals (?) and C. wallpapered with photobooth photo strips. Beans are pricy but make for more of this awesome coffee at home. I do wish their iced coffee came in a bigger glass.
author: Ana R.

description:
Loved the toffee cookie! and the latte. The wait was a bumper though and it was hard to get seats. If you want to skip the line go for the dips. It's a separate line and usually shorter. 

Very hipster place. All wood interior, bicycles racks and what not.
author: Amanda L.

description: Best coffee I've EVER had. Usually, I like short pulls or one shot lattes to reduce the bitterness, but at Four Barrel, two shots in a smallish latte tastes divine.
author: Mike M.

description:
it's cool, but I've had enough with the hipster crowd

can't go wrong with the coffee, and yes, fun meeting space
author: Alanna F.

description:
It's hard to five stars for any coffee bar. But four barrel is outstanding coffee made to perfection. 

If you want to be super cool. I mean beyond trendy nearing cra cra hipster then you are in the right place. 

This place one ups coffee bar with people likely to be using small personalized notebooks or perhaps typewriters to be hipper than hip, cooler than cool, ice cold. Yeah it's a scene but that doesn't mean the coffee isn't good.
author: Joseph M.

description:
I don't know what it is about four barrel coffee  - its one of the smoothest and creamiest (is that even a word?) blends I've ever tasted. My Saturday routine includes a walk to Four Barrel for a cup of their coffee.

It's about a mile walk from SOMA - I really have to like your java to make that kind of an effort.

On weekends, people are packed in Four Barrels like they're giving something valuable away. I don't mind the crowds, but I have special 'hate face' for the hoards of 10+ people who stand around the damn milk and sugar table like it's a standing bar or something. Fix your coffee and please keep it movin'. 

Overall, the staff is friendly and it has the cool "hipster" vibe of the Mission. Good coffee in a great neighborhood.
author: Robin P.

description: Coffee ~ awesome. Looking forward to try the slow bar on the next visit. They roast their beans at the back of the store. Staffs are always friendly.
author: SevLong L.

description: Waited in line for 30 minutes for a cup of cappuccino but it was worth it! The coffee was made absolutely delicious. It was smooth and the foam sits gently on top of my coffee. I enjoyed drinking out of the modern coffee cup without any ear. Wish there's more coffee roasting shops like this one in Southern California.
author: Pokemon P.

description:
I think Four Barrel was probably my first foray into more... bitter coffees. I was hanging out with an acquaintance, and, with only a very short list to choose from, I got a regular latte, which led to this whole phase of I-must-learn-how-to-drink-real-coffee!! Which was mostly non-voluntary and overall very painful. (Believe me, I would have stuck to my Starbucks caramel macchiatos and white chocolate mochas if I hadn't been so desperate to look cool. Okay, semi-cool. Fine, I didn't order black coffee, I'm not cool at all.) 

Anyway, it was good. At that point in time, I honestly had no idea how to judge - I'm still not really sure I do. Lattes for me are either "good" or "bad" - I find no real in-between when you're drinking mostly steamed milk. But I've heard it's the favorite of some more advanced/sophisticated coffee drinkers, so I'll trust 'em on that.

Other than that, there's really limited seating and only one bathroom for both guys and girls, so I'd recommend going there for a quick pick-up only.
author: Emily H.

description:
Came here to get my coffee fix after I got some cookies at Anthony's Cookie's. The coffee was ok in my opinion.. I'm trying to find a good description for the flavor but all I can think of is "grassy". Not quite right, but that's all I can think of right now. 

The space is super cool though. I enjoyed watching them roast all the beans in the back.
author: Eugene Z.

description: Waited over 10 mins for a ice coffee when it wasn't busy. I had to go up to the cashier to remind them about my order because they forgot about it.
author: Eric P.

description:
I'm a coffee noob but I've been doing my research. 

The dude at the pour over station was super nice and helped me pick out a blend that was suitable for me. I normally put tons of creamer and sugar in coffee but ever since I actually started to drink GOOD coffee, I now take it black. 

If your not sure about what to get just ask the baristas, they are super nice and knowledgeable about the coffee. 

Decor is modern and hip. Good amount of seating inside but can get crowded. The only thing I had a problem with is the bathroom. It smells in there and I feel like there's no ventilation. Ew. Gross.
author: Harry T.

description:
Great coffee shop with interesting outdoor seating.

I found this through Foursquare.
author: Melissa C.

description:
oh Four Barrel...you might make me leave Peet's.
How very much I've longed for an espresso with a proper creme on top...a cappucino you can float a quarter on...well, since I left Italy, where I once lived.

This is the real deal.  Bow, genuflect, something as you walk in! This is the holy of holies as far as coffee is concerned.

I've found my new home :)
author: Lisa B.

description:
Better coffee for the snob/discerning hipster is hard to find this side of the Atlantic. Unfortunately the american palate seems to not want the darker roasts which means that the pour over here will never truly be up to par with northern European ones.

Only drawback with this location is the fact that it is almost always full, so you end up with a "to go" order. I like my coffee in non-paper cups thanks...
author: Roberth K.

description:
One of the coolest coffee shops ever. Not ideal for studying or doing work, but definitely the place to go for amazing java and to rub elbows with SF hipsters.  The baristas here compete in the national Barista Competition every year, if that gives you an idea of how seriously good the coffee is.  

On top of the delish beans and espresso drinks, FB also serves donuts from Dynamo Donuts and an Afogato (espresso over ice cream) with beer ice cream!  Staff is super helpful and friendly, and you can even bring your dog inside!  Loves it.
author: Karli S.

description:
