Yes the coffee is good, and my last visit during their 2nd birthday event made me love them event more.  The normally mellow coffee shop was decked out in birthday gear from balloons to ponies.  Even their well known boar heads had party hats on.  
For their birthday celebration they had complimentary coffee all day (lattes, americanos, macchiatos, etc...if it's drinkable, it was free).  We missed out on the Tartine cake that was going around, but we did get to utilize their photobooth before leaving.
author: Agent X.

description: So the coffee is acceptable.  Not something that I'd necessarily get super excited about...  Also not sure what the satanic symbolism is all about at the ferry building coffee tent besides being a huge turn off.
author: Slone F.

description:
Loved my experience here. It lived up to every heightened expectation. Just a short walk away from the 16th St. BART station, I found myself in a nice open industrial space that still felt pretty cozy -- probably thanks to the dark tones and lighting, with compact table/seating arrangements. Started with a brewed coffee and a cherry cornmeal donut, ended with a latte. All excellent. No snobbery, if that's something you're worried about. 

Miscellany: The store's music is played from a turntable at the corner of the bar, which is a nice touch, imo. And if you're here to do work, be warned that there are no outlets.
author: Eddy P.

description: The coffee's good. I even bough a couple of their freshly ground bags for home, and they're all very good. I even got my sister, who hates drinking coffee w/out sugar and cream, to say she liked the coffee as-is.
author: Henry N.

description:
There's a moment in your life when you are: not caffeinated by the perfect cherry from Earth -- the coffee plant -- that's roasted as delicate as the skin on the cherry that's roasted. And that moment sucks. 

It's the moment before NASA's Curiosity Rover landed on Mars. It's the moment before Barack Obama was announced as the Next President. It's the moment before you lace up your boots. It's the moment before Whitney sings the National Anthem. It represents what we yearn for: to wake up. 

However you get there -- love, a face splash, a jog, a morning dance with your spouse -- get there. I get there by what I love. I love the story of Earth that coffee tells. It's a deep planted passion that I've been growing into for the last 7 years. From tended, cared for land, up sprouts a plant with a cherry that holds a bean worth while enough for a person to wash, process, peel -- or not to peel -- another person to roast, brew & cup, another person to distribute, then another cadre of people to roast & then, like here at Four Barrel, one wonderful man to brew the cup in front of me. I asked for something citrus & punchy, and what he gave me was citrus & punchy in the perfect way: their current Guatemalan Retana. Brewed to precision, the cup told the whipping lemongrass tale of all that made its way to me. 

Be inspired by the passion that it takes for the Direct Trade farmed cherry to brewed cup -- because in your hands rests what embodies the expoobident of how we endeavor to care for another to get us to that moment after we are: caffeinated, on Mars, with The President, with boots laced, singing the National Anthem, awake.
author: Jon A.

description:
I LOVE 4 Barrell!

The caffeinated perks (+'s):
+ Line moves fast. It may go out the door and onto the sidewalk but those coffee makers know how to take orders and kindly ask you which side to wait for your caffeine fix.
+ Decor is awesome. I love the industrial feel with wood tables.Tables are built for one person or more. Yes counter seating by the window front is plum for watching the other coffee revelers sitting at the sidewalk patio.
+ Coffee? Yes of course it's good. They roast them in the back if you want to check it out.
+ Almond latte's made with Califia Farm. Yeah it's $0.50 extra but hey it's an option.
+ Pastries are on par with the Grade A coffee. That means kouign amanns ($4 or $4.25 if you want that blackberry center) from B. Patisserie are stocked in the case. Baked by Belinda Leong who hails as the wondrous pastry chef from Manresa, these kouign amanns pair well with Four Barrell.
+ Cookies by Anthony's Cookies are divine too. Grab it if you need something sweet. Love that local bakeries are being supported.
- Caffeine is a diuretic so I got to use the bathroom--it's a nice for a restroom. I dig the powder soap and it's not gross whenever I use it.

The coffee dregs (-'s):
- Yeah just this location in the Mission where the SFMTA meter maids are out in droves.

TIP: Grab a seat beforehand while your friend waits in line if you want to chill here. Gets filled pretty quickly.
author: Yiven C.

description:
A year ago, I told a co-worker I wanted to buy an espresso machine. He asked me why and I said I want to make mochas. He recommended I try espresso straight up from places like Four Barrel and Blue Bottle before I buy a machine so I could truly appreciate good espresso first.

Flash forward to two weeks ago, and I finally got my hands on, well, a mocha at Four Barrel. Okay it wasn't straight espresso, BUT, I could definitely see what my co-worker thought. I could taste berry and nut flavors in the mocha. I thought he was full of shit when he said I could taste those flavors, but he was right. And it was delicious!

You'll have to wait 10 minutes for a drink, but it's worth it. And it gives you a chance to slow down and relax instead of rushing out the door with a drink.

I sat down and enjoyed it in a real ceramic mug. How often do you have coffee/espresso drinks in real ceramic mugs? (workplaces don't count) I loved sitting in the back where the coffee beans are processed. All the machinery made a mechanical engineer like me drool.

I also got a toffee chocolate cookie with my mocha. The cookie was very small and cost $1.50, but it was yummy.

And my review wouldn't be complete without mentioning all the hipsters there. There, I did it. I wore a hipster shirt that day to blend in. Or maybe I'm a hipster...yikes...
author: Josh O.

description:
4 solid stars for this coffee spot. My wife is a regular for good coffee, if she know of a place and likes it she recommends it to everyone. This is such a place where there is an expresso bar in the front to the left and you can get full glasses in the middle in the far back they are cooking the beans with a fairly large machine not as large as the kind you would see in Kona Coffee factory but for the size of the cafe perfect.

This place has rustic feel to it, there are different types of game heads propped up on the far left hand wall, looked like few different breeds of boar total of 4 if I remember correctly

My wife had a regular mocha but will be back to hit up the expresso bar

coffee **** per my wife definite spot to hit up for some good coffee
price $ standard cost
ambiance **** it does not reek of coffee even though there is a large machine cooking it all day and fresh brands are being ground all day, interesting 
service ***** excellent service, waitressess are very friendly
author: Clarence A.

description:
While picking up my car from Wind Ward Automotive, I bumped into Bone, the wire-haired mutt who had me pat him down on my visit to Four Barrel. I'm including a picture and a heads up/shout out.

Bone, himself, is a five star dog but he needs an expensive ACL surgery. As a 5 time knee surgery veteran, I've already contributed to his surgery hope chest. He lives right there on the block with his owner (sorry, I lamely forgot to ask her name) who is looking for donations. I 've suggested she start a Facebook page.

Please look for Bone on Facebook and/or Valencia near 15th. Poor lovely dear needs a revitalized knee.

Four Barrels will remain at a four star rating until they decide to fork out for more comfortable seating.
author: Novato A.

description: But only for the quality of the coffee. Service is slow (though the product is uniformly excellent), parking can be a chore, and the crowd would make you feel inadequate if only you didn't care...
author: Juan N.

description: Coffee is actually good. The low rating is for the price increases.  I used to get mochas several time a week. Prices where always more than other places. Within the past year they had raised Prices twice!  So now they charge $5.75 for one.....almond milk...another $1.00 !  So if money is No Object then this is definitely the place for you.
author: John C.

description:
I stumbled upon Four Barrel coffee while wandering around the Mission District. As a tourist, I didn't realize I had entered one of the most popular coffee places in SF (although I should have guessed it given the big crowd there). 

I ordered a Latte, and it was no doubt one of the best I've had. The drink had a good aroma and flavour, and it blended well with the milk. It was also well prepared, and came in the appropriate degree of warmness (warm, not hot). I haven't tried anything else there, but I'm definitely looking forward to go back there again the next time I'm in town. 

The place was certifiably hipster. Everything from the decor to the staff there were hipster-ish. It's got an amazing atmosphere there (high ceiling, converted factory style). In keeping with the hipster style, WIFI is not provided.
author: Don L.

description:
Coffee here is exceptional. Top tier artisan roasters. We've continued to purchase their beans after our initial visit. 

The interior of the cafe is very pragmatic, minimal, but very well designed. I can't think of any improvement. Really one of my favorite cafes.
author: Raymond G.

description:
Glory, glory, hallelujah. 

It was pouring outside and this cozy roastery provided the perfect respite. Great coffee, relaxed vibe, amazing toilet floor mural. 

Go here!
author: Jonathan W.

description: This place is just straight cool. Awesome record player. Great vibes and good coffee. Pretty fun to people watch as well.
author: Kellie R.

description: Friendly staff, excellent coffee and chill atmosphere more than make up for the lack of WiFi.
author: Wesley R.

description:
love their coffee. And I agree with their anti-soy stance - soy imparts a bean-y flavor to their exquisitely pulled coffee.  Their choice to use almond milk is fabulous - don't even miss the milk.

Despite the lack of wifi, Four Barrel is packed with people with their Macs all hours of the day.
author: Madison W.

description:
Only a review of their coffee beans.  I purchased one pound each of one of their Ethiopian and Guatemalan beans.  I brew fresh ground coffee beans at home. Brewed when freshly roasted/purchased.  Made several attempts with each type of bean.  Use a burr grinder. I allow the coffee to steep for about 4 minutes before brewing. I use the same method for any beans I try.  

The beans I purchased from here brewed unsatisfactory, sour coffee.  Body approaches harshness found in typical lower end robusta coffees. Disappointing as I had heard such praise for Four Barrel. Briny, sour body and acrid acidity -- perhaps over fermented? Astringent aftertaste. 

Distasteful.  Hate to be wasteful but didn't finish beans. Regretful that I purchased 2 lbs but I felt confident from the volume of positive word-of-mouth.
author: Liz K.

description: I'm sure Four Barrel is and will continue to be the butt of many a hipster joke. Shops like this are the poster child for increasing rent and gentrification in San Francisco. As hard as it may be I implore you to look past the beards, bike racks, and obnoxiously authentic vinyl record player. Remove all the bespoke design and you have a company that roasts some of the best coffee beans I have ever tasted in my life. Everything from the decor to the baristas seem designed to market to a higher paying consumer while providing quality small batch beans sourced responsibly from growers direct. Their bourbon beans are to die for. My husband and I go out of our way to come here whenever we are in San Francisco. The shop is usually crowded and you regularly get baristas who seem to know nothing about the product. Still the quality of beans keep us coming back again and again.  We usually get our coffee to go and find a nearby park to enjoy. Best coffee in San Francisco - arguably the best coffee in the United States.
author: Ashley J.

description:
Ok, stalkers...gather round. If you want to track be down pretty much every weekend morning all you have to do is pop in to Four Barrel. Not only do they make a mean cup of Joe (or in my case a mean soy latte) but they also sell Dynamo Donuts and play awesome music on vinyl! Think Frankie Goes to Hollywood followed by the xx followed by Fleetwood Mac followed by Hot Chip.

And did I mention that they are dog friendly? Willie loves all the people watching. Fantastic, friendly, hipsteriffic staff and a comfy space to kick back and enjoy your coffee. See you tomorrow!
author: phil h.

description: Warning: Starbucks may never be enough for you again! One of the best coffee experiences I've ever had. Not for those in a rush but for connoisseurs who have time to linger while their pour overs or espressos are lovingly made. Compare tasting notes with the extremely educated and passionate baristas who know the science behind making every cup of coffee the best you've ever tasted. It will take you on a journey and bring you back to yourself! All coffee is freshly made in the grindery at the back of the bar. Leaves all other coffeehouses in the dust.
author: Pun B.

description:
If you're in this neighborhood, then hit this coffee joint...parking is a tease around these parts.

Purists only.  If you don't know coffee, better just keep on movin.  The buristas at Four Barrel don't have time for idiots looking for a Tall White Chocolate Mocha with whip.  The latter does not exist here.  No additives and no mounds of sugary syrups awaits you.  No mess up in the cup at Four Barrel.  So if you want the real deal, order a cup and see.

P.S.  Their pastries are delivered by bicycle every morning.  Get some!
author: Michelle H.

description:
Coolio was dead wrong- This is NOT a Gangsta's Paradise, this is a Hipsters Paradise....and only if you LOVE coffee. Because this is what they serve here...not iced tea, not bottled water, not juice...just coffee and ($10 chocolate bars). 

So if you came for a bagel- you are not going to get it.
If you want a soda, not happening.

This is a Coffee Loving, Hipster's Coffee house.

$15 for a coffee and a $10 chocolate bar....and it was melted.
author: Sarah M.

description: I like the space itself, and the quality of coffee was quite good. The reason I cannot rate this more highly is that a single espresso costs $3.25. That is insane. I have had plenty of good espresso all over the U.S. and Europe, and there is no reason why a single espresso (of high quality) should cost more than $2.50, max. They really shouldn't be more than $2. This really took away from the experience for me.
author: Louise I.

description:
First time I visited they couldn't make me a cappuccino because they were closing in 5 minutes. So the cashier gave me coffee from a pot.

It was acidic, fruity, sour, and undrinkable. Very disappointed.

I came in today and tried their cappuccino, too much milk, more like a latte. Also, the barista accidentally bumped the cup with espresso and it spilled over, she then proceeded to wipe the sides of the cup and the lip of the cup with her dirty fingers. Ugh. Try a towel maybe? 

1 star for the cool ambiance
1 star for the cool roaster in the back
author: Mario M.

description: Cappuccino was to die for. REALLY delicious. I also had a Cafe Ole but not as good. The Chocolate Claw (croissant) was pure heaven as was the banana chocolate scone. They have the perfect combination of pastry, espresso & atmosphere. Highly recommended.
author: Jeffrey L.

description:
The Dish: I got the latte, and just like every other incredible/hipster cafe in SF, it has that vibe to it - with artsy photos and cool tables. It's a little more hipster-feel than Blue Bottle. Its coffee is great! 

Ambience: Best thing about Four Barrel is its proximity to Tartine Bakery, Bi-Rite Creamery and Mission Dolores Park. Mind you, I walked from Sushirrito (yes...the one all the way at Montgomery/Embarcadero) to get here.
author: Gina T.

description:
Good friendly service, a good (not great cup of coffee) definitely better than Ritual and  Blue Bottle but not nearly as good as Philz.  Ambiance is very cool although the music was too loud for me.  The espresso was great, the americano was just a bit too watery on the occasion I had one. 
I am not hurrying to come back since I am a die-hard Philz lover but when I am close by I will stop in for a nice cup of coffee.
author: Nilu r.

description:
In my quest to find a "home" cafe, I decided to try this one today. Great ambiance, it looks like old factory. Airy, open, LARGE, not too noisy. Lots of wood and metal. I'm sure it need not be said that this is an epicenter of hipsterdom. They conveniently have their own bike hangers outside. The service is great! I felt confident that they knew their coffees... 

...I ordered a plain black cup of coffee. It was Guatemalan in origin. It had an off-putting sourness to it, like fermented tree bark. I had a hard time distinguishing any other flavors. It was also not nearly hot enough. I was disappointed. If I do decide to give this place another try, I will order an espresso, as that does seem to be their speciality, according to the other reviewers.
author: Heidi H.

description:
I know this is like... taboo to say, but I loved the fact that when I ordered a cup of coffee, I didn't have to wait for it to drip down. 

They have a super cool shop and some bomb donuts.

I wish I was taller so I could align my face with the mustache sticker on the bathroom mirror. Oh well, will have to suffice with rockin' the squiggle on the inside of my index finger. *sigh* so close...
author: Emily D.

description:
These guys travel the world to buy and redistribute their favorite coffee. It's more than a coffee place, it's a degustation experience. 

Art on the walls quickly turnover and are well chosen. The ambient is friendly, community seating, making contacts... 

One down fall about this place: coffee is a natural laxative, theirs is particularly potent, more than ever. Plus only one bathroom for the venue! explaining the missing 5th star.

still one of my favorite coffee in SF
author: TheReal C.

description:
Been here four times now, twice on a visit a couple years ago and then twice again because we're here again.  I love this place.  First of all, it's just a great space to be in.  It goes straight through the building so you get windows and a lovely breeze on both sides.  On a warm breezy spring day like today it was really a wonderful space to spend an hour or two.   

The lattes are top notch.  The pastries, too, are really great.  I had a kouign amann (queen anne).  It's a dense chewy cross between a croissant and a sponge cake with caramelized butter giving it a candy crunchy top.  It is super rich and hard not to eat rapidly.  Le Reve in Seattle makes a killer one, that's how I discovered this bit of butter and sugary goodness.   At Four Barrel Coffee you can get a superlative cup of coffee to go with that heavenly treat.  It's great when you get a cafe that excels at the food as well as the coffee.  

Also, the people behind the bar are quite interesting.    And nice and polite.  There is an enchanting blond man who works there with a wildly beautiful long red beard.   A strikingly beautiful woman I took to be his sister made me a latte.   It was fun.  I like to go there and see what everyone is wearing.  Everyone is so interesting and individualized.

The music can go from offbeat and subtle to jarring and chaotic.   

They don't offer wifi but we got a free signal.

There is a good number of tables to allow lingering or studying and the tables are sturdy and enough for a laptop or notepad.  People don't mind sharing when it gets crowded.  

Really great cafe.  Perfect for stopping in while browsing all the mid-century modern furniture stores that dot the area.  Definitely check out Monument, Farnsworth, Tradesmen and Stuff - excellent products and prices in all.
author: Michelle O.

description:
Coffee houses, ahmm Sightglass, have started to confuse rudeness with charm. WE LIVE IN A SOCIETY. Nowhere else does etiquette and politeness matter more than in cities where we live atop, beneath and beside one another. Where privacy is sacred and simple pleasures, like cups of perfectly prepared coffee, become sacramental. 

Thank you four barrel for always smiling at me when I order my latte. Thank you for carrying dynamo donuts, white choc macadamia nut cookies and introducing me to kouign amann. Thank you for offering a coffee bar for those weekend afternoons when I have time to kill, but also for setting a quick pace when the line is out the door and I have somewhere to be in fifteen minutes. Thank you for roasting your coffee in house (your ace in the hole) and letting me observe the process of turning bags of green beans into a lovely black elixir. Thanks for rotating your art. Thanks for buying the parking spots and putting chairs outside. Appreciate those spots for the city makes them pay and maintain them without giving them ownership of them! And just cause I can't say it enought, THANKS FOR SMILING. Its so easy to do. All it requires is a little ATP but dammit it means so much. 

THANK YOU THANK YOU & THANK YOU. 

your advocate, fan and lifelong customer
author: K H.

description: 2.5 stars for the taste of latte, it was a little sour and they only have whole milk or soy milk no nonfat or low fat. Also no truvia, Splenda, or any sugar substitute for Diabetics. I should of read Yelp a little closer, after buying my damn expensive latte I find out the place has no Wifi or electrical plugs damn! So I had to pack up and ask for my latte to go. he pours my latte into a togo cup and I notice it wasn't even half of a medium size  cup of coffee, what a rip off.
author: Karen T.

description: Great ambience and the smell of roasted coffee is invigorating! I had mocha almond and it was awesome! Great place to meet friends, but not so great to pop your laptop and code.
author: Richard S.

description: The coffee is very tasty. I tried the mocha and really enjoyed it. The place has a cute style, it brings a feeling of comfort. The pastries are fresh and tasteful. Must try the mocha will not be disappointed.
author: Emily B.

description: They make flat whites!!! This is the real deal for coffee addicts that know how to appreciate a perfect cup of coffee. I have been drinking coffee at barrels for a while now. It's my favorite place in San Fran.
author: Carla P.

description: Where there is a line... There is greatness! Great Vinyl Record Library to the left of the main coffee bar, pushing tunes to the coffee goers. Coffee is top notch! So whether you're staying or taking it to go - make this a stop on your route!
author: Joseph W.

description: I've been here twice, and on both occasions, I ordered hot chocolate. The first time I ordered, it was great. The hot choc wasn't too sweet and choc powder to milk ratio was perfect. I went there again last Wednesday. Ordered the same thing to go & it was horrible. My hot choc was sour. I'd to throw the whole cup away.
author: Jun N.

description: Unfortunately, while the taste was good, they have absolutely no clue how to make a cappuccino. It was essentially a tiny tiny latte with a tiny amount of foam. It's amusing watching them make it, because it looks like they know what they're doing, but they don't, because the end result was not what I has asked for. Absolutely unacceptable in San Francisco, when 1000s of other great coffee shops will let me buy an overpriced cappuccino with better results.
author: Susan N.

description:
No. Do not get coffee here. Buy the beans but don't wait in the long ass line to be served with poopy attitude from the baristas. Don't. 

Like all good coffee shops in the city (Blue Bottle, Philz,etc.) there's always a line. But here, they don't care if they don't they're not friendly nor smiley so it just ruins the overall coffee experience that we all seek with our cup of joe. For most peeps, the best part of getting coffee is the actual "getting coffee" part than the product part. You know, when baristas and cashiers are cordial and inviting..not stuck up and hipster-ish with the "I'm better than you attitude."
author: Joy A.

description: Hip and lovely coffee shop/roasters.  I wouldn't necessarily "hang out" here, as the vibe can quickly turn abrasive - but definitely worth your time to get some coffee and noms and check out the neighborhood.
author: Maggie V.

description: I've been sampling coffee all over San Francisco in the three weeks I've been here. My drink of choice is an Americano - no sugar or milk and I like my coffee intense and smooth. Four barrel had friendly service and a decent Americano - not my favorite, but definitely one of the top three. No wifi or place to charge up, but a good place to recharge for thrift shopping.
author: Jori K.

description:
941 reviews for this place?!  I guess I'm not surprised, as the one word that sums up this third wave coffee joint is "hipster."  And as we all well know by now, "hipster" has become the new commonplace, hackneyed term used to describe anyone living in the city between the ages of 12 and 45 who has shaggy hair, dons raggedy, "vintage" clothes, and is loath to make extended eye contact with anyone in his/her vicinity for fear of looking uncool.

As soon as I walk in I'm greeted by a menacing trio of boar's heads, mounted on the wall.  The roasting facilities are also in the same joint and not only are the patrons hipster, the baristas & uhm, service folks, are also uber-trendy.  The bathroom has a mural on the floor--which happens to smell like stale urine, btw--and the handsoap is some straight-up powder concoction that the proprietors of Four Barrel probably bought from some online "vintage" shop (btw, that lanolin-infused powder hand soap most likely has zero anti-bacterial properties.  Something that does not sit well with me as the bathroom smells strongly of pee--just sayin').

The coffee itself is fairly decent.  I got a latte (no, I cannot do straight up drip or espresso, I need dairy with my caffeine) and the latte art is quite impressive.  It's the usual "tree/leaf" motif with many branches, but they modify the art so that the tree "branches" look rounder, to match the round rim of the mug.

Final verdict: Blue Bottle is better.  Heck, I even liked the latte that I got from the Equator Coffee kiosk at SFO more (strong stuff, rounded out by creamy dairy).  I probably won't be back unless I am dragged here by my (non-existent) hipster friends.
author: Connie K.

description: I ordered the Mocha with extra chocolate and it tasted like hot water.  This coffee was worse than Starbucks.  The place was nice, open, and airy.  I like the outdoor seating - which is the only thing this place has going for it.
author: Shaun W.

description:
Cool place. 

I mean, cool place. Located on Valencia, with that huge wrought iron structure out front and all those hipster bike people reading their iPads and drinking coffee...

My poured coffee was excellent. Pricey (for coffee) but excellent.

The coffee beans I purchased were not so great. I bought two bags (pricey) that turned out to be "just okay". They didn't resemble the flavor profiles that were described.

Perhaps it is my coffee maker? Or my grinder? Whatever the case, the beans I bought were a bit of a letdown.

Still, a cool place to get a cup of joe, when I'm in the Mission. I just won't buy the beans.
author: Jefferson S.

description: How could this not be the best coffee in the Universe? The drip is OK, but the espresso is heaven. Fruity, citrus, and remember to stirring the crema into the cup. Great hipster mission design too - you know if you live nearby.
author: brian b.

description:
From across the street, I could clearly identify Four Barrel by the metal terraces and custom built bike racks on the sidewalk. SAN FRANCISCO, you are so cool/ridiculous.

I ordered an almond milk latte (+$.50 for almond milk), and I'm pretty sure I could have died happy. So incredibly smooth and flavorful! 

The space is beautiful but was too loud (not white-noise), so I probably wouldn't study here.
author: Caroline W.

description:
Came here only for coffee a few times.  Four Barrel doesn't have an extensive coffee drinks menu like some European cafes, but their coffees are good.  Strong but not overpowering.  I think it has to do with them using Clovers diary that the cream tuned down the coffee's strong body.  

They also have a table for coffee tasting.  The staff would walk you through  how to filter coffee grinds for tasting and you can choose up to 5 coffees to sample.

Parking is not too easy on the busy street, but walking seems to be the life in SF anyways. 

The deco tends to be in the industrial style, half of the room was used as roasting factory at the back (though I've never seen the machine at work).  There are wooden seats around the shop, but sometimes they run out of seats fairly quickly.  The first time I walked in, I felt this coffee shop had unusually large space but they didn't really make them efficiently useful.

Staff is very friendly.  Price is reasonable.  I still haven't tried Blue Bottle, so no comparison offered.
author: LeeLee C.

description:
Worst thing about the visit is that every coffee they had on their brew-bar was from Central or South American. I will always choose an African first, SE Asian second if it comes well rated. I'm not a fan of 99% of what comes out of Central/South America. 

It was missing a head, hehe, they said the new one was on order.

Good place to go though.
author: Susan J.

description:
The best friend & I grabbed some Four Barrel Coffee before going to see "KickAss," which is actually the perfect adjective to describe their service, vast space & their brand of brew. 

I spy with my little eye: decorations that are kind of random (i.e four boars' heads & rope "sculpture" lighting in the window), ample seating, your typical Mission Street crowd possessing books and/or journals & high ceilings in an industrial looking building.  

Single origin espressos made up front. Mochas, Lattes, Iced Coffees, etc made in the back. My decaf Americano had a nice nutty flavor & did not give me the jitters three hours after I drank it (huge bonus points for a spaz like me.) The BFF had a soy mocha & enjoyed it as well. 

I always add something to my coffee. I was amused to see their milk & sugar options were very "Hobson's Choice" (no Splenda, only raw sugar; no half & half, only whole milk or soy for non dairy drinkers.) I'm not picky when it comes to what kind of milk & sugar I use, but I can see how the lack of options would have some people up in arms.
author: Fancypants X.

description: Just darn good coffee.   I love the single drip coffee.
author: Marck N.

description:
Arguably the best latte I have had in the city though I wish they offered non-fat milk (maybe the whole milk was the reason it was so good!). I had a really great experience here today with a very yummy beverage, comfortable seating both inside and outside, and some tunes via the record player in the back left.

I really like the old school vibe of this place and how they stay true to it by not having wifi. That being said, if I had come with a laptop, I may have been a wee bit annoyed.
author: Raina B.

description:
I gave it 5 stars because 

a.) my friend the coffee connoisseur loves it here (and I love coffee too but I think his judgment on coffee is better, I used to make myself jet fuel out of a french press every day. . it looks like mud and made me act like a crackhead so I had to give it up )

and 

b.) Staff was pretty nice/friendly/patient.  My other friend and I were feeling quite ditsy the weekend we went here (clearly in need of some caffeine) and we were probably being kind of annoying because we were arguing amongst ourselves about whether to get a donut and whether my nice friend would please just let me buy the coffees this time. .  anyway, we were space cadets that day and the guy working there was not snotty, rude, or even acting at all annoyed by us, and I always appreciate that.  (I worked in bars and restaurants and other places where that would annoy me on a bad day.)
author: Muriel D.

description:
Fantastic coffee bar in the front. If you love coffee it's a must! 

Coffee coffee coffee our modern day legal drug. We rely on it to get through our day so why not find a way to enjoy it? Well when I want to enjoy some great coffee and learn about the different brews this is that place I go to. The coffee bar in the front is so helpful. The man that works there is so friendly and helpful. None of that pretentious crap I see at many other coffee shops. I also love the atmosphere and they have the coolest Parklet! So come come come drink drink and have some enjoying a great cup o' Joe.
author: Jacqueline C.

description:
I need to preface this review with two facts:
1: I worked in a cafe for three years, I could talk your ear off nerding out about coffee and tea and what-have-you. I've trained many a barista, I've mastered latte art, and I can disassemble and rebuild a espresso machine like it was a service rifle.
2: In spite of the above, I am not a picky fellow. Left to my own devices, I will absolutely drink whatever fluid contains caffeine if I need a fix. Also, I'm a smoker, so I don't have great taste buds to begin with.
So... onto this review. This shop looks F'ing amazing. They have these weird silhouette-shoplight fixtures, there's dead mammals on the wall, the employee's are all fabulous hipsters that are just the right amount of aloof. Seriously, it's just bell-jars and upcycled hardwoods as far as the eye can see. And the architecture of the space is amazing. Floating tables bolted straight into the walls... I'm such a sucker for that. There's outdoor seating too, which I usually hate, but Valencia is one of the pockets of the city where you're not likely to see someone crapping or shooting dope on the sidewalk, which is a huge plus. Also why the entire street is out of my price range virtually all the time, this cafe included; but my poverty is my own problem and does not affect the score of this establishment.
The first time I went in there I ordered a macchiato, which is my go-to drink if it's my first time at a cafe. It was damned good. I only have three categories for coffee: "This is coffee" "this is good coffee" and "this is damned good coffee", so Four Barrel is in the upper echelon as far as my limited senses are concerned.
However, I am going to avoid the place selectively, depending on who is working the bar. You see, last time I was in the barista making drinks paused after making an Americano, sipped it to assure it's quality, and then handed it directly to the customer. Thankfully that customer wasn't me. Dude either didn't notice or didn't seem to mind, so I kept my mouth shut. Now, I'm all for the occasional quality-check to make sure the shots are pouring properly, but you want to just pour one shot for yourself... not check the drinks as they go out. That's pretty disgusting, actually. So minus one star, because I doubt that was an isolated incident.

Edit: Just noticed today that they do not, in fact, have wifi or even power outlets. I've noticed some places starting to do that lately... and I guess it boils down to personal preference. I understand that there's a camp of folks who want bars and cafes to be places for strangers to get together and talk to each other, and feel like other people's use of technology is alienating. I'm not changing my 4-star rating on this basis, because a person ought to run whatever kind of business they so choose, but for the record I find that attitude rather creepy and the practice silly and inconvenient.
author: Bill G.

description: Decided to have an early morning breakfast at Four Barrel and was super surprised to see that the place was already bustling. The place itself is gorgeous! The wooden accents look beautiful in contrast with the industrial concrete and old metal. The employees were super sweet. I ordered a cappucino and a gluten free almond cake. Although I found it a bit pricey, I thought the beautiful location and lovely ambiance was worth the cost. The coffee was one of the best cups I have ever had the pleasure of enjoying. It was perfectly brewed. It was a bit fruity and slightly acidic, so it was definitely a unique taste. The unfinished, slate gray ceramic mug it came was also gorgeous--they have their aesthetic down. The almond cake was deliciously light and delicate. It was the ideal balance between the nutty almond flavor and the cake texture. The music was great, the vibes were great. Definitely suggest this little shop to anyone looking for a quality brew!
author: Juliana B.

description:
Hipsters schmipsters, this place has excellent coffee.

It takes a while, but if you're a coffee snob (and I'll hesitantly admit that I fall into this category), you'll love Four Barrel's selection, variety, and excellently brewed joe.
author: Adena B.

description:
Being from Portland, Oregon, I have an affinity toward truly good coffee.  And no, Starbucks does not count as good coffee.  Being acustomed to the likes of Stumptown and Coava Roasters, finding good coffee anywhere else has always been a chore.  My first trip to San Francisco a year ago revealed a good niche in the area, but I had yet to find something I enjoyed more than my hometown coffeeshops.  All that said, Four Barrel certainly is giving my shops a run for their money.

My first impression when I walked in was "this place is crazy busy" but after guessing which mob of people to line up near, I was quickly signaled toward the counter to order my drink.  The guy taking my order was all smiles and courteous as he broke down the issues with my initial order...

As a lactose-free individual, I figured I would order a small soy latte.  After all, the menu hanging above said "soy" quite clearly.  This is where I found my first issue.  They recently stopped serving soy, but offered almond milk as an alternative.  As that was my only option, I went with it, but think it would be good to more clearly annouce the options available.

My next issue came from the simple fact that there is only one size when ordering to-go.  A bit odd, but I shrugged it off.  Why worry about what you can't change, right?  And I always appreciate the use of sustainable materials, so the cup size was not much of an issue.

Small complaints aside, my drink was made rather swiftly and with obvioius care.  As busy and seemingly unorganized as the place appeared, i was impressed with the service.

As I walked out the door, I took my first sip and was immediately satisfied.  After trying 3 other shops in town, this has become my current favorite in town... At least for now.  

Later in the day, I stopped by another restaurant for lunch and finished my meal off with a cup of simple black coffee, roasted by Four Barrel.  While I am not a huge black coffee drinker, this cup was more than acceptable.

All combined, I happy with my choice to come hereand will certainly be returning when I can.
author: Jason W.

description:
Where all the cool people at? Four Barrel Coffee, stupid.

This place is crazy hip and kinda pretentious. The pretentiousness is justifiable since they really do have the most amazing coffee. I'm literally buying bags of Four Barrel roast to bring home with me to Chicago even though I don't have room in my carry-on luggage. Intelligentsia, don't be mad at me baby girl.

Great neighborhood coffee shop for people watching and the laptop toting set. I think it's a prerequisite that you must be cool and good looking to walk through their doors. CASH only here.
author: Polly S.

description:
The barista hands me my cappuccino. He says "Nice shirt." "Thanks, we just moved here." "Welcome!" 

If you are missing Alterra coffee, go here. If you don't know about Alterra, go here anyway.
author: Mark R.

description:
Never judge a book by its cover. Many of the reviews on here pejoratively describe Four Barrel Coffee as hipster. Regardless of whether that label does or doesn't apply I've found myself pleasantly surprised by their addition to the block. I've been a local merchant for over a decade and this is one of the friendliest and most welcoming businesses in the area. 
  I'm always acknowledged and greeted by the staff and owner and made to feel welcomed whenever I go in for coffee. Never any attitude or rudeness. The various employees are also friendly when passing around the neighborhood as well which I also appreciate. The facility is large and inviting and very well designed. One can see the roasting stations in the back in plain sight. This place is top-notch for coffee connoisseurs. I'm just a simple guy that appreciates good coffee and a pleasant atmosphere.
author: Hasad F.

description:
This is not Starbucks. if you want a mediocre coffee made in a mediocre way, at a mediocre pace go there. But if you want really GOOD coffee, made really WELL by people that care, made at a SLOW pace but made right. GO TO FOUR BARREL COFFEE! 
this place is great, my wife's friend Annette (who happens to be a bread baker at TARTINE BAKERY) showed us Four Barrel. It didn't let down, one of if not the best cups of coffee. I would highly recommend them to any one.

Thanks for a great cup of coffee!

As a side note, Annette also recommends, Tartine (duh) The Outerlands, check them both out on my yelp reviews.
author: Spencer K.

description:
Like my sister in law, I love going to new coffee spots & see the hype. I guess once you've been a barista, you are a coffee snob for life! Not afraid to admit it:)

 i love the inside and that theres no wifi so you are forced to chat like how it use to be haha. I stood in line which went by pretty quickly. Was warned about snobby hipster employees but good thing i didnt encounter that. It was quite packed when I went there on a Friday with a friend. 

I ordered a mocha, it took awhile to get my drink even though there weren't too many ppl in front of me when I ordered. The mocha is strong for sure! But really tasty! The espresso was smooth and not too acidic. At the bottom of my cup, it looked like real chocolate bits in there and not just syrup. Their chocolate was a nice dark chocolate. Pretty heart design too. Then we sat where u can see them roast their beans.

 It was pretty cool! Bunch of hipsters for sure haha. Like the industrial design. When we left, we put our dishes in the bin cuz we know how annoying it can be when ppl just leave their crap when its on their way out...well the owner or manager noticed and thanked us and hoped we would come again. 

I would def come to this place for coffee and catch up with a friend:)
author: Angela C.

description:
I drink my coffee black. So I am picky. Can't be distracted by anything else.

Some of these artisan coffees have tasted burnt to me lately. And I think everyone knows it--- but the coffee is so expensive, so highly reviewed, so hip that some of us are afraid to say it. I have been frequenting a lot of these hipster places as I have been working all over the city-- and I started to think it was me. That all my years of black coffee--- (and hot--did I say say I take a sip as soon as it is pulled or poured-- had warped me. 

Then I got to Four Barrel and I realized that I do love good coffee. Perhaps the beans I have been choosing in the more well known upscale places wasn't to my liking-- but Four Barrel is deep rich and NOT burnt tasting--everytime I have been there.

My go to place on Valencia. Worth the walk if I am even parked a bit away.
author: Dani K.

description:
Creamy delicious cappuccino, light flaky croissant. This is the type of perfection I love when I want my caffeine fix. Luckily I got there just in time; the line moved quickly and I was able to order from the simple menu. I wanted to go back in and grab another croissant but the line had now moved outside of the shop.

The only downside is no Wi-Fi But it makes sense as everyone there seems like they want to hang out for hours anyways.
author: Mikaela s.

description: Four Barrel Coffee, my first stop in San Francisco, which deeply delighted my trip as an enjoyable beginning. Having Los Cauchos beans in pour over on the street was so comfy. It was 16C here in SF this noon, unlike 33C in NYC. The taste of my single origin coffee lightly breezed over my body and has got rid of the summer heat in NYC. What a perfect cup!
author: Wei-Hsiang H.

description:
After a terrible experience at Piccino coffee bar today (see my review), I was compelled to write a review for Four Barrel.  

They make great tasting, balanced, not bitter coffee.  Whether it's a latte, cappuccino, or a drip...you can tell that it is made with care.
I've never had a barrista that didn't smile and make me feel welcome and appreciative of my business.
The lines can be long but they are as efficient as can be and the wait is never intolerable.

Thank you for, Four Barrel, for being a great example of service and quality.
author: blue f.

description: Great coffee, lots of seating (although it's still hard to find one that isn't occupied), and cool atmosphere. But why no power outlets?!
author: Laura A.

description:
I'm a fan of good coffee, so when given the opportunity to get a good cup of coffee I'll take it even at night. Having heard of Four Barrel in passing, I was walking by when I suddenly had the craving for an iced coffee. 

The interior is modern with natural elements, it has a nice open feel but the seating was pretty limited for the space. They roast their own coffee in the back, I'd like to see how's its done. 

The iced coffee was good, I'd like to come back and try some of their other coffee beverages.
author: Rebekah T.

description:
Great customer service. Waited 10-15 minutes for the espresso by a female barista. She made a practice shot before hand. I liked that. I was okay waiting because I was looking at her making caps and lattes for other customers. I bet those are good too. Anyway, I had a timer with me so I could time how long the shot was pulled. YaYa. It's only coffee right? NO IT'S NOT JUST COFFEE!

Anyway, the moment of Truth: Perfect temperature, sweet aroma and excellent taste.  The shot was easily ranked 8/10. One of the best shot I had in San Francisco. I give 5 stars. Is it the best in the world? No, try some shots when you are in New York.
author: Ka N.

description:
I've given this place a few tries to see if I was going on one-off days. The plain coffee here is rich, not bitter, but has slightly sour notes. However, the main problem is if you stomach reacts to acidic coffee, it will bother you while and for a few hours after drinking it. So, that's why it's two stars. 

Haven't tried the other drinks.
author: L C.

description:
Yeah Yeah, there are a lot of hipster at this place and the area but F it, being a San Franciscan, we all have somewhat hipster attitudes, being that we're all elitest and we think we're better than everyone else since we're from SF. See what your response is when someone tells you they're from Walnut Creek and then you call them a bridge and tunneler behind their back.  See what I mean?

The first thing I noticed of the place is how popular it is in this area. SFers really love coffee.  There is so much energy in this place.  It's pretty modern looking and clearly the lovechild of the Web 2.0 movement.  Plenty of laptops in full effect with glowing apples.  Not really a long wait in line, which was surprising to me since it seemed like there were a lot of people there.  Ordered an iced coffee which was ok. I'm not a coffee expert, but it was decent enough. It didn't blow me away though.  My friend ordered some pastry which tasted pretty f'ing good, although I think he paid like $3.50 for it. I don't know if any pastry is worth $3.50, but it was pretty damn good.  It was some kind of apple turnover type thing, but it had a nice flaky taste to it.

Pretty nice parklets outside since it's so sunny in the Mission.  It is a nice touch.  I would come back here and would rate it more of a 3.5.  I have to have a few more drinks here to get a better feel.  If you really want to see SF in it's element, come here and have a cup of joe.  I think a lot of people mostly come here for the atmosphere more than the coffee, but f it, why not, it's pretty nice here.

Parking here is hit or miss at times. Which goes for every DAMN place you go in SF.
author: Jason Y.

description: I had an iced coffee on a warm day, but the iced coffee was a little bit too light for my liking. When I have fancy iced coffee, I like for it to have a little bit more flavor and this one didn't do it for me.
author: Scoot S.

description: Four barrel is amazing coffee. Worth every penny. They even have classes! Awesome upstanding business
author: E S.

description:
really solid coffee, not the friendliest staff but my coffee was great so I can't complain.

just a heads up that they do not have wifi or power outlets.  I flew in and had to find a place to work for a few hours and found that this is not the coffee shop to do that in.  But thats ok, really great coffee!
author: Amber M.

description: Okay so I am not into their pastries, way too healthy with a price tag to match. Service is hit or miss, great sometimes, uber pretentious others, it just depends. The five stars is for the amazing coffee and great space. The coffee is really good and unlike anything else available where we live in the Peninsula. Whenever I am in the area I always make a point of stopping by.
author: Tasha A.

description:
Had a cappucino here while waiting for a table @ Limon...I can now say I'm a fan =) I love how they actually have the coffee roaster right in the store! 

Side note: the place is typical Mission hipster....
author: Betty C.

description: My boyfriend and I came here; you'll immediately love the modern, hipster decor and communal seating arrangements. I got a latte and he got an affogatto, which he loved. The ambiance here is very cool, definitely a nice place to stop for a coffee break.
author: Victoria G.

description: Came here once on my stay in SF. It was literally around the corner from where I was staying. I walk in and I love the feel of the openness. Most places in SF can seem cramped because there is not much space available. I wanted to get some iced coffee and some to go as a gift. The iced coffee was very good with a bold flavor. I decided on the Las Canas, Guatamala to gift because the description just sounded so good. I was sad that I found this place my last day but I will definitely be back when I'm in town again. Oh and I really liked that they had this cute little parklet just outside your doors.
author: Yuo W.

description:
It really is the best coffee I have had in my life.
It is the sort of place that when ever I am in the city, I grab a cup of coffee and talk with a  friend in the outdoor seating area about what it would be like if we all lived in the same town again.
Bikes go by and I think about knowing the people on the bikes
Posters on lamp posts for bands I don't know that I imagine knowing
Weather patterns changing from BART stop to stop
That i would become familiar with
And I would know what records they play here very well (without having to ask)
How nice would that be
If you go to San Francisco,
get a cup of coffee here or you might hate your self forever
And you do not want to go to the grave with that feeling
author: Kyle B.

description: One of the best cappuccinos you can get and watching them roast the beans feels like a school field trip, in a good way.
author: Noah R.

description:
Four Barrel Coffee is like hipster central, but they brew a mean cup of Joe. There's a big bike rack outside of the entrance. There's a huge coffee roaster in the back. Talk about hardcore. The restroom is a bit weird with it's sandy soap inside of liquid. The atmosphere here is pretty interesting as it's mostly filled with young people. There's quite a long line of people here.

== Drink ==

The cappuccino that I got was really good, but it wasn't an "oh my god" great. There's a really large selection of coffee here ranging from brew to espresso-based coffee. Then there's some pastries and some random chocolate bars here.

== Overall ==

Nice place to come by and sit down to have some coffee. I'll be back to give their brew coffee a shot.
author: Steven B.

description:
Rolled in before a yoga extravaganza at Yoga the the People, in need of a caffeine boost--which apparently every hipster in a 5 mile radius also felt--octopus tattoos and piercings aside, the coffee is still great, but my soy latte was warm, at best.  Nice flavor, but I drank it in .5 seconds just to grasp onto whatever little heat was in there.

Baristas, stop spending so much time chit chatting with each other and pay attention.  If I'm paying $4 for it, I would like it served properly.  

Scolding accomplished.
author: Rachel N.

description: Among my favorite coffee spots in SF. Period. I enjoy every coffee drink served here!
author: josh a.

description: Solid iced coffee while I waited for a friend after work. The decor was neat and the place is really spacious. However I was not a big fan of the pig and boar heads on the wall. Biggest loss of stars for the strange lack of outlets and wifi. Not a place you can stay for long- is that their intention?
author: Winnie T.

description: One of my favorite coffee shops and roasters.  Fantastic espresso and I love their Friendo Blendo!
author: Lee R.

description:
My gold standard in terms of San Francisco coffee.  When given the chance, I will venture into the Mission and hit Four Barrel.  The beans are amazing, the barristas are knowledgable and the brewing methods are great.

I take guests when in town here and consistently buy beans from them.
author: Elliot G.

description: This place must be great if you like light roast, Portland-style "coffee" that tastes more like an old orange peel than coffee.
author: Dan N.

description:
I am a big fan of this place and If I live a tad closer I would definitely be here everyday. 
I truly believe their coffee is the best in town. It definitely hits the spot. The only disappointing piece is that they run out of my favorite croissant very quickly. I live 25 minutes away and I am not a morning person so by the time I get there around 1030-11am they already ran out of the amazing pistachio croissant. But overall I am in love with this place
author: Dyma K.

description: Almond milk was too hot!  Flavor of espresso not rich enough/bitter. I will try again for just dark roast sometime.
author: Heidi A.

description:
This place has a nice, chill, albeit hipster, vibe.
A few comments:

Atmosphere: I love the bike racks here!! and they have seating outside that's open to the general public...i like that hospitable spirit. It's really spacious inside, with high ceilings, and has pretty good seating options. They roast their beans onsite! which may account for the large space. so even though it can be crowded, and the lines are long, it doesn't feel claustrophobic.

Coffee: you can either stand in line for espresso drinks, or you can go to the slow drip, pourover coffee bar. We all got lattes, which were nice and smooth...no bitter aftertaste. But i heard the pourover drip coffee was delicious too.

Pastries: I usually don't think much of coffee shop pastries. but out of all the coffee shops i've been to, Four barrel has one of the best pastries i've ever tasted! the kouign amman. GET IT. you won't be disappointed. It's an apple pastry, flaky and moist. and it doesn't taste too heavy...the four of us shared one, and in our heads we were wishing we each got our own. My sister mentioned that they seem to outsource a lot of their pastry items to top notch places....like Dynamo Donuts and Anthony's cookies.

Service: the servers were great. very chill, but efficient. even though the line was long, it moved pretty fast.

i'll definitely be back to try the slow drip!
author: Fara C.

description:
now THIS is good coffee.  Four barrel is awesome- the cafe itself is super cute and really friendly and the coffee is delicious.  i drink coffee because i like the flavor of it (though don't need the caffeine) and was really impressed by the level of flavor in the iced coffee i picked up on my way out of the mission.

the pastries all looked great- i've heard about the kouign amann from here, but physically already had anthony's cookies in my hand as i was picking up coffee so i'll have to wait til next time to try them.
author: Lisa C.

description: Hands down best coffee in SF. No question about it. And of course it is! It's coming from guys will legit passion for what they do. Keep it up FB. I love you.
author: Teresa R.

description: So I do believe that avoiding the rush is key to enjoying this place.  We got a latte and cappucino, and neither required sugar. It means that the coffee is smooth and flavorful.  Beautifully poured, and then the Kouign-amann was probably the best I've ever had. Very light, airy, and crisp and tender at the same time. I felt like I was submerging myself in hipster, but that means there's usually a love of the product, and it shows.  the bike racks outside in the parklet were industrial adorable, and actually reasonably practical as well.  I was fond of the mug sayings, but I don't actually use a mug, so it seemed a bit silly to get one.  I'd be happy to go back for just the pastry (I'm not a big coffee person), but the coffee was worth the line too.
author: Erin O.

description:
I was drawn to Four Barrel after reading a post on Dave Asprey's Bulletproof Executive blog about how to find the best coffee in your city. He names Four Barrel as the best quality coffee in San Francisco. You can read the post here for the reasons why: http://www.bulletproofexec.com/3-steps-to-finding-the-highest-performance-coffee-in-your-city/

Asprey is big on the benefits of high-quality coffee, and the significance of the difference between good and bad coffee. I am not a coffee aficionado, but I do drink coffee almost everyday, and if you do too I highly suggest you read Asprey's stuff about coffee and how to know what and where the best beans are.

The decor of the place is nice and the staff buck the hipster stereotype by being very friendly.
author: Alex K.

description:
I cannot say enough good things about Four Barrel!

Best coffee in the city.
Best people watching of any cafe on Valencia.
Awesome parklet.
Chocolate spice donut.
Great interior architecture.
Clean, fun (yes, fun) bathroom.
Solid rotation of interesting artwork on the walls.
Friendly hipster service with a non-ironic smile.
AFFOGATO!

I could go on with the effusive compliments, but really, I don't want you to go there, because that would mean I would have to stand in line longer.
author: James B.

description: Great stop for coffee and to catch up with friends! The menu is simple but does not disappoint. I had the mocha and it was not too sweet, which I was very pleased with.
author: Kylie B.

description:
I've been here a few times with fellow Yelper, Jeff W.   The coffee, particularly if you love coffee, is good.  Indeed, if you just want to dash in and run out with a cup of java, Four Barrel is perfect.   It's staying there that it's less perfect.

How so?  One is the attitude of the staff.  I ordered an iced coffee.  When I went to add sweetener, there is no Splenda or other artificial sweetener. I asked about the lack of a sugar substitute and got a haughty, "We don't serve that."   Ah, but Four Barrel does serve soymilk for those opposed or allergic to milk.  Um, for those of us trying to watch calories, I don't want to put a quarter cup of sugar to sweeten very strong coffee.  

I also wonder why iced coffee is $2.50 and regular coffee is $2.  Does the ice really cost that much?  

I'll probably go back to Four Barrel, but only because Jeff W. loves it so much.
author: Scott S.

description: Gorgeous space and fantastic coffee.  LOVE!
author: Karen N.

description:
Great coffee, big surprise.  Here's the gouge:
1) The main line down the center is for people on the go: espresso drinks & french press.  The line may be long, but it goes fast.
2) The little bar on the left makes coffee and espresso slowly on purpose.  It's the good stuff: V60 pour-overs, hand pulled espresso shots, and personal conversation with the hipster making it for you.

Admittedly not a hipster myself, I found the staff to be ridiculously friendly, outgoing, non-pretentious, and knowledgable about their coffee.  Also a great place for people-watching.
author: Dan R.

description:
Four Barrel allows those who are bandwagoners in the caffeine world to jump on and never get off. The space gives way to sleek architecture and plays right into the San Francisco joe scene: minimalism with rather adept pourover fiends slinging hot water kettles left and right and hand cranking the 'spro.

If you get a chance to head to the mothership, do so, but if you just find their beans around, pick some up. Without as much of a tenure as some of the other big name roasters in the US or the Pacific NW, you can still feel pretty hip by getting into Four Barrel. Otherwise, you will soon just see this in the top tier of roasters without much of the "I was first" appeal.

Opened in 2008, this shop has spearheaded the "no wi-fi" trend, and I cannot quite say what I think about that quite yet.... over in Austin, I enjoy my wi-fi and cup of black way too much, regardless of how good the coffee gets. But, if you look up "Four Barrel" on Google, the first thing to come up in the news is their ditching of soy for almond milk. Interesting... and progressive....
author: Solomon W.

description:
Their espresso drinks are amazing. The crema is like 1/4 of an inch thick and there are absolutely no air bubbles in the steamed milk. It's pretty much the perfect cup of espresso.

Also, the decor is fantastic. Everything looks industrial (read: dark and sexy), and there are dead animal heads on the walls that keep the preachy vegans at bay.

But the REAL reason I go is to get waited on by the most beautiful barista/viking that I have ever seen. Is there anything better than a 6 foot 2 red-bearded man, silhouetted against wall-mounted boar heads and serving me amazing coffee? I don't think so.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
I have the coffee taste palate of a Plebeian. 

That being said, the coffee I had here seemed pretty average. I have this weird brand of lactose intolerance that renders me unable to drink whole milk, but I can squeeze by on nonfat if I don't have too much of it. Unfortunately, I could only choose between a diarrheal death or paying 50cents extra for soy milk. I went with the latter.

For some reason, there's only one dude who prepares the coffees, so my open cup of coffee was chillin on top of an espresso machine while other people were served their mochas, lattes, etc. It took them a while to finally get to my cup of coffee, and then the coffee dude reaches for a jug of whole milk and proceeds to tip it into my cup. It was all I could do to keep from leaping over the counter and slapping the treacherous dairy out of his hands.

I told him (probably too quickly and too loudly) that I wanted soy milk. He stopped, blinked, seemed to contemplate my request, and said sure, he could put soy milk in my cup for me. He seemed to think he was doing me a huge favor or something.

I then realized, stupidly, that I could have just gotten my milk for free at the side.

Besides the ridiculously hipster ambiance, I was pretty underwhelmed by my experience here. I hope the espresso is as good as people say it is, because the coffee and service were a yawn-worthy average.
author: Janet W.

description: One of my favorite coffee places in the city. I always enjoy sitting down with a delicious cup of coffee and getting to enjoy a good conversation with friends or family.
author: Tom V.

description: Loved the atmosphere and that there is a lot of seating. Coming from Seattle, baristas tend to be a bit pretentious and rude, and these guys were all super friendly as they answered questions about espresso and talked about the chemistry behind the slow pour. Planning to go back tomorrow morning!
author: Kristin S.

description:
MEH!!! METHINKS NOT!!
I understand that this place is super popular and it gets crowded, but dude they need to work on their system. I ordered from one counter thinking it would be served by the barista on her side, but nope. the person who ordered 4 lattes got theirs before mine even showed up, which was ON THE OTHER side of the counter. That just seems counterintuitive. Then... the latte.... BLEH. No flavor... it just taste like water. Not smooth either.

The pastries looked good in the counter, so I got the apple coffee cake, banana chocolate scone, and the kavign mann(?). However the hell you would spell it, basically it's a croissant that has been folded in. There's something in the middle, which makes it taste nasty. It's way too sweet. The scone tastes raw. The inside was mushy. There was a hint of banana though. The apple coffee cake ..first thought that came into mind, it tastes like dog slobber. Never coming back to this place. What a huge disappointment!
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Yummy yummy ... another great coffee place in SF.  This place was huge!  It's pretty large inside and you'll see their coffee roasters in the back of the store.  

I ordered a Decaf Soy Cafe Latte which was really good.  I can't drink caffeine or regular milk and usually when I get this drink at other places it tastes terrible.  This is probably one of the best that I've had and I loved it.  The coffee flavor was strong which is what I always look for in my decaf coffees.  It is now on my list of stops whenever I'm in SF.
author: Stephanie H.

description:
Simple, good coffee. Brewed with diligence and care, starting from roasting their own raw beans in the back (by the way, the coffee "shop" is huge) to their immersion and pour-over filter methods, and into your hand. Starting from the roasting, there is someone there who is controlling the heating process by hand - which looked like a pretty tedious process. Baristas are helpful, and you can tell they enjoy and have a passion for what they're doing. They also have a "bar" on the side where you can buy beans, filters and brewers (v60's or Chemex), and if you're confused, there are baristas behind the mini-bar that shows you how to brew your own cup! 

And why do I say simple? They don't over-complicate the process, whether it's getting the beans to a brewed cup o' Joe, or their menu (no crazy concoctions or seasonal drinks with loaded flavors and syrups), or even their coffee-shop DJ (only play music from big record disks). No wi-fi either, which at first angers the majority of us who are addicted to being on our phone, but forces you to go back to the basics: good coffee and good conversation.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Super good and convenient! There's so much to do in this neighborhood and Four Barrel starts the beginning of Valencia's stretch of cool shops and restaurants. 

I knew I'd make this a nearly second home to me when I walked in to find taxidermy on the walls and the sweet voice of Dolly Pardon playing on the turntable. The staff is friendly, they've got good jams and the lattes are awesome. Considering they've always got a line in the am, there's hardly a long wait at all. 

I'd give it 5 stars, but there's no wifi. I understand that this is to keep people from camping or encourage people to enjoy the parklet outside, but it is a coffee shop with no wifi. It's the ONLY reason I didn't give 5 stars.
author: Sheena A.

description: I don't particularly like bitter tastes, so I judge the quality of a cappuccino by how smooth it is - in a good cappuccino I don't have to add sugar to temper the bitterness.  Mission achieved at Four Barrel!  The cappuccino was good and they have some tasty baked goods.  It's a beautiful space and not too loud.  It's a pleasant place to hang out and get some work done if you don't need wifi.
author: L C.

description:
I work a couple of blocks away and decided to try this place base on yelp's glowing reviews. It was very busy but surprisingly the line moved swiftly. I ordered regular coffee and seeing a thin layer of oils in the coffee tells me I'm going to get good coffee since most places use paper filters that soaks up all the natural oils, which is why I brew my own coffee at home using a French press. What I also love is that they are so far the only ones to have almond milk! 

The coffee is light and sweet, I was hoping for something more dense and bold but without the bitterness. It's still good coffee and would definitely go there again, price is the same as other places, win win for me!
author: Larry O.

description:
Here all the time. Really nice people working here. Always a pleasure to be served.
Crowd is also nice, young and friendly.
The coffee is simply the best in town. And their little candy (chocolate, caramel and nuts) are just delicious!

Hint: on week-end, go get your coffee at Caledonia, their mini coffee shop behind.
author: Jonathan P.

description: Great cup of espresso. Only four stars because the lines can get long and slow in the mornings. Close to my yearly seasonal job in the mission, but once my contract ends in April, it's too long a drive from the Outer Richmond.
author: Frank B.

description:
I have several words for this place.

1. Over hyped

2. Expensive

3. Long lines that are not worth-it. Your time is better spent at Coffee Bar.

4. Coffee is ok.

5. Really? That's it? So Sad.
author: Truong P.

description: Switched from soy to almond milk. Much better alternative. Really does compliment the coffee well. Thanks for the tip 'Elisha'
author: Ed O.

description: I spent a day with my local San Francisco friend and he had the day planned out, full of must see local sites and must have food and coffee places, and this was one of the coffee places for him. The atmosphere is much like intelligentsia in Pasadena with distressed wooden tables and and industrial look throughout and the workers definitely know their stuff. I had an iced coffee and it was probably the best cup of coffee I've ever tasted. I sat outside in their "public parklet" and talked with friends and had a great time there! I didn't think it was overly caffeinated either, energized me for the day of walking but I was able to sleep easily
author: Brianna R.

description: Best coffee shop in SF !! High quality beans and a really hipster, awesome coffee bar.  Outside seating or in which is great for meetings or friend hang out.   Priceyyyy beans !  Paid $17.50 today for a 12 oz bag. I'm sure it's worth every penny but as I'm watching my SF pennies , a single cup of coffee is all I can do.  They offer a monthly membership too...  Over all = yum !!
author: T L.

description: Great coffee, lovely staff. Came here almost every day to get a decent coffee fix on my recent trip to SF. Will definitely be back when I visit again.
author: M F.

description: It might be the wrong review for saying this but I love the ambiance!  hahahhaha  I like how they don't have much ornament but it's the rustic beauty with the mission vibe.
author: Jee C.

description:
Hipster central! LOL. Love the vibe and atmosphere of this place.

GREAT coffee, and the lemon thyme donut (??) is absolutely yummy. Will definitely be back to watch the fauna in their natural habitat. :)
author: Wendy P.

description:
The coffee here is one of the best in the city. The latte had a great combination between the expresso and has good food options. Dinamo doughnuts are available here in case the walk to 24th St seems too long. 

I could deal without the taxidermy on the wall, but that's my personal two cents.
author: Carolina S.

description:
If you're from Seattle and you need something like Vivace / Victrola / Stumptown / etc.... four barrel is where you go.

Machiatto made my mouth say "THAT RIGHT THERE IS A FIVE STAR!"
author: Kimberley D.

description: This is my favorite coffee place. You work in the back at the counters and watch them roast the beans and fill the air with great aromas.
author: Danny Y.

description:
Space: High ceilings, well-lit, with all the Mission essentials of exposed industrial whatever, hip art and gargantuan lighting fixtures. Jam-packed with folks in line and tables small enough to demand the choice: coffee or laptop on the floor?

Service: There are a couple people who will help you through the assembly line of getting your order. In my visits, one will always be pleasant, and the other simmering with resentment over the last 10 minutes of her shift.

Substance: Coffee's good, but limited. They got what they got and you better like it, no adornment. Scowls for decaf and soy. OK, OK, sorry!

Overall, this place is structured to discourage settling down to work and, at those busy-busy need energy to-go times of day, the line's out the door. What's the point of you, Four Barrel? I like everywhere else better.
author: Stella S.

description: This place lives up to the hype. Worth a visit just for the ambience. The coffee is expertly made with perfect ratios.
author: Daniel L.

description:
My go to stop for my ride into work. For amazing coffee, great service, and a friendly people - I can always jump in and get what I want within 3 minutes! Spectacular! 

Also, I must stress, there are plenty of coffee shops in the city. They have 'good' coffee; but the coffee here is incredible. And you can customize your order - and they are quite attentive at what you want and what you don't want. 

I love this place!
author: Jane E.

description: This is just a review for the coffee.  The interior seemed fine; I'm sure I'd enjoy sitting here to enjoy a latte' were I staying.  Instead I selected a bag of Montanita Pacamara (El Salvador).  Look, I wanted to think this would be high-end coffee.  I've made half a dozen pourovers from this, before posting this review.  I've taste-tested with my spouse.  We lived in Portland and travel to Hawaii.  We've had excellent coffee many many times, whether Stumptown's best or pure Kona, but this roast was just simply average.  Not bad.  Just average.  Certainly nothing to write home about.  Flat and sour (but not excessively so) and I'm a fan of Central American . . . but this coffee was just a real disappointment.
author: Michael W.

description: I personally was astonished by the way they pour there coffee!  I am a coffee fanatic and I can truly say 4 barrel is one of my favorite coffee joints!
author: Hideki S.

description:
great little coffee shop on valencia.  simple, rustic decor complements their uncomplicated approach to coffee.  None of the holiday specials you see at starbucks,  just the basic coffee drinks here at the main counter.

Then on the side is the coffee bar where they make the coffee for purists with the proper temperatures and filters.  if you are discerning enough, than  this is the place for you.

I had their latte last time I went.  Definitely will be back, next time i'm in SF.
author: Alex M.

description:
Whenever I'm in the area I try to make an excuse to get into Four Barrel for either their latte or iced coffee.  SO RICH AND CREAMY and gives me a nice lift in spirit for the day.

I LOVE the whole design of the coffee shop.  It's spacious, utilizes space well, allows for the in and out coffee drinker, the day time studier, the I want to chit chat over a cup of coffee lover and the I WANT TO SEE them actually roast their own beans and be totally involved in the business of what makes this coffee so ridiculously amazing.  In summary, they cater to all types and are more than happy to mix/mash all of them under one big ginormous roof. 

After I order I usually scoot my way to the rear of the coffee shop so I can get a glimpse of them roasting/packing the beans.  They have a bench in the back and I will sip and watch them busily making their wonderful coffee.

I haven't experimented much with all their coffee options but I am always consistently happy with their lattes and iced coffee.  GO GO GO!!
author: Sandy L.

description: They made that quadruple latte with skim milk, splenda AND honey that I asked for, and didn't bat an eye. My friend ordered the steamed Orangina and it was so spongy and delightful. Wow, that's all I can say. Wow. Everything was sourced by elves wearing cotton, paying farmers in pure gold nuggets so you know it's fair. This brand is one to watch: if they made denim, I would wear it!
author: Thompson O.

description:
I'm actually surprised to see that other yelpers call the staff unfriendly-- they may just be my favorite part of Four Barrel coffee! Whenever I have a question about beans, the drip process, etc. I am always answered in an informative manner and leave with an even greater love of coffee than I came in with. 

In addition to unique roasts, beautiful latte art and an open and visually pleasing space, Four Barrel cares about coffee first and foremost. 

I'm a fan.
author: Tracy L.

description: Good coffee, nice ambiance, and spacious for a coffee place. it was great hanging out with friends here after a good dinner at a restaurant nearby. Too bad they didn't have tea though.
author: Cindy S.

description:
This might just be one of the coolest coffee places in SF!! I'm not a coffee drinker but we had friends visiting from my home who are coffee connoisseurs and owned their own coffee place back in Perth, Australia. They were on a world trip to visit the best coffee places and Four Barrel Coffee was one of four in SF that was on their list. They were so impressed with their coffee, they bought 8 bags of coffee beans to bring home!!

Personally, I love the vibe here and what's even more awesome???? They allow patrons to bring in their pets! I loved seeing big and small dogs sitting around in the shop!
author: Jamie C.

description: Very good coffee. They got a maple be con dounut. I'm a fan. It's a little busy on the weekends but worth the wait.
author: Bill H.

description:
interesting place ... stay until your battery dies because there is not a power outlet in sight. Coffee is carefully roasted and brewed onsite. Very cool atmosphere. 

I enjoyed sitting at the window bar people watching and being watched. Good experience.
author: Andy N.

description:
I don't claim to be a coffee connoisseur by any means, but damn this is great coffee!
 
I rarely drink coffee anywhere, and even when I do, I always need to add sugar/cream to it.. that was, until I found Four Barrel. My cup of coffee (equipped with it's cute little foam art) needed no extra additions from me. This is how I KNOW that THIS is good coffee. The little cup of goodness has sooo much flavor.. I never really understood the whole depth/layers of coffee beans thing.. but now I do. Now, I'm a believer.. and a coffee drinker!! 

Great place. A must stop, every time I'm in the Mission. 

p.s. this joint gets packed.. but its so big and open, you won't feel the least bit claustrophobic.
author: Tammy S.
