description: I'm a musician and frequent the mission's night clubs and venues, four barrel has always treated my band mates and I right. Amazing sound system, ample seating and overly friendly (not snobby) staff. My favorite cappuccino south of North Beach!
author: Hunter S.

description:
By my measure, Four Barrel roasts the best beans in San Francisco. It doesn't taste burned (I'm looking at you, Ritual), holds up well in milk or alone, and is reliably complex and flavorful. I wish there was a place in the East Bay that hawked their goods, but until then, I'll cross the bridge to get at these beauties. If you have an espresso machine at home, I suggest you grab a bag of these beans and give 'em a whirl. (UPDATE: Now both SubRosa in Oakland and Local123 in Berkeley are using Four Barrel beans and have bags of beans for retail. Hallelujah!).

Their cafe, on the other hand, has its pros and cons. The decor is interesting and funky...but the tables aren't all that comfy, and the crowd slash lack of wifi makes this a less-than-ideal place to camp out for an afternoon (the primary function of cafes in my life). However, their baristas know what the hell they are doing, so if you want a tasty cappuccino and can find space to sit and enjoy it, Four Barrel is worth the pit stop.
author: Monica S.

description:
Yes, there are hipsters here. Yes, the baristas are hipsters as well. BUT, it's worth going inside and at least trying the "pour over" style coffee. I had some Columbian beans and I normally add creamer and sugar to my coffee but I didn't even have to this time because it tasted so rich and heavenly. 

The only downside is that it's in the Mission district which is pretty sketchy in some places especially coming from the BART.
author: Ashley S.

description: This review is about the guy who makes the drip coffee. This guy is sure that the sun shines from his behind (and not in the positive Smiths way). He thinks patrons are there only to watch him do his "magic" they should definitely get rid of this dude. He's is like all the bad stereotypes about SF/Mission/Hipsters in one guy, and it's a shame. I stay with Sightglass - where they actually care about coffee and clients and not about putting a effing show and talking down to clients. Seriously.
author: Too M.

description: I don't drink coffee, however I love the smell of coffee. So what better way to enjoy that by going to a coffee shop that roasts their coffee beans in the same location you can relax. The fact that you are in the middle of it all is pretty awesome. I've been going to this place for a while now and love the environment. The people who go there and who work there remind me of why San Francisco is my home. The interior is spacious and extremely well thought out. Four Barrel Coffee deserves 5 stars because it's Four Barrel Coffee. - Ray Clay
author: Ray C.

description:
Easily my favorite roaster in the city. Their Ethiopian roasts are wonderfully light and acidic. The selection is always a good diversity, and they know what they're doing when it comes to pourovers. The baristas are exceptionally well versed, and very excited to talk to you about it even when they're working hard because of a long line.

Consider this a four and half star review with the half star docked from this location because it can get a tad busy but for no other reason that.
author: Bruno H.

description:
I love how spacious Four Barrel is inside and I love the decor and I love the outdoor seating - sooo nice to sit outside when the weather is good like it was today. The warm afternoon sun was a pleasant surprise for January. 

I just had a latte which came with pretty latte art - a leaf. I wonder if they have animals in the repertoire. Anyway, latte was delicious. Didn't have anything else yet so cannot comment on that, but I like the decor a lot.
author: Veronica H.

description:
Before you even walk into Four Barrel, you'll be barraged by clues that will tip you off to a changing atmosphere. Bike racks, rolled up skinny jeans and a fair share of flannel shirts were some gems that I saw. 

This a very hipster place. This is neither a good nor a bad thing, but if you don't like that kind of vibe, you probably shouldn't go here. If you don't like dozens of people sitting at tables lining the wall people-watching the you-know-what out of you, you shouldn't go here either. Ambiance can truly make or a break a place for some people, you know?

That being said, this place has wonderful coffee. I don't claim at all to be a coffee aficionado, but I've learned a little bit about telling a bad cup o' joe from a good one...and this place has good ones. I love me some lattes and I love me some mochas, and I enjoyed the two that I tried (one was a friend's). Nice job, Four Barrel.
author: Christine V.

description: You can't argue with the quality of the lattes here - it was spot on. All drinks are one-size with double shots. This isn't the place to go if you want to be quick about grabbing your morning coffee - I came in on a weekday around 9am and all the tables were taken and the line was 5 people deep. But they move as efficiently as they can, so if you're willing to wait a bit for quality coffee, then this is your place!
author: Karen T.

description: #1 in my list for coffee in bay area. Anything here is good from Americano to Latte. If you have enough time and patience, try their dripped coffee, it is an EXPERIENCE.
author: Nadia A.

description: The coffee here is terrible. It had a sour aftertaste. I usually don't put a lot of cream and sugar in my coffee but I had to for this cup and I am lactose intolerant. On a positive note I like the outdoor seats in the front.
author: Bobby C.

description:
I am not into coffee unless it's great quality. 
I would absolutely reccommend this place. 
I had a regular cappuccino honestly to test the quality of their coffee, it was great!
This place is also roomy, has a great trendy atmosphere. It's fun also with its rustic style. 
Definitely one of those places you want to go for a coffee date :)
author: Trevor B.

description:
Raised in Venezuela, I appreciated know the difference between great coffee and crappy dirty water by just smelling it. So when I entered Four Barrel, my nose told me they were into something!

It didn't lie: the first thing I saw was a nice barista making a drip coffee with such dedication that you thought it was a work of art. Then, I asked what kind of coffee he would recommend and his reply was:

"What kind of coffee do you normally like?" 
"Intense flavor, fool body, sweet berries," I said.

So he recommended one of the specialty coffees of the day. He made it one, looked at my little cup, having an internal telepathic dialog with it, and then proceeded to make another cup.

"That one poured too fast," he said.

Granted the espresso left me $4 poorer, but it was perfection in a cup! Unforgettable!

I've been back a few times, trying different coffees, some espressos, some Macchiatos, some with sugar... and they have consistently exceeded my expectations. The patrons are nice local people that are happy to let you pet their dogs and engage in conversation.

Maybe they are a bit of coffee snobs, but you see, these coffees deserve respect!
author: Gabriela P.

description: I love their Almond milk lattes but wish it was a bit hotter though. The place is super hipster. It looks asif its a hipster convention but they have great coffee so I dont mind them at all. Everyone is super friendly and they have great coffee. I love this place.
author: Jessica A.

description:
I love coming to this place to get coffee. They have many single origin coffees and they are all tasty! The interior decor gives this place sort of an industrial feel which adds on to the experience. Four Barrel is great for having coffee and getting some alone time as well as gathering with friends to catch up. If you want to come do some work here beware because there is no wi-fi but I find that helpful because that means less distractions when it comes to studying. 

You will often find this place with a line but the line moves pretty fast. There are 2 lines, one for your lattes, mochas,... etc. and one other line for individually dripped coffee on your left. Yum!

Oh and don't forget to lock up your bike on their bike racks outside!
author: Kevin C.

description:
If you live in SF you already know where to find your favorite coffee roaster.  I would put Four Barrel in my top 5, but not number 1.  The line is always long, but they are efficient and it moves fast.  The bathrooms are nice and have always been clean when I visit.  They aren't labeled as such... but I am pretty certain they serve Dynamo Donuts in their case (unless they have stolen the passion fruit chocolate recipe bc it was exact).  They sell whole beans to take home and they rival all the greats of SF.  

Perhaps they deserve 5 stars... but after living in Vienna and SF I am not sure I remember what bad coffee even tastes like... so in a group with the best of the best, they get 4 stars.
author: D M.

description:
About as hipster as you can get. Bike racks outside, individual drip coffe, etc, etc.

This review is for the espresso, since I am much more of an espresso snob than a coffee person. Sadly, the most you can say about it is it was okay. Average espresso with a normal price. I guess it has a good location if you live in the Mission.

I tried the coffee another time at work. That was much better. Strong without an overwhelming taste at the end.
author: Ethan R.

description:
Enjoyed a cup at their pour over bar and WOW was I impressed with not just the taste but the service. 

The guy working the pour over bar exuded his love for coffee & was so excited to share it with everyone. He took the time to explain the different roasts and help us each find something we'd really love.

It's a great place to hang - usually pretty crowded - but if you can find a seat along the back bar, grab a cup of coffee & watch them roast the beans.

The also have a big bike rack out front so ride your bike over!
author: Sam H.

description:
I was hesitant to come here as it might be too hipstery I might not blend in :).  The place was okay.  It had an industrial feel to it and I can't help stare at the bear heads on the wall.  I can't quite place it but it creeped me out.

I'm not a coffee drinker so I didn't have coffee.  I did try one of the donuts.  The maple bacon one, it was alright.  

What I like about this place is the roasting scene in the back of the shop.  That was such a delightful sight.
author: Pam S.

description: We all have different tastes for coffee. This coffee smells great to me but tastes bitter and burnt. Doesn't have a wonderful finish too.
author: M W.

description: Excellent coffee in the Mission. Baristas are very serious about coffee and they can pour superb espesso-based drinks. I terribly disliked the feral pig heads in the walls. Not cool.
author: Ato B.

description: This cafe looked awesome as I passed it, cool brackets for bikes street side, great vibe and cool crowd, sandwiched in a stretch of eclectic shops. Will definitely be back to try it the next time I'm in Frisco.
author: Jiahui Y.

description:
"I've been roaming around I was lookin down at all I see....painted faces fill the places I can't reach....You know that I could USE! somebodayyy..." 

Am I the only one who sees Kings of Leon or The Civil Wars when walking into a Mission district coffee house? 

Granted, Four Barrel Coffee doesn't play any of the aforementioned bands overhead, (they're equipped w/their own stash of long play records of Black Sabbath and the likes) but I'm telling you, the ambiance, the scene, the people: Mumford & Sons. 

The coffee and service though? Stellar. I had a soy latte, and for a girl who drowns her coffee in splenda and the likes (I know) I found myself not having to sweeten this cup at all. My friend had a black cup of their current brew and liked it. She ended up buying a bag of different beans for home: Costa Rica Aserri las palomas, even though she hadn't even tried a sample. To me that shows trust at first cup. 

Will I be back at Four Barrel? Most likely. Do I wish my home mimicked Four Barrel's set-up of industrial mixed wood & metal chic decor? Yes. Aside from jocking the ambiance, do their paintings of clowns on the walls still scare me? 100%.

"But iiiiiiii will hold on hope and iiiiiiii won't let you choke on the noose around your neck...
And I'llllllll find strength in pain and iiiiiiiii will change my ways I'll know my name as it's called again..."
author: Rho T.

description:
Yep, its a solid 4.  The slow bar coffees are fantastic.  Every once in a while I've drew a prick as my barista at the slow bar, but that's literallly one guy.  Everyone else I've dealt with has been AWESOME.

I'm not a big fan of their espresso blend.  A little too acidic of an espresso for me, so I stick to drip coffee.  Their prices have recently increased, which makes it less awesome.  Its still good stuff, but if the slow bar wasn't open, I wouldn't make a point of going there.
author: Chris A.

description: When I want the best cappuccino or latte in the city I go here, they use Strauss organic full cream cafe style milk (or Almond Milk for ¢50). Their menu says what they have, if you don't see it, you shouldn't try to order it. They might make it for you, but like most coffee shops that take coffee this seriously (and sometimes come off as pretentious) they might not like making it for you. They're friendly so long as you don't ask too many questions since there's usually a line out the door. Bottom line: Best latte in town, but this is not Starbucks so don't ask for silly drinks.
author: Chris R.

description:
Went here last week for a quick cup of coffee since my friend and I were feeling a good cup of coffee. Got here around 730-8ish I believe? Easily one of the best coffees I have ever had in my life (except fot eh iced coffee, I would pass on that if I were you). They have a station specifically for the pour over coffee seekers with a barista there for any sort of questions you have or just want a specific taste to satisfy those craving taste buds itching at you for that insanely good cup of good old Joe! 

Now I am unsure of what the coffee was exactly called at the drip coffee station, but I can say that it has a fruity taste and has coconut in it which when you smell it, your senses instantly say "GIVE IT TO ME!!". This is one of those coffees where you do not have to add sugar or cream, yes I said it, you do not have to add sugar or cream for which any cup of coffee iced or hot, I must have cream and sugar. This is one of the hardest things for a coffee shop to do for me and that only blue bottle has ever done to me before which is saying a lot, and yes I am an amateur when it comes to coffee too, not some big shot who knows a ton about coffee so just fyi.

This place has many draws for all types of people, not so much students (like me) I believe however if you are trying to study since there is no wifi, or outlets anywhere here. I remember the news talking about this a few years ago and they're reasoning behind it is so people are not so connected into what is on their screen, but to interact with people around you, which after all is what a coffee shop is also part about.

Overal I believe that four barrel is one of those chill places with great coffee where if you just want to chill and relax with friends, this is the place to do it! I will return when I have time for a good cup of good old coffee!
author: Brannon T.

description:
Been here a few times now. Honestly this is becoming one of my favorite spots. Basically coffee for me is tricky. You have your commuter coffee (Starbucks and Peets) that is super dark and roasted and brewed in a pot to pretty much no flavor and served hot. And then you have your extreme cutesy (Philz) with overly aromatic, more so drinking a hot blueberry rather than coffee. Four Barrel I find to be a very good balance in between. Their coffee is a a little bit acidic with a really good flavor. It's a little cloudier than other coffee I have had (like not all one black, mostly blends of dark brown throughout). Very comforting and overall easily drinkable. They have donuts here which believe it or not are sweeter than krispy kreme  (a little too sweet imo).

The interior has a rustic look to it which I like. It's a little small even though it's layout gives it the appearance of being huge. There are some outside seating/leaning area but it is usually covered with cyclists so good luck with that. There is a small coffee bar near the entrance which I still haven't tried. Seems more for fancy stuff. I wanted to try the normal first. Working my way up. It's pricey so give me a break :)
author: Greg G.

description:
Cheers to Nicky, the manager of Four Barrel.  He has taken the time to humbly apologize for the bad service I received.  

I had a really good iced americano (it was 84 degrees out today) while we chatted about my experience.  He promised that is not their standard practice.  Totally fine with me, mistakes happen.  When someone takes the time to apologize, that is going the extra mile to win back my service.

I will gladly come back here again because of the follow up.
author: Kellan M.

description: Super friendly and affordable. I had a brain fart moment bc i didnt know which counter to order my drink and the cashier and barista escorted me to the proper counter. It was super funny and nice. The coffee wasnt bitter at all too!
author: Sun K.

description:
Quite honestly, I don't know what to really think of this place. My husband said we should try this place and he heard it's better than Philz. Okay - fair enough. Let's go try it! So we headed over there after looking at their menu on yelp (which isn't updated, btw) and I picked a roast I wanted. Walked in, scoured the walls for a legible menu, offerings, selections, and found one. Kinda. Read what was available, and wasn't impressed - everything is a medium-light to medium roast. I'm a dark to dark-medium fan (I don't particularly like adding anything to my coffee and I like bold and rounded out taste). They had a French press special (recommended to me by the barista helping us after I told her what we liked) and couldn't drink it for at least 60 minutes because it was so damn hot. When I finally tried it - holy shit was that coffee damn sour. Maybe I should've gone to the pour over bar, but it's not really obvious that they serve people at that bar area, but then again, they had no true medium roasts. 

We headed to the ball game after and I went into Philz and got me a Silken Splendor. Smooth and rich. Just as it should be. 

1 star for the barista attempting to find us something, 1 star for the baked goods and 1 star for the decor/ambience. Loved the rustic theme they're going for. 

Also, would it be possible to put soy out in the bar - my coffee probably would've been more palatable if I could put some sort of cream in it and cut the sour bite. Though, I may not come back, so I guess it doesn't matter.
author: Kelly Marie C.

description:
I picked a very great place to start my summer hunt for the best coffeehouse in San Francisco.

Four Barrel offers two products to its customers: coffee and a unique experience. As soon as you walk through the doors, you immediately smell the coffee beans. The design and the customer service immediately stood out to me! I ordered a regular coffee and a macchiato; both were amazing! I've never a better coffee in my life. I've got to give Four Barrel props. Whatever they're doing, they're doing it very well.

As for the overall experience, I give Four Barrel a 5/5. Great community feel to it. People have conversations, work on their Macbooks, sit outside next to the bike racks. The music volume's just right. Everything was awesome! I definitely recommend people try this place!
author: Michael U.

description:
I work right down the street from Four Barrel now. I like coffee, but I'm not a fiend. Being this close to Four Barrel may change that.

Cool thing last time I was there - a coffee sampling/grading going on in the back.
author: Emily M.

description: Excellent, complex and bright espresso, the pastry I had was also fresh and decadent. The one issue I have is with the knowledge of the staff, I ordered a dry cappuccino and received nothing of the sort despite me clarifying that it was to be dry. Nonetheless the quality is there just a lack of training for their employees.
author: Adam S.

description:
This place is very neat -- definitely a must-see in San Francisco. The coffee is great and if you tell the barista what flavors you like, they'll recommend a blend for you.

All of the coffee places in SF make me cringe every time I get Starbucks...
author: Lauren F.

description: I visited Four Barrel at least three times during a recent five day stay in SF. I was in love with the atmosphere, the macchiato, and all the pretty people. I'm in love with coffee, period, but this was a little piece of shangri-la right around the corner from where I was staying.
author: Crystal W.

description:
The battle of the coffee roasters is alive and well. 

I've been to Four Barrel a handful of times. And each time I sipped my coffee nice and slow, just to enjoy the experience of it all. 

Summary:
coffee - love it. need it. gotta have it.
ambiance - cool industrial meets hunting lodge look
friendly service - as in with a smile and no attitude when i have my kids in tow?
clean bathrooms - hey sometimes nature calls
great selection of "oh what the hell I'll take two of those" baked goods - to savor with my "morning cup of life"

So what differentiates one from the next? I mean beyond the obvious list above? The people behind the business - the ones who care about the community that they do business in. Imagine my delight when I heard that Four Barrel would be a sponsor of the Rosa Parks Elementary Parents Coffee Klatch. Now that's just cool. Raising my mug to you all. Cheers.
author: Stephanie I.

description: Love the fact that they have just 7-8 items on their menu. I feel I need to get addicted to coffee when I visit this place. Good place to catch up on your week's economist articles. Victorian restroom!
author: Rahul V.

description:
Four Barrel is the best cup of coffee I've ever had. I've resided most of my life in the Peninsula/East Bay. Though Philz and Blue Bottle have made their way across the bridge, I am sad to realize how sheltered from good coffee I have been!

In the Mission, the place is naturally very hip - I like Ritual's branding more - but I enjoyed the ambience and decor at Four Barrel - love the urban indsutrial feel, the rope lamps by the windows, the boar heads, the roaster in the back, and the wooden tables coming out of the wall. I'd love to just spend an afternoon inside with a good read.

We ordered an Ecuador roast, which had honey and berry flavors, and it went down so sweet and smooth, much to my liking. I would come back for this again and again and am so devastated that there isn't one much like it over here. We also got an iced coffee that was nothing special (poured out of a pitcher) and a disappointing waste of $2.5; oh well, the good coffee discovery was worth it. Ah, can't wait to go again!
author: Jen L.

description:
No comments about the coffee, since I just had a meeting there whose purpose was to talk to someone.

At that, Four Barrel is pretty bad. The place is VERY LOUD. The seats aren't comfortable. The best is probably the counter (kitchen-island-style) next to the door.

Yelp, where's your noise rating? WTF.
author: Vlad V.

description:
Whenever I am in the Mission, I have to stop in to Four Barrel, even if only to use the bathroom - they have one and it's reasonably clean and easy to get to. 

I always like the music they play, the scene, the smell of roasting beans and the space itself. OK, it's true I am older than 95% of the customers but no one holds it against me. Have had lively and fun conversations  while waiting for the bathroom or my drink. 

The coffee, well that's not always my favorite part of the experience although it is certainly OK, but since reading other reviews, perhaps I should try an espresso drink rather than the usual plain black drip I typically order. 

Still, one of the must see and be seen spots on Valencia.
author: Marie K.

description: :/ it took 10 mins just to have an iced mocha and for some reason it tastes very powdery. Disappointed.
author: Albee Z.

description: Really good coffee but its a loud mad house in there.  Music blaring and tons of people.  Not my vibe but may be back.
author: Chelsea D.

description:
Delicious espresso, great environment...loved this place so much.

Noteworthy--they only have whole milk.  Not the end of the world, just unexpected.  

Great service!
author: Shannon H.

description: Great late. In fact it's my favorite in the city. The baristas will take special care to make it how you want. Outside parklet is a hip spot for people watching.
author: Mila L.

description: I was visiting in town and excited to come here.  Four Barrel has been touted as some of the best coffee roasters in the country so I was interested in checking it out.  I got the pour over of their Rwandan Cotecaga.  It was delicious and well-executed.  The ambiance was a little overly hipster for me...and I'm used to being surrounded by hipsters!  This was hipster to another level.  But coffee was superb and the actual space is large and really cool!  Definitely worth a visit. I bought many bags of coffee to bring back across the country!
author: Linda R.

description:
Love this place.  

It has what every coffee shop should have--character.  You walk in, and immediately get hit by that smell that's only around when coffee is being grinded.  It comforted me to see them taking care of their coffee in the back.  Their menu is simple, their treats are one of a kind (although their donuts are prolly from Dynamo), and the service is friendly, efficient, and one can tell that they really know their coffee.  I ordered a mocha and a toffee cookie, both of which were excellent.  The toffee cookie tasted even better when I dipped it into my mocha.  :)  Last time I was in, I ordered the vanilla bean donut, which was excellent.  My only gripe would be that it's hard to find a place to sit, but hey, when you're loved, you're loved.  Can't blame them for that.

I love very strong coffee, and I thought that Four Barrel was a very close second to Blue Bottle.  That doesn't dampen my love for this place, though!
author: Kai C.

description:
I'm not a coffee drinker, and though the taste of this coffee wasn't all that memorable, I was definitely jacked up for about 4 hours after I drank it. So if you can't afford cocaine or speed, grab a cup of black here.

The space is a real pleasure for the eyes, too. And if you have a requisite bicycle, there's plenty of places to park it. They also have $8 bars of chocolate. Because nothing says I love you like wasting money.
author: Alex S.

description:
I've been wanting to try this place for a while, so when we were meeting some friends one morning and had a few minutes to spare, we headed here, just to get that caffeine flowing.  It was really good coffee, and the vibe inside was super hipster, but I really liked it.

Even their bathroom is cool.  No really, go use it.
author: Jenna L.

description:
If you like getting your coffee served by a lumberjack then I suggest you come here. 

This place is pretty hip...but more like where the OG adult hipsters with real jobs hang out. It's a huge coffeehouse that looks like a warehouse. The design is just cool. Open and Clean. There was always a line when I came here, but it was worth the wait.

I like that Four Barrel Coffee has a simple menu and a simple attitude overall. The staff is cool and friendly. I didn't mind waiting for my latte because I knew the staff took their time to make it just right. The mocha is rich and the butter croissant is so good. I was a little sad that I didn't try the maple bacon donut while there, next time.

There's bike parking, a record player, Wi-Fi, deer heads mounted on the wall, cute babies, fashionably hip dudes who dress better than me, fashionably hip dudes who dress better than me and have cute babies--just nice people overall. 

I'll be back soon. This will be my go-to place when I'm visiting my sister and friends in SF.
author: Marilu R.

description:
Excellent coffee, and I highly recommend the mocha.  Located in an amazing space elevating coffee as an art, not just a quick drink.  With the addition of the bike-friendly parklet in front it is now impossible to bike by and not stop for a cup.

Similar to comments from Denise C., this business also gives back to the local community and is helping the parent group at Rosa Parks elementary school grow, one cup at a time.  They had me at the mocha and the sincere service; local community building takes them over the top!
author: Naomi M.

description: Cappuccino was more on the darker roast, bitter. $4 for short size cappuccino was a bit steep. Have still yet to try their drip coffee.
author: J C.

description: Love the ambiance. Not a coffee fan or expert and it was a bit bitter for my taste, but can't judge by 1 drink. Will be back! Staff is sweet and friendly, props to that!
author: Nara B.

description: Four Barrel is great.. The space is really unique and well laid out. Although it is usually slammed- seating does tend to open up pretty regularly which is great... The only real downside is the line, but it moves pretty quickly (hit or miss on the weekend!!). I personally really enjoy the lattes and their baked goods are pretty tasty too (cookies n cream cookie is amazing!). The staff is definitely knowledgeable of coffee and coffee drinks.. sometimes not the most friendly but they are often contending with a orders at once, so I give a pass on less than stellar attitudes! Four Barrel is definitely my go to coffee place in the Mission- check it out if you're in the neighborhood!
author: Frank L.

description:
Slow paced, pretty coffee place full of hipsters.  You could probably say that about the coffee also.  Our latte's and cappucino's were made sloooooowly one-by-one (nice touch, but no good if you are in a hurry or thirsty) and were only just about room temperature.

Saying that, they were delicious - the cake was yummy, and the staff were really nice. So I'll be back to give it another go.
author: Beekay M.

description:
excellent coffee and dessert with wonderful barristas. we ordered

capuccino
kouign amann
croissant

all excellent, but the kouign amann really stood out for layering and crunch.best i have had outside of seattle.
author: Char Y.

description: Delicate, nuanced roasts that taste best when brewed at the attractive slow bar, where the baristas are well informed but offer varying levels of service.  The overall decor leans modern rustic and a bit dark, but is balanced by ample natural light pouring in from skylights and windows.  The ready-to-go brew is good but best when in a rush.  The pastries are the hidden gem and pair very well with coffee.  There is no wifi offered, but if bored, head to the back and watch the crew roast coffee on the gorgeous, vintage Probat.
author: Vin J.

description:
Jitters Jitters Jitters

Seriously I couldn't sit still for the next few HOURS after drinking this coffee. So good yet so strong! I think I'll get a latte next time. Loved the vibe in here and the baristas were really friendly! I'll be back for coffee if I need an upper!
author: Ezequiel R.

description:
Ever walk into one of those places and you have to look around because you think you might have walked into some episode of Stargate that transported you to another culture and dimension?

Okay . . . MAYBE that's a little hyperbolic and it's not quite that different, but for this middle-aged, chubby, 40+ Asian guy, the people who gather here might as well be from another planet.

Now I do not say this in a bad way at all, I love aliens . . . especially when they rock the Tom's, skinny jeans, off facial hear, ironic glasses, thrift store outfits that don't go together so much that they really do . . . and are all probably changing the world as we know it through their work, social engagement and commitment to important causes.

So . . . I love this place because there is def a draw here that attracts a particular element of SF life that is exciting and full of energy.  The coffee is darn good, not overly priced and roasted right here.  Just beware that the order process is more clump-based than line-based ;-)

And the bad, AKA why four and not five stars . . . No wifi, which makes it hard to tweet @fourbarrel . . . just saying. I suspect that is a "We're so plugged in that we don't need to be plugged in" statement, but I still wish there was WIFI and more outlets. Also, while I totally dig the crowd that is here, where are all the brown people? I know it happens, but seriously, in the MiSSION, in SAN FRANCISCO and a real lackof community diversity.  I could the number of brown folks here this morning when it is packed using only 7/10 of my fingers.

That said, this is def worth a visit if you are in the area: for the coffee, the energetic vibe and the pure people watching value.  Give me a wave if you come by.  I'll be the dude sitting in the back . . . the too old/chubby to be wearing ringer-t's and jeans, and REALLY trying unsuccessfully to fit in . . . and wearing ironic glasses ;-)
author: Bruce R.

description:
I am obsessed with coffee shops and thought it was about time that I learned how to make my own fabulous coffee at home. I was already doing my own research when, on a lazy afternoon stroll on Valencia, I found out that Four Barrel had their very own 'brewing better coffee at home' class. I signed up right away. What a treat!

Four Barrel, with its industrial open space, boards' heads on the wall, lack of pastries variety and pretentious hipster crowd, is not necessarily my type of coffee shop. I am more into the cozy ones, with lots of seating and gracious baristas, where I can spend hours immersed in a book, or simply relaxing and people watching. However, when I am around that part of the Mission, I find myself lured into it and grabbing a cup of coffee to go. I do like their coffee, and I like to watch them make it so slowly and carefully, with so much reverence as if they are painting the Monalisa.

They have their coffee class once a month, on Mondays. It is a two hour class, and it goes by really fast. There were 11 people in my class (usually 10), and everyone was engaged and asking tons of questions. The instructor, Matthew, a self proclaimed coffee geek who owns 6 grinders, was very knowledgeable and kind of funny. We learned about the coffee bean, roasting, under-extraction, over-extraction, coffee ratio, types of grinders, water temperature, etc. He covered four brewing methods: French press (still my favorite), chemex, clever drip and V60. At the end we could purchase any of the tools with a class discount, and pretty much everyone in the class bought something. We were all so ready to put our new knowledge to the test!

What makes me a fan of Four Barrel is their passion for coffee, which is reflected all the way from the sourcing to the serving. And now they are even sharing their love and expertise with us, coffee aficionados. If you are one, go take Matthew's class.
author: Simone W.

description:
People aren't kidding when they say it's hipster central. But is that a bad thing? This place has a really nice interior with some funny art on the right wall (check it out!). The place looks huge when you first walk in, but the back third is not for seating. It seems like it would always be crowded (it certainly was when we were there), so it may be hard to grab a seat. 

I got a latte and could taste the quality. I personally liked it better than Blue Bottle. And they do pretty latte art! I was sad to see that they didn't have the chocolate spice donut and got a toasted coconut donut instead. I would have liked more coconut flavor, but it was still pretty good.

The staff behind the counter was REALLY friendly. I interacted with two of them, and both were so, so nice.
author: Janet P.

description:
I met a tall, hot, dark and sexy stranger in here. I paid in cash, it was worth every penny.

I also splurged on an aero-press for $20. Again worth every penny. Like hot sex in my mouth, I could drink this coffee on my last day and be a happy woman.

It's 5 stars but not perfect. There seems to be a lack of bras in the Mission. I swear a nipple dipped in my cup before the server put the lid on and handed me my coffee. It wasn't just here, there was another gal with asbestos nipples dropping them all over the shop. I was concerned that they might get shut in the cash draw - ouch!

Anyway, great coffee, loose boobies.
author: Lizzie S.

description:
Damn.  

So my only experience with Four Barrel up until last night was at The Rose in Salt Lake City where I swung through on my way from Sacramento to Joe's Valley for a week of falling off boulder problems and generally acting like a jackass with the boys.  Even brewed with my camping set up out of a old kettle with no thermometer, i was impressed with their product.  THese guys know their shit.

Alright, first off, they pull a SOLID shot.  I'm not 100% sure on the varietal (yea, I know, shame on me.  I'll give you some money out of my wallet) but it was bright, juicy, floral with a silky mouthfeel and a round aftertaste that stuck around just long enough.  Siiiiick.  My wife's soy cappuccino, while not the best I've ever had, was still excellent and the soy was brought to more or less the perfect temperature without a hint of scalding.  I'm thoroughly impressed so far...

Second, I also ordered a cup of the Yirgacheff Biloya, a new favorite Ethiopian varietal, and through a snafu of communication the barista thought I had ordered a bag.  When we sorted it out, i happily took my very fairly priced bag, and the barista slid my a cup of their pressed Guatemalan Antigua Pompeya on the house, which was also exceptional.  Furthermore, as I was waiting for my espresso (which was also on the house, I assume because I purchased the bag of Biloya), I was eyeballing the homemade apricot doughnuts in the case and as luck would have it, one was passed my way across the counter.  These guys are cool.  I should probably mention that we were in there around 10 minutes to closing, so Im sure they dont go around handing out freebies, but damn, talk about right place at the right time.  

Long story short, aside from Sightglass, Four Barrel is my new go-to in San Francisco.  Im excited to go back and get a cup from the slow bar, and as luck would have it, I'll be back in the Bay tomorrow to pull at Planet Granite, so...
author: Adam B.

description: I wanted to give Four Barrel Five Stars but they only have Whole Milk and ummm well... how do you make a NON FAT latte with Whole Milk?!?!?! Answer: You Don't! My latte was still delicious - I sucked it up and had whole milk since we had waited to try this place. I may go with espresso or drip coffee next time to save myself the caloric intake of whole milk but this place is damn good stuff! Love the interior - didn't notice it being trendy or hipster - just a good mix of everyone. The scones are really good! My son had a butter croissant and enjoyed it just fine. Awesome spot to grab a cup of joe! The slow bar line was a whole lot shorter than the main line. Bathroom smelled like a bathroom :( but was decked out almost as fun as the rest of the place.
author: Candace L.

description: Four Barrel is my favorite coffee spot in the city.  The soy latte is always consistent and delicious.  I love the public parklet right outside.  It's a great way to enjoy a latte and bacon maple donut on a sunny day, and awesome people watching to boot.
author: Wendy S.

description:
This coffee shop is awesome.
The macchiato (and everything else) is awesome.
The Dynamo donuts are awesome.
The hipsters are awesome.
author: Glendon M.

description:
I've had some of the craziest adventures here...

They always start out the same.  I walk in. Sometimes I wait in line.  I order either a latte or cappuccino.  I like it with soy milk if you must know.  I wait for a few minutes and watch as he or she does 85 different coffee movements in 3 seconds.  For a minute it stresses me out, because it looks so complicated.  Then I sometimes wonder if they trained for 10+ years to know how to do that.  Ok, back on track, they call my name.  I pickup my drink.  Sometimes I drink it there, sometimes I get it to go.  I dig the atmosphere though, and the people are cool, so usually I like to drink it there.  So then if I am staying there, I sit down at one of the tables along the side of the place and enjoy my drink.

So now...the crazy adventures.  One time I spilled my drink and they were nice enough to make me a new one.  I felt like I had committed a crime after spilling my drink because of the great design artwork they had made in my latte.  I didn't sleep for weeks.  Another time I got a donut from there. I was shocked how good it was.  Just because it looked like the simplest of donuts.  Again, I didn't sleep for weeks.  Unrelated.  See, amazing adventures.  Told you.

I love Four Barrel Coffee.  The end.
author: John R.

description:
I have been turned around. After returning many times, I have seen a full baked good section (with some delights) and some really amazing coffee. Maybe my switch to black coffee has increased the value of Four Barrel to me.

Good sourced coffee is hard to come by. So I appreciate it when I find it.
author: Ben V.

description:
I have to say Four Barrel has become my favorite roaster in the city. This location is large with plenty of seating although it does get packed. I certainly don't recommend going here to study, especially during peak hours. It's best for meeting with a friend and having a conversation.

The gentleman who works at the coffee station is helpful (and adorable.)
As far as the espresso bar goes, best almond cappuccino I've ever had.

The only issue is that there are so many orders, you never know when yours is coming up. I think that they should take names, it would make things much easier for everyone.
author: Jamie M.

description: Great coffee but no wifi and dumb seating layout. Was given a pretentious spiel that I should consider "disconnecting" for a while... Sure that's why I come to a coffee shop, to drink coffee... I thought we all knew that the coffee was just the arkward way we purchased wifi and a comfy desk? ;-)
author: Liam G.

description: The hipster just oozes out of this place. Cool room. Espresso? Ranks 3 in city with the usual players. OK, not great. Better than starbucks and petes! We did have fun watching the crowd. The guy bagging coffee in the back was having way too much fun.
author: C. J.

description:
Love this place. It's everything a coffee house should be and more. Excellent coffee, few delicious sweets, and some crazy beer-ice-cream float... The smell, the design (you kinda have to see it), and location are perfect for a proper start to a Mission exploration.

The place: great location; uber-cool warehouse-looking space with crazy hog heads on the wall and a few pieces of equipment that look like they came from the set of Wild Wild West
The staff: cool and knowledgeable
The meal: pretty amazing coffee
The bottom line: i'm a fan
author: IkkI K.

description: It ain't for everyone and it sure ain't for me. Totally acidic coffee in an environment of utter pretension.
author: Andrew D.

description: What a spacious cafe!  Stopped by here for some iced coffee since it was a very warm day in the city.  Somehow, they ran out of iced coffee (really?  can you run out of such a thing?!) so they suggested an iced Americano instead.  It's espresso with hot water, but for me, I didn't care for it since it tasted like iced coffee that's been sitting out and diluted by all the melted ice.  Basically, a watered down coffee.  It's probably supposed to taste like that, but who would really enjoy that?  Probably best to have their hot drinks, like the drip coffee instead.
author: Erica S.

description: They stopped French pressing their coffee, used to be a huge fanatic, not digging the new large filter brew. BRING Back French press!
author: Allen S.

description: Still the best in the city, and the current art installation is brilliant.
author: J S.

description:
It was such a weird day for us in terms of clean dining experience standards.  Following the hair incident at the brunch place today, my husband suggested we grab some coffee from Four Barrel on our way to the cell phone place.  I have been in Four Barrel before and loved the latte I had there (and I'm not a coffee drinker).  I was looking forward to trying something new and expanding my coffee horizons because I have been rather jet lagged lately.  Standing in line at the slow drip coffee place, the lady is helping a gal in line before us.  The gal hands the worker a $5 bill and needs change.  The lady worker, proceeds to hand her a dollar and some change back and she is very pleasant.  Yet, pleasantries or not, what transpires next is just plain gross.  This friendly worker with her cute vintage-y dress and in her pleasant way asks Mike for his order.  He tells her and she proceeds to immediately grab one of the conical filters and uses her hands to open the filter, spread it open by placing her fingers all along the inside, and drops it in place to filter the coffee.  She notices me watching her but she probably just thinks I'm curious about the way this all works or something but all I can think is Abort Abort Abort!!!!!

My husband, too preoccupied with whatever doesn't seem to flinch as this transpires.  Turning to me, he asks her on my behalf which coffee is the least acidic and as they discuss this amongst themselves, I'm not paying one lick of attention to them.  He turns to me and says, "Do you want to try blank..."  And, all I can say is..."You know, I don't think I want any coffee anymore..."...."You sure, you said you were craving some...," he asks....."Hahah, Ah, yeah, I'm sure...but thanks.., " is all I can say.

As my husband is handed his fresh cup of coffee, I tell him what happened and he just laughs....."Oh, and tells me I'm weird for noticing."  Being the guy that he is, his standards are just not on par with mine and he proceeds to drink his coffee...the whole time offering me a a sip, lol.  How many times has that lady made coffee in that manner, reusing the same coffee beakers and handling cash and touching the greasy computer screen and keys....without washing her hands?!?!?!  I mean, there is a sink right there at that station less than three steps from her!  That place is always busy, too!  Look, I know this kind of stuff happens in food establishments all over the world every day all day (not that it makes it acceptable)...yet, seeing it first hand the minute before I am to order is another thing altogether.  It's food handling 101, people!  I just couldn't do it...It puts a whole new meaning to the term "handmade".  Uck.
author: D. J.

description:
(reviewing from my partner's account)

Met a friend here mid-afternoon on a Thursday. Waited for a solid 15 minutes to order my Guatemalan blend drip. Prices are reasonable and the coffee is great. Grabbed a seat at a strangely large/thick table against the side wall. BTW, this wasn't an easy task - I think it's pretty reasonable to assume this place is always crowded. 

On par with the 2 other progressive coffee cults in the Bay: Ritual/Blue Bottle -- these are all places where you can get coffee that doesn't really taste like coffee. aka coffee sans acidity. Anyone else think of Breaking Bad? Anyway, it's nice if that's what you're going for. I like it, but won't go out of my way for it unless for an occasion like a meet up. 

Ambiance is typically SF - reclaimed wood, macbook pros, angsty baristas. You know?
author: Eugene M.

description: Love love love their coffee! The batistas are always very friendly, and the coffee tastes consistently good.  It only takes a sip of their coffee to make me smile.
author: H K.

description: My favorite cup of coffee in the city.  Get ready to stand in line, but realize you'll be sipping the best coffee in San Francisco in no time.
author: Rich S.

description:
Don't think I give this compliment out easily.  I am vicious on yelp.  If your place sucks, I don't hesitate to rip you a second asshole.  

However.....  here goes......

Best Coffee In San Francisco
author: Christopher F.

description:
This is an amazing coffeeshop! I met up with a family friend here in the Mission. Their coffee was really, really good. I also had a croissant, which was crispy and freshly baked.

My friend described it as a place where "all the hipsters come and record their deep thoughts into their journals." Ironically, that's exactly what I did after my friend left. The decor is perfect - it's beautiful inside... even the bathroom is amazing. They even had fresh lilies in there.

I would love to come back and just people watch here. It's quite the atmosphere!
author: Joyce H.

description:
#hellahipster

Lets just talk real quick about how you can actually surpass hipster...and move to hellahipster...

1. have the most amazing bike parking, turning the usual hub bub of mission bikes into an art piece of brightly colored vintage bikes hanging on mate steel..beautiful

2. speak softly...and don't ever move to fast....the loft ambiance with its was soft colors, beautiful wood and great contrast...it feels like a different planet and brings out the soft speaking side of people. It is nice to sit and read when people aren't shouting and ordering loudly.

3. Not sure about the pig heads....but they are def hellahipster

4. the coffee will make your mind spin, i know you are going to want to stay for a second cup, but get a decaf...you will fall off the very slim legged stools

5. the staff is so freakin' cute

when people come to the mission...take them here and go...this is the mission and it's #hellahipster
author: Patrick D.

description:
"social sustainability", "direct-trade"...great quality of coffee beans here...old fashioned roasting: roast on a hulking beast of a vintage german roaster--one that was made to hold consistent heat & let air flow thru simple ways controlled by a person.

The baristas always make my coffee really good and strong...Great for an early morning pick me up.....
I love the interior design of the cafe...tables for people to share, meet new people, hang out, and socialize.....

so if you are looking to work on hw or projects, this is not the coffee shop to do it in......there are no wi-fi or plugs here....

one of my favorite valencia coffee spots ever!!!!
author: Rae R.

description:
Good coffee at unpretentious prices!

$2 for a cup is absolutely unheard of nowadays, but you can find it here.

A for effort!  I watched the barrista make conversation with every person he served.

My pistachio blackberry croissant definitely kicked up the bill, but I was happy to pay the $4 something for it because it was REALLY GOOD.

Love the spacious parklet outside with copious amounts of space for bicycles.  Not to many cars during the day, so you're not breathing in too much CO2, and the noise level is low.

No power outlets means you actually see people talking to one another.  Only spotted one laptop.  Probably not the best location for a group of over 4 unless you stand up in the parklet outside.

Lovely for people watching, especially if hipster is your flavor!!!!
author: Michelle L.

description:
Don't you think it is time to launch yet another Four Barrel? Obviously you have conquered the market as the place is always filled in your wifi-less store, lines out the door and spilling into your parklet. There are many more pockets of the Mission to cover so that hipsters can walk less and pay $17+ for a small bag of coffee beans. 

C'mon Four Barrel. You openly mock your competitors and then shame negative Yelp reviewers on Twitter AND play awesome loud music on vinyl. We can find your delicious coffee in many fine restaurants, you give away coffee for free on your birthday and make us walk long distances to stand in line, then stand in line again and then hunt for limited seating. How could one not love the experience? Time to expand my friends. Your contrarian approach has won us all over so why not open more locations?
author: Dave B.

description: Yes.. still 5 starts and still my preferred coffe shop in San Francisco !!!!! You can have your perfect espresso now with a great Dynamo doughnut and sit outside in the sun!!!
author: Gianguido G.

description: My friend and I got a latte and a capp and they were both substarbucks quality. The milk was not prominent in either drink, big bubbles in the capp and watery bottom. Maybe new barista?  I'll give it another try because I've heard great things.
author: Elizabeth R.

description: My friend Charlie kept talking about this place and how great it was so my date took me here to try it out. I love the atmosphere of this place, you could totally just chill here all day and people watch while drinking your coffee. I ordered the ice coffee and tried my date had the mocha. The coffee was perfect because usually it's bitter but it had the right amount of bitterness and boldness to the coffee, I would definitely return.
author: Matthew L.

description:
I'm sorry, but I have to say that i honestly don't get it. What is the deal with all these local hipster micro-roasters? Since when is coffee not supposed to taste like coffee and be served luke-warm? 4 bucks for a cup of joe?
I guess that you gotta pay for those $150 skinny jeans somehow, right?

I'd been a fan of blue bottle for a while (although they're also falling out of favor with me), but i kept hearing about this place so i decided to give it a try. sure, the place itself looks great and the staff are very nice, but at the end of the day it's the coffee that makes the difference between a good cafe and a bad one.

The scene is definitely too cool for school, but whatever, I can deal with that (I love school, btw), but the coffee was $4 dollars and tasted like someone filtered lukewarm water through an ashtray (no joke!). I'm sorry, but tobacco should not be one of the 'notes' you taste when you drink coffee. My husbands espresso was so sour (yep, you heard me right, SOUR!) that he couldn't even drink it.

In short, this place is great for people watching, but terrible for coffee
author: Danielle J.

description: I am giving four barrel coffee two stars because I was there last week and the latte that I order tasted like water and my wife ordered a mocha and it was god awful terrible. Four barrel used to be really good when I first started going there but the quality has gone down a lot so we went across the bay to Berkeley to the cafe med which is the best coffee shop in the entire bay area, but as long as there are yuppies four barrel will always survive
author: Tom P.

description:
This place is great. The only thing they're missing are couches.
The coffee is some of the best I've had. The pastries are good but pricey. Knock a dollar off the pastries and I'd probably buy 2. The guy in the blue shirt was nice and cute! I was there for Outside Lands, so unfortunately, I only went there twice. I'll be back next time.
author: Stella H.

description:
Best coffee in SF. I know, this is a bold and probably controversial statement. I've only lived here for a few months now, but i have learned quickly how much San Franciscans love their coffee, and i am proud to be amongst those ranks. 

I've done blue bottle, I've done Brown Owl, I've done Pete's, Starbucks, Coffee Bean, and more; but i always find I go back to one place. The store sporting heads of boar?

Sorry for that, i just felt it... However, back to reviewing. It's trendy, It's Indie, It's Hipster chic. It's intimidating on first visit honestly, but man-oh-man the coffee. Its all basics here. No frappe-chinos, or other non-sensical, confectionary nightmares. The beans are roasted in house by people who care more about coffee than I have about anything in my entire life. All their beans are personally chosen by the roasters from private coffee growers and personally roasted in small batches to peak perfection. Their in store selection is quite impressive. I recommend taking a 1/2 pound home with you. Its a bit pricey, but its well worth every cup. 

The baristas do the artful pours with their milk and the free pitchers of water are nice. The drip coffee is just as good, but it can take a while to get one. The best thing about this place. besides the beans is their music. All music is hand selected from an extensive vinyl collection- very cool.
author: Chad B.

description: The almond milk latte was delicious - maybe the best latte I've ever had. And the chocolate croissant was amazing and not overwhelming at all. Great way to start a Saturday morning!
author: Abbie K.

description: Coffee is good, but everything is unnecessarily overpriced and not worth your money. Also, no WIFI and no power outlets! Seriously?
author: Daniel D.

description:
We stumbled upon this awesome coffee shop in the Mission our last day in SF.  It was chilly walking around, so the lure of a nice place to sit and a warm cup of coffee were too great to pass up.  Thankfully we were inside when the flash hail storm hit and we saw people rushing into the place to get dry and warm.  

I love the architecture of the building.  It's a big open space with lots of wood and metal making it feel like a coffee barn.  The register area opened up to the double espresso machines which were neat retro pieces.  Then you got your grinding stations and regular drip coffee going on all in one open space.  

Then, there was the back roasting area.  They actually roast their own coffee?!?! Awesome!  

Anyway, the vibe was chill and it was a nice way to spend our last afternoon in SF.  

P.S props for the old skool stero system, I haven't seen a place play LPs in a looooong time.
author: Jaemie D.

description: There's always a line, but the place is very cool, and they have amazing pastries which is always a dilemma for me!
author: Carole P.

description:
MISSION--The grandest of the Mission's many hipster coffeehouses, Four Barrel has been the catalyst for the subject block's remarkable transformation in the last year or two and now is the north Mission's cultural anchor in a way that former torchbearer seedy Zeitgeist never really was.

Four Barrel roasts its own on the premises and they make a damn fine cup of coffee. Apparently, many people feel it's worth a special trip as the number of bicycles outside spills over into the street so much so that the city has recently converted the curb-side parking to benches and bike parking.

This all-day parade of alt-lifestyle folks make for continuous eyecandy. The compact space seems to promote the rubbing of elbows and community building.

The staff here don't engage in the tiresome hipper than thou attitude you'll find at some of their competitors. The backdrop of the establishment is a large roaster with humongous bags of beans piled around it, and on a shelf within reach of the baristas is an even more original functional conversation piece--a hi-fi system replete with turntable and a collection of vinyl (not so) rarities. In between pulling shots, the staff keep the place jumping as they rotate discs that lean toward the dated-to-the-point-of-being-hip-again end of the dial. Coffee over Black Sabbath and the Bay City Rollers never sounded so good.
author: JayBee L.

description:
Let me set the scene:

Outside, you pass by dudes holding coffee cups, chatting near a bench/bike rack (presumably talking some hipster talk and..insert bike talk). You walk inside and.....taxidermy?? There are few tables where people are quietly reading and sipping coffee. There are two counters, one I have no clue about and the other for ordering your coffee. And finally, a big machine in the back, which is probably related to the art of making coffee ----------- It is a very interesting place. 

Now in terms of the coffee: YUM. It is strong but good; a really good way to start your day, midday, evening, or whatever.
author: Lily Z.

description: Great atmosphere. The classes they offer to the public are extremely informative and helpful. The coffee is excellent. The line can be long at times, but it's is definitely worth the wait.
author: Britton C.

description:
Hipster haven meets coffee central?  Indeed.

From the moment you drive by and notice all the ruckus that's outside and plenty of heads standing in line, you know theres something good about this place.  It's a living coffeeshop/roastery/cafe.  It's the got the engines and machinery in the back to populate the air with the tantalizing aroma of coffee beans, and baristas going at it to give you that nicely pressed and brewed espresso.  And at times and times again, the scenery changes, not just on the outside with the nice bike racks and friendly seating to soak up the sun under a garden like fixture overhead.  At times the place can be as loud and crackn as a bar or club, and at other times it may quiet down to just the background music playing while individuals read their book or study their academics.  

But a lot of what makes this place is in the living atmosphere of the roastery itself, the people, and of course the coffee and espresso drinks, which are like the driving lifeblood to the place.  With decent prices and a warm setting, I was able to catch up on my reading for 2 hours situated at the front window enjoying the whole experience.  

Four Barrels, you've got to be perhaps my favorite coffee spot in the city at this moment.
author: Vincent K.

description: If you like thin acidic coffee this place is for you. I've given this place many chances and just don't get the hype. I drink coffee black and their coffee makes me have to add sugar. If you have to add to coffee just be a Starbucks
author: David W.

description:
Sure, the coffee is delicious. But did you know their hot chocolate is perfection? 
Dark, sweet, and not too obnoxiously rich. 

Particularly JJ's. Tal's is super, but JJ's  hot chocolate is divine.
author: Anamarie P.

description:
4.5 stars.

This may well be the best coffee roaster in San Francisco. The Friendo Blendo espresso is my all-time favorite, and it's stellar in this shop. French press cups for $3 won't ever disappoint, either.

The single origin pourover/espresso bar (to the left as you walk in) is awesome, and often oddly uncrowded. Coffee might run you $1.50 more, but you choose what you try. It used to be that I'd recommend this option without reservation, but now I don't think it's worth it. Four Barrel switched from using Hario V-60 to Beehouse style drippers at the single-origin bar, and I think the coffee quality has suffered because of it. (Hence the docking of a half-star.)

Four Barrel used to make the best coffee I could find, but now it's easier (and better) to buy the beans and make it in my kitchen.

Lovely parklet outside.
author: Justin M.

description: Ordered a cappuccino here (my standard drink I always order in all coffee shops to compare) and my girlfriend got a cup of drip, which was a Latin American coffee, I believe. My cap was delicious and sweet with perfectly foamed milk. Her drip, on the other hand, was way too acidic without enough body to balance the acidity. Latin American coffees are usually more acidic in general, but this one was waaay too tangy. I loved the blend they used for my espresso, did not like her drip at all. So skip the drip, but four stars for the espresso, which was almost up there with Stumptown and Sightglass.
author: Kel S.

description:
Absolutely not worth the wait out the door and on to the sidewalk.
Plus, they only have whole milk or soy.
Finding a seat there is impossible because it is jam packed full of hipsters updating their Tumblr accounts all day.

I used to love this place, but it has become so much of a hassle, that it is not even worth the trip anymore.
author: Brett P.

description:
This review is coming from the viewpoint of a girl in search of a coffeeshop to study in.  That means I'm looking for: deskspace, lighting, distractions, coffee, convenience, etc.  That's why I'm not giving it a 4 or 5 star rating.

That being said, I'm also not a hipster, which may color my opinion a little bit.

Why?  Bcos Four Barrel Coffee is HIPSTER CENTRAL.  My jeans were ashamed at how loose and roomy they were, and I felt a sudden urge to get a tattoo, adopt a dog, and attack my hair with a pair of blunt scissors.

Anyway, in terms of studying: it's really crowded, the seats are uncomfortable, and the table space is tiny.  There's always a huge line, so getting coffee, refills, etc., is difficult.  The coffee isn't bad, though.  

This would be a good place to hang out and people watch (oh BOY, was I people watching while I probably should have been studying-- oops :D).  Not so much a place for studying.
author: Jeanne Y.

description: UM_ what's the hype? The coffee was good. ok. not great. But it's cool. super hip. the bike parking/ re-po'd street parking is cool. bathroom's also. I thought the scone I had was pretty boring. maybe that is effecting me.
author: Judith M.

description: Great coffee, awesome environment, but baristas are super slow. Make sure you have plenty of time when visiting this cafe.
author: Justin C.

description: I have never had such a great ice coffee and mocha..  We had to wait in line for good amount of time but it was worth it.. I can't wait to go back.. Everyone there was friendly and their coffee is to die for.. Well done!!
author: Seda M.

description:
I have heard tons and tons about how awesome Four Barrel coffee is, I just had to try it for myself. This place is exceptional all around!

I love the vibe! Lots of bike racks, tons of hipsters, dual barista's, epic setup, and the roaster in the back. Its all there. These guys definitely look busy, pulling back to back spro on the regs. Also, mad props for spinning vinyl, really adds to the feel of the place.

Awesome coffee! All that generic high end coffee crap applied. Well trained barista's, seasonal micro lot coffee roasted on a probat.

This place has everything a high end coffee establishment is expected to have. I am becoming tired of the homology between roasters in SF, but you can't knock them for a successful business moto.

Good coffee, good atmosphere, good job!
author: John S.

description:
DO : if you want to have some damn fine coffee
DON'T : if you want wifi for your ipad, iphone, or iwhatever.

This place is for drinking coffee and sharing some time with friends. Its simple. It works.
author: nick n.

description: Excellent, fresh roasted coffee.  Friendly staff, great atmosphere.  These guys really know coffee and care about what they're doing.  Superb!
author: Karen U.

description:
Definitely a solid 2.5 stars, but I wouldn't round up.

After passing by here more than a handful of time, I finally came in to experience 4 barrel.  It's alright.  The employees here are pretty nice and I love the experience, which is why they got the 2 stars.  It's like they are demoing roasting all day, pretty cool, the seating isn't really up to par, with the tables too high from the bench, it's kind of hard to study, it's more of a conversational place.  

The coffee::hmmmm, not sold.  Everytime I try out a new place, I judge the drip, 4 barrel for some reason taste watered down, like they took the espresso machine, used one portafiler and filled up a jug and sold it as drip. Gross.  I don't know, I can't explain it. It's just not the cup of coffee I would enjoy.

Sorry 4 Barrel, maybe next time.
author: Edrian D.

description:
One of my biggest regrets in life - other than not figuring out that whole Middle East thing - was not taking the time to try the much-revered Stumptown Coffee up in Portland. I was there for an extended weekender a year ago and heard much of this praise after my trip as a you-shoulda-gone comment from people who regale in letting me live in regret about such ignorance. The bitches. 

So imagine my pleasure in finding out that they serve Stumptown coffee at Four Barrel on a Mistral, at least in the short term. The coffee is French-pressed and the quality shows. Nice and rich. I was living my own Folger's commercial. And such a big, mellow space on the quieter stretch of Valencia approaching Market.

There are dark wood beams, black granite counters, and smooth concrete floors that give it the necessary industrial, anti-homespun look for this part of town. They'll eventually serve their own coffee, I imagine. I think I'll try it. 

COFFEE - 4.5 stars...Stumptown lives up to its reputation...we'll see about their own brew 
AMBIANCE - 4 stars....wide-open and surprisingly low-key for a Saturday night 
SERVICE - 4 stars...OK, not particularly friendly 
TOTAL - 4 stars...another nice caffeine option on Valencia
author: Ed U.

description:
Creative space, with separate counters for pour overs and espresso drinks.  Plenty of tables, though they're usually all filled.  They're roasting beans out back, which is fun.  There's almost always a line, but it moves quick (couple of minutes).

The espresso was on the acidic side, and they fall in the almond-milk-only camp, but I still enjoyed my latte.  The iced mocha was the real winner - and I usually can't stand mochas!  They use good quality shavings (or imperfectly melted chocolate, maybe Dandelion?), so it has a bit of texture to it.
author: E O.

description:
I walked in here and the first thing I saw was two La Marzocco three group professional espresso machines lined up side by side like the two  halves of a Chevy Small Block V-6 engine.

Ok. 

Wandering further into the back half of the shop, I see rows of bags of green coffee beans stacked up against the wall, a massive German gas-fired Probat Professional coffee roaster, a big old grinder (was that a Kony?), and in the back what looked like maybe a sample roaster.

Respect.

Basically, exactly what I would want if I were going to open up a coffee shop.  SO, I guess they are serious about it.  I didn't want to stand around TOO much and single myself out as a coffee geek, so after drooling a bit over the 58 mm triple group on the La Marzocco, with the guy behind the counter looking a bit puzzled and politely waiting for my order, I asked for a double cappuccino. 

I told the barista that I was trying to learn how to make latte art, and she very kindly gave me a few tips on how to pour a heart shape, which she proceeded to do in a matter of seconds while not really looking at the cup.  Of course, it was perfect. A nice rich ristretto shot and sweet, sweet whole milk.

Oh, yeah.

They were very friendly, had great barista skills, and freshly roasted coffee.  Can you ask for more?

Well, there is more!  

Even better, there are not TOO many chairs and a distinct paucity of AC outlets, ensuring that there will NOT be a herd of laptop wielding twenty-somethings staking out the place all day long like hobos in an espresso shanty town. Yay!  And the prices are reasonable.  No more expensive than Starbuck's, only your mouth doesn't pucker up from the incredible bitterness of the super-auto crap espresso they serve there, and you don't have to vomit afterwards.

Woot!
author: Adrian B.

description: Valencia is one of my favorite locations to visit while in SF. Is the reason leaning toward urban boutiques and galleries or four barrel coffee?  I choose the latter. The coffee really just sets the foundation to a great day and trip in SF. Although busy, I've been fortunate to not need to wait for a place to sit. I find it unbelievably entertaining to watch the cupper roast their beans. He eyes them every few seconds- I can feel the love and warmth he puts into this harvest. Again, highly recommend.
author: Joseph N.

description:
This location is super spacious, they could easily put some more seating in here, but I do like the minimalist vibe they are going for. I especially love seeing the old school vinyl and turntable behind the coffee bar...music just just sounds much better the old school way. 

They have great iced coffee, very strong,smooth, but not for wimps.
author: Maria M.

description:
Dear Mister Four Barrel,

Congratulations on being one of the best coffees in the world.
It is quite the honor. But...with greatness comes a lot of expectations.
I heard in the new Avengers movie you have a cameo to lay a subplot for a part three where you save the world. I believe it. 
I saw a picture of Obama walking up the backside of his place nestling a bag of Four Barrel coffee. That is pretty cool. 
Breezy should take their BEST logo and put it with a Four Barrel Coffee mug. 
Sucks that the Taliban declared Jihad on you for being better than Allah but so it goes with the territory. I think they are just misguided. A lot of us were young punks growing up. When they get older and drink some of your coffee. They will understand. They will. 
If Finn from adventure time drank coffee; he would drink Four Barrel and Lady Rainicorn would also. And the world would be a better place for it. We would have Four Barrel Coffee rainbows all over the place. 
I had a good weekend this past one. Real good. Would have been better with Four Barrel, tho. It would have been better. You make everyday better. Can't wait to have those everyday better days with Four Barrel Coffee.

Anyways...
See ya soon,
Rossi
author: Rossi H.

description:
I was about to tell them their cream had gone bad, but I tried my friend's black coffee to double-check and it wasn't the cream.  Their coffee tastes like soured pea soup.  Without exaggeration, the worst tasting cup of coffee I've ever had in my life, including the powdered nescafe you're served in India.  Bummer, because it's a cool place to hang out.
Admittedly, I have only tried their basic coffee, and only twice, and it wasn't that bad the first time (but not that good either).  But a friend had the same sour-pea experience on another day so it wasn't just a one-time mistake.
Amazing that such a sophisticated-looking cafe would do so much damage to a simple cup of coffee.  Maybe they're trying too hard.
Back to Philz and Blue Bottle for me.
 
*update*
I originally gave 1 star but am upping it to 3 as that was excessively harsh. I've come to realize the sour-pea-soup-tasting coffee is an aesthetic choice a number of roasters are now making (like Ritual) that I just personally don't care for. I wouldn't 1-star a good winery for their Rose just because I don't like Rose. These folks are friendly and they know what they're doing when it comes to making coffee. I just wish they made coffee I liked.
author: Kaleem K.

description:
This was probably the only time I could walk into any establishment after camping (no shower, smelling of camp fire) and felt 'OK' doing so.

~yes that was my jab at the hipster crowd~

Seriously, I needed coffee before going home to shower and not only was my coffee amazing, but the pastry that accompanied it was also quite good (a ham and cheese poptart). Cool oozes out of this cafe, and not because of the patrons but the coffee really is top notch!
author: Hilda Z.

description: A great coffee place, though this place gets really crowded. They should add more tables...they seem to have the space for it.
author: Margaret R.

description:
The espresso drinks are spot-on. They choose only to use whole or soy milk because of the texture of the milk will complement the espresso the best. Not the best scenario for someone who can't really drink whole milk, but since I dislike soy milk, I had no choice but to go with whole milk.

Yes, the latte was perfectly crafted and smooth down to the very last sip. The lingering after-taste was so pleasant that it was worth it for my extra few trips to the bathroom that afternoon. 

The things I do for good coffee...
author: Lynn C.

description:
Met up with an old co-worker here before grabbing brunch.  Thought the atmosphere and vibe of Four Barrel was great.  I really liked the table setups and open space.

I decided to get a cafe latte even though I normally don't really drink coffee in the US.  Call me an elitist, but nothing compares to a good 'ol café con leche from Spain.  Really not sure what people find so good about this coffee.  It is so diluted.
author: Christopher W.

description:
Fantastic coffee - both made in-house or for buying beans to go.  The line can sometimes be long, but it moves fast.  or just pay $2 extra for a specially-made fresh cup of coffee, made with fancy filter machinery.
The pastries are amazing - they now carry B Patisserie pastries, except they don't advertise the supplier and I don't think enough people know.  These French (Breton) pastries are fantastic!
Seating is a total gem.
Plenty of street parking thanks to parking meters!
author: Michael S.

description:
Tried a cup at Spork and it was solid.  Not sure which blend it was speaking in general terms of what I prefer,  this blend didn't have any unique character or  the depth, finish and overall balance of what I consider good coffee.  Just my opinion although I'm sure it may have tasted better at Four Barrel which is located several doors down across the street.

I'm also not the biggest fan of Blue Bottle either as Ritual does it for me out of all the cult coffee brands in the city.
author: Shiho F.

description: No trip to San Francisco is complete without a visit to four barrel (daily) while visiting....hands down my favorite brew up north as there's several delicious competitors in the city that are good but not as moving to my tastebuds. The decor is very cool as there's wooden patio seating (with plenty of racks for cyclists ) in the front of the shop and within where you can observe the bean to brew process in the back. Adorable and styley regulars which make for great fashion observations as well. I got my photo snapped by refinery 29 when leaving once so this must be a fashion induced stomping ground of sorts given the cute boutiques on Valencia adjacent to it as well.
author: Michelle P.

description: What a good place to start sf trip. I ordered a regular drip coffee and i have to say "Woohoo! As good as it gets!" according to yelp rating system. It got all the right elements of a solid coffee. It was bold, nice aroma, little bit of bright acidity, and mostly complex in flavor. I would love to try their espresso drinks next time.
author: Hyuk K.

description:
I went Coffee shop hopping today. I'm new to the area & really wanted to see what the coffee culture is like here in the bay area & wanted to try the best coffee from each source. This was definitely in my top two.

Coffee plays a huge factor in how i rate a coffee shoppe, but the customer service has to be just right, or else it'll leave a bad taste in my mouth no matter what. Today was great! My buddy grant was working the slow bar, we ordered an Ethiopian pour over & also a El Salvador, & we also got one of their single origin espressos. It  was all great! coffee was fantastic, customer service was fantastic, location fantastic, all the things!

i will be back for sure....
author: Joshua D.
