Would recommend giving it a try and judge for yourself.
author: Dave N.

description: I really liked! They have very good coffee! And the pastries are so yummy. The cheesecake pumpkin muffin is awesome! Soooo good! Loved it! The staff is young and friendly. There's also outside seating. Dogs are allowed inside (even big ones). The bathroom floor mural is amazing:) And I liked the interior! It's one of San Fran's many unique coffee places!
author: Katja J.

description: Absolutely my favorite coffee place in the city. Great atmosphere. Amazing coffee. Friendly staff. It's my second home.
author: Derek P.

description:
Four Barrel has donated $500 worth of coffee to my daughter's elementary school over the past year.  Parents have commented on how deliciously awesome the coffee is and even became Four Barrel patrons because of it.  

We thank Four Barrel for its continued support of the community and keeping us public school parents caffeinated. You rock!
author: Denise I.

description:
I love the aesthetic and the atmosphere of Four Barrel--chatty yet calm, and quiet but without a dozen people on laptops. The staff is always warm and attentive and the seem to enjoy being there as much as the patrons. 
Unfortunately, I've always found their coffee to be unimpressive and even sub-par--usually watery and/or greasy.
author: stephanie l.

description: The wafting smell of coffee lured me in, along with the fabulously hipster vibe. The iced coffee was simple and satisfying; I would definitely return.
author: Meghan B.

description:
best coffee in the City and the employees are awesome.
great tunes in the background...what else do you need?
length of line can be a little downer but not enough to keep me from going when I am in the neighborhood. Well worth it.
author: Scott Y.

description: Just a few blocks away from Ritual Roasters, Four Barrel is yet another coffee gem in San Francisco. While they have much in common with Ritual (roasting their own beans, properly trained baristas, correctly steamed milk with perfectly executed latte art) they are in some ways the opposite of Ritual. Four Barrel does not have wifi, they are cash-only and the ambiance is much less modern.
author: Fouzi H.

description:
After writing our names on the Mission Beach Cafe waiting list, we had about an hour to kill before we got seated. We hopped over to Four Barrel Coffee for a cappuccino and in about a minute we got our drinks.

This was the best cappuccino I have ever nommed. Smooth, almost chocolaty. There was a perfect leaf in the froth and the aroma was awesome.

They roast their own beans for Christ's sake...

Truly outstanding, will go again.
author: Anders N.

description: hands down the best almond latte in town! it's a headache to get a seat on the weekends though
author: JinJin ..

description:
It's been almost 2 years now, I still live around the corner, and try to patronize Four Barrel as often as I can. Times have been tight, but I can scrape up a few dollars for a wonderfully brewed coffee.

A few things...
1. They're still on a cash system. Will this change? I'm not sure, but come in knowing this beforehand. Although I wish they'd accept cards, as I'd be more apt to treat friends, buy beans or stuff my face with one more pastry.

2. People need to stop complaining about the lack of tea. Come on! I've never been to a tea place (Samovar, for example), and heard someone complain about their lack of coffee. This is a coffee place folks... not the Wal-Mart of cafes. The fact they actually focus on one thing is admirable.

3. If you order the iced coffee and you need some oomph, get it with an extra shot. Better yet, try a quad iced Americano in a 16oz cup/glass packed with ice, and just a splash of cold water. That'll curl your hair!

4. Yes, they only have organic cane sugar, soy milk, and half-and-half on the condiment offerings. That's fine. No matter how much you Splenda/Equal/artificial sweetener folks complain, you really need to quit that junk, or go to some other place that'll mainline it to you. I feel for your livers.

5. The baristas have almost always been friendly, to the point, get the job done, etc... Some of them won't stroke your ego, which can be interpreted as snobby. I beg to differ, but to each his own. Although there's one barista, with the tie, who is so upbeat, and on top of it, he just makes my day. I always look forward to him --his eyes sparkle. And lastly, I have a crush on the new girl's thighs. I feel criminal just watching her pull those espressos. I'll say no more!
author: Antoi C.

description: Best coffee I've tried in the city  (Blue Bottle included).  Friendly barristers don't have typical sullen demeanor.  Cookies also good, the only bit I didn't love was the Guinness and pear doughnut - but maybe that was just me.  Great indoor space and outdoor street seating as well.
author: M M.

description: Really super cool looking coffee place! They were very busy, and very fast and efficient about taking orders, and preparing drinks.  The staff was friendly.  I really loved the decor of this coffee place... one of the nicest I've been in, and I've been to a lot.  My chai was wonderful!  It is definitely a happening place, and if I lived closer, I'd be frequenting it a lot!
author: Tina I.

description:
This coffee is super sour.  That should not happen. One should not have to pour sugar and cream on coffee, but it works for desert.  If I wanted desert I would go to starbucks.
And don't hipsters know that they all look alike?  These are the kids who when teens wanted to be oh so individual.  they are literal clones.  My 9 year old stepson asked if "those glasses were their uniform?"  Sigh, the diversity of San Francisco has been reduced to the colors on plaid shirts.  Will someone behind the bar please break the mold?!
author: Sakura F.

description: nothing bad to say about four barrel. if there are constantly crowds of people then obviously they're doing something right!  one of my favorite places to grab some coffee when i am in the mission dist.
author: Donald G.

description:
On my coworker's recommendation I came to try the coffee here.  Walking in the first thing you'll notice is the decor.  It's pretty awesome.  They've got animal heads and large wooden tables.  Out in front the lights are these giant rope things with light embedded in them.  Over in the back they're actually roasting the beans.  Oh yea in the bathroom they use powdered soap!

They make your drinks to order and have snacks and actual food you can order as well.  The snacks seemed to mostly lean towards the savory side.  They also have an affogato using ice cream from Humphry Slocombe.

I decided to tried the ham and cheese pop tart and a latte.  The server was really nice  and as promised the coffee was excellent.

The tart was pretty good too.  I wish it woulda been toasted a bit tho.  I also tried the asiago and pepper puff thing.  I liked the moist inside (kinda like a pâte à choux).

It looks like a lotta people hang out here with their laptops.  If you want to do the same you'll prollie have to stake out a seat cause it was standing room only when I went in the afternoon.  If I happen to be in the area I'll drop by again for sure.
author: David K.

description:
Today was the first time I visited Four Barrel and I was pleasantly surprised. A coffee aficionado friend recommended I try Four Barrel in Mission area and I was a bit skeptical thinking that it's just another hipster elitist joint where they would sneer at me for adding sugar to my coffee (I'm looking at you Barefoot!) or other such Coffee crimes, but nope, this place ended up being just excellent!

I was told to expect a very nice interior decor, but I wasn't ready for the awesome open space and beautiful surroundings (hell, even the people looked purty!). 

I ordered a breve latte (cafe latte with half & half milk) and it was just perfect. I was able to pickup free wifi from a nearby location (SF-something or the other) and appreciated that I could sit at the window bar and keep an eye on my bike.
author: Chubby K.

description: Very hipster. No electrical sockets?! GREAT COFFEE, but baristas take their time... My dry breve cappuccino was perfect :) My friend's cafe au lait was spot on as well.
author: Alex F.

description:
Unfortunately, in my opinion the coffee here has changed. I have completely stopped coming here. The last 3 americanos I've had were extremely acidic and watered down, made me angry.

Staff is still super nice!
author: Kara S.

description:
Four Barrel. What can I say that hasn't already been said? 

Four Barrel is one of those hipster coffee shops in the Mission, albeit a larger space than one would expect. Upon first walking in, you could tell that it has a very organic feel, surely a great place to grab a cup of coffee to-go or just catch up with friends. Four Barrel consistently serves up great coffee AND Dynamo Donuts to go along. 

There's also seating in the back if you want to watch coffee beans getting roasted while sipping on your coffee and goodies. 

I definitely stop by whenever I'm in the area. And even though I'm nowhere near as hip, I never feel out of place here.
author: Elaine T.

description:
After a few more visits, I've decided it's not quite as big as it seems, as there really isn't all that much seating.

Also, they've only mostly figured out how to specify the orders for the shot pullers.  Currently, they seem to be using some form of post-it-note method, which seems rather more wasteful than just writing the order on the cup (for to go orders).  Still, you'd think this would work.  Not so much.  At least one person's order has been wrong every single time I've been there.  I'm rather stunned by this - you'd think getting orders correct would be a rather essential part of doing business and not losing money.

Anyway, it is good coffee as long as you like it strong like an ox.  Or the Hulk.  Or Superman.  Or something else that's strong.  And the 2 espresso machines means you never have to wait long, which is a pretty damn big plus.
author: Don H.

description:
I visit this place every time before I drive 2 hours home after visiting friends in the city. It's great because they seem to be the least dark hipster (definition: douchey trend snob, latest band hipster. Also a hipster that likes drinking coffee at night), coffee-like-piss cafe in the mission district. I love the mission district. Anyways, the coffee is fuckin' GOOD. Everything is a double shot, which is why a mocha is gonna ding you 4 bucks. But here's the thing I love about this place so much:

1) good coffee drinks
2) Not so intimidating baristas. Plus, right?
3)Great atmosphere. 
4)Super roomy
5)They put fresh flowers in the john daily. Makes me feel like a princess.

Now go fill up on some mochas, and pretend it's just black coffee in that cup whilst you drag your Parliaments the night away, my dark hipster babies YOU KNOW I LOVVVE YOUUUU
author: Niku S.

description: Four Barrel has a tasty iced coffee, but in the time I waited in line I probably could have walked to Philz and downed a Mint Mojito iced coffee. Still, if you're looking for a good place to work or chill, the open warehouse layout is pretty awesome and reminds me a lot of Intelligentsia Coffee in Venice.
author: Nick S.

description: Really nice space but the coffee is for hardcore drinkers only. Really earthy and bitter. It's like squeezing the superconcentrated grind juice from the coffee filter into your cup. (I tried their iced coffee, black coffee, and cappuchino, and this is true for all of them.)
author: Rachel Y.

description:
I've been here a few times now. I didn't find any rudeness from the staff. Just don't expect them to engage you in conversation about anything other than coffee. 

As for the coffee itself, I will rate it in three categories:

1) Expresso drinks are incredible! I love their cappucino. It's smooth and naturally sweet. I normally add sugar and found it unnecessary.

2) The house coffee is bizarre. It's a kenyan bean that is sour tasting instead of bitter. I expect that it is likely something you either love or hate (I hated it).

3) There is "one cup at a time" coffee station, although its not always manned. This is a much better option than the house coffee, since you can choose from 6 kinds of beans, and the staff is more than willing to talk about the taste of each variety. I had a coffee that was delicate, crisp, and complex.
author: Philip S.

description: I love love the way this place looks - it's so cozy and it looks like it would be a great place to chill or study. The Kouign Amann (Queen A-mahn, not cone amen like I stupidly though, learn from my failures!) was good, but it tasted like one of the typical Chinese pastries I've had before. It's pretty much a bread pastry coated with a layer of sugar. I think the main negative for me is that the cashier we had at the time seemed to be zoned out the whole time. It seemed like it would take her an extra beat to process what we said, which would normally be a little questionable but not a big deal, but when my friend picked up her coffee and some of it spilled on her arm/sleeve and the counter, instead of offering any words or napkins, the cashier continued to stare blankly at us. Hopefully that was an one-off experience - I would still come back.
author: Melody L.

description: The place is beautiful and the atmosphere is great. Unfortunately the coffee was really horrible.
author: Omri E.

description:
Best coffee we had in San Francisco (double espresso and double short latte). The only confusing part was I asked for a triple tall latte and they couldn't accommodate the third shot, although the person working the cash machine tried really hard to find a way to accommodate it, it was too much of a hassle. Being from Seattle having as many shots as I would like, this was very strange. The atmosphere was great, I loved the parklet outside sitting area. The only thing.. come on give me my extra shot, is that too hard coffee elitists? If you are an instant Folgers drinker, this is not the place for you, your whole months worth of coffee costs more than a double espresso. 
All in all, I would say the taste of my coffee was fantastic and would go back in a heartbeat for the whole experience the place has to offer.
author: Tasha O.

description:
As a company, I respect Four Barrel's mission and values, from their respectable sourcing practices to their meticulous craftsmanship of each individual cup of coffee, latte, cappuccino, etc. They've built a beautiful cafe further down Valencia street, helping to revitalize the area. 

Yes, it gets busy. 
Yes, it attracts hipsters. 
Yes, their coffee is damn good.
author: Regina A.

description: A Mazing!  Truly fantastic coffee!  Stopped in when I found myself in the neighborhood-Valencia St is way more cooler than when we lived here!  They have two serving areas: general drip coffee & food & a barista area for chemix, etc. I had a medium blend Central American cup and was wowed. My barista was friendly and knowledgable and I left thrilled!
author: daniel m.

description:
Dynamo Donuts a plus. Whole (and soy) milk only, a minus.

The place is better decorated than Ritual Roasters (cool boar heads on the wall) and has a good amount of seating.
author: Anton S.

description:
Very nice coffee shop with delicious coffee. 

A little surprised they don't offer wi-fi, however.
author: C R.

description: Four Barrel is my favorite coffee in SF. Besides the good beans, other pluses include a cool parklet, neat decor, and good people watching.
author: Nels A.

description:
I once had a friend, entirely well-adjusted, who had one trigger for severe panic attack: taxidermy.

We traveled to China one summer, and i'd act as scout before entering a night club, a "western-style" restaurant. Its not that there is more taxidermy in Asia, but that its context is in selling Americana. Lets just say, we missed a couple karoke bars keeping her nervous system on the even. And that's ok, another rendition of the Jets "lets hear it for the boy" is probably not what the world needs.

Anyway, it may seem i digress, reviewing a coffee shop, in San Francisco no less. But I tell ya, i'm about to pull it together. You see, Four Barrel makes an exceptional coffee. The drip, the espresso pulled, its all reeeaaalll nice, and this is coming from primarily a serious tea drinker (i could go back to discussing China here, but i won't ;). That said, the decor is mission-hip, lofty, industrial. But the downside: mega taxidermy. Its not that i've adapted her distress, but rather feel its excessive, assaulting even, with coffee is so darn stellar, to also jar ones senses with bullish gaze of a hairy animal head. I'll take mine to-go, but that's ok, i needed to practice my karoke at home anyway...
author: Rachel S.

description:
My friend and I ordered our coffees and while looking for a place to sit down, we put our drinks on the side counter. The gal behind the counter curtly told us: "We're having a tasting here." 
That's fine with me but how about a "pardon me, please or thanks"? We ARE paying customers after all.
There are a few Mission coffee shops like this one, staffed by surly film students. I give 'em all a chance but never return if I'm treated rudely.

Coffee shops where the service IS always friendly include: Progressive Grounds, Phils, L's Cafe and Dynamo.
author: Hank A.

description:
The coffee is so very yummy 
The staff is pretty alrighty
The interior is sparse & lovely
The scene is undeniably mishy
4=4 
for me

(ps:  vegan treats would be appreciated)
author: Dizzy L.

description:
Four Barrel is no Philz in my opinion but it's definitely a close second. The coffee here is delicious and STRONG; it's not for wussy coffee drinkers, that's for sure. I ordered the cappuccino and it was so rich I had to request a latte instead which, BTW, they were great about and didn't charge me the extra $.50. 

Things I'd like to see here in the future: 

1) More seating - this is a really large building and when you walk in there's a lot of space that isn't utilized. I think they could have been a lot more efficient with how they designed things. 

2) More food - They only have one small pastry case and most of it is just donuts and croissants. They were delicious but it's rare that when I go and get coffee on the weekends that I don't get food too and I like to see a little more variety.

3) Cash only...really? It's time to step in to the 21st century.

That's all.
author: Julia N.

description: Fuck it. I have to say, the coffee is worth 5-stars. I had a delicious cuppa French Press this morning and it MADE MY MORNING. Seriously... this is worth traveling to the Mission for.
author: Don B.

description:
I am obsessed with this place for the moment because of their delicious soy latte!  Think of it as artisan coffee where each person takes great care in creating the right coffee for you.  

The cookies are good, I had their oatmeal chocolate chip cookie and can't stop thinking about them.  One thing, studying here may or may not be the best place considering the noise level but the lack of cell phone reception makes up for it!
author: Carmen C.

description: Great coffee spot. (No outlets to plug in computers though)
author: Sarah M.

description:
Happy 2nd birthday, 4 Barrel!
And way to go, throwing yourself an all-inclusive party.  I loved you before, but now love you more...

I never particularly thought of this place as family-friendly, but mostly b/c I'd only been with friends.  Having pony rides, a photo booth, cake from Tartine, and free steamers (oh, yeah and coffee!) for children of all ages and those who accompany them in honor of your big day won me over most thoroughly.  We'll be back, and  now sometimes with the little guys in tow...
author: Laura K.

description: I am only provide a review of the ice coffee and it is a bit too sour for my taste but lots of people seems to like it the day I was there. The place is just one of a kind and what a great hangout for friends or visitors from out of state. Be aware that the drip coffee stand closes at 6 and probably if I had a chance to try the drip coffee instead of the ice ones i would have give it a better score. I am planning to go there again and would give an update when the time comes. Price wise their price is relatively higher than most good coffee places that I've been to. My tiny glass of ice coffee (about 6 ozs) cost me 2 dollars.
author: Wai C.

description: Some of the best coffee i have ever had. the attendant who prepared our coffee was very knowledgeable,  not to nice though. Looks like Mr. Arcade fire hair cut needs to get off his coffee pedestal.
author: AXEL A.

description: Not buying the hype. Ordered two different slow-brewed pourovers, but it was bland and unremarkable. I think she poured them too fast, since there was a bit of line forming. The atmosphere was busy and pleasant. The coffee just wasn't good.
author: Cory B.

description:
My favorite coffee place in the city!
Industrial environment, friendly service and great coffee.
MUST try the affogato.
author: Nadia M.

description: This is a review of the coffee beans, not the cafe or the espressos that are served by the cafe.  The coffee beans: they're great!  I picked up a 12-ounce bag of their Concepción Pixcaya at yesterday's Pop-Up General Store.  I've been making French press coffees with the beans today, and I really like what's in my cup!  This coffee is totally delicious; it's certainly on par with the Marcala Honduras coffee that I've gotten from Blue Bottle lately.  Thumbs up!
author: Kenneth R.

description: The hubby and I both had cappuccinos that were, in no comparison, way better than any Starbucks or Coffee Bean could ever create. The froth was spot on, not too much, just creamy enough to balance the slightly bitter taste of the espresso.
author: Luvinyaa C.

description:
This Saturday morning, my friends and I had a breakfast in the Mission in a nice quite Mexican restaurant called Los Yaquis. After, my friends and I decided to try Four Barrel Coffee a few blocks away because we have heard a good thing or two about Four Barrel.  It is a very spacious and hip coffee shop with cool and crafty decor inside.  I realized I was already in Hispterdam as soon as I stepped in. The prices are on a higher end of spectrum, yet, not so overpriced. There were four baristas and they are approachable and engaging. I did not get the sense that they are unfriendly despite some people in yelp have opined otherwise. I liked their very simplistic menu with fewer than 10 options. It seemed to communicate their confidence in the quality of their products. In the end, I ordered a cut of coffee and my friends from Italy had macchiato and espresso each. I have to say I was not particularly impressed with its coffee. I usually like rich flavorful dark coffee. At Four Barrel, its coffee was very acidic, not bitter but sour and not hot but lukewarm. Both of my friends also had similar impression of their drinks. In fact, half way through, I stopped drinking it all together.

On the flip side, what I particularly like about the place is that it was full of lively people conversing with each other.  Of course, there were some people in the corner trying to read or on their laptops. Since there is no wifi or outlet to charge computers, this place is not most suitable for studying.  

I would think that this place is a cool place to hang out with your friends to converse and socialize, as you are basically paying for the ambiance. We were wondering how this place came to attract such a crowd when, in the vicinity, there are cafes with better tasting coffee. I understand that people say "to each his own" but I am quite not sure how the hype came about. I guess it is like a group psychology where people buy into what others with similar taste are telling them. Hence, seemingly high concentration of white middle class SF crowd in their twenties and thirties. It certainly has its charm but nothing out of ordinary in my opinion. 

In terms of coffee, I would not recommend it at all. They roast their beans light to medium, leaving coffee to have unpleasant acidic aftertaste. Staff were generally very nice and courteous. One warning, though is that, If you are allergic to hipters, you might get an anaphylactic reaction.  

Overall, I would have to say "Meh.  I've experienced better."
But it was a valuable exotic and cultural experience, nonetheless.
author: fiona B.

description: Great shop.  I got a pour-over and bought a bag of coffee.  Barista at pour-over bar was super helpful, and directed me to a great coffee and a bag that better suits my taste.  I really like this shop.
author: Tom N.

description: After a mother-daughter date in the city, my mom and I came here based on a friend's recommendation and we were not disappointed.  We went at around 2:30 pm on a Friday and the place was packed and the smell and taste of the coffee was soooo good.  We stopped at the slow drip bar on the left where Kurt, an extremely attractive and articulate barista from Oakland, explained every detail of the drip process, every tool he used, etc.  I felt bad for all the customers in line behind us but he didn't seem anxious at all and it was so nice to have the whole process broken down for us - that never happens in cafes!  Ever!  He was even nice enough to charge my mom's phone behind the counter for a bit which is nice considering there are no plugs anywhere else in the building.  I'll definitely come back here next time I'm in the mission!
author: Michelle F.

description: When I walk in here I feel so out of place (Hipster central), but I LOVE what they have to offer. The pastries (which aren't too many) are really tasty. The coffee will cure any ailment you have (and this is coming form a non daily coffee drinker). Service has been hit or miss, but the product served has always been way above average.
author: Amelia M.

description:
Still my go to place for coffee in SF. Except now I always lean towards straight up black coffee. 

Love that they have French press as their regular to go coffee option. 

The side bar is pretty fantastic as well. Super friendly, knowledgeable service. I love watching them carefully measure out and prepare each cup. And picking their brains about how they make it if it's not too busy. They make the whole process seem like such an art form...
author: Monica C.

description:
Ordered a dbl espresso. very well made, sweet w/ thick crema-mmm.

Guy who took order was very friendly, and energetic without being too much. 

JJ (I think her name was) pulled the shot. she worked quickly, efficiently at bar and was very friendly, too. I liked it; I'll be back.
author: Mark M.

description:
These five stars are based on the coffee and staff alone.  The crowd that gathers here on the weekends isn't quite my scene so I get kinda intimidated...  but OMG the coffee is SO good!

I have been trying to go around to all of the new hot coffee joints over the past year, and this has been one of the best so far.  It's super basic- coffee, or an espresso drink.  I have had a soy latte and it was great, but come back for the coffee.

The staff so far has been so nice.  The first morning that I came in i didn't know that they only took cash, so the guy just said i could come back and pay him later! I have never had that happen to be before!

Keep up the good work!
author: Laura P.

description:
Let me make this quick and to the point:

Went into Sightglass Coffee right before 4BC and received a horribly weak Soy Cap. 

20 Mins later (around 12pm or so), I went to 4 Barrel an received the best soy cap ive had in a long while. Although they were super busy (line to the door) the barista chick nailed my drink. 
-will continue to go back when in the bay.
author: Franky G.

description: I don't understand the hype.  The drip was okay, nothing mindblowing.  Latte was ok too.  Might need to retry their fancier stuff.
author: Xue H.

description: I found this place while walking along Valencia. The cappuccino is about as perfect as you can imagine. Full flavored but not so bitter as to require sweetener. They do that cute thing with the foam, which to me is a signature of the barista's pride in her work. I took home a bag of Bolivian coffee called Typica & Caturra. The smell of it is intoxicating. The ambience is lively, rustic, industrial and modern. Friendly staff. Exterior street side seating is cool and feels part of yet separate from the busy street. Not far from the BART station at 16th and Mission, and a good spot to meet up with friends.
author: Presh C.

description:
Hooray for the next creation from Jeremy Tooker, one of the original Ritual Roasters founders.  Head for the back window on Caledonia for now...
Bring a pocketful of beef jerky to placate the pack of pit bulls that guard the half-block area around the entrance.  They hide under the cars and they respond best to teriyaki-flavored beef jerky.
author: sean s.

description: What a large coffee shop for the Mission!  The atmosphere is very cool and my latte was delicious.
author: Christy L.

description:
love the space and from what i hear/remember the coffee is amazing and strong

BUT.. they dont serve any tea!!! i hardly drink coffee and i love this spot. i understand that that they're good at what they do.. and they stick to what they're good at.. but... damn.. wish i could grab tea there when i meet w/donors/volunteers. 

it still looks amazing.. and i guess i can just smell the coffee :)
author: Art A.

description: Fanciest, tastiest coffee without being the most presumptuous or boastful. Unique outside area, great art, and an amazing energy to the place. A must see and taste!
author: Kira M.

description: Really good coffee and a nice atmosphere. Love the wooden ceiling!
author: Alberto T.

description:
Maybe if I tried to go here a bunch of times the review would average out to be higher. But I'll probably never know, because my first visit was not great.

It was a Saturday morning, and I wanted to go somewhere to write and get coffee and a pastry. I remember riding my bike by this coffee shop many times and it looked all clean and yuppy-ish, which is a compliment for coffee shops.

It certainly was clean and awesome-looking in the inside. BUUUUT there were no pastries. There were _spots_ for pastries, all labeled. But it was completely empty.

Someone in management screwed up. I'll stick with Modern Times Cafe and Ritual Roasters!
author: Stu M.

description: Fantastic selection of coffees. Prompt, helpful service. No pretension. Are you surrounded by hipsters? Sure, but everyone seems happy and well caffeinated. Will become an institution.
author: Paul S.

description:
They roast their beans at the back of their cafe. Very sexy.

This place could be a little loud sometimes, definitely not a study place. Despite that, I love the decor, music and quality of their coffee. Very bold, milk is perfectly froth, the pull is perfect. 

Perhaps my most visited places and I always go for their capp, although I heard that their Iced Coffee is pretty good too. Interesting drip coffee section/bar that's separated from the espresso machines.
author: Rika P.

description: Love me some Four Barrel. It's my neighborhood go to place. They really do have some of the best coffee I've ever tasted. The baristas are always super nice and never short of a smile. Even though there's typically a line to the door most mornings, it goes fast. Well worth the 5 minutes you may have to wait.
author: Eddie C.

description:
I share this poem from one of my favorite poets.  
  

A Miracle for Breakfast  

 At six o'clock we were waiting for coffee, 
waiting for coffee and the charitable crumb 
that was going to be served from a certain balcony 
--like kings of old, or like a miracle. 
It was still dark. One foot of the sun 
steadied itself on a long ripple in the river. 

The first ferry of the day had just crossed the river. 
It was so cold we hoped that the coffee 
would be very hot, seeing that the sun 
was not going to warm us; and that the crumb 
would be a loaf each, buttered, by a miracle. 
At seven a man stepped out on the balcony. 

He stood for a minute alone on the balcony 
looking over our heads toward the river. 
A servant handed him the makings of a miracle, 
consisting of one lone cup of coffee 
and one roll, which he proceeded to crumb, 
his head, so to speak, in the clouds--along with the sun. 

Was the man crazy? What under the sun 
was he trying to do, up there on his balcony! 
Each man received one rather hard crumb, 
which some flicked scornfully into the river, 
and, in a cup, one drop of the coffee. 
Some of us stood around, waiting for the miracle. 

I can tell what I saw next; it was not a miracle. 
A beautiful villa stood in the sun 
and from its doors came the smell of hot coffee. 
In front, a baroque white plaster balcony 
added by birds, who nest along the river, 
--I saw it with one eye close to the crumb-- 

and galleries and marble chambers. My crumb 
my mansion, made for me by a miracle, 
through ages, by insects, birds, and the river 
working the stone. Every day, in the sun, 
at breakfast time I sit on my balcony 
with my feet up, and drink gallons of coffee. 

We licked up the crumb and swallowed the coffee. 
A window across the river caught the sun 
as if the miracle were working, on the wrong balcony. 

___
 PS- This miraculous coffee caught me by surprise. Bright and Lively. Drank on a summer sandy beach or on a cold drizzling rainy night- its flavors embrace like a long missed friend.
author: Arissa C.

description: I am fan of their Latte. Never tried their drip coffee. I also buy their espresso beans which I use at home with my espresso grinder. All I can say that the outcome of my latte is very close to Four Barrels Lattes which means their beans and roasting is always consistent. I held back the star for the service speed and lack of Pistachio croissants. If you go anytime after 11 am, they are always out I would recommend increasing your purchasing par for that specific item to accommodate the late comers.
author: Shadi K.

description:
THEY DON'T HAVE NON FAT MILK!

Only whole milk & soy.  Not that I care, but for those of you that are watching your cholesterol, this might be a hindrance.

and it's cash only.
author: Josie M.

description: A quintessential local café with ample bicycle parking and seating. Wifi is saturated with personal hotspots.
author: Johnny F.

description: Sign says the coffee is $2 but it was only $1.  Seriously??  $1??  Amayjangg.  The place looks beautiful as well.  The bathroom even has a chandelier.  There are no outlets or wifi so you shouldn't come here to study but its great for having a nice chat w/ a friend.
author: Christine B.

description:
Best. Coffee. Anywhere.

To boot, they're all incredibly nice and willing to share brew tips. Tops.
author: brad m.

description:
Okay, I'm not going to make any more dramatic claims lke "BEST COFFEE IN THE CITY", but the percolations within this coffee experience have been my favorite in San Francisco thus far.  No ordinary baristas here.  These gals and guys are on a mission (not to be confused with THE Mission ...*drum kick*)

Sometimes it can be a challenge to find a toilette in the Mission.  Here at Four Barel, you can pee your pants over the fabulous coffee, or you can just use the clean, friendly bathroom in the back.
author: Jesse M.

description:
Trendy coffee shop for all the hipsters.  They have a espresso bar to the left once you walk in.  I guess it's for concocting new flavors or just to try out their beans.  I think they also roast their own beans because they have a big machine in the bag used for something dealing with coffee.

I've been here a couple times and i've has the mocha and ice coffee.  They use two shots for espresso drink that you order, but tastes nothing like it.  The espresso has a weird taste in my opinion and is very light; I"m use to  strong tasting espresso.
author: Cedric F.

description:
I think my chest has more hair because of Four Barrel.  

I actually *like* that there are no plugs and no wi-fi here.  It's so retro, having a coffee shop filled with people talking and reading rather than a bunch of eRefugees plugged in and glowing radioactively.
author: Ben A.

description: My husband & I just discovered this spot last Thursday. The ambiance and details are well layed out. I love the chandelier peaking through the bathroom window and the rope lighting up at the front windows! The steel rod bar area off of the side walk with a bike rack is a genius idea! The line was at the door when we arrived but the wait was not long at all! The cashier at the  time seemed to be very well liked by regulars. There was a lot of attention being given to the big roaster towards the back of the coffee shop, which I love that they roast there own coffee! Our experience was great! My latte was perfect & we both loved the banana chocolate scone. My husband tried their Mocha which he didn't wave to much about,  it was a bit tangy. My daughter got a chocolate rose donut which was okay! I need to try their drip coffee ASAP. definitely coming back.
author: Giselle G.

description:
Only two observations:

1) Is it really hard to smile and personable while pouring the hot water over the deliciously aromatic ground coffee that will be touching my soft lips in a matter of minutes?

2) Do POC (People of Color) not like coffee?  You wouldn't think so by the hired staff here. 

Overall, great tasting coffee... but I left wondering how an establishment in the Mission can be so non-representative of the neighborhood.  Oh wait... I guess Viking deities are becoming the majority.

If I do go back, it'll be with my brown posse in tow.  trust.
author: Sas C.

description: On first sight it is impressive - the metal  fixtures outside, the wooden plank seating, the industrial feel and the buzz from hipsters/wannabe's hovering around. Think intelligentsia clone. But leaves more to be desired. There is no wifi, the seats are cutesy but not comfortable, they're pumping super loud and unidentifiable music and worst of all the coffee is watery. The expresso missed the mark too
author: C R.

description: Super good iced coffee but I'm sure there are other stars to try. I don't know why I felt like I was on a music video set but I'm going back.
author: Matt Z.

description: Best coffee in San Francisco. I love the macchiatos, cold brew and the hot coffee. Sometimes the wait is steep, but it's worth it. It is in close competition with Ritual and Sightglass for best cup in town, but it edges them out with consistency and the readily available press pot coffee (the other places don't do that!)
author: David S.

description: AMAZING coffee. Great cafe, really chill and relaxed and not super crowded. Great selection of pastries and cakes. They roast the coffee there on site, and have lots of different bean types for sale. And they do flat whites!! I have lived in New Zealand for the last 10 years and after a month back in the states have still not found a really great coffee. Let alone a flat white. Not only did they know what a flat white was, but they did it just perfectly.
author: Jen H.

description:
3.5 stars. 

We heard some girl talking about this and needed a coffee fix as we are addicts so we went to check it out. 

The chairs were really uncomfortable, but I liked the ambience, though it had a very sparse feel and definitely wasn't someplace I could picture working in for hours at a time. 

Still, the coffee was good and you can see where they have all the beans. Friendly staff. Low-key.
author: Eva K.

description:
My rating is actually somewhere between a 3 and a 4.

GREAT coffee, fast service, pastries are more of accompaniments to the coffee and unfortunately I learned that the boring way. Nothing too crazy about them. Big space which is a nice changeup to the usual sf-this-used-to-be-part-of-another-building-but-now-its-a-unique-tiny-space-rawr cafes.
author: Jen N.

description:
I used to not be a coffee snob, but with all the really great cafés around San Francisco, I'm slowly but surely turning into one.    I blame Blue Bottle, Philz, and Four Barrel (all of which are quite different) for ruining me.   

I deliberately avoided Four Barrel for months, because it always struck me as a little TOO hip.  Walking by, I'd stare in at the masses of people, all of them hipper than me, and I figured I would feel like a completely unfashionable loser going in there.  

But eventually, I sucked it up and walked in.  Yes, the crowd is exactly what I thought it was, but it's worth braving them for the delicious coffee.   I've had a variety of espresso drinks, as well as straight-up coffee, and all of them were perfect.  

The décor is great - stark design with just enough warm elements to make it feel comfortable.   The boars' heads on the wall are a little weird, partially because they're boars' heads, and partially because the OCD part of me wants them to be arranged by size--smallest to largest, of course.   Okay, that's not really a complaint. Just a comment. :o)

Maybe this is a little nitpicky, but the only time I got a little irritated with the Four Barrel folks was when my husband ordered a coffee, and I ordered an Americano.  His was poured right away, while my order went into the long cue.   He ended up being nearly done with his coffee before I got my drink.
  
Pros:  Amazing coffee, cool atmosphere, nice baristas.  Did I mention AMAZING coffee?
Cons:   Long lines, not welcoming for the self-conscious & fashion-challenged, no comfy seats -- mostly just tables for two.
author: Jane A.

description:
Soy latte, 3 stars (I think I prefer Blue Bottle)
Lemon pistachio donut, 4 stars
Service, 4 stars
Bathroom, 0 stars

Love the feel and décor, but the noise level was a bit high for me--and I wasn't trying to study or read like many of the others there.
author: Ali A.

description: Cute, hip, and great coffee. Perfect place to catch up with anyone
author: Jayme N.

description:
(09 local SF mag)

This Anti-Starbucks is the kind of place Jesus would go to if he were alive-all carpentry paneling, oblong tables nailed to walls like craft class, recycled laminated beams (eco-friendly), pencil sketches of snow owls over dry board canvases; kinda like The Labyrinth meets The Wild Wild West. You'll see a huge industrial monster of a roaster in the back behind the counter guy who will serve you your liquid crack.
author: jana h.

description:
i met a friend there today for coffee and it was good - i wouldn't say amazing but some beans do taste amazing and some don't. they do not have wi-fi but all of the tables are taken anyway. also there regular coffee, not the pour over is $2 which is the normal price in this town for good coffee. i was reading the other reviews and they talk of ultra hipsters? i just don't get it, is that a night time thing. today there were all kinds of people - no one seemed especially different or tre' hip. 

so some guy walks in while i'm telling my friend about the uber hipster reviews and he starts right in on our conversation and says yeah - you're an ultra hipster (i'm wearing shorts and a pocket t), he's wearing RED courdoroys, a red vest and a Huggy Bear hat (white guy) very very slender. So I says - yeah man you too. Then he gets upset w/ me calling me names and telling me he's 45 yrs old and is a Native (which means don't mess w/ me, but I can say whatever I want). 

So I asked him if he was an American Indian?
author: Rew C.

description:
Fell in love with my cup of joe at Bakery Tartine, so I asked them what it was....something from FourBarrel.  Off I went on a quest to find those beans.  When I arrived, they mentioned that Tartine had recently picked up some Sulawesi Sumatran, which I happily purchased.  As for this place, I certainly don't fit in...

Was thrilled to discover their beans at Rainbow, where I now obtain them.
author: John K.

description: I love Four Barrel! This place is amazing. They have roasters on site. The baristas are real crafts-people. They do not just push a button and over drawn crappy espresso comes out. They create delicious masterpieces.  As a coffee nerd, I highly recommend this place. The espresso drinks are creamy, smooth and flavorful. The shots are never overdrawn or left to sit and get sour. This place is awesome if you really love coffee. Next time I go, I have to remember to get a few pounds of the beans. I want this at home too! As far as the location, the mission is a great place to explore if you are visiting SF. So go check it out and stop in here. You will not regret it!
author: Betsy R.

description:
Okay, I like coffee a lot. But I el oh vee ee Four Barrels. 

The staff are ALL nice. How often does that happen in The Mission?

I love the location (next to my gym...Valencia St. Muscle and Fitness) and easy to get to on a bike (or BART). And I love the space. The tables are these behemoth chunks of rough polished wood that don't rock or move at all...which is so nice. Huge windows and a nice open space with a few cozy spots. 

I also love the coffee here. Prices are good and who can argue with $1 refills? But let me tell you about their decaf. Decaf, you say? Yes, their decaf is heavenly. I usually opt for the decaf americano and it does not disappoint, ever. It's like a cup of creamy smooth goodness. It's kind of like drinking a cup of dark, dark caramel. 

Did I mention they don't have Internet?  Thank you! It fosters an environment where people actally talk to one another instead of basking in the glow of their iBook. 

It can look hectic on weekends but the wait is never long.  I prefer weekdays to have a casual cup of joe or informal meeting, though.
author: John G.

description:
I am totally not cool enough to come here, but yes,.the coffee is so delicious that I will wait in that line....totally bringing down the level of coolness in the joint. The artisan coffee beverages are worth it.

+ Nick gets 4 stars for giving killer high-fives and generally being awesome.
+ The space is fantastic and level of attention to detail is painfully wonderful (see chandelier in bathroom, retro soymilk packaging)
+ I want those little bartender-style glass/pitcher rinsers in my house.
+ Bug-man is a regular. Sometimes he wears his SpongeBob towel cape. Enough said.
author: Lindsay M.

description:
I have been here a few times and each time it has been packed and bustlin' creating a lively environment.  I really love the layout and the decor and I can imagine spending hours here just relaxing with a good book and a delicious cup of coffee.

Each visit I have only been able to spend minutes at a time but each time the coffee has been consistently excellent.  The lines were long but the baristas were pumping out the drinks quickly.  Four Barrel is definitely a haven for people obsessed with finding top quality coffee and drinks.

My only criticism is their lack of seats.  The tables they do have are really cool because they are built into the wall.  Maybe they don't want too many people lingering but they have such a large amount of floor space that could hold at least a few more tables. Other than that minor issue, great place.
author: sergio a.

description: They have a tasty smooth latte and great pastries. I had a pistachio blueberry croissant that was super tasty :)
author: Tina F.

description:
My lovely sister, a decade+ Mission-dweller, recently mentioned this new SF coffee spot to me. So last week on a typical foggy SF summer morning we decided to be adventurous and check the place out. The coffee itself was great - not too acidic but still with enough character to keep me entertained. My one complaint would be that there was no skim milk option so when the cafe is fully up and running I hope the milk offerings expand. The chairs in the ally were also a nice touch - there is something really nice about being able to sit and enjoy a cup of coffee in one spot before running off about our busy days. 

Oh and one final comment - with so many Mission coffeeshops full of people squatting hour after hour, I'd love to see Four Barrels take a different approach and create a culture that encourages patrons to use the place as a spot for coffee with friends rather than as a full-time library.
author: Erin W.

description: There is a reason why the line is consistently out the door here.  The coffee is exceptional and the baristas know their craft damned well.  My friend and I were able to claim a coveted wooden booth by the wall and savored our cappuccinos.  The espresso was strong with light floral hints without a note of acidity and bitterness.  I was transported back to my days in Italy, where I drank two cappuccino cups a day.  Of course, the little leaf coffee topper enhances the experiences a tad.  The ambiance of this place is also fun - rustic and woodsy.  In addition to the mounted animal heads on the wall, booths that look like tree stumps, and forest lined wall paper in the bathroom, there is a huge roaster contraption that takes up half of the space.  Good thing the rest of the space also includes plenty of indoor and outdoor patio seating.
author: Pauline L.

description: Coffee that's stylish and pricey, to go with that $1000/month luxury 6'x10' cell in a Mission flat you share with 20 others.
author: Kate H.

description: I had a latte, it was really good! The atmosphere was nice, i loved the decorations. The baristas were nice and seemed knowledgable. There weren't that many places to sit inside because it was busy, but there were some benches and stools right outside looking out onto the street!
author: Megan S.

description: Good coffee? Yes. Best I ever had? Not quite. I ordered a cappuccino with nonfat milk. They were out of nonfat so instead I opted for the soymilk which made my drink $3.75. It was very good, however, I have had better (i.e Temple Coffee). If you decide to go on a Saturday afternoon, prepare to stand in line. A very long line. Though it didn't take more than 10 minutes, still be warned. In addition to the long line, there was no place either inside or outside to sit. Every spot was occupied. I would say Four Barrel is definitely worth a visit, but not on Saturday.
author: Kim S.

description: This place is a hipster haven!  That being said, they have boar's heads and ridiculously creamy espresso.  Maybe those hipsters have it all figured out....
author: Sally L.

description:
I swear to god, when I read reviews for this place that take stars off for not having sweetener or soy milk or skim milk or tea it makes me want to shoot blood out my eyes.

This place has coffee.  It's tasty coffee.  Just because it doesn't have all the crap that high maintenance tit-bags who hold up the queue at every other coffee shop in the city have, doesn't make it inferior.

The fact that I don't have to listen to some asshole order a non fat half caf extra hot extra wet chocochino with six pumps of light vanilla syrup - in my world - is a plus. 

Also, the staff are always nice and they work pretty fast for an up-its-own-arse hipster cafe.
author: David K.

description: Absolutely delicious coffee! Very beautifully made cafe lattes as well. They turn making coffee into an art. It's busy and kind of loud. Though you can sit out front and enjoy the fresh air and do some people watching. They always have some interesting baked goods. Try the mushroom tarts! I will definitely be back for more!
author: Alexia M.

description: I think this is the coffee shop where cool hipsters go to drink coffee when they die.  It's one of the cool places nestled in the Mission along Valencia.  Even before you walk in, you'll see hipsters drinking coffee on sturdy wooden stand-tables outside.  Walk in and you are in a large workshop-like space, high ceilings, open space, cool wooden furnishings.  Again, sturdy, well-spaced.  Generally crowded.  You hear music playing on vinyl records, and to one side, various coffee making machinery, and on a wall, even set of buckheads.  It all adds up to wonderfully orchestrated mix of hip elements making for a great coffee drinking experience.  Yes, granted it's not the classic Northwest coffee drinking environment that includes quaint and quiet reading space, but hey, I mean, these guys got the magic right!
author: David K.

description:
Wow, talk about great amazing coffee! The last time I had coffee thsi yummy was in Europe. Although I am not a regular coffee drinker_ just for the taste of it_ this is the real thing! I ran all my errands for the next 2 weeks in a day and I am still going, wow!
If you ever need a lightning jolt or just the taste of great coffee, you must come to Four Barrels! A definite 5+ stars!
author: Melanie S.

description: Love the parklet with bike spaces and general vibe, but found the coffee sadly a bit on the bitter side...
author: Michelle P.

description:
This is the only coffee place that makes me think _I'm_ the crazy one.  The coffee is so tasteeeeyyyy, I can't be productive drinking their coffee because at each sip my brain actually interrupts what I was in the middle of doing to wonder.  Hey--wow.  Really?  This is good!

The coffee actually brings me delight and I love how the foam from the French press forms around the rim, and then I notice how uncomfortable I am because my butt hurts from perching forward on these wimpy metal chairs with no padding because I'm a wuss and like to be warm.  And to be warm, I can't be in San Francisco in a place that offers metal on top of concrete to get settled on.  My theory is that they don't actually want people to get comfortable.  It's like an art gallery where you don't intend for people to to sit down, you want them to be drawn through the--oh, does this coffee really taste the way I think it just tasted?  Wow!

WHY do people like the decor so much?  I feel as if the irony of taxidermy is completely missed if it's real.  It LOOKS cold.  And it's hard to get a seat but there's so much room!  Why not more seating?  It's so uncozy and there's something about---hey!, wow, yum!  Have you tasted this coffee?
author: Y W.

description: I had a good Americano, and was blown away with the speed that the large line was serviced in a friendly and professional manner. I was so impressed that I grabbed my coffee and pulled out my phone to take a quick video of the process. It was then that the dishwashing girl got all agro on me and copped an attitude. I was not being some voyeur stalking your shop, I was just getting footage to post as a compliment. You are now officially the capital "C" in Four Barrel Coffee. Do not flatter yourself. I am sorry for your coworkers. It ruined what was magic Saturday morning with friends.
author: Ezekiel D.

description:
For about 3 months I've been staring at the phrase "You have 1 unfinished review" at the top of my profile. For some reason, I've just never been inspired to finish the review. Still not.

So here are my notes. 

nice people, kind of snooty about only using whole milk, major hipster crowd and staff, back half is all bean roasting, dude what do your earlobes look like when you pull those Flintstone wheels out of 'em, plenty of space to chill, I wonder how I'd look in those skinny jeans, insanely fresh and flavorful cappuccino with impressive foam art, damn that tatted barista chick is hot.
author: Jay Z.

description: cheaper coffee, nice modern industrial minimalist interior...fun place in the mission to meet at. professional, but hipster.
author: Denise C.

description: Two coffee stations, just wanted a cup of coffee so went to the station straight in from the door.    Frankly not impressed, I make a better cup at home.  Coffee that day on the weak side..truly a place to see and be seen, cool atmosphere.  Pastries a winner.
author: Jeff R.

description: I'm a total espresso snob, and I'm not afraid to admit it. That said, Four Barrel Rocks. Friendly baristas who know their stuff. The cappuccinos were quite perfect, and the beans we brought home are fabulous. We tried a number of shops in SF, from Philz to Blue Bottle to Sightglass, and this was our favorite. We'll definitely return on each trip to SF.
author: Jamie S.

description: I went there today for the first time and I was so stoked to see that they had skeeball! Skeeball is making a comeback at it was rad to see that four barrel had a machine that I could throw a few lanes on while I drank coffee.
author: Captain J.

description:
Sure, Blue Bottle is nice and Philz is also very good but this is quite simply the best coffee I have ever had in my life, by a LONG SHOT.

Strangely enough my first exposure to Four Barrel was not in SF but in a great little coffee joint called Red Rock down in Mountain View.  Their coffee has always been excellent but starting in January this year I noticed that they were brewing lots of new stuff and it was all noticeably even more delicious than before.  I asked the barista what was up and he informed me that they are now serving Four Barrel exclusively.

Of course I'd heard great things about this coffee on Yelp and elsewhere but I thought it was very cool that my first exposure to it was essentially a "blind" test, for me it just confirms the fact that Four Barrel really is a cut above the rest and that my taste for it was not merely due to any pre-conceived notions brought about by all the rave reviews.

The only drawback is that they've practically spoiled me for anything else!

PS- Contrary to popular opinion I think it's great that these guys don't feel the need to cater to the lap-top crowd, it's a really gutsy "old-school" move and besides, there are plenty of other places for those people to go.
author: Mike J.

description:
I have mixed feelings about Four Barrel.

Pros:
1. The coffee is good and carefully made.
2. The decor is homey, comfortable and suits the location.
3. The record player is a nice throwback, and it's great seeing the stacks of records behind the counter.

Cons (and these are biggies for me):
1. No wi-fi or power outlets (Is it too much to plug in my low-battery-life computer and do a little writing while I sip my latte? After all, what good is mind stimulating coffee and urban space if I can't use it to get something on the page, or screen?). (Minus 1.5 stars).
2. The record player (I like the kitsch factor, but ultimately it is inefficient when a record side ends every 15 minutes and the ambiance is ruined by the ensuing minutes of silence until the barista has time to flip it over. Not to mention it also creates a back-up in drink creation). (Minus .5 star).

All-in-all, I'd stop by for a coffee, but wouldn't plan to spend any extended time at Four Barrel (Which might be their entire intent).
author: Z. M.

description:
Best coffee, and most importantly, best mocha in town. I've been hooked on Four Barrel mocha for years by now and it's always, consistently been great. One thing I learned through that is that ground (Tcho) chocolate is really so much better than what other places use (syrup). You don't want your mocha any other way.

Not too forget, place and team. I love the spot (though it doesn't lend itself to working very much--volume), and the team of baristas is fantastic. As I moved I'll miss them, and of course the mochas, dearly.
author: Jens M.

description:
Wonderful vibe here, where the staff plays records and is helpful in answering your coffee related questions.
Lots of seating. 
Huge coffee machine/time travel device to investigate in the back area.
Coffee is smooth, strong, and flavorful. 
There is a painting of a woodland scene on the floor of the bathroom.
author: Addyline L.

description: My second favorite coffee place in the city. The place has a simple menu, talented staff and fabulous coffee.
author: Alex H.

description: I like that the regular coffee is under $3... I remember paying $3 if not more for a cup of Ritual coffee a while back... Their Blackberry Pistachio croissant is soooooooooooo DEE-licious~! This pastry is 5-stars! It's not inexpensive, but I'd rather pay a little more for something really good than to pay half the price for some warehouse brand pastry...
author: K M.

description: I've been to many different coffee roasters and shops throughout San Francisco, and Four Barrel is by far the best. Their Colombian roast for the pour over coffee was very flavorful, bold, smooth and airy. And if you don't want poor over they also brew coffee via french press. Their bostock pastry is incredible, its dense, moist and beautifully crafted. Everything i have had here has been outstanding from espresso to the pour over, from the bostock to the croissant. It also has a very comforting cabin-like interior that makes this place so warm and different from other coffee shops. And they have a turntable behind the counter where they play all their music in vinyl (just another reason why this place is so great!). This is THE best coffee shop/roasters I have been to in SF and the Bay Area. If you love coffee, then this is the best possible place to experience it.
author: Eric S.

description: Best coffee/espresso drinks I have ever had in my life. Visit here every time I come to San Francisco.
author: Krista S.

description: One of the best in the city!  Service has always been good.  They have a little side bar for drip only which is nice if the main line is really long.  The people working at that bar know everything about all of the coffees and want to tell you about them if you are interested.
author: McKenzie M.

description: Really nice look inside. They have a bike parklet! Sweet.
author: Justine L.

description:
Believe the hype. 

The coffee here is transcendent and (along with Philz and Blue Bottle) is one of the Holy Trinity of Bay Area Coffee.
author: Kendall D.

description:
Using my experiences with Blue Bottle as a comparison in this hipster coffee area...

I have a big hate on Blue Bottle. I do like Four Barrel quite a bit!

Unlike BB, 4B has a staff with some personality and smiles, the coffee has really impressed me as being superior, and he space is great to hang out in. Oh, and they have Donuts! Fuck yeah!

A couple weekends ago I dropped my GF off at work in the morning and before heading back to Alameda to sleep the rest of the Saturday morning away I decided to grab some food and coffee... but where? where?...

Four Barrel was easy to park near and was close to the freeway entrance, so cool. Standing in line I had a few minutes to consider the strong display of current mission hipster cliches surrounding me. Fixie bikes, massive beards, chicks wearing all 256 colors in one outfit... I was truly impressed at the point-perfect hipster specimens. I wasn't hating on them, it was too early in the morning for that, but I was well amused. I though, "how cute, these little sheep, these slaves to the current trends. They must be so happy to think they are on some 'next shit' individuality, when really they are all copies of the same master hipster." I thought to myself, I'm glad I don't bow to every cool new thing I see or hear about, that I don't have to buy a new pair of shoes each season or throw out the music I listened to last year.

So then it was my time to step up to the counter. I ordered my two donuts and a coffee and slapped down my $8. I then sat down at a table and, still amused by the trendies, I pulled out my iPhone, and was surprised to have caught a strong 3G signal from AT&T. I brought up the Facebook app and updated my status...
author: Jesse C.

description: Four Barrel roasts and brews really great coffee, and makes top-notch espresso drinks too.  It's usually very busy, but somehow the baristas keep track of who gets what in the chaos.  The atmosphere and the clientele are almost too cool for school, but that makes for some delightful people-watching, even if you look a little out of place while doing it.
author: Dan W.

description:
Great Latte.  Really.  One of the best I've had.  No flavored syrup or sugar... just a plain Latte and it was just right.

Free WiFi, lots of eye candy, great location, and great coffee.

Downsides:  
No plugs (That I could find)
Chairs were pretty uncomfortable.  You basically have to sit up perfectly straight, but my legs are too long, so I was constantly shifting my position.  The bar stools in the window are the same design, but your legs can hang lower so I was much more comfortable.

I'll be back here.  I've added it to the regular rotation.
author: Kevin O.

description: This place is fuckin cool! I'm almost too lame and or old to be in here. But I still love the energy: taxidermy, coffee roasting, the whole cafe setting. Only one negative thing: It's full of hipters and apple laptops (which is the cafe setting for any cool place in the Mission). Poop. Oh well. Ohhh I almost forgot! One of the best bathrooms everrr.
author: Amy W.

description:
4.5 stars for their espresso drinks (mocha could have been a tad hotter but still expertly prepared); 5 stars for decor and vibe

I took a $16 cab to grab a cup of coffee here. The whole ride I kept praying that it was worth it. The line was to the door, but I was just happy to squeeze inside to get out of the rain. Whoever designed the space has great taste and logic. Love that they put the ordering counter so far from the entrance and left that vast space open. If they hadn't, the place would be a nightmare with the long lines of people that go there for their amazing coffee. Love the wooden bench seating on the side. The line was prob 20-people deep, but it went shockingly fast. I had my mocha in hand in under 10m and my FI had his coffee in 1m. They only have whole milk here, so it's worth cheating on the diet a bit. They use a nice bittersweet chocolate powder for the mocha (which you will probably have to sweeten a bit more yourself to bring out the choco flavor and distinguish it from the bitterness of the coffee). You could taste the deep richness of the roasted beans and the bitter chocolate. I'm a fan of bitter and sweet, so I loved their mocha. FI said that their coffee was a bit watery, but he likes his coffees super strong-like Vietnamese coffee strong. Enjoyable nonetheless. 

Love their banana chocolate chip scone. Lordie! Where do they get them from?!? So good. The rest of the pastry case looked just as delicious. I would be here daily if I lived in the neighborhood.
author: Catherine N.

description:
The coffee here is outstanding.  If you are looking for a sweet weak prissy drink that barely tastes like espresso (a la Starbucks), this is not the place for you.  If you are looking for espresso based drinks made the proper way, and with freakin good beans at that, then this is Your Coffee Shop.  Sure, it's hipstery, but whatever.  Hipsters can't be blamed for their recognition of a righteous brew.  Also, I must note that the staff is super friendly.  Always smiles with the service.

Oh, and they have Dynamo Donuts.  Yum.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
New Years Eve in the city. Gorgeous weather. Time to kill. Easy parking. Wish we had fed the meter more quarters so we could have hung out longer. Even my 9 month old was having a blast people watching and banging my coffee cup lid on the table.

We will be doing this family outing again - SOON! Maybe later in the day next time so we can slink into Little Star for an early dinner or take out before heading back over to the East Bay.
author: Tracy A.

description: I really like their space, and their use of the space. Their coffee was good, but there's a number of good coffee places in SF/Oakland so that alone doesn't make it stand out. Friend order a pour over and had a really good discussion about coffee with the barista. He seemed passionate and knowledgeable about the coffee. He was also very chilled so maybe he doesn't drink as much coffee as I assume he might given his profession.
author: Jess L.

description:
I wasn't a big coffee drinker until I started going here. I didn't really know that you should be able to taste coffee and that it should taste good.

Go here and step off to the left of the main checkout line and have a hand brewed cup of some single origin beans.
author: Martin E.

description:
During the school year, I hit this place up almost every morning. It does put a dent in my wallet but its just so convenient and tasty, that I don't have the discipline to say NO. 

I think other reviewers have mentioned. There is a guy sometimes that works the register, that is just so happy, that it just makes YOU so happy. He is so nice, and positive, and I just want some of what he's got. And it definitely makes my walk to the impeding doom of law school, slightly more manageable. I might give this place a 1/2 star less but this dude is just sugh good energy. 

The COFFEE . its just really good. Im not a coffee snob, I cant explain the underlying notes of this or that, but I am french. So I think it gives me some credibility, maybe? and I think its really good coffee. They have good politics about coffee trade. and they have great chocolate croisants - which , again, as a french, I definitely think I have some credibility in that department. 

the place doesnt have wifi. which as much as I am addicted to the internet, i think it refreshing to have a place where maybe you just go to hang out and talk to people and not play on your computer. could make doing work there tough though.
author: Milo B.

description: This place is definitely hard to miss with the line out the door...but worth the wait. Great coffee. The barista at the pour-over bar was so passionate and excited to share his favorite coffee with us. Answered all of our questions and didn't make us feel rushed even with the long line.
author: Amanda R.

description:
I'm from Boston, where the coffee shops seem to be mostly of the chain variety, the beverage menus abundant with sugary coffee-flavored beverages that appeal to the tykes being toddled in by their suburban moms--or the teenagers who think drinking coffee makes them appear "cool" and "grown up." You'll find none of that here. 

The clientele has an air of "it's cool to be uncool" about it--making this an ultra-chill place to just come and hang and drink some expertly roasted and prepared coffee. You can tell a lot of love went into the birth of this place--and you can tell a lot of people have already fallen in love with hanging out here.

I'm not a huge coffee drinker, but it's obvious this brew has that deep headiness to it that tastes complex, but without that burnt smell to it--or the icky aftertaste. The menu is spartan. No muffins, no sandwiches, no bottled beverages. But if you're looking for an awesome cup of coffee, iced or straight up--latte, cap, or espresso--it's worth the trip.

N.B. There's an ejector-like feeling to the seats here. If you're here for the long haul, try spinning it around and sitting on it backwards.
author: Holly S.

description:
The soy cappuccino is a revelation.  The espresso and the soy pair beautifully, the foam is perfect, and every cappuccino I've gotten has had a feather or fern on top. Every time I walk around the neighborhood drinking one, strangers say hello--I think it's because I look so at peace with the universe and they're hoping my improved mental state will rub off on them.  The soy cappuccino just puts me in a good place.

Also, the baristas are nice.  

The interior is less than conducive to, like, hanging out with a cup of coffee.  I ran into a friend there once and she looked around and commented, "Wow, this place was definitely designed by a man."  It's angular and there are Javelinas on the wall.  It's beautiful but in sort of a brutal way--though there is a lovely view from the rear window of the place.
author: Caroline M.

description:
This is the best coffee in SF. I know that's a bold statement, but I really do prefer it over any other coffee house. Their roasts are impeccable.

The only downsides are the lack of wi-fi (which is intentional, I know, but makes it not such a great hang-out space to do work a la Ritual).

I enjoy coming to the back window on weekends as well to get away from the crowds.
author: Graham H.

description:
Don't get me wrong the coffee is amazing... Best I've had in the city.  I also really enjoyed the ham and cheese croissant... But it's A Terrible place to use a laptop. No plugs that I could find and some of the most un-ergonomic tables I've seen at a coffee shop. I don't think there was any free wifi either.

My review is only based upon my use of coffee shops as an office.
author: Allen P.

description:
3.5 stars

I love the space here.  It's all wood and rope and boars heads mounted on the wall.  Natural lighting (I think there's a skylight) offsets the decor and the attractive staff.  It feels cozy and hip and communal.  When you're here, you feel like just maybe you're part of something really awesome.

The set-up the baristas have is in my opinion, unparallelled.  This barista watched in awe as the espresso drinks were prepared in the most efficient and high-tech workspace ever with consistently perfectly textured milk and latte art.  Literally, I almost had a coffee-gasm watching the barista work.  It's like coffee and a show, in one.

Only, I was kind of underwhelmed by the finished product.  The milk, while conducive to making great art and perfectly silky in texture, was only lukewarm when I got it.  Although it was only a small 8oz cup, and the shot was a double, the taste of the espresso was insipid and overwhelmed by the milk.  Bf's mocha was similarly uninspiring, although I love the way they prepare it with really high quality semi-sweet chips rather than powder or syrup.

I've had the drip too, which was good, but not that great.  I think the only time I've ever finished a whole coffee from Four Barrel was the time my bf and I shared a small cup instead of getting one each.
author: Jane F.

description:
Simple menu. What they do, they do right. 
Simple but hip design with plenty of seating and space. Great place to read or study.
author: neal s.

description: I thought consistently delicious soy cappuccinos were an impossibility, but Four Barrel makes a mind melting one every time. Great beans, too.
author: Loren C.

description:
Four Barrel pretty much rocks. They really have great coffee without a lot of attitude. A good deal is the drip coffee, well French Press, actually... It's rich, not sour, and a pretty nice sized portion for the dollar. Their cappuccinos are also really well prepared, served at the right temperature with a delightful thick and luscious foam. Coffee is definitely 5 stars, some of the best I've ever had.

Their Valencia location is convenient, and very spacious. They could fit more tables in here though, so people can stay awhile and listen to their collection of vinyl LPs which range the gamut from vintage Madonna to Interpol to Willy Nelson (well, I'm not sure about Willy Nelson, but definitely stuff that sounded like Willy Nelson to me). A huge huge drawback is NO WIFI. I mean, what self respecting cafe doesn't have WiFi? I get that they don't want people to stick around all day, but really... 

The ambiance is a mix of hipsters, unemployed artists, and mornings even see whole families (dog included!) coming in for some caffeination. The dogs are particularly cute, although not conforming to health code I'm sure. There is a massive roaster in the back and it's fun to see the guy checking the beans and the smell of course is delicious.

Well, I guess the final comment would be that the 4 wild taxidermied boar heads are not all that appetizing. One is even missing a significant portion of its ear. But the coffee is good and it's good for people watching for a few minutes, and checking your email on your iphone.
author: Darcy V.

description:
Just finished off my coffee and vanilla bean donut. They were both delicious and I will definitely be back. I love the industrial space at Four Barrell. Its so wide open that there's not really any bumping into people that commonly stagger around like zombies waiting for their coffee. The barista who made a cappuccino for my girlfriend also capped it with a nice milky heart. 

They also have a bunch of different beans that you can pick-up for brewing at home. I saw at least 3 people stocking up this morning, which looks pretty funny when you see someone with 3-6 bags at ~$12 a bag. Regardless, its pretty clear why they might crave these beans. The coffee really is just that good.
author: Ed B.

description:
Picking a coffee in San Francisco is like picking a religion.  Polite people tacitly agree not to try and convert each other.  

So I'll just simply say, and without proselytizing, that Four Barrel is my coffee religion.  The latte is the most perfect in the city, a balance of flavor, smoothness, and creaminess.  The baristas meet you where you are:  if you're chatty, they chat with you with no snotty "leave my alone you coffee peon" attitude I've seen elsewhere (cough ritual cough).  If you're uncaffeinated and uncommunicative, they sense that and leave you alone.  

The music somehow is always what I need to hear, played on vinyl.  The lines, when they get long, move fast.  In the morning's it's Dynamo Donuts, in the afternoons Anthony's cookies so there's always a high quality sweet to compliment your fix.  

I love this place from my toes to my face.
author: Mel B.

description: The coffee is great and I highly recommend the scones! They were dense, moist and flavorful. I wish they had nonfat milk and sweetener available for those of us who don't go for almond milk, cream and sugar. Nice vibe. Hard to finding seating at peak times.
author: Dana E.

description: They like coffee here. A lot! Very passionate about what they serve, and it shows in the coffee and the excellent shots of espresso. I'll be back.
author: Rick L.

description: I would give this place 3 stars, but the extra one is because they support Rosa Parks Elementary school. Really the coffee is 3 stars. I've tried their drip and latte. Pretty good, but I don't know what the hype is. The pastries are pretty good, too, with some unusual flavors. The staff is variable--generally friendly, but service can be slow and frazzled. But I will repeat again, they are helping a local public elementary school. What's not to like about that?
author: 和子

description: I am a coffee ho and Four Barrel is the real deal. This is the best coffee outside of Italy.  I go to the pour over counter and get mine brewed to order from the most knowlegeble barista you will ever meet.  The man knows his coffee and brews it to perfection.  I love the ambiance too.  Everything from the lighting fixtures and turntable to the boar's head.  The new outdoor seating area is urban looking and beautiful.  Worth a visit just to check out he decor.
author: Denise C.

description: I got a black coffee but was disappointed by its flavor and body -weak and acidic. My boyfriend wasn't overly enthused about the espresso either. However, I will say that the hazelnut coffee cake was well worth it -very moist and flavorful yet not too sweet.
author: Katie V.

description: This place kills it. They are the real deal - roaster/coffee shop in one building. They work directly with farmers and bring in high quality green coffee to roast on-site and prepare expertly in a variety of styles. Unlike many "third-wave" shops the atmosphere here was friendly and welcoming, with some good jams playing from the turntable and excellent coffee served with a smile.
