A lot of shops could learn a thing or two from Four Barrel.
author: Mark E.

description:
Good coffee and all blah blah..

Great bathroom though.  That's the surprise.  Not good coffee in SF but a chandelier in a restroom in the Mission.
author: Patrick A.

description: Perfectly made espresso drinks, and delicious treats as well. Nice atmosphere. Friendly staff.
author: Janel A.

description:
If Hipsters were forced to leave the country and had to live in hiding - I'm positive that Four Barrel Coffee would become the #1 secret commune. 

Ok - so that was harsh. It really does have a lot of great vibe...unique aesthetics with having the roasters exposed in the back of the shop. 

The coffee was good, but nothing to write home about. The beans are burnt a little much for my taste. 

Good food. 

All in all, a good experience, but the decor definitely makes this place.
author: Nathan M.

description: I wish this place wasn't so dang crowded all the time.  If you can snag a table and handle a long line, for my money there's no place better in the city for java.
author: Maisie G.

description:
A friend and I were walking through Valencia and decided to grab some coffee & doughnuts. 

Seriously this coffee is soo good! You don't need any cream or sugar. Oh My gosh. 

The doughnut was so delicious and had this lemony and a small hint of thyme herb aftertaste. I was so amazed I had to go back in line to get another one! 

Five stars! I want some now
author: Esther L.

description: As a first timer at Four Barrel, my expectations for this coffee shop was high since so many of my friends love this place. Unfortunately, I don't know what happened when I was there. I brought my dad in with me since he loves coffee as well. I ordered a latte while my dad looked around of the different choices of coffee beans offered in their store. My dad wasn't sure how their coffee tasted like so he asked for a sample and the girl working the counter had an irritated demeanor and had an attitude. Mind you that my dad is not fluent in English and his grammar is not perfect but he gets his points across. My dad asked her if they had any dark roast coffee, the she rudely replied that they don't have any. She didn't even care to help my dad look for a coffee blend he liked best. So my dad went to one of the baristas for help instead and all the guy said was "huh?" And continued on with his work. Like are you kidding me? All my dad was looking for was some good coffee to bring home and the workers did not have good service at all! I was so disappointed. I don't know why they would hire people that are rude and unhelpful at this place. I mean the coffee is good, but the service is horrible! I won't be coming back to this place ever!
author: Cynthia T.

description:
Life, today, is a lot like a Four Barrel cappuccino; The bitterness of the coffee offset by the naturally light-sweetness of the frothy, steamed milk reminds me that the roughest edges can be smoothed over with just a little TLC and good dairy. 

Four Barrel Coffee makes a great cappuccino. For $3, it's not something I want to be shelling out for every day... but, like Mom always said, you get what you pay for. The quality brew makes the trek into the Mission on a weekday morning almost as uplifting as the company I like to keep. 

Another life lesson might also be learned at the pastry shelf at the ordering counter: A vanilla donut ($2.5) reminds us that sugar and spice make everything nice, but vanilla icing makes it even better. 

A little on the macabre side, adorning the wall  are the heads of 4 gents who must have lost their way on Folsom street, many years ago. Busts, as it were. Not sure what they had to do with coffee, but they'll help you find subject matter if you need a conversation kickstarter.

Sit and stay a while in the spartan interior. Sip your drink, don't gulp. And as the sun climbs, and your energy level is artificially augmented, remember that you are in one of the best cities on the planet and you're about to make life happen.
author: Razoo D.

description:
love the attention to the craft, customer, and community! 

tasty, tasty, bean and cookies. short cap, americano, iced, french pressed, can't go wrong!
author: Derek T.

description:
I don't love four barrel... for a really simple reason. I don't really like their coffee. Simple enough, right?

It's just got a funky taste. So yesterday I gave it another try and went with a mocha. Still didn't do it for me. It was kind of grainy too... maybe I accidently got some coffee grounds in there? Regardless... I'm sticking with Blue Bottle!
author: Abbey S.

description: The beer-flavored ice-cream affogato I had in the early afternoon left my heart racing till 4am. Now that is some serious caffeine. I should probably go for the decaf next time.
author: Kori M.

description:
I was disappointed in my first experience with Four Barrel. After all the hype I heard about it, my expectations were high. I didn't like Ritual (too hipster) and I loved Philz (just right!), so I was hoping for gold with Four Barrel. Unfortunately, when I went in at 4 PM on a lazy Sunday afternoon, my coffee was luke warm. Seriously? Luke warm coffee in a place like this? I was shocked. Also, it was really bitter. I usually don't mind extremely strong coffee if it's smooth. This was just super bitter. 

I'm going to chalk it up to a fluke, and give it a second go. For now, it's Philz that reigns supreme.
author: Amanda D.

description: Their menu is simple and short ... there's only a few choices on it . I had their mocha which was neither bitter or sweet ...  it just tasted like a cup of something warm . I also had their four cheese crossaint which was not bad . They also sell coffee beans and coffee makers here . As for the coffee shop , it's pretty big and spacious but I feel like there's too much empty space which is kind of weird . The tables kind of remind of the office tables for some reason .
author: Eileen L.

description: Awesome store, awesome music, awesome vibe, awesome coffee. Only been once, but I DIG this place. They make a killer latte, do single-cup brewing, and roast their beans in-house. In-house as in, in the back of the store. Check this place out pronto.
author: Alex S.

description: One of the best latte's I have ever had in the world. Yes there are thousands of places that I have not been but I've been to hundreds. And yes hundreds all over the world. Four Barrel just knows how it's done. A lot of seating, and pretty nice staff. Small amount of bakes goods. Very few outlets but a good place to work nonetheless. Oh and their espresso by itself is absolutely incredible. Bike rack out front is a plus albeit a bit over crowded with fixed gears.
author: Shane T.

description:
Only in the mission could you find a coffee shop with four boar heads displayed along the wall.  Hah.. I though one of them smiled at me.

This is where I get my coffee and pastries in the morning.

It's clean and the service is on par..  And the coffee is addicting.

I don't see any outlets in here.  This is a social coffee shop and the atmosphere gives Four Barrel character.  Starbucks.. Peets, I don't even utter their names anymore.

Open up your mind to Four Barrel.  Who knows, you might like it..

Huge plus that I feel at home with all the young hipsters in this shop!!
author: Walter C.

description:
You know you are in for a good and pretentious cup of coffee when you walk into hip, industrial space with beans roasting in the back. This place feels like stepping into Portland, and that's a good thing. The coffee is perfect and reasonably priced, and the menu is kept simple. 

On a weekday morning, the shop was busy. There was ample seating along the edges, though the chairs are small and metal like those in an old elementary school cafeteria. The patrons were a mix of hipsters, grey beards, and miscellaneous in-between job fellows. Despite the possible lack of wifi, about a quarter were on laptops. The rest were actually talking to each other.
author: Nik D.

description: I love four barrell!  Their coffee is amazing, most of the time.  There are a few baristas that could use an attitude adjustment, but most of them are sweet and talented people!
author: Justin J.

description:
I saw this place a few nights ago, and it looked pretty cool.  But, I wasn't about to have coffee an hour before I was going to bed.  I go decaf sometimes, but if I'm going to rate a place based on their coffee, I wanted the real stuff.

So, a bright sunny Christmas Eve day, about an hour after my caffeine withdrawals were kicking in, I got a chance to try it.  It's thick coffee.  A tiny bit of fine 'dirt' left at the bottom.  It's a very fine line between strong coffee, and drinking grounds.  This was right there.

I like the minimalist decor - kind of a reminder that they serve coffee here, not hipster vibe.
author: masa s.

description:
Wow. 

Service = amazing.

Interior design = funky and inviting.

coffee = KILLER

There's a freakin employee that's paid to just DJ all day! 
This place is worth a visit... daily!!
author: Sho B.

description:
Latte is goooood. Loved the Duncan Estates blend, the Kenyan such n such blend was OK.

Love that they offer silverware to stir your coffee instead of creating waste with stirring sticks. Peeps working were all very nice, inviting ambiance- even the boar heads are smiling :P )

I'm tempted to get some Duncan shipping to me here in OC... hmm!
author: Sassy-and-Pablo D.

description: For every cup of coffee you drink here a child is cured of cancer. Quick! We need your help!
author: Tiger H.

description:
Fantastic place to see and hang out. If I lived in the city, this is where I would go to get my daily coffee. My only qualm is the staff doesn't show any personality. Would it kill you to be nice to me?

Other than that, they put a lot of care and love into each cup and that shows. Props to them!
author: Lauren D.

description:
There's a belief that, if you're a coffee-drinking San Franciscan, you're either team Four Barrel or team Blue Bottle.

I don't see why you can't be both.  But then again I am not one with strong allegiance and/or emotional connection toward anything, so maybe mine isn't a view shared by everyone.  

I love Four Barrel - the big open space, the ample sitting areas whether you're drinking solo or with a companion or two, the fact that the servers check up on you if they don't see a cup of coffee on your table, and of course the smooth strong drip coffee (no sugar or cream needed).
author: Ange L.

description: This place has spoiled me forever because honestly? Coffee doesn't get better than this.
author: Aisha I.

description:
I am a coffee gimp.  I really only like it if I can add a lot of sugar and cream. So this is not my ideal place to come.

If you like STRONG coffee, this is your place.

Nice outdoor seating area.
author: Lux P.

description:
Great cappuccino. 

Really nice place, though for the size i'm surprised they do not accept credit cards.
author: Lion G.

description: Delicious coffee and even better people watching. If you want to see every caricature from the pages of the Bold Italic you'll find them here. Instagram your coffee, wear thrift store boots and start up shirts, bring your fixie bikes and settle into one of the better parklets. Over priced coffee is a cheap price for the quality of the experience.
author: Urvi N.

description: My succinct review:  Though the ambiance of this Hipster Central Coffee Joint was quite eccentric & memorable (...especially with the Boar Head Wall Mounts and Vinyl Records playing), I don't have anything to rave about their lattes. ~$5 for a latte?! Uh, No thanks.
author: Jessica P.

description:
Yeah, yeah, yeah ALL SHOTS DOUBLE. They roast their own coffee, blah, blah, blah.

I've been known to point out all the bad stuff and definitely focus on the negatives. It's my forte.

I've been here so many times and every time I wonder the same:

What the fuck is wrong with people who feel they must hog all the small tables for about 3 hours after their coffee is gone? Some places have sings asking people to limit their stay when clearly, the establishment is so empty, they don't need them. Four Barrel needs to clutter their space with these sings. Maybe it's the unemployment rate. Maybe these people don't have a house to stay with a sofa. Four Barrel can me a cozy spot, but please, it's not a fucking library. 

Everything would be fine if there were enough seats for everybody. I'd be happy. Yelp! would be happy. This review would have 5 stars. People would steal the wi-fi for a buck a day, but sadly, things never work out.

Consider the fact that Four Barrel seems to be divided into half. One half is roasting equipment and beans, while middle is the espresso bar, and the the other chunk is wasted with a bunch of room  and yet, not enough seats. Barely any seats. You got nothing in the middle. 

Does the owner not notice all the people standing up lounging at the espresso bean bar because there's simply no room to seat? Does the barista notice? Does anyone? 

Hell, even the bathroom is pretty big.  I should start drinking my coffee there. Yeah. Why didn't I think of this before?

Like Blue Bottle, Four Barrel's seats and tables remind me of my middle school science lab. Is that a designer trend? Is this why everyone chooses to bring their laptops and stay there for over an hour? 

Also: No dogs!? I saw the owner with his dog inside *tsk, tsk, tsk* then I returned my coffee because I found a doggy hair in it. *tsk tsk tsk*
author: Alexia R.

description:
Don't be put off or intimidated by the overwhelming hipster vibe, Four Barrel serves up some honestly good coffee by a friendly staff, while playing awesome music. I usually stop in here while walking the pooch to Dolores Park. 

Love the decor, rustic but modern.  

Limited seating, so maybe not the best place to study.  More of a conversational coffee house.  Awesome people watching.  

Dog friendly as well!
author: Elle B.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE LOVE LOVE their latte! Best I've had in the city.  It is done with just the right amount of beans! It definitely lightens up my day with a cup in my hand. 

The only thing that annoys me is that they don't have wifi there.  I guess that's a way of keeping people moving out of the shop.  If you are not in a rush, bring a book in, you'll really enjoy the ambiance.
author: Cathy Y.

description: Go to Four Barrel and drink excellent coffee every time.  Super super busy on weekends - share a table!
author: Dave B.

description:
Housed in a rustic loft in the northern corner of the Mission, the huge front windows provide an interesting view outwards onto Valencia for people watching, as well there are many tables out on the floor.

By contrast to Blue Bottle's fanatical focus on bean selection and highly controlled brewing, Four Barrel geeks out with the roasting process, a hulking old-world roaster in the running at the rear of the shop. Overall, though, this seems to make for a smoother, if not as richly flavorful, cup of coffee.
author: Jake G.

description: Lots of space to sit, smooth coffee, what?--friendly hipsters behind the coffe bar?  Yup.   They're spinning old-school vinyl too.  A chandelier in the bathroom when we're not even in the Castro?  Good tables to sit at on top of it?  Yah.
author: Patrick B.

description: Beautiful atmosphere. walked in here trusting reviews from yelp. Asked for a regular coffee, it was terrible.
author: Ahm G.

description: Would have been 5 stars if it wasn't for the pretentious staff.  Terrible greeting, no smiles.. AMAZING coffee.
author: Winter G.

description: Coffee hipster paradise. And by hipster I don't mean just any young person who dresses weird. I mean mustaches and fedoras and skinny jeans and bacon. Great people watching for sure...though it closes far too early and I didn't see any plugs. Check out the bathroom...but you may have to wait to get in cuz it's only one room.
author: Sarah B.

description: This was the best cup of coffee I've had since about 5 years ago at Intelli Chicago with the Clover brewer. So why only 3 stars? Well, to start it took a while to find parking in the area on a Saturday afternoon, but finally I did find someone leaving. Since I was travelling I didn't have any quarters on me (I always keep them in my car), but she left me 18 minutes of parking time, which I thought would be perfect for getting a cup of coffee and a quick lunch to go. I was very wrong! Iget in and it isn't that busy, but not dead either. Note: there are two lines, one for espresso drinks and/or drip and one for espresso and/or pour over. There were two people doing pour overs: one apparently was giving a bunch of groupies a cupping class, and the other serving the rest of the customers. After they grind the coffee they give it to you to smell; I love a great cup of coffee and seek out 'third wave' shops when I travel, but I'm not a professional. I could see doing this for someone in the industry, but between this, the groupies, and the big shot serving the groupies it was all just over the top and snobby. This place demonstrated much of why I did not like San Fran. I also waited over 20 min for a cup of coffee when the place wasn't very busy. It took less time at Ritual with a huge line (I'm not expecting it to be right away, I mean I am ordering a pour over). The staff is very friendly, but the friendliness toward the current customer means all the people in line behind them are just standing there waiting. I couldn't see this place lasting very long in NYC, but I guess things are a little slower in San Fran. I would recommend this place for the coffee, but that is about it.
author: Jacob M.

description: Absolutely perfect espresso, every time.  I never miss a chance to grab a cappuccino here when I'm in the Mission.  They often have amazing pastries as well.   Super cute parklet out front.  Vibe is uber-hipster but the staff are always great.  Yes, the line is worth it!
author: Amelia B.

description:
A perfect cup of coffee with a pastry to match, good people, chill vibes and music played from vinyl. It is unusual these days to hear an album being played the entire way through. Four Barrel understands the importance of the complete experience and this is reflected in their coffee. 

The open space inspires creativity and the light pouring in from large street-facing windows and the sky lights of their lofted ceiling adds natural warmth to the cool ambiance. 

All of us living in San Francisco have a list of places we would truly miss if we ever moved away. On my list, Four Barrel Coffee is bold, italicized and underlined.
author: Michael R.

description: Wasn't a fan of the late I had. I'll try the coffee next time though. I had a almond milk vanilla late.  Very crowded place so I assumed the drinks were better than just d debt to good.   Nah... I'll probably stick with Starbucks....
author: Peter G.

description: Four Barrel Coffee is just your typical coffee house. I once tried their coffee there and it was okay. No difference at all compared to Starbucks (In my opinions...). The workers have good communication skills, understanding what the customer wants and are also friendly. The atmosphere of the place is pretty hip and urban. Oh and they have good treats! Yum :-)
author: Lauren Y.

description: Beautiful coffee shop. exposed wood ceiling, record player, back area coffee roasting and donuts... a true hipster paradise. The coffee here is some of the best, my cappuccino was fantastic. The baristas were friendly and quick. i'll take four barrel over blue bottle any day.
author: Mariam H.

description: OH EM GEE. Very smooth coffee. May be the best in the city. I can't believe I'm saying this but....it's actually better than blue bottle! What? I know it's hard to believe. But seriously it out! Cool space in back where they are roasting beans as you enjoy your delicious brew.
author: Amanda C.

description:
BLAH. another pretentious mission coffee joint. This one doesn't serve skim or 1% milk... I'm sorry, but I don't want to drink think disgusting creamy milk. Thats my prerogative. 

What kind of coffee joint only has one type of milk?? I know we are in a recession, and you are kinda uppity, but give your paying clientele some choices here people!!
author: amy b.

description:
Love it here. The coffee is amazing but some of the workers here and so uppity. The cookies are okay but mostly pretty sweet. 

Wish they would add more food items to their menu - oh, I know it's a coffee place, but I still want more food! :-) The cookies don't quite cut it for me, but I always buy a donut if it's available.

But, oh, the coffee! *heavenly*
author: Mary M.

description: Love the industrial feel of this place and the coffee rocks! The line seemed overwhelming at first, but they do a great job at keeping it moving. Outdoor seating is a nice touch.
author: Juliana C.

description:
Absolutely LOVE this place! 

Their coffee is one of the only coffees which I actually feel awake after drinking! It's hard for me to start my morning without one. 

The staff are friendly & they are always playing great records.
author: Peter T.

description: Very good. It doesn't seem quite as amazing as I've heard from others, but great coffee and great pastries in a funky/cool setting. Probably not great for a date though as most of the seating are these communal small tables so you can't really have an intimate conversation.
author: Charlie C.

description:
If you're a tea drinker, you will have to bring your own stash.  This spot only serves coffee.  The alternative is water, literally.  The other major missing element is wifi.  This is a travesty for such a great coffee house!  Counterbalancing these lacking essentials is an incredible ambience.  The architecture is hip and unlike many coffee shops, you have abundant space, high ceilings, and perfect lighting (not dark, but not hockey-rink bright either).

Added bonus: they serve Dynamo Donuts here - yumm!!  

ps. Four Barrels, You could offer free wifi on off peak hours.  For example, I see some coffee shops with free wifi during weekdays, but not on weekends.
author: Heather W.

description: I guess I just don't get it. The coffee tastes like Nescafe to me. And wow - pricey...
author: Leonard A.

description: Love this place. It was packed when we went. I had a decaf, non dairy mocha. They grate the chocolate for the mocha on the premises so it wasn't as sweet as other mochas. Note they don't use soy-- almond milk only. The espresso my hubby had was great. We split a mushroom tart which was wonderful; the donuts looked fantastic with different and  unusual flavors. Will definitely stop in again if we are in the area.
author: MB B.

description: Enjoyed a satisfying hot cup of delicious cappuccino at Four Barrel Coffee. Awesome aroma. Intense flavor. Rich. Decadent. Luscious. Paired it with toffee and white chocolate cookies from Anthony's. THIS IS THE LIFE!
author: aL Z.

description: Damn good latte and delicious chocolate chip cookie. Love. BUT their mocha is gross and not recommended!
author: Olivia P.

description:
Coming from Australia I've found it difficult to get a decent coffee here in San Francisco -- Four Barrel do a pretty good job.

Try the donuts too -- amazing!
author: Sam J.

description: Great coffee! Would go there time n again . Friendly staff! Industrial decor looks really great!
author: Avi S.

description: As you walk in, the wide expanse and boar heads arrest your attention. The music is alluring as is the decor. Minimalistic n artsy, just the way I like it.  They even have a bunch of books n records stacked up in shelves. Their coffee is pretty darn amazing. As you can see I love this place. Can't come to mission n not come here cuz that would be blasphemy.
author: Natasha I.

description: A true neighborhood café, and top-notch coffee roasting in house. Try one of the scrumptious pastries from b.patisserie along with your espresso beverage or pour-over coffee (available at the "slow bar" from 9-3pm). On the weekends, there's a secret entrance in the back alley, usually with no line.
author: Karl N.

description: Best latte I have ever had. It's rich, creamy, and delicious. The blue bottle latte is a very close 2nd for me.
author: Captain B.

description: What can I say that hasn't already been mentioned 100 times before. Of the fancy coffee in SF, Four Barrel is definitely my favorite. I love their espresso beans. Drop in get some coffee and pastries you won't be sorry.
author: Mike K.

description: This place is HUGE inside, especially for a coffee shop. It's impossible to feel cramped here if you come to work or have coffee with a friend. Most coffee shops can feel a bit too small and close-quartered. I love the rustic design of the inside. The staff is friendly and helpful, the menu is simple, and the coffee is delicious. Probably my favorite coffee stop in the Mission neighborhood.
author: Ashley D.

description: This is my favorite coffee shop in the mission. I prefer to buy my beans from here and make coffee at home, but I love visiting the shop as vinyl is spinning on a vintage rig (sansui, luxman, tannoy, etc) the baristas have no attitude with me, and the coffee is spot on.
author: Ameer N.

description:
the friendliest guy in the world works at this place, people who want a lesson in customer service should go there and watch this guy do his thing.  Amazing coffee and donuts at a good price.

I also like how they use metal spoons to stir your coffee instead of adding to the waste in the world with plastic/wood stirrers
author: Bryan B.

description: It's always a special treat to come here and enjoy the awesome coffee, hip atmosphere, and cool people that like gather here. I bring friends from out of town to show them one of my favorite spots in the city.
author: Johnny W.

description:
I have been on a coffee tasting kick lately so I wanted to see if Four Barrel lived up to its hype.  Did not visit the store, but got the coffee by mail which came very promptly.
Opening a bag of fresh roasted coffee is one of lives great pleasures. Yes! Smelled great... Taste? Not So Much.
As others have pointed out--if you like dark roast you will not find it here. 

I tried the Costa Rica San Luis De Grecia El Venda, which was so sour that I could not drink it.  I was looking for the "creamy vanilla mouth feel" that they describe on their web site, but perhaps it ended up going down the drain where I dumped this expensive little experiment.  Also gave the Guatemala Antigua Chuito a go.
Nothing special, but not as punishing as the sour sip I had earlier.

Web site descriptions vs. Actual taste test. Try it Kids!
author: Gem J.

description:
I was walking down Valencia Street last Sunday on my visit to SF and I walked past the musty boarded up storefronts and viola! saw the inside of Four Barrel Coffee. I was taken aback from the very clean, contemporary, roomy interior as opposed to right outside. I was looking for a cup of tea and asked if they had any. They replied they only serve coffee which I thought was very admirable, a coffee house that only serves coffee. Just like a tea house should only serve tea. I am a tea conoisseur and appreciate fine tea. I wouldn't want my tea house serving coffee also, it would show that they're not taking their tea seriously. 

So I didn't order any drink but saw some pastries. Now since they said they focused on coffee I assumed they didn't focus on pastries but I really wanted sugar so I got a chocolate chip cookie thinking it would be crappy. Oh my goodness it was one of the best chocolate chip cookies I've ever had! I was sorry I had already walked down the block when I started eating it because I nearly turned around to get another one. 

Girl at the counter was normal, the barista acknowledged me right away and was very polite and chill. If I am in the area I would stop here again.
author: Sarah A.

description: Cavernous hall with entertaining view of the roasting operation. Super slick espresso machine. Multi-talented barrista took out a drunk guy as if he tazed a sick bunny. Kept an uncomfortable scene from getting ugly. Extraordinary!
author: Ed r.

description: After years of living across the street, I've finally discovered there actually is an option for non coffee drinkers. FB serves hot chocolate (actually quite good) that isn't listed on any menu.  If you ask for something -- anything -- without coffee in it (as I have done), but don't specifically request the hot chocolate, you're liable to get the cold shoulder, so be specific!
author: David C.

description:
Updating my review.... 3 to 4 stars.

I previously had complained about the $1 refill, but have since realized that the new reality is $1-2 refills anywhere they serve the higher grade stuff.  Still, I'm not a big fan of the muddy style, but I really like their new drip station.  I don't buy coffee in the main line anymore.

I don't understand any of the comments about rude hipsters.  I'm certainly not a hipster (unless by iPad toting coffee snob qualifies me).  Still, everyone there has always been super polite to me so I have to assume that the whiny reviews say more about the reviewers in this case.

Love the wild boars!

Bottom line, if you want a kickass doughnut, go here.  If you want the best croissant in the city, go to Mission Beach around the corner.
author: Leon S.

description: Long lines, but they keep it moving and the coffee is worth the wait. New baristas are helpful, friendly, and quirky. This place beats any shop in city.  Four Barrel is better than Blue Bottle, Sightglass, Ritual, & anything else
author: Jorge D.

description:
Super cool place.

Philz still has the best coffee.

Tartine started serving four barrel coffee recently according to my friend who works there. But even people who don't know about that, think the coffee sucks at Tartine.
author: Yuchi C.

description: Best espresso in SF. I'm a graduate student so I basically run on caffeine. I usually get the americano, but I tried the mocha and it was amazing as well. I have bought ground coffee for my lab and home so I will never have to go without :)
author: Beatriz A.

description:
I may have heard about this place through friends, but stumbled upon it on my own.

The first thing I noticed about this nondescript coffee shop was the spaciousness walking in.  It was like walking into a very aesthetically pleasing warehouse.  A great ambiance.

The second thing was the simple, clean menu.  Simply said, this place is the real deal.  None of those "or-ange mo-cha frappu-ccinos" everyone raves about.  Nothing to confuse or distract this ADHD patron.  For me, fewer choices translate into a happier experience.

And the drink - the mocha!  I think it was made from real chocolate shavings, not chocolate that comes out of a pump!

Sadly, when I sat down and looked for a power outlet, the guy behind me informed me that there were none.  No power, no WiFi.  Which only means one thing - the folks who do come to Four Barrel come for the coffee.

Not that I'd ever go to a place just for the quality of the coffee, being the non-coffee drinker that I am.  But I'd consider coming back here, if I had a fully charged laptop on hand or needed to get disconnected for awhile.
author: Athena ..

description:
This place is the High Fidelity equivalent of cafes.

Don't take that the wrong way. This is one of the best places to get espresso in San Francisco. I have to admit, the place can be intimidating upon first inspection, but take a moment to reflect upon what's going on here and you'll realize you're visiting a special place when you walk into Four Barrel. 

The baristas, the roasters in the back half of the cafe, and the "hipster" taking your order--that so many of these reveiwers seem to be intimidated by--are there for one thing and one thing only. They drink, sleep and breathe coffee. These aren't just some college kids trying to pay their way through their next semester of art classes. They're full blown coffee nerds. This is their passion and it shows in their product. 

Take some time to smell the bags roasted beans they have available on the wall while you wait for your drink to be prepared on the functional, Italian sculptures that are Four Barrel's customized La Marzocco "Mistral" espresso machines. The roast they use can only be found at Four Barrel (note: they no longer serve Stumptown's Hairbender blend) and their chocolate for their mochas comes from Schmidt, a local chocolatier (beware, it's not sweetened... you get total control of the sweetness of your coffee via brown, liquid or regular sugar on the bar.)

Bear this in mind when you visit Four Barrel:
This is a roastery, first; a cafe, second.

There is no WiFi here. 
No comfy chairs. 
Drink your coffee, then get out!
Go see the city! 
Visit a museum! 
It's a beautiful day and you've just had some of the best espresso SF has to offer!
author: MonkeyDude S.

description: Love the atmosphere, and want to love the coffee, but it was SO not good for me. This is clearly a matter of taste, as many people love Four Barrel. But as a "black as midnight on a moonless night" kinda dark roast kinda girl, this medium roast sludge was NOT my cup of tea (or coffee).
author: Dana O.

description: No nonsense. Minimal interior. Great people work here-they play funky music too. Treat yourself to a delicious cup of coffee and don't forget to tip.
author: Gene W.

description: A nice place in the trendy Valencia neighborhood. Good atmosphere. Fun to sit in the back and watch as they do the roasting and packing process. Wonderful cappuccinos, with gourmet coffee from around the world.
author: Mary R.

description: Not so crazy about The Mission. But I would gladly pay a visit to get a cup of Four Barrel. I am a fan, Jeremy. From everything to anything, well thought out. Kudos!
author: Kara Y.

description:
Love.

What's so great about Four Barrel Coffee? Um, hi. Everything. 

Stumptown coffee from Portland. They serve it. My favorite coffee. Love.

Here I am, slightly hungover from a long night, wearing my sunglasses and reeking of booze. Here you are, awesome coffee guys, smiling at me and not judging me for being a total slob. I love you, cute barista dudes. Let's cuddle.

I love you, affordable latte. I love you, latte art. I love you, lemon-sage donut. I love you, regular mug of coffee.

I love you, tattooed guy(s) with beard(s).

I love you, Anna and Lea for loving people-watching as much as I love it.

I love you, caffeine jitters and cups of self-serve water.

I love you, establishment that doesn't offer wifi and encourages actual human interaction over electronic obsession.
author: Pamela D.

description:
This is a place where you would see folks looking like  American  apparel models all hungover craving good coffee..

here's some key points why I like this joint
1)ice coffee is good..Really good
2)Unique flavor donuts..Bacon glazed donuts 
3)The og record player playing tunes was cool
4)Anthony's Cookies..MY friends started this company and was happy  Four Barrel was carrying them and the are screamming good

only problem...No CC or ATm..You gotta go to the corner store ..aka no bank shady atm
author: Eko A.

description:
Four Barrel, in my opinion, is the best coffee experience in SF. Starting with the space: industrial, preserving the feel of the original building and enhancing it with natural materials. I loved their use of thick wooden planks and steel. It is a warm space with the perfect amount of natural light; acoustically live enough to generate a buzz but not loudness.

I also love the visual process/progression. It screams passion for coffee. Up front there is activity at the drip bar. The focal point is the espresso bar, where one can easily interact with and observe the baristas. They have the most fantastic low-profile espresso machines that almost look like giant mechanical spiders. The back half of the building has racks of green coffee in burlap bags and their vintage Probat roaster complete with belt drive (like a machine from the start of the industrial revolution).

Approaching the espresso bar, the staff is friendly. We are coffee cognoscenti, so we did not make any faux pas, but they did not seem the type that would verbally flagellate a novice. Our barista made a perfect cappuccino with a crisp rosetta on top. The flavor and mouthfeel were right up there with the best I've had.

In summary: clearly passionate about coffee, a glorious space, AND a staff that cares about people, too (rare in some other coffee places).
author: Joe J.

description:
It was love at first sight...of the ambiance, the boars heads on the wall, the bathroom floor, the wooden bars, the french presses, the open roasting area in the back. It was love at first sip. It felt like home. 

The only thing missing was attitude. And I didn't miss it.
author: Susie W.

description: Great coffee. Very hipster and laid back coffee shop. Enjoy the vinyl they are spinning while you wait for your drink. I've heard it's always busy here due to the great drinks that they make.
author: Shannon H.

description:
My friend always gets a coffee at Four Barrel everytime they're in the city. Today we headed down ther for our ritual of dirnking four barrell coffee and smoking cigarettes on the curb. 

Now, I'm pretty sensitive to the effects of caffeine, so I usually get a decaf capp wherever I go. Today I got a decaf and my friend got a normal capp. Mine was good, a little bitter, kind of intese in flavor, but well made. I've had ones that had better foam, but overall it was money well spent. 

Then, I had a sip of my friends' regular capp. Jesus effing christ. It was heaven in a cup. I literally almost ran from the curb to go get one for myself. But then my friend told me to go sit back down, finish my cigarette (which I threw on the ground during my launch), and that we could share theirs. Good idea, since all of that caffeine would've made me feel cracked out.

I am planning my schedule tomorrow so that I can go back there and get a real frikken coffee drink. Tasty-town!
author: Ezra S.

description:
I realize they are going for a specific vibe, and they don't want you hanging around. It's just not my style. I like seats, plugs, attentive customer service, at least the option of black tea and a different type of sweetener. I've been more than once... I don't know why.

Oh yeah, the coffee is good. Like really good.
author: Kiki C.

description:
The fact that they don't offer nonfat or even reduced fat milk is annoying. Maybe I don't LIKE the thick, nasty feel of whole milk in my latte...ever think of THAT Four Barrel??

But whatever, I live a few blocks from Blue Bottle where they're not such haters.

Since I was DENIED my nonfat latte (in a really nice way though, I have to say...the cashier guy was the best thing about this place), I had a cup of regular coffee and sure, it was tasty, but not so tasty that I'd be willing to go out of my way for it. 

My coffee buddy asked if I wanted to find somewhere to sit but all the urban hipsters in that place made me feel like I needed to go get a hipster scarf and some skinny jeans and start a band or something so no, I didn't want to stay. But that's what I get for going to the Mission. Besides, we had a plan:

#54. Spiced-chocolate doughnut at Dynamo Donut with a Four Barrel coffee.

From this list:

http://www.7x7.com/content/eat-drink/big-eat-sf-100-things-try-you-die

I'll be back though because Dynamo didn't have any of the spiced-chocolate doughnuts and I can't cross it off my list until I've had one. (And yeah, I know Four Barrel sells Dynamo doughnuts, but I was trying to follow the instructions and go to Dynamo.)
author: Elizabeth H.

description:
Wow, Four Barrel is taking a beating with reviews so far in 2009.

Allow me to be the first in '09 to say that I actually had a good time enjoying my hot coffee whilst chowing down on one of those bacon-covered donuts. Sitting in the rather large space with lots of fun locals around me was alright. It was actually a nice place to just sit, eat, drink and relax reading the newspaper and getting in some quality "people-watching."

As for the coffee, well, let me just say that I got a nice jolt to start off my cold Saturday morning. Thanks Four Barrel. We'll be back.
author: Mickey A.

description: Great service! Coffee is good, not over the top. Great dessert. I got the passion fruit bostock, yum.
author: Dane H.

description:
Gross coffee.  Rude and ugly staff.  Like so LY.....

P'ster
author: Pammy S.

description:
For San Francisco independent roasters Four Barrel Easily ranks in the top three. I think that it's every bit as good as Ritual, and Blue Bottle. Yet, they all have their differences. RItual has the clover machine madness. Blue Bottle has the pump espresso and the siphon. And Four Barrel. Well four barrel has the most beautiful Espresso Bars and luckily some Baristas that know how to use it.

When I was there a few weeks ago they were serving this delicious Kenyan Peaberry on the espresso bar and it was smokin. The Capp's were great and so were the Latte's. My friend got a Mocha one of the times we were there and I really appreciated that they actually put cocoa beans and crush them into the drink. The attention to detail on their drinks is just great. 

Without a doubt one of the best spots for coffee in the city.
author: Jonathan D.

description: This is a big weirdly laid out modernly rustic spot that I have passed by a million times without noticing. My iced americano was good, but I think all Bay Area coffeehouses should offer brown sugar as a sweetening option.
author: Andrew K.

description:
Coffee makes me crazy.  Like, bouncing of the walls, singing loudly on the street, running up and down a flight stairs reciting the multiplication table kind of crazy.  Then a couple hours later I totally crash and I'm sad.  So most of the time, coffee just isn't worth all the drama.

But Four Barrel.  The smooth, bold flavors of the espresso and the perfectly balanced notes in their coffee.  I will humiliate myself publicly and fall into a deep caffeine-crash depression for Four Barrel.  

I am but a puppet.  And Four Barrel is my puppet master.
author: Diana Y.

description:
I've experienced really excellent "hip" culinary goodness in and around this neighborhood, so upon seeing Four Barrel's exterior, the line awaiting a cup of brew, and all the folks just hanging out, I expected more of the same. Sadly, from what I have tasted, Four Barrel is more scene than anything else. 

The descriptions on their beans whisk me away to mini-vacations, but I simply cannot imagine anything deep in flavor after a soy latte from their establishment. It sang one note -- bitter water. 

If this wasn't enough to turn me off, the odd decor of boar's heads across the wall sure did. I don't really understand why anyone would want animal heads dawning their walls, but it certainly does not say "hip" or "fresh" to me.
author: Shannon F.

description:
REALLY GOOD coffee for $2!

The space is pretty cool, although very loud (due to the long line of patrons) and no WiFi/power outlets.  As a result there aren't many startup hipsters coding on their macbooks.

They have this weird arrangement of barstools and a tables on the other side of the sidewalk which is pretty cool!

They also have donuts which i'm assuming are from Dynamo and other pastries, although the coffee is so good you'll be satisfied with just that.
author: Nikhil K.

description:
2.5 stars...

Minus: Coffee from a thermos... Pretentious clientele... 

Plus: Service is nice, if a little shy... Coffee is good, have to give them that... Bacon doughnuts!

If it weren't on my walk to work, I wouldn't go out of my way to go.
author: marco a.

description:
3.5, and willing to raise it, if someone there in a management capacity starts paying attention to:
1. the details.  Hershey's chocolate?  Say what...aren't you local, artisinal, made from good stuff.  How in the heck can you justify the crap that comes out of a plastic, corn syrup Hershey's dispenser?
2.  the filthy bathroom.  come on.  the decor is so cute.  just get someone to clean it once and a while.
3.  the gnarly attitude of most of the staff.  what, you don't pay them enough?
4.  get some better edibles, and buy enough to last pay 11 am.  geesh.
the coffee is good.  I've been semi-regular.
author: Kenzie D.

description:
The coffee is quite good and the interior is rather nice.

But:
 It's a case study in bad use of space.
 And there are no outlets for laptops ( why, god, why?! ).
 But to make up for it, there's moto parking right by the front door
 which results in the sweet smell of burnt exhaust drifting in. 


 Why bike exhaust is preferable to letting people do work/reading on 
 their laptops I will never know.
author: Max R.

description: Beautiful space, great customer service, and excellent coffee.  Blue Bottle makes a slightly better espresso in my opinion (although all taste is subjective), but Four Barrel does a great job at everything.  Very good experience here.  I've been in the coffee business for many years, and this is how it should be done.  The only negative - I'm not a fan of the boar heads.
author: LeftCoast R.

description:
As if this place needs another glowing review....

On a recent visit back to my home town of San Francisco I stopped in to meet a friend at Four Barrel...her new daily coffee ritual. What a beautiful space. My latte was hot and perfectly poured. The Bacon glazed donut was an easy sell and well worth every last crumb. Luckily the friend declined my offer to share it with me. 

I don't really know how else to describe my experience at Four Barrel  other than saying it was "inspirational". You'll have to go there yourself to see what I mean. 

Sit at the window bar - by far the best view in the house.
author: lillie m.

description:
How can a coffee place not have skim milk???  Please answer!  So, I couldn't order my usual skinny latte & was forced to drink a regular latte. With the richness of the whole milk, I had a hard time hunting down the true & smooth flavor of the latte.  On a positive note, there were no burnt taste!  

I also tried their chocolate cinnamon doughnuts, which were honestly... so-so.  I could totally have lived perfectly fine without ever trying that.  

Also, the workers there look quite....Evil which matches perfectly well with their rude attitudes.  If only you could have seen the disgusted look on the guys face when I gave my order of a nonfat latte.  Thank goodness he didn't spit at me or my drink!
author: Sheryl S.

description:
Easily ranks high up there with the likes of Blue Bottle. Fantastic coffee. And bonus points for a fantastic, huge warehouse-y space.

Not somewhere you can work from, though.
author: Premshree P.

description:
I try to come here as often as possible...
Great Coffee and great beans to take home and pretend that your living room is as cool as Four Barrel (it isn't).
The Maple Bacon Donuts are ridiculous, they may kill me but they are worth it.
But more than anything - they have the golden coffee and a great place to hang out, read a book and drink coffee... what else does one need?
author: Nathan H.

description: Like their coffee and mocha.  They serve their mocha with only whole milk or soy milk so don't ask for lowfat.  Mocha is made with good chocolate not loaded with sugar.  The lines are constantly very long and the espresso drinks take a few minutes to make.  One of the best aritsan roastery in the city (Sightglass is my other favorite).
author: Irene C.

description:
Pretentious. Cavernous and cold. The coffee is good, but it's not worth two dollars for twelve ounces. It's small-batch French press, and they get some pretty good Ethiopian blends, if that's what you're into. I prefer Muddy's, actually. I'm a traditionalist.

The hipsters love it, though. White people love expensive coffee. See all the designy-looking people with their casual business meetings and their sketches of things you can't afford?

Some of the staff is super nice, and the rest of them are rude and snotty. Not my favorite. Valencia is full of less intimidating places.

And trust me, I used to be a hipster AND a dot-commer.
author: Tarin T.

description:
Simplistic and minimal menu. Coffee, latte, americano, machiatto, cappuccino... I think that is literally it. 

Really, why let complexity ruin coffee in its purist form. And why let the ambiance get carried away with so many laptops? That's right, enjoy your coffee and perhaps a heavy pastry, and move on to your next destination in life. Life is too short to be glued to a lifeless screen and keyboard.

As for the decor... Months of biking back and forth on Valencia, quickly glancing in the work space and watching the hardworking people who were hand-sawing the wood, manually soldering the metal, and rotating the Phillips head by hand, I finally get a final visual of where all that handwork went into. The visuals, every table, the racks, shelvings, even the open window above the bathroom, and the wallpaper...all of this was done by passionate crafts people. DIY approved!
author: Cathy H.

description: Another overpriced coffee joint with great bike racks, no wifi,music so loud the cashier didn't hear my order, and WHAT is up with that bathroom? It needs some attention, for sure...if not some seat covers. Meh...
author: N B.

description:
this based on their retail beans and not on service or ambience.... which I'm sure are delightful,

 we bought the latin blend to brew from Whole Foods to try  at home, having been told their coffee is great. what a disappointment..
 bitter and lacking depth. Tastes like Folgers if you brewed it strongly.
 It doesn't even smell like coffee. I'd drink a cup of Starbucks first.
I'm just confused by all the great ratings these light coffee roasters get... maybe it's my palate that needs re-educating.
author: Stevie D.

description:
I can't tell you how strong the coffee is at Four Barrel, because I got a decaf latte, but it tasted great, and the ambiance of the place is pretty awesome. The space is so large that I kinda wished they had expanded to the back or had more tables and chairs to accommodate the large influx of customers during weekend afternoons. But maybe they just want to maintain that spacious feel and not crowd the privileged few lucky ones that scored a table. The thick slab of wood of the tables is very attractive and rustic. The chairs are extremely uncomfortable, which might be good to deter people from staying for too long. 

I like how the service seems very efficient and fast, despite a long line. And they provide a pitcher of water for self-service, which is great, because let's face it, coffee can't quench your thirst ever. If anything, coffee + long conversations with a good friend = one thirsty customer.
author: Candice B.

description:
I'm not a coffee connoisseur, addict maybe, but I don't really know the difference between a pump and a piston. I do know when I like the way something tastes though, and I approve of Four Barrel Coffee's flavor.

Most of the time I can waltz in, grab a latte, chug it beneath their most recent art installation, and go on my way. A few times I've felt like I was cramping the style of other customers because I'm not wearing the same green RVCA windbreaker as them. 

Either way, I know the staff doesn't care, because they're damn friendly, and will chat you up if they're not too pressed with customers. Wonderful music selection and large space that makes the whole environment buzz with an easy sense of...togetherness? I'm such a sap.
author: Leslie F.

description:
This is the perfect place to go if you want to grab a coffee and chat with a friend, study or just grab a quick one to go.  They make great coffee, and the place is spacious with plenty of tables for you to sit with friends or study. 

However, if you want to grab a bite in addition to your coffee, you might want to look elsewhere. Although they have some baked goods available at the front, they are limited and do go quickly.
author: Jackie C.

description: Good tasting complex coffee.  Good place to chit chat.  Not good place to work.  This turns out to be my favorite cafe in SF.
author: Byron L.

description:
Great industrial space with high ceilings and tons of natural light. Tasty coffee and plenty of spots to sit back and relax. 

I grabbed my cappuccino ($3) and beelined for a coveted vacant seat by the window.  The barista had crafted a heart in my foam, and questions began to fill my head:  
- Is this heart a sign that love is coming my way?  
- Was the mysterious barista so impressed with my drink order that he hid a 2-carat engagement ring at the bottom of my drink? (I do!)  
- Will Don & Betsy Draper on 'Mad Men' finally get back together?  

Unfortunately, my daydreaming was interrupted by a homeless guy banging on the glass window, trying desperately to make eye contact and then hollering and wiggling his tongue at me through gapped teeth.

-1 Star for still working out the kinks - and for not having tinted windows.
author: Janney B.

description:
I can't find espresso drinks or beans as consistently excellent as Four Barrel. I spend too much money here too.

On the coffee itself, I'm just gonna say this is among the best the world via extreme anecdotal evidence and fiat of opinion. Many folks are likely used to much darker roasts will probably notice Four Barrel's coffee renders more acidity and fruit flavors--this can be a little weird if you're not used to it--so I'll go out on a limb that you may not enjoy their French press if you like a big much of their nice "darkly" flavored coffee to start your day. However, their espresso and espresso drinks really shine in texture and aftertaste.

I buy all kinds of beans but Four Barrel's are the only ones I can uniquely identify in a taste test--their coffee tastes like their coffee. Aside from being delicious, I swear there is a definitely Four Barrel signature flavor across all their coffees. 

Service/hipsters/blahblahblahblahblah. I've never had anything but friendly service and good coffee. Their baristas take what they do pretty seriously which I appreciate--I've never had any other coffee shop wait a few moments for the espresso to settle in my machiatto before they put the milk in.

PRO-TIP: Weekend mornings before 10-11ish, just roll around to the back alley bar if there's a line. It is not a particularly great place to sit around to read or have a conversation, but if you want to people-watch the Mission crew, enjoy.
author: Jim L.

description:
I live around the corner from 4B and have been going there since they opened.  It warms my heart and makes me inexplicably proud to see how well they're doing! Sure I used to hang out there a little more when it was less crowded, but even with a line out the door, the talented staff work so fast that I'm always surprised how fast the line goes. I've never waited more than a minute or two to order and they have me out the door with my always excellent coffee or beans in no time. 

It's amazing to read that some folks think the staff is rude. In close to two years I haven't had a single negative experience with anyone who works at 4B. In fact, I've had multiple members of the staff go out of their way to geek out about coffee with me (JJ!) or just chat about nonsense (Justin!). I can only assume that some folks interpret being busy with a massive line of customers and not having time for a full conversation right at that very moment as having 'attitude'.  

I love you 4B! I'm glad you've made it, you're a welcome addition to the neighborhood.
author: Laura H.

description:
Are you freaking kidding me?  This is the coolest coffee bar. EVER. 
Seriously, I could live in this place- the rope chandeliers, the boar heads,  standing bar area, mini library style tables attached to the walls, and the massive coffee roaster machine in the back all make this place somewhere I'd literally want to inhabit.  Oh, and they serve coffee, too.

I didn't try the apple maple bacon concoction in the display case simply because I had just eaten brunch- but I will be back and it will be mine.
author: Sonia S.

description:
Love the atmosphere...looks like a modern version of an upscale saloon. I am hoping that the pig heads on the wall are fake (which were apparently bought on eBay for pretty cheap), but I have a feeling they are real. There are wood table/bar counters around the space, which is actually pretty big for a coffee shop.

The service was awesome! The guy at the register was super nice & friendly & was even recommending coffee machines to my dad and giving him tips on why his coffee art (the leaves & hearts made with foam) is not working.

The coffee itself was good, it was not the very best I have had, but it is definitely up there towards the top.

I like the fact that they do not have wifi or outlets, because it makes for more open tables & the turn over rate of customers is higher.

I was not a huge fan of the crowd, which consisted of a lot of snobby pretentious hipsters, but I cannot make generalizations for all of the clientele, so I shouldn't judge.

Overall, great place to grab coffee & hang out with a friend or two.
author: Elaine S.

description: Love the espresso, hate that its such along wait.  These baristas take...their..........time.   But that's part of the fun, I guess, watching the staff move at such a leisurely pace despite the long lines, it's clear they love coffee.  or are just mildly hung over.  or both.
author: Joyce J.

description:
Too hip to have good customer service- ? 
Prepare to be looked down upon.
These beautiful people are so effin RUDE!!
I bring 2 carafes up to the register because both creams are empty and the guy rolls his eyes at me, like I'm bothering him, then proceeds to make me wait till he fills both up, then- wait for it- then hands it off to another customer. WTF? Lastly, he was a complete jerk to my friend who is a very sweet guy ! I mean- how about a little - customer service? just a tad? 
I will give it to them- their coffee & beautiful decor is tasty & unique.
But my god they have THE WORST customer service. 
Im too sexy for my coffee too sexy for my coffee too sexy to give service.
author: star v.

description:
Can't stand this place. Overrun by dirty hipsters. Can't get in the door most of the time, blocked by fixed gear bikes. And Puch Mopeds? I mean, really. I just want to tell the kiddies at this scene about how in 1998 dot-commers thought swing dancing would NEVER go out of style. 

The coffee's pretty good, however.
author: Kourosh K.

description: Currently my go-to place for a perfect brew. Making good coffee is a complex art and four barrel has mastered it. I hope it does not go the way of blue bottle--believed its hype and compromised quality for quantity.
author: aj s.

description: Exposed wood joists, huge rope lights in the window, well-detailed designed concrete counters, friendly cool staff & patrons & absolutely lovely, lovely rich coffee to rival Blue Bottle. Mmmm. Decadence.
author: Jamie R.

description: No wifi, a strange choice for a coffee shop in one of the most wired, connected cities in the world.
author: Laura K.

description:
Four Barrel caught my eye long ago... I was in the Mission for my motorcycle classroom training, just a few doors down, and while on my break, I walked on by and stopped in my tracks when I saw Four Barrel's big, beautiful space! What a shame that it wasn't open right then and there when I could've used a latte to keep my lids open.

Fast forward to last Saturday when my bf and I were in search of a good coffee shop to post up in and do a little reading. Luckily, I remembered Four Barrel and off we went! 

The place is stunning in a modern, woodsy, loft-like space kinda way, complete w/ high ceilings and a wall tastefully studded w/ a few wild boar heads. The rope light fixtures in the windows couldn't be a better fit for Four Barrel and the artsy bathroom had me all kinds of impressed.

The menu is no fuss, no muss, w/ just a handful of solid options. I went for their latte, which came complete w/ a big, wispy heart. 'sigh' Four Barrel, you have won me over.

But apparently, Four Barrel is quite the little charmer around town. When we arrived, all the tables were chock full of customers. We had to do a little quick maneuvering to snag a table, but once we were settled in, we were all set. 

Overall, Four Barrel is one of my top picks as far as coffee shops go. The only 2 items on my wish list? More seating and Wi-Fi!
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Dear Four Barrel,

the votes are tallied, and  everyone loves you!  congrats! I do too. but seriously what is up with the Dog Policy? Are they allowed or not? I assume not because you serve food and you know, dogs+food= health code violation.  But then I was gingerly served a steaming Americano over a poor pooch's head the other day. so, um, what? Can I bring my dog? Or is it just cool dogs of people you know? 

also, could you put a hook in the bathroom? The floor is always wet and there is no place to hang a jacket, bag, accoutrements.

thank you.

p.s. your coffee is still awesome.
author: Mission S.

description: People can debate their favorite cappuccino in SF (Blue Bottle, Ritual, etc), but I chose Four Barrel.  Disclaimer, I am now a decaf drinker so I have not tasted everything that Ritual has to offer.  Nor do I get triple capps (which some people claim makes Blue Bottle the winner).  Note: if you like your drink being prepared in under 5 minutes, this is not the place for your.  It's amazing how long I have to wait for espresso here and yet I still leave each time smiling.  And no, it's not simply that I am entertained by the hog heads mounted on the wall.
author: Matt G.

description:
Great coffee and a great music selection.  

This is where I learned my son liked metal.  I was in there with him one morning and he starts jumping up and down when they put on Black Sabbath.  What am I supposed to do with this?  My wife and I met at a Reggae club.  I don't think we even own any metal.  

Unfortunately the music comes with a super hipster attitude and lack of wi-fi that keeps this from being a great coffee shop.  Oh well, what else do you expect in the mission?
author: Steve S.

description:
i had an extensive list of coffee shops to visit in san francisco, including four barrel.  i am very much into the specialty coffee art and industry.  i'm sitting there now enjoying my properly-sized 5 oz americano (in which they miraculously serve cappuccinos as well), my third time in.  

i asked myself, "with so many shops to visit in such a short time, how is it that you're back here again and again?" 

then i answered just as quickly, "because the environment is beautiful and cool, the music is good, the employees are friendly and believe in giving the experience of coffee rather than just the cup of it, and everything is delicious."

the one thing that's even questionable about it:
-no outlets for people to work.  BUT-- i also completely understand this move because it gets them more traffic through their limited seating and prevents 'camping.'  i personally would just love to work there. :)

some other things i love about four barrel:
-they use V60s
-they're not afraid to say they don't know an answer to a question
-they'll happily explain everything
-they're well-staffed so they can take time to do those things
-they taught me about versalab grinders
-they use naked portafilters
-they use a record player
-baristas seem to have a nice amount of independence and freedom to their own style

the list goes on.  stop in!
author: Hallie T.

description: Was there resting up, chatting with a great friend. Drank a slow- dripped brewed Costa Rica Tajo. Unique taste, bitterness with bit of tang. Nice environment.
author: Pepe W.

description:
I walked into Four Barrel Coffee and had noticed the spacious interior of this coffeehouse.  This is a great place to relax and drink coffee.

I ordered a Latte which had a robust espresso and was topped off with a very thick frothy steamed milk.  Since I was feeling groggy that morning, it was the perfect wake-up call.

On my way out, they were laying out their selection of Dynamo Donuts.   They looked really good and found myself staring at the case.  Fortunately, I didn't fall under temptation this time but will have to check it out next time.  Thanks guys!
author: Janet H.

description:
Coffee, now with lowered expectations!

This place used to be good when they had the back alley kiosk.  I didn't care that it was 'cozy'.  The coffee was good and the service was straightforward and simple.  Now that they have opened up the main store they have established piss poor processes and hired idiots.

I've gone there two days in a row to give it a second chance.  I will not return.

POOR LAYOUT: The waiting area to receive drinks gets potential customers confused and keeps people in the way of the cream and sugar.

SERVICE: The cashier is not suitable for customer service.  She is too busy chatting it up, and sometimes with people that aren't customers.  The first day I was served quickly, but the guy after me had to wait for her to finish a conversation with someone.  You know what?  He had cash in his hand.  He left.  Then the processor forgot my order.  At Ritual, BlueBottle, etc they never forget your order or which sequence it came in or the details.  The guy apologized and seemed sincere.  He explained that he was distracted by training the not-so-bright cashier.  I suggest thinning the herd.

Second visit: Same cashier, she decided to chat it up with an actual customer this time before taking my order.  Then the processor ( a different person) did my drink after the two other people behind me had their order filled.  And he mixed my order into someone else's order.  This guy used to be on the ball at the kiosk.  Now, different story.

Coffee: good,  on par.

Instead of the fancy decor, they should have put the money into process and selecting better employees.  Is it that hard to hire someone that can multi-task (do you need a GED for that)?
author: H C.

description: I buy my beans from Four Barrel every few weeks.  Definitely on the more expensive side, but you get what you pay for.  Never bitter, never moldy, always extremely high quality beans.  I also love reading the descriptions they provide -- almost wine-type descriptions -- and then trying to gain an appreciation for those subtle flavors when I later drink the coffee at home.
author: Michelle L.

description: While I've professed my allegiance to Team Blue Bottle, sometimes it's nice to pretend like I'm a Cold War spy and get my coffee intel at Four Barrel.  Black, smoky, aromatic goodness up in this business.  I was also sold when I walked into them bumping Rubber Soul...on vinyl.
author: Michael D.

description:
First let me say, this place serves one of the best cups of coffee in SF...right up there with Blue Bottle and Ritual...maybe even better. They share DNA with Stumptown Roasters in Portland. I think all the reviews here may be a bit premature...Four Barrel is about to fire up their own roasting in the store.

Is it perfect? No. No wi-fi. Selection of pastries, etc. is light. These are far easier to rectify than trying to make a better cup. So...if I'm gonna meet somebody for a serious cup of coffee...to talk philosophy without the need of a laptop, I'll just head to Four Barrel and leave connectivity at the door. When the roaster is fired up I'll revisit this review.
author: Gary C.

description:
"Personality goes a long way. " - Samuel Jackson, "Pulp Fiction"

I was ready to give my ENTIRE heart to Four Barrel until:
1) I realized there is no WiFi; and 
2) The guy at the counter looked down on me for asking how much a refill was (as if the assumption that it would be cheaper was outrageous).

Despite these annoyances, however, I still find myself drawn to this place because of the yummy coffee and really ok here it is: the hipster-chic-urban-loft with discordant animal-heads mounted on the wall and oddly-shaped tables with throwback-schoolhouse-like seats.....a microbrewery, artist's loft kind of feel that is so eclectic that it simply does me in... attitude-and-all. Like Hosea, I'm wed to this imperfect beast.
author: Diane B.

description:
Stopped in here for a warm cup o' joe on a frigid walk back home from the Zeitgeist.   Never would have expected to find this spacious urban setting in this location.  High ceilings, modern but warm decor, *excellent* coffee.  Sit at wood plank bar-style tables or sit at the back bar to watch the (live) roasting action.  I was mesmerized.   The spacious unisex restroom features an explosive bouquet of fresh lilies and, best of all, a buck mural on the floor for your viewing pleasure.  
Definitely a hipster venue, but they served me anyway.  Buy some grounds on your way out - you'll not be disappointed
author: Jennifer D.

description:
This place is ok. Coffee is great but the music is kinda loud and the scene kills it for me. Its too young hipsterlicious for me. 
I used to come here every morning but I got tired of trend.  Again, I like the coffee alot because I respect the young guy who started it! Kudos
author: Nene D.

description:
" I need to go pee..."  my friend complained as we're driving around the block to find parking. 

"ohh look...lets go in there..looks like a coffee shop!" I said to her. we went in..she went to the bathroom and I wanted coffee. so I looked around and it was a cool vibe. very different than the normal coffee shop. I got to the register and looked up at the menu and I there was no "vanilla latte, caramel macchiato, white mocha..." so I asked the girl " do you guys have syrup??" or flavored lattes??" she replied "no..sorry we only have chocolate for the mocha. I answered "wow...that's really odd but fine I'll try the cappuccino."

the cup was pretty small but the foam caught my eye. literally it was the prettiest foam I've ever seen in my whole entire life!! I mean it was soo pretty that I needed to take a picture of it...it was thick rich and creamy...no sight of bubbled foam at all. n u know what they say " a barista is only good when they know how to make a good foam.." its true. the coffee was splendid and I'm definitely going back there again...

"ok I'm done..." my friend said.

"ok good..I just found my new favorite coffee shop and all because of you my dear friend."
author: Rika K.

description:
Nothing special...not impressed.  Coffee was NOT strong.  Prices were rather pricey given the product.  Place was noisy...faux hipster, and what was with all the boar head taxodermy on the wall?!

Will go to Soma when it re-opens.
author: L U.

description:
Latest entry in the self-roasting, hipster paradise, ultra high-end coffee shop category. While walking down Valencia looking for this place, we spotted a pile of moped's and fixed-gear bicycles chained up and a bunch of people loitering around in plaid shirts. That's got to be it, (sigh) ... so cliche. In any case, the coffee was pretty good. Very limited drink menu, and milk is only available in the whole or soy varieties. Guess they normally carry Dynamo Donuts, but today was a holiday, so there were none of them and no other food to speak of.

I appreciate that this space seems designed to alienate laptop squatters. No outlets or wifi, and the chairs are uncomfortable. This is a serious coffee joint, get your coffee, enjoy it, and leave. If you want food, wifi, or non-fat drinks ... go somewhere else.
author: Joseph R.

description:
Terrible coffee, no chairs. No Food. Don't go here!

If you all start giving this place good reviews on yelp, twittering about it, blogging about it, eventually it'll end up in the New York Times and then there will be endless lines. 

Also they lie about the hours. It's really only open from 2 to 4pm Tuesdays and Thursdays and after midnight on Monday. Seriously folks... nothing to see here, move along.
author: evan r.

description:
I really don't understand how people have been rating this place so highly. While the inside is certainly spacious and inviting, the coffee lacks any real flavor and seemed pretty bland. The staff is wonderful and very friendly and if the coffee was better I'd give it four stars.

(note: As people have said, this is a cash place. No cards)
author: Andrew F.

description:
The mecca of caffeinated hipsters. 

The layout and general rustic decor is not unlike other Mission cafes, but it's certainly more spacious and generally overwhelming (in a good way). It functions like a well-oiled engine and feels like a natural ecosystem of its own, replete with its coffee-bean flora and hipster fauna. The outdoor structure serves as a two-in-one bike rack; the music system revolves around a vintage record player; and the baristas have mustaches, tattoos, tight black clothing, and often all of the above. Honestly, it all just kind of works well together here. 

And it gets better. 

Unlike many other places (cough cough, Blue Bottle), there's one barista for in-house orders and another for take-out's, which minimizes the waiting time; there are two cashiers in the middle speeding the process up; and all of the coffee is roasted on display in the back, which is just plain neat.

As far as the coffee itself, I loved my de-caf (I know, I know) cappuccino... and, as my husband aptly put it, it was overall expensive, but not overpriced. It was tough -- in fact, impossible -- to find seating indoors on this wintery Sunday afternoon, but we were content to plop down on their outdoor terrace with other fellow coffee drinkers wrapped around their drinks for warmth. It was not short of perfect, really.

There's a reason, I guess, why Four Barrel pops up (second... after Ritual, of course) as the "most hipster coffee place in SF" on Google. Yeah, I went there. It was so worth it.
author: G. J.

description: I am truly in LOVE with this place and the people. Only Four Barrel Coffee has taught me what great coffee is all about!
author: Claudia G.

description: Amazing coffee! The latte was delicious and it was beautifully made!
author: Marie C.

description: I find myself asking, do I wanna drink coffee next to dirty bikes and dogs? NO. Do I wanna hang with the organic youth of Mission street who walk around aimlessly withno cause?NO. Than why would I find myself wandering into this coffee joint? Because it kicks major ass to the max. The decor is in-between a roast house and a wharehouse, the staff is so very kind, even when you walk in looking like you enteredthe wrong place, and the coffee is thebest I've tastedhands down. Their Americanos kick all other coffee house Americanos away. Totally solid joint.
author: Tasha T.

description:
when i feel like splurging on a great cuppa coffee you'll find me here. whether it's hot or iced, their coffee's a robust and full of flavor. i was so impressed i bought some grounds beans for home!

depending on my mood, i can enjoy the spacious layout that doesn't make you feel cramped. kinda looks like a warehouse inside so this place definitely lacks the warm coffee-house feel.
author: Mayson J.

description: Such a great place to enjoy coffee or tea indoors or outdoors. The baristas are friendly and try to get to know the customer. I've only been there once but will surely go back. I went on a warm day so the inside was also warm but they have okay ventilation.
author: Brenda M.

description:
The best thing about this place is also the worst thing, but best outweighs worst, so hence 4 stars.

There's no wifi! A cafe in SF with no wifi? WTF?

But you know what, it works! And I actually managed to get some (real) work done thanks to the lack of electro-distractions.

Good coffee, airy space, mellow ambience, and possibly the most "deco" bog (in UK speak) of any cafe in the city.
author: Richard B.

description:
Incredible coffee from a master roaster, what else do you expect?  Blue bottle in my mind created a standard and Four Barrel has taken that standard, met it and improved on it by using the finest beans to create rich roast with expressions full of fruit and other unique flavors.  If the coffee isn't enough the fact that they serve Dynamo donuts and kick out beats on a vintage hi-fi system should be enough to draw you in.  It was a choice for the proprietor to choose not to offer wi-fi and not have laptop outlets and good on them for that!  There is enough of those locations out there full of people on computers camped out everywhere. 

The fact still remains this is a mellow coffee shop which features different local artist works and offers the finest beans for sale and fresh coffee with zero attitude!  Where else will you find hipsters serving coffee and not serving attitude?
author: Michael M.

description:
They make a great cup of coffee/espresso/whatever, that's for sure. Nice and roomy, although they could do with more seating (I think they're opening up the back area? Or is that just for the roaster?)

The donuts are to die for (try the maple bacon!) and my only complaint are the mopeds parked outside that stink up the joint. God I hate those things. 

Anyhow, a great spot if you need a change from Blue Bottle or RitRo.
author: Veronica B.

description: The coolest thing about this place is the building. It love the architecture and the art on the walls. Really modern and industrial. I also like the bike racks and seating outside. The coffee is really good as well. The major downfall is the pretentious customers and staff that fill the space. I felt judged and unwelcome. It wouldn't be so bad if the staff didn't have the same 'hipster' attitude as their customers. If you ignore the 'too cool' stares, your experience will be better. I'm not sure I'll be a frequent visitor though.
author: Elise M.

description:
This is my favorite coffee spot in the city and my kids love the bran muffins at Four Barrel as well. 
I'd highly recommend Four Barrel for anyone looking for a great cup of coffee!
author: Joyce S.

description: Good coffee. Super laid back.  Epitome of San Francisco coffee scene.
author: Roger H.

description:
Maybe it's just because this rugged cafe is so new, but the menu is stripped down (basic coffee items and some baked goods) and there's no wifi. It's like Ritual Roasters for people who aren't chained to a laptop.

Four mounted boar heads balance out the brightly colored art. The furniture (and the building itself, with exposed wooden rafters) looks hardy and beautiful. And while the counter is arranged a touch sporadically, there's no dark back corner like the sunken couches at Ritual.

I only draw the comparison because Four Barrel will certainly be dubbed the Ritual of the Inner Mission, thanks to a similar aesthetic and clientele, as well as Ritual-style crowd-pleasing drinks (served a bit cooler than usual). If only gentrification always felt so invigorating.
author: Nick D.

description:
On the coffee tour. (why are there so many reviews from confessed non-coffee drinkers?)

I like the feeling of unfinished work, not left undone, just not yet finished. This place is in flux and it's fluxing forward. Exhibit A, the not-yet-working roaster that dominates the place like a Mt Fuji looming over the espresso machina.
