The tables may be my favorite things about 4B Coffee, chunky, simple, narrow. But they're there aren't they? I'd love to have a desk like that. In fact, where the hell did you get those things?

I also like the dueling espresso machines approach. One cashier in the middle and two espresso machines on either side. This place seems built to beat the crowds--though I didn't experience a crowd. The lines pulsed like VU meters, but never seemed static.

THE DETAILS:

My espresso, though it was served to me quickly from barrista al' izquierda was not hot. Not sure why, it just came out of the machine that way. Taste was very good. Light brown color. Good aroma. Pretense low. But the bottom line was that my first cup there was imperfect. My friend met me later, and didn't want an espresso, saying that their beans are too bitter for him. Funny, because we went there at his behest. We talked a long while.

Later, I had another. This one from different barrista (a la derecha) and it was hot and good and perhaps bitter, but I appreciate a wide variety of espresso tastes--and so I did just that.

The overall vibe is relax. I still can't get over having an espresso in what used to be a war zone just 14 years ago. Even less. So, can't quite get the condos from across the street out of my head. Didn't that used to be public housing?

Finally, on my way out at the end of this in came the chicks with the donuts. Smiling like they must be the most popular chicks in 8th grade with those donuts. What appeared to be pistachio covered, iced, cake, and on and on. But sorry ladies. You gotta bring fucking donuts in the AM. I left at 11am. Perhaps these were afternoon or lunchtime donuts. They looked good as I passed them.
author: Thomas R.

description: I'm giving it 3: 1 for the coffee, 5 for the hot chocolate=3 on average. The first time there I got a mocha. It had a bit of an acid taste. I thought it was the chocolate, but this time I got a hot chocolate and it was DELICIOUS!!! Dark and Creamy. I tasted my bf's coffee and it tasted acidic. So now I know! The sweets are delicious too...don't think they make them there though. It is a FUN place to go however, and the staff is SUPER NICE!!! and friendly. So, we'll be back...and my BF likes the coffee...so it's just my personal taste...I like a more nutty flavor. Oh and every time we're here we get parking right in front - Yay for that!!
author: L Z.

description: Coffee was phenomenal but the lady on the register is a big turn off, she wears a sleeveless shirt and i can see her armpit hair.... very unsanitary.. If you work in a beverage/food industry wear something pleasing and not disturbing...
author: Ar L.

description: Tried their iced, non-fat latte. One word: yummy!  Located in a very trendy looking building, with trendy looking people buying coffee- I guess its hard to be serving bad coffee here.  Good for Four Barrel Coffee.  I'm a fan.  Saw their coffee actually being served at a frozen yogurt shop in palo alto recently.  I hope they do really well as I'm not a fan of blue bottle coffee (what's up wit dat??).  Go Four Barrel!
author: Steven D.

description:
The bad:  Not really the most comfortable place to sit, and thus not an ideal study spot.  Don't bother bringing your laptop - there's no wi-fi or plugs.  And while this doesn't bother me so much, the trendy hipster crowd will also most certainly be another strike against this place for some people.

The good:  the coffee, the coffee, the coffee, and did I mention the coffee?  It's not as awesome as you've heard - it's better.  On a scale of 1 to 5, this averages out to 5 stars:  3 stars for the ambiance, and 7 stars for the coffee.
author: John L.

description: I love me some coffee. LOVE IT. And in San Francisco, the choices for a good roast leave a humble consumer to ask, "What's the difference?" Honestly, I can't taste whether there are hints of caramel or tangerine or bowling alley floor in your roast, but I know that I appreciate a smile from the person serving me, and that is something  that can be missing from other coffee spots in town. The old adage about surly and apathetic baristas can be true, and it's not a good look. More than once, I have received a free cup from someone at Four Barrel because I had to wait a few minutes for them to press a new brew. I will gladly stare at cool art and mounted animal heads for a free coffee. And when I do pay, 2 bucks for their excellent product is fine with me. Four Barrel makes me happy to live in San Francisco.
author: Patrick V.

description: Drip coffee and espresso beans both taste like a blend if plum and dirt. Not my cup of tea...no pun.
author: Victor C.

description:
I'd heard good things about this place, so a friend and I decided to give it a go yesterday (after one aborted attempt by me when I just couldn't deal with the lineup of yuppie/hipster-types and the bacon-topped donuts staring me in the face). Unfortunately, Four Barrels didn't live up to the hype. 

Honestly, I don't get it. The coffee was actually gross. It had the same dull taste that you find in gas-station or even instant coffee, and the first few sips actually whiffed mildly of vinegar: off putting! I was willing to forgive the mounted animal heads on the wall and the really pretty poorly laid out space (my friend and I agreed that there was no way 4B needs 280 square feet of space to accommodate potential lineups) and EVEN the bacon-topped donuts and complete lack of vegan food items if the coffee had been all that, but it wasn't. Sigh. Such is life, I guess, and now continues my search for a favorite coffee hole.

Sorry, Four Barrels. Check your coffee, and throw us vegans a cookie or muffin or donut or something, and I'll be your devoted slave forever (even with those stupid narrow tables where my knees awkwardly hit my coffee partner's), but until then, adieu.
author: Jordan P.

description: Espresso mixed with ice cream.  Enough said.  Na I'll say some more.  Seating is tight and almost impossible.  Really cool to see the coffee getting roasted in the back.  Funky fun place to chill out, better than any coffee shop in the city just cuz of the open floor plan.  That's enough, after all it is just coffee.
author: A A.

description:
Gotta love the Cracker Barrel, although I wish that the alley-way service still existed. The coffee is high-quality, the menu selection is simple, the doughnuts are delightful, my soy lattes are made on point most of the time, and the foam designs always look nice. The barista(s) is so good that he can even foam-design a moped. Crazy huh? This place has personality and a great music selection, rather than those humdrum corporate coffee huts. 

And someone please clarify... is this place a hybrid of Stumptown Coffee or whaaaa?
author: Lea S.

description: No lines + killer beans = good times. This place is gonna be more packed than Ritual when it opens it's doors so hit the back alley and enjoy. Looking forward to home roasted beans and Dynamo Donuts.
author: Phil M.

description:
The decor screams, "WE ARE SERIOUS. SERIOUS ABOUT COFFEE." It's a glorious, impressive interior and a sleek shop but the ambiance far outstrips the coffee, unfortunately.

I am dying for a staple coffee shop near my new home in the mission so I was disappointed by the fact that their espresso wasn't interesting enough to become habit forming; the Americanos I've had here don't have the excessively creamy or fruity characteristics I've come to expect and were flat by comparison to my former Seattle staples.

They just need to raise the espresso to the level of their decor and they're golden...
author: Alan F.

description:
Really REALLY good. 4 stars because it is in a great location, has nice and plentiful seating, AWESOME coffee (and the best iced coffee ever... strong AND with amazing coffee taste and character), good prices. Only reasons you don't get 5 stars:
1. I went out of my way with heavy bags to go here once and you were closed during normal business hours for an improptu pow wow that was not posted online at all (I had checked before walking over, and didnt have my phone to call)... stupid, I know, but sad for me
2. Not a fan of the boar heads on the wall. Too freaky and not very animal/work/sanity friendly
3. The whole heavy metal thing. I want a place to drink coffee and read/talk quietly in peace. Music is fine but something conducive to intelligent thoughts, not head banging

You beat Blue Bottle any day of the week though! Yay!
author: Amanda S.

description:
By golly. My friend is a genuis! Genuis I tell ya! Its a wonder this woman is still single! She's smart, funny, not bad to look at, and has a great palate for coffee! Anyhoo, enough of my match.com tirade! 
She took me here for a coffee that changed my life. Decaf latte. Smooth, balanced, and with just the right amount of foam. Heavenly. 
The ambiance is kick ass to boot. Wild boar heads on the walls, tables that look like they are made from old railroad ties, and a huge roaster in the back. Awesome. I wish she had shown me this place earlier...but then again she might just save it for special occassions with special people! No wonder I was left out of that equation.
author: Stacy T.

description: Nothing over $4. Prices start amazingly low at $2 and go up from there. Extra $0.50 for soy. Baristas making fresh coffee as you order while more beans are being roasted in the back. I prefer the hot mocha over iced mocha since the sugar doesn't melt with iced drinks. Pet-friendly. Kid-friendly.
author: Anne T.

description:
Great coffee!  I mean Really Great Coffee!  I am so glad this place is here!  I drink Four Barrel every morning at home.  And on weekends I bike here to enjoy a cup or two in-house and watch the "hipsters" troll through on their fixed gears.  

The doughnut delivery girl is fun to watched to, not for the "hot" factor so much as that she delivers the doughnuts by bike.  

Come and see the staff make and grind the coffee!  Enjoy delicious doughnuts and other tasty treats!
author: dianthe h.

description: The best coffee shop I visited in San Francisco! It's dog-friendly, they play great tunes on vinyl, all coffee prepared by french press or glass drip, and has lots of comfy space to kick back and enjoy your delicious coffee and/or a pastry. My boyfriend and I both had mocha lattes and shared a chocolate chip cookie - only the "chips" were crumbled pieces of oreo cookie. HELLO GENIUS! I wanted to fold this place up, put it in my pocket, and take it home with me.
author: Patricia S.

description:
The Emperor's New Clothes = Stumptown = 4 Brl

Stumptown is inherently pansy because, fundamentally, there's nothing there.  Sufferin suc-ass drip.

SOS industrial design with the added bonus of Why Don't You Go Over There and Grab One of the Thousand Bags on the Wall Yourself.  The coffee makers (I refuse to say baristas) don't know what's up there and how it tastes because it ain't their merde.  "Plummy" does not describe jo, morons; it's not supposed to taste like a friggin late harvest Frog Hollow fruit.  
At least make a half-assed attempt at marketing like that florid roccoco shit they write at Blue Balz.
author: Peter A.

description:
listen, the coffee is expensive but good. i always grab a guatamala blend and justify the price by how cool i look carrying the tiny bag around SF.  the ambience of the cafe is strictly artsy hipster and most people appear cooler once they step in.  

i buy pounds of coffee here when i am in the neighborhood and a grab donut when it feels right.  sometimes, if i am feeling especially wild, i sit out on the parklet and buy vegan tacos from the dude that posts outside sometimes.

the baristas are williamsburg-cute and equally friendly.  i like the spacious, open floorplan of the cafe and the art displayed.  everyone should stop in at least once, it smells so good inside.
author: Carmel U.

description:
The coffee here is amazing. I've tried many coffee shops in San Francisco and hail from Seattle. Coffee is a raison d'etre for sure and this place provides not only wonderful delicious smooth artisan coffee but great rock tunes and you can still talk. The space is lovely, lots of wood with funny craft-project metal seats. I could spend long periods of time just due to the calm vibe there, the music and the coffee.

On the downside, I am not a huge fan of the chairs though I like the concept of the place and 2.50 for one small simple organic donut Jesus Christ! There is absolutely no justification for it and it reminds me why I should poke the economy in the ribs by not spending anything.

I've tried all of the coffee shops in the area, I have a favorite not going to say which one since this is about Four Barrel, but I will choose Four Barrel happily over my favorite to mix it up. The service is good and unpretentious and always on point, I like the vibe of the place. 

It might be due to the space but probably of any coffee shop I've ever been to, this place reminds me most of what it feels like when hanging out with friends, this could very well be someone's pad, if it weren't a business.

...

I'll probably go out of my way to stop into Stumptown when I drive up the coast to Portland next week as my first destination because coffee is  that important, coffee in hand you can get a lot done, amazing coffee you can really do anything.

Worth mentioning is the Stumptown coffee served is fair trade so you can feel good supporting businesses which help serve someone other than just themselves, it might sound trivial but you read about Rwanda (check out Bikes for Rwanda by the way which I just read about: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stumptown_Coffee_Roasters) underpaid workers on the news and shake your head but here's a tangible way to help funnel money toward the right ideas just by drinking amazing coffee, funneling your cash toward one vendor who cares over another who serves his own pocket solely, it's a no brainer.
author: Magdalena G.

description:
My partner and I have given up calling "Four Barrel" by its name. Instead, we prefer "the Moose Lodge" --  thusly named for its twee hunting lodge aesthetic. Apt moniker, I think.

They're not consistent, but when it's good, it's spectacular. 

I took home a bag of Kenya AA -- the fragrance is unbelievable, and the coffee even better.
author: T.-A S.

description:
Yummy soy lattes. Spacious environment in the Mission district. Fun to sip coffee while people watching next to a big window. 

Limited selection of pastries and cash only.
author: Lisa W.

description: Hard to find a spot to sit but incredibly cute and busy place in the Mission...the expresso is good
author: Jamie T.

description:
I love coffee. Period.  I will try any joint that looks like they have great coffee or proports themselves to have great coffee.  I have gone on train rides and bus rides and long walks to get to places that supposedly serve the area's finest cup (depending on what area I am in).
That being said, I, of course, knew about 4 Barrel, I just hadn't made it out there yet.  After reading about their high marks in Travel + Leisure, however, I knew I could no longer be the lame-o that doesn't know.
This place makes a fine cup of coffee (*all I have had is a standard cup; no espresso drinks). The thing that is really stand-out, however, is there treats, namely, their donuts.  They make, what I would like to call, a grown-ups donut.  Meyer Lemon, Chocolate Anise, Pear/Molassas/Guiness (yea, you read that right).  The donuts are expensive at $3 a pop, but hell, good--it keeps me from eating lots of donuts.
This place pretty close to "has it all." Very nice atmosphere; lots of wood furnishings and old metal, high ceilings, very clean.  Neat parklets outside wear you can sit and enjoy your coffee and treats! 
And a bit of a cherry on top that is growing to be an unfortunate must-notation: the people here are NICE (unlike Blue Bottle, bastian of the silent judgement, or worse, Ritual, a company from whom I will not buy coffee again despite the tasty quality because several of their employees have unbelieveable problems with not being dicks).  Good service with genuine smiles and "Hey, how's it goin?"s......not condesending smirks and silent judgements of my clothing.
I didn't give it 5 stars because it wasn't a life-changing experience with the coffee.  I'm strict about that one.
author: Lila G.

description:
San Francisco has lots of good coffee shops. San Francisco also has a lot of douchebags. And it seems to be that there seems to be some magnetic attraction between the coffee shops in the Mission and the douchbags that inhabit them at all hours of the day. 

Thankfully, Four Barrel seems to be flying a bit under the radar now, which is, in fact, fantastic because I can go there and get top-tier coffee and pastries and not have to feel ashamed for not looking like a douchebag. 

From my perspective, great coffee isn't that hard to find in the city, it's just all the crap that you have to do to get to the good coffee places that annoys me. I don't want to have to wait in line in a shaded, windy, cold, narrow alley to get coffee from behind a roll-up door and I don't want to smell dirty hipsters that haven't showered in days while they've been biking all around or deal with the attitude associated with either. So yea, four barrel is where I go. For now.
author: Joe K.

description:
Just phone banked for Obama here, the people who work here couldn't be cooler. Despite all the chaos and demanding people wanting coffee (oh, it was also raining and packed), the baristos--pretend thats a word--were quick and so nice. 

The lattes were dreamy the croissants were perfectly flaky and buttery, not too buttery, don't worry I know how you like your croissants.

A lil $, but live a lil...this shit is fantastic.
author: Alison D.

description:
I thought Ritual was great, then I found Blue Bottle. I thought Blue Bottle was awesome, then I found 4 Barrel! WOW, they are def tops in my book for the smoothest, richest espresso in SF.

Do it, You'll love it!
author: neil c.

description:
Ritual who??

OK, Ritual's tasty and all, but I know I'm going to have a much longer relationship with Four Barrel. Finally made it out yesterday with an out-of-town friend, and FB hits it on friendliness (add to their foreign currency collection!), spaciousness (large space, good number of tables and stools), design (natural woodsy furniture), and most important of course, taste.

I tried the macchiato. Zing!! Strong and hearty, yet smooth and flavorful. Great to find a cup that robust without tasting burnt, muddy, or acidic.

We also tried the maple bacon Dynamo donut. Heaven.

I just wish they had actual food. But the lack of snacks is pretty negligible. Overall, fantastic!
author: shirin s.

description:
Okay--The Good:

1-Lattes, though served a little cooler than I'm used to? Tasty. Very, very, tasty. 
2-The space--Incredible. Just beautiful. Well used, large, open, airy, and comfy, all the same. 
3-The Music--Always playing cool, old records. 
4-The Bacon Donut---I've had a bit, so weird, so awesome it works. 

The Bad:

1-Full of hipsters. I don't mind hipsters (or any people en masse) however, I receive glares and stares when I walk in there in my work attire (I'm a teacher, not a stockbroker).  And before you say it, I wish it was only in my mind, but it's happened to many times to at least make note of it. 
2-Regular coffee is, at best, a C-. It's really, really sad they can't do it. 
3-This is an obscure complaint--but their sizes? Small. Really, really small. This is much more personal, but in the morning, I like a 16 oz. coffee. 

See? More good than bad. I read a review written by someone else who said they were rooting for the place, and I am 100% behind that. That part of Valencia street, which is my neighborhood, has really begun to bustle, and this is one of the most fortunate additions. They've gotta step it up!
author: Chad G.

description:
Yeah man!

Great coffee, cool atmosphere.  Lots of natural light, lots of wood, coolest tables in the world, really creepy boar heads, and good looking staff.

I've been here twice now, once for a latté to go, and today for a regular coffee for there but in a to-go cup.  So irresponsible of me, I know.  Get over it.

They have lots of seating, but not many of those seats are open...  Which is always a good thing I suppose...  I found a chill spot in the corner by the window, and got to work on Atlas Shrugged.  For it being busy, I was able to feel really comfortable in there and managed to get lost in my book, which is more than I can say for other cafes in the area...  I'm sure it helps that Ayn Rand is a good author.

They serve dynamo donuts which are always an interesting mix of flavors, and again...  the coffee is delicious.

They only offer up soy or cream, and I believe only have raw sugar???  Just an FYI for you non-fat, non-real-sugar heads...  but if you need to mask the flavor of your coffee that much, why bother??

Also, they're cash only and they do not have wifi, which at first kind of bothered me, but then when I actually THOUGHT about it, I realized that it makes me love them even more.  Do your facebook crap at home, no one needs to see that.
author: Jess R.

description:
I will admit, it took me awhile to grow into the taste of this coffee. Different extraction processes make it very strong...more so than your average coffee house but very high end beans. All of the staff is very knowledgeable, ie. how the beans are grown, their country of origin, etc. 

These guys really know their stuff. You can't order a breve macchiatto just anywhere. Def not for your average coffee drinker. This is an acquired taste, connoisseurs only!
author: Brendon M.

description:
I asked my friend for a good coffeeshop recommendation around the Mission, and she told me, "Go to Three Boar. It's new. They roast their coffee on the premises. It's rad."

So we walked around looking for this fabulous Three Boar place she was raving about, and couldn't find it. We google mapped it. We yelped it. We searched high and low, and then we called her back. "All i can find around here is spot called Four Barrel," I told her. "That's IT!" she said, "There are three boarheads on the wall. So I got confused. Teehee!" 

My feet were sore and my brain was decaffineited (sp?), so I was ready for just about anything that involved chairs and espresso. But Four Barrel was oh-so-much more. Indeed there were three boar's heads on the wall, and indeed there was a huge coffee roaster in the back. There were also skylights, an expansive yet busy space that looked rugged yet sophisticate and a simple menu of coffee drinks. The Americano hit the spot, and I would have bought a pound if I had any room in my suitcase. 

To mix metaphors, the wild goose chase ended up with the golden egg.
author: Anita S.

description: The espresso was nearly undrinkable without a good dose of cream and sugar (heresy in Italy).  Tragically hip - 'The Herd' in presence.  To paraphrase Ruth Reichl:  The coffee's bad, but at least the service is slow.'
author: Sam C.

description:
I had a great experience here.  They were quite busy, and I'm a bit fiddly when it comes to my coffee order.  Considering past barista experiences (Blue Bottle, Sightglass, and Philz - though it's a stretch to call the staff at Philz a barista), I'm prepared to get the frustrated vibe from counter help.  The kids down at Four Barrel remained friendly and informative throughout.  At the main counter, I asked for something they don't offer.  Hey, you can always ask, right?  In an extremely friendly way, they explained I was a bit off menu, but they could work it out just for me, because I'm awesome and they care deeply.  Well, maybe it wasn't quite all that, but it was definitely friendly.  I was directed to the other counter.  This is the 'slow' order stand, where a single cup was carefully crafted just for me.  The guy working that counter didn't have the beans I wanted, but said 'no prob' and walked back to the roastery to get me what I asked for.   I love that. 

As a general rule, if a place serves great coffee, plan on not being able to get a seat.  Makes sense, right?  Four Barrel seems to be no exception to this rule, as it was packed and lively when I was there.  If your criteria includes quiet, or the need to let you set up shop at a table, you better plan ahead, or pick a place with less demand.
author: A B.

description:
Zen of Coffee.  Pure and simple.

I had just returned from Italy when a friend took me to four barrel. It was great to find a place that serves Italian style coffee in pure form. No six layers of choice to muddle through. Real coffee. Real milk. Real cups and saucers. Not quite enough seating, but we managed to find a table for a couple hours. Of course, in Italy, to save a few euros, one would toss back the bean juice while standing at the bar, talking to amici and gesticulating wildly about something or other.   The genteel barista actually apologized for being a bit shaky (it was Sunday), but I noticed no flaw in his heart-shaped foam.  

And of course, my northern-raised heart was happy to find the deer frolicking on the bathroom walls under a lovely chandelier.  

A final word, watch out for those who are unaware and will swipe your cappuccino from under your nose, believing it to be theirs. Ah, the entitlement issues around here. Some people never pay attention to where they are in the line... always thinking they're first up. But no worries, our barista soon had a perfect cup ready for my friend.
author: Paula A.

description:
I judge coffee houses by the quality of their drip coffee - and this place has a great, not-bitter brew with a subtly silty body, so that ranks as cool for me.  $2 for a cup, and $1 for every refill thereafter...

But the thing I appreciate most about this place is that they don't have Wi-Fi, meaning people actually unplug from their gadgets and Talk To Each Other.

Is human connection now ironic enough for the hard-core hipsters?  Wow.
author: Anna H.

description:
So I used to live across from Four Barrel, and I loved it.  The coffee is consistently good, and the employees are all down to earth.  I went in the morning of my birthday and asked if they'd give me a free cup if I told them it was my birthday.  Well needless to say, they did!

I absolutely LOVE mornings when they have bacon donuts in stock.  I wish EVERYDAY were bacon donut day.

So why the four stars?  It is such a scene full of hipsters who love to give you that look "What are you doing here?".  Four Barrel, I love your coffee, I love your staff, but I think a lot of your clientele is "douche-y".
 
Eh -- that's why you order coffee to go.
author: Avery H.

description:
One star for the coffee, which had to be one of the worst cups I have had at a coffee shop.  Starbucks mops the floor with it.  Heck, it was worse than the diner coffee I had earlier that same day.  And don't tell me I don't know good coffee.  I've lived in some major coffee producers and been to some of the fincas were the really premium places get their beans.  This was not good coffee by any measure I know.  

It does, however, get five stars if you want to make fun of absurdly-dressed hipsters.  The humor value alone was worth the price of the mediocre coffee.  Thumbs up to the mounted animal heads as well.
author: Brent C.

description:
The espresso here is very, very good.  This isn't surprising, because it's one of Stumptown's spicy blends (how I do miss the Pacific Northwest when it comes to coffee.)  It'll be interesting to see what happens once their own roasting operation starts up.  In the meantime, this is definitely one of the best choices for really good coffee in this city.  

The cafe is lovely, too -- beautiful wood tables, though the height is a bit awkward (sit at the bar instead).  Four Barrel is not a place for setting up to park it for hours of work/study (no WiFi, no outlets, etc.)  Not that I don't sometimes bring my laptop for a few hours of distractionless dissertating.  But it's far better to come here with a good read -- or a good friend -- on one of those foggy-gray San Francisco days and let the urban hunting lodge ambiance, wonderfully dark bubbly crema, and whatever classic rock record is in play all seep in and work their magic.  Your foggy-gray San Francisco soul will thank you.
author: Lulu W.

description:
Your local coffee house... ON STEROIDS!

The coffee is awesome, let's establish that.

I felt rather tepid about the rest.  I felt they could've used more seating, this place is huge.  I don't know that I'd call it comfy but it works.

Also, if you're going for cheap, you may want to turn somewhere else.  A pedestrian mug of coffee goes for $2 with refill coming in at $1.  Not a big complaint for me, but just thought i'd throw that one out there.
author: Steven R.

description: Really excellent coffee.  Somewhat long lines. HOWEVER, watch your stuff!  I had my screen protector for my laptop stolen from me while I was sitting there with it.  Some hipster snagged it for his Macbook Pro.
author: Richard L.

description:
I wanna ask you: What the EFF is wrong with hipsters?  If you don't want to see them, stop going to places that were opened up by hipsters!  And shuddap!  Stop yelping about how you hate them.  I'm sick of hipster-haters on Yelp.  It's not like they killed your puppy.  They just love American Apparel hoodies.  And?

Anyhoo, with that said, I like this place and I don't care what you look like.  Just give me the fucking yummy 4 barrel coffee.  Hi Jeremy!
author: aleks k.

description:
Beautiful space!  I got a bag of coffee to take home.  I asked for a recommendation from the guy bagging the beans.  He didn't have much info to offer -- but that may have to do with the fact that I said I really like dark roasts.  They don't do any dark roasts.  Too bad.  

Okay, here's the other thing.  Now, am I being suspicious?  The coffee he recommended was the most expensive one they have.  I felt like a sucker at the cash register.  I did, however, partake in a salted caramel doughnut.  NICE!

Bottom line, if you like the south or central American fruity roasts, go for it.  If you like the hair on your chest Euro roasts, forget it.
author: S S.

description: Probably the worst cup of coffee I've had in years and this counts the diners I've frequented. I got a mocha that was sans any coffee and the bottom of the cup was a generous portion of gelatinous and flavorless chocolate. Ugh. My wife's cappuccino tasted like burnt and old coffee. I don't know what they hype is all about other than a room full of tragic hipsters and lousy coffee.
author: Kevin C.

description: Coffee seems to rule every part of my life. I'm a barista at 2 different coffee shops, and even though I live in the inner sunset, on my days off or any time in between classes and work, I go all the way out to Four Barrel for coffee. I love it that much. I will drag my ass out of my warm bed, get on the N, and travel all the way to Four Barrel for their espresso. The baristas are friendly, the line moves fairly quick, and the space is absolutely beautiful (I love wood).
author: Catface G.

description:
USE THE RESTROOM AND CHECK OUT THE JUNGLE FLOOR

that could be a solid review on its own, but in order to be most helpful, i am going to include that...
if one has not been to Uncle Randolph's hunting den in recent years and misses the boar heads, then a visit to Four Barrel is in order.
sit at the bar in the back where you can watch Johny plaid shirt with PF Fliers bag and stamp your beans (oooh, does that turn anyone else on?)
it's also pretty charming how closely you get to sit to other folks at those plank tables in front.
kiss me, four barrel, and be kind to my heart.
goddam, i get carried away with these reviews... they're addicting
author: Raven K.

description:
five stars on atmosphere! they did such a great job designing this place. no matter how crowded it is, it doesn't feel cramped. also loved the parklet outside, complete with bike racks. (wish we could adopt this concept in houston). 

our coffee came relatively quickly -- i got a cappuccino & my friend, who brought me here, got a latte. no complaints.. adorable place! love that they roast their own coffee.
author: lauren c.

description:
They have Dynamo Donuts, and their espresso shots are awesome.  Same goes for their latte.

Jeremy (the owner) is awesome.  I wish he was there more rather than this one girl that works there.  My friend and I walked in just casually talking with one of the bearded guys that work there (cool guy), and my friend asked about the new beans and "this one girl that works there" butted-in and pretentiously said, "You have to buy those beans."

My friend and I were thinking "wtf!?"
I have dykey friends are nice, but she wasn't.

Despite those damn wanna-be hipster yups that looks like every other wanna-be hipster yups, this place still gets 5 stars because the espresso is awesome and Jeremy's a way cool guy.
author: Winton W.

description: great location and atmosphere !! but I only really love the latte .. the drip coffee has this weird tangy taste to me .. great place to meet friends !
author: Micah W.

description: will not mention anything about the crowd , and who they seem to cater to because the coffee is awesome . People working here in all their coolness , are usually not assholes . STRONNNNG LIKE I LIKE IT, meow!
author: Lauren V.

description:
Yes the coffee is very good, but what about those of us who want something OTHER than coffee now and then?  Like, tea, for example?  Would it really destroy the "purity" of your "coffeehouse" to keep a couple boxes of various teas on the counter and offer them with a mug of hot water?

I really like the vibe of this place and would love to hang out here more often--the fact that they don't have Wi-Fi means I could take my computer here and ACTUALLY GET SOME WORK DONE!  But are they okay with me just hanging out and not buying anything?  If I explain there's nothing on their menu that I want, that even their DECAF coffee gives me the jitters, do you think they'd still let me just hang out?  What if I just left some $$ in the tip jar?

Incidentally, the few times I have been in here, service has been very friendly.

Everyone should lean on Four Barrel to expand their menu.  Non-coffee drinkers are people too!
author: Kevin H.

description:
I wanted to meet up with my friend to get some coffee because it was cold out. If I'm not at home or work, I usually get my coffee at a chain coffee shop or a casual cafe... But just because I don't spend a ton of money doesn't mean I don't love coffee. I really do love it. The good, the bad, the mediocre. 
I went here and the music was really ridiculously loud. I bought a mug of coffee for $2.73. That is probably the most I have spent on coffee for a long time (maybe ever?), but whatever. I sat down at the counter facing the area that they roasted their beans in and a couple of the workers gave me weird stares. Really?
It was hot so I waited a minute. I was also waiting for my friend and I didn't have that much money, so I decided to let my coffee cool off. When I took my first sip, the aroma was really offputting... I couldn't tell initially what the smell and aftertaste was, but after a while I realized that it tasted like my mom's tomato soup.
Now it would be one thing if it was like caffeinated tomato soup. That sounds really gross, but it was way better than coffee that tastes like tomato soup. It was gross, and I tried my best to finish my coffee, but a 3/4ths of the way through I just couldn't take it anymore. I lightweight wanted to puke. The aroma and aftertaste had become so strong the further I got, the more disgusted I became with myself and my need to drink this coffee. My friend had ordered some coffee too. She isn't a big fan of coffee and she could barely get through a 1/4 of her mug.
I went over to the barista and started talking to her about the coffee. She went on to explain how coffee really comes from fruit and how tomatoes are also fruits. I knew this already, but at least she knew her stuff (kind of). She then went to say that it was from Guatemala. That still didn't explain why it tasted like tomato soup. She did say that every day they switch out their blend, which is good. She did also say that I wasn't the first person to say it tasted like tomato... Are you serious? Some people actually like this shit? She mentioned she wasn't a fan, and I appreciated her honesty. She then asked how I felt about it, and I said I thought it was gross. She then said that the espresso was way milder and doesn't have the tomato taste and offered me an americano for free because she thought I might like it.
That was probably the best part of this experience. The barista was nice and somewhat knowledgeable and was willing to give me something for free. She even thanked me for not drinking all the coffee. I probably would have if it didn't make me want to puke. I would have stopped earlier, but I was pretty tired and I needed my caffeine fix. 
So I got my americano. I tipped because of my weird tipping policy that negates the fact that they had two glass milk containers stuffed with tips and really I was saying "thank you" for the service. I then sat down. The americano was strong and kept me up way too late... But it still kind of tasted like tomato soup. Not to the point where I wanted to puke, but the aftertaste was slightly there.
I don't know if I want to come back here. If I do, I hope the coffee does not taste like soup again.
author: Dale S.

description: It is so fun to sit on those new seats in the coffee drinking parklet outside!  We perched on the high wooden things and drank our drinks!  Great people watching, a public bathroom with deer wallpaper on the floor, and an area to watch them roasting coffee.  So many hipsters on bikes!  CRAZY!!!!
author: Julia D.

description:
Amazing Coffee and super-friendly staff.
THE perfect soy-latte hands down.
author: JawkDNA X.

description:
Definitely my current favorite coffee shop in San Francisco. Amazing coffee and amazing espresso drinks. All espresso-based drinks are double shot only (se eno complaints here). Very cool decor and just a great spot to hang out and enjoy your drink. It was surprising to me to read reviews of bad service because everytime I've been here everyone has been super friendly. 

The space is very open, so even when it's packed, it never feels crowded.
author: Jon N.

description:
The menu is pure and simple.  

They don't have skim milk (which I would usually count against them except I did coffee catering for a while and I learned that steaming skim milk just doesn't work as well so Four Barrel is authentic in their coffee making hence why they kept the star)

The crowd and staff are uber hipster...I'm pretty sure I saw at least 3 people reading Jack Kerouac last time I was there..

The barista's make really pretty designs in your latte. Done and done..
author: Ariana K.

description: After drinking coffee at Sight Glass I wasn't expecting to find something that good here.  I was fortunately taking the scenic route and stumbled into Four Barrel.  I had a macchiato and an espresso, both of which made it worth coming all the way out here from NC...
author: Justin T.

description: The natural morning light and energetic young crowd make for a positive coffee experience. Great for people watching too.
author: Stacy W.

description: I'll keep this short and sweet: great coffee, cool decor, really nifty public seating outside. GO GO GO!  I have yet to try the pastries, but the 7x7 list said that the doughnuts are definitely something to have.
author: Jerome R.

description: This place is def the best coffee store in SF! Good service, cool atmosphere, and did I mention? Most AMAZING coffee I've ever had!
author: Arjun G.

description: Good but not great espresso here - maybe somewhere above ritual but not as good as Blue Bottle.  I appreciated the multiple baristas compared to other places, but it still took a long time and there weren't many people in front of me.  I wish it was possible to buy some of the freshly roasted beans coming from the roaster but they want you to buy what's on the shelf first.  Restroom was nice.
author: Albert H.

description:
the french press house coffee is always weak and paltry in flavor.

a snooty coffee house with shitty house coffee!?

the espresso drinks are good and the dynamo donuts are great.


look up the word pretentious and the dictionary says: see 4 barrel

wow cool.... all the guys wear tshirts 4 sizes too small, they have facial hair and horn rimmed glasses. 

eeewww, they have a record player... wow whats that!?

and i swear every time i am there they are literally playing the same t-rex record.
 hahaha

i go in there for the hand poured coffee, and a donut and get the fuck out immediately.
author: midas r.

description:
I had a one of the best lattes I have had in I can't remember how long.
As Arnold said.  "I'll be back!b
Only down side was no cards, cash only.  For Business the cards thing is better for me.  But it's not about me so I will go back.
I like this place.
author: Manuel G.

description:
Delicious Stumpstown iced and hot lattes, and the owners/staff (men so far) are hot.  They replaced a garden center in upper Berkeley that I used to go to for excellent indoor houseplants and succulents.  

The only thing is the place is to close at 8/9pm which makes me sad since it looks to be a nice place to hang out while I inject caffeine into my body.  I wonder if there will be delicious food to quell the shakes I get from delicious coffee
author: Diana L.

description: Amazing coffee! Its a coffee where you can actually taste the complex flavors of the beans (even the Decaf). During the mid-day they have a coffee bar where you can experience their fancy approach to brewing a cup of coffee. The experience of making the cup may not be for everyone, but the resulting flavor sure is. Especially when they only charge $2.5-$3 for it.
author: Daren D.

description:
The drip coffee was a bit bitter for my taste. But I will be back to try the espresso drinks and the fantastic donuts from Dynamo. 

Servers were not that friendly though and the place is so hip it hurts.
author: Maya F.

description:
Never heard of it?!??!?!

9/9/08:

OH there it is.

So, Four barrel finally opened (OK, so I'm like a couple of months late) and i finally got the chance to check it out the other day with some blank pieces of paper and a self-help book.

First of all the interior of this place is pretty awesome.  One of my favorite features are the rope sculptures that also serve as the chandeliers above the front windows.  My second favorite feature is the floor of the bathroom.  I love the deer and duck nature/hunting scene.  But the whole place is pretty to look at.  Lots of big chunky pieces of reclaimed wood; i love how the tables jut out of the walls and the school house chairs.  Exposed wood beam ceilings.  Ultra-cool modern espresso machines.  I like the three little pigs and bear heads on the north wall (I guess they all got theirs).  Decently interesting art on the wall.  Even the coffee manufacturing machinery in the back looks cool.   This definitely ain't no cushy couch relaxation station coffee shop, but it's a cool place to hang out for a bit.

The baristas behind the counter are pretty nice and my latte... not too bad.  Nicely roasted with a lot of flavour.  A little pricey at 3.50 a pop, but that's just compared to my standby cuppa.  I'll definitely be back for some good times with something warm and brown.
author: Adrian L.

description:
In an ironic twist, my bf -- a confirmed coffee-hater -- seems to be the pied piper of hipster coffee joints. His last apartment was at 6th and Howard, and while he was living there, Blue Bottle opened their new-ish Mint Plaza branch, just a bean's throw away from his place. 

A few weeks ago, he moves to 16th and Mission, and lo and behold, Four Barrels pops up. 

I told him he owes it to the rest of us coffee-addicted junkies to keep moving throughout the city and spreading the caffeinated love. 

Four Barrels is a cool space, but not as cozy as Ritual down the street. Still...the coffee is excellent, and the doughnuts come in tempting flavors like pistachio lemon and salted caramel.
author: Katherine T.

description:
You had me at on-site coffee roasting, but you made me a fan because of the experience.

It's 10AM on a Wednesday, I'm sipping on a latte and a Dynamo Chocolate Spice Donut. There is a team of employees roasting coffee on-site, a barista working the pour-over bar, and 2 baristas each manning their own espresso machine. You'd think this would be a pretentious place filed with snobby baristas, but you'd be wrong.

The service here is fantastic. The baristas were always smiling, talking with the customers, and working through the line to the door very well. 

The only reason I didn't give this 5 stars is because I felt that the espresso lacked some of the richness that I've had at places like Blue Bottle, Stumptown (Seattle), and Ritual. But I absolutely fell in love with the Dynamo Chocolate Spice donut. It was a little pricey at $3, but well worth it. One of the best donuts I've ever had because it was sweet without being sugary, dense without being too cake, and had a perfect balance of chocolate and spice.
author: Ben S.

description:
Oh scenester coffee shop with your taxidermy and what have you. I was craving a decaf soy latte that would rock my world and sadly the only movement I felt was that of a sigh..a sigh of disappointment. Overly bitter, watery, and completely lack luster. The highlight was the foam..

Maybe it was the "barista"..maybe it was me..maybe they could just tell by my regular fit pants and my absence of ironic imagery that I wouldn't 'get' their coffee anyway - so why even try? 

I would be willing to try their drip coffee but I have a sneaking suspicion the descriptions are far more luscious than their brew could ever aspire to be.  

Prove me wrong, Four Barrel!
author: Natalie G.

description:
So this place is around the corner from one of my Clients, which is really the only reason I went there. It was down a funky little alleyway which looked kinda sketch. There was no sign, just a smell.

I had an espresso and my buddy had a soy latte.
The espresso was pretty good, but it didn't really suit my tastes...
Better than a lot of other coffee that I've had in the mission. Apparently people don't like to taste their coffee down here so I've gotten pretty tired of drinking watered down flavorless coffee/espresso.

One plus for it - its not swarming with stupid annoying hipsters talking about how cool their iPhone(y)s are and how many bongloads they smoked last night. Seriously, go back to living in your parents basement...

Prices were pretty reasonable:
$2 for espresso
$3 for a soy latte
author: Tom S.

description: Ah, the smooth, buttery, and full bodied drip. Beautiful bouquet.
author: Hung T.

description: "Hipsters R Us" is what this place should be renamed to but the coffee is good and the people watching is right up there with the best spots in The Mission, so that's enough to make me want to return on a regular basis.
author: Roberta W.

description:
3.5 stars.  We made a quick stop before heading up to Point Reyes for what was supposed to be an all day hike.  We got 2 coffees, a Dynamo chocolate spice donut and a ham and cheese croissant.

The coffee tasted burned so it wasn't as good as I had hoped.  The donut and the croissant, on the other hand, were great.  The donut was cake-like but not too sweet and the cheese in the croissant was very mild and went well with the ham.  I will be making a visit to Dynamo very soon.

I'll try the coffee again but for now, it was only ok.
author: Seong P.

description:
Good coffee in the Mission without the attitude!
I'd be back. Nice baristas, nice atmosphere, no frills but tasty.
author: Rachel M.

description: If you're the Starbucks type who loves to order drinks with names that are a sentence long, I'm not sure you'll like this place all that much. I have a feeling Four Barrel appeals more to coffee connoisseurs. Having said that, you don't feel out of place regardless what kind of coffee drinker you are. I've tried only the latte and drip coffee here and while I didn't have a "WOW" experience with either, both met my expectations after reading the positive reviews on Yelp and elsewhere. The latte was smooth and had a good balance of milk and espresso. The first sip of the drip coffee caught me by surprise--I was not expecting the sour taste and wasn't sure I liked it at first but upon subsequent sips I started enjoying it. As some people here have said, this place has a "hipster" vibe, but I feel like that could be said about most places in SF. The shop itself is quite unique, with wooden tables, super high ceilings and lots of space to roam and look at different types of coffee in jars. I was disappointed to find no power outlets or WiFi, but had a good time anyway just soaking up the scene (hipsters and otherwise). Great place for a quality cup of coffee.
author: Zohal S.

description: One of the best if not the best Latte in the city (comparable to the new Schweet Boks in Sunset) I also love the friendly staff and pretty atmosphere and GREAT music however the downside is there is no wifi and no outlet plugs for laptops.. I am sure there is a marketing reason for this but I truly think they would gain much more business if they had both of these amenities.
author: Mike P.

description: Maybe I'm more of a Blue Bottle type gal.  The coffee here was good, but I'm more of a fan of BB. The space itself is really nice, and the place to stand outside with your coffee is nice.  I think I was just a bit too overwhelmed with the hipsterdom going on.
author: Nancy C.

description: I currently love Four Barrel Coffee. Roasted on the premises and delivered without any snobbiness. My first thought was WTF? This shit is weak! But about two minutes later the hair on the back of my neck was standing up. Didn't realize what I thought was drip is actually pressed coffee. Nearly impossible to score a spot at one of the counters, but I still love it. Even the iced coffee is thrilling.
author: Robert M.

description: This is a very artsy cafe, came here to try that chocolate spice donut and coffee... unfortunately, they ran out !  .. had to settle for the corn cherry donut and coffee.  Also had  a chance to try the apricot cardamon flavor donut also.  Both were good. These donuts are probably fried but not as heavy tasting as typical donuts.  They are light and fluffy, although they don't look like it. The coffee is ok, nothing special in my opinion.  They tend to have no space to sit.. but a nice little side walk resting area is available.
author: Margie C.

description: Smells pretty coffee...It has an old-fashioned gramophone and a lot of LPs... Playing New Order... Awesome!  Estimulating all senses ...
author: Alida G.

description: I had the iced coffee and spicy chocolate donut. The iced coffee was pretty good. I didn't need to put any soy milk in it because it wasn't too bitter. It was a bit watered down, though. But, it's one of the better ones I've had. I still think that Philz makes the best coffee, though. The spicy chocolate donut was pretty good, too, but I'd probably not get it again. It wasn't amazing enough for me to WANT to buy it.
author: Vera W.

description:
Simply great. The Americano and the Breve Latte rock! We love Four Barrels, think it is better than Blue Bottle, Ritual, Philly's. 

Their product is simply wonderful and brings a smile every time I taste it --I look for places serving Four Barrels and love going over to Valencia on the weekend for my end of the week treat. If there was a place that served Four Barrels near my house on Polk I'd go there every day, right now stuck with Starbucks (the staff is great!) and Peets, etc.

Go to Four Barrels!
author: Alexandra S.

description: Walked by today and looks like they are using two parklets for some nice outdoor seating.
author: marcie v.

description: I brew Four Barrel coffee regularly and always enjoy it. When I visit their shop, it's an authentic experience. It's like no other coffee shop I've been to -- boar's heads lined on the wall (not saying I love that), vintage wallpaper, interesting art on display, and a separate espresso and drip bar. The unique shop experience combined with the great coffee = a solid 4 stars in my book.
author: becca j.

description: Very simple review. Fabulous almond lattes. The best. Food selection not very good, but their focus is clearly coffee.
author: Shirin A.

description:
Four Barrel fills a delicate niche for mission hipsters who cannot be bothered with the hassle that is Ritual, nor do they wish to travel the city blocks that distance themselves from Philz or Blue Bottle.  

The space is bright and open.  The coffee is good and it is cheap.  Sit in a chair, take a moment for yourself and sip from a formidable white mug.  I promise their coffee will please you.
author: Ryan P.

description: kisses, hugs, more kisses..I consider myself a coffee diva, I have worked in the business, do more than my fair share of drinking it.  I love the pour over bar, a great way to try new coffees.  The employees are great and wonderful..yes I know its along wait, but worth it.  I love you and all your employees...And what a great addition the lovely and talented Ian is to your staff...
author: Mark C.

description: You haven't experienced SF if you haven't tired four barrel!!! It's pretty much hipster heaven...and great coffee.
author: Elena T.

description: One of my favorite spots in the city. The coffee is surely strong and the pastries are delicious! Not to mention it is located in a good area with tons of shops and restaurants nearby. P.S. Try the almond cake!
author: Yalda M.

description: I had a cup of delicious pour over Ehtiopian coffee (black).  Perfectly made. Cool building and decor and coffee is roasted right there.  A bit on the hipper than thou side, but I will likely go back and try their more reasonably-priced drip coffee.  Which brings me to my main gripe.  Cheapest pour over was $3.50.  Plus tip that's over $4 bucks for a 12 ounce coffee.  Blue Bottle does the same for $2.75 AND they can make more than one cup at a time.  (I waited  more than10 minutes for my coffee as there were two people in front of me).  Overall, excellent coffee but not an everyday place given the prices and the excellent competition in the neighborhood.
author: Dan W.

description: Hot chocolate on the secret menu. Love this place. Always has amazing service and amazing coffee and drinks. Being located in the Mission, it's also geographically desirable. Sometimes I love just sitting here and people watching too. Love you Four Barrel!!
author: Sue Y.

description:
This is my favorite coffee shop in the bay area, and we have lots: ritual coffee, blue bottle, cole. their espresso is perfect--bold yet smooth. the baristas are (generally) friendly and i've only had someone make me a subpar cappucinno once (espresso was kind of sour). but given that i've probably been there twice a week for the past year i would say that is about as good as it gets.
Decor is beautiful. Boar heads are something interesting to stare at while waiting for your drink/company/ etc. i like the roasting equipment in the back. 
Only thing that gets me about Four Barrel is the seating. The chairs are awkward and the screws in them snag and tear my tights.
author: Lia B.

description:
Opening its door on Thursday (Aug 21st) .. the coffee cart out back is closing up for good today so stop by if you can!

Can't wait for this place to open for real.  Awesome coffee, perfect location.  Should give the peeps at ritual a break from the crowds.
author: greg t.

description:
4BC is bad ass.

i love that they don't have outlets and wireless. talk to your friends.

and of course the coffee is amazing.

i love the rope and awkward seating. lounging-style comfort is overrated. i don't want to be wired and about to fall asleep in some gigantic lime green beanbag. i want to be upright and alert.

it gets packed in here but that's only an indication of how good it is.

nicely designed potty room too.
author: Victor B.

description: "A-Ok."  Yeah, that pretty much sums it up. Cool space, but LOADED to the gills with hipsters and pretense. Not a place I'd want to hang out unless I lost 50 lbs and shopped in the girl's dept. Coffee was good, but didn't blow me away.  I'm old school.  I want at least 16oz, and I just want coffee. I don't need my coffee to be wanked up, and I'm not a fan of bitter.
author: Steph P.

description: $4 for a pourover coffee? I'm sure the coffee is good but come on...its coffee beans ground and put in a filter with water poured over it. I ended up going to Peets where I could get an actual 16 oz. coffee. for a little over $2.
author: Mark O.

description:
NEVER AGAIN! This place gets an F- for customer service. I met friends here early this morning and tried to order some tea. The very rude cashier told me this is a coffee place, they don't serve tea and how the two don't go together. I work in the food biz and so do many of my friends and this is a first for all of us. She did admit that many customers have asked for tea, so its amazing this place can't be bothered to invest a few dollars in some tea. Seriously folks???

I'm not much of a coffee drinker first thing in the morning, so I ordered some hot chocolate instead. More rudeness. The design on the foam was pretty, so I complimented the barrista on that and she just looked at me and said nothing. I suppose rudeness and arrogance is a requirement here.

One of the friends I was with this morning works in the coffee industry and commented on the snottiness he experienced too. The attitude of these two women was unacceptable and would never be tolerated at my job or in any of the restaurants my friends own.

This place has a LONNNNNG way to go. I won't waste my time or money here again.
author: Dani X.

description:
After being at 4 stars for months, I really need to give Four Barrel 5 stars. My boyfriend and I are regulars here, and absolutely love the place. Four Barrel is the first thing we think about in the morning and the last thing we look forward to before we go to bed.

The people are awesome, and we feel especially special when we come in at 7:15am and they know our order without our saying anything (that's how often we come..). Staff is friendly, trendy, and cool. Espresso is strong, slightly bitter, but very flavorful; amazing aftertaste. Decor is always nice, artwork changes and is never boring, cool music.

LOVE IT.
author: Angela H.

description:
Stumptown beans are my favorite and it's great to see a place in SF that gets it. They will be roasting their own beans after the official opening and talking to one of the employees it sounds like they will be roasting in the Stumptown style. Hooray!

The interior looks amazing as well, can't wait to hang out there as I am anticipating it as my new favorite coffee shop! 

And as other's have mentioned, I too hope they keep the back alley open.
author: Scott T.

description: Best mocha in town - unless you like super sweet starbucks-like mocha. Unsweetened chocolate with rich and intense flavor. Dynamos donut always helps unless it's your low carb day.
author: Fred F.

description: The most legit coffee shop, ever. Roastery within the building. Homebrewed furniture and fixtures, awesome layout, window art, plenty of bicycle parking poles out front, all the employees ride bicycles to work as evident with the bike parking within the roastery. Important: all the coffee is prepared via french press. You can get your espresso on and glass drip as well. The bean flavor descriptions made me laugh, a bit pretentious but I applaud the passion and copywrite creativity. The coffee really is fabulous, and they have the acidity and roast down very unique and original as hard as it is to separate yourself from the millions of wannabe coffee shops in the city, no less the Bay Area. The pricing is right, the mood is on point, and I'm always leaving totally stoked. from Four Barrel.
author: Wilson T.

description:
I LOVE the fact that this place does not have Wi-Fi or outlets for laptops. You would NEVER get a seat if this was a former Ritual Roasters. The open space in front - as my wife points out - helps the inevitable line flow smoothly. The folks behind the counter don't seem to have the 'tude that the do at other gourmet coffee joints.

Now for the brew...It's great. F-ing great.  I actually muni / drive down there from my hood, so that is saying something.
author: masugu m.

description: It's hard to really not like any of the coffee offerings we have in the Bay Area. We have a lot of quality stuff, but I always notice when I have my lattes from Modern Cafe in downtown Oakland, it's usually with Four Barrels coffee, so of course I had to stop in to the actual place from whence it came. Yummo. Fancy whiskey house like decor. Like out of Dwell magazine. Friendly service, yummy coffee cake, like really yummy and of course a quality latte.
author: Farah S.

description:
i love their coffee
enough said

you have to award people who tries to be best at their craft
author: Joseph K.

description: Best and most addictive humphry slocombe beer ice cream affogato.
author: Jessie J.

description: Another great cafe for me to crush on!  The space is wooden, sharp edges, and beautiful!  Shared table space is something I'm very appreciative of!  My macchiato was excellent -- smooth, rich, milk chocolate finish.  Paired with a salty caramel donut?   Ohhh.....
author: Sarah G.

description:
Super strong coffee. 

Whoa, I should have gotten a soy latte instead of the cap. I admit that I'm a caffeine lightweight. I average a cup of coffee a month. 

The ambiance reminds me of Ritual (oops is that a faux pas?), dark with beams and the same pastry display case. 

I think of this place as a temple to coffee.
author: Monica L.

description: I'm on vacation.  No wait, I'm in Chicago at New Wave Coffee... No, I'm in the mission, San Francisco...wait.. where am I?  Reminiscent of our own hipster cafe in the heart of Logan Square, Four Barrel Coffee is comparable in a good way. As much as people may complain about New Wave or another hipster coffee joint, in many ways that's just how it should be.  It's a familiar, ironic t-shirt, apple macbook or mac air-toting vibe, complete with humorous and yes, ironic artwork adorning the brick walls.    You wanna know the best part about these types of coffee shops?  The coffee. Any good hipster has amongst their other bragging rights, a wealth of knowledge about good, strong coffee.  The cappucinos require instagram photographs with their beautiful artistic swirls.  There is no need to take off your sunglasses when entering this shop.  Most are nursing hangovers or can't be bothered to disrupt their look of "cool."  All humor set aside, this place is awesome.
author: Julia H.

description:
It's too loud. The food costs too much. And it's my favorite. I do feel like packing a lunch when I go there, but the people working there are friendly, the atmosphere great, and the customers are friendly too! Many happy hours spent here, and it still feels like a treat to go there.
OK, I have to update this one. I still like it quite a bit. Everything that was good before remains good. But prices keep going up, and I now rarely go there. They've upgraded to a better grade of customer. I did not make the cut.
author: Mike K.

description: Big fan of Four Barrel! Their soy lattes provided me with a much needed Monday morning jolt and was strong enough to power me through the day. I really like the quality of their coffee and the actual shop is huge and welcoming. I get the sense that the barristas really know their stuff and are coffee connoisseurs.5 stars for Four Barrel!
author: Kelly N.

description:
I can dig it.  Four Barrel is tied with Ritual for my second favorite beans in San Francisco (Blue Bottle is still # 1).  However, the layout of the store is nice, I like the openness and the wood.  They don't encourage laptop use (in fact they discourage it), but that's okay with me.  I can give up internet for a few minutes.

I'm not sure if they are still doing this, but they were doing free coffee tastings at 2 PM every day.  Definitely a good way to check out the coffees if you are not sure what to buy for beans.
author: Richard N.

description:
The battle for the mission takes an unexpected twist.  The hipsters don't want to be left out of the strife between the nortenos and surenos.  The fixed gear skinny pant nation needs a side to cling to.  Hence, the Battle of Valencia between uber-coooooool Ritual Roasters against the wannabe uber-cooooooooler Four Barrell.  What a surprise that the new entrant in hipsterian coffee warfare seeks to define itself as just a little cooler, an espresso just a little snottier, an ambience just a little less yuppier, stump town coffee just a little more bitter.  And on and on and on.

All that being said, Four Barrell needs to learn that the holy grail of hipsterianism values supposed "originality."  Thus although on its face its taken all of Ritual, put the good parts on steriods and got ridden of the baggage... its still not Ritual.  And frankly, im not a fan of the bitter espresso.  I feel its makes my cappucino taste like the proper and delicate mix of coffee and milk has not been achieved.

Long live Ritual, the capital of the Mission, the mecca of coffee snot-ery.
author: S. K.

description: The coffee was pretty bad here but then again, everyone's got different preferences. When I didn't like their coffee, I just end up finding the decorations to be pretentious.
author: Maya L.

description: Yes, it's a matter of taste, but their coffee is excellent and, while, yes, it's also Mission hipster, it's a comfortable place to hang out.
author: Brett W.

description:
Good coffee, even better that I got it for FREE as part of their "recession special." 

Kind of bummed that they did not have Dynamo doughnuts the day I went. The nice guy at the counter advised me that they don't have it on Mondays because Dynamo is closed in Mondays.
author: Ava C.

description: No low-fat or non-fat milk? I do like this place & the staff are very cool but as an everyday coffee drinker_ I find myself going to Ritual instead... more options, not as pricey.
author: Ms. T.

description:
Want a good cup of house coffee for $2? This is the place!

I'm an ex-coffee drinker...I stick to primarily green tea now, but man...if we had a Four Barrel in LA I'd be wired all day err day! It's smooth, rich, bold but doesn't burn a whole in your stomach.  

They also sell a variety of different blends that you can take home four about $14 a bag.  

Very cute place with a lot of seating and free wi-fi.
author: Kristen H.

description: So, I've continued to drink the delicious elixir at this place, and I've noticed that when I don't go in during the weekend mornings (duh), I get great service-- smiles, greetings, thanks and all. So, I am not going to stand by my previous statement about the unfriendly service. I am simply going to avoid the high traffic hours as best as possible. Yum.
author: Brandy E.

description: i'm not sure what the big deal is with the coffee here...it's better than peet's and seattle's best, but i still prefer starbucks. i like burnt food, maybe that's why i like SB more? anyway, their cappuccinos are served in a tiny shot mug topped with an expertly crafted design using milk foam, it's pretty awesome.
author: Melissa Y.

description:
Atmosphere: beautiful.
Quality of coffee: A+
Seemingly friendly staff.

A little crowded, but there's always seating.
author: Dani S.

description:
YES!

1. Awesome latte
2. Cool atmosphere
3. Clean bathroom
4. Chill customers
5. Relatively easy to find parking

OUCH!

1. Cash Only
2. I got parking ticket right in front (my fault, not theirs....)
author: Yoko S.

description: Great coffee and super sweet outdoor patio.  Good chocolate filled doughnuts.
author: Arcelia G.

description:
For the TLDR crowd, I give them a B+.  Nuff said. The Mission feels more and more like Portland every day. 

Granted they just opened and are working out the kinks. The place doesn't seem laid out to the best use of the space. Coffee was excellent. Brewed same as Ritual. Service was spotty  though. 

Example: Coffee runs out, and I am waiting for a fresh brew. Meanwhile, the cashier starts gabbing with some friends and forgets my coffee, starts serving other people. Not sure where I am suppose to stand. Afive minutes passes. Now, I wasn't like standing there getting mad or giving her lazer eyes, but I wasn't just being a passive lump either. She is gas faced when she sees me still waiting, hustles to pour me a mug, instead of a to go cup which I requested, which is substantially less coffee when poured back into the to go cup. Whatever. I am happy to finally have it.

Does this make me sound like a prissy jerk to care? I don't know. Still, the staff was friendly and the coffee was great.  I will absolutely go back there but not going to throw in the towel on Ritual so fast. Gonna try the beans at home and update this after a second visit.
author: Zac H.

description: Best espresso, best chocolate croissants, awesome baristas. What else is there to say?
author: Stacy B.

description:
Not your run of the  mill, vanilla cafè.  Four Barrel is true to its Mission District surroundings: eclectic, distinctive, and grungy (not in a bad way). Not really the type of coffee shop you would want to study or read at, but I think it's great here. 

If you visit at the right time, you can watch them roasting beans right behind the bar and it smells incredible.  I always judge the quality of a coffee establishment by the quality of their espresso, and Four Barrel serves a great cup of espresso. Great coffee, fun ambiance, and friendly staff make this place a great spot for a coffee at any time.
author: Nathan L.

description:
lighted rope sculptures, boars heads, and nice bearded boys, if you're into that kind of thing. the atmosphere is basically a saddle creek album cover. the coffee is pretty good and the roaster is right in the back for all to see, which is neat. 

they lose a star for not taking cards. i always think that's pretty inconvenient. and i admit it's a little funny that there are spray-painted electrical outlets throughout the place. but it's also kind of shitty. like, who are you teasing with that? your customers. laptop-laden people who just want to get a little work done. that's right, guys, you're a business, not a grizzly bear concert. try not to loose too much sight of that, you know?


*edit* i was just informed that four barrel does, in fact, take credit cards now. that's so worth another star. :)
author: bex m.

description:
Beautiful space, for real real... not for play play. I stopped in for a quick ice coffee, it was hot the other other day. Admittedly, not the tastiest ice coffee.. I ended up putting sugar and milk in it. I normally don't with coffee. THOUGH I am more than willing to come back and have a hot cup of coffee with friends. This place seems like the perfect place to sit back and shoot the shit with a good friend over a cup of something. It is, at first glance, a hipster haven... but on closer look you notice that every one just strolls in (business folks, mom's with kids, tourists... etc). It's just a bunch of hipsters who lounge out side and work inside, and you know what... it totally makes the place look good. I would rather hang out with hipsters here than at any bar in the mission.

Again... BEAUTIFUL SPACE! I will definitely come back and give their coffee another chance.
author: danny e.

description: My drip coffee was poured from a thermos, and tasted highly acidic. Hardly comparable or even close to Blue Bottle. Maybe the espresso is better?
author: Derrick V.

description:
We all hate hipsters. Hipsters hate themselves. So why make a fuss? This place is hands down over Blue Bottle in the Americano department. I don't go there to see or be seen, or sit around and chat and drink coffee. I go in, pay my $2, and get a great fucking cup of coffee. 

I am also a big fan of dead animals.
author: Jillian S.

description: I love "attitude" anywhere when it says confidence not arrogance.  Four Barrel's coffee from the product itself to the way it's served, just doesn't deliver. First of all, there's a lecture with every shot about why they only have whole milk.  Second, the coffee is NOT better than Blue Bottle,Sightglass or any of the other stiff competition around town.  The space is cool and I love the design.  But, unless I gotta have it, I go to all the other great places where the customer is as important as the cup of Java.
author: FairReviews A.

description:
The rating isn't related to the coffee.  The cappuccino I had was awesome.  Very smooth, creamy and full of flavor.  I wish I had more because it was very small.  

Almost $4 for basically a shot of a cappuccino is ridiculous.  Also the Batista were really snotty and stuck up.  The place is really beautiful but the clientele and the employees make the place feel cold and uncomfortable.
author: Eric Y.

description:
Welcome to the neighborhood. Four stars means I am a fan, not so much for the coffee itself, but more for the purpose. Don't get me wrong, the coffee was totally fine, though wish they had skim milk. Healthy yelpers beware - whole or soy is your only choice. Fortunately, living a block away, I can just bring it home.

No, this is more a yelp to support their very existence. The more places we get like this in our little slice of paradise, the better the neighborhood gets, and more places like Four Barrel move in. Kudos for joining the ranks of Bar Bambino, Conduit and Mission Beach Cafe in making the neighborhood better than ever.
author: Jason B.

description:
best coffee in San Francisco in my opinion. consistent, fresh, well crafted. 
dynamo donuts and other bites are awesome as well...
the interior is quite shmancy/cool too.
author: Mohammad G.

description: They take cards now. Fix those chunky mochas and we have a winner on our hands.
author: Tom M.

description:
I happened to come here on their 2 year anniversary and there are two highlights of my ten-minute experience. 

1. The coffee was amazing. But, so was the croissant and I'm having difficulty deciding which was better. I've found that trying to describe coffee is a futile exercise, so I won't waste time with froofy floral tasting notes (I hate those.) Basically if you enjoy coffee as a drink rather than a wake-up fix, you'll like it here.

2. It was their anniversary, meaning all the coffee was free and the place was decked out in celebration. They have these boar heads mounted on the wall and for that day they all had those birthday party whistles in their mouths. Just goes to show the attitude of the people working here.
author: Victor L.

description:
I love this place.  Its a no frills place - you walk up, your options are simple, you get your drink... and done.  If my memory serves correct, you get the choice between coffee, latte, espresso, and maybe a couple other drinks... but don't expect to walk in and be able to order as if you're at starbucks.  They roast their beans in the back and serve an amazing cup of coffee.  Its probably the best cup of coffee I've had in San Francisco.  
The atmosphere is also quite nice - I love all the wooden tables, chairs, etc...  its very minimalistic.  Not your typical cozy coffee house, but who cares - it looks nice and the coffee is great.  I also picked up one of the donuts, which I believe they get from Dynamo?  I could be wrong..  but, I just remember really hoping they'd have the maple bacon one that I've been wanting to try... but i settled for the vanilla bean which was AMAZING.   I can't wait to get back to San Francisco and visit this place again.
author: Lauren A.

description:
i had been there several time. it becomes one of my favorite placece for coffee. i would go there everyday if i live around this awesome place. i heard about a guy  who's owner of the place first. i should remember his name and let you guys know about him. Unfortunately, i am not good at remembering names. You will see,have and feel coffee here. What i mean by that is....you will realize when you get there. i will tell you a little. When you walk into cafe, you can taste their coffee with your eye. Your mouth will be full of  coffee that make you special and you can feel it with your whole body.

i know my review is pretty abstract so it is not really helpful for you guys. "Coffee is abstact," to me. it is not formed . it can be totally different by you. 

Enjoy! If you want to feel the same way..
author: WONIL P.

description: Five stars for making THE BEST almond milk latte. I've always liked Four Barrel but now that I'm not drinking regular milk this is for sure my go-to place.  I don't know how the baristas do it, but the foam is incredible (they use Califia Farms fresh almond milk) rivaling the best foam on a whole milk latte. Delicious!!
author: Michele M.

description: Very friendly staff.  Great place to sit outside and enjoy the sun with a cup of espresso.
author: Heather R.

description: Love the ambiance. Love the coffee. And most of all, I love the Costa Rica Montes de Oro - barista chick said it tastes like a Toblerone when paired with cream, and right she was! :)
author: Sally M.

description: Nice, spacious, and a delicious $2 cuppa joe. They play records and there are these creepy truffle sniffer heads on the wall...
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I love good coffee, and SF has a lot to offer in this department.  

I only came in to buy some beans after lunch, so my review isn't going to be that complete.  

The venue itself is pretty nice and clean.  They a decent amount of seating, but because there are SO many people there, it feels like they haven't put in any seating...I'm not sure if that makes sense.  

I like that the pour over bar is separated off to the side.  I think this helps alleviate some of the traffic.  The guy at the bar helped me with my purchase.  He was very friendly and we got to chat a bit about pour over methods even though it was busy.  I never felt rushed with my purchase like I experienced at Ritual.  

I'm really enjoying the beans I got there in my v60.  

I would definitely come here to buy beans or get a drink to go, but it is a bit too crowded to just hang out, especially if I brought my family with me.  But this isn't necessarily a reason to subtract stars....it is what it is.
author: John G.

description:
Judging by the three times I've been here since I moved to San Francisco, this has got to be the most consistently pleasing coffee joint to date. Their americanos are delectable, though I think I would pass on the normal brew - it's alright, though much better than the tar I've been drinking from most other places I've tried so far.

The baristas are very sweet and patiently attentive, which is always a plus. Four Barrels also gets extra points for the Seth Quest light fixtures, funky wallpaper, and bathroom chandelier. This place definitely has a unique, positive vibe to it.
