The music tends to be a bit loud and they don't offer wifi as of yet, so don't expect to come here to get work done, but it is a great place to meet a few friends for an espresso or two.
author: Becky L.

description:
Pros
- Excellent Coffee
- Nice, airy, original space
- Coffee Roaster in the shop
- Friendly barista that took the time to tell me about my coffee and explain the brewing method

Cons
- Tough to find parking
author: Roger R.

description: LONG wait for a latte. Price was good, esp considering all the hype here. Services was OK, but not the cashier/barista who sneezed into her shirt , handled cash, then went to making drinks. Latte price is good, but the size is small.
author: Booger D.

description: I came here last weekend because I heard so much about this place.  I was worried that all I had heard was hype, but it was not.  I got just a drip coffee.  My boyfriend got a cappuccino, a chocolate spice donut, and a strawberry earl grey donut.  Everything was uniformly excellent. I have never had better drip coffee. It was thick, soupy, and strong.  I felt awake but not jittery after. The creative donut flavors were impressive.
author: Victoria R.

description: 5 stars for the coffee but 3 stars for the attitude and the line. One time I made the mistake of asking for low fat milk and I was given a surprised look from the barista because apparently that is not their style. I dunno, I really want to love this place because their coffee is so delicious but I always leave feeling like I am not cool enough.
author: Jessie H.

description: Four Barrel is such a hip space, exactly the type of chicness I would come to expect out of a similar cafe in Brooklyn or Seattle. I came here for the first time on a Saturday with a close friend who shares my affinity for a good cup of joe and together we enjoyed delicious soy lattes while we actively hipster-watched, er people-watched.  I'd definitely come back for more.
author: Katie C.

description: Now, I don't drink coffee, so really this isn't my review, but a very picky coffee drinker that I know and love said this coffee was absolutely delicious and regretted not buying some to take back to LA.
author: Stephanie F.

description:
It's not Stumptown, but it might be the next best thing. 

Too hip by a mile, but who cares if the coffee is good?
author: Daniel M.

description:
I am not sure if Four Barrel is competition for Blue Bottle or even Ritual.  Though Jeremy Tooker was co-founder of Ritual has created a business model that is both similar and different from his former business.   It is not easy creating one let alone two coffee houses in San Francisco let alone two on the same street.  The only commonality is that the Four Barrel and Ritual is that they are both on Valencia Street and both use French Press for the production of their final product and both have pour over coffee service.

Four Barrel is Aspen meets Urban.  I do like the space and it's openness; I am sure the space- big as it is will bring displeasure to someone; very few tables compared to total square footage.  Jeremy is a pleasant soul and always eager to serve the best coffees possible; I hope he does well; imagine leaving Ritual; a brand he helped to build to it's current brand format.  He succeeded in creating another excellent brand--Four Barrel.   

I love the pour over coffee bar-- the barristas are superbly friendly, coffee interested and each experience I have had here is fantastic.
author: Jaime Patricio M.

description:
There are so many choices to make in  the course of the day.   During  every damn minute of the day,  I am making AT LEAST one damn decision. It sucks. 

But, at Four Barrel, my decisions are limited. Do I want a(n excellent) cap or a coffee? Soy or milk? Maybe I will get a donut or an h&c croissant (which truly are exquisite) And when I sit down, I can sit, talk, or read. I don't have the option of cruising the Internet.

 Great coffee. Cool boars'  heads. And no Internet. It's a little bit of paradise.
author: Jill R.

description:
4Barrel makes me feel cool because I started going when they were operating out of the back loading dock door on Caledonia.   Other times it makes me feel like I have friends because people I know walk in and we talk.  Generally speaking all the guys and barista staff are friendly and mellow.  I get lots of homework done here too.  

Mission Beach has better pastries, lots of them, and don't run out nearly as fast, but it takes a year and a day to get a decent cup of drip Blue Bottle there.  If 4B had a cheese croissant as good, Mission Beach would be dead to me.

4B's current pastries aren't that awesome - the ham and cheese is pretty good but they're always out, so I end up w/the plain and it's boring and has the texture more of bread than a croissant.  Their pies were yummy, too bad the pie-lady couldn't keep up with the demand.  Yes, the donuts are good, obviously.  Try Maple-Bacon - wow-wa-wee-wah.  I love their coffee.  I love the floor in the bathroom.  I wish they had a phone so I could call them right now to be SURE that they do not have wireless so I don't truck my laptop down there for nothing.  I have seen lots of people w/their computers there recently so I wondered...

Saturday morning I needed my 4B fix rul early (7:30am), but they don't open till 8am on the weekends.  And not till 7am on weekdays.  I will never again be awake that early, but it was too bad.  

Oh, and Thomas R., those are not condos across the street.  Those are the remodeled Valencia Gardens, and yes, it is still Section 8 housing.
author: Loren R.

description:
I was really rooting for this place since they're like 5 blocks from our startup (SlideRocket.com). I would love to give them 5 stars but I'll have to go with 3 since they always serve their latte's "cold". There may be an optimum temp. for lattes (feel free to rip on me and point out why I shouldn't want a hot latte) but I like my coffee hot, hot, hot!

The people are extremely nice and the donuts are heavenly. Atmosphere is good but there's no power or wireless so not a great place to set up camp.

Overall though a great addition to the Mission.
author: Nathaniel R.

description:
Yum, tasty coffee. Nice atmosphere to chat with friends, no computer zombies hanging out here - creates a real social environment.

The staff is really nice, and the coffee is to die for. My only suggestion would be to have more than just donuts to eat - coffee induces hunger!

Also like the boar heads.
author: Spoon G.

description: I love the coffee here, other than that the staff is great. They look happy which sets my day off on a positive note.
author: Maria V.

description:
Things that are great about Four Barrel:
--the coffee (strong, balanced, not bitter or burnt)
--the donuts 
--the decor
--the music
--the cute customers and their moustaches

Not great:
--no wifi
--pricey (drip coffee $2, donuts $2.50)
author: Paddy G.

description: I LOVE their espresso drinks w. soy. Likewise, bakery goods are EXCELLENT!
author: Yoshiko M.

description:
I was introduced to Maple doughnuts sprinkled with bacon here. I can stop there but it really wouldn't do this place justice. The place is great, coffee is awesome and the people are not uppity coffee sh!theads that smell their own farts for satisfaction. Cheers Four Barrel for making a nice potentially pretentious art school drop out joint into a genuine place for good drink, good food and good times. Good times indeed. 

And they have a nice restroom...
author: Paul J G.

description:
Four Barrel's coffee beats any around and the fact that not one of their staff is a coffee snob like you find at Ritual makes the experience even better! 
Not to mention the kick ass vinyl collection playing as you walk in. Best coffee house in town!
author: Karen C.

description: Very hipster, clean, modern cafe that takes coffee very seriously (and rightly so). A great drip cup of coffee, roasted and steeped on site... also quite good espresso drinks. A good spot to take advantage of ample seating, fast wi-fi, and sit for a while as you enjoy your drink of choice and the current music selection playing on the old LP in the back.
author: Beth P.

description: In house roasted. Very tasty. Many varieties. Pressed coffee not drip. If you like drip, get the Americano. Open space and clean artsy interior. Will return.
author: Judy L.

description: This place was directly across the street from my old apartment (thank god). The coffee is amazing, they always have these really cute and unique delectable treats too! I feel like they really hit home with the decor as well...being a tall woman and all, space is greatly appreciated. They have lots of SPACE, high ceilings, lots of windows. Great for grabbing some coffee and reading a book.
author: Beta B.

description: I used to love starting my morning with a Four Barrel Cappuccino till I had to relocate for work. Best coffee in San Francisco, nicest barista's as well. Though they do need to get with the Free Wifi program, people already sit there for hours at a time. The atmosphere is addicting.
author: Matt P.

description:
Four Barrel is to coffee and espresso as Self Edge is to denim.
Taking coffee to a seriously new level....
A welcome addition to the neighborhood indeed.
author: Kiya B.

description: Love the cappuccinos here, so good! And of course, great coffee. I like Ritual down the street, but prefer Four Barrel so much more. The whole staff is so friendly, unlike most at Ritual. The general feel of everything in here (the decor, the customers, the building, etc) is so great. I feel like if I could design a coffee shop, this is what it would be like. I would like a couple more chairs though.
author: Wes K.

description:
Good coffee; not great.

The decor is distinctive, interestingly done. Nice touch.

The narrow tables make it feel more like sitting at a bar than sitting in a cafe. You kind of stop in, have a coffee, and move on; you don't really feel as much like you can settle in with a book, or a computer, or a conversation, as you might in other cafes with other seating arrangements.

Lastly, there's a feeling that the staff are *trying* to be hip and stylish. They lack charisma, frankly, and seem to want attention for their appearance. Which, for me, is an unimpressive vibe. I'm really just going in for coffee, not to have the barista looking out the corner of their eye to see whether I'm noticing them. A bit adolescent... If you have to try that hard, then you probably just haven't got it...
author: Michael S.

description: Easily the best coffee in San Francisco right now since Blue Bottle has taken over the city and let quality slip. I really like the "cowboys coming home to the ranch" feel they have going on.  I make a trek here every time I am in town and its spacious layout is the only thing it has over Abraço. That and unicorn mugs!!
author: Jasmine T.

description:
If your looking for starbucks don't go here.  
If your looking for coffee with minimal additions you will love it here.  
The coffee is tasty, strong and dark. 
One of the coolest coffee shops I've seen.  But hay thats just me. 
Enjoy
author: Dave S.

description: Four Barrels, Blue Bottle, Barefoot Roasters.  I always have a thick glass canister of these beans at home.  De La Paz should be mentioned as well.  Philz is OK.. but they've become too big and the quality of thier beans has definately taken a dip.  Ritual is OK, but I have no room for them. I order beans straight from Costa Rica and Puerto Rica from micro farms I've visited.  There are others out there.  I'll get around to them one of these days.
author: Demanding T.

description:
This little place was recommended to me by a barista over at Ritual Coffee when I stopped in last week. 
Wow! I can probably count the great espresso I have had on one hand, and this place even bests what I have had at Stumptown. Espresso here has a nice sweet finish. Very surprising!!

And to the barista at Ritual.... you guys rock too!
author: Scott M.

description:
Excellent coffee. As good as coffee gets.

Good atmosphere for discussion. Friendly people. No WiFi.
Excellent beans, drip, and espresso
author: J M.

description:
Bottom Line - excellent, excellent coffee.  Well prepared.  Friendly staff.

The decor and atmosphere is alright too, its unique.  Its not a comfortable place to spend too much time - the chairs are uncomfortable, there is no wifi/outlets (a SF norm that by my Seattle standards would be scoffed at... but of course the weather is much worse up there... hmm)

to note - no nonfat milk avail.  I can only hypothesize this is the result of establishing some sort of standard, because nonfat just doesn't create as high quality of foam as whole milk... but still, a good barista can do both well... and if your presuming that a nonfat latte is beneath a whole latte.. then what about the 16 oz. americano?.. at what point does the copious scalding hot water not degrade the experience of the espresso?.. 

check it out, though.  great coffee for us whole-milkers. and quality press.
author: Zachary K.

description:
better than blue bottle. coolest vibe of any coffee shop. hip as FFFFUUUUUUUU-. saw that fear the beard dude in here once. he had a yoga mat. seemed chill. local celebs, bomb coffee (slow and express-oh) and top notch taxidermy make this place my favorite coffee shop that I can see from my house.

also: sit outside + under the window. too good.
author: Sean F.

description:
Four Barrel is good, but I prefer Blue Bottle. That being said, this is my go to spot when I need a coffee break at work. 

While their coffee is really delicious and the people that work there are all very nice, it is a little pricey and they only have whole milk or soy milk. I mean, yes, I get the whole coffee purist thing, but whole milk is like a mini-meal for me.
author: Carmen C.

description:
The mocha was meh.  It had no actual chocolate flavor.  In fact, I couldn't really identify what had been added to the milk/espresso.  Maybe they screwed up and gave me a latte.  Dunno.

The space and staff are great though.  I'll just order a plain ol' coffee next time.
author: Robert S.

description: If you like coffee, this is a must visit.  They roast their own beans on sit for the coffee they are serving each day.  It's exceptional.  Everything from cappuccinos to slow coffee, they are true artists of the bean.  Totally hip as well... you just feel cool being there... even the bathroom is badass!
author: Kimberly W.

description:
NOT SO MUCH: espresso was way too bitter and tasted like ass juice (I've had various exotic blends in my travels around the world and this was very lacking. .was it the beans or the brew? I'm no expert, but you know bitter when you taste it. I'll gladly pay extra ...if it's extra good.

I'll give them one more chance to impress me (and I'm not too hard to please).  My GF feels the same (and she's a coffee whore).
author: Hunter B.

description: The lines may be a little long at times, but its totally worth the wait. Perfect place to have a great cup of coffee and the occasional sweet treat. Another great thing is that the staff is super friendly and helpful.
author: Farien F.

description:
Great coffee, had a dbl espresso and a cappuccino. Skipped the donuts. Coffee tastes a little sweeter than the other small brews I've tried, overall very good. 

Cool space, friendly barista and a short wait. Who knows how long that will last though. It is a huge space, pouring espresso must be a really high margin business and/or they have a great deal on rent.
author: Jason M.

description:
No Inspections Available

Does this place have tea? Cuz I don't do coffee!

And I usually don't like croissants but DAAAAAAAAMN those almond croissants were tre magnifique!!!!
author: Kristina C.

description: Great coffee shop that's very serious about it's product. Went on a weekend afternoon and the place was packed.
author: Justin C.

description: I am going to to review this place based on the cup of coffee I got and the service I received, I don't care much about how it was designed or how cool it is. I went there with couple of friends who highly recommended this place. like many places in san francisco, we had to wait in line, I was really anticipating this great coffee that everyone talks about. ordered two coffees and a capuccino. the blend itself was very light, and the coffee didn't taste so great. maybe it was the roast of the day that was too light, I really can't say, it was so crowded that I couldn't really discuss it much with the barista. the cappuccino was cold, but the barista changed it right away and he didn't have an attitude about it. we ordered a butter croissant, but it wasn't fresh. If that's the usual quality of coffee then I am really not impressed.
author: Noura K.

description: This seems like more of a bookstore hangout spot, rather than a coffee shop.  Coffee was alright, nothing to write home about.  Definitely a hipster, too cool for school type of spot.  Kind of a bummer that they don't have non-fat milk.  "Only whole milk or soy milk" is the dealbreaker since I'm allergic to soy, and whole milk sticks to my throat like glue. yuck.  More options please - a girl like me doesn't settle.
author: Betty W.

description: Today I had my coffee at Four Barrel for the last time. It's a shame, but I'm unable to tolerate their behavior toward my daughter. I was a customer for two years and I was going there almost every weekend with my wife and daughter. Today my daughter was louder than usual and screamed five or six times. At that point a member of the staff asked us if there is anything we can do to keep the noise down. When my wife pointed out that it's not easy to control a three-year old, she suggested that the parklet outside might be a better place for us. This happened on a Saturday at 5pm. When I discussed the incident with the manager, she claimed that other children do not scream and that some customers complained. When I pointed out how loud the coffee shop usually is, she pointed out that screaming is not acceptable in any space. At that point, I realized there was no reason on keep arguing. Very disappointed to see how narrow-minded these people are. Again, not because they asked us to be more quiet, but because they suggested we don't behave like all other customers.
author: Michalis P.

description:
6 of us were on an espresso crawl in San Francisco...

One of my friends had recently been to Four Barrel and had a bad experience with snobby obnoxious staff and an Ethiopian Yrgacheffe pour over that was so bad she had to add cream and sugar, but every place you'll go has an off day now and then so we tried it anyway.

The place is gorgeous. I can see why someone else here referred to it as a grown up version of Ritual. Cuppings at 2pm on week days. Single origin espresso at the bar up front. Other than the too-loud-to-think music the ambiance was great. Vinyl for the music was a fun touch. The two baristas were very serious looking.

We got a single origin espresso (Colombia Huila), regular espressos, a machiato, and a latte. All of us had great initial experiences with our coffee. They all started out fantastic. Then they all started to go bad.

What started out as a fantastic espresso with flavors I've never had in an espresso (granny smith apple, etc.), ended as a horrible metallic finish that just wouldn't go away. It lasted and lasted and lasted. Then my husband, who had earlier said his latte was excellent, said it had gone all wrong too. He let me have a taste and if he hadn't earlier said his was good I would have sworn I was tasting burned milk. It was awful.

Great. Now I had TWO bad tastes competing with each other and they just won't leave.

All 6 of us agreed that what started out good, even great, ended terribly. We had 3 different baristas and two different beans so you can't say it was a bad barista or bad beans. Oh well.
author: Mitch H.

description: Way cool hipster hangout, where skinny jeans and $50 hair-cuts flock for a reasonably priced great cup of coffee.
author: John C.

description: Most (all?) coffee professionals have already made Four Barrel a "must" destination anytime they pass through northern California.  For us non-professionals, we can just ask any Four Barrel employee (all are expert-level) for details about the careful sourcing, roasting and brewing that contribute to one of the best coffee experiences in the world.  Don't be scared off if there's a line; it moves surprisingly quickly.
author: Larry B.

description: turns out I had four barrels before over at one of my fave cafes - Red Rock!  Totally confirms its superiority.
author: Emm C.

description: A classic cup of iced coffee with no bells and whistles is not only cheap here, but also delightful and perfect. You can't walk out of this place without a smile on your face. Staff can be a bit pretentious at times, but it is a hipster joint in a hipster neighborhood, so what do you really expect? It's legions better than Ritual Roasters. And have to tried the maple bacon doughnut? Come on...it's great. Get some Wi-Fi and plugs here and I'd hang out all day.
author: Julie D.

description: This may be the best cappuccino (5+ stars) in town. This brew makes the A-list. High quality roaster, and well-poured to say the least. As a cafe, open space and a not so bad place to people watch.
author: Eloy T.

description: The coffee is terrible. Can't touch Philz, Blue Bottle or Ritual. I actually prefer Muddy's and it's only a block away.
author: Raj T.

description: Wow, this coffee is fucking delicious. I've always had Four Barrel coffee at various coffeeshops that feature their roasts but have never been to the actual location. Everywhere else manages to make their coffee taste bitter and burnt rather than smooth and dark and rich like this tasted. I loved the fact that they were playing the Smashing Pumpkins and I was with a good friend discussing protesting and the political actions that we are working on together. The overall experience was just really incredible. Thank coffee for grassroots movements!
author: Lauren S.

description: Very nice place to go. However, it's always crowded. The coffee is good but I know better coffee shop.
author: Josh S.

description:
I dig the big open space. Dark wood surrounds you everywhere you look. I dont dig the attitude of those who work there though. Seemed like I was doing them a favor by coming in when taking my order and not making a sincere effort of letting me know that the drink was ready.

Latte was aight. Not bad but nothing I would remember ten minutes after consuming it. An interesting experience but my personal feeling is that the place seems straight out of Brooklyn. Maybe even the Marina. Or a bunch of places I have never been to. But not the Mission. I think that its not necessarily the worst thing -- just depends on what you are looking for...
author: Dmitriy S.

description: Seems to be the only game in the hood so the line was out the door.  It's a very cool space but the service was so lousy that it gets a two star review.  Baristas are way too cool for school.  God forbid you order a decaf!  By the time I got it it was cold and i was so annoyed at their attitude that i never got to find out if the coffee was any good.
author: James S.

description: seriously?  i don't get it  coffee is ok and def not worth the cost.  sorry, but Peets and even Starbucks beats this place everyday and twice on Sunday.
author: Wayne W.

description:
I had originally heard this was a place to showcase their wholesale coffee, and had grabbed a few shots when they were on the DL serving coffee only in the alley behind their current shop. I'm not a laptop squatter or a pastry nut; I want one thing from a coffee shop and that's good coffee, coffee good enough to send to a friend in Tennessee who sends me Bar-B-Cutie bbq sauce (aka B-B-crack) in return. Four Barrel delivers. 
I can get a regular cup of coffee and expect something on par with a good cup of cocoa - subtle flavors, smoothness, and body, but different because it's coffee. 
I'm not so down with the dead animals on the wall and I'm really not down with them adopting Iron-Maidenesque typefaces while not playing Iron Maiden ALL THE TIME, but oh well - their java is the best.
author: Christopher D.

description:
Love your coffee, your friendly baristas, staff, no attitude attitude, no attitude atmosphere, and pastry/donut offerings.  Go there for coffee, really.  You must go there for coffee..  And stay a little while because you can.  There will be seats open unlike most other popular local cafe spots around.

For those of you who are tired of going to coffee shops where the clientele or the staff make you feel less than welcome but you go there because the coffee is so darn good, Four Barrel should be your next spot.  Unless of course, you like that less than welcome feeling first thing in the morning or anytime of the day.  Four Barrel serves up exceptional coffee with little to no attitude.

As much as I love the fact that there's only cream or soy milk available to creamy up your coffee (yes only 1/2 & 1/2 or soy), as I am watching my waste line grow, I would love you more if you would stock whole milk.
author: Mina C.

description: Love the hipster crowd, decor, location, music and most of all the AMAZING coffee. Best place in San Francisco to get caffeinated.
author: M M.

description:
Good coffee....but not Ritual. Seating definitely not as comfy or conducive to studying. Even though this place is closer to where I live by about ten blocks I will STILL go to Ritual. 

Don't get me wrong Four Barrel still has very decent coffee (read: liquid crack). xo
author: Joy A.

description: It is a nice location, but otherwise has too many inconveniences. (cash only, no outlets, no wifi, no comfortable furniture...)
author: laura g.

description:
Alright guys. You got me. I'm in. I promise to bump this review up to five if you do a couple things for me. Don't take this the wrong way. I think you're doing a GREAT job. Just a couple suggestions for ya. So, take a knee.

Description placards for the grind coffee would be fucking rad. That's the reason I'm coming there. Of course to get a great fresh drip but to pick up a bag of some shit I can't get anywhere else and that helps me save some scratch. Let me know what them fuckin' bags got in em (kudos on the thrash metal font stamps btw). I wanna be blown away.

Brown sugar or at least something unprocessed at the bar. Soy container kicks ass. Hate having to ask baristas for the carton of silk. 

Other than that keep it up. The spot looks awesome. As Tim and Eric would say, Great Job!
author: Farallon Living I.

description:
Space: Beautiful space with lots of potential. Very uncomfortable chairs. Not conducive to relaxing or socializing.

Coffee: Amazing although the over-attention paid to making the filter coffee seemed a bit Santa Monicaesque.
author: Jesse W.

description:
By far the BEST coffee I have ever tasted! The folks who work here are amazing too, very friendly and knowledgeable about how to make great coffee.
The interior space is quite beautiful and spacious. I very much enjoy that the music that is played in the space is actually from an old record player and real vinyl. 
I certainly will be a frequent customer...along with any one I have visiting me - they must try this divine coffee.
author: Jamie K.

description:
UPDATE!

yeah, thats right, i took off a star. cafe opened and i'm not going to lie, i'm not very impressed. dont get me wrong, the decor is great, location is great, people are great, i like going in there and i'm pretty sure i will continue to do so, but the coffee? not my favourite.

i dont want to call anyone out (though i know i'm not the only one to voice this) but i feel like certain barista(s) just dont hit the mark like everyone else and maybe its coincidence, but man, i always draw the short stick here, you know? i noticed it in the alley once, but since then the ratio has flipped. too bad.

like i said though, its not like i'm never going back. when it is good, its real good.
author: Jaei P.

description:
My new favorite coffee shop--they make one mean Americano.
Too bad it's all the way on the other side of the country!!!
author: gina p.

description:
Nice people, and I like the warehouse-y space which isn't that noisy most of the time. (Though the last time I was there they were both blasting music -- but music I liked! -- and having an Obama phone banking thing in the back -- which I support! Though I wonder how the latter could hear anything, given the former.)  And the coffee is terrific. I have to say, it's also quite strong. I'm not a daily coffee drinker, though I do love the stuff, so I may be more sensitive to it than your average (cuppa) Joe but hoo boy! I was bouncing off the walls the rest of the day and night after one latte. Okay, maybe it was a double latte. But still.

They also don't have a lot of options -- just coffee bar/espresso drinks (they do offer soy, too) -- and a few pastry items as far as I could tell. Not a lot to choose from, so if you want a smoothie or whatever, go to Jamba Juice. If you want really good coffee done with love, and a cool place to hang out, then go here.
author: Craigary P.

description: I cannot describe the flavor of the coffee. I wanna say "hoppy" as in beer hoppy.... but don't think that is the right word. Maybe "floral". What ever it is, I like it. Cool that they have some boars heads hanging on the wall trying to scare away all the hipsters.... it ain't working
author: jerry a.

description:
So here I am, taking business away from the coffee bar by buying a V60, beans, filters, etc.  Ask the guy a few questions and he gives me a great reason to get the ceramic (no plastic bits) and the method of brewing they use there.  Also, lets me know about brewmethods, a site with about 10+ ways to brew with the V60.

Had it for a day but already put a few amazing cups of coffee out of this with his help.  This sort of service is what makes local purchasing worth it!

Thanks!
author: Scott D.

description: Beautiful building, fun music and delicious coffee.  Espresso drinks are smooth and devine.
author: Lauren M.

description:
The first time I visited Four Barrel, they were still serving out of the little kiosk in the back alley while they finished the main space. I realized AFTER the nice gentleman had made my beautifully leaf-patterned cappuccino that I had lent my sister my last $5 the previous night, and had no money to pay him. I graced him with some highly embarrassed stuttering, and he magnanimously pronounced it "no problem at all" without a single hint of attitude, eye-rolling or annoyance. Seriously. Just acted like we were old friends, and it was his pleasure to spot me for a coffee.*

Oh, and the cappuccino? Flawless. Smooth, full-bodied coffee, organic milk (makes all the difference, trust me), and they are always accommodating about my request to put a bit of sugar in the bottom of the cup (I like a little sweet, but it's a crime to ruin the art of the rippling patterns with a stir stick).

Yes, the place is occasionally packed with hipsters, but whatever. I live here, so I've gotten used to ignoring the rude and scornful behavior. I most often go in after my morning workout all sweaty in my shorts and sneakers, and the staff is always peachy, so F the pretentious jerks.

The space itself is like a beautifully curated mountain cabin/art gallery. No, there is no wi-fi. Coffee shops are not, contrary to popular belief, required by law to provide free wi-fi. Get over it and drink your cappuccino.


*Of course, the next time I went back, I made sure to pay them for it (how honest of me, right?).
author: Valerie M.

description: I really enjoy the physical setup in the place although the tables are a bit on the skimpy side...still a great place to hold meetings! I love the coffee here, it reminds me of my better coffee days in Vietnam and Costa Rica... Ahh... The coffee actually has great taste and character...not too earthy at all. I love the designs that they make in the coffee...makes me feel special and gets me all giddy. haha! The only thing is this place can be a crazy wind tunnel is you are sitting by the door!
author: Ân T.

description: The espresso and coffee is more consistent than blue bottle...sometimes blue bottle can taste funky. Although i like ritual as well, sometimes the espresso can be too acidic. I find the overall range of four barrel to be a much smoother and balanced taste, with just enough sweetness to come off as caramel, rather than fruity.
author: Helen I.

description:
I don't get the hype about this place. Of course, this is just my opinion on the matter, but I felt strongly enough about this place to voice it.

I went by there on a hot Sunday afternoon, making a special trip to try the coffee. Since it was so hot today, I figured that I'd get myself an iced coffee and top it off with sugar and cream. Well, the carafe said "cream" but I assume it was half and half since the only dairy accouterments were marked "cream" and the other "soy". The coffee was undrinkable - it tasted like I was sucking on a penny or a nickle, with a twangy, metallic, and acidic taste that lingered on my palate for a disturbingly long time. I took three sips and then threw it away at the next trash can.

An argument can be made that I shouldn't be basing a review on iced coffee since it is pre-made and refrigerated, but I feel confident that, on this hot day, there was enough turnover of the iced coffee that what I was getting was not stale. And why should it be regardless?

Lastly, I looked over the selection of whole beans and concluded that they have lost all credibility as coffee mavens after I read their descriptions of the beans. Fine, be creative and fresh with your descriptions, but there is no way in hell that anyone could make an informed purchase with the silliness that they came up with.
author: Horns D.

description: This place is spectacular.  Architecturally, the industrial-style space gives the interior a nicely open atmosphere.  I don't really like the chairs - they're too shallow, but the coffee is generally great and the entire place is a step up from down-the-street Ritual's slacker vibe.
author: Denis Y.

description:
Ritual roasters used to be this good...it could also seriously compete with a Blue Bottle gibraltar
The Americano I had yesterday, an Ethiopian blend, had very overt floral and exotic notes in it. It knocked my socks off!
What a talented dude...I can't wait to return for more.
Vibe: as expected: lots of hipsters in black clothing.
author: Sara K.

description:
At first I thought about giving a bad review just to keep the line out. But that would be just wrong.

The espresso drinks are amazing. I mean, really amazing. The service is nice, friendly. But you are going for the coffee.

I want one now actually...
author: sam p.

description: I wanted to like this place so bad -- but, I just couldn't. You see, the coffee I was survived was lukewarm and tasted like old dishwater. Perhaps the baristas were particularly inattentive with replenishing freshly-brewed coffee that day. I'll never know, though, because I don't have a penchant for giving my money away with nothing of value in return.
author: Melissa S.

description: I don't drink coffee, but the tea is alright. the place reminds me of my local Haus cafe but i'm not sure which one came first. Of course, because of where it is, the place is crowded in the morning but I'm sure it's worth the wait. Limited seating though so be prepared to stand outside or get a cupholder on your bike!
author: Jim L.

description: Any place with no store sign puts me off, but after coming here I can see why Four Barrel doesn't need one.
author: Jen Y.

description: This place is pretty awesome. I love the open space and decoration.  Menu is limited but does the trick for coffee lovers.
author: Moko R.

description: I've been here a couple times and the espressos have been very good, but not great -- a bit overly acidic for me. I didn't visit when they were using Hairbender beans, so I can't compare, but I would say it's a bit below Ritual in terms of smoothness. Cool decor and seating, if not the most comfortable -- custom-made for the Mission hipster!  I broke down and got my first Dynamo Donut here -- very tasty and original, but at $3, 4X the price of your average donut???  (and that's what you pay at the Dynamo stand!  sorry, i know this is not the spot to rate Dynamo, but...  damn they know how to market!)
author: Ari M.

description: One of the best espressos I've ever had. Perfect croissant to accompany it and some of the best people watching in the mission, not to mention great ambient music. I come here whenever I can.
author: Christophe T.

description: hmmmmmm...how shall i start? i was told by a cranky barista girl, that "hey, what you are having is actually called  a ghetto latte." shall i be thankful for the lesson in urban lingo (i am from europe and not a native speaker) OR shall i be offended? my first time @ Four Barrel i ordered a shot of espresso and asked for cold almond milk. i was told to fill it up myself at the bar. cool. the second time i thought i knew the drill. i ordered an espresso and went straight to the bar but then the crabby gal informed me what i was having. i told her what happened the first time and i also told her that i was happy to pay extra if that's what  she wanted to indicate with that comment. I actually tipped 1$ and it would have covered my almond milk. i am happy to pay to have my drink the way i like it, i am not a cheapo. well... she couldn't really answer me. i guess she was pissed and wanted to let it out on me. on a costumer for crying out loud???!! bad move. i kinda liked this place the first time but she ruined it for me...
author: Oyo S.

description:
Four Barrel's coffee is the best.  I buy bags of the stuff for gifts, and feel empty inside when I run out at home.  I still drink coffee inside the store, however, and not just so I can look at hipsters and dead animal heads.  It's a great place to get work done, despite the uncomfortable chairs and strange-table heights.  Plus, yesterday I was engrossed in reading, and the hot barista with the black hair and nose ring dropped off my cappuccino.  I think I even got a smile.  These are things I cannot get when I make coffee at home, sir, and they keep me coming back.

Four stars for four barrel!  Wait, I can give five?  Aw, but that doesn't sound as good.  Fine, five.
author: Colin A.

description: When I first walked into Four Barrel I was amazed by the grandeur devoted to coffee in the establishment.  Coming from New York, I am used to tight quarters and no roasters in sight.  Four Barrel amazed me with a good record collection, an almond croissant I would question expressing my devotion with obesity, and coffee I could drink endlessly (I do not even like coffee).   It is spacious, not loud, but not so quiet that you feel obnoxious talking on the phone.  My favorite spot in this place is the bathroom, check it out and look down.
author: sophia s.

description:
In the S.F. coffee ecosystem diagram that spreads itself out in my mind when I'm thinking about where to go to satisfy my deep brown, fragrant addiction, Four Barrel occupies the space between Ritual and Blue Bottle. Blue Bottle in part because their coffee is similarly delicious--my top two in the city, though Blue Bottle's actual coffee still retains a slight edge (and I always think I should get beans at Graffeo in North Beach more often but it's so far away). The two also remind me of each other for their minimalist, modern, airy aesthetic. I somehow got into the naughty habit of accidentally calling Four Barrel "Blue Barrel," perhaps my fantasy of their over-caffeinated-to-the-point-of-being-sexually- frustrated love child.

The Ritual connection is easier to establish, since the owner was originally part of the Ritual partnership and broke away to start his own spin-off. But if Ritual is "Friends," Four Barrel isn't exactly "Joey." Rather, it is a more collected, less hyperactive, arguably more successful (not necessarily in monetary but in cool terms) version of its older half-sibling. The space is so large, and the vibe so relaxed that they can be playing an angry angry punk record, and you can still find space to be with your own thoughts (or coffee companion).

Some things I love:
- their americanos in the larger cups, really rich for americanos (plus $2 is a fun price to pay for fancy coffee).
- sitting in one of the high chairs looking out onto the street like Poe's narrator in "The Man of the Crowd," a story you should find and read right now!
- the woodland fantasy bathroom with super strong air blower hand dryer
- the fact that they opened their space for Obama phone banking
- the day when I shamelessly asked what their cheapest beans were and in response to my pathetic question, the coffee man found me a leftover bag of beans they had been sampling that day and gave them to me, bestowing upon me such a boundless joy that he could never have anticipated (he also has the amazing and rarely spotted ability to flash a little peace sign as a goodbye wave in a way that is totally unforced and mysteriously unfobby--if you don't know what "fobby" means, ask a California Asian person).

I sit in that picture window sometimes, half-reading, half-gazing at passersby while swinging my legs, and I think about what a beautiful space it is and how their employees are said to have nice healthcare benefits and livable wages, and I wonder how they can keep going on coffee alone. It seems like a beautiful dream.
author: Katrina D.

description: Nice inviting coffee shop. Big open spaces for hanging out with friends. Coffee was delicious. Especially the latte's and vanilla bean donuts. Perfect together. One thing that was a little weird was the animal heads on display. kinda off to be in a coffee shop no?? all in all great coffee and kool dive to chill at.
author: Joseph G.

description: Man, oh-man...dynamite in a cup!  Got a cup of their hot, delicious, coffee and it was not hot, but it was delicious.  I mentioned this, to the nice person who served me, and asked if I could replace it with an americano.  He cheerfully, and promptly, refunded my money AND slid me the americano, gratis!  When does that ever happen?!  Very, very unusual and certainly well appreciated!  As for the americano?  Well, it was quite simply the most perfectly crafted americano I've ever had.  Hot water poured gently beneath crema-laden shots of espresso.  My friend's cappuccino was also expertly prepared with dense, creamy foamed milk and perfectly drawn espresso.  I love that there's no wi-fi - places like this promote interpersonal interactions, not the virtual kind!
author: Loretta G.

description:
Four Barrel has quickly become my favorite coffee shop - and I'm pretty serious about my coffee. Highly recommended, especially for espresso lovers.

It's easy to get so-so espresso in this town, but there are few places that make a knock-your-socks-off demitasse - the kind that lingers on your tongue for half an hour and makes your mouth all happy. Even rarer is the coffee shop that's able to pull off exceptional shots with great consistency. I used to go to Ritual for my espresso, and they sometimes pulled off a great shot, but Four Barrel has much, much better consistency and overall better quality. This is _the_ coffee shop I tell people to visit to learn what really good espresso tastes like.

Four Barrel also has a good selection of roasted coffee for sale, with reasonable prices and detailed descriptions. My only qualm is that the coffee on their shelves is often 1-3 weeks old, which is much older than I'd expect from such a great shop. My standards are probably a bit high, since I often buy green coffee and roast it myself at home, so I'm used to drinking 1-to-5-day-old coffee; most people probably won't know what they're missing. Even so, it's good enough that I buy their coffee fairly frequently, since I don't roast enough at home to match my consumption. Just check the roast date on the bottom of the bag and pick the fresher roasts. Their roasts are on the lighter side, so if you like your beans burnt to a crisp, you'll probably want to look elsewhere.

Four Barrel's baked goods are pretty good; flaky, buttery croissants, little tart-sized pies, tasty donuts, etc. Good for a breakfast on the way to work or a midday dessert, though not quite Tartine-level.

The space is large and doesn't usually get too crazy, so it's a good place to get a little work or reading done, if the lack of power and wifi isn't a problem (that's a plus for me). I personally wouldn't try to set up camp here all day, but it's good for a few hours. They've got good taste in music (e.g. Bowie) too.

One last note, about the service: I don't understand why other reviewers are complaining; I've never had any problem here, and find the staff to be friendly and relaxed. If you're expecting subservient, ingratiating drones, I guess you'll be disappointed, but if you're a polite, friendly customer, I think you'll find they're great.
author: Rick B.

description: drinking hot chocolate made of dark real choclate and enjoyong the roasting smell and view.
author: Daf N.

description: Four Barrel Coffee is trendy, hip, and overpriced.  Problem is, they have KILLER java, a spacious setting, and tables where I can get work done.  Now if only the 90-pound size-2-girls-jeans-wearing-beard-sporting-beanie-off-the-back-of-his-head barista/DJ/hipster extraordinaire would turn down the Sabbath at 3pm on a weekday so I could hear myself think, we'd be cool.
author: Eric S.

description: Big, friendly, wood-modernesque. Perfect iced coffee with soy. Sometimes cold coffee can taste stale and bitter but this brew was smooth and fresh.
author: Cori W.

description: Great coffee here,the place is clean and the service is on par....  Starting with the space: industrial, preserving the feel of the original building and enhancing it with natural materials. I really like the way they use of thick wooden planks and steel. It is a warm space with the good amount of natural light; acoustically live enough to generate a buzz but not loudness and a chandelier in a restroom in the Mission.
author: christy l.

description: Everything here is a piece of art. The coffee, visually and in the mouth, the place, and the people serving it: very friendly! But nothing is perfect, and they have these creepy animal heads in the wall: Please, remove that crap!
author: Javi V.

description: A nice place. The place is very open. It looks like they actually roast the coffee brand there in the back and you can easily see it. The coffee is alright. They don't really have regular milk. Soy and some other kind of milk they have. There is a lot of local painting/drawing on the walls that look really nice. A pretty nice place to sit and chill.
author: Jimmy H.

description: I've only had the pleasure of coming here twice, both experiences were wonderful. I cannot get the soy mocha that I got last time off my mind. It was so smooth, velvety, and wasn't sweet at all, which was delightful, it was kind of bitter and to my surprise was better than any sweet mocha i've had. This place has a great vibe, i'd prefer it over ritual for that reason. Next time I NEED to try some of their pastries including the vegan options. The spaciousness of this coffee shop is also unlike any other without ruining its comfy vibe. I wish this place was a little closer so i could spend my life savings on this coffee everyday!
author: Ali S.

description: Woohoo! As good as it gets!,Heck Yelp seems to say it best.It is hands down the BEST and most CARED for cup of Coffee you will experience.I advise all potential new customers to go to their website before Bitching about Parking,Wifi,or electric outlets.I mean really people if thats any reason to take stars off,You should move to New York,we'd both be better off.This place is about community.And those of you that give less stars due to the "hipster"effect,I think u have Personal issues with confidence.Four Barrel coffee is a melting pot of very different people.While those who work there might fit into this genre that u want to pigeon hole them into,for the most part the patrons are of all ages,younger(count the strollers)older(there usually out front ,420)and in between.Maybe if we spent more time in conversation,community building,and enjoying our coffee we would have less time to judge.Hmmm,The only thing i could ever find wrong with 4B,is not even their fault.It's the lack of bike parking.The city should just ban cars on Valencia street,at least on the weekends.But hey,nobody listens to me,I'm just a Parrot ..   Pdbird.tumblr.com
author: patty d.

description:
yip yip!  I dig this place.  Coffee is outstanding and I'm fully addicted.  Music is an added bonus: every time I walk in, I start dancing. 

5 happy, caffeinated stars
author: Ginger B.

description:
I really like this place. The coffee is very, very good and I usually like a darker roast! The decor is very tasteful with unfinished, natural wood - which seems to be all the rage these days. They also have taxidermy (another ironic, hipster revival?) A plus is the real dairy products - no lo/non-fat crap. If you knew how it was made, you wouldn't drink it. Also, I was surprised how nice the staff is when I visit. One time I was near the  back counter, checking to see if their register took credit cards. An employee noticed me and asked if he could help me. I told him I lost my wallet recently and just had a credit card. He told me they didn't take'm but there was an atm nearby. I completely understood as I hate it when dorks pay with credit cards for a freak'n two dollar beverage and slow down the line. But the guy was really nice and helpful! In the end,  I had enough change a got a little cup of their coffee for $1.50.

Another cool plusses were their recession buster,  free coffee mondays and love the old records on the hifi with the retro Bose speakers! 

You can also get their beans at Oakland's new Sub Rosa Café on our mini hipster-zone 40th St.
author: Dave B.

description: Amazing space, swampy home roasted drip, great reprieve from the weather. I feel as though the preponderance of open floor space - though wonderfully airy - might be better filled with seating? A great meeting place, in either case.
author: Alex B.

description:
Favorite coffee in San Francisco. I send all my tourist friends there.

Love the spacious, wooden interior. High ceilings.

The bathroom is awesome too!

five stars.
author: Tara S.

description:
I loved going behind the store in its pre-opening days: The Stumptown espresso was always a favorite, better than Rituals by far, and their  whole beans became one of my home coffee staples. But after the opening my experience has been uneven at best. The Stumptown espresso, roasted in Portland,  has been replaced by home roasted beans( weirdly enough, with a two dollar increase in price!), and the quality has fallen: the layered, bright, herbal notes of the Portland roast have given way to a tobaccoey, over cooked style  by Four Barrels' own roasters.  A real loss of quality.  Worse, many of the other region-specific brands have an unpleasant chalky notes and unfocused flavors. (I don't mean this across the board. Two months ago, for example, I drank a Sumatran blend in house. It was delicious, maybe the best Sumatran I have ever tasted). 

Question: Are they simply mediocre roasters?

As for the experience drinking there, the music is loud, the tables are hard and uncomfortable, and the space itself seems busy and grim at the same time. The addition of art will help, however.  As for the counter service, the boys and girls have been nothing but polite and charming. So I haven't given up hope yet---if only they would lower the price on their house espresso roast (back to 14 bucks a pound, please) as well as improve its quality, put cushions on the chairs and lower the volume of the music .
author: Pan K.

description:
The service here is horrible- really rude & unfriendly. I was actually shocked by how condescending the guy who took my order was-  I just tried to order a drink!

Also- the fact that they don't have any other milk choices is completely lame. 

The drip coffee is good quality, but their carafes are not maintained and given the attitude of the people in this place, I'll pass....
author: Sapna M.

description:
I am so happy to learn I'm not the only one who is totally intimidated by 4-Barrel. I inevitably feel: a) too old b) too straight c) like I should have a bone through my nose, but sadly I'm a late 30s white chick who lives (gasp) north of California St. and wears (wait for it) gold jewelry.

Whatevs, I bravely trek below the Mason-Dixon and endure the scrutiny I deserve to sip the ambrosia of the gods, the black gold of the Mission, the heaven that is 4-Barrel coffee. You can't stop me you vinyl-worshipping nerds!
author: Elise B.

description: I went in here for a quick cup of coffee, and if you are a coffee drinker; then you will find that this little jem has fantastic french presses' and their very eco-friendly. I really like that. This place is hipster, granted I was the only Asian girl sitting there, it was okay; they have cool decor -- and they're hella busy. I went in at 4PM and damn they were packed. Also, their drinks are only one size. Which is also, very cool. I really like how it's super chill & very simple; not starbucky or even close to Peet's. This is straight up, great coffee with a hipster edge. I'm coming back.
author: Lois R.

description:
this place is no non-sense, almost to the point of being pretentious.

want some tea?
-too bad.

decaf?
-eff you.

want smoothies? sandwiches? (gasp) lowfat milk?
-get out of the Mission you wimp!

but if you want really good coffee, they have it here. the prices are pretty reasonable considering the fact that every drink is a double. great iced coffee. great music at all times.
author: Daryl F.

description: We had about an hour to kill Friday night and wanted some coffee close to the 16th St. Bart station.  Yelp to the rescue!  $3.50 for a latte.  Two frothy, rich, delicious and beautiful lattes later we were deep in conversation catching up on eachothers week at one of the tiny tables for two along the wall, perfect for intimate discussion.  At 5:30 in the afternoon the place was very relaxed and low key.  Mostly your usual Mission hipsters milling about, a toddler here, a small dog (?!) there.  I did notice though that it takes them a long time to clean up after patrons.  Empty cups and glasses sat around without anyone paying attention.  Maybe it would be different if it was busier.  In any event, we were both very happy with our coffee.  While its not the kind of place I would normally frequent in the Mission, at least I know where I can get a good cup of joe.
author: Nancy M.

description: Incredibly good coffee. The atmosphere is also pretty cool. Most of the employees I've encoutered here seemed pretty pissed or just plain disinterested. That deducted a star for me.
author: Juliana S.

description: The finest coffee in America in the nicest setting with the best and most informed staff of any roastery/coffee bar i've ever been to. The best, period.
author: Andrew B.

description:
oh goodness,  four barrel used to be my favorite beside farm:table, but!!!!
my last visit a couple of weeks ago showed me a trend: arrogance and sloppiness! today was just another experience of the same kind.

for example: the barista poured the surplus ground, after leveling off the portafilter, back into the doser of the grinder! wtf! i think recycling is a big no no.
another one: after the barista pulled a shot for my latte, she let it sit on the counter for maybe 4 minutes before she poured the milk for she was too busy with pulling other shots. wtf! 
i think i won't come back for a while. but do they really need my business? i guess they couldn't care less...
author: bmwcafe c.

description: Had a mocha there that I wasn't super crazy about, but the apple-bacon donuts were amazing!  When the barrista first told us that's what they were, I thought I had heard her wrong, but no:  apple-flavored donuts, covered with flecks of apple & bacon.  A bit wary, we got one (and another kind that I can't remember).  And wow - it really worked.  We went back the next week to try another one, but they didn't have any that day.  Apparently some of the donut flavors rotate.  We have been told that the vanilla bean donuts are to die for, but have yet to show up on a day when they've got them (or aren't already sold out of them).  Alas, we keep trying.
author: Angela B.

description: Went on Thur afternoon with my best friend. The place is so big and they got their own roaster in the back. They have many ways to make coffee via Steam, Filter Dip and different types of beans. The price is cheaper compare to Starbucks and other cafe. Service is excellent. The Staff is happy and cheerful probally cuz they are well paid and well tipped from making all these yummy coffee. Place is awesome can bring ur bicycles or ur pets inside to order. They have good music playing not too noise with so many people inside. I will upgrade this to 5 star soon if they keep serving great coffee.
author: Amano T.

description: These people certainly come across as obsessed with coffee.  And it's pretty good coffee.  I like their light roast approach which I first came to like after consuming Blue Bottle brews.  Their verbose, colorful coffee descriptions lead you to believe you're in for a coffee unlike any other.  But I've got to say, I detected a mass delusion bubble.   The impression my wife and I came to immediately was that our individually-brewed cup did not compare to Blue Bottle.  The ever-ironic, authenticity-seeking, fixie-riding hipsters are entertaining to watch, however.
author: Matt W.

description: My favorite coffee in the entire city. I don't make it out there too often, but when I do, it's really special. Great pastries, great service, great coffee. I recommend this place to everyone! You wont be disappointed if you go here.
author: Oscar M.

description: There isn't much else left to say about four barrel, the have delicious coffee (but no tea?) awesome music and no computers. I love the retro feel about this place, and the awesome decor in the bathroom (how odd?). I think the only thing that I would like the see different about Four Barrel is for there to be more places to sit down, especially now that it has become so popular.
author: Allyson S.

description: A recent stop by four barrel this weekend reminded me how much I like this place.  I usually get a coffee (french press I believe) or a macchiato. Donuts and croissants are on offer by local folks-- the apple bacon maple never disappoints, and the ham and cheese croissant is  flaky & hearty.  The rotating art shows keep the walls interesting; the built-in wood tables provide a solid grounded feeling to the industrial decor. I actually love that there's no wi-fi or outlets-- instead, there's the warm, steady buzz of conversation. Sure, when you first walk in the line feels like a runway where everyone in the place is checking you out, but it's all good. We all just rolled out of bed anyhow. Stop by to pick up your dogs of coffee calendar, put out by sweet marias: http://www.sweetmarias.com/prod.dogsofcoffeecalendar.php
author: Miz J.

description: Four Barrel's coffee is excellent and their baked goods not too shabby either.  And I can't beat the location, only one block from my home.  But what gripes me if their sanctimonious no skim milk, no fake sweeteners policy.  Could I really be the only customer who wants a fat free latte with Equal, Four Barrel?  Of course not.  Therefore, that means you don't care about what this cash wielding customer wants.  And that, Four Barrel, is bad business.
author: Leslie B.

description:
i like the space, vibe and simplistic-ness of the place. pretty atmosphere with nice touches as far as decor (although the giant hovering boar heads are a little daunting for my taste). coffee is decently strong, but i was a little disappointed with my choco croissant. it was just ok. but it was ok. i wouldn't touch a bacon donut, but that's just me.

no wifi. awh, isn't that a shame....what to do? since it's available everywhere else these days (not to mention my iPhone addiction),  i am happy they don't have it. it's a great place to meet friends, chat and people watch rather than be anti-socially buried in your laptop (like i am right now). music is good. you could even have a spontaneous mini dance party if you wanted with all that space!
author: Isabel C.

description: Good coffees & yummy rosemary chocolate doughnuts.
author: Gregg M.

description: Four Barrel will now be my go to place in the Mission for coffee.  Unlike the Blue Bottle stand in Hayes Valley (whose coffee I love too), this place is spacious with a comfortable atmosphere.  I've only had the latte, but it's a good latte complete with pretty design in the foam.  I really like how I don't have to wait outside for my coffee especially since it was raining the day I came.  In many ways, it reminded me of coffee shops in Seattle especially in it's decor.  A very welcome addition to the city.
author: Joann C.

description: some of the best coffee in the city.  industrial, yet homey.  parklet.  beautiful.
author: K.G. V.

description:
"Fantastic", I thought, as I was led town Valencia following the 18th street gourmet block party this Saturday by my coffee snob friends, "a new roastery even closer to my house than Ritual". Apparently, Four Barrel Coffee was started by the same people that initiated the RCR cult, and by the look, feel, and taste of this venue, it's blatantly apparent. Inside has a modern feel, spacious with a few tables here and there. A coffee stand sits in the middle of the room, and behind that a bar overlooking a somewhat empty area with a giant coffee grinder and hipster bikes hanging from the wall. On the shelf you will find bags upon bags of freshly ground aromatic beans- each scent inhaled surpassing the former in richness and complexity.  I ordered the standard soy latte, this time going for a decaffeinated twist, as it was getting late in the day (and I cannot drink coffee after 1 pm if I want to get any sleep that night). The small cup soon emerged boasting a milk froth pattern rivaling and perhaps exceeding the artistry of Ritual and Bluebottle. And the taste, oh the taste. Absolutely perfect in all respects- not too strong, not too hot, not too burnt, not too bitter.....just right. It gets better though- as we sat down at the bar I noticed a huge box of scharfenberger chocolates. I asked the barista how much they cost (as these things can go for $1 a piece easily) and was shocked to hear "free, take as many as you want". OMG, free chocolates to dunk in this creamy frothy bliss, what could be better?
In summary, I found my new home away from home, even though I live just a few blocks away.
author: Kate A.

description: nicely done, except for the dead animals on the wall. perfect cappuccino every time. fast service, usually served to me before I get a ticket out front...
author: H K.

description: A friend recommended me to this place and the mocha is to die for. It is so good you wanna cry. I don't even like to share a sip. The iced coffee is great too on a hot day. I made the mistake of having two back to back. I buzzed around the city for hours.
author: Angela S.

description: Best coffee in my immediate neighborhood by far. (What's with all the bitter coffee on Valencia?) Although due to the ultra fine grind and french press brewing, don't drink that last gulp. Yeech.  The pastries are also very good especially the ham and cheese croissant. They have an abundance of those crispy bits of cheese around the edges that I love. The staff is very nice and strangely soft spoken. The music is good and unobtrusive, all on vinyl (yeah, a bit of pretension). Decor is rugged and well executed (be sure to look up if you go in the bathroom). Big windows to sit at and watch the world go by. The clientele tends to be on the uppity side, the spaciousness ignites some agoraphobic feelings and the chairs are awkward and uncomfortable (certainly not a cozy, curl up and read a book kind of place) so I usually don't hang around.
author: Tara D.

description: ooooooh heaven.  Four Barrel Coffee reminds me of Back Porch Coffee in Bend - both roast their own beans and only serve french press sludge which is my idea of a tasty brew.
author: Lauren L.

description: my tour of SF ended here just followed by a great shot of snow cone from ritual and my espresso was nothing short of expectations! The custom mistrals did their magic but i'm waiting for an extraction from the SLAYER in the back. The use of all the large lumber to perch and that unknowing stare by a wild boar begs me to come back for more.
author: Kai L.

description: Four Barrel continues to impress me. They are being generous with their customers for the recession and offered free coffee for the month of March between 8am-10am on Monday's. Also, I called Dynamo donut to see when they will have the apricot cardamon (I know I'm obsessed) and the lady who answered happened to be the one who makes them and offered to make them any day I liked. She made them for me that Saturday. Needless to say I am impressed and so happy with Dynamo and Four Barrel. Thank you for making my Saturday mornings more enjoyable.
author: Kristy H.

description: Gorgeous cafe. Gorgeous hipsters. Good coffee.
author: Rex D.

description: Now that they are roasting their own - we're addicted to the Friendo Bendo espresso blend. Whole beans please....a little pricey at $16.50/lb but very worth it for the amazing cappuccino every morning.
author: Mariangela S.

description: I'm out of nespresso capsules at home (please don't judge - it's just much more convenient than grinding your own beans and making "real" espresso at home, especially when pressed for time in the mornings) , and the coffee at the office irritates my stomach, so I took this opportunity to check out Four Barrel Coffee on my way to work this morning.  I ordered a soy cappuccino - it was great!  Four Barrel is comparable to my other San Francisco favorites, Blue Bottle and Ritual.  The animal heads hanging on the walls are a tad disturbing, though.
author: Grace W.

description: My fav coffee place in SF. Their espressos are the best in the world. Love it
author: Archana S.

description: I love it here.  This place is probably going to pose some serious competition for Blue Bottle.  Coffee is delicious.  I'm predicting this will be the next Ritual (you know, Ritual in 2005, before it was overrun by hipsters and went seriously downhill).  The guy who owns the place is serious about coffee (former Ritual owner, I believe).  My husband is friends with the owner, and says he's a good guy.  They did an amazing job on the build out of the cafe area also.  I love that I can meet friends here without a bunch of laptoppers taking up precious seating.  Go now, because this place is going to get CROWDED.
author: Poker B.

description: Fantastic coffee. No Wifi, or credit cards, but you will actually talk to the people you come with.
author: Scott F.

description: This place has very good coffee. Currently its my favorite. The whole cafe expirence and  the coffee itself is of stellar quality.
author: Mark W.

description: Hey  the coffee is really good but come on, there's lots of places to go in this burg for a great cup of coffee.  Why Four Barrel?  Well, this place is seriously designed - out.  I dare say you will feel just a little bit cooler sippin' your Joe here.  It's that kind of place.  FUNKY.  And yes, the guys behind the counter are pretty hunky.  If that is a draw for you, you 'll be quite happy here.  And  they do seem to be quite particular about their coffee, so take comfort in the fact that you're in good good, if super-caffeinated hands and kick back, dig the music, and give you and your friends the gift of living cool ;-)
author: Mark N.

description: The house coffee was not out of this world.  I would not order it again.  It tasted a little watery and acidic.  Blue bottle is better.  I might have to go  back and give it another chance and order a latte.  The interior design is cool...wood beams and lots of natural light.
author: H G.

description: Energetic.  The coffee was very good but I really enjoyed the vegan bran muffin.  It was really tasty.  My only complaint is that I wish it had more seating but clearly that's purposeful.
author: S W.

description: Everything here is a double shot! The lattes are awesome. They have soy milk for the vegans. This place is usually packed during the day and the weekends! They definitely need more seating here. I usually find myself standing and drinking my latte.
author: Philip R.

description: Stopped in here for a latte on a Sunday morning after hearing many positive comments about the coffee and atmosphere.  My latte was smooth and delicious, accompanied by a tasty pistachio croissant (recommended by a helpful friendly barista).  I appreciate the lack of wifi.  It means people are actually conversing with each other instead of staring at screens and camping out at tables for hours on end so other patrons can't find a place to sit.  If you are there to enjoy a good cup of coffee in an interesting setting this is the place to go.  If you have to have wifi there are plenty of other options.
author: Debbie C.

description:
To paraphrase another reviewer who gave this spot three stars:

"I appreciate that this space seems designed to alienate laptop squatters. No outlets or wifi, and the chairs are uncomfortable. This is a serious coffee joint, get your coffee, enjoy it, and leave. If you want food, wifi, or non-fat drinks ... go somewhere else."

So, if your definition of a coffee spot is a place to have great coffee, then this place wins.  If you want a free office, coffee-infused whirled triple nonfat mocha surprises, sandwiches, parties, and bedding, go somewhere else!  I don't think this place even advertises as a cafe, just a roastery (which it hasn't even started doing yet!).

[edit: They are roasting their own now.  In the back half of the shop, no less.  There's still no WiFi or mochachinos, so feel free to go elsewhere!]
author: Arlo J.

description: I don't drink caffeinated coffee so, to me, the true test of quality coffee is the decaf version -- FBC's decaf soy lattee is very smooth and the acidity is perfect. Anyway, this coffee is amazing, so are the Dynamo Bacon Doughnuts.
author: Chris G.

description: As I get older I can't stomach the dark over-roasted coffee anymore. I love the taste of coffee but end up drinking tea most of the time now. I have been a big fan of the new artisan coffee roasters Blue Bottle and Ritual Roasters. Now we also have Four Barrels! I had a soy cappuccino and it was delicious, full of flavor without the heartburn.
author: E. M.

description:
I really like the atmosphere here, and I'm so happy they have dynamo donuts, but I have to admit their coffee isn't that good.   I've only had their coffee, though, so maybe their other beverages are good.

I'm a fan of blue bottle drip, so I end up going to mission beach if I want just a cup of coffee. But if I want a dynamo donut and a fun place to hang out, I'll go to Four Barrel.    

The staff is great, though. Everyone is pretty friendly.  I do recommend, however, that you count your change, since I've found myself a dollar short on some occasions.
author: A J.

description: Coconut donut is bananas good if you can get there before they sell out.  Cash only- boooo.
author: K W.

description: Very good coffee, nice staff, and cool interior.  They roast the coffe inside i think.  I would have given in 5 stars but Blue Bottle is still the best, sorry.
author: Katya T.

description: AWESOME!  i always get "regular" coffee here and since they didn't have decaf drip i got the wife a latte.  WOW!  it was even better than ritual's latte, which is saying something.  so creamy and delissh.  made me wish I had gotten one too.  took forever but soooooo worth it.
author: chris m.

description: What's up with the dead animals on the wall, doods? This is too many levels of irony for me.
author: Warren K.

description: What a yummy $3 (small) cappuccino. And I loved it when they had Paul Madonna's art up.  On the down side, hard to get a seat (and they are pretty looking but not so comfy) and the dynamo donuts don't taste quite as fresh as when you get them from the source...
author: marisa e.

description:
For me there are three criteria by which I evaluate a coffeehouse: 
1. the quality of the *coffee* 
2. the customer service 
3. the comfort, functionality and decor of the *house* space.

Firstly, the soy latte I ordered ($3) was priced within reason, given this is supposed to be one of thee best espresso drinks in town. That being said, the latte I received was 3.5 out of 5, my espresso was weak, did not stand up to the soy milk and it was lukewarm.  The foam was pretty damn amazing but what is good foam without a strong espresso finish? So the drink I received was not worth the money I paid. I would pay 3 dollars for a latte I know damn well is going to be good. By the time I got the drink though (as you will see) I didn't want to bother the employees anymore so I just drank and judged what I got.

As for customer service, 2/5.  There were two baristas working when my friend and I walked in. The guy barista was nice and helpful with my questions about their menu and took our order (2 soy lattes), and the lady barista got busy on that.  
She made 2 lattes and I asked "are these our two soys?" 
To which she replied "Ughh, F$#K"  She begrudingly paused and continued "Are they both soy?" as if we inconvenienced her.  We said "yes, sorry" sheepishly and walked to a table while she started over.  I wasn't rude or pushy or anything about it, so why the attitude? I can understand some customers get all uppity and rude but I'm definitely not.  So I felt really annoyed and frustrated this being my first experience here.  Maybe that's why the soy latte was weak? Maybe she said 'sorry guys' when she called out the soys but it wasn't any sort of meaningful statement and I just assumed get on with my life.

3. 4.5/5 on the space.  It was extremely pleasant, lots of tables to choose from, nice music and clean bathrooms. The decor is really unique and well organized.  I think the seats, though fashionable are wanting in comfort.

I'd probably go back eventually but I'm in no rush. I will grant my barista may have just been having a bad day which happens but if I get another weak coffee or attitude there are plenty of other dependable coffeehouses in the city.  I'm sad, my friend hyped this place and sadly we got that stereotypical hipster than thou treatment you would expect from a hip coffee joint. Sigh.
author: Maryanne R.

description: Vibe = Great! ; Donuts = Good ; Coffee = OK ; Blue Bottle = Better
author: WW R.

description: This is my favorite coffee house in the city.  I live near by and am there nearly every day.  I cannot be more happy they are here.  The coffee is top notch and atmosphere is always pleasant.  Thinking about going right now.
author: Joshua W.

description: This place is a COFFEE house, which apparently means they don't care about us tea drinkers. I was pretty disappointed by this when they  were the only place opened early on a holiday weekend and I needed to kill some time waiting for my car. It's a vast space, a little to pedestrian for my taste, but the staff were pretty friendly so there was some warmth there. Later in the morning they had some pastries delivered, wow...they do have more than just coffee after all! I was enjoying a savory croissant when this woman came in and sat next to me with her two mutts. I love dogs a lot, but they really don't belong inside at cafes where people are eating. Hopefully one day Four Barrel will expand their horizons so those of us non java junkies can enjoy the place with our coffee imbibing friends.
author: Colleen B.

description: Wow.  That was about the best latte I have had in the U.S.  It took me a long time to get over there and I am so glad I did.  The service was lovely; the coffee was amazing, and the environment was sublime.  I only saw one person on a laptop which made me happy.  People were actually having conversations here.  I can't wait to go back.
author: Andrea S.

description: Best coffee, best donuts.  If this place had wi-fi, I'd never leave.
author: Sven E.

description:
things i love about this place:
- the array of roasted beans
- the decor
- flannel shirts 
- french press
if i'm in the neighborhood, i'll definitely stop by everytime
author: Erin M.

description:
with all the hype (justified no less) over blue bottle, i wasn't sure if this would hold up. let me just say...

best soy latte i've ever had.

period.

steamed to perfection, the flavors and texture are just perfect.
author: jen m.

description:
Great, open, spacious.  A bit achingly hip, but it is the Mission, after all.

The worst cup of coffee I've had in SF.    I was looking for a Blue Bottle/Peets experience, and got something thinner than midwest diner coffee.  Heartbroken!
author: Dennis T.

description: sweet sweet coffee 'o' mine! Stumptown by far is one of my all-time favorite roasters! and you don't have to travel up north to get it, you can get it here at this sweet little shop in frisco! plus they sell Dynamo Donuts too! So if ya happen to hop on the 16th St Bart station in the morning and looking for a good pick me up, here's your place to go!
author: Jasmyn W.

description: Four Barrell has good coffee and espresso, a great atmosphere and hip clientele. No wifi makes people actually talk to each other instead of sit in front of their glowing black boxes.
author: Justin V.

description: This is a great room with terrific coffee and better music.  The guys are friendly and did I mention the coffee?!  yum!
author: K A.

description:
5 stars for looks. This is a great looking coffee shop.
3 stars for coffee.
1 star for service.  

I had a hilariously snobby experience when I got coffee.

Me: Do you now what time it is?
Status Anxious Barista: I actually have no idea what time it is.
(A few minutes pass. I realize he is not interested in finding out the time for me)
Me: Is there a clock in here?
Status Anxious Barista: No its like a vortex. (pauses, reaches in pocket, gets iphone). Its six.
author: Jonathan F.

description: Great coffee...very smooth, delicate and wonderful flavor.
author: Juju F.

description: Went for a business meeting here today. I'm a recent graduate to decaf. Shit was bangin. Normally decaf lacks something in flavor. Not this time. Friendly staff. Cool atmosphere. 5 stizzies.
author: David S.

description: Excellent cappuccino. A place that I hope to be returning to soon. Its a very cool, open, space with a chill atmosphere and you can see them roasting the beans in the back. I look forward to trying the delicious looking pastries and donuts that they sell
author: Jordan M.

description:
