Oh, how the Valencia corridor has changed over the years since I first lived there in '99.  Our good old friend gentrification has brought us the likes of Conduit, new lofts, revamped public housing, and now if Valencia Street Muscle would only remodel...well...it's nice to daydream...

Four Barrel is tied with Coffee Bar (on the cusp of the mission/portrero) as my favorite new coffee shop in the city (blue bottle is in a league unto its own, folks).  

The drip coffee is significantly better than Ritual's.  Not to mention the layout here being pretty spiffy.

But is it just me, or could the chairs be a bit more comfy, and the table/chair/floor height ratio improved?  I'm tall and don't like feeling slouched when im sitting...so I opt for the bar area by the window.

However, these are minor complaints.  And yes it's nice to see a cafe that doesn't look like an Apple commercial, but every now and then im sure i'd like to do some work online.  Enjoy it while it lasts because I imagine wi-fi is coming at some point.

All in all  I'm into it.
author: Marc A.

description: Wow. This place is stunning.  There is SO much open space.  I felt like I could breathe when I walked in.  Sometimes the city is so overwhelming and crowded.  It was nice to find a spot where I could sit quietly and enjoy my coffee.  I'm not a total coffee snob, but I though my cappuccino was light and delicious.
author: Jessica T.

description:
someone told me a new coffee shop was serving Stumptown (Ritual used to do so until they started roasting their own [and not quite comparable] espresso beans). being a Portland coffee snob (yesh, i admit it, coffee and microbrews in Portland have spoiled me forever), I sought out the spot and got myself a double americano (with barely any water). YAY! excellent flavor! and what was curious about the Four Barrel decor is that it reminded me a lot of the downtown Portland Stumptown shop (sans beer). even the doughnuts were eerily familiar (voodoo doughnuts' maple bacon bar still tops their barely bacon sprinkled maple doughnut though). 

ANYWAY, I'm not in Portland anymore, but am always happy to stumble into a place that makes me wax nostalgic about my old stomping grounds and a cupful of the coffee I am most fond of. wheeeeee!
author: ray e.

description: this is perhaps the greatest coffee shop i've seen. first of all, the coffees taste GREAT. they definitely live up to their reputation as one of the premier independent roasters in the area. it's not cheap, but it's definitely among the best coffee you can get. the space of the cafe is awesome. the roasting machine is right at the back; you see and hear the roasting, there's no glass separation or anything. it may not be a suitable place to work or study, but as a place to hang out, enjoy the scene, and enjoy the amazing coffee, it's second to none. this is my favorite coffee shop, period
author: Dave Y.

description: Great great great latte. Beautiful fleur. Love the alley location! Kisses from Seattle, home of coffee and rain and MS.
author: Marianne G.

description: The neo-rustic decor was nice, but we loved the coffee even more!  This is my new destination for soy lattes.
author: Sid D.

description: Four Barrel coffee has crack in it.  It's become sort of a problem; coffee from other cafes just does not compare and since I am often forced to leave the Mission, I find myself twitching without my fix four days out of the week.  This coffee is so good that I've converted back to real cream and sugar, sworn off Starbucks and have dreams about the euphoric high I have after a nice cup.  Five stars.
author: Justin H.

description: Yay for four barrels, definately try this place. I've been to pretty much every cafe in SF and I'm a fan already, nice alternative to, ritual roasters, of which i'm not all that fond of its loud and stuffy. I like the rustic kind of naturalism atmosphere here and the deer art on the floor of the bathroom is nice. its very open high ceiling and great front window seats for people watching in between internetting.  My latte was very good, not bitter or burnt at all.
author: Mary M.

description: I really hate it when people insist on one coffee shop being "the best." The amazing thing I love about coffee is that there are so many ways to enjoy it. It is, after all, an extremely diverse beverage, and I hold the greatest respect for my fellow growers, roasters, and baristas. That being said, almost any good coffee establishment does one aspect "the best." I really do love Four Barrel for their ambiance. It reminds me of home, Portland, Oregon. Maybe it's because they get their beans from Stumptown... serious cool points there. I like everything else about this place, but the thing that sets them apart is, by far, their interior and cafe space. Original, comfortable, and fun, I always want to stick around for more. You never know when you're going to run into bath towel super cape guy with hair ponytail antennae.
author: Adrienne F.

description: This place is great and the coffee is awesome!  Friendly service, awesome and the decor is my style.  If you're ever in the Mission you gotta try Four Barrel!
author: John B.

description: As I've mentioned in my previous reviews of coffee shops, I'm not really much of a coffee drinker so I'll let a real coffee connoisseur tell you the details of their offerings. But what I will tell you is that at Four Barrel, I found an unassuming coffee shop from the outside, with no signage announcing its presence. Inside was a very industrial-like decor with what I thought was poor use of the space. I dunno if it was just the time that I went (11am on a Thurs), but all the 25 or so odd seats were taken. Despite the fact that there was plenty of more space for additional seating, the were just swaths of emptiness that let you know if you weren't there early to claim your little corner, you were S.O.O.L. Also, no wi-fi! Maybe a good thing if you want to escape from the overload of technology that has taken over every aspect of life, but I feel it's a heinous travesty for a coffee shop.
author: Cristofer P.

description:
Oh yum!  
Coffee really is my last vice and thank god for this delicious roaster about to open a block from my house.
In the interim -Bobby made me the most delicious cup this morning at the Caledonia "entrance".  
Counting the days (possibly June 1st) when the front doors open!  :)
author: Amy C.

description:
great space.
seriously RAD soundtrack.
baristas make me feel like i am like, unworthy to even say the word coffee, let alone drink it, and heaven FORBID it be in their establishment.
really really nice cappuccino.
author: Lisa M.

description: Great coffee and don't forget to get a donut (although you could just go to dynamo for the opposite experience). Nom nom.
author: Jeannette L.

description:
preview next cafe
belly up now, wait later
back alley cache
author: Jessica Y.

description: today was my first trip to the new 'hot coffee shop in town'. as someone who works at one of the other 'hot coffee shops in town' i figured i better check it out. sooooooooooooo dope. EXCELLENT design, the machines are gorgeous and i love that each barista has his or her own work space in their 'duelling barista' set up. the cappuccino i got was great. love that they use clover milk. love that the music is via turn table. just all around impressed. unfortunately, i rarely go to other coffee shops since i work everyday and well...free coffee is best for the barista on a budget. but ill be back...
author: Lindsey B.

description: Maybe it was the collection of paintings of evil clowns, maybe it was that my order way wrong, maybe it was the so-so coffee - whatever it was, I just didn't really like it here.  I would put this place behind Blue Bottle and Sightglass.  Given how much of a pain it is to get to this place if you don't live within walking distance, I don't plan to go back.
author: J Y.

description: Visiting from Seattle I found this cafe...the owner has close connections to Stumptown where I work, so it was a nice surprise away from home. Great coffee, decor, and neighborhood. The baristas are really nice too. I also love the foresty wallpaper. Short menu, but to the point which is good for indecisive customers...They also have some amazing miniature pies. Peach and Lemon Meringue when i was there. Cash only..
author: Sera D.

description: Great coffee, very fun atmosphere and the folks are very nice. Only issue I have is that the chairs are not comfy. Definitely worth going back for, but not if you intend on sitting there for awhile having a long conversation.
author: Rayne M.

description:
Restraint. While four barrel cappuccinos are filigreed leaves of perfect microfoam, and their donuts are the wicked little morsels from dynamo, it's not the offerings at the counter that force me to call on my reserves of self-discipline.  Rather it's the space itself. Huh? With 280 square feet of 'wasted' space, a turntable and high ceilings, all I want to do when I walk in is dance.  Not smooth dancing (that I'm afraid is beyond me)  but crazy, just me-and-the-music, Ian Curtis-brand dancing. 
         But instead, I demurely order, get my cup of bliss and settle in at a window seat.  I look like I'm people-watching, while really I'm scheming dance parties, rounds of duck-duck-goose and live music for the center of the room.  And the standing table?  Awesome!  Nabokov wrote all of his novels standing up.  Really the only thing I find lacking in this cafe is their indifferent drip coffee, but I haven't found anything in the city to replace my beloved light roasts from Toscaninis, so take that with a handful of salt.
author: Emily T.

description: Great coffee and they know how to serve it. I only drink small cappuccinos, here they only come one size and as a double. Perfect! And the lack of snobbery from the workers is quite refreshing. Only complaint is they are so far from my house that I have to drive to get coffee in the morning.
author: Kellie M.

description: Yup, it's coffee greatness. Every cup has a little bit of coffee crack in it.  It's so good, I'm willing to ignore the annoying Mission hipsters. That's right, I said it.
author: Pamela S.

description: Funky decor - sort of hunting-lodge-meets-hipster-hangout chic. Kinda fun though. And the coffee is excellent, as you'd expect from these (ex-Ritual Roasters) guys.
author: Hywel J.

description:
Okay, I've been interested in trying 4barrel for a few months now, and finally found myself in the Mission AND undercaffienated. Despite the reviews I read, the hipster behind the counter was pretty cool, and took my order politely. Probably because I just smiled and ordered a macchiatto. I'm not much one for the non fat extra-hot crap, as I'm a barista, and I know how frustrating it is to have your art put to shit just because someone wants to sound cool ordering their drink. The decor of the actual shop was pretty tragically hip, but it's a coffee shop in the Mission. If you're expecting something else, this probably was not the place to find it. The setup behind the counter is probably the coolest coffee shop setup I've ever seen though. The espresso machines are beautiful, and I love the way the double bar is set up. Drinks were well put together as well. The three stars is mainly for the drinks. It was good, and they know how to steam milk, pull a shot, and put a drink together pretty perfectly. Unfortunately, the espresso was just not mindblowing. I could probably make a drink of equal caliber from any decent coffee in town. Hopefully when they start roasting their own coffee, the experience from Ritual will help them to one up their friends up the street. 
I swear to God, one day I will find a coffee shop that out does Peet's :)
author: Edwin M.

description: Four Barrel Coffee makes an excellent latte! Two shots, the perfect amount of milk, and excellent foam, and topped by pretty latte art. I'm really looking forward to going back for a mocha! There is a good amount of seating with tables both large and small, and conveniently located power outlets. The layout leaves plenty of empty space however, so I'm hoping it doesn't get too packed on a busy weekend. Oh, and right now the walls have an installation by Paul Madonna (http://www.paulmadonna.com/), the guy who did All Over Coffee!
author: Will A.

description: great coffee.  good music.  the patrons seem prouder of the coffee than the folks who work here and roast the stuff.
author: Joseph C.

description: This place is awesome.  The coffee is really good, the decor is minimalist, yet funky/cool, and the donuts are amazing.  I'm from Seattle so have yet to find decent espresso down here, and yes I've been to Blue Bottle...I have no interest in coffee served with attitude....The people that work at Four Barrel are really sweet too.  I'm a fan.
author: Josie B.

description:
This places gets a lot of favorable reviews about their coffee. And, it should. I had an Americano and it was the best I ever had. 

Plus, the staff is super friendly and helpful. They took the time to explain how to use some of the different coffee brewing equipment they have.
author: H N.

description: Loved it! They should have more food available, but the vibe was rocking.  Also the chandelier in the bathroom was a big plus.  I went while there was an Obama call center going on so the vibe was definitely alive and moving.  Not a slow-paced coffee house and with two shots in ever cup, i doubt that is what they are going for!
author: Sarah A.

description: This is the cup of coffee i look forward to at any time of the day. The place almost feels like an art gallery and it smells delicious. As for the staff they are super friendly and i'm always greeted with a big smile. Definitely my favorite cup of coffee in the city!!
author: Dash F.

description:
welcome to the neighborhood, seriously. everyone else has kind of described it well already, so i will just say:

1. this place could never existed when the OLD Valencia Gardens was in full swing.
2. love that it is a block from my digs.
3. lacks the homeless & panhandler crew that haunts Muddy Waters on Valencia. yes i know, everyone is a potential Buddha.

however, i wish they had LIDS for the to-go coffee? hello.
author: Applejack W.

description: Solid 4 stars for this coffee shop. The roast here is darker than Coffee Bar and significantly darker than Blue Bottle. It's really good, but not as good as the two aforementioned establishments.
author: Erik S.

description: Oh my goodness was that a good latte! Being from Seattle, I'm an admitted coffee and beer snob. That was the most satisfying latte I've had since moving here! Was also fun to the watch the coffee being roasted. My only complaint is that there isn't any wireless. Yes, I'm probably spoiled from Seattle where there's good coffee with free wireless on every street corner, but I really don't think it's too much to ask for.
author: E C.

description: not as easily impressed as by philz and blue bottle, but definitely the archtypical ambiance and mission hip vibe coffee house
author: Rob C.

description:
bleh-- i'm giving it only two start for ambiance and the fact that it's in my hood.  i gave it three tries.. try 1.. the cappuccino was cold, but hey the staff friendly and it seemed like such a scene i was sure people came here for a reason (and over paid for the coffee)-- time 2... still cold, 
time 3, i ordered an americano-- the man behind the counter looked over my head (had asked for 1/2 decaf)... i get the coffee- lukewarm again and confirm it was infact 1/2 decaf from the barista who said 'no but i can pour in an extra decaf shot for you'.. i mean im a simple woman, just can't handle the caffeine so for 2 bucks a pop HOT coffee and a little customer service would have been nice. 
next time i'm making the treck to tazza de amore on 16th and sanchez!
author: Tiffany A.

description: I've had some ups and downs at four barrel, but my last visit was a success.
author: Rochelle E.

description:
I really like this place.  The decor is interesting, and there is always something to look at while you space out with your coffee.  I especially like the bathroom wall paper and the flowers in there.
Regular coffee is strong and thick, though it goes cold really quickly.
Service is always easy and nice.

the only reason I'm giving 4 instead of 5 stars is the chairs.  They are really uncomfortable!  And they slant forward so i always feel like I'm just about slip off.
author: erika s.

description: They were skating on thin ice with three barrels, but after adding the fourth they really jumped the shark...
author: Eric S.

description: really like the coffee here.  atmosphere is great too.  better than Ritual down the street.
author: Paul C.

description: The best as far as I am concerned. Straight forward, honest coffee with real milk and real flavor. Love the space. Why deal with attitude down the street when you can get a better cuppa served by the friendly people for Four Barrel?
author: marc S.

description:
amazing space -- big, airy, spacious,  industrial-meets-rustic.

the coffee is good, but not insanely good. 

also, i appreciate the purist, no-frills coffee thing in theory, but it also feels vaguely condescending that they only do double shots and they don't have skim milk or fake sugar. same goes for dynamo donuts. would it kill either of these shops to offer splenda?
author: Elle B.

description: This coffee is great - on the brink of too bitter, but delicous.  And, It's definatley packed full with wake the hell up!  I always find it amazing that there is always such a long line in here.  Where do these people come from?  I wonder, if, like me they are traveling from a far (from Zietgiest) to get this delicous coffee in the middle of no where.
author: Jenn D.

description:
The black tar heroin of coffee.

If anyone wants me to hold their hand down the alley to kneel before the elixir of the gods, too bad, get in line. Seriously, this is my methadone clinic. Welcome to the 'hood boys.
author: Charles S.

description:
This has been my new favorite ever since it opened.  Great vibe, nice donuts (yes, i also wish there were more food options), and

AMAZING espresso drinks.  Every single americano i get there is perfect.  It's amazing.  Never too weak.  Always thick and flavorful.  Thank you, 4BC.
author: Troy B.

description:
The coffee itself, is solid. The latte I enjoyed was very good--HOWEVER--when I arrived, I was pleasantly surprised to find no one in line! great! I can order and go. I walked up to the counter and deliberated for oh, about 45 seconds whether I wanted a capp or a latte.

I ordered then went off to stand by the side, where I noticed another lady waiting. No big, I'm in no really hurry. The barista was standing by the machine *but NOT doing anything*. huh. The counter person left from behind the bar and when over to where a coffee cupping was going on and 3 more patrons arrived. It took him about 2 minutes to go BACK to the counter and take their orders. 

meanwhile---NO DRINKS ARE MADE. In fact, another barista walks in, and takes some of the drinks to be made and begins working on them--the order placed AFTER MINE came up before the lady in front of me...wtf?!?!

In all, I waited over **SIX MINUTES** for a latte. 

Shit service!
author: Persephone J.

description: I think about their coffee and take special trips to the neighborhood to satisfy my cravings! Hands down one of the best lattes I've ever had. The staff is friendly and they are always playing great music. Just bring cash - I'm not sure if they take cards.
author: Lindsay W.

description: My favorite coffee in SF.  They do a great job on all drinks.  I would recommend buying something from their custom espresso bar.  Always stocked with interesting diverse beans.
author: R M.

description: People say this is the best coffee in SF and it's true, so that's why I'm giving them two stars.  But no internet?  And no place to smoke?  Question: why do I go to coffee shops? Answer: to smoke and play with my computer.  So, suck it Four Barrel.
author: Michael F.

description: The ladies and gents of Four Barrel are the happiest, kindest people I've ever seen working for a living.  They have a wide and constantly changing selection of single-origins for your home needs, and they rotate coffees often for their press pots.  The press coffee and espresso are both phenomenal and affordably priced, and the hipster-watching is more fascinating than an episode of Planet Earth.  I can't get enough.
author: Aaron Z.

description:
I've been to Four Barrel twice, and both times I was really impressed by how warm and unpretentious this place is. Though I love Blue Bottle, I constantly feel talked down to, and it's nice to know that there is a place in SF where you can get great coffee, from people who know what they're doing, without getting all the attitude. I got great friendly service, and a velvety smooth macchiato. And they were playing the best of Hall & Oates! Does it get any better?
I would suggest, however, sticking with espresso over their brew.
author: Caitlin O.

description: I love going to SF for beer and coffee. This is a place to stop by if you are in the area. Great coffee (my girlfriend's latte was superb), and the space is really cool. It is definitely worth checking out if you are a coffee nerd or hipster wanting to hang out with your people.
author: Brian C.

description:
Found out about these guys from the chef at spork one night. We'd ordered a post-dinner coffee, and he asked us, "Have you guys had this coffee before?" When we said no, he told us the whole story about how one of the partners at Ritual had decided to leave to start his own business.
The flavor of the coffee is good enough on its own to make finding out where to get another cup was entirely worth it. Add to that the fact that the place was started one of the Ritual guys (who, as much as folks might hate on that place, you can be assured this guy KNOWS his coffee), and you've got something with serious draw. I'll make that walk to not have to go to Ritual. Hell, I'll make the walk to Four Barrel over Ritual just because the menu in the place is easy to read, there are actually places to sit inside, and the staff has time to serve you, which feels pretty good, I must say.
In other words, we even get our whole beans here, now.
author: Erin P.

description: Great espresso shots. Nice space, friendly people at the counter. And those donuts!
author: Wayne B.

description: I really enjoy Four Barrel. The coffee is the richest and most complex yet very well balanced, perfectly prepared. They chocolate spice doughnuts are amazing. The space is amazingly cool and very spacious.
author: Eater S.

description: I love this place.  It smells right, the staff is friendly and the coffee is excellent.  I also like that they don't rush you to make a decision (sometimes Philz people pressure), they offer to help then give you space.  I've been known to go way out of my way to pick up some coffee here.
author: Brenda B.

description: I found this place by accident months ago walking below 16th on Valencia St.  For me, it's the best cappuccino's so far.  A large and tall warehouse like space.  There's not much place to sit, vinyl records playing and a large area in the back with a huge coffee machine.  No wi-fi.  But it all makes sense, allowing you concentrate on enjoying your coffee, the people, book or laptop item your working on.  Very nice difference.
author: Enric T.

description:
This is why you're lucky to live here.

BTW, obviously the coffee and dynamo donuts are insanely good, but the almond croissant is also ridiculous.  Where do they get them from?  I'm addicted.
author: Matt F.

description: best coffee.  i like it actually better than blue bottle because of the atmosphere and decor of this joint.  it's unfortunate that they don't offer free wifi but it's really awesome non-the-less.
author: Ingrid Y.

description: This place is great, I've been twice this weekend and plan to keep up my trend.  I love coffee but I Hate strong tasting coffee, sorry Peets :).  Four Barrel makes coffee just right for my taste and it doesn't come blistering hot either which I also like.  I also have to second Diana in saying the guys that work there are definitely muy caliente!  Food or snacks would be a nice option.  See you soon Four Barrel Coffee!!!
author: Michele G.

description: Truly sublime & well-made espresso drinks.  Simple menu, minimal line moved pretty fast.
author: Adam G.

description: Dude--- go for the chocolate spicey doughnut.   I am loving their spicey chocolate doughnuts.  The ice coffee delicious.  The barristas--- not a personality disorder in the bunch,  or they're all really well medicated.  Seriously though.  I've been here 4 times in less than a week.  I love it.  Love it!
author: Ona E.

description: well if they are trying to alienate me from my laptop here (like lots of reviews say) it's not gonna work, with or without internet provided, ...besides, except for that first dodgy connection, you can sometimes for a second or two find wifi, ....but i guess i don't really need wifi anyways being oldschool nerdy or something.  I guess i'm used to sitting on my ass, too, cuz the chairs are kinda nice, ow well... that's my 2cents edit.
author: Today Y.

description: I have used Four Barrel only once.  The interior is very cool and looks like the designer specialized in high-end clothing stores.  The barista station is way too big and if a little smaller the place could sit 20 more people but they seem to be heavy on coffee-to-go.  The atmosphere is hip and I know the barista, of that day, from somewhere since he recognized me to greet blah blah.  Since they have no wi-fi, and the place was packed, I just got a cup of joe to go and that is the limit of my experience.  The coffee was good but not the greatest cup I have had.  The one-size cup is 12 oz and the price is $2 all of which are justified since Four Barrel is a fashion destination and the cost goes with territory.  It has a lot of atmosphere for hanging out.
author: Cush D.

description: fast, friendly and cheap. what more can you ask? i miss when it was just the back alley, but the beautiful architecture/design combined with the ever changing art on the walls is gorgeous. also, i like that there's no wifi and people can't sit around with their laptops for hours. sorry, ritual, this is closer to my house and i like the atmosphere much better. and, people complaining about hipsters shouldn't go to places that hipsters own lol.
author: K R.

description:
big fat caveat:  i don't drink coffee!!!!
so this is pure design atmo critique:
you must check out:
-gorgeous wallpaper for bathroom, in & out.
-unique floor drawing in bathroom.
-cute graffiti scratches on mirror. yes, in the bathroom.
-so amazing - solidified in mid air chain link near -you can say it -  the bathroom!
-really cool heavy metal desk in back behind coffee roasters.
-to die for wooden cubbies w/ perfectly fitting milk cartons.
-steampunky lighting.
-artfully wilted flowers.
-so authentic re-purposed wooden desks w/ metal fittings.
almost makes me want to drink coffee.
author: Kim Y.

description: This is the French Laundry of coffee houses.  I never knew coffee could have such complex flavor profiles.  And the boys who work there are smoking hot.
author: C. W.

description:
my new favorite coffee house in the city. ok i'm biased cause this is in my neighborhood, but everything about this place is perfect.

the attention of the staff and how nice and friendly they are... the wood beams and tables bolted to the walls... and more importantly, the great great coffee they make :)

perfection and happiness all in one place.
author: Afonso S.

description:
great coffee, lousy service.

i hate it when the person serving your coffee is too busy talking to someone else behind the counter and doesn't look you in the eye or say thank you...

there's lots of great coffee out there, you gotta be more special than that to exude that too-hip-to-serve-you 'tude...

coffee yum tho
author: slapaham s.

description: This is one of the best coffee shops in San Francisco not just because it's in a hip neighborhood, staffed with attractive baristas, and with Wolf Parade LPs on the turn table but because it has amazng coffee. At the moment they're serving Stumptown coffee (Portland ho!) until they get their own roaster off the ground. You can watch them build it day by day in the back of the shop. Love this place.
author: Gabe F.

description: As an ex-partner or whatever the relationship is to the ritual crew this place to me still has a similar vibe but a bit of a more relaxed atmosphere and the coffee is superb. The service is good though I wish they had a bagel sometimes rather than all the pastries. Oh well, what can a girl do. I guess I just need to crab that doughnut sometimes.
author: Madeline T.

description: Hipster Hell with good coffee and no seating. Either that appeals to you or not. The space is pretty amazing, and the coffee is good. Just make sure your pants are tights, your glasses have big frames, and your hair is cut asymmetrically.
author: Shawn B.

description: Best coffee I've had in San Francisco so far.  Sweet vibe.  Good pricing.  They seem very 'quality over quantity' and I dig that.
author: Scarlett S.

description: Don't be put off by all of the bearded hipsters-- this place has the best cappuccinos around. Personally I like the hay-barn-meets-industrial-loft aesthetic, but I know some will find it too cool for school. Service does tend to be slow but friendly, probably because as far as I can tell the baristas are perpetually stoned.
author: Jane R.

description: Next best thing to Blue Bttl. I love that the waits are reasonable. And the brew is not half bad.
author: Moy A.

description: Beautiful design. The coffee, from Stumptown, as far as I gather, is rich and delicious.  I love the house French Press coffee.  Oily and a touch of grit.  Delicious!  I also love Ritual and I would never be unloyal to my true love Blue Bottle, but Four Barrel is a welcome addition to the neighborhood.  A few complaints keeps me from giving it 5 stars: no wifi, not a ton of seating, minimal laptop plugs, and no savory snacks (I can't eat donuts everyday, as good as they are).
author: Caricia C.

description: Great coffee, nice employees, comfortable location, and they carry Anthony's cookies. What more do you need?
author: John W.

description: Sometimes I feel a bit too hipster trendy SF walking down the alley to get my daily dose, but the coffee and service are fantastic.  Friendly skilled staff. Love the latte art.
author: Dena E.

description: Excellent coffee.  My new favorite place.  And the only place in SF I know of that serves Stumptown...  Can't wait for it to open proper.
author: Darren S.

description:
Terrible coffee. Like the worst I've ever had. It's pretty hard to mess up coffee that bad, but this place definitely succeeded. Even after putting way too much sugar in there there was no way to get rid of the disgusting taste that the espresso left in my mouth. And it's not that I don't like bitter coffee either ... this was just plain nasty.

To top it off, the chairs are super uncomfortable (cool style, maybe, but I'm not a big fan of the style-over-any-sort-of-substance fad) and there is a ton of wasted open space, so you have to wait for someone else to leave before forcing yourself to down your coffee. Maybe if they had an amazing product I could appreciate the style, but that's not happening.
author: Raphael M.

description: if four barrel were a dog, it would definitely be a french bulldog. not because it's cute or adorable to be around, but because lots of french bulldogs go here for coffee. i go here for coffee sometimes too. the first time i had their iced coffee i was like "dang." it was hella good in this strong way where it's kind of like drinking high end motor oil. then i started getting annoyed by how many mustaches and little groups of sniveling weiner children were gathering and taking up space instead of doing things like working or just getting out of my way. then i started getting the hot coffee because as it got colder i started to think that the iced coffee started to taste like what their bathroom smells like. the hot coffee is good, really strong and combined with the middle-school type atmosphere, makes you really sweaty and nervous. bravo!
author: beep t.

description: Finding a GOOD coffee spot where you can sit is a difficult task at times. Four Barrel luckily is a great space, with great coffee and yummy treats!
author: Danielle L.

description:
The cappuccino's are fantastic. 

Only complaint is lack of diversity in milk substances. The choice is half and half or soy-milk. Can we get some low-fat milk please?
author: stacey m.

description:
Great locale...coffee a step below BB and Ritual.  They seem to pull longer shots that tend to be a bit thin...and the beans from Stumptown are not the most flavorful - I had an espresso and even brought a bag to go...

Though good spot if you are not scrutizing coffee like an idiot like I tend to do...
author: Dan G.

description: Went on the opening day of the cafe. very impressed with the coffee. the new cafe is awesome. the only problem is that there is no chai so my non coffee drinking girlfriend can't join me. EIther way i definitely enjoyed my first experience here. i will be coming back.
author: Derek Y.

description: Wonderful coffee, and just that coffee and some yum eats. (Coconut Donuts :-)). Doesn't have internet (not a bad thing).Internal Deco does give one a seattle or NW feel, esp with hendrix playing in the backdrop!
author: hemang k.

description: I have gone here a couple of times in the last few weeks and I have to say I am impressed with the espresso and espresso drinks. I have had some truly delicious lattes I also like that they get started on you espresso drink while you are standing in line if they can. Ohh and they seem nice. My one disappointment with the place is the brewed coffee ( I have only had one) but it was pretty weak and flabby and I don't think it is because they seem to brew medium and light roasts like is all the rage these days(arrrghhh) It just wasnt brewed strong enough for my taste.  All and all it is worth a stop.
author: Ben S.

description:
My favorite place for whole beans and macchiato (spresso + smidge of milk).  As a preggers-lady, I was happy to discover that their decaf espresso is as flavorful as the caf. Quality seems consistent, regardless of who's working the bar. 

Although I'm an East Bay gal, this is my preferred spot for beans (barely eclipsing Blue Bottle).  

Ambiance-wise, seems like more of a spot for a quick chat with a friend, or a spot to read ten pages of a novel, rather than to camp out with a laptop for hours. Tables are teeny - lots of bar seating and stools.
author: Robin K.

description:
Here it is in a nutshell-

The Best Coffee in SF 
Great Space
Cool Vibe (no WiFi)
Friendly Service
Nice Music Selection ( all vinyl)
Good People Watching  AND Dynamo Donuts!
author: David M.

description: perfect espresso and dynamo donuts....the perfect pair.. not to mention the awesome taxidermy on the wall
author: M. A.

description: I just had a mocha and men, that's the most disguting coffee I ever had! There was no taste of chocolate. It was heavy and tasted like something that has been made with expired milk. ON top of that $4 for a small cup. I'll never recommend this place to anyone! So GROSS!
author: Valerie T.

description:
Not impressed.  i was very excited to hear that Jeremy of former Ritual fame was opening a coffee shop.  He seemed like a nice guy and a good coffee roaster (both of which i am sure he still is).

However, this place is out of hands.  i mean boar heads on the wall. really.  it looks like someones rich uncle died and gave his millions to the Four Barrel.  Ridiculously artsy lighting, everything with dark, dark wood and vintage this or that.  Way to fancy and hip for me especially for JUST A CUP OF COFFEE.

thats right: no tea, no food other than the disgusting vegan doughnuts with rancid oil, no sweetners other than white, i think they lowered themselves to provide soy milk (but nothing organic - milk or otherwise for condiments).

I was so irritated that i almost didn't buy anything. BUT i did get an americano.  alright - didn't blow my mind.  philz was better with way less pretense.
author: joolay l.

description: Excellent staff.  Beautiful design.  Attentive to the coffee.  Fuck your laptop!
author: Dronic D.

description: Errr ... really?  I think its a bit much - between the attitude (don't embarrass yourself by asking for tea or skim milk), the uncomfortable seats, and the bad (yes - I said bad) coffee.  stick with Philz.
author: Fallon C.

description: Most flavorful and delicious coffee in SF.  It is also an incredible ambience with some amazing woodwork, quirky details on the walls, and wonderful rotating art exhibits.
author: Rachel Y.

description: exceptional coffee, good prices, interesting contemporary interior...one of the best coffee spots in SF hands down.
author: Grant B.

description: As much as I'd love to rave about local roasters who happen to have picked a very nice spot on Valencia for their business, I'll have to pass.  The espresso I was served was literally undrinkable. Not only was it barely lukewarm, but it tasted like liquid molasses. With an extra bitter twist. Yep. Maybe the kinks are still being worked out, but until then, I'll take my business to Blue Bottle or the Ritual folks down the street.
author: Rebecca P.

description: pretty good coffee.  when i went it was very busy and so there was not much seating.  i had to sit on a stool by the potty :(  my mocha was nice and they made a pretty design in my foam (which always makes me happy).  the chocolate cookies were also pretty yummy.  the atmosphere was almost too hipster for me, but i can deal with that if the coffee is good.
author: Liz T.

description: Really great.  The best of the "new generation" outfits in SF.  Espresso isn't bitter (unlike Ritual and Blue Bottle who seem to confuse strong with bitter).  Relaxed place to sit, excellent space.  Still uber-trendy, but not as obnoxious as Ritual or as rude as Blue Bottle.
author: Ritch G.

description: Blue Bottle and Four Barrel is my place to go for a great cup of beans.  I love the culture there and next time, I will sit down with one of their gourmet doughnuts.
author: Carol K.

description: Good espresso for certain. Felt like I got spinal meningitis from sitting in the chairs after a mere 5 minutes (crazy uncomfortable). Found the stuffed animal heads a bit revolting. But crucially, the barista's finger tamping down the espresso really made me want to 'srow' up. Bleech-a-roonie.
author: Minou V.

description:
I have mixed reviews about this place, but first and foremost it is great coffee... sooo therefore GO....check it out, why not.... it's really good.
Period.
I get a little angry at all the people who comment on the hipster cliental, those who rage about the decor. I don't really know how that is a constructive post, because Four Barrel didn't send a memo out... "calling all hipsters"..... and they keep the place clean with a new modern feel. I can't really criticize somebody else's design aesthetic, unless it is just god awful.
Anyways... that being said, they make a great smooth cup of coffee. 
There is limited seating, which is difficult if you don't want to drink out of a paper cup on the street corner. 
I kind of wish that they did individually prepared coffee instead of out of the press, because shouldn't every cup of coffee be consistent? What if you had the last bottom bit? yuk.
I recommend this place for somebody looking for a good, quick caffeine fix rather than sitting around with friends
author: Alexandra a.

description: feh... nice decor, good coffee, good coffee... but it takes more than good to get me there. and yes, a bit of a snooty attitude w/ the "we don't have skim milk!"
author: Yaz S.

description: I stumbled upon this place while walking in the Mission the other day. I can't believe I haven't been here before. I love the space inside and the coffee was fantastic. It reminded me alot of the cofffee I've had in South/Central America. I don't typically drink my coffee black but I can see myself drinking this coffee black because the flavor is awesome. I can tell that it is very strong and the color of the coffee is unlike what I have seen before but I loved the cup I got to go. While this places does get crowded, the prices are reasonable and I can see this as a great place to meet up with a friend and start your day walking around the Mission. I think next time I'll try to find a spot to camp out for an hour and enjoy my coffee while reading the Sunday paper.
author: N S.

description:
Call me crazy but I'm not down with this place.  After I ordered a donut and an iced latte with nonfat milk, I was told that they only have whole milk or soy.  Okay...before I could rethink my order, the cashier was trying to talk me into and basically already pouring me an iced coffee...hmmm, do I even want an iced coffee?  Not really but hey I'll take his word for it.  "It's delicious", he claimed.  Whatever, I'm still going to want to add nonfat milk, right?  "No, just a splash of half and half is all you need"......Perhaps we're on 2 different pages buddy.  I wanted an iced  LATTE with nonfat milk, do you understand?!  An iced coffee with half and half is something completely different. Anyway, I'm paying too much for this damn iced coffee and donut when I realize they don't have splenda either.  Awesome.
There is reason behind Starbucks success- options.  You can have your nonfat milk and splenda too.  Not here.
Only saving grace- dynamo donut.
author: Jessica K.

description: i really want to like four barrel, because the decor is manly, the equipment is legit, and the baristas have a clue; however, i've been here twice and both times our cappuccinos left something to be desired. i know they use stumptown beans, but this weren't stumptown cappuccinos. i hear they're still kind of experimenting and so i'll give them some time, but for now, i still prefer the others.
author: Trogdor B.

description: love, love, love their coffee!!!  the place itself and the decor is amazing (love the boars' heads), the staff is awesome and they always play great music.
author: M. B.

description: I really wanted Four Barrel to be better than Ritual and it was off to a good start - great airy space with one of those nifty garage doors that roll-up to let in the fresh air, DELICIOUS apricot and cardamom doughnut...I was so prepared to love FB, but then my cappuccino came :-(  It wasn't a *real* cappuccino (1/3 espresso+1/3 steamed milk+1/3 frothed milk) and not only were the ratios off, but there was no froth.  Maybe the barista thought I ordered a cafe latte??  She was chatting with her friend and was distracted. Hmm...either way, a bad sign.
author: Lori G.

description: The space is killer, I love the open feel and the fact that there are no outlets or wifi. The espresso was pretty sub-par though, almost three ounces, with a light crema that dissipated very quickly, the flavor was quite sour and bitter. There were no single origins available for espresso. My friends' hot chocolate was not very chocolately and it was excessively sweet, obviously that's not their focus, but I believe a coffee shop should take pride in every drink that they make available and serve.
author: Frances O.

description: Really good latte today but: only one size cup, only whole milk or soy, and the girl at the register sucked - forgot my drink and thanks, I didn't order any attitude to go with it.  For me the lack of choices in size and milk are deal breakers - I want a small latte made with lowfat milk...pretty simple.
author: Coasting is cool o.

description: Beautiful space, good espresso, SUPER weak drip coffee. Think Denny's but $2.00 a cup. If you usually drink drip coffee and like it strong, get an espresso instead. No fooling, they seem to be proud that their coffee is really REALLY weak.
author: Angus J.

description: I'm not into the industrial motif. I'm also not into coffee. I like tea. However, after randomly walking into this place.. I was like "ok..i'm digging the high ceiling..the industrial feel of the cocoa/coffee brewery.. and the way the spaciousness allows for a nice flow of air through out the cafe." I like how they kept things simple. they have like 5 types of coffee and a few donuts,  so youre not sitting there trying to decide what kind of manipulated type of starbucks coffee you want. i love it. so real and unassuming. plus, the service is great, respectful, and straightforward. if the coffee shop could talk i think it would say "Look, you want coffee, we have coffee and it tastes like quality/wholesome, not some especially vegan, watered down or over seasoned coffee. you can drink your coffee here and leave, or you can stay and hang out. but while youre here, we will treat you as a guest (not overly or underly done). so, i hope you enjoy what we have to offer. thank you." i had mocha coffee. i have no complaints. =) I like how i can drink my coffee and  im not too close to the other patrons, but still have their company.  i really like this place. I hope you do too.
author: Shayenne G.

description: fantastic coffee with baristas that have a true passion for the art. beautiful austere space, friendly staff, and great music. i'm really going to miss this place. no chance you would want to open a location in LA? heh.
author: Blythe H.

description: Love the decor, but the coffee is mediocre. Espresso drinks are good, hot chocolate is really good, but the drip coffee tastes bitter. The service sometimes has that Mission too hip to care vibe, but it's unwarranted. I prefer Faye's.
author: kathryn s.

description: OK, so I went mostly because of that photo of the maple bacon donut on their website. Sadly, no donuts today! But the latte was perfect. Love that bathroom! Still thinking about that maple bacon.....
author: Patricia H.

description:
the coffee is fantastic.  (sigh, for memories of 7 years of consuming prodigious amounts of stumptown in portland.)

the seating--stools and chairs that look like they were swiped from a decommissioned high school chemistry lab--aren't terribly comfortable, but the tables are beautiful.

does anyone know their hours, though?  they're mysterious that way.
author: H H.

description: Four Barrel has this ex-Portlander's vote for best coffee in SF. I went to a cupping a couple weeks ago and was pleased with all but 2 of the coffees on the table. The person hosting the cupping was very friendly and helpful; she pointed out some aspects of the coffees' flavor profiles that I probably would have missed otherwise. The espresso's also good, though I feel like it's served a little too hot. In the kiosk days, I was told to wait 20 seconds after you're served your shot of 4B 'spro, which I actually never did but might be worth trying out next time. The baristas here all seem like a bunch of nice folks who are really into coffee; never had a bad experience with them.
author: josh r.

description: Interesting minimalist type of place. Definitely low key. Coffee tasted bland, dispened from a thermos jug. Steady stream of customers tells me they must like the place. Not for me though.
author: John C.

description:
i wish there was a place like this near me in nyc!

while in the bay for thanksgiving weekend, a friend and i stopped at four barrel while waiting for a brunch table elsewhere.  i was immediately wowed by the space and the vibe-- huge, well-lit, cool decor, vinyl records playing... you definitely don't see places with all of the above in new york.  there was a little counter in the front with a guy brewing coffee in pour over brewers, which was both fascinating and intimidating.  after selecting two bags of extremely specifically-described coffee beans to bring home, i ordered a latte.  it was the most beautifully crafted latte i have ever had in my life.  it was so pretty i didn't want to drink it!  but i did, and it was perfect.  we also shared an almond croissant, which was flavored with rosewater and i'm not a huge rosewater fan... it worked here, but i'd still prefer it without.  still, the coffee was fantastic.  i didn't want to leave.
author: cathy w.

description: Best designed coffe shop on earth. Props to the dude's that pulled this off. This place and Philz are my fave's.. SF is very fortunate.
author: Ryen M.

description: i found this place a few months ago when they were still serving coffee out of the back alley.  my first thought was , "oh no, not another mission coffee shop with mediocre beans run by a bunch of hipster douchebags."  however, to my surprise, this place has really good coffee, and altough it is run by, (as well as frequented by), a bunch of fixie ridin' hipsters...they aren't douchebags!  really!  i couldn't beleive it either.
author: kris m.

description: grt stuff! awesome coffee plus good attitude (rare in good coffee places in this town)= wonderful place. kudos
author: christina h.

description: great coffee! nice ambiance too, it was very easy to read in there.
author: parker h.

description:
I consider this place the best coffee in SF.  I think it edges out Ritual Roasters and blows away the Blue Bottle in Mint Plaza (which I have been told is not representative of true BB quality).  However, like all coffee shop, the most important determination of the coffee is the skill and intuition of the baristas.  There is some variation between the baristas here, but overall, it's excellent.  I also love the ambience of this place.  I come here alot.  It's a great place to chill out and have discussions with friends.  It can get crowded, but I've always been able to find a seat.  There's a lot of seating in this place.  I shake my head when I read other people complain about not having enough seats here.  Are they kidding me?  They're mad because they came at very busy time.  I haven't seen any coffee place with more seating than this place.  What do they want?  An auditorium?   And then the people who complain about the spartan seatings.  No, it's not the foo-foo, fake warm and cozy Starbucks feel.  You come here for the coffee and to chat, read, and work on your laptop not lounge around.

If you're looking for other good coffee places, there's Ritual Roasters in the Mission and Cento in SOMA.  I need to try the Blue Bottle in Hayes.  The BB in SOMA is just not that great.
author: Loc N.

description: This was 5 stars, my favorite coffee in SF and on par with Grumpy Cafe in NYC, but they went and changed the beans.  They no longer use the hairbender beans they used to carry from Stumptown roasters in Portland.  Now they roast their own, which are still very good, and about the level of Blue Bottle, if not a bit better, but not quite as great as the hairbender ones were.  They;re just getting started, so I'm guessing they'll get even better.  The space is great, very big, and parking is usually not too tough.   Music is always good. This is my favorite coffee spot in SF now.
author: r h.

description: my favorite coffee, tasty and smooth.
author: Briana B.

description: This nice place was unfortunately left out of the new independent documentary "The Perfect Cappuccino," but it is run by Jeremy, who's former cafe, Ritual, IS featured in it. One of the reasons I stopped going to Ritual was because every table had 1-4 laptops on it and I was tired of seeing this. Laudably, Jeremy's new place, 4-Barrel Coffee, has no wireless connection, so you are free to read a book, a newspaper, dream, or even talk to the stranger next to you. Fabulous coffee, good, funny baristas (who even helped me get my scooter started when it died), and a wonderful space without wireless all conspire to get my full five stars. The bitter coffee on Valencia is a spillover from other chain cafes, which will remain nameless, whose best idea ever was to take bad beans and overroast them to give you a "French Roast," the oily black rancid coffee that most of the west coast drinks, which requires lots of milk and flavored syrup just to make it potable. To find out about good coffee, ask a good barrista here, at Blue Bottle, or at Intelligentsia, if you're in Los Angeles, or DoubleShot, if you're in Tulsa. They love the stuff and will tell you all about it. Clientele, well, there's not much you can do about that, and it's not the owner's fault, it's the neighborhood. When a thing is good, it usually takes a lot of money to operate and compensate workers fairly, this means the price is going to be higher than the 25-Hours-a-Day donut shop's coffee. So, you get a lot of people with excess cash and, what is it they say? With the rich and mighty always a little patience? Yeah, I think that's it.
author: Jean Marie M.

description: i like this place. the coffee was tasty and not bitter at all. the prices are decent and the help staff is really nice and happy. the pastry i had was good and i will definitely go back again. hopefully they will get wi-fi soon. i'm excited because they are fixing up their roaster in the bag, so it will smell great!
author: Katherine F.

description: lol this is not a coffee shop, this is a loading dock with an espresso machine and a stack of coffee bean bags. totally quick friendly service. they currently are serving stumptown coffee, but will soon be serving their own roasted beans. the most entertaining part about stopping here is that its a loading dock in the end of a dead end rape alley. definately worth a stop.
author: christopher a.

description: Simply stated, this coffee house and roaster knows coffee.  From espressos to mochas they don't mess around, and the produce high quality drinks on par with the best specialty roasters anywhere.
author: Mark H.

description: 2.5 stars. amidst my spree of glowing 4-5 star reviews (i've been feeling nice lately, what can i say?) 4 barrel comes and spoils it. i don't deny their coffee has great flavor. however, i ordered a non-fat cappuccino to be told there was only regular (another one of those places - cool, it will taste better anyway). i order the regular cappuccino while eying the one on the counter, thinking about how tasty my wake up call is going to be. then i wait. and wait. watch others grab their orders. and see the lone cappuccino on the counter mocking me. I tell my bf (we were going to his company art show), "i'm sorry we stopped for coffee, i had no idea it would take so long!" the barista looks at me, "there's a cappuccino here on the counter." to which i say, trying not to sound offended, "that cup was there before i stepped in or ordered. i remember b/c i was eying it as i was ordering!" granted, she made a funny joke ("we knew you were coming and what you wanted so we made it ahead of time!") and then made me a new one. but really, you tried to give me an old, cold, abandoned coffee? no thank you.
author: Dee C.

description: Best coffee in town.  Friendly staff.  My husband is obsessed now and won't go any other place to get coffee, even though it's a thirty-minute drive from our house!
author: Vic P.

description: Good coffee and donuts from Dynamo Donuts.  A little chaotic, but worth it if you can get them to pull a good shot for you.
author: Matthew H.

description: Finally! a BEAUTIFUL space to read, without excessive laptops.  Great coffee.  If you're lucky you'll catch the baristas singing David Bowie.
author: Lucy B.

description: OK. New plan. Everyone click Valet for Four Barrel to see how many cars actually drive down the alley looking for parking to a cafe that's not even open yet!  But seriously, if you want my thoughts, check out my blog. Besides I'm too lazy to repeat myself here.  (http://manseekingcoffee.wordpress.com/2008/04/15/4barrelearlyreview/)
author: Man Seeking C.

description: I love this coffee. Just took a trip to Colorado and after numerous disappointments, I came to the realization that there's no fix like Four Barrel. Jeremy and his crew are true artisans when it comes to Coffea Canephora. The Barista's presentation is top notch, the place has a great vibe and the coffee is awesome.
author: Dallas H.

description: the coffee is great and everything and i love the donuts but the real reason i love this place is because of THE PLACE. the space is open and warm and beautiful and designed. i also love the packaging for the beans. SO WELL DONE!
author: darrin t.

description: nice , strong espresso , friendly  barista, very simple and right to the point .i respect the owner courage for not serving non fat milk, fake sugars... etc
author: james b.

description: I was wandering toward a bakery or a coffee shop or some other undetermined place to spend a few hours working, and I stumbled on the storefront with its huge glass pane windows and lots of light. This place is lovely, not too hipster-y (yet...sigh sigh), and great service. I'm baffled by all the wasted back space where the roaster is -- they seem to have a great view of sky and space back there, and I'm wondering why it's not accessible to the customers? Also very very few tables (and very narrow), so I fear this place will eventually become impossible to come to linger. The donuts are phenomenal. I had never had these donuts, nor do I usually care about donuts. But...oh...my.... Also, coffee was good. I had an iced Americano, and the barista asked me what I wanted while waiting in line (cf. Intelligentsia in LA...good practice). Their menu is simple and straight forward, which is a pleasure after all the foofy drink menus out there.
author: hellskitchenbaby g.
